DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 2, or the 19th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine- year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
2003: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian offers condolences over the loss of space shuttle Columbia and the seven astronauts aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former U.S. baseball players in Taiwan as sports envoys
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 10:48:07 (By Bien Jin-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. professional baseball players Barry Larkin and Joseph Logan arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit as sports envoys and will conduct baseball clinics around Taiwan.
Both Larkin and Logan said upon arriving at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that they were glad to be here and looked forward to meeting local players and interacting with young people.

The two former players are scheduled to conduct six baseball clinics and visit schools, orphanages and social service organizations in Taipei and Kaohsiung Feb. 2-7. They will also attend an exhibition baseball game between two Taipei high schools.

Larkin and Logan are visiting Taiwan as part of the Sports Envoy Program co- sponsored by the U.S. Department of State and the American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

Larkin, a legitimate candidate for the Hall of Fame, was one of the rare players in the modern era who stayed with the same team throughout his entire career, starring at shortstop for the Cincinnati Reds from 1986 to 2004.
He was a key member of the Reds' 1990 World Series championship team and was named the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1995. He also earned three gold gloves and was a 12-time All-Star.

Larkin finished his career with 2340 hits, 441 doubles, 198 home runs and 960 runs batted in, and he had only one season in which he made more than 20 errors. He is considered to be a legitimate Hall of Fame candidate.
Logan pitched in the Montreal Expos organization between 1989 and 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Hiking health premium rate
DOC.DATELINE: Department of Health (DOH) 02/02/10 11:25:08 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Minister Yaung Chih-liang's recently stated that health insurance premium rates would have to be adjusted before the Lunar New Year holiday, but the Executive Yuan slammed the brakes on the plan Monday in a move seen to avoid fueling public backlash ahead of legislative by-elections in four electroal districts.

President Ma Ying-jeou was also cited as having instructed government officials to refrain from revealing details of public policy before it became mature, in an apparent reference to Yaung's outspokenness.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issues:
United Daily News:
Premier Wu Den-yih said Monday after listening to Yaung's briefing on the DOH- initiated premium adjustment plan that there is no timetable for adjusting health insurance premium rates.
He also asked the DOH to design better or more viable complementary measures to mitigate possible backlashes before unveiling any adjustment plan.

For possible future adjustments, the premier outlined several principles, including that increases in premium rates should be limited to less than half of the population and premium rates should even be cut for Taiwan's bottom 25 percent income earners. (Feb. 2, 2010)
Liberty Times:

During a meeting Monday with Yaung and Cheng Shou-hsia, head of the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance, Premier Wu asked them not to publicly talk about any premium rate increase plan before a well-rounded plan or policy discourse had been formulated.

Wu also directed the DOH to accelerate preparations for implementing a new generation health insurance system, with premiums collected on the basis of overall household income or overall personal income instead of the current system based solely on earned income.

Wu further requested that the health insurance bureau prioritize three tasks in drafting reform initiatives: fairness in premium collection, review of problems in the current system, such as possible loopholes in drug pricing formulas, and increasing health care demand due to an increasing elderly population.
Meanwhile, a private health insurance program watchdog body slammed the President Ma Ying-jeou administration Monday for failing to actively promote health insurance reform.

The group critized the Executive Yuan for not including a draft bill on revising the current health insurance act among the three top priority bills that it wants the legislature to pass after it returns from its winter recess later this month. (Feb. 2, 2010)
China Times:

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party said the government should resolve the issue concerning local governments' huge debts to the health insurance bureau before considering any premium hike program.
Only when such a debt issue is resolved can the government reform the health insurance system on the basis of social justice and fairness, the DPP headquarters said in a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Eurozone's new challenges

TEXT.P: The eurozone, which was established in 1999, entered its second decade this year. But it immediately faces financial crises in Greece and Spain, resulting in a warning that the monetary union could be dragged down by the two countries.
Such forecasts are not new, although European Central Bank Chairman Jean-Claude Trichet has dismissed as "absurd" financial market chatter about Greece ever leaving the eurozone.
Europeans have spent nearly half a century to integrate both politically and economically and create a single currency. During the process, the world has continued to be amazed.
One of the wonders is that the Maastricht Treaty (the Treaty on European Union) set a high standard for EU membership. The second is that no member recklessly quit after entering.
The eurozone has made it through its first decade and proved that a fixed exchange rate mechanism is workable under the trend of rapid globalization.
Fixed exchange rate mechanisms are not perfect, however, and the global financial crisis has also exposed its vulnerability.

The eurozone obviously cannot be guided by rules based on the high standards of the Maastricht Treaty, and the rules must be eased. Second, authorities must design exit mechanisms to let those who are lagging behind quit the union.

With the impact of the global financial crisis not yet ended, the eurozone will face stark challenges ahead. For those who have advocated the establishment of an Asian dollar, the eurozone's ability to tide over its difficulties will be a living reference book. (Feb. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: About Education Ministry's swimming pool project
DOC.DATELINE: 02/02/10 12:11:51 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education announced recently that it would help 300 schools build swimming pools over the next ten years. At the rate of NT$50 million (US$1.56 million) per swimming pool, the project will cost the country NT$15 billion, quite a fortune in light of the government's tight budget.

At the same time, the Department of Health is trying to scrape up NT$58.8 billion to close the National Health Insurance program's financial shortfall, with its chief vowing to raise insurance premium rates even it costs him his job in the Cabinet.
Both are agencies under the Cabinet. Why does the education ministry have money to burn while the health ministry has to live on a shoestring budget?

Building swimming pools is not the education ministry's priority. The ministry probably came up with the swimming pool project because President Ma Ying-jeou is an enthusiastic swimmer, and here we would like to throw in our two cents.

Ma recommended swimming to a student during his term as Taipei mayor when incumbent Education Minister Wu Ching-chi was the city's education chief. When asked why he recommended swimming, Ma answered, less than seriously, "because Taiwan is surrounded by the sea."
It wasn't a good reason to build new pools, and Ma didn't squeeze the city's budget to finance them in city schools because of it. So that reason can't justify a project costing NT$15 billion.

Swimming pools are not only expensive to build but also costly to maintain and could ruin a school. If the ministry is really concerned about the health of students, it should try to ease their stress.
As a loyal subordinate of President Ma, Wu won't necessarily earn credit from Ma for carrying out Ma's campaign promises, which were patched up in haste for the presidential elections.
Finding the right person for the right place is the most demanding job of a chief. Whether President Ma can reverse his flagging approval rating depends on it. (Feb. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: U.S.-China-Taiwan ties after arms sale

TEXT.P: The Obama administration recently announced arms sales worth about US$6.4 billion to Taiwan, which immediately drew strong protests from China.
Relations between the U.S. and China seemed to be in their best shape in a long time after Barack Obama's visit to China last year, but the arms sale changed that.
Why would the U.S. want to do that? The stock answer is that Washington wants to fulfill its commitment to the island's security, but in fact, the U.S. wants to maintain its influence in Taiwan.

We can get a fuller picture why the U.S. wants to maintain its influence from its recent strategic intent toward Japan. The U.S. marine base in Okinawa has become the focus of U.S.-Japan conflict. The row actually reflects a change in Washington-Beijing-Tokyo triangular relations.
Japan has developed close relations with China since the Hatoyama government's inauguration, which worries the United States, as its alliance with Japan has been the cornerstone of security in Asia.
Washington's security alliance with Japan is the most important hedge mechanism against the threat posed by an emerging China, meaning the U.S. cannot allow Japan to tilt toward China.
Facing an emerging China, the first flashpoint may be in the Taiwan Strait. Although Washington does not want to get involved, it also cannot let go.
Beijing has so far targeted its anger against the arms deal at the U.S. while avoiding a direct attack on Taiwan so as not to harm warm cross-strait relations. But Beijing is still upset.

Although Beijing expressed goodwill in the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with Taiwan, it has not relaxed its security threat. It has still not promised to renounce the use of force against Taiwan nor has it removed missiles targeting Taiwan.

The ruling and opposition camps have expressed support for the arms sale, showing that on national security, the mainstream view of the majority is identical. We hope that more similar examples of consensus will be seen on cross-strait policies. (Feb. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Downpour blamed for wiping off Siaolin village
DOC.DATELINE: The Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) 02/02/10 12:42:41 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: released on Monday a report in which it concluded that massive rainfall was the culprit that doomed the mountain village of Siaolin in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County in August 2009.
A total of 1,856 mm of rainfall pounded Siaolin in two days during Typhoon Morakot, far surpassing the critical point of 1,700 mm in that area, according to the report.
Siaolin ended up being covered by mudslides, with nearly 500 people buried alive.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issues:
United Daily News:

The PCC report pinpointed "super large rainfall" as the cause of landslides that resulted in the major disaster. It concluded that other factors, including the Tsengwen Reservoir diversion project, mass stockpiles at gravel yards and forest logging, could not have caused as devastating a disaster as was seen in Siaolin.

Responding to the conviction of some Siaolin survivors that the Tsengwen Reservoir project was the killer, PCC chief secretary Wu Kuo-an stated that theoretically and practically, the procedure of tunnel drilling had not affected the geological structure in that area in a significant manner.
While explosions set off by dynamite might make local residents feel uncomfortable, houses located 150 meters away from the explosion zone are safe and structures are unaffected, according to Wu.

Takao Green Association for Ecology and Humane Studies Director Lu Tai-ying said, however, that the Tsengwen Reservoir Cross-Border Channeling project involved two geologic faults. He noted that the report failed to explain whether the faults were active or not, and whether the drilling explosions had affected underground rock formations.

The chairman of the Kaohsiung County Siaolin Village Development Association, Tsai Sung-yu, said he and all Siaolin village residents will not accept the report, and that village residents will organize a truth investigation committee to probe the case.
Liberty Times:

Siaolin Village Development Association Chairman Tsai Sung-yu was extremely displeased with the report's conclusion, suspecting that it was arrived at so that the suspended construction of the Tsengwen Reservoir project could be resumed.
Meanwhile, Takao Green Association Director Lu Tai-ying believed the PCC investigation report was made based on a presumptive stance.

Lu said that 30,000 kilograms of dynamite had been used in the project, which he believed affected the rock formation. He suggested that the government be honest with the people and admit the project was related to the tragedy to a certain extent.
China Times:

Tsai Sung-yu, who is also the chief executive of the Siaolin village self-saving association, said his group will not accept the government investigation's conclusion that the project did not cause the tragedy.

"No procedural justice! " Tsai said, arguing that the entire investigation process was never transparent. Though they were the direct victims, Siaolin village residents were never invited to join the probe, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Capital punishment should be abolished

TEXT.P: Entertainer Pai Pin-pin, whose daughter was kidnapped and brutally murdered more than a decade ago, fumed when she learned that the Ministry of Justice was considering abolishing capital punishment.
The abolishment of capital punishment is the set policy of the ministry. Two thirds of the world, or 132 countries, have abolished or not executed capital punishment.

It has become a trend in the world. From the Christian point of view, man's life is created by God, and only God can take it away. But for non-Christian society, it is a hard point to swallow. It believes in an eye for an eye for the sake of upholding justice.
Taiwan has already signed several international conventions on human rights, which include the abolishment of capital punishment, and it has the obligation to abide by them.
In addition, there is no evidence to indicate that the social order of those countries with capital punishment is better than those without.

The nature of a democracy is not to strip the basic rights of the people, especially the right to live. If complementary measures, such as life imprisonment or no parole, could fill in the gaps in legislation, then capital punishment should really be consigned to the dustbin of history. (Feb. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to boycott MAC briefing on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 13:13:59 (By Su Lung-chi, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Tuesday that its members will not attend a briefing on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China given by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
"The DPP opposes the briefing, because it is being held outside the legislative system, and we will boycott it, " asserted DPP legislative caucus whip Lee Chun- yi.

Officials from the MAC and the Ministry of Economic Affairs are scheduled to report to the legislature Wednesday on the progress in negotiations of the controversial trade deal at a meeting to be chaired by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.
Lee argued that the legislature should set up a dedicated supervisory mechanism by forming a legislative task force to oversee cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, including the ECFA issue.
He asked Wang to host negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties to determine how the legislature should oversee the administration's ECFA talks with China.

In response, Lin Hung-chih, a whip of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, said listening to the briefing will help lawmakers better grasp the process behind negotiations on the trade pact.
Lin called for his DPP colleagues to attend the meeting.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng criticized Lin's proposal of establishing a separate task force as "needlessly redundant."
"What is crucial is whether the legislators are attentive enough to the ECFA issue, rather than establishing a separate task force, " Wu argued.

Besides, he said, when the DPP was the ruling party during the Chen Shui-bian era, it opposed a proposal by the then opposition KMT caucus to set up a legislative task force on cross-strait affairs and labeled it "unconstitutional."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA raises travel alert for Indonesia, U.K.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 13:46:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has elevated its travel alert level for Indonesia and the United Kingdom (U.K.) over concerns of potential terrorist attacks, the ministry said in a statement Tuesday.

The ministry has elevated the travel alert level for Indonesia and the U.K. to yellow, the second lowest on the MOFA's four-scale system, and also issued a red travel alert, the highest on the scale, for Iraq.
The MOFA said Indonesia, and especially Bali which attracts the most Taiwanese tourists, could possibly be targeted for a terrorist attack.

The ministry issued the new alert for Britain after the U.K.'s Home Office raised its domestic terrorism threat level in late January from substantial to severe, the second highest in its five-tier threat warning system, which means an attack is highly likely.
A yellow alert warns travelers to take extra precautions and reassess their travel plans for the place in question.

The terrorist group Al Qaida could also possibly launch attacks in Iraq, prompting the ministry to issue the highest red alert before the country holds its parliamentary elections on March 7. The ministry again advised Taiwanese travelers against visiting the Middle East country.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Taiwan issue is an international one
DOC.DATELINE: 02/02/10 13:52:07 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. defense ministry announced it would sell a package of five weapons systems to Taiwan last week. Unfortunately, the F-16 C/D fighters and diesel submarines that were urgently needed by Taiwan were not included.
We are not surprised by U.S. President Barack Obama's decision to announce the arms sales at this time, as he is trying to show that his country is still a state to be reckoned with in Asia.

What about Taiwan? Some weapons -- Patriot missiles, anti-submarine aircraft and the submarines -- were approved in 2001 by President George Bush. However, Taiwan's Legislative Yuan didn't approve the budget for the procurement until 2007 owing to the opposition by the Kuomintang when it was in the opposition.
However, Taiwan's requests for F-16C/Ds and submarines were put on hold by Washington in 2006 because of Taiwan's delay in preparing its budget for the Bush package.
In Taiwan, President Ma welcomed the U.S. decision, saying it gives Taiwan more confidence in engaging with China.
If this is true, why would his party block the arms procurement budget in the legislature when it was in opposition?

Angered by Washington's announcement, Beijing suspended its military exchanges with the U.S. But why didn't China punish Ma's administration by stopping its negotiations on a proposed trade pact with Taiwan, if that pact is really as favorable to Taiwan as is claimed?
Why would China snarl at the U.S. but coddle Taiwan? The answer is obvious that U.S. arms sales would hinder its ambition to take over Taiwan while Ma's administration is favorable to that cause.

Fortunately, the Taiwan issue is an international one and not to be decided solely by Ma's administration. Even if Ma ignores public opinion at home, the international community won't let him have his way.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI denies spousal consent idea for sex trade its own
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 16:18:20 (By Hsieh Chiachen, Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is contemplating new legislation that would redefine prostitutes' legal status, but it said that the idea of having sex workers get spousal consent to do the job was not its stance, as was reported in the local media.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Tuesday that requiring prior consent was only a suggestion made by scholars in a study commissioned by the ministry last year on decriminalizing the sex trade.

The suggestion and other issues -- whether to set up special zones, whether to hold a local referendum on the issue, and whether the trade could be operated by corporate entities -- are all being studied and have yet to be finalized, he added.
"There is no draft law on adult sex transaction management, only the studies by scholars, " he said. "The issues involved are wide-ranging."
Jiang said the ministry hopes to complete its preparations for drafting new legislation within six months.

During that time, it will invite experts, scholars, religious groups, and sex worker representatives to seminars to solicit their views and help it balance the rights of sex workers with concepts of decency.
The ministry needs to revise the legal framework covering the sex trade following a ruling by Taiwan's constitutional court last November.

The Justices of the Constitutional Court found that a provision in the Social Order Maintenance Act allowing prostitutes, but not their patrons, to be punished was unconstitutional, and they ordered that it be invalidated within two years.
"The ministry will complete the legislation within the two years, " Jiang said, pledging not only to revise the law but also establish a set of rules guiding adult sex transactions.
Meanwhile, the reports on the spousal consent suggestion drew flak from lawmakers, scholars and sex workers Tuesday.

Female legislators from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasted the proposal as chauvinistic and argued it could not achieve the goal of decriminalizing prositution.
Legislators Lo Shu-lei of the KMT and Huang Sue-ying and Chen Ting-fei of the DPP said the proposal came from the point of view of men.
"If the government sees prostitution as a job, then it should protect the women's right to work without the need for the husband's consent, " Huang said.
Attorney Yu Mei-nu said the Ministry of the Interior has to first figure out whether it wants to decriminalize or legalize sex workers.
"If it is to legalize the sex workers, then it is to say that the work is legal. In that case, legal work does not need spousal consent," she added.
A sex worker said the idea of spousal consent was "absurd" and "impossible." enditem/ls
was responding to reports that the ministry is working on a draft sex transaction management law in which it was stipulated that adult sex workers should obtain the consent of the spouses.
He said that the

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan joins NASA-led international environmental project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 16:23:56 (By Lin Szu-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: For the first time ever, Taiwan is working with the United States' National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) to monitor environmental quality in the South China Sea, an environmental official said Tuesday.

"NASA has provided Taiwan's National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium with state-of-the-art equipment to help check background air quality in the South China Sea area, starting in January this year, " said the official of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration.

Taiwan has two similar monitoring stations on the Dongsha Islands in the South China Sea and on the country's highest peak, Jade Mountain, to measure the impact of biomass burning in Southeast Asia on Taiwan's environment, the official said.

The installation of the NASA equipment at the coastal national marine biology museum in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung is part of an international cooperative project to study and monitor special features of biomass burning in Southeast Asia, long-haul transmission of pollutants, atmospheric chemicals and global climate changes, the official said.
Major Southeast Asian countries, including Singapore, the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam and Malaysia, are also taking part in the four-year research program, from 2010 to 2013.
Under the project, Taiwanese researchers, along with research teams from the United States and Southeast Asian countries, are collecting and monitoring background air quality data, the official said.
"This is the first time that Taiwan has joined a NASA-organized international cooperative project to monitor environmental quality in the South China Sea," said the official.

The project is expected to help upgrade Taiwan's environmental monitoring capability and documentation technology and facilitate the integration of Taiwan's environmental data into international databanks, the official said.
"The program has opened up a new era for Taiwan's participation in global environmental monitoring," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global warming alert should be integrated into school courses
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 17:06:19 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Information on global warming alerts and prevention should be made part of the school curriculum to help raise environmental awareness among younger generations, first lady Chow Mei-ching suggested Tuesday.
Chow called for the government to develop an integrated, environmentally friendly industrial policy and include global warming issues and green lifestyle information in school courses.

In a blog article in the magazine Education, Parenting, Family and Lifestyle, Chow noted that Taiwan is on a U.N. list of Pacific island nations classified as "the first batch of climate change refugees." However, most Taiwanese children have little knowledge of global warming and climate change issues, she wrote.

In the article titled "Green lifestyle starts from childhood, " Chow said it would not be very difficult to lead an environmentally friendly lifestyle once people put into practice the notion of reducing their carbon footprint and saving energy and resources.
"Taiwan society should strive to make energy saving and carbon reduction a trend or fashion," she suggested.

Only when people agree that personal vanity, luxury and fun should not lead to a scarcity of resources for future generations will they develop environmental consciousness as a sustainable way of life, she stated.

Chow said she was invited to participate in several reading sessions for children in local communities last December when global warming issues were being hotly debated in Copenhagen. She discovered that most of the children who attended the sessions knew little about global warming or energy and carbon emissions issues, she stated.

However, this is not the children's fault, she wrote, adding that the government, society, schools and parents will have to take the blame for the failure to integrate environmental issues and relevant human responses into the education system.
Children must be taught about social responsibility, the relationship between humans and their environment, and how to live in harmony with Mother Nature, she suggested.
"They need to know about the greenhouse effect and how to measure carbon footprints,"she reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on Taiwan bourse fall to three-month low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 17:22:02 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange fell Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted index dropping 95.06 points to finish at a three-month low of 7,429.61.
The local bourse opened 109.07 points higher than Monday's close but ended low, with the weighted index fluctuating over a 230-point range during the trading session.
Market turnover was NT$109.66 billion (US$3.42 billion) , with local and foreign institutional investors selling a net value of NT$7.782 billion worth of shares.
Foreign investors continued to sell heavily for the seventh consecutive day, reversing a net buying trend since the start of this year.

Analysts warned that foreign investors might sell more heavily ahead of the Feb. 14 Chinese New Year holiday out of fears that the easy credit policy will end as a result of China's recent demand that its banks increase their deposit reserves and due to U.S. President Barack Obama's restrictions on U.S. banks' investment activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation finds straws still high in lead content
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 17:35:01 (By Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Tests on a small sampling of straws from around Taiwan have found that more than 10 percent contain hazardous levels of lead, the Consumers' Foundation (CF) said Tuesday.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said the group collected 80 straws in November and December from breakfast outlets and night markets in the greater Taipei area, Taoyuan County, Taichung County, and Tainan, Kaohsiung and Taichung cities.

The tests found that the lead content in 10 of the samples, or 12.5 perent, exceeded the 100 ppm standard. The straws were also tested for cadmium, but they all fell within the 100 ppm standard, according to the consumer group.
Last year, the foundation randomly tested 41 disposable bowls, spoons, stirrers and straws, and six of them, or 14.63 percent, failed the lead test.
"The latest test has not shown marked improvement from the previous test," Hsieh said.
He urged the Department of Health to ask shop owners using substandard items to destroy them or face fines ranging from NT$30,000 to NT$150,000.

Lo Shan-lien, a professor at National Taiwan University, said that while the test covered only the composition of the materials and not their dissolution volume, he strongly suggested that people not use straws to drink hot beverages to avoid ingesting unsafe levels of lead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water diversion project not behind Siaolin tragedy: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 17:51:44 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former residents of a village that was buried by landslides last August have voiced anger over the official explanation given for the disaster, but authorities insisted Tuesday that a tunnel project could not have caused the tragedy, as some of the survivors suspect.

Fan Liang-shiow, chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) , reiterated that the energy released during the explosions set off for the tunnel project was far weaker than the minimum needed to trigger a disaster.
The commission on Monday released a report on its investigation into what caused Siaolin Village in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, to be buried by landslides during Typhoon Morakot last August.
The report fingered massive rainfall as the culprit that doomed the mountain village.
Siaolin absorbed 1,856 mm of rainfall in 72 hours during the typhoon, triggering mudslides that covered the village and buried nearly 500 people alive.

Survivors and environmental protection activists believe, however, that explosions to build tunnels for the Tsengwen Reservoir water diversion project, as well as other factors including mass stockpiles at gravel yards and overlogging, were also behind the disaster.

They did not accept the report's conclusions, but Fan explained that a research team analyzed the explosion-triggered energy release in four fields from four perspectives: scientific theory, international experience, construction records and seismologic monitoring.
Based on its conservative calculations, the research team found that the energy released during the construction was far lower than the trigger point of 120 gal.
Gal, formerly known as galileo, is the unit of acceleration in the centimeter- gram-second system, equal to 1 centimeter per second squared.
Fan pointed out that although a blast of such a degree can be felt at a distance by people sensitive to tremors, it was not big enough to cause a disaster.

According to records on vibrations caused by construction in the area between Dec. 20, 2006, when the explosions began, and Aug. 6, 2009, only 0.51 percent of the records showed figures higher than noise vibration standards set by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
By comparison, 0.6 percent of the vibrations recorded between Sept. 10, 2004 and Dec. 20, 2006, before the blasting began, exceeded EPA standards, Fan said.
The figures show that the tremors caused by project's explosions could not have caused a disaster.
Fan stressed that an evaluation by the Central Weather Bureau's seismologic monitoring station and U.S. geologic surveys targeting tremors set off by dynamite also reached the same conclusion.

Meanwhile, when asked whether the suspended Tsengwen Reservoir water diversion project would be resumed, Fan said a PCC research team has suggested that the water channels be completed to prevent them from collapsing.
He added, however, that it would be up to the Ministry of Economic Affairs to decide whether the project will be restarted.
The project was launched to channel river water to the reservoir for agricultural irrigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan helps eradicate epidemic diseases in Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 18:52:35 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's medical assistance mission currently working in Haiti will focus its efforts in the future on eradicating epidemic diseases and rebuilding public health systems in the Caribbean ally ravaged by a magnitude 7.0 earthquake recently, medical sources said Tuesday.
The efforts need governmental and NGO collaboration to become effective and influential, said officials from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).

Emergency medical aid have been donated by countries around the world to Haiti. The international community now needs to rebuild Haiti's public health systems in the following three to five years, with setting up an epidemic disease prevention system topping the list, said Steve Kuo, director-general of the DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
"Taiwan will be among the few countries offering personnel and goods to help Haiti build a disease prevention system," Kuo said.

The long-term disease-battling task in Haiti will represent the first time that Taiwan helps a diplomatic ally to form part of a national public health system since Taiwan launched "medical diplomacy" several years ago, Kuo added.

The International Cooperation and Development Fund, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs operation, will dispatch its officials to Haiti next week to probe the situation and assess actual needs for the establishment of the disease prevention system, he added.
The CDC head made the remarks after talking via mobile phone with two members of the Taiwanese medical assistance mission currently working in Haiti.
Lien Chia-en, a CDC physician in charge of epidemic prevention, told Kuo over phone that he has helped identify and prevent two cases of measles in Haiti's capital Port-au-Prince.

As the rainy season is approaching in Haiti, a disease prevention system needs to be built there quickly to closely monitor the epidemic situation, said Lien, a graduate of National Yang Ming University's medical school who gained prominence serving as a health care worker in Burkina Faso from 2001-2003.

Chuang Chia-chang, head of the Taiwan International Health Action, who was with Lien, said that only about 40-50 percent of Haitians have been vaccinated against lockjaw and diphtheria, a bacterial disease characterized by infectious lesions in the mouth area.
Coordination over vaccine requisition and distributions, led by the World Health Organization, was not smooth, Chuang said.

The progress of other efforts, including mother and child health care and rehabilitation and artificial limb service for the earthquake survivors, will need further cooperation and coordination by governments and non-governmental organizations, Chuang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president Chen Shui-bian indicted again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 19:08:33 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian, who has been convicted on corruption charges, was indicted again Tuesday on charges of abetting his subordinates to give false testimony.

Taiwan District prosecutors accused Chen of coaching Lin Teh-hsun, who served as a Presidential Office director during Chen's presidency, and three other aides to mislead prosecutors in August 2006 during an investigation into corruption allegations against Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen.

According to the indictment, Lin falsely claimed during questioning that Chen had used a special state affairs account to fund two secret diplomatic missions, while the other aides untruthfully denied that Wu Shu-jen had ever used invoices provided by other people to claim reimbursements from the state affairs fund.
Lin was indicted for perjury in the case, but the other aides were let off because they had only trivial roles, the prosecutors' office said.

Since Lin has already lodged an appeal with the Taiwan High Court against a 16-year sentence for perjury and embezzlement in another case involving Chen, his latest indictment will be referred to the same court for trial.
James J. Lee, a former chief of the Hsinchu Science Park, was also indicted Tuesday for perjury.

The indictment states that Lee went to Chen's official residence sometime on Dec. 30 or 31 2003 to discuss the difficulty Lee was having to acquire a piece of land in Taoyuan for the Hsinchu Science Park.
Chen promised to help and instructed Wei Che-ho, then-minister of the National Science Council, to allow the science park to first rent the land and then buy it, according to the indictment.
Chen and his wife obtained NT$300 million in kickbacks from the private owner of the land, according to prosecutors.
The prosecutors said Lee gave false testimony during the prosecutors' investigation of the case and during the trial, insisting that his briefing was to the first lady and that Chen was not involved.
Lee was found to have received a NT$30 million kickbacks in the land deal and was given a six-year sentence for corruption.
Chen, who has been in custody since Dec. 30, 2008, and his wife have been given life sentences on charges of embezzlement of the state affairs fund, money laundering and corruption.
They have both denied the charges and appealed their sentences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Ma Ying-jeou is no Obama
DOC.DATELINE: 02/02/10 19:13:47 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In the United States, which is a world model for the presidential system of government, the president gives a state of the union address to the Congress every year, although he is not responsible for the legislature.
His address is usually watched closely by people around the world for indications of his agenda and U.S. policy.

Taiwan should also follow that trend because its government is a hybrid of the presidential and parliamentary systems. The government is headed by the president who is not answerable to the legislature. The premier, who heads the Cabinet and is subject to legislative oversight, is in effect the president's chief aide.
Therefore, the people are eager for their president to outline his political agenda at least once a year, explain his vision for the state and detail his responses to the problems facing the country.
Taiwan, like the U.S, has suffered as a result of the global financial crisis and its leader is facing the same mounting public anger over economic problems.
The Taiwan people listened to U.S. President Barack Obama's address to hear if there were any antidotes that could be applied to Taiwan's economic problems.
To our surprise, we learned that the U.S.' economic problems are not as serious as ours. However, many of Obama's solutions seem almost tailor-made for Taiwan.

Of particular interest was Obama's promise to set aside US$30 billion to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) . Taiwan's SMEs, which used to be the backbone of its economy, have been ignored for many years and have withered under the government's policy of nurturing giant companies and hi-tech industries.
When those large enterprises were hard hit by the global financial crisis, Taiwan could not fall back on its SMEs to tide over the crisis.
More urgently than the U.S., Taiwan needs to revitalize its SMEs. But will President Ma Ying-jeou follow Obama's lead and earmark funds for that purpose?

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Fine Arts Museum showcases work of young artist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 19:20:52 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Fine Arts Museum (TFAM) is hosting a solo exhibition, "Wunderkammer, " that features the sculpture installations and architectural proposals of young Taiwanese artist E Chen.
Chen's works are full of imagination but his ideas are inspired by real life, the organizer of the exhibition said.
According to the TFAM, the exhibition includes six installation works and three architectural proposals.

One of Chen's architectural proposals is to establish a Titanic-themed casino in Las Vegas that would include a 5-star hotel, a fun park, high class restaurants, luxury stores and movie theaters. This concept explores the juxtaposition of tragedy and gambling, the organizer said.
"This proposal caught the attention of the media when it was exhibited in the United States, and some people even believed it would really be developed," she said.
According to Chen, his works attempt to reinterpret artificial object space and subvert the functionality of artificial objects. His pieces are closely related to anti-consumerism, he said.
In recent years, Chen has been very active on the international arts scene. After the TFAM exhibition ends on March 14, one of his architectural proposals, "Lost City," will be shown in London.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma touts policy to broaden cross-strait student exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 19:50:09 (By S. K. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday touted his administration's policy to broaden exchanges between students of Taiwan and China on condition that the rights of Taiwan students will not be affected.

Addressing the opening of a two-day meeting of university presidents at I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, Ma said the government will definitely take steps to avoid pitfalls in the process of allowing Chinese college students to study in Taiwan and recognizing diplomas issued by some of China's elite higher education institutions.
Ma listed three reasons for his decision to implement the policy.
First, he said, it forms part of the government's China policy and the goal of forging friendly ties with other countries around the world, including China.

He reiterated that under the fremework of the Republic of China Constitution, Taiwan will maintain the status-quo in relation to China, which means no unification, no independence and no use of force across the Taiwan Strait. This will allow exchanges between youth from both sides, he added.
Secondly, the president said, he thinks the youths of Taiwan and China should learn from each other and sharpen their competitiveness.
Thirdly, Chinese students could help to boost dwindling registrations in Taiwan's colleges due to a falling birth rate in Taiwan, he said.
However, the main aim of the policy is to allow for deeper interaction between young people on both sides of the strait and to create greater possibilities in bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: British Council to hold spring exhibition on UK schools
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 19:55:37 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition to promote studying abroad in the United Kingdom will be kicked off in March in three cities in Taiwan, the British Council said Tuesday.

The Education UK Spring Exhibition 2010 will begin from March 6 in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung cities, the Council said in a statement. This year, representatives from over 30 British universities and colleges will fly to Taiwan to attend the show, as well as the officials from the secondary schools will also be available to answer questions.
According to the director of British Council, Christine Skinner, over 8,000 students from all over Taiwan came to the event last year to collect information on UK schools.

She indicated that representatives from famous British universities and schools will be taking part in the exhibition this time, including from the Newcastle University, the University of Manchester, University of Warwick, University of Southampton, University of the Arts London and many others.

Students will be able to find out about a wide range of courses from secondary schools to university study, including English language and vocational courses, as well as undergraduate education, master degrees and PhD qualifications.
In addition, counselling services will also be provided to cover studying and living in the UK, IELTS preparation, English learning and financing, she noted.

The time and venues for the Education UK Spring Exhibition 2010 is as follows: Taipei is at 6F, Eslite Hsin-yi Bookstore on March 6-7; Taichung is at the National Chung-hsing University on March 9; Kaohsiung is at the National Sun- Yet-Sen University on March 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public's views on decriminalizing prostitution mixed: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 20:09:46 (By Hsieh Chiachen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The public has mixed views on whether prostitution should be a punishable offense, according to a poll conducted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Tuesday that the survey, which was completed in the last half of 2009, found that 48.8 percent of the people think the government should protect the working rights of prostitutes, while 43.2 percent disagree.

"The results were just as mixed among women's groups, with some advocating the decriminalization of prostitution, some taking the opposite view, and others suggesting that any penalties should be extended to patrons of the trade," Jiang said.
According to the survey, 60.1 percent said they are aware that the Social Order Maintenance Act stipulates "prostitution is prohibited and violators should be punished."
However, only 23.3 percent of the respondents were aware that the penalties apply only to prostitutes and not to patrons.
The majority -- 52.9 percent -- were of the opinion that consensual sex trade between adults is not a crime and should not be punishable, while 42.7 percent disagreed with that view.
The survey also found that 74.6 percent think that sex trade among adults is common in Taiwan society.

Some 68.5 percent of the respondents said that sex trade between adults should be managed, with 83.6 percent of that group favoring the establishment of a special zone, and 25.1 percent saying the sex trade should not be restricted to any particular area.

As for the opinions of local governments, Taipei and Chiayi cities are opposed to setting up special zones, while Kaohsiung, Hsinchu, and Taichung cities and Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Penghu counties favore special zones.
Taipei County is in favor of designating red-light districts, but does not want them within its boundaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: King working from outside in to reform KMT: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 21:21:18 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) latest hire of a human resource expert shows its Secretary-General King Pu-tsung's determination to reform the century-old party despite mixed responses to his decision across party lines, scholars said.

King confirmed Saturday that Ryan Wu, former executive vice president of the online 1111 job bank, has been hired to help plan KMT human resource initiatives. Wu will work as a personnel project manager in the party's Administration Committee on a one-year contract.

"This is a move that aims to bring a breath of fresh air into the KMT's rigid system and transform its image into that of 'youth-friendly' party, " said Liao Da-chi, a political scientist at National Sun Yet-sen University.

King's first major hire since he assumed office last December drew attention because of the timing and Wu's controversial past. King, however, brushed off the criticisms from some quarters, and said he hired Wu for his expertise.

The appointment came in the wake of King's pledge to reform the KMT in three years and turn the party into an election machine. Since last year, the KMT has suffered three straight setbacks in two by-elections and a mayoral election, and many of the party's employees have expressed fears about losing their jobs.
Post-election analysis suggested that the KMT needs more young talent at the local level to boost its appeal to young people.

Wu, 43, worked as a media relations chief at the Taipei City Department of Labor in 2001 when King was deputy mayor. However, his appointment to the party post came as a surprise as he has had little connection to the KMT and is seen as an "outsider".

Several KMT legislators have spoken against the appointment. Legislator Lu Hsueh-Chang said that while it's a good thing to bring in "corporate management, " Wu is not familiar with the way party affairs are run, which could be dangerous. Some KMT legislators have claimed that they do not know Wu.

"It seems to me King is trying to use outside resources to carry out his reform, working his way in from the outside rather than taking the 'inside-out approach', " said Hsu Yung-ming, a political scientist at Soochow University.
Wu's appointment could be the "turning point" for the KMT, which now has little or no appeal for young people because of all its old politicians, Liao said.

"In addition to having a human resource background, Wu is media-savvy and outgoing. That can be a plus for the party. And he has been hired on a one-year contract. If he does not deliver, he can be let go. The KMT has nothing to lose," Liao asserted.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Huang Wei-cher was quoted as saying that Wu's appointment was "a brilliant tactic because, as an outsider, Wu carries no baggage and can do what he wants based on his own assessment."
For a party with 106 years of history, a full-scale reform will be difficult, Liao said. That is why King is giving priority to party image and communication before restructuring, the scholar added.
King's main options now are to create a new image for the party and build a human resource pool so that the young generation can step in when the current generation fades away, Liao said.
"I also think it would be better if King avoided any action that involved local party factions, as it is one of the most complicated factors related to party reform," she said.

According to Liao, King's short-term goal would be winning the next two elections -- a by-election involving four legislative seats in late February and the elections in five special municipalities later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Cloud Gate performance praised by Washington Post
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 21:37:09 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's famous Cloud Gate Dance Theatre's performances at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has won rave acclaims.
Sarah Kaufman, the arts reporter of The Washington Post particularly gave high praise to the performance "Moon Water" in a dance review published in the newspaper on Monday.
Kaufman gave a great deal of attention to the power and idea of the performance of the theatre's young dancers Tsai Ming-yuan and Huang Pei-hua.

Kaufman described the movement of Tsai in her report as something that "seem to melt away as he lunges and folds, then, as he is still crouching, a leg will lift, spiral, slice the air around him like a blade and slowly, slowly descend with the weightlessness of tissue."
"It brought to mind that staple of the ballet gala 'The Dying Swan', a solo of great pathos and no small degree of virtuosic flexibility in the arms and upper body." she said in her report.

Kaufman also indicated that tai chi's inner calm and outer poise is reflected in the work of "Moon Water"," adding that its "unhurried elegance and pliable movement can be beautiful and even uplifting to watch."

She also praised Lin Hwai-min, the founder of the troupe, saying Lin has lit the way to a new vocabulary in dance, one that reaches back to ancient wisdom and ahead to future fruitfulness, with a cool, unforced, yet insistent power, like water, "Moon Water," indeed.
After finishing the performance in Washington, the troupe will fly to Canada to perform at the Queen Elizabeth Theatre in Vancouver Feb. 5-6.
The performance is the group's first at the Kennedy Center since 1995 - something Kaufman found perplexing, saying more performances soon by the troupe ought to be "inevitable."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax on upscale residential properties expected to double
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 21:43:08 (By Johnson Sun, Lin Ye-fong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 11,000 housing units will be affected by a Taipei City government plan to raise taxes on upscale residential properties, a city official said Tuesday.

Some properties will be subject to twice the amount of taxes being paid on them at present, while others will be taxed NT$30,000 to NT$60,000 (US$1,870) more, said Taipei City Department of Finance Director Chiu Ta-chan.
The introduction of the so-called "luxury house tax" is aimed at making the system of taxation "more fair and reasonable," he said.
Currently, a residential property valued at NT$100 million is subject to the same tax rate of 1.2 percent as one valued at NT$3 million, he noted.
According to Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, the definition of a "luxury residential property" will no longer be based on the ground size of a housing unit or its market price.
The definition will take into account the number of households on each floor of the building, the construction materials, the number of parking places, and security in the building, Hau added.
Commercial buildings and villas will not be subject to the luxury house tax because they are already listed in another taxation category, Hau said.
According to Chiu, the city government plans to introduce the luxury house tax in 2011.

Meanwhile, revenue officers at a meeting held by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) earlier in the day agreed that the existing house tax system must be adjusted because the house value assessment standard is unreasonably low, said MOF Deputy Minister Chang Sheng-ho.
For example, the current assessment value of a 10-story building in Taipei City is NT$4,580 per square meter, but the construction cost is NT$21,000 to NT$26,000 per square meter, Chang said.
In Taiwan, house tax rates are decided by local governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5,000 blood donors offered coupons for free steaks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:02:30 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Five thousand gift certificates for free steak meals were distributed to blood donors hours after a one-day nationwide blood collection drive kicked off Tuesday.
For the third year in a row, Tasty steakhouse joined forces with the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation to launch a blood donation drive, said Hung Ching-yu, the steakhouse's spokesperson.
Long lines were seen at the 40 designated sites around the country, with latecomers sighing and complaining.
"I came here with my friends who got up at 3 a.m or 4 a.m. to get ahead in the line, " a Taipei woman, who was identified as Chu, told the CNA's English Web site Focus Taiwan.
"In fact, people should rest well before donating blood, " said Lee Hui-chen, spokesperson for the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation.
"Simple tests are usually conducted on the potential donors to ensure the quality of the blood," she said.
Lee urged the public to donate blood regularly over the long term.
"Donated blood expires in 35 days, so it is not a good idea to collect too much in one day as it will all expire at the same time, " she said.
Blood shortages often occur during summer or winter breaks in Taiwan as students are a major source of blood donations, Lee noted.
Tasty steakhouse sponsored 1,000 gift certificates last year, but they were all offered at one designated blood donation site, according to Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dealer offers free inspection service amid Toyota recall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:29:46 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwan distributor of the Japanese car maker Toyota, is offering free inspection service to users of Toyota vehicles who may be concerned about problematic gas pedals that have prompted massive recalls in the United States and Europe.

However, Hotai Motor Co. executives claimed Tuesday that the defective accelerator pedal made by CTS Corp. is not found in vehicles on the Taiwan market, as they use an entirely different one produced by Denso Corp.
The two types of gas pedals were displayed at a press briefing held by the car dealer, the Taiwan government's Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) officials and experts.

Auto parts for the same car model can be different because they have to be designed according to the needs in the different countries, Steven Yang, general manager of the dealer's External Affairs Division, explained.

Hotai Motor has promised to confirm the cause of the recall of over four million cars in the U.S. and Europe in recent weeks. The Japanese company CTS has denied that there is any problem with the quality of the gas pedal it designed.

The commission will ask the transport ministry to investigate whether local car companies used the problematic gas pedal and will release the results of the investigation by Feb. 10, said Liu Ching- fang, a division chief at the commission.
Drivers are advised to shift into neutral gear if their vehicles develop gas pedal trouble, according to a statement released by the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan universities need to be globally competitive: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:38:50 (By S. K. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou stressed Tuesday the importance of making Taiwan universities globally competitive, and said he hopes they can attract 30,000 foreign students over the next four years.

"It is urgently important to make local universities and colleges internationally efficient so as to recruit more students from other countries to help Taiwan sharpen its competitive edge, " Ma said at the opening of a two-day meeting of university and college presidents at I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.
Currently foreign students account for only 10 percent of the student body at Taiwan's tertiary institutions, he noted.
"Judging from Taiwan's past history, it is a fact that opening to the rest of the world will make our country strong, and we hope to lure more foreign students," Ma said.

The president said a scholarship program run by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has initially succeeded in attracting foreign college students, but he called for a further upgrade so that all courses can be taught in English. So far, all- English courses are offered at 39 Taiwanese universities, he added.

Ma said Taiwan's dwindling crude birth rate -- which was the world's lowest at 8.29 last year -- poses a great threat to its higher education system, which might see an oversupply of places in the coming years.

The president announced that the government is planning to implement a performance-based "flexible salary program" from the fall semester of this year, to keep good professors and researchers at home as part of its efforts to cultivate world-class human resources over the long term.

According to Ma, education is at the core of the government's efforts to secure Taiwan's continued survival, as the country does not have rich natural resources and because of its disaster-prone environment.

Minister of Education (MOE) Wu Ching-ji also announced in the meeting later the same day that tuition and miscellaneous fees at nationwide universities and colleges will not be raised for the next academic year.

In light of rising consumer prices, decreasing salaries and shrinking household incomes, the MOE has decided to freeze tuition for one academic year, starting from September, until the economic recovery takes hold, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to fund swimming program for 50,000 students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Tuesday that it will provide funding to help 50,000 underprivileged students develop swimming skills.
The school children targeted in the 12-year swimming training project include those from low-income families, indigenous tribes and remote rural areas or outlying islands.

Vice Education Minister Chen Yi-hsing said that in the first four years starting 2010, NT$3.9 billion will be allocated to the project, with NT$400 million to be used to help schools at various level to teach their students to swim.

An additional NT$750 million will be made available each year for counties and cities to promote the use of swimming pools, install water warming facilities or build new swimming pools, Chen said. (By Lin Szu-yu & Bear Lee
