"In addition to having a human resource background, Wu is media-savvy and outgoing. That can be a plus for the party. And he has been hired on a one-year contract. If he does not deliver, he can be let go. The KMT has nothing to lose," Liao asserted.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Huang Wei-cher was quoted as saying that Wu's appointment was "a brilliant tactic because, as an outsider, Wu carries no baggage and can do what he wants based on his own assessment."
For a party with 106 years of history, a full-scale reform will be difficult, Liao said. That is why King is giving priority to party image and communication before restructuring, the scholar added.
King's main options now are to create a new image for the party and build a human resource pool so that the young generation can step in when the current generation fades away, Liao said.
"I also think it would be better if King avoided any action that involved local party factions, as it is one of the most complicated factors related to party reform," she said.

According to Liao, King's short-term goal would be winning the next two elections -- a by-election involving four legislative seats in late February and the elections in five special municipalities later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Cloud Gate performance praised by Washington Post
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 21:37:09 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's famous Cloud Gate Dance Theatre's performances at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has won rave acclaims.
Sarah Kaufman, the arts reporter of The Washington Post particularly gave high praise to the performance "Moon Water" in a dance review published in the newspaper on Monday.
Kaufman gave a great deal of attention to the power and idea of the performance of the theatre's young dancers Tsai Ming-yuan and Huang Pei-hua.

Kaufman described the movement of Tsai in her report as something that "seem to melt away as he lunges and folds, then, as he is still crouching, a leg will lift, spiral, slice the air around him like a blade and slowly, slowly descend with the weightlessness of tissue."
"It brought to mind that staple of the ballet gala 'The Dying Swan', a solo of great pathos and no small degree of virtuosic flexibility in the arms and upper body." she said in her report.

Kaufman also indicated that tai chi's inner calm and outer poise is reflected in the work of "Moon Water"," adding that its "unhurried elegance and pliable movement can be beautiful and even uplifting to watch."

She also praised Lin Hwai-min, the founder of the troupe, saying Lin has lit the way to a new vocabulary in dance, one that reaches back to ancient wisdom and ahead to future fruitfulness, with a cool, unforced, yet insistent power, like water, "Moon Water," indeed.
After finishing the performance in Washington, the troupe will fly to Canada to perform at the Queen Elizabeth Theatre in Vancouver Feb. 5-6.
The performance is the group's first at the Kennedy Center since 1995 - something Kaufman found perplexing, saying more performances soon by the troupe ought to be "inevitable."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax on upscale residential properties expected to double
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 21:43:08 (By Johnson Sun, Lin Ye-fong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 11,000 housing units will be affected by a Taipei City government plan to raise taxes on upscale residential properties, a city official said Tuesday.

Some properties will be subject to twice the amount of taxes being paid on them at present, while others will be taxed NT$30,000 to NT$60,000 (US$1,870) more, said Taipei City Department of Finance Director Chiu Ta-chan.
The introduction of the so-called "luxury house tax" is aimed at making the system of taxation "more fair and reasonable," he said.
Currently, a residential property valued at NT$100 million is subject to the same tax rate of 1.2 percent as one valued at NT$3 million, he noted.
According to Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, the definition of a "luxury residential property" will no longer be based on the ground size of a housing unit or its market price.
The definition will take into account the number of households on each floor of the building, the construction materials, the number of parking places, and security in the building, Hau added.
Commercial buildings and villas will not be subject to the luxury house tax because they are already listed in another taxation category, Hau said.
According to Chiu, the city government plans to introduce the luxury house tax in 2011.

Meanwhile, revenue officers at a meeting held by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) earlier in the day agreed that the existing house tax system must be adjusted because the house value assessment standard is unreasonably low, said MOF Deputy Minister Chang Sheng-ho.
For example, the current assessment value of a 10-story building in Taipei City is NT$4,580 per square meter, but the construction cost is NT$21,000 to NT$26,000 per square meter, Chang said.
In Taiwan, house tax rates are decided by local governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5,000 blood donors offered coupons for free steaks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:02:30 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Five thousand gift certificates for free steak meals were distributed to blood donors hours after a one-day nationwide blood collection drive kicked off Tuesday.
For the third year in a row, Tasty steakhouse joined forces with the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation to launch a blood donation drive, said Hung Ching-yu, the steakhouse's spokesperson.
Long lines were seen at the 40 designated sites around the country, with latecomers sighing and complaining.
"I came here with my friends who got up at 3 a.m or 4 a.m. to get ahead in the line, " a Taipei woman, who was identified as Chu, told the CNA's English Web site Focus Taiwan.
"In fact, people should rest well before donating blood, " said Lee Hui-chen, spokesperson for the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation.
"Simple tests are usually conducted on the potential donors to ensure the quality of the blood," she said.
Lee urged the public to donate blood regularly over the long term.
"Donated blood expires in 35 days, so it is not a good idea to collect too much in one day as it will all expire at the same time, " she said.
Blood shortages often occur during summer or winter breaks in Taiwan as students are a major source of blood donations, Lee noted.
Tasty steakhouse sponsored 1,000 gift certificates last year, but they were all offered at one designated blood donation site, according to Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dealer offers free inspection service amid Toyota recall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:29:46 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwan distributor of the Japanese car maker Toyota, is offering free inspection service to users of Toyota vehicles who may be concerned about problematic gas pedals that have prompted massive recalls in the United States and Europe.

However, Hotai Motor Co. executives claimed Tuesday that the defective accelerator pedal made by CTS Corp. is not found in vehicles on the Taiwan market, as they use an entirely different one produced by Denso Corp.
The two types of gas pedals were displayed at a press briefing held by the car dealer, the Taiwan government's Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) officials and experts.

Auto parts for the same car model can be different because they have to be designed according to the needs in the different countries, Steven Yang, general manager of the dealer's External Affairs Division, explained.

Hotai Motor has promised to confirm the cause of the recall of over four million cars in the U.S. and Europe in recent weeks. The Japanese company CTS has denied that there is any problem with the quality of the gas pedal it designed.

The commission will ask the transport ministry to investigate whether local car companies used the problematic gas pedal and will release the results of the investigation by Feb. 10, said Liu Ching- fang, a division chief at the commission.
Drivers are advised to shift into neutral gear if their vehicles develop gas pedal trouble, according to a statement released by the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan universities need to be globally competitive: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/10 22:38:50 (By S. K. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou stressed Tuesday the importance of making Taiwan universities globally competitive, and said he hopes they can attract 30,000 foreign students over the next four years.

"It is urgently important to make local universities and colleges internationally efficient so as to recruit more students from other countries to help Taiwan sharpen its competitive edge, " Ma said at the opening of a two-day meeting of university and college presidents at I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.
Currently foreign students account for only 10 percent of the student body at Taiwan's tertiary institutions, he noted.
"Judging from Taiwan's past history, it is a fact that opening to the rest of the world will make our country strong, and we hope to lure more foreign students," Ma said.

The president said a scholarship program run by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has initially succeeded in attracting foreign college students, but he called for a further upgrade so that all courses can be taught in English. So far, all- English courses are offered at 39 Taiwanese universities, he added.

Ma said Taiwan's dwindling crude birth rate -- which was the world's lowest at 8.29 last year -- poses a great threat to its higher education system, which might see an oversupply of places in the coming years.

The president announced that the government is planning to implement a performance-based "flexible salary program" from the fall semester of this year, to keep good professors and researchers at home as part of its efforts to cultivate world-class human resources over the long term.

According to Ma, education is at the core of the government's efforts to secure Taiwan's continued survival, as the country does not have rich natural resources and because of its disaster-prone environment.

Minister of Education (MOE) Wu Ching-ji also announced in the meeting later the same day that tuition and miscellaneous fees at nationwide universities and colleges will not be raised for the next academic year.

In light of rising consumer prices, decreasing salaries and shrinking household incomes, the MOE has decided to freeze tuition for one academic year, starting from September, until the economic recovery takes hold, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to fund swimming program for 50,000 students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Tuesday that it will provide funding to help 50,000 underprivileged students develop swimming skills.
The school children targeted in the 12-year swimming training project include those from low-income families, indigenous tribes and remote rural areas or outlying islands.

Vice Education Minister Chen Yi-hsing said that in the first four years starting 2010, NT$3.9 billion will be allocated to the project, with NT$400 million to be used to help schools at various level to teach their students to swim.

An additional NT$750 million will be made available each year for counties and cities to promote the use of swimming pools, install water warming facilities or build new swimming pools, Chen said. (By Lin Szu-yu & Bear Lee

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 3, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 09:11:05 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday than its previous close, moving up 94.18 points at 7,523.79 on a turnover of NT$2.5 billion (US$78.13 million).
The weighted price index lost 95.06 points, or 1.26 percent, to close at 7,429.61 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Apple Daily: Irresponsible DPP
DOC.DATELINE: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 02/03/10 10:59:08 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: has been clamoring for the executive branch to give a report on the cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) before signing it.

Now that the executive branch has agreed to come to the legislature to report on the trade pact, why does the DPP refuse to attend? The refusal only highlights the DPP's irrational attitude of opposing for the sake of opposing.
Refusing to listen to the briefing is an act of irresponsibility toward voters and an abdication of the DPP's responsibility as an opposition party to monitor the government.
We hope all DPP lawmakers will attend and listen to the report on the ECFA and raise questions to let everyone see the party's quality and standards. (Feb. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cries foul over unfair cross-strait flight arrangements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 11:12:03 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's transportation minister has cried foul over China's unfair treatment of Taiwanese carriers in allocating additional cross-Taiwan Strait flights during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday.

"China has not treated our carriers fairly in allotting additional cross- strait flights during the Lunar New Year holiday. Chinese carriers are allowed to operate far more extra flights than Taiwanese airline companies, " Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Tuesday.
Taiwanese and Chinese carriers will operate a total of 350 additional flights during the Feb. 13-21 Lunar New Year holiday.
Of the amount, 252 flights have been allocated to Chinese carriers, while the remaining 98 were allocated to Taiwanese carriers.
"The more-than-two-fold gap is very regrettable and extremely unfair to our carriers," Mao said.
The imbalance resulted from a different approach by the two saides to carrier applications for extra flights, airline sources said.

While Taiwan's authorities agreed to Chinese carriers' applications for extra flights as long as they complied with local regulations, the sources said, China rejected a number of requests by Taiwanese carriers on technical grounds, brandishing the excuse that its flight routes were overcrowded.
An indignant Mao described Beijing's action as a "technical contradiction" in its flight allotment.

Even more ugly and outrageous, Mao said, is that many of the additional flights allocated to Taiwanese carriers will land or take off at around midnight or in the early hours of the morning in popular destinations such as Beijing and Shanghai.

This year's Lunar New Year festival is the first since the two sides opened regularly scheduled non-stop flight services, and Mao said this year's experience should serve as a new starting point for future cross-strait negotiations.
"Similar unfair treatment for Taiwanese carriers should never happen again, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC briefing legislature on cross-strait ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb.3 (CNA) 02/03/10 11:24:55 (By Chang Ming-kun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan has begun briefing a group of influential legislators on progress in talks with China on a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Before appearing before the legislators Wednesday, Lai told reporters that the briefing exemplifies the executive branch's commitment to keep the legislature well informed on the ECFA negotiations and to accept its supervision.

The briefing is being chaired by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and attended by legislative caucus whips of the ruling Kuomintang and its allied Non-Partisan Solidarity Union and conveners of various legislative committees.
No opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers attended the meeting because the DPP caucus said the briefing was being held outside the formal legislative system.
The first round of cross-strait ECFA talks took place in Beijing Jan.26.

The MAC and other relevant government agencies have promised to give regular reports on progress in ECFA talks ahead of the fifth high-level round of talks between Taiwan and China in May or June, which is expected to focus on the trade deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 11:33:57 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$31.994 at 9:30 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.066 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Stable Taiwan-U.S. ties good for cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: The United States' recent announcement that it will sell US$6.4 billion worth of arms to Taiwan highlights a continued stable relation between the two countries.
But the arms sale, which has excluded submarines and F-16 C/D fighters requested by Taiwan, fell far short of expectations.

The deal will represent 69 percent of Taiwan's defense budget this year. As stunning as that may seem, the weaponry has been in discussions for years and the U.S. should have approved the package earlier without delaying it for six months, a never-seen-before phenomenon.
Arms sales have been a key indicator of the stability of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

The fact that approval for this latest package of arms has been delayed for so long seems to send a sort of warning signal, with some asking if this will be the last and the largest arms sale by the United States to Taiwan.

Such worries are not entirely unwarranted. The U.S. is willing to sell defensive weaponry to Taiwan not because of the law, or the Taiwan Relations Act signed after it broke diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan, but its firm political commitment to Taiwan's freedom.

The strength of such a commitment will hinge on whether the strategic interests of Taiwan and the United States are identical and on the impact of China's emergence. Past U.S. administrations have tried to maintain the balance, and if the Obama administration attaches greater importance to the latter than the former, then the Ma administration will have to be cautious.

Politically, the arms sale will involve the three parties of the U.S. , China and Taiwan. But the issue belongs to a dispute that should be put aside. That is, if the arms sale could not be solved in a short time, why not put it aside?
Militarily, Beijing's worries that Taiwan will "use force to reject unification," or "maintain the status quo forever" are also unwarranted.

The United States has never sold offensive arms to Taiwan, and Taiwan could only maintain minimum defense. Taiwan's military has also begun a transformation with the emergence of non-conventional security issues, epitomized by its C-130 transport plane carrying relief goods to quake-stricken Haiti recently.

The U.S.-Taiwan arms sale will be the cornerstone of a stable bilateral relationship. With the warmer cross-strait relations, arms sales could be adjusted based on Taiwan's defense needs and the transformation of its military, but it should never end because of threats.
Past experience has shown that without stable Taiwan-U.S. relations, there will be no stable cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Blind man riding a blind horse

TEXT.P: As the elected president of Taiwan, Ma Ying-jeou must specify his position and which side he has taken in the ongoing bickering between China and the United States. This is an issue that concerns the security and well-being of Taiwan's 23 million people.

Despite its brilliant economic performance, China is in fact one of the gaggle led by Japan in the "flying geese" model for Asia's economic development. It is China's 1.3 billion population that gives the false impression that it is a huge economy.
Unfortunately, this false impression has confused the international community and some people have even proposed the idea of a G2, which would put China on an equal footing with the United States.

Among those who have indulged themselves in this serious illusion is Ma, who believes that China is the savior of the world's economy and the hero of his administration. Ma has therefore been leaning heavily toward China, paying no attention to Taiwan's allies, including the United States and Japan.

Worldwide, both developed and developing countries are on the alert against China's threats. The Ma administration alone is like a blind man riding a blind horse, who cannot see the traps all over the place and is still rushing forward frantically. The security and property of Taiwan's people are thus hanging by a thread. (Feb. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Luxury home tax could push up property prices
DOC.DATELINE: 02/03/10 12:11:45 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government has decided to increase property taxes on upscale residential properties in 2011. The plan, designed to promote tax fairness, has sparked widespread debate and could lead to further fluctuations in property prices.

Real estate brokers believe the so-called "luxury home tax" will not dampen the market for luxury housing units but rather push prices higher because the tax will endorse the targeted properties as brand names synonymous with luxury, on a par with such brands as Hermes or Lamborghini.
In Taipei City, over 11,000 housing units will be subject to 120-280 percent hikes in property taxes.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issues:
Economic Daily News:
The luxury home tax will trigger a "price tag effect, " said DTZ Taiwan general manager Billy Yen on Feb. 2.

Yen described the planned tax hike as akin to "government certification" of upscale properties, and he anticipated that this endorsement would prove attractive to some buyers and actually help push prices of the "certified" housing units higher.
He predicted the price of some luxury residential properties will increase by 20 percent.
United Daily News:

Land Bank of Taiwan Chairman Wang Yao-shing expressed support for the move to impose a luxury home tax, saying that while it only represents a drop in the bucket to wealthy people, it could increase the state's revenues.
However, Chao Teng-hsiung, chairman of the Taipei-based Far Glory Group, argued that raising taxes on luxury properties might have violated the principle of tax fairness.

Factors such as the building's structure, its location, and the floor the home is on have already been taken into account in assessing property values under the existing property tax system, Chao said.

Only if wealthy people purchase property in Taiwan will the country's economic development benefit, he argued. Chao said it was not good for the government to solicit inflows of overseas funds while taking measures to frustrate wealthy people from investing in the country.
China Times:
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin defined upscale residential properties as "properties that the public commonly defines as luxury."
According to a city government survey, 269 buildings with 11,177 housing units will fall into the category of luxury housing units.
According to preliminary estimates, the city will collect more than NT$300 million in revenues annually after the tax is imposed on July 1, 2011.
Commercial Times:

Foreign brokerage houses said the tax increase will still be lower than the properties' monthly management fees. At the same time, however, the prices of the luxury housing units could rise by 20 percent because the tax would be a form of brand endorsement, they believed.

Meanwhile, scholars described the luxury home tax as a "fake issue, " a measure they felt would not stem short-term property profiteering. They suggested that the government impose a true capital gains tax on real estate.

Yang Song-ling, dean of National Cheng Chi University's College of Social Sciences, said the Taipei City government's tax measure would do nothing but increase the cost of owning property over the long term.

But to those buying and then selling housing units valued at over NT$100 million within a year or two and making a profit of at least NT$10 million, a tax increase of NT$20,000 would mean nothing, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- ECFA briefing stirs controversy

TEXT.P: The executive branch will brief the legislature Wednesday on the first round of talks with China on a proposed bilateral economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
It will mark the first time that senior officials responsible for the issue have briefed the legislature on progress on the controversial deal that has yet to win a consensus in society.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang and Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan will lead a group of working-level officials in giving the briefing at a meeting chaired by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issues:
Liberty Times:

In response to criticism of the lack of transparency in the government's handling of cross-Taiwan Strait engagements, senior officials will brief lawmakers Wednesday on the first round of cross-strait ECFA talks held in Beijing Jan. 26.

Only lawmakers from the ruling Kuomintang and its allied Non-Partisan Solidarity Union will attend. The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday it will boycott the event because it is being held "outside the legislative system."
KMT legislative whip Lin Hung-chih said the DPP's boycott could not be justified, as listening to the briefing will help lawmakers better grasp the process behind negotiations on the trade accord.

Moreover, Lin added, the administration has not rejected legislative supervision within the legislature's system since the MAC has agreed to give regular reports on ECFA talks to the legislature's economics and internal administration committees.

On the DPP proposal that the legislature set up a special panel to oversee cross-strait engagements and treaty talks, Speaker Wang said he already conveyed the message to President Ma Ying-jeou. Ma did not express his own opinion but said instead that the KMT legislative caucus should further discuss such a proposal.
The caucus vetoed the proposal on the ground that the legislature already has an effective mechanism to supervise cross-strait engagements and did not need to create redundant bodies. (Feb. 3, 2010)
United Daily News:
Former Vice President Annette Lu will interview President Ma Ying-jeou Thursday in her capacity as Formosa Media Co. founder.
Lu said Tuesday her interview will focus on a range of topics, including cross- strait relations, national defense, and diplomatic, financial, economic and social issues.

On cross-strait relations, Lu said, the government should forge a national consensus first. Regrettably, she complained, the Ma administration has often struck deals or signed accords with China before informing the legislature. (Feb. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Where to send the tickets?

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih took the initiative to investigate public grievances last year, but there is still a clear and present one -- traffic tickets that are sent to one's registered address, which might not be the offender's actual address.
There is a dateline to meet for paying fines, but if the ticket is sent to an address that makes it difficult to pay, then the administrative measure is obviously deviating from its original intent.

The relevant government agencies have shirked their responsibility, making what should be a simple issue very sticky. The root of the problem lies in the executive branch's mentality of "maintaining the status quo, " which is after all the least risky option.

If the premier is serious about addressing this public grievance, he can start by making sure the tickets are sent to people who have clearly registered their present address. In the case of those who have not registered clearly, then the tickets should be sent to both the registered place and the present address.

The government should never think that ensuring convenience for people is a favor for them. On the contrary, it is a way to prove that it has the ability to govern and create better lives for the people. (Feb. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Commerce Dept should move soon on SOGO case

TEXT.P: Share prices of the Far Eastern Department Store plunged over 20 percent in one week over fears among investors that it may lose the ownership of one of its subsidiaries, the Pacific SOGO Department Store.

The uncertainty on the ownership of SOGO arose from a ruling by the High Court recently that the Far Eastern forged the conference records of both its share holders and board of directors in capital replenishment by which Far Eastern was able to become owner of SOGO in 2002.

Based on the ruling, the Prosecutors Office of the High Court asked the MOEA's Commerce Department to nullify Far Eastern's official replenishment registration -- a move that will make Far Eastern's acquisition of SOGO void.

The Commerce Department, however, has not taken any immediate action on the case, saying more considerations are needed since the ruling is not final after Far Eastern appealed the case to the higher court.

The controversy highlights the role of the Commerce Department in approving business registrations based on a documental rather than substantial screening process, leading to its failure to prevent those disqualified corporations from completing registration.

To prevent the SOGO ownership dispute from hanging in the balance for too long, the department should move soon to conduct a substantial screening and to decide whether to drop Far Eastern's registration, so as to help maintain share market stability and boost investors' confidence.

For the long term, the Commerce Department should consider requiring accountants of companies to improve their screening accuracy before giving endorsements, and introduce change in the system to stop businesses from resorting to means of forgery to defraud the government agencies and investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young diplomats from Taiwan pose questions to U.S. officials
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/10 13:28:20 (By Zep Hu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A group of high school students who are elected to be young diplomats of Taiwan, and are on a visit to Washington D.C., asked U.S. officials they met many questions, including about U.S.-Taiwan relations, Taiwan's Representative Office in the United States said Tuesday.

It was the first time young Taiwanese diplomats visited the capital city since Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) launched the annual program eight years ago to select high school students who can speak English fluently to join its diplomats training camp.

The 2009 camp is made up of 16 students from four high schools, who have been traveling in the United States since last week. The tour has taken the youngsters to New York and Philadelphia before they arrived in Washington D.C. earlier this week, according to the office.

The group has visited U.S. officials, U.S.-based representatives of the American Institute in Taiwan, and local high school students during their stay in the city, according to the group leader James Chang, deputy dorector-general of the MOFA Department of Information and Cultural Affairs.

Praising the students' performance, Chang said the young diplomats had raised many questions about issues concerning traffic and unemployment during their meeting with U.S. officials, whom he noted sometimes appeared not quite able to cope with the students' sharp questions.
The students had also asked about Taiwan-U.S. ties and beef disputes in the conference with AIT representatives, he added.
Some students said the trip to New York and Washington D. C. enabled them to better understand the United States, and that the contact with foreign officials raised their self-confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Industry upgrade or migration

TEXT.P: An increase in operating costs and a shortage of migrant workers are the two biggest challenges facing many enterprises in China's coastal areas ahead of the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.

The migrant worker shortage is a problem that has lingered for some time. In early 2009, many companies in China hit by the global financial crisis were forced to scale back spending, and laid off a great number of workers from rural areas, most of whom had no choice but to return to their hometowns.

However, following a surge in exports amid a gradual economic recovery in the second half of 2009, companies tried to recall their laid-off workers, only to find that the demand for such workers far outstripped the supply.

The problem is especially serious in the Yangtze River Delta area of Guangzhou Province and the Pearl River Delta region around Nanjing, two of the main areas in which Taiwanese businesses have invested.

Even though some enterprises are offering financial incentives such as pay hikes, bonuses and fringe benefits to lure employees, it apparently does not help much, mainly because most laid-off workers are unwilling to take the risk of leaving their hometowns after suffering their previous setbacks.

In addition, job opportunities in some inland Chinese provinces have been increasing because of the launch of various economic stimulus projects in the provinces over the past two years, which has also dampened local residents' interest in working in urban areas.
As the Chinese New Year approaches, companies in coastal areas are worried that many of their employees will not return to work after the holiday, making the worker shortage even worse.
In addition, after various parts of Jiangsu Province announced a minimum wage increase from Feb. 1, other cities in the country are also mulling increasing their minimum wages.
Wage hikes would put businesses under tremendous pressure because of higher personnel costs and could undermine their competitiveness. However, they could help ease the labor shortage.
Another wave of industry migration could also be triggered, either because of factory closures as a result of the labor shortage or business failures due to higher operating costs.

The migration could be characterized by the move of industries from the high- cost Yangtze Delta and Pearl River Delta regions to Southeast Asia and inland Chinese provinces, where land and personnel costs are low and there is an abundant supply of cheap labor.
Aside from migration, companies have been given another choice in the face of the challenges -- transform and upgrade in order to survive.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC to step up communication with public on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:01:59 (By Chang Ming-kun, Chou Yung-chieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government will step up its communication with the public on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in an effort to assuage misgivings about the trade pact, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Wednesday.

Three categories of individuals will be targeted -- residents in central and southern Taiwan, those from low- and middle-income households, and owners of small- and medium-sized businesses, Lai said while briefing legislators on the progress of the ECFA talks with China.

She said the MAC will send officials on campus visits to discuss the issue with students, using "the language of young people" and will also explain the policy to the public using clear, easily understood language.

According to Lai, the Cabinet has arranged a series of briefing sessions on the ECFA issue for various legislative committees and will also report to the legislative speaker and the legislative caucuses of the various political parties.
"This is aimed at showing the executive branch's sincerity in communicating with the legislature and accepting its supervision. We hope the public will see our hard work," she said.

Lai said it remains the government's goal to have the deal sealed during the fifth round of talks between the leaders of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) slated to take place at some point in the first half of this year.

To pave the way for the signing of the agreement, the two sides held the first round of formal negotiations Jan. 26 in Beijing, in which they discussed issues such as the title and basic structure of the agreement and the establishment of a consulting mechanism.

The two sides agreed that the pact will cover the liberalization of the trade of goods and services, rules of origin, an early harvest list, trade remedies and dispute arbitration, as well as investment and economic cooperation.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said the date for the second round of talks has not been decided upon, but added that they will not take place before the Chinese New Year holiday in mid-February.

According to Lin Hung-chih, a whip of the ruling Kuomintang's legislative caucus, between February and June, the MAC and the Ministry of Economic Affairs will deliver a total of 10 reports to the Legislative Yuan, including five to be given in joint committee meetings.
After the pact is signed, the document will be required to pass a legislative review before it can be put into force, Lin said.

The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which did not attend Wednesday's briefing, demanded that a cross-Taiwan Strait affairs panel be set up under the Legislative Yuan to monitor the signing of the ECFA.

Lee Chun-yee, a DPP caucus whip, said his caucus did not receive an invitation from the MAC to attend the briefing, although it was invited by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to take part as an "auditor."
"This was an insult to the DPP caucus, so it rejected the non-institutional, informal report that lacks any legal grounding, " he said.
Unless the Cabinet submits its ECFA impact assessment report to the legislature, legislators will have no way to monitor the matter, he argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green energy production value to hit NT$1.15 trillion by 2015
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:10:17 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: With the government' s efforts to develop green forms of energy, Taiwan's production value in the sector is forecast to have hit NT$1.15 trillion (around US$35.9 billion) by 2015, an official in charge of energy affairs said Wednesday.

Speaking at a Taipei seminar on the era of low carbon emissions, Wang Yun-ming, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that "green investment" now dominates the economic development agendas of many countries.

He cited statistics compiled by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation as saying that the U.S. government has set aside US$67.7 billion in its economic stimulus measures for developing clean and green energy, while the European Union has committed 105 billion euros by 2013, South Korea has earmarked 50 trillion won over the next four years, and Japan has decided to make available 100 trillion yen by 2015.
Taiwan for its part will focus on solar power, LED lighting, wind power, bio- energy, fuel cells, energy information communication technology and electric vehicles.

By that time, Wang went on, with its backbone industries having shifted to areas featuring low carbon emissions and high added value, Taiwan will be one of the leading countries in terms of new energy technology development and production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sports council vows to turn Taiwan into 'sports island'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:11:33 (By Liu Mei-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) will spend NT$1.6 billion (US$50 million) this year on a program aimed at building Taiwan into a sports island, the country's top sports administrator said Wednesday.
SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the program will help finance construction of sports or exercise centers in cities and counties around Taiwan to encourage local residents to exercise regularly.
The council also intends to invest NT$4 billion over the next four years to build new cycling trails in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan. Tai said.

"The trails will connect with 17 road networks around Taiwan to form two round- the-island cycling trails -- one a 1,022-kilometer coastal path and another a 907-km mountain trail, " explained Tai, who said the new trails would give local cycling enthusiasts a wide variety of options.

With the Asian Games coming up in November, the council is actively helping athletes prepare for the event, but it has also launched a medium- and long-term incubation program to nurture Taiwan's outstanding athletes of the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice Premier: FocusTaiwan connects Taiwan with the world
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:24:05 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Wednesday that the newly launched English Web site FocusTaiwan (focustaiwan.tw) of Taiwan's news wire, the Central News Agency, can help the international community gain a better understanding of Taiwan.

Speaking at the FocusTaiwan launching party at the CNA headquarters in Taipei, Chu said that while the 86-year-old CNA has reported on major news events and kept a record of the history of the Republic of China over the past decades, the news agency's English language news service has served as a voice of the nation to the world.

The vice premier pointed out the significance of FocusTaiwan as an English news platform to provide real time, objective and detailed reports which enable English language readers around the world to know more about Taiwan and the issues and events happening here.

The editorial abstracts and Talk of the Day are features of the service that the vice premier found very useful to inform international readers of the different opinions over issues and events in Taiwan, as reflected in its media.
He also said that he was impressed to find that he can read CNA news stories and view CNA photos on his mobile phone.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA celebrates launch of new English-language Web site
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:25:04 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 guests representing foreign missions in Taipei, as well as international and domestic media and government officials attended a launch party for CNA's new English-language Web site, FocusTaiwan (focustaiwan.tw).

Welcoming the guests, CNA President Chen Shen-ching said CNA is offering news services for the Internet age. While FocusTaiwan provides real-time English- language news reports, mobile phone news services in Chinese and English started Feb. 1, with video news soon available online and for mobile phones.

Addressing the occasion, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said that while the 86 -year-old CNA has reported on major news events and has recorded the history of the Republic of China over the decades, the agency's English-language news serves as the voice of the nation to the world.

Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Chairman Wang Chi-kang said in his speech that like economic and trade personnel, journalists play the roles of pioneers on the international frontier.

In today's era of globalization, Taiwan's contributions should be made known to the world, Wang said, adding that TAITRA and CNA should work together to promote the country's integration with the world.

Features of FocusTaiwan include Talk of the Day, a roundup of various newspaper reportage on the events of the day, editorial abstracts from six of Taiwan's major newspapers, Forum, which presents views on issues of concern, and Who's Who, which offers background information on the newsmakers.
Presenting Taiwan's many faces through real-time, objective and in-depth reports in English, FocusTaiwan hopes to function as the prime English-language news resource in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for lithium battery development increased
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:45:26 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government has increased its annual budget for assisting research and development institutes in the development of lithium fuel cells as part of efforts to promote the development of the electric vehicle industry.
The budget was increased from last year's NT$120 million (US$3.75 million) to NT$160 million this year, Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Wednesday.
Electric automobiles carry high price tags because of the expensive batteries they require and this has become a major factor in the low popularity of green vehicles.
According to the CEPD, the cost of the batteries alone accounts for nearly 50 percent of the cost of making an electric car.
Last year, Japan introduced fuel cell-leasing services in an attempt to reduce the cost to the public of electric vehicles, the CEPD said, adding that local businesses could adopt a similar model.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close higher on rebound
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 15:54:23 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed 1.59 percent higher Wednesday on a rebound led by semiconductor issues.
A strong rebound in the U.S. stock market helped Taiwan's shares reverse the decline of the three previous trading days, when the benchmark weighted index fell nearly 265 points, analysts said.
The Taiex rose 118.37 points Wednesday to finish at 7,547.98. The local bourse opened at 7,523.79 and fluctuated between a high of 7,550.82 and a low of 7,441.92.
A total of 3.15 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$91.5 billion (US$2.86 billion).
All eight major stock categories gained ground, with electronics and machinery issues the biggest gainers, rising by 2.2 percent.
Textile issues rose by 1.8 percent, bank and financial stocks by 1.4 percent, and foostuff issues by 0.9 percent.
Cement shares gained 0.7 percent, plastic and chemical stocks 0.5 percent, paper and pulp stocks 0.3 percent, and construction issues 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,796 to 1,183, with 269 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of shares for the ninth consecutive session, selling NT$2.27 billion more in shares than they bought.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel restrictions on Chinese tourists to be further eased
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Jan. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 18:11:37 (By Jian Chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Travel agents on Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu will be allowed from May to apply online for travel permits on behalf of Chinese tour groups who want to visit the two islands via direct ferry services across the Taiwan Strait, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Wednesday.

Chinese tourists who have already visited Taiwan over the past five years and who want to visit Kinmen and Matsu as part of a tour group of between five and 40 members can apply online for travel permits through Tourism Bureau-sanctioned travel agencies on the two islands.
The applicants will not be required to provide documents or photos and the travel agencies will not need to deliver application forms to the prospective travelers.
The review procedure will take just a single day, which means travel agents can obtain the permits the day after they register the applications through the NIA's Web site.
Chinese travelers can also visit Penghu -- another of Taiwan's outlying island groups -- via Kinmen or Matsu using the online permits, according to the NIA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five groups from Taiwan to perform at French art festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 18:17:02 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Five performance groups from Taiwan, including prominent dance and theater companies, will give performances at the Festival D'avignon Off 2010 in French southeast city D'avignon in July, the Council for Cultural Affairs said Wednesday.

According to a CCA official, the groups are the Ten Drum Art Percussion; the Scarecrow Contemporary Dance Company; the Riverbed Theatre Company; the YIlab, a contemporary dance troupe as well as the Playbox Ensemble, a theatrical company.
The official said that this is the fourth year in row for the CCA to select and support prominent Taiwanese performance groups to show their works in the international event.
Festival D'avignon Off is one of the leading art festivals in the world. In 2008, more than 800 groups from different countries performed in the festival, attracting about 700,000 audience members.
Held annually, the festival this year will last for three weeks and will feature performance groups from around the world.
The CCA indicated that they had chosen five groups from among 32 which applied, which will present their works at the theatre La Condition Des Soies.
The performances will showcase the vigorous and creative power of Taiwan's performers, the CCA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 18:47:24 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, shedding NT$0.060 to close at NT$32.00.
A total of US$757 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.060 and fluctuated between NT$31.960 and NT$32.060.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific student leadership seminar to be held in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 18:54:58 (By Amy Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Exchange and Leadership Development Seminar is being held by the world's largest student-run organization, AIESEC, to provide a platform for students to share their thoughts and sharpen their competitiveness, according to Yao Hui-ju, a journalism student at Taipei-based Chinese Culture University.
This year's event will focus on the theme "leadership in action," according to the organizers.

In addition to AIESEC members from 15 Asia-Pacific countries, participants in the conference will also include students from Croatia, the United Kingdom, Russia, Germany and the United States, Yao said.

Lin Wan-ching, a finance student at National Taiwan University, said the issues to be discussed in the conference will include entrepreneurship, global leadership, climate change, green technology, changes in labor flows and sustainable development, and will show the attention that students attach to global issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady sentenced to nine months in prison
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 19:03:11 (By Laid Yup-chai and Elizabeth Hu)

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen was sentenced Wednesday to nine months in prison for abetting false testimony by her family members.
In the High Court case, Wu's son Chen Chih-chung, her daughter Chen Hsing-yu and son-in-law Chao Chien-ming each received a three-month sentence for giving false testimony on Wu's instruction.
In addition, former chairwoman of the Taipei 101 tower, Diana Chen, was sentenced to eight months in jail for her involvement in the same case.

Wu was found guilty of prompting her son, her daughter, son-in-law to tell the court that the invoices Wu used to claim reimbursements from a special state affairs fund during her husband's presidential term were from the first family's spending for shopping and entertainment.
Wu and her husband, former President Chen Shui-bian, were convicted last year for embezzlement of the state affairs fund.
It was found that Wu had collected invoices from her family members and used them to claim the reimbursements from the Presidential Office special state affairs fund.
It was also later determined that she coached her children to tell investigators the invoices were from "public affairs spending."
In the ruling against Diana Chen, it was found that in April 2009 she gave court testimony that conflicted with her statements during the investigation of the former president and his wife.

In the District Court trial of the case last September, Wu was sentenced to one year in jail, while her son, daughter and son-in-law were each given six months, and Diana Chen received an 18-month sentence.
In response to the High Court ruling, Chen Chih-chung said although they were all given lighter sentences, the punishment was still "too heavy."
Chen Sui-bian, who has been in custody since Dec. 30, 2008, and his wife have been given life sentences on charges of embezzlement of the state affairs fund, money laundering and corruption.
They have both denied the charges and appealed their sentences.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets with Control Yuan members over MRT Neihu Line
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 19:13:51 (By Wen Kui-hsiang, Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou defended his decision to make the Taipei MRT's Neihu Line a medium-capacity system when questioned Tuesday by Control Yuan members investigating alleged irregularities in the planning and construction of the line.

Four members of the Control Yuan, the nation's leading monitor of the government, visited the Presidential Office as part of its investigation to question Ma, who served as Taipei mayor when the Neihu Line was planned and when construction began.
Ger Yeong-kuang, the leader of Control Yuan's investigation, said the group's focus was "mainly on the decision-making process of the construction of the line."
On why he decided to make the Neihu Line a medium-capacity system, Ma said an assessment at the time suggested that a medium-capacity system was more workable.

Also, the then central government controlled by the Democratic Progressive Party government did not support a large-capacity system and would not have helped the Taipei city government finance a larger-scale project, Ma said.
Moreover, the city council and public opinion were both in favor of a medium- capacity system, Ger cited Ma as saying.

According to Ger, the president also defended his decision by saying that because there were so many pipelines under Neihu, the line might not have opened last year if a large-capacity underground system had been selected.

On why the project's electrical and mechanical work was tied to the civil engineering tender, Ma said it was based on concerns that German engineering giant Siemens would have monopolized the bidding and forced the city to pay more than its budget could afford.

A local construction company, Kung Sing Engineering Corp., won the civil engineering bid for the MRT's Neihu section and selected Canada-based Bombardier to be responsible for the electrical and mechanical part of the system.
The Neihu Line was designed to link up with the former Muzha Line, which was built by French contractor Matra Co. in the 1990s.
But because of compatibility problems between the Matra and Bombardier systems, the line suffered repeated glitches after opening last July, leading to questions over its design and quality.

Control Yuan member Hung Chao-nan asked Ma if he would be willing to share responsibility for the problems since the line was built in part during Ma's term before being inaugurated under his successor, Hau Lung-bin.
Ma answered that "if there is responsibility to take, I'm willing to shoulder it," according to Hung.
Ger said the meeting shed light on the controversy and that the investigation would conclude at the earliest before Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 14 this year.
Ger said investigation officers did not accompany the Control Yuan members to the Presidential Office to avoid giving the impression that the president was "under investigation."

But the DPP criticized the encounter, contending that the Control Yuan should have first determined if it has the right to investigate Ma for possible negligence occurring before he served as the president.

If such a right exists, they should have had investigators accompany them, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said. If they do not have such a right, they should not be allowed to investigate the case until after the president steps down"
"They should by no means close the case rashly," Tsai said.
The right to impeach a president belongs to the legislature, and whether the Control Yuan members have the right to investigate the president is a gray area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may allow voters more flexibility on where to vote
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 19:21:31 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese voters may be allowed to vote at the constituencies where they work rather than where their legal residences are registered in the year-end elections for heads of five special municipalities, a senior official said Wednesday.

"If necessary revisions to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law and relevant preparatory work can be completed in time, we will not rule out the possibility of introducing transfer voting in the year-end mayoral elections, " said Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-hua at a news conference.

The move could have an impact on the results of the elections as many people, especially young people, do not work or live in the same cities where they are registered to live. In previous elections, voters have had to take trains, buses or planes to go back to the city of their legal residence to cast their vote.

Also according to Jiang, the Ministry of the Interior has been studying the feasibility of enacting absentee voting to provide a means for eligible voters to participate in upcoming elections even though they may not be able to go to the polls on election day.
Absentee voting can be implemented in several variations or options, including vote-by-mail or postal voting, proxy voting, voting in advance and transfer voting.

After discussing with the Central Election Commission, however, Jiang said the ministry has tentatively decided to first introduce transfer voting, which will allow eligible voters to vote in the constituencies where they work instead of the constituencies where their legal residencies are registered.

"We are scheduled to come up with a draft package of amendments to the election and recall law for legislative screening during its new session to pave the way for enacting transfer voting for the convenience of our voters," Jiang said.

The ministry originally planned to introduce transfer voting in the next presidential election in 2012, but if legal revisions and preparatory work can be completed in time, the new voting option may be launched in the year-end elections for mayors of the country's five special municipalities, Jiang explained.
"If necessary legal amendments and preparations cannot be finalized in time, the new system will be put into practice in the next presidential election," Jiang added.

As the year-end elections will only be held in five municipalities -- Taipei City, Taipei County, combined Taichung City and County, Tainan City and County, and Kaohsiung City and County -- many other cities and counties will have to set up polling stations if the transfer voting is indeed adopted.
"Although such a measure may increase cost, we will work to the best of our ability to overcome all obstacles to protect our people's voting right," Jiang said.

The year-end elections are being seen as a key indicator of the popularity of President Ma Ying-jeou and his party -- the ruling Kuomintang -- as well as a gauge of whether Ma might win a second term in the 2012 presidential race.
Overseas Taiwanese, however, will still have to fly home to vote, as transfer voting will be restricted to voters working in Taiwan and will not be applied to those staying abroad, Jiang said.
Jiang admitted that the study about transfer voting has not been finalized.

"Our major goal now is to come up with a comprehensive raft of amendments this year," Jiang said, adding that the U.S.-style postal voting by absentee ballots may be adopted one day when security and confidentiality can be ensured.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA celebrates launch of new English-language Web site (Update)

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 guests representing foreign missions in Taipei, as well as international and domestic media and government officials attended a launch party Wednesday for CNA's new English-language Web site, Focus Taiwan (focustaiwan.tw).
Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office, said that since the establishment of the CNA, the foreign community has always relied on it as a truly dependable source of information.

"It is precisely due to this reason that a Web site like Focus Taiwan will play such an essential role for us," Ledoux said, adding that the news agency's effort is "testimony to Taiwan's freedom of speech."
"The function of a Taiwan editorials abstract is extremely valuable as it gives an insight of Taiwanese opinion makers, " Ledoux noted, referring to a new section on the Web site.

Welcoming the guests, CNA President Chen Shen-ching said the agency is offering news services for the Internet age. Focus Taiwan provides real-time English- language news reports, while mobile phone news services in Chinese and English started Feb. 1, and video news will soon be available online and for mobile phones.

Addressing the occasion, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said that while the 86 -year-old CNA has reported on major news events and has recorded the history of the Republic of China over the decades, the agency's English-language news serves as the voice of the nation to the world.

Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Chairman Wang Chi-kang said in his speech that like economic and trade personnel, journalists play the roles of pioneers on the international frontier.

In today's era of globalization, Taiwan's contributions should be made known to the world, Wang said, adding that TAITRA and CNA should work together to promote the country's integration with the world.

The features of Focus Taiwan include Talk of the Day, a roundup of various newspaper reportage on the events of the day; editorial abstracts from six of Taiwan's major newspapers; Forum, which presents views on issues of concern; and Who's Who, which offers background information on the newsmakers.
Presenting Taiwan's many faces through real-time, objective and in-depth reports in English, Focus Taiwan hopes to function as the prime English-language news resource in Taiwan.
In Ledoux' words, CNA's new package of service provides easy access to news stories and more communication options in a time "when we are sometimes lost in identifying what information is relevant."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT must win upcoming legislative by-elections: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 20:03:17 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Legislative by-elections for four seats to be held Feb. 27 are so crucial for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) that the party is under tremendous pressure to win, President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, said Wednesday.
In a morale-booster at a KMT meeting for the party's candidates in the by- elections in four counties, Ma called on all party members to strive for victory in the upcoming battle.

Ma said that since the KMT came to power, it has encountered numerous challenges and that as success in the by-elections is so vitally important to make up for the party's setback in Jan. 9 by-elections, everyone in the party should do their parts to drum up support for the KMT candidates.

During the meeting, Ma also presented party flags to all four candidates -- Chen Shueh-sheng for Taoyuan County, Cheng Yung-tang for Hsinchu County, Lin Teh-jui for Chiayi County and Wang Ting-sheng for Hualien County.
Chen described the by-elections as a crucial point in the party's efforts to move from defeat to victory, adding that "I have to win."
Cheng for his part said he hoped to secure a victory in Hsinchu County by integrating various local factions.

Proposing a new vision for Chiayi County, meanwhile, Lin vowed to break former Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen's political monopoly because after serving out his term as magistrate, he will also be eyeing a legislative seat.

Vowing to seek more budget for construction of the controversial Suhua highway if elected, Wang urged voters "not to be fooled" by opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Hsiao Bi-khim, who has promised to cut train ticket prices by half for county residents instead of going ahead with the new road.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait links make Taiwan more attractive to foreign investors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 20:14:12 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As cross-Taiwan Strait travel has become more convenient, several international corporations have expressed interest in investing in Taiwan, and in particular the American wholesale chain Costco is planning a NT$30 billion investment, according to an official of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Director of the commission Ning Chia-yu said recently that Costco plans to set up an Asian-Pacific regional distribution center near Taoyuan International Airport, in addition to its business expansion plan in the Taiwan market.

Since the first Costco warehouse was opened in Kaohsiung in 1997, the American company has established five more warehouses in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung. Its latest NT$30 billion investment plan includes the establishment of another 20 warehouses around the island.

Ning said that direct cross-strait transportation has also boosted interest among overseas Taiwanese businessmen to make investments in Taiwan. In 2009, overseas Taiwanese investments amounted to NT$36.2 billion, compared to the total of NT$20.4 billion in 2008, and NT$14.1 billion in 2007. The Investment Commission projected an 8% growth this year, to NT$38 billion.

Ning said that as the government is ready to further loosen the restrictions on investments by mainland Chinese, the Investment Commission plans to organize an investment promotion mission to China in April, targeting leading Chinese businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three endemic tree species found to have high CO2 absorbency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 20:32:06 (By Chou Pin-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Three indigenous Taiwanese broadleaf tree species -- Taiwan acacia, Formosan ash and Taiwan zelkova -- have been found to be very effective in removing carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere, a researcher said Wednesday.

"In a series of studies on the subject, it was found that the Taiwan acacia has the highest CO2 absorbency of all tree varieties, " said Huang Yu-hsing, head of the Forestry Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture (COA).
The Formosan ash was second, followed by the Taiwan zelkova, Huang said.

Huang said his institute has cultivated seedlings of the three endemic tree species for forestation programs around the island to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and contribute to the fight against global warming.
Generally speaking, he added, broadleaf trees have higher carbon absorption capacity than needleleaf trees.
Compared with fossil fuel restrictions, tree planting is a far more effective and cost efficient way to cut greenhouse gas emissions, Huang said.

As Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyodo Protocol on greenhouse gas emission reduction, it cannot secure international certification for the carbon absorption of local tree-planting programs at present, Huang said.

In the future, he said, the government should formulate a comprehensive set of rules to regulate forest carbon sequestration operations. This should include the establishment of a certification mechanism to pave the way for local companies to take part in global carbon trading and offsetting, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second round of ECFA talks may be held late February: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 21:17:18 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The second round of negotiations on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will probably be held at the end of February, according to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

In a report to the Legislative Yuan, the MAC suggested that substantive issues such as the "early harvest list" -- the list of industries to be initially given tariff concessions -- will be discussed in the second round of negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
The first round of ECFA talks, held in Beijing on Jan. 26, touched only on procedural issues, including the name of the agreement, its basic structure and a mechanism for future negotiations.

The MAC will join the Ministry of Economic Affairs and other related agencies to brief Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and the various party caucuses in early March on the progress of the negotiations, the MAC indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expanding participation in global aid efforts in Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 21:35:45 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expanding its participation in the international relief efforts in earthquake-ravaged Haiti by sending an assessment team to join forces with United Nations-related organizations in the Caribbean country, a Taiwan agency said Wednesday.

The effort is also in keeping with the Taiwan government's promise to fund four aid projects in Haiti, said Lee Pai-po, deputy secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under Taiwan's foreign ministry.

"It is not easy for Taiwan to join international relief operations, as it is not a member of the United Nations, " Lee said at a press briefing. "But this time, it's very different because the United Nations has included Taiwan's relief efforts as part of its rescue system. "
Taiwan has also been invited by Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez to take part in an international meeting in mid-April to exchange views on long- term aid to Haiti.
So far, the Taiwan government and private sector have provided a total of US$13 million in aid to Haiti.
A Taiwan mission, led by ICDF Secretary-General Tao Wen-lung and other officials, will depart Thursday for Haiti to carry out the assessment, according to an ICDF statement.
The team will focus on public health, the settlement of victims, vocational training and orphan adoption, the statement said.
Meanwhile, the third medical team from Taiwan will leave Friday for Haiti on a two week mission.
Jeffrey Chen, head of the 15-member medical team, said that when the rainy season begins in Haiti in March it "will make the rescue work much more difficult."
"By then, the safety of drinking water will be a top concern as the drainage system is poor," he added.
"This will also make it difficult to control contagious diseases at a time when resources are lacking," the doctor said.
He called for donations of medical gauze, saying there is plenty of room in 10 of the 60 pieces of luggage his team is carrying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan NGOs voice support for Chinese dissidents
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 21:46:59 (By Chen Hung-chin & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Representatives of several non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in Taiwan voiced support Wednesday for dissidents in China who have suffered as a result of suppression by Chinese authorities.

The representatives of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights and the Taipei Bar Association, said at a press conference that many Chinese human rights activities have been followed, jailed and have even gone missing.
They urged that Taiwan, while engaging China economically, also promote concepts of democracy and human rights in China and push for the release of jailed Chinese dissenters.

Lawyer Kao Yung-cheng said that Kao Zhisheng, a Chinese lawyer who has handled a number of sensitive religious cases, was arrested and tortured, and his whereabouts have remained unknown since February last year.

He noted that Liu Xiaobo, a prominent opinion leader in China, was sentenced to 11 years in prison late last year for co-authoring "Charter 08, " which calls for an end to Communist Party rule and the implementation of constitutional democracy in China.
Exiled Chinese dissident Yang Jianli, who was also at the press conference, called on President Ma Ying-jeou to use the "universal language" of freedom and democracy in Taiwan's exchanges with China.
Yang called on Beijing to better protect human rights and to stop suppressing activists.
The representatives jointly tied yellow ribbons on a map of China to express their wish for the quick release of jailed Chinese dissidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan diplomats urge prompt release of detained fishermen
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/10 23:16:49 (By Mike Chang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Taiwan representative office in Yakohama urged Japanese authorities Wednesday to release the captain of a Taiwanese fishing boat that was seized as it was entering Japan waters earlier in the day.

Ke Ching-kuo, captain of the Yilan-registered fishing vessel the Chuansheng No. 36, was brought to Yakohama for questioning after his fishing boat was seized by Japanese marine patrol personnel for allegedly crossing a temporary marine boundary between Taiwan and Japan in waters near the Iwo Jiwa islands, 1,200 km south of Tokyo.
The Taiwan officials, who visited Ke soon after his arrival in the city, said that he was in relatively good shape but needed medicine for his diabetes.
Japanese officials said the Taiwanese boat was intercepted and seized after it refused to be checked by the Japan coast guard.
The 98-ton Chuansheng No. 36 left its base in Suao, Yilan, northeastern Taiwan, on Nov. 23 last year.
The fishing boat and its crew of 10 Indonesians were detained in the Bonin Isands, 1.000 km south the Japanese capital.
