DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday Feb. 4, or the 21st day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Official quits over surcharge controversy
DOC.DATELINE: 02/04/10 12:11:05 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of highway transportation and relevant affairs quit Wednesday over an NT$8 surcharge controversy.

Lin Chih-ming, head of the Directorate General of Highways under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), offered to resign, saying in the written statement that he had not properly managed a proposal to increase the service charge for the collection of motor vehicle fuel tax at convenience stores.

Lin's resignation was accepted by MOTC Minister Mao Chi-kuo the same day. Premier Wu Den-yih was said to be "very upset" the previous day over the MOTC plan that would have raised the fuel tax service charge at convenience stores from NT$8 to NT$15 per vehicle.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issues:
United Daily News:

Premier Wu Den-yih was reportedly very upset about the proposed NT$8 service charge increase. He said officials should empathize more with ordinary consumers, and officials who turn a deaf ear to the people's outcry are not fit to hold their positions.

It is not known whether it was Wu's remarks that prompted Lin to step down, but following the premier's statement, Transportation Minister Mao Chi-kuo on Wednesday nixed the plan for the service charge hike.
The merits of the proposed increase were indeed debatable, but allowing the top highway official to step down simply because of an NT$8 surcharge controversy seems to be a disproportionate response.
Mao said he was accepting Lin's resignation with a heavy heart.
Lin was awarded two major merits by the MOTC last year for his part in the government's rescue, relief and reconstruction work in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

Lin, a graduate of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) , said at the time that when he was engrossed in the post-typhoon work, he had not even stopped to see his mother while he was on the road in Wanluan township in Pingtung County near where she lives.
China Times:
One day after the MOTC responded to Premier Wu's comments and defused the surcharge hike controversy by dropping the plan, the top highway official resigned.
While approving Lin's resignation, Minister Mao said he respects Lin's decision to quit and referred to him as a "gentleman."
Mao said Premier Wu attaches great importance to the people's feelings and had asked for a prompt resolution of the controversy over the proposed price hike plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taipei Game Show to open Friday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 12:16:00 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei Game Show will open Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 62 game developers and distributors presenting hundreds of new games at 450 booths.
On of big events at the five-day show will be the Intel Extreme Masters Asian contest, which will feature such exciting games as "Counter- Strike 1.6," "World of Warcraft," and "Quake Live."
The competitions are expected to draw large crowds, mostly young fans, as students are on winter vacation, the longest break in the academic year.

According to the organizer the Taiwan Computer Association, the Taipei Game Show, which is now in its 18th year, has become a springboard for the Asia- Pacific digital content industry to explore the tremendous potential of the Chinese market.

With 57.5 percent of Taiwan households having access to the Internet and 72.1 percent of them using broadband connectivity, the Taiwan environment is suitable for further development of the game industry, the association said.

Digital content development has become the focus of many university and college programs in Taiwan, and this year, 18 college departments and institutes will display the creative works of their students at the exhibition, according to the organizer.
The exhibition will run from Feb. 5-9 and will be open daily from 10 a.m.to 6 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Ma bashing becomes pop culture

TEXT.P: Bashing President Ma Ying-jeou seems to have become a fad in Taiwan society. That's because he holds power and sits in a high position. Criticizing him probably gives people a kind of false gratification.

Ma's detractors like most to bash him as being timid and lacking guts. Pro- independence activists slammed him for his refusal to meet with the Dalai Lama in Taiwan last year for fear of offending China, while pro-unification proponents criticized him for failing to take bold enough steps to move Taiwan closer to China. Beijing is also dissatisfied with Ma's reluctance to take strong action against pro-independence advocacy.

Semiconductor business tycoon Robert Tsao mentioned in a recent speech that many people have taken Ma to task for what they call his lack of courage and resolve. Tsao expressed the view that a stiff backbone is the most important attribute in corporate manpower because a timid and spineless person tends to lack vision and superior judgement.

However, a democratically elected president should demonstrate his courage and boldness only within the realms of his power, and should not flex his muscles to abuse his position. In a democratic country, every citizen has his own personal rights that should not be infringed upon by national leaders or agencies. (Feb. 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA Air outfitted to help promote Taipei flora expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 14:38:10 (By Sun Chen-wu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, Taiwan's second largest air carrier by revenue, is scheduled to launch a fleet of four passenger planes with floral themed cabins Friday to help promote the Taipei International Flora Expo (TIFE) 2010.

The Taipei City government has designated EVA Air as the official carrier for the TIFE, which will run from Nov. 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011. The airline said the four planes will take each off from a different Asian city Friday to launch the TIFE promotion drive.
The four Asian cities will be selected later Thursday from among Nanjing, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Osaka, Fukuoka, Seoul and Bangkok.

EVA Air has outfitted with floral themes four of its Airbus 330-200s that fly shorter-haul and regional routes. More than 40 items, including place mats, cups and head-rest covers, have been imprinted with flora expo images, the Taipei City Department of Economic Development (DED) said Thursday.
The airline is also featuring expo images on its luggage tags and boarding passes, which can be kept by passengers as collectors' items.
In addition, EVA Airways said, it will also offer special fares and airfreight rates for visitors to the expo and for participating exhibitors.

A ceremony to launch the expo theme on EVA flights is scheduled to be held at the airline's hangar near Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport later Thursday, with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin officiating.

Children from an orphanage run by the non-profit Taiwan Fund for Children and Families will be invited to board one of the theme flights and will be treated to a "TIFE inflight dinner, " DED officials said.
According to the DED, as of January, 99 organizations and groups from 68 cities in 37 countries had registered to take part in the 2010 Taipei flora expo as exhibitors.
EVA serves a worldwide network of major business and leisure destinations in Asia, Oceania, Europe and North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day---Far East's control of SOGO now in question

TEXT.P: In the latest twist in the fight for control of SOGO Department Store, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Feb. 3 invalidated a 2002 decision by Pacific Logistics Co. Ltd., which controls SOGO, to allow the Far East Department Store to invest in the company. The MOEA's move brings into question the Far East Group's control of SOGO's Taiwan stores.
Following are excerpts of local media coverage of the issue: The Liberty Times:

The MOEA's decision was in line with a 2009 judgment by the Taiwan High Court which found that Far East's investment in SOGO was null and void. The minutes of a Pacific Logistics board meeting, which claimed that approval was given for the Far East investment, were in fact forged, the court found.
According to the court ruling, the board meeting never took place. The Far East executive who forged the minutes was sentenced to two months in jail. (Feb. 4, 2010) China Times:

By revoking the legitimacy of the Pacific Logistics' minutes, the MOEA has set the stage for a rematch between the Far East group and SOGO's founder Pacific Construction Co., Ltd. for control of SOGO.

It also reinstates Lee Heng-lung, chairman of Pacific Logistics in 2002, as the logistics' head and thereby gives him a deciding role in the battle between Pacific Construction and the Far East group.

This senario seems unfair to the Far East group, as it has funnelled more than NT$4 billion into SOGO through Pacific Logistics in the last eight years, while Lee holds only NT$6 million worth of shares.

Pacific Construction, which is the founder of Pacific Logistics, said it would ask the court to appoint a caretaker for SOGO rather than hand control to Lee Heng-lung who, according to Pacific Construction, acquired control of Pacific Logistics by fraudulent means. (Feb. 4, 2010) United Daily News:

Lee Heng-lung rebutted Pacific Construction's claims, and argued that the dispute is between him and the Far East Group and has nothing to do with Pacific Construction, which he said would never get back SOGO.
Meanwhile the Far East group said it would appeal to the MOEA to reverse its decision and will ask that any action be put on hold while the appeal is being considered.

The group said in a written statement that the dispute surrounding SOGO is very complicated and has given rise to many lawsuits. The ministry should not interfere with the matter and let the court settle all related cases.
An MOEA official said the ministry has only invalidated the Pacific Logistics board meeting minutes and is in no position to decide who should control SOGO.
This means the Far East group's NT$4 billion investment in Pacific Logistic will be converted into loans, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free trade talks with Japan new year's goal: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 15:37:42 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he hopes Taiwan and Japan can start negotiations on signing a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) this year, while continuing to promote their strategic partnership.

"Taiwan and Japan maintain very close economic relations, so both will benefit greatly if they can sign a bilateral FTA," Ma said while meeting with the new Japanese representative to Taiwan, Tadashi Imai, at the Presidential Office.
Japan is Taiwan's second-largest trade partner, while Taiwan is Japan's fourth- largest trade partner, according to government statistics.

After designating 2009 as the year in which Taiwan was supposed to have forged a special strategic relationship with Japan, Ma said, his administration will continue to boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation in various fields this year.
"In addition, we hope to start discussions with Japan on the feasibility of striking an FTA that will bring good fortune and well-being to our business community and ordinary people," said Ma.

The 2010 work agenda also includes preparations for opening direct flight services between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport in October, as well as the promotion of an exhibition in Japan of ancient Chinese art treasures from the National Palace Museum in Taipei, he went on.
Touching on Taiwan's diplomatic policy, Ma said his administration's main goal is to pursue peace and balanced development.
"We believe our efforts to improve relations with China are conducive to Japan, South Korea and other East Asian countries, " he said.

Under his "modus vivendi" policy toward China, Ma continued, relations across the Taiwan Strait have improved greatly since his inauguration in May 2008, while his flexible diplomatic approach has also allowed the two sides of the strait to respect each other and avoid their previous controversial tug-of-war to lure away each other's diplomatic allies.
While working to improve cross-strait ties, Ma said, Taiwan has also spared no efforts to strengthen relations with Japan, the United States, the European Union and Southeast Asian countries.
On East Asian security, Ma said Taiwan attaches great importance to the continuity of the Japan-U.S. Security Treaty, describing it as a cornerstone for regional security and stability.

According to the president, Taiwan has never overlooked its security relations with the U.S., and he hailed a recent U.S. decision to sell Taiwan a package of weapons as a further guarantee of Taiwan's security.
"Taiwan will be more willing to improve relations with China when our people feel safe and confident in our country's defense ability," Ma told Imai.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Advice to health minister --think before you speak
DOC.DATELINE: 02/04/10 15:52:03 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang announced last week that National Health Insurance premiums will be raised, only to have the information denied by the premier.
It was not the first time that Yaung said health premiums were to be raised. However, his proposal has never been discussed in the Cabinet, let alone approved.
Yaung's plans for a premium hike have been shelved mainly because they were made too close to election time and the ruling party did not want the issue to become an election albatross.
However, our focus is on the minister's plan to raise premium rates rather than broaden the base for calculating payments, to include total personal income instead of just wages.

Raising premium rates seems to be an easy way out of the health insurance program's financial problems, but as the ruling Kuomintang controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, it can easily pass a bill to broaden the premium calculation base.

We fully agree with the premier that the health ministry should try every possible means to address the program's financial problems before resorting to an increase in premiums. For example, computerization of patients' case histories would help save costs.

It is only natural to want to raise premiums when a health insurance program is in the red, but Yaung needs to convince the public of the need for the increase, explain fully why that particular option is being chosen, and obtain approval for his proposal through the legal process.
As he has not taken his premium increase proposal through that process, Minister Yaung should be more contemplative and thorough in the execution of his duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves Animal Protection Law amendment draft
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 16:03:19 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved a draft amendment to the Animal Protection Law Thursday to regulate pet food products and product suppliers.
The amended draft states that manufacturers, processors and importers of pet food products must register the products they produce or handle with the central government.

Producing, processing, packaging, wholesaling, selling, importing, exporting, giving, or attempting to sell or display pet foods tainted with excess levels of pathogens or substances detrimental to health will be prohibited, according to the draft.

Those found manufacturing, processing, importing or selling such products who fail to recall, destroy, or properly dispose of the products will face fines of between NT$50,000 (US$1,560) and NT$250,000 and will have their names, store names or photos published.
Those who provide product labels, promotional literature, or advertising that are untrue, exaggerated or cause misunderstandings will face fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000.
City and county governments will be allowed to carry out spot checks and random inspections of pet food products and to demand that pet food sellers provide proof of the safety of their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-U.S. Major leaguers impressed with Taiwan's youth baseball
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 16:26:52 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Major League baseball stars Barry Larkin and Joseph Logan said Thursday they were impressed with the development of youth baseball in Taiwan and they encouraged young players to work hard on the fundamentals of the game and "dream big."

Larkin and Logan are visiting Taiwan as part of the Sports Envoy Program co- sponsored by the U.S. Department of State and the American Institute in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

The pair have been coaching high school players in various clinics in northern Taiwan over the past three days, and are now in the south of the country. Larkin, a former All-Star shortstop, focused on infielders' training, while Logan coached pitchers.
At a press conference held midway through the week-long tour, Logan praised the enthusiasm of Taiwan players and the "above-average velocity and potential" of the young players.

Larkin said one of his surprises was that while young players in the U.S are not receiving enough training and attention due to the economic downturn, this is not the case in Taiwan. He said he has seen "a lot of voluntarism, hard work and attention from coaches, who have been doing a phenomenal job."

A legitimate candidate for the Hall of Fame, Larkin was one of the rare players in the modern era who stayed with the same team throughout his entire career, starring at shortstop for the Cincinnati Reds from 1986 to 2004.
He was a key member of the Reds' 1990 World Series championship team and was named the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1995. He also earned three gold gloves and was a 12-time All-Star.

Citing his own history as an example of persistence, Larkin said when he was a boy his feet were turned inward and had to be treated by doctors. However, his love of the game, dedication to baseball and perseverance helped him to reach Major League stardom, he said.

He said he was very happy that after he told his life story to youngsters in the clinics to inspire them, the number who said they wanted to someday play in the Major League rose from "maybe one or two to almost 120."

The Cincinnati native declined to comment on a game-fixing scandal that has rocked Taiwanese professional baseball, but he urged Taiwan baseballers to "do what's right" and resist temptation because "regardless of what you do, you have to look at yourself in the mirror every day."
He also paid respect to all those foreigners, including players from Taiwan, who chase their dreams of playing in the Major League.
There are many barriers and obstacles to the dream of playing in the U.S., including language, a different culture and different skill levels, he said.
"You have to be a special talent, a special person, and then the skills, work ethic... all of these are important" to get into the Major League, which is "an elite class," Larkins said.

Larkin finished his career with 2340 hits, 441 doubles, 198 home runs and 960 runs batted in. He had only one season in which he made more than 20 errors. He is considered to be a legitimate Hall of Fame candidate.
Logan pitched in the Montreal Expos organization between 1989 and 1991.
Larkin and Logan will travel to Kaohsiung and Pintung where they will hold more clinics before concluding their Feb. 2-6 visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close slightly lower on consolidation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 16:35:18 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed slightly lower Thursday on consolidation.
The Taiex shed 5.94 points, or 0.08 percent Thursday to finish at 7, 542.04. The local bourse opened at 7,563.19 and fluctuated between a high of 7,578.18 and a low of 7,504.96.
A total of 2.81 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$ 79.4 billion (US$2.48 billion).
Most major stock categories lost ground or remained unchanged, with textile issues the biggest losers, falling by 0.6 percent.
Foodstuff issues lost by 0.4 percent, bank and financial stocks by 0.3 percent, and electronics and machinery issues by 0.2 percent.
Cement shares, paper and pulp stocks, and construction issues kept flat; while only plastic and chemical stocks rose by 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,434 to 1,324, with 373 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of shares for the tenth consecutive session, selling NT$7.23 billion more in shares than they bought.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese cagers might be allowed to play in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 16:45:58 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Sports Affairs Council will draft an amendment of the law governing the issuance of work permits to Chinese athletes, in response to suggestions from legislators that Chinese basketball players should be allowed to join Taiwan's semi- professional basketball teams and play in Super Basketball League (SBL) contests.
Now entering its seventh season, the SBL boasts seven teams -- Bank of Taiwan, Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor, Dacin Tigers, Pure Youth, Taiwan Beer, Taiwan Mobile Clouded Leopards and Yulon Luxgen.
Legislators Ting Shou-chung and Chang Hsien-yao called a meeting at the Legislative Yuan Thursday to make the request.

Vice Sports Minister Tseng Tsan-pao pointed out that under existing laws and regulations, Chinese referees and coaches can apply to visit Taiwan to attend conferences, while Chinese athletes can attend only non-profit sports activities. The duration of stay is from two months to four months.
In order to join Taiwanese semi-professional teams, Chinese basketball players would need to apply for work permits, Tseng said, adding that the authorities must also work out tax issues.

Beginning this year, all SBL teams are allowed to hire foreign players. An immigration official who attended the meeting suggested that the authorities take into consideration a possible crowding-out effect upon foreign recruits, as well as Taiwanese players, should Chinese players be permitted to play.

The legislators suggested that the seven SBL teams should prepare a report on the possible impact of opening to Chinese players and that the Sports Affairs Council should complete a law amendment draft within a month, while the Mainland Affairs Council should organize a cross-agency coordination meeting in two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Is Taiwan still a democracy?
DOC.DATELINE: 02/04/10 16:49:42 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In a contest organized by the U.S. State Department, the winner, a Chinese political dissent, characterized democracy as a gradually improving game in which an independent identity and organization seeks to optimize its interests through transparent means other than violence.
By this definition, many people question whether Taiwan under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou is still a democracy.
The people of Taiwan have long forsaken violent means, but the ruling Kuomintang resorted to violence to push through a revision of the Local Government Act in the legislature recently.

The transparency of policy-making is ignored by Ma's administration, which kept secret the content of its proposed trade pact with China and refused to send it to the legislature for approval after it was wrapped up.
Furthermore, the wealth gap is widening under Ma's administration, owing to Ma's policy of seeking detente with China, which benefits the country's giant companies at the cost of the little man.
Under the governance of Ma's administration, Taiwan is regressing in both democracy and economy. When they dip to the levels of China, it will be time for Beijing to annex Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet denies premier's role in official's resignation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 16:57:00 (By Lee Ming-tsung, Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Executive Yuan denied Thursday that Premier Wu Den-yih played a role in the resignation of Taiwan's top official in charge of highways over an NT$8 surcharge controversy.

Su Jun-pin said Wu made some remarks two days earlier in which he urged civil servants to empathize more with ordinary consumers, but did not "hint" or "imply" that anyone in the government should step down, nor did he offer suggestions on any specific personnel reshuffle.

Lin Chih-ming, head of the Directorate General of Highways under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), offered to resign Wednesday, saying in a written statement that he failed to properly manage a proposal to increase service charges for the collection of motor vehicle fuel tax at convenience stores.

Lin's resignation was accepted by Transport Minister Mao Chi-kuo that same day. Premier Wu Den-yih was said to be "very upset" over the MOTC proposal, which would have raised the fuel tax service charge at convenience stores from NT$7 to NT$15 per vehicle.
A local daily reported that Lin resigned after the premier "hinted" that he should quit over the proposal.
The spokesman further said that Wu said Tuesday that the people's dissatisfaction with the government will mount even further should problems that have existed for decades remain unaddressed.

Those problems include motorists often failing to receive traffic tickets or fuel tax notifications because the tickets and notifications are mailed to motorists' household registration address rather than to the address they currently live at, Su said.

Wu was reported to have been very angry about the proposed NT$8 service charge increase and to have said that officials who turn a deaf ear to the people's outrage are not fit to hold their positions.
It was unclear whether it was Wu's remarks that prompted Lin to step down, but following the premier's statement, Mao nixed the plan for the service charge hike and signed Lin's resignation letter.
Mao referred to Lin as a "gentleman" and said he accepted Lin's resignation with a heavy heart.

Lin sent an open letter Thursday to his colleagues at the Directorate General of Highways in which he offered his heartfelt appreciation to them for their unwavering devotion to work aimed at making Taiwan a better place in which to travel and live.

He exhorted his former colleagues to work hard on a string of reconstruction projects still requiring completion, including 50 old bridges that need to be rebuilt within two years, the integration and computerization of all motor vehicle service and management units, and a review and overhaul of the safety of tour buses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Side-effect scare slows down demand for self-paid vaccines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 17:18:03 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The demand for various self-paid childhood vaccines has slowed down in Taiwan amid reports of severe side effects allegedly linked to the influenza A(H1N1) vaccine, a pediatrician said Thursday.

According to Lee Ping-ying from National Taiwan University Hospital, fewer children are receiving self-paid vaccines such as the rotavirus vaccine and pneumococcal vaccine due to the public's hysterical reaction to those reports.
Other government-funded vaccination programs for children, however, have not been affected, Lee said.

Officials of pharmaceutical firms said that parents are hesitant about their children having the shots because of the many reports about needle phobia and limb weakness allegedly related to the H1N1 vaccine.
Also, many parents are terrified by reports that the thimerosal contained in most vaccines can cause autism, they said.

Shih Wen-yih, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) , said the incidents have had little impact on the existing government-funded childhood vaccination against hepatitis and the three-in-one vaccination against measles, mumps and rubella.

From March 1, the CDC will provide children with free five-in-one shots against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio and Haemophilus influenzae type b disease, replacing the existing polio drops and three-in-one shots that cover only diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, Shih said.
Noting that the five-in-one vaccine produces significantly fewer side effects than the traditional three-in-one vaccine, Shih predicted that the new program will not face many barriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Pitching for `One China, different meanings'
DOC.DATELINE: 02/04/10 17:22:07 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: There are four scenarios for the future of Taiwan and China -- Taiwan independence, maintaining the status quo, uniting under a union or confederacy and united together.
All of them have to be based on the so-called "1992 consensus" that there is only one China, with each side of the Taiwan Strait free to interpret the meaning of "one China" as they see fit.

Taiwan independence is hardly a viable option for Taiwan, as was shown by former President Chen Shui-bian, who did not seek permanent separation from China during his eight-year term, despite his support for Taiwan independence.
He concealed his cause for independence in the guise of the Republic of China, and used that cause only in his domestic political struggle.

As to maintaining the status quo, that means maintaining the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China, both of which have the standpoint that there is only one China, although they disagree on whether one is a part of the other and whether Taiwanese are Chinese, so this option has to be based on the differing interpretations of what "China" is.
Wang Daohan, the late chief of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, said in 1997 that "one China" is an idea under development that is neither China nor Taiwan.
What he meant was a China under the umbrella of a confederacy or union, which would also entail the prerequisite of acknowledging "one China" with different interpretations.
This shows whatever political option Taiwan prefers, it has to be based on "one China" with different interpretations. (Feb. 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 17:29:16 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, up NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.020.
A total of US$684 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.100 and fluctuated between NT$31.940 and NT$32.100.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: No jobs, no votes

TEXT.P: After one year in power, U.S. President Barack Obama's approval rating has fallen to a nadir and his Democratic Party has lost a series of critical elections, including the special election for the U.S. Senate seat of the late Ted Kennedy.

Similar scenarios have occurred in Taiwan, with President Ma Ying-jeou's approval rating standing at a record low and the ruling Kuomintang having endured one election setback after another since its return to power in 2008.

Their plights should not be attributed to the volatility of voters but rather to the poor economic situation. Society tends to be volatile and unstable when the number of unemployed increases sharply and the incomes of middle-class families drop substantially.

To address the economic woes, the Obama administration has decided to spend US$100 billion to rev up the U.S. economy and create jobs. Similarly, Taiwan's government has also come up with various job creation programs, with the aim of creating more than 100,000 jobs.

However, such programs tend to offer only temporary or short-term jobs rather than solve unemployment problems caused by changes in the local economic or industrial structures. Joblessness will increase again when the emergency programs come to an end.

To fundamentally resolve the problems, the government should make job creation its top policy goal. In the past, the government has offered tax and financial incentives to encourage R&D. In the future, the government should enact laws to encourage the creation of jobs.

For instance, the government should include job creation in the proposed statute on the promotion of industrial innovation as a criteria for tax exemption and other financial benefits. Only by so doing can the unemployment issue be resolved. (Feb. 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Draft bill to impose travel ban on people owing huge customs fees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 17:56:00 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a draft amendment to the Customs Tariff Law Thursday, which seeks to impose a travel ban on individuals who owe customs tariffs or penalties in excess of NT$1 million.
According to the draft amendment, executives of companies or organizations that owe the customs more than NT$2 million will also be banned from traveling abroad.

In cases where an appeal is lodged with financial authorities against the tariff evasion penalty, the ban will be retained while the case is being reviewed, the draft amendment states. However, in such cases, it will only apply to individuals who owe the customs more than NT$1.5 million and executives of a company that owes more than NT$3 million, the bill states.
The travel restriction will be imposed for a maximum of five years, starting from the date that the immigration office records the ban, the draft bill specifies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trend Micro eyes big pie of cloud computing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 18:09:36 (By Anita Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Trend Micro Inc., a global leader in network antivirus and Internet content security software and services, announced Thursday that it has established an affiliated firm to put itself "in the clouds, " as 2010 is forecast to be "the Year of Cloud Computing."

Trend Micro founder and chairman Steve Chang said at a news conference that the affiliated firm, PCloud Computing, is aiming at putting forth its self-developed cloud computing operating system software in the second quarter of this year.
"Compared to Microsoft, Amazon or Google, Taiwan has started relatively late in terms of cloud computing," said Chang.

Noting that Trend Micro has been developing cloud computing technology and relevant knowledge for the last four years, Chang said the purpose of PCloud Computing's founding is to create an open platform for cloud computing and consolidate the power of the global open-source communities to offer users more choice.

Describing PCloud Computing as a driving force behind the development of cloud computing technology, Chang said the new company will offer technical assistance, training courses and consultation services to potential users.

Meanwhile, Jenny Chen, executive cultural officer of Trend Micro, announced that her company will collaborate with National Taiwan University (NTU) to offer a cloud computing curriculum to NTU students.

Trend Micro will initially invest NT$50 million (US$1.56 million) for the cloud computing talent-nurturing project, which will also include a Trend cloud computing lab to be manned by 10 lecturers from Trend Micro and 52 from NTU, according to Chen.

Chen quoted International Data Corporation (IDC) , a Massachusetts-based market research and analysis firm specializing in information technology, telecommunications and consumer technology, as predicting that global investment in cloud computing and relevant technology will top US$42 billion by 2012, up from US$16 billion in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT think tank denies proposing opening up to Chinese farm produce
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 18:18:09 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang think tank denied Thursday that it has proposed expanding a trade agreement with China to include imports of Chinese agricultural products into Taiwan.

The Liberty Times reported Thursday that the KMT's National Policy Foundation (NPF) recently published a research paper on the feasibility of expanding the imports of Chinese farm produce, although President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yi have many times promised not to open Taiwan up to Chinese agricultural products.
The trade agreement would lead to a lifting or reduction in tariffs for imports from China and vice versa.

In rebutting the report, NPF President Tsai Cheng-wen said the research was written by an assistant researcher in the think tank's research area of economy and technology and reflected the researcher's personal views.
"It was a small article posted on NPF's Web site and reflects her personal opinion, " Tsai added.
The Web site carries many articles posted by its assistant researchers and consultants, all of which reflect their personal views and were by no means proposals by the NPF, according to Tsai.

If the think tank wants to express its opinion, it will make its articles public, rather than posting them on the Web site, Tsai said, lambasting the newspaper for linking personal opinion to the think tank.
Wu Hui-ping, author of the paper, also issued a statement Thursday saying the article represents merely her personal research report rather than the think tank's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former legislator gets two years in dual citizenship case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 18:25:49 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former ruling party Legislator Lee Ching-an was sentenced by the Taipei District Court to two years imprisonment Thursday after being convicted of fraud in connection to her dual citizenship status.

Lee was indicted Sept. 16, 2009 for concealing her dual citizenship status and defrauding public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009.
Taiwan's Nationality Act requires those holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office.
Although Lee had held public office in Taiwan for so many years, it was not until March 2008 that she was found to have never relinquished her U.S. citizenship.

She resigned from her latest legislative post amid mounting public pressure in January 2009, after the U.S. authorities, in response to Taiwan's inquiry, confirmed in late 2008 that she still held U.S. citizenship.
Lee said through her lawyer Thursday that she deeply regretted the ruling and that she will definitely appeal it.
Lee said she was sorry for the controversy triggered by her dual citizenship case, but stressed that she never had the intention to defraud the state coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Threats lurk in global economic recovery

TEXT.P: Both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have confirmed recently that the global economy has recovered from its worst slump since the end of World War II.

However, the two organizations have warned that many worries and threats lurk in this faster-than-expected recovery and they have urged countries around the world to continue working hand-in-hand to avert the recurrence of an economic recession.

Among the worries is the slow progress of job creation in advanced countries, most of which are still burdened by high unemployment rates, high budget deficits and public debts. The current fragile recovery is not expected to resolve all these issues, while any slips could trigger more serious problems.

Meanwhile, developing countries, particularly those in Asia, face the threats of economic overheating and the bursting of property bubbles due to hot money inflows and fast expansion of domestic demand.
According to the World Bank report, China has shown signs of a property bubble and its government has taken measures in response.
As the economic growth in advanced countries still largely relies on their governments' stimulus measures, the IMF report has advised those countries not to stop their emergency measures too soon.
The World Bank report even warned that if private demand cannot grow swiftly enough to replace government-sponsored stimulus measures, the threat of a double-dip recession cannot be ruled out.
More worrisome is that the global trade volume cannot rebound to the pre- recession level until 2012 after last year's steep contraction, according to both reports.

Shrinking global trade volume poses a challenge to Taiwan's export-driven economy. With China -- the country's largest trade partner -- showing signs of a property bubble and facing ever-rising inflationary pressure, Taiwan's government should take precautions to ensure steady growth of the local economy. (Feb. 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan warned of assets bubble
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 18:33:46 (By C. F. Kao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: In view of a rapid surge in property values in the Taipei area, Taiwan should adopt measures to fend off an assets bubble, according to a senior analyst with Fitch Ratings.

Jonathan Lee, senior director of Fitch Rating's Financial Institution Group and lead analyst for Taiwanese financial institution products, raised the suggestion in a report titled "Assets Bubble in Asia?" issued Thursday.

Lee called for great attention to be paid by the government sector given that the housing value in Taipei City increased 20 percent last year alone. Since 2003, after the outbreak of SARS, property values in Taiwan's largest city has grown by a compound annual growth rate of 11 percent due to an oversupply of capital as a result of low interest rates, he noted.

The phenomenon has also trickled into second-tier cities in neighboring Taipei County such as Banciao, Hsinchuan and Tucheng, he added. Fueled by incentives from a government urban renewal program, prices of second-hand houses have also increased markedly to a point that puts them beyond the reach of salaried workers, he added.

To ease the people's misery index for buying houses, several Asian countries have taken action to cool off the overheated housing market, including China, which has imposed a real estate transaction tax and is planning to build affordable public housing, according to Lee.

The Hong Kong government has also since last year reduced the amount of bank loans to 60 percent for house buyers, while the South Korean government has slashed its bank loan rate to 50 percent for real estate buyers and investors.

Lee warned that a U-turn will take place in the property and real estate market and that financial institutions' operations and Taiwan's economic growth will be hobbled if the central bank decides to increase key interest rates in an attempt to contain the bubble.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese aboriginal singers perform at Bangkok music festival
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 19:39:41 (By Lin Ching-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two aboriginal musicians from Taiwan have been enchanting Thai audiences with their marvelous singing.

Yun Li-su of the Atayal tribe and Lu Chieh-hsing of the Puyuma tribe joined Japanese guitarist Ken Ohtake in a performance Wednesday at the Rhythm Of the Earth World Music Festival in Bangkok, winning resounding acclaim from locals and foreign tourists alike.
With her clear, resonant voice, Yun immediately became the focus of the concert held at the plaza in front of the Central World department store.

Todd Lavelle, the organizer of the music festival that is now in its fifth year, said Yun's voice epitomizes the wonder of Taiwan's myriad mountain deities. Her lyrical performances echoed the festival's theme of celebrating ethnic diversity and borderlessness, as well as supporting minority voices, he added.
Lu followed Yun performances with passionate readings of tribal love ballads, which drew enthusiastic responses from the audience.
At Lavelle's invitation, Lu also performed Atayal folk songs on the jaw harp and bamboo flute, while Yun presented tribal dances.

Huang Hung-tuan, the wife of Taiwan's representative to Thailand, attended the concert and provided an English introduction to the jaw harp, which is made of bamboo and hemp string and is the oldest musical instrument of Taiwan's indigenous people.
Eleven other bands and ensembles from the United States, Israel, Kenya and South Korea are also taking part in the event, which will run until Feb. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA helping TIMC obtain private capital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:04:28 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is assisting the Taiwan Innovation Memory Co. (TIMC) in obtaining private capital, as government investment in the company has been forbidden by the legislature, Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.
However, the ministry is not playing a dominating role in the matter, since TIMC is a private company, Shih added.
According to MOEA officials, TIMC needs capital of NT$11 billion in the initial stage, 55 percent of which has already been raised.
As far as the remaining 45 percent is concerned, the MOEA has been helping to introduce TIMC to potential investors such as financial holding companies, the officials said.
TIMC was established in August 2009 as part of a government plan to restructure the country's DRAM industry.
However, the Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution in the last legislative session requiring that the MOEA withdraw an earlier commitment to fund the company "to prevent a waste of government funds."
The venture was originally intended to salvage the local DRAM sector, which was haemmorhaging money during the global financial crisis because of oversupply and plummeting demand.
However, doubts mounted about the need for the venture once the market began picking up again.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to compensate farmers for halting rice irrigation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:15:25 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government will provide monetary compensation for farmers who have left their rice paddies fallow to save water due to a looming drought, the Council of Agriculture's Agriculture and Food Agency said Thursday.
Farmers who halted irrigation for rice cultivation and converted their farm for growing drought-reistant green manures will be given the monetary compensation, the agency added.
The compensation will be up to NT$80,000 for each hectare of such rice fields, the agency said.
To ensure adequate water supplies for household and industrial use, rice cultivation in parts of southern Taiwan was suspended for the first harvest of this year, according to the agency.
The compensation figures were derived from the calculation of 105 percent of the average income each farming household makes from one hectare of rice paddy last year, which stood at NT$72,821.
The amount of compensation marked a significant rise from the NT$60,000 per hectare offered in 2003, when the average farming household income per hectare was at merely NT$53,661.
Farmers who leave their rice paddies fallow, but have not planted other crops will be granted NT$73,000 for each hectare of the rice field.

As for farmers who got water themselves for rice irrigation, the government will not provide monetary compensation for them, but will procure rice from them according to the stipulated price, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: More cross-strait personnel movement discussed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:34:42 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that they are studying the issues of allowing Taiwanese people to accept work in China's public agencies and of allowing Chinese basketball players to play professionally in Taiwan.

The United Daily News reported that day that China's Fujian Province plans to invest 200 million Chinese yuan (US$29.36 million) to attract overseas talent, including professionals from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao, over the next five to 10 years to work for corporations. It will also recruit Taiwanese to work in public institutions.

Responding to the report, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said that according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Taiwanese are not allowed to work for Chinese political, government or military institutions without approval from the Taiwan government.

Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Ting Shou-chung, Chang Hsien-yao and Huang Chih-hsiung discussed in a public forum the possibility of bringing Chinese players into Taiwan's professional basketball league, the Super Basketball League (SBL) to "increase cross-Taiwan Strait basketball exchanges."

Some of Taiwan's top basketball talent has opted to play in China this year, attracted by higher salaries, but Chinese players are still banned from playing in Taiwan, which has created "an imbalance between cross-strait sports exchanges," Ting said.

Liu said for his part that one of the important issues in hiring Chinese players will be how their presence and status in Taiwan is recognized, Liu said, adding that if they are classed as workers rather than "professional expertise exchange personnel, " a legislative resolution will be required.

As cross-strait relations have relaxed over the past year, more bilateral personnel exchanges and movement have been discussed or implemented, including the enrollment of Chinese students in local universities and further opening Taiwan to Chinese white-collar workers.
The recruitment of Chinese basketball players will probably squeeze out job opportunities for local players, which is why the proposal should be carefully examined, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pension fund for military personnel at stake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 21:00:34 (By S. P. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The financial situation of the state-run Pension Fund for Defense Personnel is at stake and it might go bankrupt in a few years, an official of the Ministry of Civil Service said Thursday.

The fund recorded NT$8.421 billion (US$263 million) in revenue last year, outpacing its spending of NT$6.365 billion, the official said. Although spending did not exceed revenue in 2009 as had been expected, he warned that the possibility of the fund going bankrupt by 2018 remains and predicted that a planned voluntary military service system will deal a further blow to the fund.
As of the end of December last year, the fund had to pay out NT$63.33 for every NT$100 in revenue, according to a ministry report.

Worse yet, a voluntary military service system could incite a wave of early retirements among existing career military personnel, while newly recruited personnel, after serving only three years, might have paid NT$70,000 to their retirement fund, but would receive more than NT$100,000 from the pension fund when quitting under the existing rules, the official explained.
To keep the pension fund from going broke, the government must increase its contribution rate of 12 percent to a range between 30 percent and 40 percent on the military personnel, he suggested.
Should the contribution rate for individuals be raised, the portion sustained by the government should also be hiked, which would further worsen its finances, he went on.
Over the long term, adjustments in the military's retirement system will be necessary to improve the situation, the official said.

At present, Taiwan's military personnel on average are entitled to receive retirement pay 8.29 times the total amount of money they pay into their pension funds, higher than the 5.97 times for teaching staff and the 5.43 times for government employees, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges Beijing to respect Taiwanese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 21:09:45 (By Chang Ming-kun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged China Thursday to respect the Taiwanese people, in the wake of the expulsion of a Taiwanese scholar by the Beijing authorities.

According to media reports, hearing-impaired Taiwanese physicist Cheng Yao, who was teaching at Tsing Hua University in Beijing, was accused of being impolite and speaking too loudly when applying for a visa extension recently.
As a result, he was detained for a day and ordered to leave China within one month, the reports said.

Asked about the matter in a regular press briefing, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te- hsun said the government had no opinion about whether Cheng should be granted a visa extension, as that is at the sole discretion of Beijing.
However, when processing such applications, the Beijing authorities should respect the Taiwanese applicants, he said.
Liu said he believes that Cheng, who is an expert in nanotechnology, will be able contribute to Taiwan's research in this field if he returns to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll finds low public transport usage rate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 21:58:04 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Public transport accounts for only an average of 13.4 percent of the daily commutes made by local people on work days, according to the results of a massive government survey released Thursday.
In the survey, Taipei City boasted the highest public transport usage rate among the country's cities and counties, but even there, the rate was just 34.1 percent.
Up to 72 percent of the respondents said they commute by motorcycle or car.

The poll also found that only three other administrative districts, all of them located in northern Taiwan, had a higher-than-10-percent public transport usage rate -- Keelung City at 29.4 percent, Taipei County at 24.9 percent and Taoyuan County at 11.9 percent.

Chiayi City had the lowest public transport usage rate at 2.5 percent, while the usage rates in many other areas also fell below 5 percent, such as Yunlin County at 4.8 percent, Chiayi County at 4.8 percent, Tainan City at 4.7 percent, Taitung County at 4.2 percent, Penghu County at 4.1 percent and Hualien County at 3 percent.
The survey, the first of its kind, was conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) between Oct. 6 and Dec. 18, 2009 to explore the country's daily commuting methods.

A total of 24,943 valid samples were collected in the survey, with at least 1,067 valid replies from each of the 23 cities and counties in Taiwan. The poll had a confidence level of 95 percent, with a margin of error of 0.6 percent.

According to the poll, motorcycles are the most common commuting vehicle, accounting for 49 percent. Meanwhile, 23 percent said they commute in their own cars, 7.2 percent said they walk and 5.9 percent said they travel by bicycle.
The poll also found that more women than men use public transport for the daily commute -- 17 percent compared to 9.9 percent.

The reasons given by respondents for their reluctance to use public transport were the convenience of personal private transport, the fact that public transport stations are too far away, or the destination of their daily commute is very close to the point of departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Middleman in diplomatic scandal defends himself
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:04:55 (By Kang Shih-jen and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A middleman who embezzled US$29.8 million from the Taiwanese government defended himself via video from the United States Thursday as the High Court of Singapore continued a hearing in a lawsuit brought by Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to recover the money.

The ministry is trying to recover the money that was remitted to Ching Chi-ju's account in a Singapore bank in September 2006 for the purpose of making arrangements for the opening of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Papua New Guinea.
The diplomatic relations deal fell through after the money was wired to Ching, but Ching and another middleman, Wu Shih-Tsai, refused to return the funds to Taiwan.
Wu was arrested by the Taiwanese authorities when the scandal came to light at the end of President Chen Shui-bian's second term, but Ching managed to flee to the U.S.

Speaking to the Singapore court, Ching claimed that part of the money was his remuneration for being a secret emissary for Taiwan in negotiations with Chinese officials during the years from 1995 to 2006.

He said that according to an agreement he reached with Chiou I-jen, then secretary-general of the National Security Council, only US$10 million would be used as aid for Papua New Guinea, US$10 million would be given to him and Wu for making the arrangements, and the remaining US$10 million would be his remuneration for working as a secret emissary for former presidents Lee Teng-hui and Chen.

He said that as a secret emissary, he twice helped reduce tension between Taiwan and China -- first in August 2002, when Chen's statement of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" outraged Beijing and later in 2006 when Chen again irritated Beijing with independence-leaning comments.

However, MOFA attorney Loo Chun-chao rebutted Ching's claims, saying that ministry personnel involved in the case all rebutted Ching's claims and none of the documentary evidence presented by Ching could be proved genuine.

Former Foreign Minister James Huang, who appeared in court Monday to give witness testimony, said the entire US$30 million was intended solely for pursuing full diplomatic relations with Papua New Guinea and that he was not aware of any emissary role played by Ching.

DOC.HEADLINE: IBAF president promotes baseball's return to Olympics
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:09:00 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: International Baseball Federation (IBAF) President Riccardo Fraccari, who is visiting Taiwan to promote his strategy for helping the return of baseball to the Olympics, met Thursday with Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) President Chao Shou-po to discuss the issue.
Advocating baseball's return to the Olympics has been one of Fraccari's major goals since he was elected IBAF president last December, according to the CPBL.
With baseball not scheduled as an event at the 2012 Olympics in London, the IBAF must push for the sport to be included in the 2016 Olympics in the Brazilian city of Rio de Janeiro, Fraccari said.
Seeking support from professional baseball groups in various countries is one way of achieving this goal, he went on.

Fraccari said he recently visited the Korea Baseball Organization, South Korea's professional baseball league and will visit Japanese and American professional baseball organizations in the hope of reaching a consensus on sharing resources in order to make baseball more global and help its return to the Olympics.
Fraccari, who also met that day with President Ma Ying-jeou, was scheduled to leave Taiwan Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Early harvest lists might be exchanged at next ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:14:47 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China could exchange their respective early harvest lists for the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in their next round of talks, likely to take place in late February or early March, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Thursday.
In line with the goal of getting the trade pact signed in the first half of this year, the government hopes the two sides will begin discussing substantive issues soon, the officials said.

In the first round of formal negotiations held Jan. 26 in Beijing, the two sides discussed issues such as the title and basic structure of the agreement and the establishment of a consulting mechanism.

They agreed that the pact will cover the liberalization of the trade of goods and services, rules of origin, early harvest lists, trade remedies and dispute arbitration, as well as investment and economic cooperation.

Also Thursday, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang denied media reports that steel products will be included on Taiwan's early harvest list, which will mainly cover petrochemicals, machinery and textiles, as well as automobile parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma interviewed by former vice president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:22:54 (By Garfie Li and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou met former Vice President Annette Lu Thursday for an interview with the media organization she founded.
Lu, founder of Formosa Media, described the meeting as a "national affairs dialogue, " but the Presidential Office said it was just a media interview.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said the 75-minute interview proceeded "in a good and natural atmosphere" and that the Presidential Office would release the full video footage of the interview later in the evening after obtaining approval from Formosa Media.

Lu, who served as vice president between 2000 and 20008, raised such issues as whether the "(Taiwan-China) 1992 consensus" actually exists, the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement that Taiwan is set to sign with China in the first half of this year and whether Ma is considering convening a national affairs conference.
According to Wang, Ma shunned none of the questions, although he and Lu disagreed on some of the issues, especially the "1992 consensus."
The "1992 consensus" refers to a tacit agreement that both Taiwan and China accept the "one China" principle, with respective interpretations on the definition of "one China."
It serves as the basis for the resumption of cross-strait negotiations after a nearly 10-year hiatus following Ma's assumption of the presidency in May 2008.

However, the controversy surrounding the consensus has never been resolved, as China only stresses the "one China principle", while Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang prefers the right to define the meaning of "one China." The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) holds the viewpoint that there is in fact no "1992 consensus" at all.
Wang said the Presidential Office would be happy to see a similar dialogue between Ma and DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor Hu voted no. 1 doting husband
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:32:07 (By S.C. Hau and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu was selected as the most doting husband in Taiwan in a recent Internet vote, according to the results of a survey published Thursday by Yahoo!

Yahoo! conducted the online voting Jan. 28-Feb. 3, in which Hu was voted as the most devoted husband by 7,860 visitors to the Web site, ahead of actor Lee Li- jen with 6,437 votes and Sean Lien, a celebrity, with 448 votes.
Hu said he felt a bit "depressed" after learning of his new title. "I really feel embarrassed at so frequently being a survey target by the media."
"Does this mean that I should not run in the year-end mayoral election for the new municipality (that merges Taichung City with Taichung County)?" he asked.

Pointing out that he has not yet made a final decision on whether he will run and that he had not discussed the issue with his wife, Hu said he will ponder the issue when on vacation in Britain with his wife in the middle of the month.
"I will make a final decision in late February or early March after my return from Britain, " he said, adding that "probably I will make a decision that will surprise everyone."

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics Group to invest NT$650 billion in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Jan. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:46:30 (Chao Hsiao-hui and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Petrochemical giant the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) plans to invest NT$650 billion (US$20.31 billion) in several projects this year in an attempt to boost its growth amid rising hopes of an economic revival this year, Chairman Lee Chih-tsuen of Formosa Plastics Corp., a FPG subsidiary, said Thursday.
Of the total amount, NT$280 billion will be used for the fifth phase of the group's the sixth naphtha cracking plant project, which is still under environmental assessment, according to Lee.
Another NT$280 billion will be invested in the construction of a major steel mill in Vietnam's Ha Tinh Province, for which ground breaking is expected in April, Lee added.
The group generated a combined turnover of NT$1.75 trillion last year, a decline of 19 percent from 2008.

Formosa Plastics Corp. recorded a turnover of NT$156 billion, representing a fall of 13.8 percent year-on-year due to a drop in the prices of petrochemical raw materials following the global financial crisis.

Expressing optimism over the outlook for this year, Lee said that as China's Ministry of Commerce has been promoting construction in rural areas, " sales of the group's PVC, 60 percent of which is used for construction, are expected to increase significantly this year.

The global PVC production capacity was about 4.5 million tons last year and is expected to drop to 4 million tons this year because of shortages of natural gas in the Middle East that could send the prices of PVC and polypropylene higher, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA helping TIMC obtain private capital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:04:28 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is assisting the Taiwan Innovation Memory Co. (TIMC) in obtaining private capital, as government investment in the company has been forbidden by the legislature, Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.
However, the ministry is not playing a dominating role in the matter, since TIMC is a private company, Shih added.
According to MOEA officials, TIMC needs capital of NT$11 billion in the initial stage, 55 percent of which has already been raised.
As far as the remaining 45 percent is concerned, the MOEA has been helping to introduce TIMC to potential investors such as financial holding companies, the officials said.
TIMC was established in August 2009 as part of a government plan to restructure the country's DRAM industry.
However, the Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution in the last legislative session requiring that the MOEA withdraw an earlier commitment to fund the company "to prevent a waste of government funds."
The venture was originally intended to salvage the local DRAM sector, which was haemmorhaging money during the global financial crisis because of oversupply and plummeting demand.
However, doubts mounted about the need for the venture once the market began picking up again.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to compensate farmers for halting rice irrigation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:15:25 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government will provide monetary compensation for farmers who have left their rice paddies fallow to save water due to a looming drought, the Council of Agriculture's Agriculture and Food Agency said Thursday.
Farmers who halted irrigation for rice cultivation and converted their farm for growing drought-reistant green manures will be given the monetary compensation, the agency added.
The compensation will be up to NT$80,000 for each hectare of such rice fields, the agency said.
To ensure adequate water supplies for household and industrial use, rice cultivation in parts of southern Taiwan was suspended for the first harvest of this year, according to the agency.
The compensation figures were derived from the calculation of 105 percent of the average income each farming household makes from one hectare of rice paddy last year, which stood at NT$72,821.
The amount of compensation marked a significant rise from the NT$60,000 per hectare offered in 2003, when the average farming household income per hectare was at merely NT$53,661.
Farmers who leave their rice paddies fallow, but have not planted other crops will be granted NT$73,000 for each hectare of the rice field.

As for farmers who got water themselves for rice irrigation, the government will not provide monetary compensation for them, but will procure rice from them according to the stipulated price, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: More cross-strait personnel movement discussed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 20:34:42 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that they are studying the issues of allowing Taiwanese people to accept work in China's public agencies and of allowing Chinese basketball players to play professionally in Taiwan.

The United Daily News reported that day that China's Fujian Province plans to invest 200 million Chinese yuan (US$29.36 million) to attract overseas talent, including professionals from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao, over the next five to 10 years to work for corporations. It will also recruit Taiwanese to work in public institutions.

Responding to the report, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said that according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Taiwanese are not allowed to work for Chinese political, government or military institutions without approval from the Taiwan government.

Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Ting Shou-chung, Chang Hsien-yao and Huang Chih-hsiung discussed in a public forum the possibility of bringing Chinese players into Taiwan's professional basketball league, the Super Basketball League (SBL) to "increase cross-Taiwan Strait basketball exchanges."

Some of Taiwan's top basketball talent has opted to play in China this year, attracted by higher salaries, but Chinese players are still banned from playing in Taiwan, which has created "an imbalance between cross-strait sports exchanges," Ting said.

Liu said for his part that one of the important issues in hiring Chinese players will be how their presence and status in Taiwan is recognized, Liu said, adding that if they are classed as workers rather than "professional expertise exchange personnel, " a legislative resolution will be required.

As cross-strait relations have relaxed over the past year, more bilateral personnel exchanges and movement have been discussed or implemented, including the enrollment of Chinese students in local universities and further opening Taiwan to Chinese white-collar workers.
The recruitment of Chinese basketball players will probably squeeze out job opportunities for local players, which is why the proposal should be carefully examined, Liu added.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Jan. 4 (CNA) 02/04/10 22:46:30 (Chao Hsiao-hui and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Petrochemical giant the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) plans to invest NT$650 billion (US$20.31 billion) in several projects this year in an attempt to boost its growth amid rising hopes of an economic revival this year, Chairman Lee Chih-tsuen of Formosa Plastics Corp., a FPG subsidiary, said Thursday.
Of the total amount, NT$280 billion will be used for the fifth phase of the group's the sixth naphtha cracking plant project, which is still under environmental assessment, according to Lee.
Another NT$280 billion will be invested in the construction of a major steel mill in Vietnam's Ha Tinh Province, for which ground breaking is expected in April, Lee added.
The group generated a combined turnover of NT$1.75 trillion last year, a decline of 19 percent from 2008.

Formosa Plastics Corp. recorded a turnover of NT$156 billion, representing a fall of 13.8 percent year-on-year due to a drop in the prices of petrochemical raw materials following the global financial crisis.

Expressing optimism over the outlook for this year, Lee said that as China's Ministry of Commerce has been promoting construction in rural areas, " sales of the group's PVC, 60 percent of which is used for construction, are expected to increase significantly this year.

The global PVC production capacity was about 4.5 million tons last year and is expected to drop to 4 million tons this year because of shortages of natural gas in the Middle East that could send the prices of PVC and polypropylene higher, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 5, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."
