DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-China spat would not turn uncontrollable: former premier
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/05/10 11:21:31 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington and Beijing may have given each other a hard time over a host of disputes, including arms sales to Taiwan, the Google controversy and the Dalai Lama, but such spats would not escalate to an uncontrollable, a senior adviser to President Ma Ying-jeou said here Thursday.

On the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Liu Chao-hsiuan, who is leading a Taiwan delegation to attend the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast (NPB) Feb. 3-5, said there is good news and bad news. The bad news is that the United States and China may get tougher with each other over the arms sales plan, although it still remains to be seen how that would unfold, he said.

The good news is that both Beijing and Washington have said they have no wish to see tensions mounting to an uncontrollable level and both sides have at least exercised self-restraint, said Liu, who served as Taiwan's premier from May 2008 to September 2009.
Liu, along with ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yi-shih and VIA Technologies and HTC chairwoman Cher Wang, attended the 2010 NPB in Washington, D.C. Thursday morning.
Before and after the NPB, the Taiwan delegation met with U.S. officials, members of Congress and experts from U.S. think tanks to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
On the controversy over U.S. beef exports to Taiwan, the three delegates told their U.S. hosts that the beef issue should not be dealt with emotionally, according to Liu.
In addition, they said, the decision by Taiwan's legislature to pass an amendment to ban U.S. beef offal and ground beef from entering Taiwan was in line with the people's will.
"Our explanation of the issue has been acknowledged by some of our U.S. hosts," Liu told the Central News Agency.
However, it would be reasonable to assume that the beef controversy could undermine any plans by the U.S. to grant visa free treatment to Taiwanese visitors, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Recipe for riots

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday that his ministry is studying the possibility of introducing absentee voting, and will start with a transfer system that will allow eligible voters cast their ballots in the constituencies where they work rather than in area of their household registrations.
Devising an absentee ballot system that would allow voting by Taiwan businessmen operating in China and by other Taiwanese abroad is more difficult and will require further discussions, he said.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) immediately voiced opposition to the proposal.

We are in favor of the transfer system to facilitate voters in the country and to reflect the true public will, but we are strongly opposed to absentee voting by Taiwan businessmen operating in China and by other emigrants.

China has been known to influence the political views of Taiwan businessmen and it is a country that rigorously monitors all types of communications. If absentee voting is allowed, Taiwan businessmen would vote under circumstances of fear and restriction of free will.
China would naturally want the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to win and absentee voting by Taiwan businessmen operating in China will be favorable to the KMT.
The KMT also enjoys other unfair advantages -- it has a bigger party staff, more party assets and more media affiliations.

If Taiwan businessmen operating in China are allowed to cast absentee votes, it will be tantamount to open interference by China in Taiwan's internal affairs, through campaigning for the KMT. The elections will therefore lack legitimacy.
If the Interior Ministry dares to implement such a measure, it is sure to spark riots and revolution. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Former distinguished lawmaker convicted of fraud
DOC.DATELINE: 02/05/10 12:34:33 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Lee Ching-an was sentenced Thursday by the Taipei District Court to two years in prison for fraud in connection with her dual citizenship status.
The court has also ruled that the sentence cannot be suspended.

Lee was indicted Sept. 16, 2009 for concealing her dual citizenship status and defrauding the public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a Kuomintang legislator from 1999 to 2008.
Taiwan's Nationality Act stipulates that holders of dual citizenship must surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office.
Lee had been in public office for some 14 years before it was discovered in March 2008 that she had never relinquished her U.S. citizenship.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
It is up to the Taipei City Council and Legislative Yuan to decide whether or not to file a civil suit against Lee to recover the amount she was paid during her perid of public service.

Lee was seen as a star legislator because of her distinguished service for three consecutive terms between 1999 and 2008. She resigned in January 2009, a few months into her fourth term, amid public pressure.

It is believed that the heaviest blow to Lee is not the loss of her legislative seat, but rather the court's description of her as a "deceiver, " "a fraud" and a "dishonest" person, which completely demolished the reputation she had earned during her two decades of public service.
"Honesty and uprightness" were once her strongest attributes in elections, and won her the solid endorsement of most pan-blue bigwigs, including Lien Chan, Wu Poh-hsiung and Ma Ying-jeou.
Commenting on the case, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Chun-yee said that justice had come too late.
The DPP legislative caucus has demanded that Lee refund all her pay as a legislator from 1999 to 2009 because she was holding U.S. citizenship throughout that period. (Feb. 5, 2010)
China Times:
Lee's lawyer Chuang Hsiu-ming said that they will appeal the ruling because his client did not have the slightest intention of bilking the public coffers.
Legal experts have said that the question of whether Lee should be made to refund her salary should be decided by the city council and the legislature.
However, given that Lee had to pay her assistants during her period of public service, it would not be that simple to have her refund her salary, the experts said. (Feb. 5, 2010)
Liberty Times:
DPP lawmakers denounced the court for not convicting Lee on corruption charges because it had neglected to look at the truth.

Although the court ruled that the NT$102.77 million Lee obtained in salary from 1994-2008 as city and legislator was "illegal income," the amount is not reclaimable because she was not convicted on corruption charges. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day---Former vice president interviews Ma

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu interviewed President Ma Ying-jeou on Feb. 4 for the Formosa Weekly which she founded.
Following are excerpts of local media coverage of the event: United Daily News:
The 75-minute interview was more a political debate than an interview, with Ma gaining the upper hand and Lu having to concede that "you really are eloquent today."

However Lu said at a news conference afterward that she didn't agree with all of Ma's views, but could not chip in with her own opinions. "I gave Ma a chance to air his views fully, " she said, noting that it was not a debate.
Although Lu had promised to report the interview accurately, the Presidential Office later released video footage of the full interview rather than a three- minute preview as Lu's aide has requested.

The interview began with Lu questioning the existence of the 1992 Consensus, which refers to the recognition by Taiwan and China that there is but "one China, " but each side is free to interpret the definition of the term as they see fit.

Citing a telephone conversation between Chinese leader Hu Jintao and former U.S. President George Bush, Ma confirmed the existence of the 1992 Consensus, adding that dialogue between Taiwan and China could not have resumed without the consensus.

As to Lu's question on Taiwan's status, Ma said his administration adheres to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which was enacted during President Lee Teng-hui's term and was also adhered to by President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party The Liberty Times:

Ma rejected Lu's request for Taiwan to negotiate a trade pact with China only after Beijing promises not to block similar negotiations between Taiwan with other countries, saying that it is unbecoming for a sovereignty to ask another state's permission to act.

The president also defended his efforts to seek a diplomatic truce with China, saying that his administration has not lost any allies to date, while the preceding DPP government lost nine allies and gained three.

Lu said this is because Beijing has suddenly realized that the diplomatic tug of war serves no interest. Ma snapped back with the question of why China had not come to that realization when the DPP was in power.(Feb. 5, 2010) China Times:
The only point that both Ma and Lu agreed on is the need for a national conference between the leaders of the ruling and opposition parties.

Ma said he has written to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen asking for a meeting to exchange views on national policy, "but she didn't bother to reply. I don't blame her for not responding, because I understand some of her feelings," he said.

Lu's interview with Ma has been criticized by DPP heavyweights, with Chen Chi- mai, former vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, saying that Lu had debased herself by meeting Ma as a reporter rather than a former vice president.
Lu dismissed the criticism, saying that she met Ma in her capacity as publisher of Formosa Weekly and former vice president.
Her stance was supported by the fact that during the interview Ma addressed her as vice president.
Ma was obviously on edge at the start of the interview, but spoke fluently and confidently as it progressed, and toward the end he dominated the discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Piano duo from Taiwan to perform at Vatican celebrations
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 13:44:28 (By Huang Ya-shih and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A renowned husband-and-wife piano duo, Rolf-Peter Wille and Lina Yeh of Taiwan, has been invited by the Vatican to perform at the 25th founding anniversary celebrations of the Pontifical Council for Health Care Workers, a diplomatic source said Friday.
Larry Yu-yuan Wang, Taiwan's ambassador to the Holy See, said he was asked by the council's chairman Zygmunt Zimowski to invite Wille and Yeh as guest performers at the event.
Wang said the invitation underlines the Holy See's recognition of Taiwan's musicians and marks the first time that musicians from Taiwan will perform in Vatican City.
The duo is expected to perform music by Bach, Brahms, Edvard Grieg and Francis Poulenc at the function. Yeh also plans to play pieces by renowned Taiwanese composer Chen Yang, Wang said.

Yeh, born in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung, was a child prodigy who went on to study at the Mozart Academy in Salzburg, Austria, and to later learn from world-class masters such as Hans Leygraf, Kurt Leimer and Jacob Lateiner.

Wille is a German who came to Taiwan at the age of 23 to teach, soon after he graduated from Staatlich Hochschule Fur Musik Hannover. He went on to obtain a doctorate in piano performance at the Manhattan School of Music, New York.

The couple has traveled to Europe, South Africa, North America, Russia and Latin America on performance tours, and have received rave reviews from local critics. They recently celebrated their 30th anniversary as a duo.
The Pontifical Council for Health Care Workers will host a three-day activity Feb. 9-11 to mark its 25th founding anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News : Why bother to implement a luxury house tax
DOC.DATELINE: 02/05/10 15:06:37 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City has beat the Ministry of Finance to the punch by introducing what it called a luxury housing tax.
According to the city government, the tax is part of its efforts to address the country's top 10 public grievances, of which the main one is skyrocketing housing prices.
It is not a new tax, but rather an increase of existing house tax rates.

Currently, house taxes are calculated according to a universal percentage of the house value as determined by the local governments, rather than on market value, because of the difficulty in fixing the market price.

Not wanting to impose too heavy a tax burden on home owners, local governments usually value residential properties below the market price, which leads to a problem of similar taxes for ordinary and luxury homes.
However there are three problems with the proposed luxury housing tax:
First, the definition of luxury housing is too vague. The criteria used by Taipei City depends heavily on the subjective assessment of tax collectors.

Also it is widely perceived that luxury residences exist only in the metropolises of Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, which hinders efforts elsewhere to narrow the gap between market prices and their assessed values.

Second, the luxury tax is not an effective means of controlling rising housing prices. Housing tax rates are usually not very high, and the tax agencies are not likely to raise their value assessments to the level of the market prices, therefore the new tax would not effectively drive down housing prices.

Third, the luxury tax is not consistent with the goal of achieving parity in the taxation system. Houses are usually bought with personal post-tax incomes, and their owners have to pay various taxes in the process of acquiring, transferring, or bequeathing the properties. Imposing a special tax on luxury houses would only increase public hostility toward the rich, which would not serve the national interest. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature will address Lee's case after final court ruling: speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 15:20:40 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will decide after the final court ruling whether a former lawmaker, who was convicted of fraud in a case involving dual citizenship status, should return her aggregate salary, the legislative speaker said Friday.
Wang Jin-pyng stressed that the Legislative Yuan will handle the case based on the law and will make a decision unclouded by personal sympathy.

The Taipei District Court on Thursday sentenced former Legislator Lee Ching-an, also known as Diane Lee, to two years in prison for fraud. Lee was convicted on charges related to holding U.S. citizenship while serving as a Taipei city councilor from 1994 to 1998 and a Kuomintang legislator from 1999 to 2008.
Taiwan's Nationality Act stipulates that holders of dual citizenship must surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office.
Lee had been in public office for some 14 years before it was discovered in March 2008 that she had never relinquished her U.S. citizenship.
The district court also ruled that Lee's sentence cannot be suspended, but it can be appealed.
Wang pointed out that Thursday's ruling was made in a criminal case, but possible civil action had not yet been resolved.
The Legislative Yuan will take action based on the law as soon as the final court ruling is made, he added.
According to the legislature's Research Bureau, the Taipei district prosecutors office indicted Lee on charges of forgery and fraud.
On the charge of fraud, the court is empowered to declare in the final ruling that Lee must refund all of her pay for the entire period of her public service, the bureau said.
If the court does not make such a ruling, it will be up to the legislature, which paid Lee's salary, to decide whether or not to file a civil suit against Lee to recoup the funds, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Taiwan should not end up in anti-democracy camp
DOC.DATELINE: 02/05/10 15:53:42 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. unveiled a US$6.4 billion arms package for Taiwan last week, to China's irritation, and U.S. President Barack Obama said he would meet with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dala Lama at the end of this month during the later's visit to Washington.
At the peak of the financial crisis last year, Washington was pursuing a policy of conciliation with China, but this year, the Obama administration seems ready to change tack.

Based on these frictions and the disputes over trade and the value of the Chinese yuan, Chinese political analysts have predicted that strategic competition will replace strategic cooperation between Beijing and Washington.
U.S. think tanks have floated similar views, forecasting that relations between Beijing and Washington in 2010 will not progress as well as in the previous year.

China owes much of its peaceful rise to its huge trade surplus with the U. S. Competition with the U.S. will inevitably dampen China's economic growth and drive down its employment rate and domestic consumption.
China's threat to boycott U.S. firms that sell arms to Taiwan is likely to be nothing but rhetoric because these American firms have markets other than China.
However, China could hold Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland hostage and compel Taiwan to acknowledge the one-China principle on Beijing's terms.

We are not concerned about the strife between Beijing and Washington, as long as Taipei is not drawn into it. But the risk of Taiwan's involvement would become real if President Ma Ying-jeou achieves economic integration with China through his proposed trade pact.
Taiwan should plant itself firmly in the democracy camp rather than on the anti- democracy side. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices shed more than 4 percent on Taipei bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 16:21:43 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Following overnight heavy losses on Wall Street, Taiwan's share prices plunged 4.29 percent Friday to finish below 7,300, its lowest level since Nov. 2, 2009.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 324.21 points to close at 7,217.83.
At the opening of the trading session, the Taiex lost 218.88 points, dropping to 7,323.16 and fluctuated between a high of 7,352.98 and a low of 7,196.39 during the day's trading.
A total of 4.61 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$121.69 billion (US$3.80 billion).
All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks dropping the steepest, at 6.2 percent.
Cement shares lost 6 percent, textile issues fell 5.9 percent, and paper and pulp stocks dipped 5.8 percent.
Banking and financial stocks dropped 5.5 percent, foodstuff shares shed 4.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 4.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals issues fell 3 percent.

The sharp plunge in such shares was attributed partly to the fact that a ruling by the economics ministry earlier in the week canceled six items on Pacific Distribution Investment's business registration, including three capital increases on behalf of the Far Eastern Group.
The ministry's ruling cast doubts on the Far Eastern Group's control over the popular Sogo department stores.
The ruling has sent Far Eastern Group shares into a downward spiral over several consecutive sessions.
On Friday, Far Eastern and Pacific Construction, which are battling for control of Sogo, both saw their shares fall by the maximum 7 percent daily limit.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,918 to 398, with 45 stocks remaining unchanged.

Altogether, the three major institutional investors made net sales of NT$19.83 billion worth of shares, with NT$15.72 billion sold by foreign investors, NT$1.83 billion by investment trust firms and NT$2.29 billion by securities firms.
One analyst said that the Taiex is expected to hold at its yearly moving average of 7,000 and suggested that investors should find bargains if the index drops down below the 7,000-point mark.

DOC.HEADLINE: Colorectal cancer remains most common cancer in Taiwan: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 16:45:18 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of people newly diagnosed with cancer edged higher in 2007, with colorectal cancer remaining the most common form of the disease, ahead of liver cancer, according to a Department of Health report issued Friday.
Taiwan recorded 75,769 new cancer cases in 2007, 3.4 percent more than in 2006, said Chiou Shu-ti, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion.

Those figures equate to a new cancer patient being diagnosed roughly every 7 minutes in 2007, slightly faster than every 7 minutes and 10 seconds in the previous year, when 73,293 new cases were recorded, Chiou said.

The statistics are available only up through 2007 because the Department of Health needs time to collect raw cancer data from local hospitals and then cross-check it to be sure patients are not counted twice (if, for example, they have been to more than one hospital for a diagnosis) or misidentified.

In the latest version of the DOH annual report on cancer, colorectal cancer remained the most diagnosed type of cancer in 2007 after displacing liver cancer as the most common form of the disease in 2006.
After colorectal cancer and liver cancer, the next most frequently diagnosed forms of the disease in 2007 were lung cancer, breast cancer and oral cancer.
These five types accounted for 56 percent of all new cancer patients in the country for the year.
The risk of cancer among men was 1.4 times higher than among women in Taiwan, Chiou said.

Because of the largely male habits of smoking and chewing betel nuts, the age- adjusted incidence rates of esophageal cancer and oral cancer among men were 12.7 times and 11.3 times higher respectively than among women in 2007, Chiou added.

According to Kung Hsien-lan, a section chief with the Cancer Control and Prevention Division, the incidence of breast cancer and thyroid gland cancer increased the most among Taiwanese women. Both diseases were related to imbalances in female sex hormones, she said.
High fat diets and high caloric intakes, which disturb female sex hormones, have raised the risk of Taiwanese women being afflicted with cancer, Kung said.
Meanwhile, she noted, Taiwanese women were found to develop breast cancer an average 10 years earlier than their Western counterparts.
She attributed the increased prevalence of colorectal cancer among Taiwan's people to increasingly unhealthy dietary habits, such as the high consumption of red meat and fat and a low fiber intake.

Meanwhile, both Chiou and Kung said that the Bureau of Health Promotion will expand its free early cancer detection program by offering more free tests -- mammography screening for breast cancer, Pap smear tests for cervical cancer, taking samples of a patient's mucous membrane for oral cancer, and fecal occult blood tests for colorectal cancer.
Chiou estimates that the program will help detect an additional 10,000 new cancer cases this year, and those identified as having the disease will be given immediate medical attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic News: A learning session of 30 years
DOC.DATELINE: 02/05/10 16:49:31 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: At the request of Premier Wu Den-yih, the Ministry of the Interior recently came up with a plan to build 4,000 low-cost apartments near the site of a proposed rapid transit system station in Linko, Taipei County.
The housing project will be linked to the development of an industrial zone.
This plan is similar to the successful "new towns" in Singapore.
Nearly 70 percent of the population in Singapore live in these new towns that boast sport centers, schools, supermarkets, a shopping street, bus stations and rapid transit system stations.
The Ministry of the Interior's plan has a good chance of success because of the proposed location near a rapid transit system station, which was one of the prerequisites for Singapore's new towns.
Taiwan tried three decades ago to adopt Singapore's new town idea, but the government housing projects turned into slums because of shoddy construction work and ill-conceived planning.
We hope Premier Wu's plan will succeed this time and end Taiwan's three decades of trying to learn from Singapore. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks to boost exchanges with U.S. universities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 16:53:53 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will encourage local universities to seek out and expand exchanges with their U.S. counterparts in the hope of giving Taiwan a voice in public policy debates in the United States, Minister of Education Wu Ching-ji said Friday.

The government will encourage cooperation and exchanges with prestigious U.S. schools through its five-year, NT$50 billion program to help local universities transform themselves into among the world's elite, Wu noted.

Aside from that funding, the ministry hopes that more funds will be allocated to establish educational foundations or research centers at renowned U.S. schools at which Taiwanese students can continue their education.
If Taiwanese students can graduate from highly reputed schools in the U.S., they will have a better chance of finding a good job and be better placed to speak for Taiwan there, Wu said.
According to the minister, Beijing has spent a great deal of money over the past decade in forging cooperative relationships with reputed U.S. schools like those in the Ivy League.

Through the ties, many Chinese students have gained enrollment in premier U.S. schools, but the number of Taiwanese students studying at those same universities has been on the decline, and top schools are now less likely to offer scholarships to students from Taiwan, Wu said.
"If we do not have footholds at the top schools, there will be only Chinese voices in public hearings in the U.S. in the future, " he explained.

Wu noted that those studying in the U.S. on the recommendation of the local schools subsidized by the government's elite university development program are not obliged to return to Taiwan for work after graduation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liao treasures from Inner Mongolia to be exhibited in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 17:35:27 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition from the Inner Mongolia Museum, featuring the largest collection of Class 1 artifacts from China, will open Saturday at the National Palace Museum (NPM).
The organizer of the exhibition said that 115 masterpieces, including treasures from the Liao Tomb on Tuerji Mountain, will be displayed outside of China for the first time.

According to the NPM, the exhibition, titled "Gold and Glory -- The Wonders of Khitan from the Inner Mongolia Museum Collection, " will present Liao artifacts and rare wares of gold, silver and other materials, from various tribes on the great steppe, as well as from the three major Khitan grave sites.
Liao artifacts are rare in Taiwan.
"The public in Taiwan could gain an understanding of Liao culture through this new exhibit," said Chou Kung-shin, director of the NPM.
The most important item in the exhibit is a gold mask found in the tomb of a Liao princess, which has been viewed by more than a million people in Japan.
In addition, treasures from the Tuerji Mountain tomb, which were discovered in March 2003, will debut at the exhibition.
The organizer indicated that the Tuerji Mountain tomb is currently dated as the earliest of all the Khitan nobility tombs that have been excavated to date.
The many exquisite funerary artifacts include bronzes, silverware, gold ware, lacquer ware, wood carvings, horse gear, glassware and textiles, she said.
The exhibit will run from Feb. 6 to May 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Measures being mulled to save military personnel fund: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 17:42:38 (By S. Y. Shih and and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Responding to a warning that the state-run Pension Fund for Defense Personnel might go bankrupt in a few years, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Friday it is considering a number of measures, to prevent the situation from deteriorating further.
They include offering incentives to military personnel to extend their careers rather than taking retirement.

The Ministry of Civil Service (MCS) warned Friday that the pension fund's financial situation was precarious, even though expectations that disbursements would exceed revenues for the first time in 2009 did not materialize.
The MND warned that the fund could still go bankrupt by 2018 and predicted that a planned voluntary military service system will deal it a further blow.

The ministry attributed the pension fund's financial difficulties to personnel streamlining programs implemented in recent years that have cut Taiwan's military personnel from 452,000 people to the current level of 275,000.

The large number of retired personnel has placed a heavy burden on the pension fund, the ministry said, with 80 percent of the fund's revenues over the past three years being paid out in retirement benefits.
The situation leaves little cushion for the future, especially when if existing career military personnel retire in waves when the voluntary military service system takes effect.

Also, under existing rules, newly recruited servicemen could receive NT$100,000 in benefits if they quit after three years despite having paid only NT$70,000 into the fund over that time, MCS officials said.
Over the long term, adjustments in the military's retirement system will be necessary to improve the pension fund's finances, they contended.

At present, Taiwan's military personnel can receive retirement benefits that are 8.29 times the amount they paid into their pension fund, far higher than the 5.97 times for teachers and the 5.43 times for government employees, according to the MCS report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore shares its experience in water resource development
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 17:45:49 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Singapore's trade representative to Taiwan visited Kinmen Friday to provide the water-strapped island county his country's successful experience in water resources development, especially in water reclamation.
The visit by Stanley Loh came seven months after President Ma Ying-jeou proposed that Kinmen learn from Singapore's water reclamation model to solve the island's perennial water shortages.
During the trip, Loh inspected Kinmen's sea water desalination plant and water purification and sewage treatment facilities and held discussions with Kinmen County government officials.
He also presented Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Wo-shi with bottled reclaimed drinking water from Singapore.
Loh noted that Singapore has been facing a lack of water resources since it achieved independence from Malaysia in 1965.
The country now relies on rainwater collection, water imports from Malaysia, sea water desalination and water reclamation as its major sources of the precious resource, he said.

Singapore built is first water reclamation plant in 2002 and will be completing the fifth such facility later this year, when recycled water will meet 30 percent of the country's total demand, he said.

According to Loh, the reclamation process involves purifying used water with advanced membrane technology, and the quality of the reclaimed water exceeds the criteria set by the World Health Organization for drinking water.

Minerals are added into the pure water for drinking purposes. Loh said everyone who has visited Singapore has also drunk the reclaimed water, called NEWater, including leaders who took part in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum held late last year in the city state.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister departs on visit to Germany, Vatican
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 17:52:26 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang left for Europe late Thursday, at the head of a medical delegation, to explore developments relating to long-term care.
Yaung's delegation includes Cheng Shou-hsia, head of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, and Tai Kuei-ying, a senior DOH official in charge of a task force on long-term care.

The delegation will travel first to Germany for a familiarization tour of long- term care organizations and facilities in two German states, and to explore developments and prospects in that field, according to the Department of Health (DOH).

Yaung and his colleagues will later travel to Vatican City, where they will attend the 25th founding anniversary celebrations of the Pontifical Council for Health Care Workers, at the invitation of the Holy See, the DOH said.
They are expected to meet and talk with World Health Organization (WHO) officials, including Secretary-General Margaret Chan, and other health officials from the European Union, according to the DOH.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Good nominees key to election victory
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 02/05/10 18:18:58 (Feb. 5, 2010) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: recently fine tuned its local branch leadership and hired a human resource expert, with the goal of winning the year-end elections in five municipalities.

But we believe the most important factor is still whether the party's nominees can inspire confidence at the grassroots level. If they have good images and governing ability, it will be an easy task to garner support for them.

The KMT has hired an outsider to help with its human resource assessment and to rebuild an election volunteer network. Looking back on past elections, we can see that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , whether in government or opposition, has always been better than the KMT at deploying volunteers. The DPP mobilizes volunteers at election time and disbands them after, which leaves the party with no personnel burden.
The KMT has tried to emulate the DPP, but has never learned the process well.
The KMT did once have a youth corps, but it is far more difficult for young people to make their mark in the grand old party than in the DPP.
Under the circumstances, a stronger volunteer force can help propel the party toward its goal of becoming an "election machine."
However, great efficiency does not necessarily translate into election wins.
The DPP has strong candidates in the southern municipalities of Kaohsiung and Tainan, and its heavyweights are preparing for the elections in Taipei City and Taipei County.

In comparison, the KMT has no strong candidates in southern Taiwan and is facing the problem of whether to nominate an incumbent Taipei County head to run in the upgraded county despite his low popularity ratings.
In addition, there are no internal debates in the KMT on candidate selection. If the KMT wants to win, it should encourage aspirants to stand up and throw their hats in the ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funding, culture key to developing soccer in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 18:26:40 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: With the 2010 soccer World Cup only a few months away, World Cup fever is picking up around the world.
Even in Taiwan, the event will attract a devout following, but contemplating the day when the national team actually makes the big event is an entirely different story.
Local soccer experts agree that funding, culture and a proper structure are the keys to developing the sport in Taiwan, where the game has long struggled to gain a foothold.

The foremost goal is to create a "soccer culture, " which to date has been nonexistent in a nation far more passionate about basketball and baseball, says Lin De-jia, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Soccer Association (CTFA).
Without a professional league and a soccer culture, children don't have the motivation to participate in the sport, Lin tells the Central News Agency.

It's not a secret that Taiwan, currently ranked 162nd in the world, has long been an international soccer minnow, registering five wins, five draws, and 41 losses World Cup qualifying matches from 1958-2010. It scorded only 28 goals in those games while surrending 182.

Led by Japanese head coach Toshiaki Imai, Taiwan's World Cup qualifying campaign for the 2010 event quickly evaporated in October 2007 when it was swept by Uzbekistan in a home-and-home series by an aggregate 11-0 score.

In order to change its lowly status, Taiwan needs to focus on developing its youth soccer programs, said David Camhi, who is familiar with Taiwanese soccer and has been running a soccer camp for children in Taipei with friends for six years.

All training and competitions in Taiwan take place within the education system, based on the U.S. model, as was the case in Japan in the late 1980s and early 1990s, Camhi wrote in his Kick-Off magazine, and he argues it is the wrong approach.
"Japan now has three professional leagues, nine regional leagues, 46 prefecture leagues and many more municipal leagues. A football pyramid with eight levels," Camhi wrote.
With such a structure in place, Japan managed within approximately 12 years to progress to the second round of the FIFA World Cup in 2002 and qualify for the 2006 and 2010 editions.
"It's something the football authorities and other sporting bodies in Taiwan should look into," Camhi wrote.

When there is a much larger talent pool in Taiwan, the overall competition level of the sport will be elevated, said Camhi, who arrived in Taiwan in 1999 and has been working on promoting the game and teaching fundamentals to children since then.
Other than the lack of a professional league, funding also has been a problem, Lin said.
"Taiwan's government sees the CTFA as nothing more than one of more than 60 sports associations in the country, " he complains.
According to Lin, the association previously received NT$10 million in funding from the government every year, but the amount dropped to NT$6 million last year.

That's a pittance compared to the NT$30 million alone the association must spend to send national teams ranging from under-13 to the senior level abroad to play in 20 to 30 international competitions every year, Lin says.

He does acknowledge that there have been some sparks of interest over the past decade, including after the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea when Taiwan's passion for "the beautiful game" did pick up a little.
Since then, Lin said, more schoolchildren have participated in the game, and more schools have organized soccer teams, enabling Taiwan's national youth teams to fare better in competitions.

Camhi said a number of elite young Taiwanese players are even capable of playing professionally overseas now, though because they lack exposure they are not recruited by European or South American clubs.
But both Lin and Camhi acknowledge that the development of the local game will take a long time and requires patience.

Lin urged the government to plan for the long-term rather than rush for immediate results, and he urged authorities to rethink their policy of establishing "sports classes" -- which gather athletes into a single class -- because it works against achieving the objective.
Such classes actually limit participation in sports and discourages schools without sports classes from organizing athletic teams because they cannot keep up with better schools, he argues.

And that's not good because the future is with the younger generation, Camhi insists. Only by working from the bottom up can Taiwan improve its soccer performance and some day "reach my ultimate goal for Taiwan to qualify for the soccer World Cup."

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Going after Shanghai Expo 'dividend'

TEXT.P: The biggest event in China this year will be the Shanghai Expo, which will open May 1 and run until Oct. 31. It is expected to attract up to 100 million visitors if the economic environment is good.

Considering the close trade and business exchanges between Taiwan and China, the government should not ignore it but rather actively make good use of the opportunities offered by the "nearest ever expo" to the country.

In fact, the Shanghai expo has presented some opportunities to Taiwan, and Taiwan's private sector has gladly accepted them and greatly advanced the country's visibility at the event, in sharp contrast to Taiwan's overall profile at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
Another development could help push the event to the level of an official cross- strait exchange -- Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng will lead a delegation to visit Taiwan in April.

The expo will be a major topic, but as the head of China's largest economic city, Han's visit will of course bring a new wave of cross-strait trade exchanges. The government should form a task force to seize the opportunities and send officials to meet with members of Han's delegation to forge a cooperation platform.

The convener of the task force could be a minister without portfolio-level official, and its members could come from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and all related government agencies.

The task force will help support Taiwan's exhibitions and performance at the expo, solicit orders for the industrial and commercial sectors, arrange for orderly visits by Taiwan tourists and solicit the expo visitors to make a trip to Taiwan. (Feb. 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreigners dream big for Taiwan's soccer future
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 18:44:54 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: David Camhi has a goal that most Taiwanese would not even dare to dream -- seeing Taiwan qualify for soccer's World Cup one day. But that goal can only be achieved if more attention is given to youth soccer in the country.

Frenchman Camhi shares the same vision with Britons Daniel Calvert and Michael Chandler, so they started a children's soccer camp in 2004 to promote "the beautiful game" and build a foundation for the sport by teaching fundamentals to children from 3-9 years old.

They launched the program because of their love of the game and desire to see Taiwan do well in international soccer competitions, Camhi said at Shi Pai Junior High School's soccer field, where the team runs the Master Football Academy (MFA), a weekly camp.

"Taiwan is probably the only country in Asia where soccer is not a popular sport, " Camhi said on a sunny morning as he watched Calvert, the camp's head coach, lead dozens of children in a warm-up drill with parents looking on.

Children in the camp participate in training sessions every Saturday and play in real games in a league every Sunday, going up against teams from other Taipei soccer academies at Dazhi Riverside Park.

About 300 children attend the weekly camp, which sells coupons and does not require full registration. That means children can join and drop out any time, said Camhi, certified as a soccer coach by the French Football Federation and the Football Association of England.
The camp's participants have different motivations.
Yvonne Neddo, whose five-year-old son Gabriel signed on with the camp about three months ago, said she thought soccer to be appropriate for her child.
"Soccer is a good sport, aerobic exercise for the body, and keeps you 'on your toes' -- nothing heavyweight for muscle building, " she said.
A fourth-grade boy surnamed Chao joined the camp when he was riding a bike with his father -- a soccer player in college -- in the park two years ago and saw a training session.
"I think he was influenced by his father's love of the game. They watched games on television together all the time, and he found out that he loved it too, " said Mrs. Chao.
Mr. Huang said his daughter, who is one of the few girls in the male-dominated camp, "joined the camp purely for excercise."
The MFA is very happy with how the camp is developing, although it means the coaches "have almost no off days, " Camhi said, but the academy has even bolder plans ahead.

It will hold an event in collaboration with the Ministry of Education in May to promote youth soccer and the upcoming soccer World Cup in South Africa as well as a Tottenhem Hotspur International Player Development Course camp from July 12-16 in Taipei.

Tottenham Hotspur, an English Premier League team, sees the potential in Taiwan's market and is scheduled to bring in six coaches and an ambassador who is a former Hotspur player for the camp, which will consist of 50 youth players and 50 underprivileged children, said Calvert.
"We hope that this camp will be a starting point for a long-term relationship with the team to help Taiwan develop its youth soccer, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to report publicly on ECFA progress on regular basis
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 19:50:45 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will regularly brief the public on progress in talks between Taiwan and China on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , officials at the Presidential Office said Friday.
The office has decided to hold a press conference Feb. 9 to present such a briefing.
"It will be the first of its kind. In the future, there will be regular presidential press conferences on progress in the negotiations," the officials noted.

Ma asked officials to make negotiations on the cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact open and transparent after his government was stung by an outcry over the signing of a protocol with Washington on opening Taiwan's market to U.S. beef.
Mounting public protests pushed the legislature to pass an amendment contravening part of the protocol, embarrassing the government and creating tensions in Taiwan-U.S. relations.
The administration attributed the public resistance to poor communications and hopes to make the process over the controversial ECFA less contentious.
Ma, who sees the ECFA talks as the government's most important issue this year, instructed relevant authorities to brief the legislature on progress in the negotiations every month.

Publicity on the negotiations will be based on the principle that "negotiators must talk to the other side first and then brief the legislature before President Ma addresses the public, " his office said.

Ma has revealed that the second round of cross-strait talks on the ECFA will be held some time between late February and early March, and that the negotiations will focus on a range of issues, including an "early harvest" program, a list of items that could be first to enjoy tariff exemptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady arrives in Canada with Cloud Gate
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/05/10 19:52:44 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching arrived in Vancouver Thursday as the honorary head of the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, the first time Taiwan's first lady has visited Canada since diplomatic ties were severed between the two countries in 1970.
Chow was greeted at the airport by a group of more than 40 Taiwanese expatriates.
She is expected to attend two Cloud Gate performances on Friday and Saturday at the Cultural Olympiad being held in the Canadian city.
The first lady will also attend a book donation ceremony at the Vancouver Public Library and read story books to local children.

She will also visit the "Lantern Forest" -- a corridor that displays thousands of lanterns decorated by children from Canada and Taiwan -- and an exhibition featuring the works of Taiwanese installation artist Michael Lin at the Vancouver Art Gallery.
Before arriving in Vancouver, the first lady had accompanied the Cloud Gate dancers to Washington, D.C. and Chicago.
They are scheduled to return to Taiwan Feb. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presents scholarship money to flood-affected students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 19:53:48 (By Kuo Chih-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Friday presented scholarship money to 133 students in the southern county of Pingtung who were affected by the severe flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot last August.

The recipients were from five indigenous townships and villages. The amount given to those studying in senior high schools was NT$10,000 per person and to those studying in colleges and universities was NT$20,000.

According to Tsai, the DPP launched a fund-raising campaign for the flood victims last year and reserved NT$18.8 million as scholarships for students in the hope that their studies are not interrupted because of the disaster.
