DOC.HEADLINE: ROC 100th anniversary celebrations kick off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 21:48:18 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Seven activities featuring Taiwan's national parks kicked off Friday as a prelude to a series of celebrations for the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China in 2011, officials of the Construction and Planning Agency said Friday.

The activities were planned to promote the natural beauty and historic sites of the country's eight national parks, including hikes of Taiwan's seven famous mountains that will begin March 6 and a marathon to be held March 14 in Kenting in the southernmost county of Pingtung, according to the officials.
Other activities include exhibitions, a forum and a bicycle tour centered around Taiwan's national parks, as well as an environmental education session on how to explore them.

National parks have always been considered as a country's natural and cultural assets and treasure. Taiwan's eight national parks cover 8.5 percent of the country's 36,000 square-kilometer area and are truly special, the official said.
More information about the activities is available on the activities' Web site: http://parkstaiwan99.cpami.gov.tw/.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan under spotlight at Brussels travel fair
DOC.DATELINE: Tel Aviv, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 21:50:55 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's pavilion at the Brussels Holiday Show, the biggest annual travel fair in Belgium, has drawn considerable attention as it promotes the country's natural beauty, culture, fine foods and free and democratic society.
This is the seventh year Taiwan is participating in the travel fair, which is being held at Brussels Expo, the city's major exhibition center, until Feb. 8.

Taiwan's booth, shaped like an island and open on all four sides, is decorated with billboards to highlight Taiwan's abundant tourism resources and culture, Wang Chen-tai, an official at Taiwan's representative office in the EU and Belgium, said on Friday.

A wide variety of brochures, maps, and souvenirs introducing Taiwan's top tourist attractions and culture were available at the booth, and a series of documentaries and videos were screened repeatedly.
Taiwan-based China Airlines and tour operator VTB/Jetair also sent representatives to offer customers advice, promotional literature and information about holiday and travel planning.

Belgians made 10.4 million overseas visits last year, though not many visited Taiwan. Still, with the help of a low baseline, the number of Belgian tourists traveling to Taiwan in 2008 rose 53 percent, according to statistics compiled by the representative office.

Although there is still ample room for growth, Taiwan has gained increased exposure in Belgium in recent years after having held 76 events in 70 cities promoting travel to Taiwan and arranging a fact-finding trip to Taiwan for a 33-member delegation of Belgian travel agents and tourism operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dealer awaiting recall notice from Toyota
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 21:52:43 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwan distributor of Japanese car maker Toyota Motor Corp., said Friday that it is still waiting for notification from Toyota on whether to recall the 2010 Prius it has been selling in Taiwan because of brake problems.
"It's likely we'll know the result in the coming days, " Steven Yang, general manager of Hotai's External Affairs Division, told the Central News Agency.
There have been "only a few" instances in which drivers reported minor brake problems in their Prius vehicles, Yang said.
While still waiting to hear from Toyota, Hotai is willing to offer free inspection services to its customers who are concerned about the brake system in the popular hybrid car, Yang said.
There are around 600 of the 2010 models in circulation in Taiwan.
Concerns about gas pedals in other Toyota models have already prompted a recall of more than eight million cars in other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local gaming software firms complain of unfair treatment in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/05/10 22:09:51 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The government should help remove barriers imposed against Taiwan's game software companies in China's market, a local association aimed at promoting the local game industry said Friday.

"There is unfair competition between Taiwanese and Chinese online game companies, " said Aaron Hsu, the head of the association consisting of Taiwan's 20 game software companies, at a seminar held at the Taipei Game Show on its opening day.
He said Taiwanese products cannot enter China's market as quickly as Chinese products do because they are subject to a stricter and more protracted screening process.
But Chinese games can compete without restrictions in Taiwan, he complained.

"New game products from China account for over 40 percent of the total number of new products in Taiwan's market, " Hsu, also the chairman of XPEC Entertainment Inc., told an audience of over 200 people.
"This means that Taiwan has opened itself to Chinese products. There is no barrier at all."
However, new products made by Taiwanese companies account for less than 1 percent of the total number of new products in China, he added.
Hsu urged Taiwan's government to deal with this unfair treatment during the upcoming fifth round of talks aimed at further liberalizing trade between Taiwan and China.

Meanwhile, Albert Liu, chairman and CEO of Gamania Digital Entertainment Co., argued that the government is not efficient enough to help local online game companies, and he called for the establishment of a digital content industrial park to create a cluster effect.

Asked about the industry's prospects for 2010, Soft-World International Corp. Chairman Wang Chun-po said Taiwan's online game companies should not only focus on the Chinese market, but also on markets in Russia, Turkey, Europe, the United States and Japan.
"These markets have already accepted games featuring Chinese cultural elements, " he said. "The first best-selling games in Russia and Vietnam all had Chinese elements."

Paul Chiang, president of International Games System Co., suggested that Taiwanese firms should seek partnership with leading U.S. or European companies to outperform their Chinese or South Korea competitors.
A total of 62 companies are taking part in the Taipei Game Show this year. The show is expected to draw 300,000 visitors during its five-day run that concludes Feb. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 6, 2010, or the 23rd day of the 12 month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1665: Queen Anne, last Stuart ruler of Britain, is born.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist moted for work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 get the vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes first woman president of Finland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 10:12:32 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Saturday than its previous close, moving up 26.88 points at 7,244.71 on a turnover of NT$1.91 billion (US$59.34 million million).
The weighted price index lost 324.21 points, or 4.29 percent, to close at 7,217.83 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 10:50:31 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.098 at 9:45 a.m. Saturday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.089 from Friday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: 'Soft power' key to Taiwan's security

TEXT.P: Arms sales have long been viewed as a barometer of the strength of U.S. commitment to Taiwan. However, some people have ridiculed Taiwan's use of big money to buy weapons from the United States, likening the situation to "a nightwalker trying to brace up his own courage by whistling." This may sound acrimonious, but it is an indisputable fact that Taiwan lacks the ability to wage "a war to end all wars."
Under these circumstances, Taiwan has to use other ways to avoid going to war. Taiwan needs to use "soft power" to defend itself and help maintain regional stability.

There are many kinds of "soft power," the most important of which is having a well-developed democracy. Others include economic and trade power, talent and intellectual power, as well as cultural power.

Based on all these, there is a kind of "soft power" that Taiwan needs to employ using high levels of wisdom, which is to function as a leverage for peace in between the two superpowers of China and the United States. As the smallest one, Taiwan has a delicate role to play. And if such a role is played well, it will become a "soft power" that boosts Taiwan's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-premier stresses importance of TIFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/06/10 16:05:16 (By Zep Hu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Delayed trade talks between Taiwan and the United States should be resumed as soon as possible, former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said here Friday.
The talks, originally scheduled to be held in Taipei this month, were delayed due to a dispute over Taiwan's decision to resume a ban on certain U.S. beef products.

Liu said talks under the trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA) would not only strengthen bilateral relations but would also allow U.S. businessmen to fully enjoy the trade opportunities created by a planned trade pact between Taiwan and China.
He noted that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is expected to be signed in the next round of cross-strait talks that are likely to take place in the first half of this year.

The agreement will help businesses on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to adjust their fundamentals and allow global businesses to use Taiwan as a springboard into the Asia-Pacific region, especially China, Liu said.

Liu, who is a senior adviser to President Ma Ying-jeou, made the remarks while speaking at the Heritage Foundation, a Washington think tank, during which he stressed the importance of the TIFA as well as the benefits of the ECFA.
Liu said the TIFA talks have become the most important communication platform on trade and economic issues since the two countries severed formal diplomatic ties in 1979.

However, they have not taken place since Taiwan's decision to resume a ban on imports of U.S. bovine offal and ground beef amid public misgivings about their connections with bovine spongiform encephalopathy, commonly known as mad cow disease.
"The Taiwanese government is seriously and substantively responding to the U.S. request to resume imports and is trying to assuage the public misgivings over U.S. beef," he said.
Liu is leading a Taiwanese delegation attending the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast Feb. 3-5.
During his speech, Liu also said U.S.-Taiwan relations are close, adding that they are major trade partners and have made big investments in each other's countries.
Politically, there have also been positive exchanges, with the U.S. helping Taiwan to enter the World Trade Organization and participate in the World Health Organization as an observer, he went on.

He further expressed hope that the U.S. will continue to assist Taiwan to join such international organizations as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and International Civil Aviation Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Video game generation

TEXT.P: The Taipei Game Show opened Friday, attracting hordes of people, mostly teenagers.
Video games are magnets to many because the players can place themselves into the games and vicariously experience the scenarios depicted.

The movie Avatar is greatly loved by teenagers, not because of its addressing of issues related to environmental protection or naturalism, but because of the surreal effect produced by its visual high-tech 3-D viewing mode.

This paper cannot determine if video games have any impact on the development of the intelligence, psychology or mentality of young people, and cannot predict the impact on the social development of this video game generation.
However, through young people's participation and expanded imagination through video games, future society might be more pluralistic and interesting.
The insistence on ideology and traditional romanticism will be diluted, replaced or removed from the video game generation, which might not be a bad thing. (Feb. 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker released after questioning for suspected bribery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 16:14:38 (by Lai Yu-chia and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The chairman of one of Taiwan's largest banks, Taishin Financial Holding Co., was released in the early hours of Saturday after being questioned by the Supreme Prosecutors Office for suspected involvement in the alleged corruption scandal of former president Chen Shui-bian.

Wu Tung-liang, board chairman of Taishin, was suspected to have paid a huge sum of money as bribery to former president Chen's wife, Wu Shu-jen, as the private bank was planning to invest in the government-linked Chang Hwa Bank when the government was implementing a second phase of financial reforms and encouraging mergers of monetary institutions.

Wu was called in for questioning by the Special Investigative Division of the prosecutors' office after dozens of investigators made surprise raids at Taishin bank's headquarters and Wu's residence in Taipei Friday afternoon upon the closing of the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
Four others suspected of involvement in the case were taken to the prosecutors' office for questioning.

Local media have reported that in the former first lady's statement to the Special Investigative Division last February, Wu Shu-jen claimed that the hundreds of millions she had deposited at the safe of Cathay United Bank since 2006 were contributed by 20 executives of Taiwanese banks, high-tech firms and media organizations, among which NT$100 million was paid by Wu Tung-liang.
Taishin holds a 22.5 percent stake in Chang Hwa Bank and is the largest shareholder of the state-owned bank.
Taishin has been targeted by investigators since the bank was mentioned in the Cabinet's "second phase monetary reform review report" released last February.
The report indicated that when Taishin was in the process of acquiring special shares of Chang Hwa Bank, its debt ratio was relatively high.

Some financial specialists have also pointed out that it did not make sense for Chang Hwa bank to be merged with Taishin because Chang Hwa was in good financial health whereas Taishin was not at the time of the proposed merger, meaning Taishin was in no position to buy up the state-owned financial institution.
Before Friday's questioning, the Taishin chairman had twice been summoned by the investigators as a witness of the suspected money laundering and bribery case of the former first family.

He has claimed that Taishin was helping the government settle problems when it acquired shares of Chang Hwa Bank, and had abided by every legal procedure. Wu Tung-liang had also denied any involvement in the money laundering or bribery case.

In a similar case, the Special Investigative Division last December indicted executives of Cathay United Bank and Yuanta Financial Holding, which were accused of bribing the former first lady in order to "smooth" government requirements to merge with Fuhwa Financial Holding Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian paper praises Taiwanese performers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 16:21:10 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Canada's Vancouver Sun has praised the artistic achievements of Taiwanese artists who will perform at the Cultural Olympiad in Vancouver in February.
According to the paper, Lin Hwai- min, founder of Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, "could be considered the Taiwanese Baryshnikov."

The report, titled "Cultural Olympiad: A taste of Taiwan comes to Vancouver, " also recommended the performance of U-Theatre, saying that "the sheer speed and coordination of the percussionists has amazed audiences."
Meanwhile, the Chai Found Music Workshop was described as presenting "a real taste of Taiwanese music."

Cloud Gate is scheduled to give two performances of "Moon Water" in Vancouver's Queen Elizabeth Theatre Feb. 5-6, while U-Theatre's performances of "Sound of the Ocean" are scheduled for Feb. 12-13 at the Center in Vancouver for Performing Arts. Chai Found, as well as LAFA and Artists Dance Company, will perform in March.
The Cultural Olympiad Vancouver 2010 began Jan. 22 featuring hundreds of art and popular culture events from all over the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: The headstrong Ma administration

TEXT.P: China recently took a series of retaliatory measures against the United States after Washington announced a US$6.4 billion arms sale package to Taiwan. In the face of such an unreasonable reaction from Beijing, the China-leaning administration of President Ma Ying-jeou dared not speak a word.

Many important international media have spoken up in support of the U.S. decision, but the Ma administration dared not and would not express the voice of the Taiwanese people on the arms sales. Obviously, this government is not only shameful but also hopeless.

Worse still, the Ma administration has turned a deaf ear to China's attempts to annex Taiwan, and has even been cooperating with China. The proposed economic cooperation framework agreement, for example, will lead Taiwan right into China's trap.

Panamanian Ambassador to the Republic of China Mario Luis Cucalon Danello said recently that his country respects Ma's policy of a "diplomatic truce, " but will not rule out the possibility of forging formal ties with China. Cucalon's remarks immediately exposed the self-deceptive nature of Ma's "diplomatic truce."

When international media and foreign ambassadors have uncovered China's true colors and the illusionary nature of Ma's China policy, can the Taiwanese people allow this government to continue doing things its way?

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Shares slump on fear over euro zone defaults

TEXT.P: Taiwan shares tumbled heavily Friday on fears about possible euro zone defaults, with the benchmark weighted index plunging by 324.21 points to close at 7,217.83 points. The 4.3 percent drop, the biggest in Asia, was the 14th-largest single- day decline since 2000 in the local bourse.

The weighted index has dropped by over 1,000 points from a relative high of 8,300 points two weeks ago, which means that every retail investor suffered a loss of NT$350,000 (US$10,940) on average -- dashing investors' high hopes for a "new year bonus."
Analysts pointed out that Taiwanese investor confidence remained shaky amid selling pressure, with only four days to go before the Feb. 14 Lunar New Year.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue.
The China Times:

Three major institutional investors sold a total of NT$19.8 billion-worth of Taiwanese shares Friday, with foreign investors selling out NT$15.7 billion (US$490 million) of stocks. DRAM, flat panel displays, notebooks and financial shares were under heavy selling pressure.

As of Feb. 5, foreign institutional investors had sold a combined NT$l17.2 billion worth in net value of Taiwanese shares over the past 11 trading sessions, while the weighted index had plunged by more than 1,100 points, or 13.5 percent.

Market observers attributed the plunge to the drops in global stock markets and profit-taking on the local bourse after a 70 percent surge last year due to a continued influx of hot money from around the world.

Although Taiwanese shares plunged heavily Friday, market turnover stood at NT$121.69 billion -- a sign that investors are still optimistic about the local bourses' future performance, financial officials said. (Feb. 6, 2010).
The Liberty Times:

With the plummets in the U.S. and European markets and grave concern among investors as the 11-day Lunar New Year holiday approaches, share prices fell like dominoes Friday on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex).

In the face of uncertainties in the international stock market, analysts said fearful Taiwanese investors will not risk maintaining their share holdings through the holiday and predicted that selling pressure in the local bourse will persist until Feb. 12, the last trading day before the market closes Feb. 13.
As the Taiex is closely linked to the performance of the world's major stock markets, foreign investors are likely to continue selling Taiwanese shares if the U.S. stock market finishes lower Friday.

Cheng Cheng-mount, a leading analyst at Citibank Taiwan, said strong doubts about the euro zone defaults remain, as the incident is still brewing. But he attributed the global market falls to the credit-tightening measures adopted by China and the U.S. rather than to the troubles facing Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain, which are having difficulties paying their sovereign debts. (Feb. 6, 2010)
The United Daily News:

The amount of marginal trading, which signals the movement of retail investors in the stock market, plummeted NT$6.3 billion on Friday alone. With the rout in the U.S. and European markets, foreign institutional investors who had been investing in the local bourse began pulling their capital out of Taiwan in recent days. Foreign investors recorded a net sale of NT$117.2 billion worth of Taiwanese shares over the past 11 trading sessions.

An initial investigation has found that Taiwan's financial institutions' exposure to the debts of Portugal, Spain and Greece stands close to NT$16 billion, a level that experts think does not merit overreaction.

But the local currency sharply depreciated NT$0.167 Friday to close at NT$32.187 against the greenback in the Taipei foreign exchange market -- the lowest in more than one month -- as a result of foreign investors' heavy remittances of capital out of Taiwan after selling their Taiwanese holdings. (Feb. 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Probe into 2nd financial reform scandal
DOC.DATELINE: 02/06/10 17:59:33 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Supreme Prosecutors Office's special investigation division (SID) launched a search Feb. 5 of 11 offices of the Taipei-based Taishin Financial Holdings Co. (TFH) and interrogated TFH Chairman Thomas T.L. Wu.

According to the office, during its investigation into alleged scandals involving the second phase of financial reforms promoted by former President Chen Shui-bian in 2004, the SID discovered that the private banking group might have been part of illegal conduct during the process when it bought preferred stocks of the Chang Hwa Bank in 2005.
The deal made TFH the bank's largest stock holder.
It is suspected that in 2005, when the government auctioned its Chang Hwa Bank stocks, it set up regulations that helped TFH to be the largest winner of the auction.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Prosecutors and inspectors suspect that the Ministry of Finance gave TFH "technical assistance, " helping the private consortium acquire the right to control Chang Hwa Bank, a commercial bank once owned by the provincial government before privatization in 1998.
Political machinations might have been involved in the case.

Testimonies from relevant sources reveal that Thomas Wu's family is suspected of having established a connection through a middleman, former Shin Kong Hospital Vice President Huang Fang-yen, with the family of scandal-ridden former President Chen Shui-bian.
Wu's financial offers to Chen's family gave him access to the presidential residence.

The SID found that Huang was commissioned by former first lady Wu Shu-chen to handle her financial affairs and that massive cash transactions were recorded in Chen's election account at Taishin Bank. The SID suspects that Taishin might have benefited from its direct connection with the Chen family.
China Times:
Commenting on the SID search, TFH spokesman Lin Ko-hsiao said the company had cooperated with the investigators and that the raid had not affected TFH's financial and business operations.
On the Taiwan stock market, the price of TFH stocks plummeted to a nearly six- month low of NT$10.45 per share Friday.

TFH stated that it hoped its control over the Chang Hwa Bank would help offset the two companies' separate weaknesses. However, because of political interference, its 300,000 stockowners suffered losses, it said.
In a statement released Friday, TFH said it would cooperate fully with the investigation but would take legal action against any defamation.
Commercial Times:
SID Director Chen Yun-lin said TFH Chairman Thomas Wu has been listed as a defendant after SID prosecutors and inspectors conducted asearch for evidence at 11 TFH offices Friday.

On an accusation that Wu bribed former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife Wu Shu-chen before his company invested in the Chang Hwa Bank, Chen Yun-lin said further investigation is needed on the case.
Liberty Times:
Chen instructed during the implementation of his second phase of financial reforms in 2004 that mergers of local banks must be completed within a certain timeframe.
At that time, there were rumors that administration departments had assisted certain financial holding companies in turning themselves into a major banking consortium through mergers.

After the former president and his wife were found to have been involved in many corruption scandals, the SID launched a full investigation into bank accounts of the Chen family, discovering suspicious funds the former first lady claimed were donations from local entrepreneurs.
The funds included NT$50 million that Thomas Wu said was a "political donation" to Chen. The testimony, however, has failed to convince the prosecutors. (Feb. 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan among world's lowest fertility rates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 18:36:08 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is among the bottom countries in the world in terms of fertility rate, with a total fertility rate (TFR) -- the annual number of births per 1,000 of the total population -- at just 8.3, comparable to Germany and even lower than the traditionally low fertility countries such as Austria and Japan.
Statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior Saturday indicate that in 2009, there were 191,310 babies born in Taiwan, a decrease of 3.7 percent from the previous year.
Meanwhile, as more and more Taiwanese have married foreigners, 10 percent of the babies born last year were children of such marriages.

Meanwhile, the 2009 world population data sheet released recently by the U.S. Population Reference Bureau indicates that while Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, in recent years have joined various European countries with low fertility, Taiwan had the lowest TFR among Asian countries last year.
Globally, Monaco had the lowest birth rate, with just seven new births per 1,000, followed by Taiwan and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Luxury house tax is phony issue

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance decided recently that Taipei City should take the lead in imposing a luxury house tax, which seems to reflect concerns by the government on soaring house prices and the widening gap between the rich and poor.
But thinking more deeply, one can see that the issue is a phony one designed by the government to divert public attention.

The concept began being promoted by the nation's top economic planner -- the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) -- late last year. Scholars suggested to the CEPD at that time that an additional tax -- a luxury house tax -- should be levied.
However, the Ministry of Finance's approach has been to increase existing housing tax rates, which goes against public expectations on tax reform.

The level of housing prices reflects supply and demand in the market. If the government does not start with the basics -- the rule of the game -- such as financial policy, the openness and transparency of property price information, and the use and overall planning of land resources, a simple adjustment of the tax system will never be successful.

In addition, housing and land are inseparable. If the Ministry of Finance wants to raise housing values to achieve its end of imposing a heavy tax on luxury houses, then it should take the complementary measure of raising land prices.

Moreover, housing taxes are local government taxes. Although the tax law stipulates that the standard price should be reassessed every three years, the assessed price and the real housing price have a huge gap due to the laziness of the local assessment committee.
Whether from the perspective of curbing the surging housing prices or promoting fair taxes, the use of increasing assessed values to impose a luxury housing tax will only be a half-hearted approach.
If we support the measure, it will simply be because "to have done something is better than to have done nothing" and will not show any kind of measure of confidence in the government's move.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changing administration districts promotes competitiveness: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 19:00:46 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Saturday that a move to change the administrative district map is being taken to promote Taiwan's competitiveness.

As leader of the country, Ma said at a gathering in Taoyuan County attended by the mayors of township-level cities that he cares about "the happiness of the next generation rather than the next election. "

He made the remarks after many of the mayors expressed concern that their cities will be marginalized after Taipei County is upgraded into a municipality at the end of the year, while Taichung City and Taichung County will be merged into a single municipality, as well as Tainan City and Tainan County, and Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.
Currently, only Taipei City and Kaohsiung City are municipalities under the direct jurisdiction of the central government.
According to Ma, the formation of the five municipalities was designed so that the government can control the direction of future national development in order to boost the nation's competitiveness.
He said it is a model that is being adopted by many cities and countries in Asia.
In an attempt to pacify the mayors, Ma promised that funding for local governments will be allocated fairly.

Also that day Ma, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, attended an election activity in Taoyuan to stump for Apollo Chen, the party's candidate in an legislative by-election slated for Feb. 27.
Ma said the party must spare no efforts to achieve victory in the upcoming battle after its dismal showing in three Jan. 9 legislative by-elections in Taoyuan, Taichung and Taitung counties.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won all three seats contested in Taoyuan, Taichung and Taitung counties to boost its seats in the legislature from 27 to 30. With more than 25 percent of the seats in the 113-member Legislative Yuan, the DPP caucus is now capable of launching motions to amend the Constitution or recall the president

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: The DPP's blind spot

TEXT.P: A major issue currently being discussed inside the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is whether the party's nominee for the 2012 presidential election should first undergo the test of the elections slated for late 2010 in five new special municipalities.

Precedent was set by former president Chen Shui-bian, who was elected to the presidency in 2000 after losing a Taipei mayoral re-election bid in 1998. An election loss in Taipei City has since become a lucky symbol and a path that DPP presidential aspirants must take.

Following this format was Frank Hsieh, who ran for the 2008 presidency after losing a 2006 mayoral bid in the capital city. Hsieh, however, was again defeated. Despite this unsuccessful example, major DPP members still think aspirants should first embark on a crusade for the party before they can become a presidential nominee.

However, the situation might be different now that the DPP has scored landslide wins in the December 2009 three-in-one elections and the January by-elections for three legislative seats. Thanks to President Ma Ying-jeou's low approval rating, the DPP is likely to again achieve an overwhelming victory in the year- end special municipality elections. Under these circumstances, it would be inconceivable to nominate someone who has just been elected mayor to run immediately for the next presidency.

It is regrettable that DPP has turned what are supposed to be election expediencies into normal party operations. It seems that the DPP has still has a long way to go before it can become a normal political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: What happened to Toyota?

TEXT.P: The auto market has gradually rebounded, but major car maker Toyota has had to recall 2.3 million vehicles over a faulty gas pedal, as well as suffering brake problems with its hybrid Prius.
In January, Toyota car sales dropped 16 percent in the U.S., while sales of its major rivals -- Ford, Nissan and General Motors -- increased by 25 percent, 16 percent, 14 percent, respectively.

Another Japanese car maker, Honda, also announced the recall of 646,000 cars due to possible overheating of power windows. But they were cars for overseas markets. The Japanese versions had no such problem as they use different parts.

It seems that the factors affecting the landscape of the car market will not be confined to new energy technology or new emerging markets. Future car makers will also face big changes in production modes.
That is, cost-cutting will require more and more outsourcing and sharing parts, creating a problem of how to maintain quality.

The auto production model has gradually shifted to one similar to the division of labor in the production of computer parts. As long as a company can design and has money, it can become a brand car maker because most of the parts will be outsourced.

For example, different car makers and car brands could use the same engines produced by an engine supplier. Thus, even if Mitsubishi Motors had no big global market share, it would still be the largest engine supplier for Chinese vehicles.
Under this trend, Taiwan's auto parts sector is promising, because it has good quality and cheap prices.
More importantly, Taiwanese businessmen have learned how to create parts supply chains by making good use of Asian production resources.
We are looking forward to seeing the emergence of a car parts equivalent of electronics giant Hon Hai in Taiwan. (Feb. 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Renewable energy policy to start this year: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 19:53:08 (By J.T. Hsu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite considerable difficulties at present in the government's efforts to promote a renewable energy policy, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung- chiou said Saturday the policy must be implemented this year.

Speaking at a public hearing on the issue held by lawmaker Cheng Lee-wen at the Legislative Yuan and attended by government officials, academics and business representatives, Hwang made it clear that the policy must hit the road in 2010, although he admitted that this will be difficult to implement.

"It might seem an easy task to promote the policy in theory, but it is actually almost a political mission impossible in practice, if we take the ensuing difficulties into consideration, " he explained, adding that persuading Taiwanese households to pay higher monthly water fees after the implementation of the policy would be particularly difficult.

As an example of this, Hwang said, Taipei City once tried to impose a NT$0.5 hike in the unit price for water, but the proposal was met with strong objections from local councilors. At present, each unit in Taipei City costs NT$7.8, lower than the NT$10 charged in the rest of the country.
Taiwan's water price, far below the cost of production, is extremely cheap compared with developed countries.

Taiwanese families spend 0.5 percent-0.6 percent of their annual expenditure on piped water each year, much lower than the 2 percent-4 percent suggested by the World Health Organization, a local water company said.

Environmental Protection Administration Minister Steven Shen, who also attended the hearing, suggested that auxiliary measures should be put in place across the board to be in line with the implementation of the renewable energy policy, following the method used in Germany.
According to Sheng, Germany is the only country in the world that has succeeded in holding on to a renewable energy policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 cell phone fraud calls per day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 20:06:36 (By Carol Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The number of telephone scams in which callers try to defraud people of money, averages 10,000 per day in Taiwan, a major telecommunications operator estimated Saturday.

Taiwan Mobile said it has spent more than NT$10 million (US$311,530) on developing interception measures in a bid to protect the interests of subscribers and cut the harassment by fraudsters to a minimum.
Just one month after adopting measures to intercept scam calls, Taiwan Mobile reported that it had blocked 77,000 such calls.
The company found that the number of calls blocked during weekdays accounts for 90 percent of the week's total, with calls peaking on Wednesdays.
The major time period of scam calls was between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., with the number of calls blocked during the period accounting for 87 percent of the day.

The number of calls blocked was the highest at 9 a.m., showing that the scamsters use a time when people are going to work or schools, and when public offices open, to confuse the receiver into thinking that the calls are real.
The criminals often use fake telephone numbers of government agencies so that people receiving the calls think that they have received calls from police stations or prosecutors office.
Police station numbers are most often used by the fraud rings in Taiwan, with the number of intercepted calls supposedly from such facilities reaching as high as 6,000 per month.
In terms of localities, people in Taipei County, Taipei City and Taoyuan County received the most phone scam calls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Certain outside foods to be allowed in movie theaters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 20:13:25 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Outside food is to be allowed to be consumed in movie theaters, except foods with a strong odor such as fermented bean curd and fried chicken, an official from the Government Information Office announced Saturday.
Many movie theaters prohibit outside food and drink from being consumed on the premises, so that moviegoers wishing to eat snacks while watching a movie must buy from the theater's concession stands.

The GIO will make formal announcement Feb. 8 that effective immediately, movie theaters must not impose a ban on outside food and drink, but will suggest that moviegoers refrain from bringing in foods with strong odor or snacks that are noisy to eat, such as melon seeds.
The authorities will make random inspections of theaters to make sure they are not maintaining an outside food ban, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP bigwig expresses support in Taichung mayoral election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 20:31:18 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweight Frank Hsieh broke his silence Saturday over his preferred candidate in the year-end election for the first mayor of the new municipality of a merged Taichung City and Taichung County.

Hsieh, who served as premier for less than a year between 2005 and 2006, made public his support Saturday in the central Taiwan city for DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung, saying he would be a perfect candidate.

The merger is part of the government's move to change the administration district map, which will also see Taipei County upgraded into a municipality, while Tainan City and Tainan County will be merged into a single municipality, as well as Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.
The mayoral elections of the five municipalities -- including Taipei City -- are planned to take place in late 2010, just before the new administration districts are formally established.
Most of the DPP bigwigs, including incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu and former Premier Su Tseng-chang, have been tight-lipped on whether they will run.
Hsieh said he also wants to help DPP candidates win the Feb. 27 legislative by- elections in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Chiayi County and Hualien County.
Upon being informed of Hsieh's support, Lin said he will spare no effort to seek the party's nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior foreign couple tie knot in Tainan City
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/10 20:48:52 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A positively venerable foreign couple got married Saturday in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan in a traditional Chinese ceremony.

Britton Chance, a 96-year-old U.S. visiting professor at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City, and his 62-year-old Japanese bride, Shoko Nioka, tied the knot at the Eternal Golden Castle -- one of the most famous historic remnants in the southern city.

The wedding ceremony, witnessed and blessed by Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, took place according to traditional rituals with music provided by a Chinese folk music orchestra and a parade of wedding assistants in ancient garb bearing the bride in a sedan chair.
"Tainan City is home to me and Britton, and that is the reason we chose to get married here amid its cultural ambiance, " said Nioka, a Kyoto native.
Chance and Nioka decided to tie the knot after knowing each other for 26 years.
Chance, who was selected as a member of the United States National Academy of Sciences in 1952, is currently teaching at NCKU.
