DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 7, or the 24th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well- loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC first lady attracts attention in Vancouver
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Canada, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/07/10 14:42:33 (By Leaf Chiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady, Chow Mei-ching, became a focus of attention in downtown Vancouver Saturday when she visited several spots where cultural activities take place.

Accompanied by her daughter Lesley Ma, Chow visited the Museum of Vancouver, where Taiwan-born Canadian artist Ed Pien is staging a solo show titled "Tracing Night" -- a large maze-like installation that combines drawing, video and sound to recreate the phenomenon of night and darkness.

Chow later visited the "Lantern Forest" -- a corridor that displays over 2,000 lanterns created by children from Canada and Taiwan designed to celebrate the Chinese New Year and the opening of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics.

After some people of Chinese or Taiwanese descent recognized Chow as the wife of Republic of China President Ma Ying-jeou and started taking pictures of her, several tourists also took out their cameras to grab some images with Taiwan's first lady.

Chow arrived in Vancouver Thursday as the honorary head of the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, marking the first time Taiwan's first lady has visited Canada since diplomatic ties were severed between the two countries in 1970.
She attended a Cloud Gate performance Friday at the Cultural Olympiad being held in the city.
Chow was also scheduled to attend a book donation ceremony at the Vancouver Public Library, where she was to read stories to local children.
Before arriving in Vancouver, she had accompanied the Cloud Gate dancers to Washington, D.C. and Chicago in the United States.
They are scheduled to return to Taiwan Feb. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan Beer production base to be set up in China
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 15:08:48 (By Feng Chau and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTLC) plans to set up a beer production base in Huaian City, in China's Jiangsu Province, to pave the way for its Taiwan Beer brand to enter China's market, Huaian Mayor Gao Xuekun said Sunday.
The plan was unveiled after TTLC set up branch offices in Beijing and Shanghai and was named as a partner in the 16th Guangzhou Asian Games last November.

Huaian, an important city in northern Jiangsu famous for its wine production, was chosen by TTLC as its beer production base because of the high quality of its artesian water. In addition to TTLC, Japan's Suntory International Corp. has also selected Hauian as amanufacturing location, according to Gao.
Earlier this year, TTLC announced plans to select an exclusive agent among five Chinese cities and to appoint a contract manufacturer to produce and package its Taiwan Beer products in China.
The company forecast that sales of Taiwan Beer this year will grow 20 times to reach NT$2 billion, according to Gao.
The Huaian city government has also been maintaining contacts with Taiwan's agricultural industry associations in the hope of attracting investment, Gao said.

To address increasing demand for freight transport following an increase in investment in the city, an airport is under construction and is scheduled to open in the first quarter of this year, Gao noted.
The airport will initially offer flights to the major Chinese cities of Shanghai, Beijing, Shenzhen and Guangzhou and will later seek to serve direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Labeling of takeaway New Year dishes at issue

TEXT.P: Have you been cheated on purchases of takeaway Lunar New Year dishes?

One Taipei County consumers' rights protection official has taken three local convenience store chains to task on their labeling of takeaway New Year dishes made by a food processing company as "designed or prepared by chefs at five-star hotels."

Yang Shun-hui said at a Saturday news conference that she will ask FamilyMart, OK and Hi Life convenience store chains and their business associates -- the food processor and three tourist hotels in Taipei City -- to explain their takeaway dish production and labeling within one week.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Ordering takeaway Lunar New Year dishes from convenience stores has been popular in Taiwan for years.

While convenience store chains tend to advertise their dishes as being prepared by award-winning cooks or chefs at five-star hotels, Yang said the dishes are all actually made by a food processor in the county's Yingge township.

Yang noted that she personally ordered a FamilyMart taro cake -- a popular festive snack -- which the convenience store claimed in its advertising as having been made by a culinary team headed by Lo Chin-han, who won a world gastronomy contest last year.
"After I picked up the product recently, I found that the product was actually prepared by a factory called the AWH food processing company," Yang said.
According to initial investigations, Yang went on, the food processor in Yingge township has also produced takeaway New Year dishes for the OK and Hi Life convenience store chains.

Yang said that although the OK convenience store chain has advertised its New Year dishes as being "designed" rather than " personally made" by three chefs at Taipei's Grand Hotel, it has failed to label them as having actually been made in a factory.
By advertising their takeaway dishes as having been made by noted chefs, Yang said, the convenience store chains might be misleading consumers for the sake of profit.

Yang said her office will invite executives from the store chains, hotels and the processing company in the coming week to clarify relevant issues and will ask them to honestly identify the genuine producer of their takeaway dishes.

Under the terms of the Fair Trade Act and the Consumer Protection Act, companies that run misleading advertisements can be slapped with fines ranging between NT$50,000 and NT$25 million. (Feb. 7, 2010)
Liberty Times:
AWH manager Chen Chun-yuan said convenience store chains and noted hotels have cooperated with food processors in marketing takeaway festive dishes for many years.
"While we are responsible for production, the ingredients and flavors are chosen and decided by each store chain or hotel for exclusive sale under specific brand names," Chen said.

Both FamilyMart and Grand Hotel executives confirmed that it is actually AWH and not the noted chefs that makes the food. They said AWH has been certified as a good manufacturing food processor with GMP and HACCP logos and added that they do not know why the county official would take issue with their products after the business has been in place for so many years.
Yang said the stores should inform consumers about who really produces their food. (Feb. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Digital publishing in cross-strait's good books
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 16:12:43 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The development of the electronic publishing industry is in the best interests of both Taiwan and China and the two sides are coming to terms with each other to jointly tap the vast Chinese-language e-book market, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

Officials from the MOEA and the non-profit Institute for Information Industry have been exchanging views with their Chinese counterparts on technical integration and standardization of the digital content of the e-publishing industry, including simplified and traditional Chinese characters as well as the different terms and phrases used on the two sides for identical ideas, the MOEA said.
China's vast Chinese-language market is the key to a boom in Taiwan's electronic publishing industry and e-book development, the officials said.

With anticipation of booming development in the e-publishing market and the pitching in of big makers such as AU Optronics, Delta and Hon Hai, Taiwanese companies' global output of e-books is expected to increase by NT$30 billion (US$937.5 million) in two years to reach NT$42 billion, they predicted.

At present, Taiwanese companies dominate some 80 percent of the components and related hardware used in the world's e-book manufacturing industry, with sales topping a combined NT$12 billion per year.
Meanwhile, the MOEA predicted that the number of e-book readers in Taiwan will have reached 10,000 by the end of 2010 and grow 100-fold to hit 1 million by 2013.

The ministry will also funnel NT$2.13 billion over the next five years into creating large Chinese-language content trading centers, promoting e-learning model projects and seeking cooperation between Taiwan's and China's publishing markets, as well as subsidizing the research and development of related industries, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trade body to focus promotions on China's second-tier cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 16:37:11 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foremost semi-official trade promotion organization will assist local manufactures of consumer electronics to take part in trade fairs in China's second-tier cities this year, with the aim of boosting their products' visibility in the targeted cities.

The plan was mapped out after several Taiwanese electronics spare parts and flat panel manufacturers successfully tapped into the vast Chinese market by capitalizing on a subsidy program launched by China in 2009 to boost electronic appliance sales in rural areas, said Huang Wen-jung, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
The subsidy program has been beneficial mainly to Taiwanese flat panel and spare parts producers, but not to its finished product manufacturers, Huang said.

Chinese products account for 80 percent of the country's total TV market, with the other 20 percent shared by Japan and South Korean products. Taiwan's TV manufacturers do not have much of a market share there, Huang added.

Therefore, TAITRA plans to help Taiwanese manufacturers take part in trade shows in China's second-tier cities, which include Tianjin, Jinan, Dongguan, Chongqing and Chengdu, as costs for promotion in first-tier cities are considered too high, said Huang.

Although Acer and Asus -- Taiwan's two leading providers of computers -- have a presence in China, it is much smaller than that of China's Lenovo, Huang went on, adding that there is a need to promote Taiwanese name brand products in China.

According to market research firm DisplaySearch, LCD TV shipments in China are set to top 33 million in 2010, up from 25 million in 2009. The shipments will reach 372 million in 2011, surpassing the total units projected for the whole North American market and making China the biggest LCD TV market in the world, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Earthquake off Hualien coast

TEXT.P: A quake measuring 6.3 on the Richter scale took place off the coast of Hualien in eastern Taiwan at 2: 30 p.m. Sunday, with no casualties or damage reported as of press time.
The Hualien Weather Station said the epicenter of the temblor was located at 23.35 degrees north, 123.09 degrees east, or 165.7 km east-southeast of the station, at a depth of 15.5 km.

The quake was felt by residents in Yilan, Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, as well as in Kaohsiung in the south and Taipei in the north, with the highest intensity recorded as 3.0. (By Andrew J.T. Liu and Bear Lee ).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Transfer voting wave of the future
DOC.DATELINE: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 02/07/10 16:59:46 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: launched a "coming home to vote" drive last year, ahead of the three-in-one elections, to encourage its supporters to return to the districts of their household registrations to cast their ballots.

The party, however, immediately voiced objection to a recent Interior Ministry proposal to devise a transfer ballot system that would allow eligible voters to cast their ballots in the constituencies where they work instead of the areas of their household registrations.

The DPP's opposition is unwarranted, particularly since the ministry has clearly ruled out the inclusion of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and other overseas emigres into the application of the proposed transfer ballot system.
Transfer voting is a form of absentee voting that also includes voting by mail, proxy voting, designated voting and advance voting.

Voting by mail is the most popular form of absentee voting, but it is not expected to be implemented in Taiwan in the foreseeable future because of widespread misgivings of possible Chinese influence in Taiwan's elections through the large numbers of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

The Interior Ministry has decided not to adopt the postal voting system, at least at present, and will instead focus on promoting a transfer ballot system allowing those who cannot vote in their hometowns on election day to register in advance to cast their ballots in the areas in which they work.
Many people could be eligible to apply for transfer voting, including soldiers, police officers, prison inmates, students and white-collar and blue-collar workers.
According to government statistics, at least 15 percent of local people do not reside or work in the areas of their household registrations.

In light of protecting the civil rights of such a large group of people and reducing social costs, the government should introduce a transfer ballot system as soon as possible. If it does not, the government might violate its constitutional obligations.

Under the current Public Officials Election and Recall Law, polling station staff can cast their ballots at polling stations in which they work instead of the areas of their household registration. With this precedent in place, the government should not drag its feet in preparing for installing this system on a larger scale.

The DPP should also stop its opposition and instead push for its implementation at an early date for the convenience of its supporters who work outside their hometowns or areas of their household registrations. (Feb. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier demands curb on ministerial by-election canvassing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 17:24:39 (By Chen Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Cabinet officials should observe certain principles when they canvass votes or stump for candidates in the upcoming legislative by-elections, Premier Wu Den- yih said Sunday.

Wu said he does not oppose ministerial-level officials canvassing votes for ruling Kuomintang (KMT) candidates running in the by-elections for four legislative seats slated for Feb. 27, but said that the vote-soliciting initiatives must not run against party or government norms.

He said the vote-canvassing initiatives must be carried out under the principles that the activity does not contradict the propriety of the minister's position, that no national resources or budget should be used for particular candidates and that the officials must be careful with their language when canvassing.
The premier pinpointed the ministers of justice and education, as well as the director-general of the National Police Agency, as being unsuitable for appearances at stumping functions.
He said that while civil servants have the right to extend verbal support for election candidates when they are off-duty, such stumping must not be "too much."

The KMT has fielded Chen Shueh-sheng, Cheng Yung-tang, Lin Teh-jui and Wang Ting-sheng as candidates in the Feb. 27 legislative by-elections for Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Chiayi and Hualien counties, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon donates NT$600 million to charity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 17:29:40 (By Pan Su-tien and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou said Sunday at a charity carnival that it was his happiest day since the financial crisis erupted as he made a donation of NT$300 million (US$9.38 million) to several social welfare organizations.

At the event held by the Yong Lin Charity Foundation -- which he founded -- the business tycoon also donated another NT$300 million to expand elementary schools for children in remote areas and poor families.

Guo said that he had been gloomy since Taiwan was hit by the global financial crisis and Typhoon Morakot last year. However, he said he finally felt happy again after seeing so many people turn out for the carnival.

He said the carnival was aimed at raising funds ahead of the Chinese New Year for various social groups in view of an imbalanced distribution of social resources following the channeling of most donations into Morakot-affected areas, resulting in insufficient financial support for many social welfare groups.
The event gathered together a large number of entertainers and celebrities, as well as some 1,000 Hon Hai employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: What makes people dislike reading

TEXT.P: This year' s basic competitive tests -- used to gauge the academic performance of senior school students applying for enrollment in universities -- just drew to an end, and many said that the subject title of the Chinese composition -- "The soliloquy of driftwood" -- was among the best the tests have had. In general, though, the questions in the Chinese test were deemed too difficult for most of the examinees.

The Chinese course offered to students has many missions -- to cultivate their ability to think about life, to know the world, to deal properly with things and people and to train their ability of expression. It even involves an ideological dispute -- the ratio of the classical and vernacular Chinese articles to be presented in the text books.

It is no wonder, then, that many students have to attend additional Chinese courses at cram schools after their normal school studies in order to score well -- a phenomenon that confuses many parents, who themselves had to attend cram classes when they were students, but only for English, mathematics and the sciences.

The purpose of the Chinese course should be to cultivate students' interest in Chinese language, literacy and creativity, developing in them the habit of reading that will stay with them for life rather than just to cope with exams.
Without cultivating the reading habit among students, who can expect them to love reading after leaving campus? This is why the number of people who love reading is declining in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: On the brink of `monetary war'

TEXT.P: In the wake of the recent global financial crisis, the thorny issue regarding the Chinese currency's exchange rate has again surfaced, particularly after China outshone all other countries around the world by registering an enviable 8.7 percent growth in 2009.

U.S. President Barack Obama recently vowed to keep pressure on countries whose currencies have been unnaturally undervalued and whose markets have not been open enough in proportion to thier economic strength.

Obama's statement should not be taken lightly, as it could be a harbinger for a "monetary war" over currency exchange rates that might stymie the current fragile global economic recovery and send the world's financial markets into disarray again.

Thanks to its continued huge trade surpluses, China had grossed more than US$2.4 trillion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of 2009. The amount was only US$330 billion in 2003. The figures indicate how fast China's trade surplus is growing.

In terms of normal market mechanisms, countries that enjoy huge trade surpluses should allow their currencies to appreciate to reflect their economic might. Otherwise, their trade partners and competitors will not have any more means to trade with them.

Over the years, the United States has incurred a huge trade deficit with China, partly because China has deliberately pegged its currency, the renminbi, to the U.S. greenback at a fixed rate -- about RMB6.83 to the U.S. dollar at present.

By so doing, the Chinese currency has also depreciated against the currencies of other major countries such as the euro and the Japanese yen, which has in turn allowed China to enjoy trade surpluses with European countries and Japan.

In the long run, many countries could join the United States in protest against China's refusal to allow its currency to appreciate to a level that fairly reflects its economic might and trade competitiveness.

More worrisome is that some developing countries, such as Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and even Taiwan and South Korea, have also been hurt by the renminbi's unnaturally low value. Worse still, these countries will not adjust their currency exchange rates or monetary policies until China appreciates its currency, for fear of undermining their trade competitiveness.

With international pressure increasing on China, the renminbi appreciation may be an inevitable trend. Taiwan's government and businesses should be prepared and should work out response measures in advance to mitigate any possible adverse impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma entertains children at party
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 19:07:01 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou hosted a party at the Presidential Office Sunday to entertain some 400 disadvantaged children to mark Chinese New Year's Day, which this year falls on Feb. 14.

The children were mostly from orphanages, foster homes, low-income families, families displaced by Typhoon Morakot last year, kindergartens in aboriginal areas, and those who are mentally or physically challenged.

At the party, Ma spoon-fed a wheelchair-bound 10-year-old girl who suffers from cerebral palsy with cake. He said to the child's grandmother, who was also present that "it is indeed tough for you (to raise a child like this)."

Foot and mouth painter and calligrapher Chen Wen-chieh was one of the few adult guests at Sunday's function. Chen wrote with a brush held in his right foot the Chinese character "yung, " meaning "courage," on a folding fan and gave it to Ma as a present.
In return, Ma also wrote with a brush -- although with his hand -- the Chinese character, "ai, " meaning "love, " on another folding fan that he gave to Chen.
He played host to the children, introducing the nearly 100-year-old Presidential Office building and telling them that "this is where I work."

He told them that more than 500 typhoon evacuee families are moving into new homes at the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation Park built in Shanlin township, Kaohsiung County, one of the areas hardest-hit by Morakot.
"We hope that all the rest of the displaced families will be settled by the end of this year," he went on.
He called for the country to trust the government in its resolve and efforts to facilitate post-disaster reconstruction despite the many difficulties and challenges.
Ma also urged the children to get vaccinated against influenza H1N1, saying that only when one has good health can one lead a normal life with good prospects for the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government relaxes visa restrictions on Tibetan monks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 19:37:27 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government relaxed Sunday visa restrictions on Tibetan monks seeking to stay in Taiwan to disseminate Tibetan Buddhism, according to the Cabinet- level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.
Under the new regulations, effective immediately, Tibetan monks who are in Taiwan on two-month visas can apply to have their visas extended for two more months.
"They can apply for a visa extension twice, " said Kao Su-po, the commission's minister.

Kao also noted that 81 refugees classified as Tibetans who had overstayed their visitor visas were granted resident status in Taiwan last November based on amendments to the Immigration Act that were passed in January 2009.
Fifty-four other Tibetans who had also overstayed their visas failed to pass identification reviews by the commission, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Self-delusion leads nowhere

TEXT.P: Tourism is one of the six emerging industries that the President Ma Ying-jeou administration has targeted for vigorous promotion to boost Taiwan's competitiveness and sustain its economic growth.

As part of its efforts to realize the goal, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has launched a program to select 10 potential sites for intensified development into new tourist attractions.
According to the ministry's selection criteria, the qualified locations should be unique and should be able to persuade foreign tourists to stay for at least a day.
Much to our disappointment, however, none of the five locations announced by the ministry so far meet its own criteria, far less symbolize Taiwan's image or special characteristics.

The five places selected by the ministry are Taichung City's Chingkuo Boulevard near the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts, the vicinity of Taipei City's Confucius Temple, Taipei County's Shuinandong, Jinguashi and Jiufen area, Changhua County's Lugang and Fuhsing townships, and Pingtung County's Hengchun old town.

While the ministry is eyeing developing Chingkuo Boulevard into a shopping center patterned after Paris' Champs-Elysees dotted with brand name stores, the other four areas are mostly historical relics with relative short histories in terms of world standards.

Our view is that none of them is unique or special enough to attract foreign tourists to travel a long way to visit. The ministry should change its way of thinking, otherwise, it will only end up misleading travelers into overlooking other Taiwan locations that are charming and far more worthy of a visit. (Feb. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier: No preference for presidential over cabinet system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:40:09 (By Chou Yung-chieh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that he will respect the legislature if it moves to amend the Constitution in deciding whether either a presidential or cabinet political system should be adopted.
Wu said both systems have their own advantages and disadvantages, and that he will respect the legislative decision.
Wu was responding to a proposal raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Huang Yi- chiao at a luncheon party the premier attended with lawmakers from constituencies in central Taiwan.
Huang said a cabinet government system would be more suitable for Taiwan and that a constitutional amendment to achieve this end is necessary.

According to Huang, the inflated power wielded by the president under the presidential system tends to cause national uncertainty should the head of the state appear motivated to incite ethnic confrontations or negative political competition for personal gain, which he said can be seen in many other countries.

Under a cabinet system, he contended, national conflict is unlikely, as all the cabinet ministers, selected from among legislators who are all elected by voters, are subject to oversight by the public.

Many political analysts have categorized Taiwan's present government system as a "mix" between the two systems, with the premier -- the head of the administration and held accountable to the legislature -- being actually the president's "chief of staff."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT secretary-general vows to consolidate pan-blue camp
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:41:28 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will step up efforts to unify the "pan-blue camp" ahead of the year-end elections for mayors and councilors of the five special municipalities, the party's top day-to-day manager said Sunday.
"Previous records show that the `pan-blue camp' has scored wins in major elections only when its ranks stood united and worked in concert," said KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung.

Noting that preparing for the year-end elections is like playing a game of chess, King said the "pan-blue camp" must consolidate at every step and act cautiously if it wants to emerge as a true victor.
In terms of candidate nominations, King continued, the KMT will adopt a flexible approach in which each area's special political or demographic situations will be taken into account.
"We will speed up our preparations and come up with a nomination list as soon as possible," he added.

He was responding to reports that the KMT's pan-blue allies -- the New Party and the People First Party -- will nominate their own members to run for seats on the councils of the five special municipalities.

Sources said the two KMT-allied pro-unification parties will field their own candidates in the elections because they are dissatisfied with what they see as President Ma Ying-jeou's inability to take firm steps to promote closer relations across the Taiwan Strait and to more effectively investigate corruption allegations against officials of the former Democratic Progressive Party administration.

New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming said recently that his party will definitely nominate its own candidates in each Taipei City constituency, as well as in some districts in the four other municipalities.

People First Party Chairman James Soong has also been preparing for the year-end elections. In addition to fielding candidates for councilor elections, the party is also considering fielding hopefuls for the mayoral elections in some of the municipalities, sources close to the party said.

The four other municipalities are New Taipei City (an upgrade of Taipei County), Taichung City (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County), Tainan City (a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County), and Kaohsiung City (a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan blanked 4-0 by South Korea in women's football
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:52:49 (By Mike Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was blanked 4-0 Sunday in its first game of the 2010 East Asia Football Federation (EAFF) Women's Football Championship in the Japanese capital.
Korea scored in the 27th, 28th and 45th minutes of the first half, putting the final nail in Taiwan's coffin in the 74th minute.
However, Taiwanese coach Chou Tai-ying said at a post-match press conference that she was satisfied with the performance of her players, although there was room for improvement.

She said the Taiwanese played a mostly defensive game in the first half, but did pose a threat to their South Korean rivals in the second half after changing to an offensive strategy, although they were unable to score throughout the game.
The Taiwanese girls will take on Japan, which is considered most likely to win the title and US$50,000 prize money, on Feb. 11. Four teams, including China, are competing in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Central bank moves to contain speculation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange market experienced roller coaster fluctuations Saturday, attributed by traders to central bank intervention aimed at discouraging speculation that it fears could hurt the economy.

The New Taiwan dollar rose by NT$0.487 to as high as NT$31.70 against the U.S. dollar Saturday, its strongest intraday level since Jan. 15, before paring its gains to end the session largely flat at NT$32.184.

The dramatic fluctuations were widely seen as the result of the central bank's action to combat hot money, however, they also signaled the central bank's determination to hold the local currency at around NT$32.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: Liberty Times:
The central bank's intervention was in line with its monetary policy aimed at maintaining commodity prices and financial stability for long-term economic growth.
Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan warned in a report released Saturday that the nature of a financial crisis is reflected in financial instability and big ups and downs in the assets market.
Perng attributed the global financial crisis partially to financial supervisory systems' failure to keep up the pace of financial liberalization and the process of financial innovation.

The development of a more market-oriented global financial system coupled with financial liberalization and globalization has not only given a boost to the financial and banking sector and facilitated the free flow of capital across borders, but has also triggered financial crises, according to Perng.
He said finding ways to prevent financial crises in the future will be a key issue all over the world. Economic Daily News:
The central bank said in the report that inaccurate forecasts by researchers should also be held responsible for the financial crisis.

It ascribed the financial crisis to people's irrationality that might have caused assets bubbles, as well as illegal operations by financial institutions such as providing fake account books and hollowing out company assets.

The central bank said financial supervisors should conduct reforms that include strengthening the monitoring of financial institutions, giving the central bank a free hand to correct economic imbalances and keep inflation under control.
It also suggested that policy makers should not underestimate the risks of deflation and the near-zero interest rate policy, but rather should adopt more flexible monetary policies.
Commercial Times:

Touching on measures to prevent destructive bubbles in the property and stock markets, the central bank noted that it will ask banks to tighten their lending risk management to avoid assets bubbles instead of raising interest rates or using other monetary tools to help bring down housing prices.
It also said it will work to maintain order in the foreign exchange market to damp down expectations that the New Taiwan dollar will appreciate significantly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flower season opens in southern Taiwan township
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 21:28:53 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An annual floral season in Meinung township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County opened Sunday, drawing large crowds of holidaymakers to the blossom- drenched area.

Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said he took the initiative six years ago to encourage farmers in Meinung to plant cosmos and other flowers on their land during the winter when their farms were lying fallow, in order to create a draw for visitors.

"Today, the event has blossomed into a new tourist attraction, bringing additional income to local residents, " Yang said, adding that 60 hectares of farm land in Meinung township have planted cosmos and other flowers this eyar.
Although several other Taiwan townships have followed suit, Meinung, a Hakka stronghold, is the only place where cosmos blooms around the Lunar New Year festival, Yang said.
Last year, more than 200,000 people visited Meinung during the floral season, generating lucrative business opportunities for traditional Hakka-style eateries in the township, Yang said.
This year's floral season will run until March 10, Yang said, adding that neighboring Chishan township now also boasts many floral farms with colorful cosmos and other blossoms.

A national acrobatics troupe Mongolia has been invited to perform during the Feb. 14-21 Lunar New Year holiday and many other cultural and entertainment programs will also be staged during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Self-delusion leads nowhere

TEXT.P: Tourism is one of the six emerging industries that the President Ma Ying-jeou administration has targeted for vigorous promotion to boost Taiwan's competitiveness and sustain its economic growth.

As part of its efforts to realize the goal, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has launched a program to select 10 potential sites for intensified development into new tourist attractions.
According to the ministry's selection criteria, the qualified locations should be unique and should be able to persuade foreign tourists to stay for at least a day.
Much to our disappointment, however, none of the five locations announced by the ministry so far meet its own criteria, far less symbolize Taiwan's image or special characteristics.

The five places selected by the ministry are Taichung City's Chingkuo Boulevard near the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts, the vicinity of Taipei City's Confucius Temple, Taipei County's Shuinandong, Jinguashi and Jiufen area, Changhua County's Lugang and Fuhsing townships, and Pingtung County's Hengchun old town.

While the ministry is eyeing developing Chingkuo Boulevard into a shopping center patterned after Paris' Champs-Elysees dotted with brand name stores, the other four areas are mostly historical relics with relative short histories in terms of world standards.

Our view is that none of them is unique or special enough to attract foreign tourists to travel a long way to visit. The ministry should change its way of thinking, otherwise, it will only end up misleading travelers into overlooking other Taiwan locations that are charming and far more worthy of a visit. (Feb. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier: No preference for presidential over cabinet system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:40:09 (By Chou Yung-chieh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that he will respect the legislature if it moves to amend the Constitution in deciding whether either a presidential or cabinet political system should be adopted.
Wu said both systems have their own advantages and disadvantages, and that he will respect the legislative decision.
Wu was responding to a proposal raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Huang Yi- chiao at a luncheon party the premier attended with lawmakers from constituencies in central Taiwan.
Huang said a cabinet government system would be more suitable for Taiwan and that a constitutional amendment to achieve this end is necessary.

According to Huang, the inflated power wielded by the president under the presidential system tends to cause national uncertainty should the head of the state appear motivated to incite ethnic confrontations or negative political competition for personal gain, which he said can be seen in many other countries.

Under a cabinet system, he contended, national conflict is unlikely, as all the cabinet ministers, selected from among legislators who are all elected by voters, are subject to oversight by the public.

Many political analysts have categorized Taiwan's present government system as a "mix" between the two systems, with the premier -- the head of the administration and held accountable to the legislature -- being actually the president's "chief of staff."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT secretary-general vows to consolidate pan-blue camp
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:41:28 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will step up efforts to unify the "pan-blue camp" ahead of the year-end elections for mayors and councilors of the five special municipalities, the party's top day-to-day manager said Sunday.
"Previous records show that the `pan-blue camp' has scored wins in major elections only when its ranks stood united and worked in concert," said KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung.

Noting that preparing for the year-end elections is like playing a game of chess, King said the "pan-blue camp" must consolidate at every step and act cautiously if it wants to emerge as a true victor.
In terms of candidate nominations, King continued, the KMT will adopt a flexible approach in which each area's special political or demographic situations will be taken into account.
"We will speed up our preparations and come up with a nomination list as soon as possible," he added.

He was responding to reports that the KMT's pan-blue allies -- the New Party and the People First Party -- will nominate their own members to run for seats on the councils of the five special municipalities.

Sources said the two KMT-allied pro-unification parties will field their own candidates in the elections because they are dissatisfied with what they see as President Ma Ying-jeou's inability to take firm steps to promote closer relations across the Taiwan Strait and to more effectively investigate corruption allegations against officials of the former Democratic Progressive Party administration.

New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming said recently that his party will definitely nominate its own candidates in each Taipei City constituency, as well as in some districts in the four other municipalities.

People First Party Chairman James Soong has also been preparing for the year-end elections. In addition to fielding candidates for councilor elections, the party is also considering fielding hopefuls for the mayoral elections in some of the municipalities, sources close to the party said.

The four other municipalities are New Taipei City (an upgrade of Taipei County), Taichung City (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County), Tainan City (a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County), and Kaohsiung City (a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan blanked 4-0 by South Korea in women's football
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 20:52:49 (By Mike Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was blanked 4-0 Sunday in its first game of the 2010 East Asia Football Federation (EAFF) Women's Football Championship in the Japanese capital.
Korea scored in the 27th, 28th and 45th minutes of the first half, putting the final nail in Taiwan's coffin in the 74th minute.
However, Taiwanese coach Chou Tai-ying said at a post-match press conference that she was satisfied with the performance of her players, although there was room for improvement.

She said the Taiwanese played a mostly defensive game in the first half, but did pose a threat to their South Korean rivals in the second half after changing to an offensive strategy, although they were unable to score throughout the game.
The Taiwanese girls will take on Japan, which is considered most likely to win the title and US$50,000 prize money, on Feb. 11. Four teams, including China, are competing in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Central bank moves to contain speculation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange market experienced roller coaster fluctuations Saturday, attributed by traders to central bank intervention aimed at discouraging speculation that it fears could hurt the economy.

The New Taiwan dollar rose by NT$0.487 to as high as NT$31.70 against the U.S. dollar Saturday, its strongest intraday level since Jan. 15, before paring its gains to end the session largely flat at NT$32.184.

The dramatic fluctuations were widely seen as the result of the central bank's action to combat hot money, however, they also signaled the central bank's determination to hold the local currency at around NT$32.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: Liberty Times:
The central bank's intervention was in line with its monetary policy aimed at maintaining commodity prices and financial stability for long-term economic growth.
Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan warned in a report released Saturday that the nature of a financial crisis is reflected in financial instability and big ups and downs in the assets market.
Perng attributed the global financial crisis partially to financial supervisory systems' failure to keep up the pace of financial liberalization and the process of financial innovation.

The development of a more market-oriented global financial system coupled with financial liberalization and globalization has not only given a boost to the financial and banking sector and facilitated the free flow of capital across borders, but has also triggered financial crises, according to Perng.
He said finding ways to prevent financial crises in the future will be a key issue all over the world. Economic Daily News:
The central bank said in the report that inaccurate forecasts by researchers should also be held responsible for the financial crisis.

It ascribed the financial crisis to people's irrationality that might have caused assets bubbles, as well as illegal operations by financial institutions such as providing fake account books and hollowing out company assets.

The central bank said financial supervisors should conduct reforms that include strengthening the monitoring of financial institutions, giving the central bank a free hand to correct economic imbalances and keep inflation under control.
It also suggested that policy makers should not underestimate the risks of deflation and the near-zero interest rate policy, but rather should adopt more flexible monetary policies.
Commercial Times:

Touching on measures to prevent destructive bubbles in the property and stock markets, the central bank noted that it will ask banks to tighten their lending risk management to avoid assets bubbles instead of raising interest rates or using other monetary tools to help bring down housing prices.
It also said it will work to maintain order in the foreign exchange market to damp down expectations that the New Taiwan dollar will appreciate significantly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flower season opens in southern Taiwan township
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/10 21:28:53 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 8, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/08/10 09:19:41 (By Sofia Wu)
