DOC.HEADLINE: New international driving permits will remain valid for three years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 19:08:05 (By Wang Shu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese drivers will be able to obtain international driving permits (IDPs) with a fixed term of validity of three years and will no longer need to reapply for an IDP after the expiry of their domestic driver's license, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Tuesday.
According to existing regulations, an IDP remains valid for three years from the date of issue, or until the expiration date of the holder's driver's license, whichever is earlier.
The new measure is expected to be implemented from March, after the necessary legislation has been passed, the MOTC said.

Under the present rules, if a Taiwanese driver has a driver' s license with remaining validity of two or three months, the driver can only apply for an IDP with the same remaining validity time, so that such a driver using a vehicle abroad may need to mail the IDP back to Taiwan for license renewal.
Taiwanese drivers need to renew their licenses every six years.
In the case of foreign IDP holders, however, Taiwan applies different rules depending on how foreign countries or regions reciprocate with Taiwanese IDP holders, according to the MOTC.
In general, foreign IDP holders who stay in Taiwan for 30 days or less can drive without registration.
However, if they stay in Taiwan over 30 days, they must register their IDP at the Motor Vehicle Office -- with one year the longest period for IDP registration.
If the holder's IDP or Alien Residence Certificate's validity period is less than one year, they will only be allowed to drive until the expiry date of the holder's IDP or ARC, whichever comes first.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will pull its weight to fight global warming: vice premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 19:13:17 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will pull its weight to fight global warming by restricting carbon dioxide emissions, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Tuesday.

Addressing an international seminar attended by experts from home and abroad, including Germany and the United States, who discussed innovative strategies for renewable energy development and carbon reduction, Chu said energy conservation and carbon reduction are the most important human missions in the 21st century.

With per capita carbon dioxide emissions reaching three times the world average, Chu said, Taiwan must step up its efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions in order to fulfill its obligations as a member of the global village.

To realize this policy goal, Chu said, the government has been promoting the passage of four laws on better energy management, development of renewable energy, reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and the imposition of an energy tax.

"To date, two of them -- the statutes on energy management and renewable energy development -- have cleared the Legislative Yuan and we are now pushing for enactment of the more sensitive legislation on an energy tax and a statute on carbon reduction," Chu explained.
Noting that the government has set a target of bringing the country's carbon emissions in 2020 down to the level of 2005, Chu said strenuous efforts have to be made to attain that goal.

"Even if we manage to achieve our goal, we might still fail to reach the carbon reduction target set forth in the 2009 Copenhagen Accord, " Chu said, adding that he will push for the government to work even harder in collaboration with the private sector to contribute to the carbon reduction goals.

Speaking on the same occasion, Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Taiwan is determined to learn from Germany about how to draft renewable energy development strategies.

Germany originally set a target of having renewable energy account for 12 percent of its overall energy resources by 2010. In fact, the country managed to achieve 15 percent in 2008, far ahead of its original schedule, Shen said.
"We admire Germany's achievements in this regard and we hope to learn from its successful strategy," Shen added.

According to Shen, the core of Germany's experience lies in the fact that the German government has not raised debts to expand public invesmtent in renewable energy development but has instead enhanced the wholesale prices of renewable energy to stimulate private investment in the sector.
By so doing, more than 200,000 jobs have been created, which has helped reduce Germany's unemployment rate while simultaneously boosting green energy development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over NT$21 billion for 2010 railway construction: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 19:33:21 (By S. J. Ho and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government is slated to earmark NT$21.5 billion (US$671.87 million) this year for several railway construction projects around the country, exceeding the NT$18 billion set aside for road construction, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Tuesday.
The railway construction projects will upgrade the service quality of the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA), which transports some 500,000 passengers every day, the CEPD said.

According to the CEPD, the Executive Yuan has approved projects that will see the TRA phasing out its aging rolling stock in line with an electrification plan along the 155 km rail link between Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, with various other plans awaiting approval.

To increase the self-liquidation ratio and rack up greater profits, the government will also devote funds to land development in areas adjacent to the major stations along the Hualien-Taitung line, the CEPD added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has no deadline for cross-strait trade pact: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 20:05:37 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not set a deadline for the conclusion of talks on a trade pact with China, President Ma Ying- jeou said Tuesday, one day after Taiwan's chief cross-strait negotiator said that the agreement is expected to be signed in May.
"There is no fixed schedule for the trade pact negotiations, " Ma said in the first in a series of press briefings to personally report on the progress of the negotiations.
"It is hoped that consensus will be achieved on some pressing issues before the signing of the pact," he said.
On Monday, Chiang Pin-kung, Taiwan's top negotiator with China, said that the cross-strait trade agreement is expected to be signed at the end of May, before the legislature goes into recess in June.
Meanwhile, Ma said there will be no political language in the trade pact.

"For example, terms such as 'one country-two systems, ' one China with different interpretations' and 'peaceful unification' will not appear in the pact," he said amid concerns that China is using its economic power to promote unification with Taiwan.

He also said that after the agreement is signed, there will be no need for hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese to seek jobs in China, as Taiwanese businesses will no longer need to relocate to there, but instead will set up their bases in Taiwan.
The trade pact will also attract more foreign companies to invest in Taiwan, he added.

On the issue of legislative oversight, he said that ministry officials have given several briefings to lawmakers since Taiwan and China began negotiations to further liberalize trade between the two sides.
"This operational model has worked well and is, in effect, a cross-strait task force," he said.

Further discussions will be required in order to decide whether there is need for a special task force to oversee the negotiations and whether its functions would conflict with those of existing legislative committees, he added.

Hours earlier, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus whip Lee Chun-yee said that the current legislative committees cannot adequately oversee the trade agreement negotiations. He also noted that the legislature already has several special task forces to deal with various issues.

At Ma's press conference, which drew large numbers of local and foreign reporters, he directed most of his comments to local farmers and workers, detailing reasons why Taiwan needs to sign a trade pact China.
Amid fears that farmers and laborers would suffer as result of the agreement, the president pledged not to import Chinese workers or to open the Taiwan market to more Chinese agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top women's basketball team withdraws from season
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 20:35:32 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Cathay Life women's basketball team, which has won 17 straight women's titles in Taiwan's domestic league, announced Tuesday that it will pull out of the 2010 season over a player registration controversy.

The team decided to miss the 2010 season of the Women's Super Basketball League (WSBL) over what it claims is a violation by the Chunghwa Telecom team in signing Chiang Feng-chun, a former Cathay Life star forward who came out of retirement and signed with Chunghwa Telecom, it said in a press release.
The WSBL consists of five teams and is Taiwan's top women's basketball league. The 2010 season is scheduled to begin in March.

Chiang, a national team regular, returned to basketball one year after a surprising retirement in February 2009 at the age of 28. Her unexpected return sparked controversy and highlighted an "unwritten rule" that Taiwanese women players stay with a single team throughout their careers or face being boycotted by the other teams if they try to switch teams.
The teams invest millions of dollars in every player and it is unfair for teams to lose players to other teams, according to Cathay Life assistant coach Chien Wei-chuan.

The Chinese Taipei Basketball Association (CTBA) , Taiwan's highest basketball governing body, changed the rule in 2008 when lawyers said it violated the Constitution, which rules that people's right to work should be protected.
All players -- men and women -- are now free agents and free to sign with any team after their contracts expire or they receive letters of clearance.
However, Cathay Life still opposed the transfer of Chiang, who retired after a falling out with the team's head coach, Hung Ling-yao.
Chiang was quoted by the media as saying she decided to leave Cathay Life because Hung kept rejecting her wish to play U.S. college basketball or elsewhere overseas.
The case was submitted to the CTBA Disciplinary Committee for further review.

Cathay Life, which established its women's basketball team in 1969, has been one of the most successful basketball teams in Taiwan. More than half of the Taiwan national team players are from Cathay Life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers find new correlation between tobacco, lung cancer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 20:45:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese research team's new discovery of a mechanism by which tobacco causes lung cancer and other smoking-related diseases has made the cover of the February issue of The Journal of Clinical Investigation, the world's leading biomedical magazine.
The study by a National Cheng Kung University (NCKU)-led research team revealed the process by which tobacco-specific carcinogens cause lung tumors.

According to the study, the key ingredient of tobacco carcinogens, nicotine- derived nitrosamine ketone (NNK), induces the accumulation of a protein, DNA methyltranferase 1 (DNMT1), which in turn inhibits tumor suppressor genes and leads to lung cancer.
Wang Yi-ching, an NCKU professor who led the research team, said at a news conference Monday that lung cancer is associated with long-term exposure to carcinogenic substances in the environment.

"NNK was originally considered only to lead to genetic mutation, but our research further revealed how NNK could induce epigenetic alteration in the process of cancer formation, inhibiting the tumor suppressor genes and leading to lung cancer," Wang said.

The study provided strong scientific evidence for anti-smoking propaganda and proposed an important goal for lung cancer treatment, namely the development of DNMT methyltranferase enzyme inhibitors, she said.
In the future, Wang said, the research team will focus on the treatment of lung cancer patients and the invention of new drugs, based on its new findings.
Wang's team also included researchers from the National Health Research Institute, Veterans General Hospital, China Medical University Hospital and other academic institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP leader urges creation of legislative oversight body
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 22:28:03 (By Sophia Yeh and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen called Tuesday for the creation of a legislative oversight body on Taiwan-China negotiations on a proposed trade pact after President Ma Ying-jeou said more discussions are needed.
According to Tsai, it is necessary to set up a special task force at the legislature to monitor the ongoing trade negotiations as legislative committees are inadequate for the task.
The task force would allow the real participation of all political parties, she said.

Earlier in the day, Ma said at a press conference that further discussions will be required in order to decide whether there is need for such a task force and whether its functions would conflict with those of the existing legislative committees.
He said ministry officials have already given several briefings to lawmakers since Taiwan and China began the negotiations to further liberalize trade between the two sides.
"This operational model has worked well and is, in effect, a cross-strait task force," he said.
Ma has repeatedly called for a meeting with Tsai on the issue and the DPP chief said her party will send a list of questions to the Presidential Office.
If the president answers the questions at future press conferences, it is likely to pave way for a Ma-Tsai meeting, she said.
Tsai also questioned Ma's argument that the signing of the trade pact will minimize the pressure imposed by China to bar Taiwan from signing free trade agreements with other countries.
She quoted several foreign people she did not identify as saying that Ma's assertion in this regard "doesn't make sense."

In response to Ma's claim that there will be no political language in the trade pact, Tsai, a former Mainland Affairs Council chief, said that "everything has to do with politics when you are negotiating with China."

She also urged the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to find out if anyone in the negotiations team has violated rules on conflict of interests, and said those who have business interests should leave the team.

In his first press conference to talk about the trade pact, Ma detailed his reasons why Taiwan needs the pact and appealed to local farmers and workers by making various pledges in Taiwanese and Hakka, as well as Mandarin Chinese.
Amid fears that farmers and laborers will suffer as result of the agreement, the president pledged not to import Chinese workers or to open the Taiwan market to more Chinese agricultural products.

Ma said the pact, which has raised widespread concerns among the public that it will hit the country's traditional and agricultural sectors hard, is aimed at helping the people of Taiwan do business and enhancing Taiwan's competitiveness.
The pact will cover tariff reduction, investment protection and intellectual property rights protection, according to Ma.
He added that there is no fixed timetable for the negotiations, although his government has been working to conclude the pact at the end of May, before the legislature goes into recess in June.

He also said that after the pact is signed, there will be no need for hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese to seek jobs in China, as Taiwanese businesses will no longer need to relocate there, but instead will be able to set up their bases in Taiwan.
More foreign companies will also be attracted to invest in Taiwan, he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Field training for Hankuang war games slated for late April: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 23:15:22 (By S.Y. Shih and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Field training for the annual Hankuang war games this year will be brought forward to late April to allow the troops to be deployed to help combat possible flooding in the coming typhoon season later in the year, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced Tuesday at a news conference.

Lee Yue-chang, assistant deputy chief of the General Staff for Operations and Planning under the MND, said the field training will be held in late April instead of in the traditional July-October period so that the troops can be better trained in May and June in preparation for disaster prevention and rescue missions in the typhoon period from July to October.
The second-stage computer simulation section of the games will be executed in mid-July.
The field exercises will involve no military hardware, while live-fire exercises will be held separately on specific military bases or coastal locations, Lee went on.
Asymmetric operations will also be included in this year's field exercises to examine the military's ability to confront unconventional military strategies adopted by enemy troops, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT: 95% of visa applications approved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/10 23:49:45 (By Shih-Hsin-ayo and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday it has approved 95 percent of the visa applications submitted by local people.

AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges made the remarks in response to complaints on AIT's Facebook page accusing immigration officials of being very arrogant when interviewing visa applicants and rejecting many applications.

The Facebook page, set up with the aim of serving as a platform for communication with the public, has become riddled with complaints from visa applicants for what they alleged are "bad manners" on the part of immigration officials.

AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties between the two countries, said on the Facebook page that it welcomes all constructive criticism or compliments, but reserves the right to delete negative remarks to ensure peaceful, rational dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 10, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President- elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 10:03:31 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday than its previous close, moving up 77.08 points at 7,438.12 on a turnover of NT$4.26 billion (US$132.71 million).
The weighted price index rose 145.16 points, or 2.01 percent, to close at 7,361.04 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Government never to profit at consumers' expense: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 10:41:14 (By Johnson Sun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) should honestly review its gasoline pricing formula to avoid making unwarranted gains at consumers' expense, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

State-owned oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan, whose gasoline prices are determined by a formula based on global oil prices, was recently found to have overcharged motorists for air pollution fees and petroleum management funds over the past three years, and the premier's comments were his first on the controversy.

Responding to press inquiries while visiting a wholesale food market in Taipei City early Wednesday morning, Wu said he has directed Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang and relevant government agencies to honestly and carefully review CPC's gasoline pricing scheme so that it won't profit at motorists' expense.
According to Wu, the MOEA already decided more than two weeks ago to deal with the gasoline pricing issue based on the principle of "not gaining any undue penny at consumers' expense."
CPC announced Tuesday it would again cut gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.4 (US$0.0125) per liter, effective Wednesday. It was the company's second price cut in two days.
The decision, which followed a NT$0.1 per liter cut announced Monday, was reportedly reached Tuesday afternoon at a closed-door meeting chaired by Wu at the Executive Yuan.

The new price cut followed public criticism after a newspaper report said CPC and its rival -- privately run Formosa Petrochemical Corp. -- overcharged motorists while collecting revenues for air pollution fees payable to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

According to Wednesday's CPC press statement, the company grossed an extra NT$5.436 billion in air pollution fees and petroleum management funds intended for the EPA since it adopted a floating gasoline pricing scheme in Steptember 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Address roots of public grievances

TEXT.P: Reports say that over the past two months, Cabinet officials have rushed to the office before 8 a.m. to read local newspapers before Premier Wu Den-yih arrives at the office. If there are negative reports related to their work, they then clarify the reports within two hours.
It is naturally good to respond to problems, but simply responding to public grievances will never translate into good governance.

The phenomenon only reflects the fact that the executive branch has never paid attention to public grievances, let alone taken the initiative to clarify them. The officials only began to pay attention to them because the premier cares about them.

We are worried that all policies, small or large, will need the monitoring of the premier and clarification of Cabinet officials, which means that the administrative principle of each level being responsible for its own actions has completely gone awry.

We should return to the basics of problems. The public grievances could have a multitude of causes, and the government should analyze their roots and stick to its guns if it is correct or make adjustments when necessary.
Taking the initiative to clarify issues is part of good governance, but it would be better to return to the source of the problem. (Feb. 10. 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Ma should first address misgivings about ECFA

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou held a news conference Tuesday to promote the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, but he has failed to address some key questions.

The public has long wondered if local workers or farmers will be victimized if the agreement is signed and questioned why the government insists on pushing the agreement if it needs to appropriate NT$90 billion to subsidize affected businesses.

Since China has repeatedly said the ECFA has nothing to do with Taiwan's signing of free trade agreements with other countries, people also wonder why the government still claims that China is not opposed to such deals.

We question why Ma will not put the issue to a public referendum, since the agreement will have a crucial impact on Taiwan's economy and because it is in fact self-denigrating, even though Ma has claimed that the agreement will not have the political language of one country, two systems attached.
A free trade agreement is signed between two countries. But China is unwilling to sign an FTA with Taiwan and has prevented others from signing them with Taiwan.

The signing of the ECFA will only benefit a few pro-China businessmen, while the majority of Taiwan's people will suffer due to lower salaries and job losses and most businesses will face unfair competition from China.
With a great majority of Taiwan's people having realized that the ECFA is a poison rather than a tonic, they have little interest in buying it no matter how hard Ma pushes for it. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Submarine procurement plan not dropped: defense ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 11:58:26 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The military has not dropped its plan to procure submarines to help beef up Taiwan's self-defense capability, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said in a statement Wednesday.

The ministry was responding to a United Daily News report that quoted unidentified military sources as saying the day before that Taiwan has substantively dropped its plan to purchase submarines from the United States, a move the sources said would intangibly help mend a rift in U.S.-China relations.

The ministry insisted, however, that the report is not true. Stressing that submarines are indispensible to realize a strategy of "resolute defense and effective deterrence, " the military has for years put submarines on its priority procurement list, the statement said.
"We will uphold this arms procurement policy to demonstrate our determination to safeguard our national security, " the MND statement said.

It further said Taiwan hopes the United States will continue providing Taiwan with necessary defensive weapons and equipment in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act so that Taiwan will be more confident in promoting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: President Ma Ying-jeou skirts ECFA doubts

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou hosted a news conference Tuesday to discuss the importance of signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

While he managed to give a clear account of the major principles for striking such a deal with Beijing, he still failed to clarify suspicions on certain critical political, economic and implementation issues.
Politically, the public wants to know whether signing the ECFA would mean an acquiescence to Beijing's "one China" principle or lead to a downgrading of Taiwan's sovereign status.
Ma did answer this question frankly and straightforwardly, saying the agreement will not include any political rhetoric or touch on the sensitive "one China" issue.

However, Ma failed to explain why China would no longer stonewall Taiwan's efforts to negotiate free trade agreements with other countries once the ECFA is signed, as he claimed. He also did not address questions on how his administration will negotiate with China to prevent a further market opening to China-grown agricultural products.

Equally disappointing was his failure to give convincing explanations of his opposition to the proposal that the Legislative Yuan set up a special task force to oversee cross-strait engagements, including ECFA negotiations.

Ma apparently has learned a lesson from the U.S. beef import controversy and tried to increase transparency on a major policy issue like ECFA. He still failed, however, to say enough to convince a skeptical public. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Fuel prices cut amid public outcry
DOC.DATELINE: State-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) 02/10/10 12:38:55 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: surprised observers Tuesday when it announced it would cut domestic gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.4 per liter, effective Wednesday. The reduction was the company's second price cut in two days.

The cuts have resulted in prices at the pump of NT$30.8 per liter for 98-octane unleaded, NT$29.3 per liter for 95-octane unleaded, NT$28.6 per liter for 92-octane unleaded, and NT$26.1 per liter for premium diesel.
The decision, following a NT$0.1 per liter cut announced on Monday, was reportedly made after Premier Wu Den-yih demanded that public institutions not "take advantage of consumers."

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) discovered recently that since CPC began implementing a floating pricing mechanism on gasoline and diesel fuel in September 2006, it has overcharged consumers by more than NT$5.4 billion for air pollution fees and a crude oil fund.
The following are excerpts of local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Premier Wu Den-yih praised the MOEA's move to push gasoline prices lower as the "right move" after the ministry discovered that gasoline vendors had overcharged for air pollution fees.
It shows that Wu's Cabinet can quickly respond to public opinions and that the Cabinet pays attention to public discontent.

Control Yuan member Cheng Jen-hung revealed that he will launch a probe to see if there were high-ranking officials who benefited from overcharging for the fees or neglected their duty in monitoring operations of the state-run oil refiner.
China Times:

Wu believes that the MOEA should ask CPC to return to consumers the money it overcharged once the ministry discovers the difference between air pollution fee revenues and the amount it must turn over to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
No consumer should be taken advantage of, he said.
Appearing more cautious on the issue, EPA Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said the issue reflected an accounting problem at CPC and the privately run Formosa Petrochemical.
It cannot be called dirty money if the overcharged revenues were spent on equipment to upgrade gasoline and diesel quality, Shen added.
EPA officials said they will visit CPC and FPC headquarters Wednesday along with Bureau of Energy staffers to review the companies' cost structure.
Commercial Times:

Since media reports discovered Feb. 8 that CPC and FPC overcharged motorists in collecting air pollution fees, the MOEA has been busy resolving the crisis and trying to "reward" consumers by lowering gasoline and diesel prices.
The ministry, however, does not appear to believe that the state-run company was guilty of "operational flaws" in overcharging for air pollution fees.
Obviously, the MOEA lacks the courage to make an apology.
Liberty Times:

Criticizing EPA Minister Stephen Shen for "defending the businesses, " Consumers' Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said he cannot understand why the administration would protect CPC and FPC even after the MOEA and the two petroleum companies have admitted to making mistakes in the air pollution fee dispute.
Hsieh also blasted CPC and FPC for spending the money, designated for upgrading pollution prevention equipment, on their own needs in improving the oil refining process. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Impact of China's 'inland fever' on Taiwan

TEXT.P: We noticed in China's economic statistics a trend toward a major regional shift in its economy. Economic growth in inland regions has risen sharply while remaining flat or slipping in coastal areas.
We believe such a development will have a structural impact on cross-strait trade and Taiwanese businessmen's operations in China.

The economic growth in China's hinterland can be attributed to several factors. China's economy has become more domestic demand- oriented, adding to development momentum in inland regions. Also, China has invested heavily in inland regions to narrow the economic gap with other more prosperous areas. Third, the resources of coastal areas have spilled inland.
Such a development will be a new experience for Taiwanese businessmen, and we have several suggestions for them and Taiwan's government.

First, Taiwan's investment should have a focus. China's hinterland is vast, and its customs differ from coastal regions. The government should coordinate think tanks to lead Taiwanese businessmen to trade where they enjoy a competitive edge and in places that are more accommodating to Taiwan's business culture.

Second, Taiwanese businessmen should be able to properly handle local relations, as their contacts with local officials, enterprises and society will be closer than when they do business in coastal regions, meaning that the chances for friction will also be greater.

Third, Taiwan should nurture a global perspective. Even though inland regions seem remote geographically, they have actually opened up to the outside world in the wake of China's economic cooperation with the world.
Taiwanese businessmen should thus develop the mind-set of "standing in the hinterland, but with an eye to the world" to expand their niches. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: How innovation bill should be reshaped

TEXT.P: A bill on industrial innovation remains shelved in the Legislative Yuan because a clause that would offer an especially low 15 percent corporate income tax rate to certain big conglomerates has drawn strong criticism.

In response, the Executive Yuan has recently decided to delete the controversial provision and will instead include a new clause that would offer subsidies to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) if they increase their hirings.
The Cabinet reversed its policy in an apparent effort to stem anger over what critics call the government's desire to ingratiate itself with large business groups while discriminating against SMEs.

Whether this new twist or development is appropriate is debatable. But as the government redrafts or reshapes the innovation bill, we hope it will instill a new vision or adopt a new way of thinking to better address Taiwan's economic woes.
While tax incentives may contribute to certain economic sectors, they have also become a source of unfairness in our tax system.

We hope the new bill will no longer offer any tax exemption or tax deduction as an incentive to attract investment. The government should instead consider the possibility of lowering the corporate income tax rate to a low of 17.5 percent to create a neutral taxation environment.

We believe a "low tax rate, few tax exemptions" system will be equally effective in stimulating private investment if the government can improve its operational efficiency and Taiwan's infrastructure, living environment and work conditions.

As to SME development, the government should focus on assisting them by providing financing guarantees and offering guidance on manpower cultivation, technological innovation and market expansion, rather than by offering tax exemptions or tax cuts. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: DPP has no reason to oppose to absentee voting

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party's opposition to absentee voting is both "anti- democratic" and "anti-progressive."
Absentee voting will enable those who cannot return home to vote to exercise their voting rights.

One thing should be clear. The Ministry of the Interior is not promoting "mail voting, " meaning Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and emigres will not be eligible to vote from abroad under the plan. Rather, it targets students, young workers, policemen and military servicemen, and inmates who study, work or are deployed in areas outside where their households are registered.

Even after two transfers of political power in Taiwan, the confrontation between the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps still persists. This is why many have lost heart, manifested by the low turnout rates in recent elections. Absentee voting will encourage more people to participate in politics.

The DPP opposes absentee voting because it thinks that it would make it easier to manipulate vote counts. But in fact, an effective voting monitoring system has been established in Taiwan after years of democratic elections.

The more terrible "manipulation" might have taken place outside polling stations, such as the 319 shooting of former President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the 2004 presidential election. Chen then activated the national security system to bar military personnel from leaving the barracks to vote.

The MOI's absentee voting plan would allow eligible voters apply to vote outside their registered households. Such voters would have to show their IDs and seals to "transfer" polling stations. These stations are no different from others set up around the country with monitoring staff, and the DPP's misgivings are unwarranted. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum drive against U.S. beef imports enters second phase
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 16:32:27 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A campaign launched by the Consumers' Foundation to seek a national referendum on whether U.S. bone-in beef imports should be allowed entered the second phase of public endorsement Wednesday.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen, along with representatives of four other civil groups campaigning for the drive, visited the Central Election Commission (CEC) earlier in the day to collect the forms for the second-phase public endorsement.
Announcing the beginning of the operation, Hsieh said he hopes they can persuade 1 million eligible voters to sign the petition before an Aug. 10 deadline.

The proposed referendum will ask voters to "veto the government's decision in November to open Taiwan's market to U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef and bovine offal and spines from cattle aged under 30 months" and demand that the government renegotiate the beef trade protocol with the United States that opened Taiwan's market to the beef products.

Hsieh noted that the dispute on U.S. beef imports has not been resolved and that Washington has threatened to retaliate against Taiwan for breaking promises in the U.S.-Taiwan beef protocol signed last October.

Even though the Legislative Yuan has voted to revise the law to force the government to reinstate a ban on imports of U.S. ground beef and beef offal, Washington can still demand that Taipei open its market based on the protocol, he said.

Calling for the public to stand up and be counted, Hsieh said the civic groups hope the people will show the U.S. government their objection to U.S. bone-in beef out of fear of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

Under the Referendum Act, a petition is subject to the approval of the Cabinet's Referendum Screening Committee in the first phase of screening, during which the initiator must obtain the endorsement of at least 0.5 percent of the eligible voters in the previous presidential election.

The Consumers' Foundation-led initiative passed the first stage last month, collecting 129,000 signatures and far surpassing the required 86,000 from among the 17.32 million eligible voters in the 2008 presidential election.
In the second phase, the initiators must secure within six months the endorsement of at least 5 percent, or 860,000, of the eligible voters.

In response to the referendum drive, Department of Health (DOH) Vice Minister Hsiao Mei-ling said they will seek to make all the relevant information transparent to allow consumers to see that the government has never stinted on its efforts to safeguard public health.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts arms buildup, combat preparedness
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 17:06:45 (By Garfie Lee and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that a successful humanitarian mission carried out by an Air Force C-130 transport plane delivering relief goods to earthquake-ravaged Haiti late last month signifies that Taiwan's military buildup and combat preparedness is sufficient.

At a Chinese New Year gathering at the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the president said U.S. congressional Jan. 29 approval of arms sales to Taiwan means Taiwan is expected to obtain its long coveted self-defense weapons and he expressed his gratitude to the MND and the National Security Council for their comprehensive planning of the issue.
The arms sales also show that Taiwan and the United States have maintained close cooperation on security issues and in other areas, according to Ma.

The goal of Taiwan's military buildup and war preparations is to help the military transform itself into a force that is small but strong, small but elite and small but skillful, which could help attain peace, avoid war, deter attack and strengthen national defense, Ma went on.

He also praised the military's rescue work during the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot last August, saying that some 560,000 soldiers were mobilized for relief efforts, winning widespread acclaim for their performance.
He added that disaster prevention and relief has been listed as one of the military's priority tasks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign representatives curious about Chinese New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 17:27:45 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese New Year is coming, so how do foreign representatives in Taiwan plan to spend their holidays?

The Director of the French office is curious about Lunar New Year customs and foods, while the director of the British Council expects to experience a different, quiet atmosphere in Taipei City during the holiday.

"I know Taiwanese people post spring couplets around their doorways, pray to their ancestors, give each other red envelopes filled with cash and gather with their families at the New Year, " said Patrick Bonneville, director of the Institut Francais de Taipei.

Having been assigned to Taipei for about 18 months, Bonneville is already familiar with many of the local New Year customs. He said he finds the giving of red envelopes is one of the most interesting customs, in that parents give them to their children, but once the children have grown up, the roles are reversed and the kids give red envelopes to their parents each year.

The food traditionally eaten at this time of year is also of interest to Bonneville, such as the so-called "long-life vegetable," otherwise known as mustard greens, symbolizing long life, as well as steamed sponge cake and rice cake, which are reputed to bring good luck.
"The customs of Chinese New Year are related to the concepts of family, gathering, fortune and longevity," he noted.
British Council Director Christine Skinner said she expects to go shopping on Taipei's Dihua Street, where people traditionally flock in their thousands to buy many New Year products and foods.

Skinner, who has worked in Taipei for four years, has also added Lungshan Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taipei, to her New Year travel plans, although she added that what she is most looking forward to is enjoying the peace and quiet of Taipei during the holiday period, as many of the residents will be out of town visiting family further south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker backs proposal to set up cross-strait panel
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 17:43:16 (By Huang Ming-hsi, Chiu Chun-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng expressed support Wednesday for a proposal to set up a dedicated panel under the legislature to monitor and deal with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.

Wang said such a panel can serve as a communication platform between the legislative and executive branches, which he said was "very necessary" at a time when Taiwan and mainland China are working in close interaction to strengthen their cooperation.
"The Legislative Yuan should play an essential role that allows it to participate in and monitor the processes, " Wang said.

Wang made the remarks after chairing an inter-party consultation held to discuss the proposal, which was put forth by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party amid the Kuomintang (KMT) administration's efforts to promote the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

According to the speaker, legislators agreed in the meeting that the DPP should present a written outline of the party's proposition, so that the KMT can study the plan and hold further discussions with the DPP.

Commenting on the issue Wednesday, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the legislature must set up a special panel to step up its monitoring of the executive branch's dealings with China, in light of the far-reaching impact of the proposed trade agreement on Taiwan.
According to Tsai, the trade pact will cover a wide range of issues, which cannot be handled by any single currently existing committees.

The proposed cross-strait panel should not be restricted by the meeting procedures of regular committees and should be allowed to convene on a flexible basis, she suggested, adding that each party should be represented in the panel to properly reflect public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Relaxed rules on high-tech investment in China

TEXT.P: Restrictions on China-bound investment in the flat panel, chip foundry, high-end chip packaging and testing, and low-end IC design sectors will be relaxed by Taiwan's government.
In the future, applications for high-tech investment in China will be approved if they pass a review by a new core technology screening task force.
The following are excerpts of local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

In line with the government's liberalization policy, Premier Wu Den-yih approved Tuesday a proposal to revise the existing list of sectors that are off-limits to investment by local manufacturers in China.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will unveil the relaxed rules after receiving the Executive Yuan's formal notice.

According to senior Cabinet officials, restrictions will be lifted on local flat panel makers investing in facilities less advanced than 6th-generation plants, but the local sector will be allowed to set up no more than a total of three panel plants using more advanced technologies in China.
Asked why the number was limited to three, the officials said that at the moment, no more than three local companies are capable of setting up the highly sophisticated panel plants in China.

Under the new regulations, prospective China-bound investors must submit a detailed investment plan for a soon-to-be-formed screening task force for examination. The applicants must meet the principles of "their top technologies must be kept at home and their investment priority must also be at home."
Meanwhile, local companies will only be allowed to invest or buy stakes in China in 8-inch or less technologically advanced wafer fabs, the officials said. (Feb. 10, 2010)
United Daily News:
Relaxed investment regulations will be applied to high-tech industries as well as financial and telecommunication services, and poultry and livestock processing industries.
The new regulations will allow Taiwan's state-owned banks to buy stakes in Chinese banks, while local construction companies will be permitted to invest in China's property market.
Restrictions on China-bound Investment in renewal energy industry will also be lifted. (Feb. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiex closes higher on last trading day before Lunar New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 17:50:37 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) closed 80.8 points higher Wednesday on the last trading day before the Feb. 14 Chinese New Year, with its benchmark index finishing at 7,441.84 points on turnover of NT$106.71 billion (US$3.33 billion).
It was the 11th consecutive year that the Taiex ended higher on the last trading day of the lunar year.

Following the U.S. Dow Jones' recovery to the benchmark 10,000 -point level Tuesday and a lessening of market fears over sovereign defaults in the euro zone, the local bourse opened 77 points higher amid strong buying.

Chip, IC testing and IC design shares traded heavily on news that the government would soon allow these sectors to invest in China. Shares of traditional businesses, such as steel, textiles, chemicals, and construction, as well as financial shares, also rallied on sound fundamentals and optimistic business outlook.
Investors were net sellers of NT$8.377 billion in shares, the 14th consecutive trading session in which they sold more than they bought.

Analysts said the higher finish Wednesday on an expanded market turnover of over NT$100 billion signals that investors may be bullish when the stock market opens again on Feb. 22 after the 11-day Chinese New Year break.
However, they said, the local bourse will be influenced largely by world markets, despite the rise in recent days and high hopes among retail investors for a higher opening on Feb. 22.
Three main factors are likely to affect the performance of the Taiex -- the euro zone sovereign debt situation, China's monetary policy and U.S. economic data, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bargain flower prices for Valentine's Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 19:07:11 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Officials at the Taipei Flower Market suggested Wednesday that as flowers are expected to be fairly inexpensive for Valentine's Day on Feb. 14, people should celebrate the day for lovers before continuing with their celebrations for Chinese New Year, which falls on the same day this year.
Thanks to abundant supplies, rose prices will be cheaper than they were this time last year, according to Teng Yi-chin, a market manager responsible for planning.

She also pointed out that the wholesale flower market in the Neihu district had been operating round-the-clock since the previous day, and encouraged couples to demonstrate their love for each other with flowers.

According to Council of Agriculture (COA) statistics, trading at wholesale flower markets around Taiwan reached nearly 700,000 bunches of flowers Tuesday, marking a growth of 34.66 percent compared with the trading volume of Jan. 21, 2009, which was five days before the last Chinese New Year.
The average price for all the various kinds of flowers available recorded a drop of 35.04 percent from the average NT$94.1 per bunch at that time to NT$61.2 Tuesday, the tallies show.
A standard bunch consists of 12 flower stems.
Meanwhile, the price of a bunch of roses was NT$124.3 on average in market trading that day, lower than the NT$162.6 last Valentine's Day, according to COA official Hsu Han-chi.
Flower prices normally spike by as much as 30 percent on Valentine's Day in Taiwan, with the cost of a single rose often surging to between NT$100 and NT$250.

DOC.HEADLINE: Politician, baseball stars indicted in game-fixing scandal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 19:31:05 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Two baseball stars and a politician were among the 24 people indicted by the Banciao District Prosecutors Office Wednesday for fixing professional baseball games, and prosecutors are seeking jail terms ranging from two to nine years for the suspects.
Prosecutor Tseng Hsin-hung reported that Wu Chien-pao, speaker of the Tainan County Assembly was indicted on gambling and fraud charges and could face a nine-year prison term if convicted.
The two star baseball players indicted, Brother Elephants star outfielder Chen Chih-yuan and former La New Bears star pitcher Chang Chih-chia, could face two years in jail, Tseng added.

Elephants pitcher Tsao Chin-hui, a former player with the Colorado Rockies and the Los Angeles Dodgers who was also under investigation for his acquaintance with gambling ring members, was not indicted because there was insufficient evidence to tie him to the game-fixing incidents.

However, Tsao, who was the most popular pitcher in Taiwan after he returned from the United States and joined the Elephants early last year, may find himself out of job as none of the four professional teams in the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) will hire him.
The 24 people indicted in the case include seven baseball players and alleged gambling ring members.

The game-fixing scandal erupted on Oct. 26 last year when investigators raided the dormitories of Brother Elephants, LaNew Bears, and Sinon Bulls. Forty- three players from the three professional teams have been under investigation over the past months.

Upon learning of the indictments, Brother Elephants Baseball Club general manager Hung Jui-ho said that Chen Chih-yuan, a star player who was once dubbed "Golden Warrior," has been expelled from the team.
But Chen told the media that he would find an attorney to help him prove his innocence, because the indictment "is not correct and is groundless."
"It's not important whether I can go back on the field. What concerns me most at the moment is proving my innocence, " he said, adding that if he is convicted in the lower court, he would appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing pledges to expedite ECFA signing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 19:39:29 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Chinese authorities pledged Wednesday to speed up the progress of the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which Taiwan hopes can be signed within the first half of this year.

Fan Li-ching, a spokeswoman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said in a regular press briefing that Beijing will continue to promote the trade pact in a steady, step-by-step manner, in which the easy problems will be taken care of before the more difficult ones are tackled.
Fan noted that in the first round of formal ECFA talks held Jan. 26, the two sides only touched upon basic issues and did not enter detailed discussions.
Among the things that are expected to be dealt with in the next step of negotiations are the two sides' respective early harvest lists, which are awaiting confirmation, she said.

Also, she continued, further discussion is required to decide the date and venue for the fifth round of talks between the leaders of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , during which the ECFA is expected to be signed.

On a proposal that the SEF and ARATS should exchange offices on the tow sides of the Taiwan Strait, Fan said ARATS supports the idea in principle but has not worked out a substantive plan on the issue.

She noted that Taiwan and China agreed in June 2008 to exchange tourism offices and that the Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Tourism Association and the Beijing- based Cross-Strait Tourism Association have officially filed applications for the establishment of the offices.
The two sides have yet to decide when the offices will be inaugurated, she added.
Fan predicted that the opening of the offices will provide tourists with better services that will benefit the development of the tourism industries on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's oil refinery to review pricing system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 20:24:18 (By Kevin Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: State-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) will review yearly-- starting this year--its gasoline pricing mechanism to avoid making unwarranted gains from air pollution fees at consumers' expense, Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang said Wednesday.

In 1995, Taiwan began to levy an air pollution control fee on both stationary sources, such as factories and construction sites, as well as mobile sources, such as motor vehicles, based on the cost per liter for different grades of gasoline and diesel fuels.

The fee is collected on all motorists in accordance with the amount of fuel consumed or total amount of emisssions by each automobile to discourage them from driving and to reduce air pollution. The decision to require the CPC to review its pricing annually was made after the CPC and the privately run Formosa Petrochemical Corp. were accused of having overcharged motorists while collecting revenue on behalf of the government for air pollution fees. The fees are collected at gas stations and are later paid to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) by the gasoline companies.
Shih alleged that the CPC and Formosa had charged prices higher than they should have by making motorists think the overcharges were the air pollution fee.
Shih made the announcement after the CPC announced it will cut domestic gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.4 per liter, effective Wednesday, following a NT$0.1 per liter cut announced on Monday.

The price review is expected to be conducted between January and February every year, according to Shih, who served as chairman of the board at the CPC before he assumed his current post last September.
However, Shih did not say whether the CPC will further cut gasoline and diesel prices in near future.

Meanwhile, EPA Director-General of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control Hsieh Yen-ju said that the overcharged revenues might have been spent by the company on equipment to upgrade gasoline and diesel quality.

She said the EPA and the Bureau of Energy will visit the CPC's headquarters to look into whether the state-run refinery was guilty of "operational flaws" in overcharging motorists for air pollution fees.
In 2009, the revenue from mobile pollution source air emissions fees was NT$1.3 billion, far less than the approximately NT$2 billion collected yearly in the past.
This was the result of an improvement in the quality of oil products, as the level of air pollution fees depends on the sulfur content of the oil products from gasoline vendors, Hsieh said.
She added that the CPC should not take in any of the excess air pollution fees and should instead return them to consumers.
Meanwhile, Formosa Petrochemical announced Wednesday it will lower its prices by NT$0.3, effective 5 p.m..

Wang Wen-chao, chairman of Formosa Petrochemical, denied the company had pocketed a huge sum of money in excess air pollution fees, saying that the company is still fighting to make ends meet because the company has invested NT$9 billion in reducing the sulfur content of its oil products.
Wang added that the government is welcome to investigate the fees charged by the company over past few years.

Wang also noted that whether the CPC's gasoline pricing formula is reasonable has nothing to do with Formosa Petrochemical because the private company does not use the same price calculation system, but instead adopts a market pricing mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar weakens in Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 20:29:57 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, down by NT$0.034 to close at NT$32.066.
A total of US$677 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.10 and had a low of NT$31.98.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenage girls turn fatty for world tug-of-war championships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 20:36:53 (By Jian Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A strong desire to grab the gold medal in the upcoming 2010 world tug-of-war championships in Italy has made 12 teenage girls give up staying slim and eat to gain weight so they can qualify for the games.

The girls studying at Taipei Jingmei Girls High School are members of the school's tug-of-war team, which usually takes part in games in the category between 480 kg and 520 kg cumulative team athletes' weight, according to school principal Lin Li-hua.

The team began seeking to have a cumulated weight of eight persons surge to 540 kg after learning that the Tug of War International Federation has lowered the age limit to 16 years old for the 2010 world championships, and that they will only have the government's funding if they join the game in the 450 kg category, Lin said.

Over the past few months, each member of the team had to swallow down dinner for 2-3 persons. Now, every girl in the team weigh at least 10 kg more than they did before deciding to join the international competition, their coach Kuo Sheng said.
"I am touched and impressed by these girls' determination, " Kuo said.
The team leader Kuo Ya-ting, who was 157 cm tall and weighed 48 kg, has managed to gain 12 kg.
"I have never been so fat" she said. Admitting she was reluctant to look at herself in the mirror after she had gained weight, Kuo Ya-ting nevertheless vowed to bring home the gold medal from Italy.
Nine members of the team will be selected for the 2010 World Indoor Championships, scheduled to take place on Feb. 25-28 in the Italian city of Cesenatico.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker accused of financial crime banned from leaving country
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 21:29:41 (by Lai Yu-chia and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo, Jr., former vice chairman of the China Trust Financial Holding Co., has been restricted from leaving the country, as the presiding judge in a pre- trial court hearing Wednesday said Koo was considered as a suspect in a severe crime case who might attempt to escape.

Koo attended the pre-trial hearing at the Taipei District Court to face questioning on charges of violating the stock exchange law and banking law when he gave a directive for the acquisition of Mega Financial Holding Co. through a Hong Kong branch of the China Trust in 2004.

The Taipei District Court prosecutors' office in 2006 twice summoned Koo regarding suspected irregularities in the deal, but the banker failed to show up in court and he left Taiwan in September 2006.

Koo stayed abroad for almost two years after the court put him on a wanted list in December 2006. He returned to Taipei in November 2008 when prosecutors were investigating a case of alleged corruption and bribery involving former President Chen Shui-bian and several bankers.
At the pre-trial hearing Wednesday afternoon, Koo denied all of the allegations, insisting that the purchase of Mega Financial shares was purely a matter of investment.
When the judge issued the travel ban, Koo pleaded for leniency, saying that he has a sick wife in the United States, and one of his two children in Japan is autistic.

However, the presiding judge pointed out that financial crimes are considered severe offenses and the penalty could be a jail term of no less than five years. Koo, with his previous record of dodging a court order, might attempt to run again and should be restricted from leaving country, the judge said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MSCI weighting expected to have limited impact on TAIEX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Jan. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 21:37:33 (By Chou Pin-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Morgan Stanley Capital International's (MSCI's) anticipated lowering of the weighting of Taiwan stocks in its indices Thursday will have a limited impact on the local stock market which concluded its final trading session before the Chinese New Year break on Wednesday, according to a Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) official.

Lee Chi-hsien, director-general of the FSC's Insurance Bureau, said Wednesday that MSCI's adjustment downward of Taiwan's stock market's value usually causes an impact on the local bourse for one day at the most.

MSCI is scheduled to announce its latest adjustment Thursday when Taiwan's stock market begins to go into recess for the Lunar New Year, therefore, the adjustment is expected to have a very small negative impact on the local bourse, Lee added.
Touching on the big net sales of Taiwan's stocks by foreign investors recently, Lee said that inward remittance of foreign capital into Taiwan reached US$2.76 billion in January.
But as of Feb. 8, outward remittance by foreign investors hit US$1.25 billion, which translated into a net inflow of foreign remittances of US$1.5 billion, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan conditionally broadens high-tech investment in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 21:58:01 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan further relaxed restrictions Wednesday on high-tech investment in China, in another move to help local companies expand their global market shares and competitiveness.
Under the new regulations, flat panel makers will be conditionally allowed to invest in facilities more advanced than 6th-generation plants, but the number of such plants will be capped at three.
Moreover, the flat panel plants to be set up in China must be less advanced than the applicant's Taiwan facility by at least one generation, the rules stipulate.
The investment proposals will be subject to review by a core technology screening task force to be assembled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) soon.
The task force, to be composed of officials from all relevant ministries and agencies as well as industry pundits, will review investment projects based on technology, investment and finances.
An MOEA official said the ministry's stance will be that "the companies' top technologies should be kept at home and their investment priority must also be at home."

"Taiwan's high-tech companies will be allowed to invest only in plants that are less advanced than those in Taiwan and the value of their investments in China should not be more than in Taiwan," the official added.

AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Taiwan's largest flat panel maker, hailed the govenrment's relaxation of restrictions on China-bound investment, saying the move will help upgrade the local flat panel industry's overall competitiveness.

An AUO spokesman said the company hopes the government will screen its China- bound investment project in a speedy manner and with a broad perspective to cope with the rapidly changing global market situation.

The new regulations will still prohibit local chip foundries from setting up 12-inch wafer fabs or foundries in China using processes more advanced than 0.13 micrometers, but will allow them to buy stakes in or acquire China-based wafer foundries.

Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang admitted that the acquisition aspect of the regulations is mainly aimed at addressing two prominent pending cases -- China-based Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp.'s offer of a 10 percent stake to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. to settle their intellectual property rights dispute and United Microelectronics Corp.'s controversial investment in China's Hejian Co. before the government lifted a ban on such investment.
Taiwan now allows its chip companies to set up a maximum of three wafer fabs in China using processes less advanced than 0.18 micrometers.

The relaxed investment rules will also apply to low-end IC design and chip set packaging and testing industries. However, any such China-bound investment projects in excess of US$50 million will also be subject to review by the core technology screening task force.

DOC.HEADLINE: Permanent homes for Kaohsiung typhoon victims completed
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 22:24:34 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Soldiers and volunteer workers were busy Wednesday cleaning up new permanent houses built in Kaohsiung County's Shanlin township for residents displaced by Typhoon Morakot last August, in the final preparations for occupancy.
A house-warming party featuring 300 dinner tables will be held Thursday afternoon, according to the Tzu Chi Foundation, the sponsor of the housing project.

President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Wu Den-yih, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin- pyng, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing will attend the party and join the residents in celebrating the occasion, the foundation said.
The county government on Wednesday completed its allocation of the houses to 445 eligible typhoon victims, including 241 indigenous people.

The housing project in Shanlin, launched Nov. 15 last year, is called the Great Love community and is spread over a 60-hectare area. Tzu Chi, which plans to build 1,500 houses on the site, has completed the first 600.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 'Queen's Head' to be reopened to visitors Feb. 13
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 22:27:04 (By Chen Ching-ping and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The iconic "Queen's Head" rock formation at Yehliu Geopark on Taiwan's northern coast will be reopened to visitors on Chinese New Year's Eve, Feb. 13, a park official said Wednesday.

The famous sandstone, sculpted by waves and wind over time into a shape that resembles an Egyptian queen's head, is a popular attraction for many domestic and overseas tourists. But it was sealed off a month ago to facilitate a project to renovate its surrounding pathways.
Yang Ching-chien, the park's general manager, said the renovation project is near completion, and the site can be reopened to the public this weekend.

But according to Yang, due to more than 45 years of natural erosion as well as tourists touching it with their hands, the neck circumference of the "Queen's Head" has been decreasing rapidly, from 148cm in 2007 to 136cm in 2009.
It is predicted that the neck will break off naturally in five to 10 years, he said.

Having failed to stop the natural forces, the park is now trying to protect the rock from human damage by stationing two security officers nearby and installing 13 surveillance cameras there to keep a watchful eye around the clock, he said.
Meanwhile, Yang said, the "Princess's Head" -- a new rock formation that looks similar to the "Queen's Head" -- has recently drawn many curious visitors.
The park contains a number of unusual rock formations that have been given imaginative names based on their shapes.
Other noted rock formations in the park include "The Fairy Shoe," "The Bee Hive," "The Ginger Rocks," and "The Sea Candles."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax revenue for January increases 56.5% year-on-year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/10 22:52:20 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Net national tax revenue for January increased by 56.5 percent year-on-year to NT$116 billion, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Wednesday.
The increase was due to the low base in January last year because the Chinese New Year holiday fell in that month and because of the impact of the global financial crisis, according to the MOF.
Among the different tax categories, the biggest increase was in business income tax revenue, which registered a rise of NT$21.7 billion.

The main resources of the revenue included NT$19.8 billion from personal consolidated income tax revenue, NT$43.2 billion from business income tax income and NT$11.1 billion from stock trading tax income.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 11, or the 28th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: ECFA publicity strategy

TEXT.P: It is a good move for President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to try to strengthen public communication on its policy to promote the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. However, the administration should think carefully and clearly about its publicity strategy.
In the debate on the ECFA issue, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has obviously taken the offensive, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is on the defensive.

To put it simply, the DPP is playing on people's fears by emphasizing the negative consequences of the trade pact. The KMT, on the other hand, is urging the public "not to be afraid" as the government will take various precautionary measures. The KMT's assurances amount to an indirect acknowledgment of the validity of the DPP's claims, and this places the KMT in an unfavorable position.

We believe that the government, instead of trying to promote the advantages of signing an ECFA, should aggressively highlight the disadvantages of not signing such a pact. The Ma administration should use data to show the people that without an ECFA, the fears derived from the DPP's closed-door policy during its eight years in power would only persist.

President Ma also needs to change his strategy to include the voices of pro-ECFA industries, businesses and entrepreneurs in the publicity drive. This will help the DPP to realize that the fight is with Taiwan's overall economy, rather than the KMT administration.
