DOC.HEADLINE: Nationals reportedly eyeing Taiwan's Wang
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/11/10 11:12:07 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese Major League Baseball starter Chien-Ming Wang, who became a free agent in late 2009 after the Yankees failed to offer a new contract, might join the MLB club Nationals.
According to an MLB.com report, the Nationals is looking at the two-time 19-game winner who is now a free agent.
Wang could make a decision within the next 10 days, the report stated.

The Washington Nationals, which reportedly has been monitoring Wang's progress, did not formally responded to the Central News Agency queries in this regard. Wang is still recovering from arthroscopic shoulder surgery that he had in July 2009.
According to the MLB.com report, the Nationals could acquire Wang's services but it was unknown whether the club has extended an offer to Wang, who will turn 30 in March.
Nationals general manager Mike Rizzo said Jan. 31 that the team was looking for one more veteran starter.

Wang could be a relatively inexpensive addition to MLB clubs. It is believed that the Los Angeles Dodgers -- managed by Joe Torre who managed the Yankees when Wang had his best years -- would have some interest in Wang.
Wang earned US$5 million last season, becoming the highest paid Taiwanese player in any U.S. professional sport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temperatures shoot up to 32 degrees in eastern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 11:15:15 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is witnessing extreme weather conditions, with temperatures forecast to shoot up to 32 degrees Celsius in the eastern county of Taitung and 31 degrees on the west coast Thursday, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The CWB forecast clear, hot weather for the entire island Thursday, with temperatures of 30-31 degrees on the west coast, 27 degrees in the eastern county of Hualien and 28 degrees in the northeastern county of Yilan.
However, the weather will change drastically by nightfall Thursday with nosediving temperatures, thunderstorms and downpours, CWB meteorologists said.
A strong cold front from the north will bring cold, wet weather to Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Friday, the CWB said.
Highs on Friday are forecast at 19 degrees in the north, 21 degrees in the northeast, 23 degrees in central and eastern Taiwan and 26 degrees in the south, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Piano duo from Taiwan meets pope before Vatican concert
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 11:31:45 (By Huang Ya-shih and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Pope Benedict XVI granted a public audience Wednesday to a well-known husband- and-wife piano duo from Taiwan, Rolf-Peter Wille and Lina Yeh, before the couple's first-ever performance at the Vatican later that day.

During the meeting, the duo presented Pope Benedict XVI with music recordings featuring their piano performances. The pontiff said he likes music and will enjoy listening to the CDs. He also wished them great success at their evening concert at the Paul VI Hall.
The couple was accompanied by Larry Yu-yuan Wang, Taiwan's ambassador to the Vatican, during the audience with the pope.
The concert was part of the Feb. 9-11 celebrations for the 25th founding anniversary of the Pontifical Council for Health Care Workers.

Wille and Yeh, who were invited as guest performers, were the first musicians from Taiwan to have ever performed in the Holy See. Many audience members, including expatriates, religious staff, Catholic followers and business representatives from Taiwan, said they took pride in attending the concert.

The host of the concert, dressed in an adapted Oriental-style qipao outfit, said it was a great honor to invite the two internationally acclaimed pianists to perform at the pontifical council anniversary celebrations.
The duo played classic pieces by Bach, Brahms, Edvard Grieg and Francis Poulenc as well as adapted piano versions of pieces by Taiwanese composer Chen Yang.
Their flawless presentation won resounding applause and many enthusiastic fans took photographs with them and sought their autographs after the concert.
The couple said they were flattered to be invited to perform in the Paul VI Hall.

Concert organizers said they were moved by the duo's pursuit of excellence. Even though the couple has worked as a piano duo for a long time, they practiced hard at their hotel and the Paul VI Hall before the concert in order to give their best performance, the organizers said.
Zygmunt Zimowski, chairman of the Pontifical Council for Health Care Workers, said the remarkable performance by Willie and Yeh was one of the highlights of the three-day celebrations.

Yeh, born in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, was a child prodigy who went on to study at the Mozart Academy in Salzburg, Austria, and to later learn from world-class masters such as Hans Leygraf, Kurt Leimer and Jacob Lateiner.

Wille is a German who came to Taiwan at the age of 23 to teach, soon after he graduated from Staatlich Hochschule Fur Musik Hannover. He went on to obtain a doctorate in piano performance at the Manhattan School of Music, New York.

Over the past three decades, the couple has traveled extensively around the world on performance tours and has won critical acclaim for their performances. They recently celebrated their 30th anniversary as a duo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The problem lies with Wall Street

TEXT.P: Lately, the 2008 global financial crisis has been attributed to a world trade imbalance caused by an undervaluing of the Chinese currency. This argument obviously involves a loss of focus, because the crisis was rooted in greed, rather than trade imbalance. The problem came from Wall Street, not Beijing.

Over the past 40 years, during which the United States has had a trade deficit, the U.S. government has been pointing fingers at other countries for undervaluing their currencies and has been using trade retaliation methods to force these countries to raise their currency values.

However, from the Smithsonian Agreement of 1971 to the Plaza Accord of 1985, it has been proven that this approach is totally ineffective. The United States, nonetheless, has never been able to rid itself of this myth.

The problems with the U.S. financial regulatory and supervisory system were exposed as early as 2001 in the Enron scandal. Instead of critically examining the problems, the U.S. government blamed its economic troubles on other countries, which eventually led to an even bigger financial storm.
Regrettably, Wall Street bankers have not learned from the crisis and are still paying out high bonuses without any sense of guilt, even after causing such huge trouble.
Unless these greedy habits are stopped, there will probably be no way to prevent other economic crises, even after the value of the Chinese yuan is raised. (Feb. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: American stage director Robert Wilson reinterprets Chinese hero

TEXT.P: Avant-garde American stage director Robert Wilson's new work "1433-The Grand Voyage" reinterprets Chinese hero Zheng He, a famous voyager of the Ming dynasty in the 15th century, who is widely seen by Chinese people worldwide as a great explorer.

The play, which will be performed at the National Theater Hall in Taipei later this month, is presented in unique poetic beauty and represents an experiment of mixing East and West, yin and yang, as well as seriousness and humor.
Wilson's new work has attracted a great deal of attention in the theater world, largely due to his arrangement of Taiwanese opera and drums, which share the stage with Western Jazz music.

"I did not intend to portray the story of Zheng as depicted in historical accounts in the work, " Wilson said, but instead weave a parable that continues to this day, embodying a mixture of different cultures.
Although Wilson only unveiled the prelude of the drama during the rehearsal Friday, he amazed those in attendance with his mixture of different elements on the same stage.
The play was performed in collaboration with the Taiwanese famous group U Theater, a professional percussion group.
When the curtain rose, the audience was surprised by seeing a new version of U Theater. The drummers of the troupe were wearing white makeup; in the past they wore no makeup.
There was a new combination featuring the drummers of the theater and jazz master Richard Landry on the same stage presenting their music, alternately harmonizing and contrasting with each other.

Another focus of the performance is Tang Mei-yun, a famous Taiwanese opera diva, who narrates the piece in a manner unseen before, changing from a young boy into a serious man, and then to an old man.

Accustomed to playing a handsome, educated man in traditional Taiwanese drama, Tang said: "This performance is quite challenging for me, as it is the first time I could not recognize myself in the mirror; however, I learned a great deal from the director."
As for the set and lighting designs, Wilson's exquisite touches of visual elements enchant the viewers by changing light and contrast to augment the movement on the stage.

After the production of "Orlando" in 2009, "1433-The Grand Voyage" is the second important work on which Wilson has collaborated with the National Theater and Concert Hall, but this is the first time he has cooperated with U Theatre and Tang.
Wilson said in January that he believes Eastern and Western cultures are not separate, and that he has sought to find a unity of East and West through collaboration with Taiwanese artists.

In 2008, Taiwan's U theater was invited to attend a workshop at the Watermill Center in New York, where Wilson invited artists from around the world to exchange artistic experiences and collaborate in theater production.

Wilson said he was impressed by the story of the ancient Chinese explorer Zheng He by writer Liu Ruo-yu of the U Theatre, and decided to present the seven grand voyages of the explorer in the early 15th century on stage.

Between 1405 and 1433, the Ming Dynasty Emperor Yongle put Zheng as the head of seven naval expeditions designed to establish a Chinese presence in other parts of the world and to control trade. Zheng's huge fleet and armed forces visited Arabia, East Africa, India, Indonesia and Thailand. He gave and received gifts along the way, promoting diplomacy and trade. He also fought pirates plaguing the seas. Zheng's voyages, however, were called off by a later emperor. That is seen by many Chinese to this day as one of the factors that curtailed further interaction between China and other countries, which might have strengthened its global outlook at the time.
The world premiere of the Wilson's play will be presented in four acts without intermission from Feb. 20-28 at the National Theater Hall in Taipei. By Sunnie Chen CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: 'Self-protection' referendum drive

TEXT.P: The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou sees public opinion as a ferocious beast, an attitude that has been demonstrated in the administration's handling of other issues besides the proposed referendum against U.S. beef imports.
The government's fear of public opinion is most evident in its rejection of another referendum initiative on the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

It is very strange that even as the Ma administration is presenting to the people the benefits of the trade agreement, it is not allowing the people to express their opinions on the issue through referendum.
Under these circumstances, we as the bosses of the country can only try to revese this trend ourselves. One of the weapons we can use is our power to vote, and the other is referendum.

The policy to open Taiwan's market to U.S. beef is endangering the people's health and life, which is forcing the people to use a referendum to try to protect themselves. Likewise, the ECFA is threatening the people's work and lifelihood, which requires the people to use a referendum to say no to the headstrong Ma administration.

We need to promote a "self-protection referendum" campaign to reverse Ma's China-leaning policy -- an adverse current that is locking Taiwan's economy into the one-China market and entwining Taiwan's politics with the one-China pitfall. (Feb. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day---- 24 indicted for fixing baseball games
DOC.DATELINE: 02/11/10 13:47:22 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The indictment of 24 people, including well-known players, on charges of game- fixing in the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) dominated local newspaper reports Thursday.
The following are excerpts of their coverage of the issue: The Liberty Times:
The Banciao District Prosecutors Office indicted 24 people, five of whom were bookmakers, on charges of fixing CPBL games.
Wu Chien-pao, speaker of the Tainan County Council, was one of the people indicted. He was accused of luring players with money and threatening them with violence to persuade them to throw games.
Many well-known players, such as Chen Chih-yuan and Chang Chih-chia, were also indicted, to the chagrin of their fans.

Another 43 players were also found to have colluded with the gambling rings to fix games, but were either given suspended indictments or not indicted at all because they showed remorse during the probe and handed over part of their illegal gains.
The indictment stated that three gambling rings bribed the above players to throw 32 games between 2008 and 2009.

Although the league has survived four similar scandals in the past, the last one was the biggest in terms of the number of players involved and it threatened to bring down the 20-year-old league. United Daily News:

As if it were not bad enough that they have ruined their careers, the players involved in the scandal are faced with lawsuits brought against them by their clubs for more than NT$100 million (US$3.11 million) in damages.
If they lose the civil suits, they will have to refund their clubs three times the amount they were paid when they signed their contracts, and return their salaries.
La New Bears and Brother Elephants have held these players responsible for the damage to the league, in an effort to show determination to clean up pro baseball.
The players who handed over part of their ill-gotten gains and whose indictments were suspended were ordered to carry out 40 to 200 hours of community service.
Based on the amount they had already spent from their illegal takings, their service will be worth NT$4,000 to NT$20,000 per hour. China Times:
The prosecutors found that the players involved in the scandal originated mainly from several high schools that boast good baseball teams.
The bookmakers were able to gain easy access to these players by first contacting one alumnus who would then lure the others to take the bait, according to the prosecutors.
The prosecutors also found that Wang Guanghui, a former manager of Brother Elephants, was one of the few who turned down the bribes.
The investigators said the bookmakers tried three times to gain Wang's cooperation but he rejected their offers each time. (Feb. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Morakot resettlement expected to be completed before anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 14:10:48 (By Kuo Chih-hsuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-hua said Thursday he hopes people displaced by Typhoon Morakot can be resettled in permanent houses before the first anniversary of storm that wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan last August.

"I am pleased to see land being prepared for the construction of permanent homes for typhoon survivors in several mountain villages in the southernmost county of Pingtung and I hope all the new houses can be completed by the end of July, " Jiang said while inspecting Majia Farm, the site of the resettlement project.
Majia Farm in Pingtung's Majia township will accommodate about 350 households from the county's Haucha and Dashe villages, both of which were destroyed by Morakot-triggered floodwaters and mudslides.

As some households in Majia township have provided ancestral land for the construction project, they will also be part of Majia Farm, bringing the total number of houses to be built on the site to 483, according to Tu Ming-han, president of World Vision Taiwan, which is sponsoring the Majia resettlement project.
Tu told Jiang that the most difficult aspect of the construction project was the land acquisition.

"Now that the thorny land issue has been resolved, land preparation has begun and construction will start in March... Once it starts, it will proceed swiftly and smoothly and we believe all 483 new houses will be ready for occupancy by typhoon victims by the end of July," Tu said.
Typhoon survivors from Haucha and Dashe villages will be hired to build their new homes under an "employment replacing relief" program, Tu added.
"The new houses will all be environmentally friendly buildings, with each unit expected to help reduce carbon emissions by 40 tons per year," Tu went on.

In addition, nine churches and one elementary school will also be built on Majia Farm. Moreover, a specialty industry development center will be established to help residents start up new businesses and earn a living on their own in the future.
Jiang expressed gratitude to and admiration for World Vision Taiwan, a Christian charity, for its dedicated assistance in the effort to resettle displaced typhoon victims.
Typhoon Morakot struck southern Taiwan Aug.7-9, 2009, leaving more than 700 dead or missing and thousands homeless.
On Thursday, more than 400 eligible Morokot victims in Kaohsiung County were resettled in new permanent houses built by a Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation-organized construction project.

The housing project in the southern county's Shanlin township, launched Nov. 15 last year, is called the Great Love community and is spread over a 60-hectare area. Tzu Chi, which plans to build 1,500 houses on the site, has completed the first 600.

DOC.HEADLINE: Humanitarian aid knows no borders: Red Cross official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 15:00:23 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: International assistance should not be confined only to the country's diplomatic allies, and Taiwan should do what it can to extend a helping hand whether the country in crisis is an ally or not, C.V. Chen, president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, has suggested.
In an article contributed to the China Times, Chen discussed the signifance of President Ma Ying-jeou's recent trip to the Carribeans.

Chen noted that he suggested to President Ma Ying-jeou prior to the president's recent visit to Honduras and the Dominican Republic that Taiwan should not donate only money to the impoverished and devastated Caribbean nation, but should also use its expertise and resources in post-disaster reconstruction to help the Haitian people get back to normal life.
Ma then floated this idea during a meeting with Haitian Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive and Dominican President Leonel Fernandez in the Dominican Republic, winning support from both leaders.

Chen noted that since Ma declared a diplomatic truce with China following his inauguration in 2008, the president has set great store on foreign policy that has a legitimate purpose, uses legal means and is implemented efficiently.
In his article, Chen said this approach creates a situation that is beneficial in four major aspects.
First, Taiwan earns respect for such assistance because every penny spent goes toward the development of its diplomatic allies, according to Chen.
Second, it serves the people of the diplomatic allies rather than simply lining the pockets of high officials in those countries.
Third, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait no longer have to engage in checkbook diplomacy in their tug-of-war for diplomatic allies.

Finally, Taiwan contributes more to the international community with less political interference, Chen said, noting that Taiwan, though having limited resources in some respects, is rich in terms of the capacity and the will to carry out humanitarian work.
Chen also suggested to Ma that the government should track and monitor the progress and results of the reconstruction work in Haiti.

International assistance should not be confined only to the country's diplomatic allies either, Chen went on in the article, adding that Taiwan should do what it can to extend a helping hand whether the country in crisis is an ally or not.

He said the private sector is the most dynamic sector in Taiwan and that whenever disaster strikes somewhere in the world, it is Taiwanese private and religious groups that are most efficient at mobilizing for assistance.
The government, however, has not used the strengths of the non-government offices to make the maximum efficient use of the available resources, he said.
Chen expressed a positive outlook regarding the diplomatic direction of the Ma administration, but said that its attitude and operations should be more open and should be further refined.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top national security official resigns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 15:24:54 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi announced his surprise resignation Thursday, citing family and health reasons.
Su, who has recently faced harsh criticism over the controversial U.S. beef import dispute, made the announcement at a hastily called press conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Government officials, lawmakers bully taxpayers

TEXT.P: Had the state-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp. not been caught overcharging consumers NT$5.44 billion for air pollution fees and a crude oil fund, would it have returned the money to the people voluntarily? Had the dual nationality case of former Legislator Lee Ching-an not been brought to light, would anyone have demanded that she return the more-than NT$100 million in salary that she received illegally?
The answers to these questions are very simple: Definitely not.

Lawmakers are supposed to watch taxpayers' money on behalf of the people, but why do these legislators not amend the law to require those whose elections were annulled to return their campaign subsidies? The answer is because every legislator is afraid that he or she could be caught involved in an irregularity one day and be forced to return money.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang used to be chairman of CPC. How could he possibly be unaware that the company has been overcharging consumers?

If Shih was aware of the situation but did not step in, he was unfairly favoring CPC and is therefore an accomplice to fraud. If he did not know, he was muddled and ignorant. Does this make him qualified to hold a ministerial position? (Feb. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Retired diplomat to be president's new top security aide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 15:53:58 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Hu Wei-jen, a retired diplomat, will be President Ma Ying-jeou's new top national security aide, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Thursday.
Hu, who has served as Taiwan's representative to Germany and to Singapore, will succeed Su Chi as secretary-general of the National Security Council, Wang said.
The official handover ceremony will take place Feb. 23, Wang added.
Su, a former lawmaker and former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, tendered his resignation earlier in the day.
Su told a news conference that he resigned because he felt he has completed his mission after 20 months and 20 days in office.
He had recently come under harsh criticism for his ineptitude in handling the controversial U.S. beef import dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Mixed reaction to relaxed investment rules

TEXT.P: Taiwan's latest move to relax restrictions on China-bound high-tech investment has drawn mixed reaction from the local business community.
A spokesman for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. said the latest liberalization move is not enough to help local chip makers grab larger market shares in China.

Nevertheless, some foreign securities brokerage analysts said the newly relaxed investment regulations will help companies in flat panel and wafer fab sectors save transport costs and improve operational efficiency.

Taiwan further relaxed restrictions Wednesday on China-bound investment in the flat panel, chip foundry, high-end chip packaging and testing, and low-end IC design sectors, taking another step forward in its efforts to forge closer economic and trade links with China.
Under the new regulations, Taiwanese companies will also be allowed to buy into or merge with Chinese wafer fabs.
The following are excerpts of local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

Under the revised rules, Taiwanese TFT-LCD makers will conditionally be allowed to invest in facilities more advanced than 6th-generation plants, but the number of such plants will be capped at three.
In addition, the flat panel plants to be set up in China must be less advanced than the applicant's Taiwan facility by at least one generation, the rules stipulate.

Under the new regulations, the current system of allowing local companies to establish no more than three 8-inch wafer foundries will be maintained, and restrictions on the establishment of less technologically advanced facilities will be removed.

As for 12-inch wafer fabs using processes more advanced than 0.13 micrometers, Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang quoted local wafer processors as saying that they are in no hurry to head to China to build or acquire plants for the manufacture of 12-inch wafers.
"The two prominent pending cases involving Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) should be addressed first, " Shih said. (Feb. 11, 2010)
United Daily News:
The Ministry of Economic Affairs' relaxation of restrictions on Taiwanese high- tech investment in China will serve to free TSMC and UMC from their investment entanglements in China.

The relaxed regulations pertaining to acquisition will help settle the intellectual property rights dispute between TSMC and the China-based Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. and help resolve UMC's controversial investment in China's Hejian Co.
In turn, the new regulations are also expected to benefit more than 1 million investors in these two leading semiconductor manufacturing companies. (Feb. 11, 2010)
Economic Daily News:

Some people have argued that Taiwanese makers may not be able to compete with their South Korean counterparts in China because the Korean government has allowed its companies to establish up to 8.5-generation plants, while Taiwan manufacturers are permitted to set up plants only up to 7.5-generation.

Officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs have discounted this view, saying that Taiwan's cap on this type of investment is set at 7.5-generation at present, but Taiwanese makers may be allowed to invest in 8.5-generation plants in China if they continue to upgrade their manufacturing technologies at home.
Besides, the officials noted, the Chinese authorities have not yet approved high-end investment by any South Korean TFT-LCD manufacturer.

Currently, about half of the flat panels sold throughout China are supplied by Taiwanese makers, they said. In addition, the TFT-LCD manufacturing industry is expected to be included on the early harvest list during talks between Taiwan and China on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which Taiwan hopes can be signed in the first half of this year, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Tsai not ready for meeting with president
DOC.DATELINE: 02/11/10 15:59:44 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma has said several times that he would like to meet with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, but each time Tsai has given a different excuse for not being able to meet with the president.
However, the real reason is that she would find herself under great pressure in any meeting with Ma, and she's not ready for that.
Since the fall of President Chen Shiu-bian and the pro-independence movement in 2008, the DPP has not yet come up with a cohesive position on the country's status or its future.
If the DPP cannot formulate a theory on Taiwan's status and develop a China policy based on that, Tsai's meeting with Ma would be pointless.
There is some truth to the statement by political pundits that Ma has the upper hand in terms of policy but is the underdog in public polls.

Ma insists that the country is the Republic of China, acknowledges the 1992 Consensus that states there is one China but with different interpretations, and is pushing a policy of reaching out to China without altering the status quo. But what would be Tsai's stance on these issues? Would she agree with Ma on the 1992 Consensus? Would she agree with Ma's promises to set aside the question of Taiwan independence or unification with China and to renounce violence?
If she doesn't, what alternatives she can offer the people?

If Tsai is opposed to Ma's idea of a trade pact with China, then she has to offer an alternative that would address the problems Taiwan would face as the result of a new trading bloc that revolves around ASEAN.
Furthermore, Tsai's alternatives would have to stand up to public scrutiny, not just offhand snide criticisms by other politicians.

Tsai is reported to be working on a 10-year manifesto for the DPP, which would form the basis of the party's policies under her leadership. The title of the manifesto indicates that it would be a short-lived document.

We do not expect too much from this manifesto because 10 years is too short a time to implement any national policy. But we do hope that Tsai will accept Ma's invitation for a meeting and will give the public new hope.(Feb. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Oversight committee on cross-strait affairs redundant: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 15:59:48 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A scholar on East Asian affairs stated in in a newspaper opinion piece that as the legislature's Internal Administration Committee already oversees issues related to cross-Taiwan strait exchanges, a new legislative committee for this purpose would be redundant.

Professor Chiu Kun-Shuan of National Cheng Chi University noted in the United Daily News article Tuesday that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus is demanding the establishment of a legislative committee to oversee the current cross-strait negotiations.

"DPP legislators may have forgotten that in 2005 during their party's rule, their legislative caucus was strongly against the establishment of a cross- strait committee and they suggested that such a committee would intrude on the president's jurisdiction, "he stated.

He noted that President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday in a press briefing on the proposed cross-strait agreement that while the government would not shun oversight, he would expect that the jurisdiction of the legislature would be observed, in accordance with the Constitution.
From the perspective of the governmental system, a proper assessment should be made to see whether the legislature falls short in its performance of such functions, the scholar suggested.

Currently, the Mainland Affairs Council reports to the Internal Administration Committee of the legislature, and arranges informal briefings on the government's cross-strait policies to the legislative speaker and executives of party caucuses, the professor stated.
"While the legislative committee holds the decision-making power, all motions must be forwarded to the general assembly," he added.

"Important policies, such as the signing of an ECFA which involves legal issues such as tariffs, must be screened by the Internal Administration Committee and approved by the assembly before they could be implemented," he elaborated.
In addition, the Executive Yuan has decided to give 10 briefings to the legislature on the progress of the ECFA negotiations from February to June, he said.

Therefore, the creation of a new legislative committee would be redundant, Chiu said. An oversight mechanism for cross-strait negotiations has always been there, and it is not possible for the Executive Yuan to unilaterally make relevant decisions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait exchanges strengthening: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 16:06:13 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou cited Thursday the attendance at a cross-Taiwan Strait seminar in Taiwan on swine flu by an official Chinese delegation led by China's vice health minister in January as an important milestone in cross-strait efforts on epidemic disease prevention.

"We expect cross-strait exchanges to expand beyond business and investment to other areas such as the biotechnology and medical fields," Ma said at his office, where he met with winners of the 2009 National Biotechnology and Medical Quality Awards presented by the National Institute for Biotechnology and Medicine Industry.
The institute was founded by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and is presently chaired by former National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-chao.

The president noted that Chen led a Taiwanese delegation to China last year and that the visit was reciprocated by a visit to Taiwan in January by Chinese Vice Health Minister Huang Jiefu for the swine flu seminar.

He said the biotechnology industry is crucial for Taiwan's long-term development and was listed last February as one of the six emerging industries in Taiwan entitled to special investment incentives.

Meanwhile, he went on, Taiwan's Food and Drug Administration (FDA) , which streamlined four bureaus under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) into one and became officially operational Jan. 1, will also help accelerate the modernization of the country's food and drug management.

"I believe Taiwan's food and drug industry will grow into another NT$1 trillion (US$31.25 billion) business sector in four years under the concerted efforts of the government and the private sector, " he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top national security official resigns (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 16:11:38 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top national security aide to President Ma Ying-jeou, announced his surprise resignation Thursday, citing family and health reasons.

National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi, who had recently faced harsh criticism for his inept handling of the U.S. beef import controversy, made the announcement at a hastily called press conference at the Presidential Office.
He declined to take questions from the media and left the Presidential Office immediately after reading his resignation statement.
Ma immediately accepted Su's resignation, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu- chi said after Su's remarks.
The president recognized Su's contributions to the promotion of relations with the United States, China and Japan in the 20 months since Ma took office, Wang said.
Hu Wei-jen, Taiwan's former representative to Singapore and to Germany, will assume Su's post Feb. 23, Wang said.
Hu, a career diplomat, has 35 years of experience in diplomatic and national security affairs, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA denies Indonesia boycotting Taiwan shipbuilders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 16:34:07 (By Sinyao Shih and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday dismissed media reports that the Indonesian government has prohibited its fishermen from commissioning the construction of fishing boats in Taiwan.

The Indonesian government has given the assurance that as the two countries are World Trade Organization members, Indonesia would not take any discriminatory action against Taiwan that could breach the WTO's most-favored trading partner principle, a MOFA official said Thursday.

Forbidding fishing industry operators from buying boats from Taiwan, or preventing them from placing orders with Taiwanese shipbuilders would amount to discriminatory behavior, under the terms of the WTO agreement, the Indonesian government indicated.
Under the WTO principle, each members should treat the others equally as "most- favored" trading partners.

According to local media reports Wednesday, shipbuilders in southern Taiwan complained to opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Kuan Bi-ling in January that Indonesia had ordered its fishermen to stop commissioning fishing trawlers from Taiwan. The directive has resulted in losses of about NT$100 million a year, the shipbuilders reportedly said.

However, the Indonesian government said that in order to protect its fishery resources, improve management of fishing boats, and encourage foreign investment, it has suspended imports of old fishing boats, unless the import orders are placed by foreign companies or foreign-invested companies that have fish processing plants in Indonesia, according to the MOFA official.
The policy applies to all countries in the world, not just one country, the Indonesian government said, stressing that it has not banned the importation of newly constructed fishing boats.

Suhartono, head of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei, has said that Taiwanese ships are popular among Indonesian fishing operators because of their competitive price and quality, and are incomparable with those built in other East Asian countries, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 16:35:38 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0. 021 to close at NT$32.045.
A total of US$597 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.095 and had a low of NT$32.030.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: The economic problems of four EU member states

TEXT.P: 500 days after the eruption of the global financial crisis, four EU member states' financial problems have sent shockwaves through the world again.
The four countries -- Portugal, Italy, Greece and Spain -- are saddled by huge government debts that have put their sovereign credit in crisis.
As a result, investors have retreated en masse from their bourses, causing a plummet of stock prices worldwide, with even Taiwan feeling the pinch.
The four states were relatively feeble in the EU in terms of financial strength prior to the crisis.
At the beginning of the global financial crisis, all four followed the lead of other EU states by raising loans to finance extra spending to stimulate economic growth.
However, as states with the euro as their currency, they are subject to EU limitations on government loans and had to increase taxes to offset the loans.
They therefore found themselves stuck between a rock and a hard place, as increasing taxes undid their efforts to stimulate the economy by increasing government spending.

In order to defuse their crises, the EU has had to funnel 200 billion euros into them, or they would be forced to withdraw from the EU in exchange for free scope to deal with their problems, which would cripple the EU, or else they would have to retreat from the euro, which would reduce the EU into a free trade zone and put paid to the EU's hopes for a currency with the strength of the U.S. dollar.
It seems the EU will have no option but to help them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. turns tough toward China: lawmaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 18:11:55 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has adopted an increasingly tougher stance on its dealings with China, according to ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, who had just returned from a visit to the U.S.

Hsieh said Thursday that many of the senators, congressmen and scholars he met during his visit were of the opinion that there might be "subtle" changes in Washington's China policy since President Barack Obama's moderate and low-key approach toward China has received no positive response from Beijing, as evidenced by such international issues as the value of the Chinese currency and climate change.

After being criticized as being "too weak, " the Obama administration has recently turned tougher toward China, Hsieh said, citing Obama's approval late last month of an arms sales package to Taiwan and the possibility that he might meet with the Dalai Lama.

The U.S. government has notified Congress of its decision on the arms sales package, which includes 60 UH- 60M Black Hawk helicopters worth US$3.1 billion, two Osprey Class mine-hunting ships and 12 ATM-84L and RTM-84L Harpoon Block II Telemetry missiles.

Also included are 114 Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missiles and technical support worth US$2.82 billion, 35 multifunctional information distribution systems low volume terminals (MIDS/LVT-1) and 25 MIDS on ships terminals. The arms sales will take effect if the U.S. Congress does not voice objections within 30 days of the notification and the package is expected to become effective in a week.

"Subtle changes are taking place among the triangular Taipei- Washington-Beijing relations, and Taiwan should try to strike a strategic balance in the relationship so as to pursue its best interests, " Hsieh said.

Hsieh met with U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski, House Representative Patrick J. Kennedy and Walter Lohman, director of the Asian Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation, as well as several other think thank experts.

He extended his appreciation for the arms deal, and expressed hope both that a Taipei-Washington extradition treaty can be signed and that Taiwan can be included on Washington's list of visa-waiver countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier pushes for better management of state enterprises
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 18:22:50 (By K. S. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih stressed Thursday the need to improve management of state- owned businesses and he instructed a Cabinet task force to ensure greater transparency in the operations of such enterprises to make them more competitive.
Wu issued the directive after being briefed by Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials on the issue, at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
The premier asked that the task force, led by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, to more closely monitor the government agencies that are in charge of running state companies.
He said management transparency and the operational strategies of these businesses must be improved in order for them to become more efficient and profitable.
To that end, a set of national-level management mechanisms must be put in place, Wu added.

In the Cabinet briefing, the MOF officials said the central government has total "direct investments" of NT$37.9 trillion (US$ 1.184 trillion) in 49 businesses. Some 377 government appointees sit on the boards of these enterprises, the MOF reported.
The central government also has NT$74.24 billion worth of "indirect investments" in 674 businesses, in which there are 2,214 government appointed supervisors and board members, the MOF said.
The major problems facing these state-run companies are the lack of a standard system for evaluating and paying personnel, as well as poor performance and incompetence, the MOF officials said.
With some of these state enterprises being operated by different government agencies, there is often a lack of coordination among the different departments, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Players involved in game-fixing banned from teaching
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 18:34:04 (By Lee Ming-chung, Hsiao Pao-hsiang, Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Thursday that baseball players who face termination of their professional baseball careers for game-fixing will also be forbidden from becoming teachers or coaches.

The tough move is seen as a fresh show of the SAC's determination to revitalize baseball in the wake of the indictment of 24 people on charges of game-fixing in the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) a day earlier.
Among those indicted were Brother Elephants star outfielder Chen Chih-yuan and former La New Bears star pitcher Chang Chih-chia. Brother Elephants said Wednesday that it had decided to fire Chen.

SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said that although not being able to play baseball again is the biggest punishment for a professional baseball player, there is a consensus between the SAC and the Ministry of Education that the criminals must also not be allowed to teach or coach. Tai expressed hope that the prosecutors will bring all those involved to justice.
"We will face this crisis even if it means rubbing salt into the wound," she said.
She said the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has cooperated with the National Police Agency to set up an emergency game-fixing reporting system.
After the CPBL season begins March 20, prosecutors will also visit various stadiums to monitor the games, she added.
According to Cabinet spokesman Su Jun-pin, Premier Wu Den-yih has asked the MOJ to step up its crackdown on game-fixing so as not to disappoint the country's baseball fans.

Also Thursday, Sinon Bulls released a statement announcing its decision to dismiss outfielder Hsieh Chia-hsien for receiving inappropriate gains and for maintaining close interaction with a gambling ring, although Hsieh was not indicted due to lack of evidence.

Meanwhile, the ruling Kuomintang's disciplinary committee decided to revoke the membership of Tainan County Council Speaker Wu Chien-pao, who was indicted on charges of fraud and gambling for bribing baseball players to manipulate game results.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd round of ECFA negotiations to begin soon: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 18:41:51 (By Chang Min-kun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The second round of negotiations on a proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will begin after the Lunar New Year holidays, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

MAC Deputy Minister Chao Chien-min said the cross-strait trade agreement is expected to be concluded during the fifth meeting between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

He called on Taiwanese people with businesses in China to support the signing of the ECFA in light of its significance from the perspective of cross-strait relations as well as Taiwan's economic strategies.
At an SEF party for Taiwanese businessmen and staff of Taiwanese schools in China, Chao briefed the participants on the progress of the cross-strait negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhaustion prompts top national security advisor to quit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 19:21:20 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Exhaustion has prompted Su Chi to step down as the top national security advisor to President Ma Ying-jeou, sources said Thursday.
"I am actually very exhausted, " the government sources quoted the secretary general of the National Security Council (NSC) as saying.
Su expressed to Ma his desire to quit after he returned from a diplomatic tour to Central America at the end of January with the president, according to the sources, who requested anonymity.
Ma approved Su's resignation earlier in the day after holding several discussions with Su in recent days. Su Announced his resignation at a hastily called press conference Thursday.
Su is expected to remain as one of Ma's important advisors on national policies, the sources said.

Su is known for coining a term of "1992 consensus, " by which he asserted that Taiwan and China agreed to have their own interpretation of "one China" to avoid Taiwan's sovereignty issue becoming an obstacle in developing cross-strait relations with China.
The sources said Su decided to resign at this time because he believes the NSC has made several achievements, including restoring the trust of the country's "important international friends."
Also, the NSC has helped ease the tense situation between Taiwan and its long- time political rival China since Ma took office, the sources said.
"Su hopes to take a break for a while because he never took a day off during his 20-month term in office," the sources said.
Su had liver cancer in the past and needs to undergo a health checkup every four months, the sources said, adding that Su has delayed his health exam several times because of his job.
The result of Su's last health checkup was okay, they said.

The sources dismissed allegations that Su resigned to take responsibility for the U.S. beef import controversy which erupted a few months ago, in which the U.S. accused Taiwan of violating a protocol after Taiwan's legislature passed a law amendment to restrict U.S. beef products, overturning an administration decision to lift a ban on certain U.S. beef products.

The impact of the controversy has already been minimized and it did not affect the decision by the United States to allow President Ma to make a recent transit stop in the U.S. during his diplomatic trip abroad, the sources noted.
New NSC Secretary General Hu Wei-jen, a career diplomat, will be sworn in on Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68% of local firms have plans to recruit: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 19:21:30 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Following an improvement in the unemployment situation, 68 percent of enterprises that responded to a recent survey plan to recruit new employees after the Chinese New Year holiday, an online job bank said Thursday.

According to the results of the survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank among 604 companies Jan. 14-20, of the 68 companies planning to recruit, 49.5 percent have listed job vacancies before the holiday.

The survey shows that 77 percent of the respondents said they believe that this year, Taiwan's economy will revert to how it was before the global financial crisis, while 53 percent even expressed optimism that the recovery will take hold in the first half of this year.

Finance, investment consulting and insurance providers are the most optimistic of economic recovery, with 64 percent predicting that the economy will rebound to the level of before the financial crisis in the first half of this year.

Their optimism is based on the hope that the signing of memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial regulatory cooperation with China and the opening to Chinese investment in Taiwan will give a boost to teh local economy, said Fang Guang-wei, public relations manager for 104 Job Bank.

Meanwhile, 60.8 percent of companies from the information technology, software and semiconductor sector, and 60 percent from the construction industry, expect the economy to recover to the level of before the financial crisis during the first six months.
Less than 40 percent of enterprises in the logistics and warehouse sector, as well as in the tourism, leisure and sports sector had the same opinion.

Among those with the highest demand for new employees are computer, consumer electronics and semiconductor manufacturers, the insurance, financial and banking industry, and the optics and photonics sector.
In terms of occupation, marketing and sales representatives, finance professionals, technicians, customer service personnel and R&D specialists in engineering are in highest demand.
According to another survey by the same job bank, the number of job-seekers in February dropped 10.5 percent year-on-year.
Over the past two months, unemployed people spent an average of 6.42 months finding a job.

Of those looking for work, people in the medical and health care sector and the environmental sanitation sector spent the least time of about 3.6 months before finding a job, while those in the construction and real estate sector spent 3.6 months and those in financial and insurance companies spent 3.8 months before finding work.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP unimpressed by change of president's top security aide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 19:41:53 (By Wen Guei-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The resignation of President Ma Ying-jeou's top security aide has come too late and the political integrity and ability of his replacement remains questionable, a spokesman for the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Liu Chien-hsin, deputy head of the DPP's policy research and coordination department, was referring to the resignation of Su Chi from his post as secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC) and the Presidential Office's announcement of Hu Wei-jen, a retired diplomat, as Su's successor.
"Su should have resigned much earlier because his inept handling of the U.S. beef import protocol has cost our country dearly, " Liu said.

Su, one of Ma's most trusted advisers, is believed to have played a key role in striking a deal with the United States last October that would see Taiwan lifting import bans on U.S. bone-in beef and bovine offal.

The deal sparked strong opposition in Taiwan and prompted the Legislative Yuan to pass legal amendments to bar imports of U.S. ground beef and bovine offal over mad cow disease concerns. The about-face, however, drew a backlash from the United States, which has suspended a planned resumption of sub-Cabinet-level talks under a Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement and has threatened to bring the dispute to the World Trade Organization for arbitration.

Legislator Lee Chun-yee, the DPP's legislative whip, said Su's resignation was mainly a gambit by the Ma administration to sacrifice a lower-level functionary in a bid to protect Ma and halt the continuing downward spiral of his public approval ratings.
Nevertheless, Lee said, he doubts the effectiveness of the tactic because the resignation came too late.
"Su should have resigned right after the legislature passed amendments to the Food Sanitation Act," he added.

On Su's replacement, meanwhile, Liu Chien-hsin noted that Hu was Taiwan's representative to Germany and then to Singapore when the DPP was in power. Before his resignation from the Singapore representative post in 2007, Hu criticized then-President Chen Shui-bian's de-sinicization drive and his branding of the late President Chiang Kai-shek as a dictator.

"Hu's statement was a show of loyalty to the then-opposition Kuomintang... His political integrity is something that should be monitored, as he did not voice his disagreement with the DPP's ideology until after having worked in the DPP administration for seven years," Liu said.
According to DPP Legislator Tsai Hung-liang, Hu is a hardline ideologue and career diplomat, with little national defense and intelligence training.
"Hu is a greenhorn in security affairs... He might be even more incompetent than Su... the personnel change is a bad call, " Tsai claimed.

While announcing Ma's decison to name Hu as his new top security aide, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Hu was familiar with diplomatic and national security affairs as he is a career diplomat and has served as deputy chief of the National Security Bureau and deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veteran diplomat Hu named Taiwan's top national security aide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 19:51:13 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou wasted no time to appoint his new top national security advisor as Hu Wei-chen was selected to fill the void left by Su Chi, who resigned as the Secretary General of the National Security Council Thursday.

Hu Wei-chen, 63, will assume the post Feb. 23 right after the nine-day lunar New Year break, replacing Su Chi, who resigned, citing health concerns and family reasons, the Presidential Office said in a press release.
Hu is a seasoned veteran on foreign affairs and national security matters and has a military background.

His father Hu Tsung-nan was a high-ranking general as well as a close confidant of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in the Kuomintang (KMT) government during World War II and the Chinese civil war in the 1950s.
His background and familiarity with military affairs will help Hu in his post at the NSC, said Justin Chou, a ruling KMT legislator.

Hu started his career as a diplomat, serving as Director General of the Department of Protocol in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and was posted in Chicago and other cities in the United States. Later he served as Taiwan's representative to Germany and Singapore.

He was also familiar with national security affairs, serving as the deputy chief of the National Security Bureau under former Presidents Lee Teng-hui and deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council under former President Chen Shui-bian's administration.

The timing of Su's resignation is intriguing, said Lo Chih-cheng, a political scientist at Soochow University. Lo said he believes there have been internal and external pressures -- from the U.S. or China -- that forced Su to step down.
Choosing to announce the resignation right before the lunar New Year break, Lo said, is a tactic to avoid the resignation turning into a hot topic in the media during the nine-day break.
Legislator Chou said that while it is a pity to see Su go, Hu's appointment is a correct move. He praised Hu as "a man of integrity and decency" and expected his "brilliant performance" at the NSC.
"With his military background and expertise in foreign affairs and national security, he will do a good job, " Chou said.

As Taiwan's representative to Singapore, he criticized his own government in 2007 when then President Chen attempted to "de-Sinicize" Taiwan and to play down the legacy of Chiang. Hu was forced to resign over the ensuing controversy.

Hu is expected to pick up where Su left off in terms of national security policy and he alone will not be able to make dramatic changes, which means the policy of the Ma administration will remain unchanged, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to build affordable housing near MRT station
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 20:24:14 (By Ho Hsu-ju and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The government will offer 4,000 affordable housing units for sale near the projected Linkuo station of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system in 2013, with low income families who do not already own property given purchasing preference, a Ministry of the Interior official said Thursday.

Yeh Shih-wen, director of the ministry's Construction and Planning Agency, said the government will use approximately 226 hectares of reserved land and farmland around the projected MRT station to build the housing, with each unit price kept as low as NT$150,000 per ping (3.3 square meters).

While housing prices in Taipei City and some locations in Taipei County have been skyrocketing over the past few years, a survey report released by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Cabinet last December indicated that high housing prices in the city topped the list of public complaints.

To help the payroll class live in their own apartments, the government therefore decided to build affordable housing units with traffic convenience. The 4,000 units at Linkuo are expected to be completed in 2013, when an extension of the MRT system to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is completed.
According to Yeh, the travel time from Linkuo to the MRT's Taipei Main Station stop will be around 30 minutes.

He said more affordable housing units are planned along the line and added that the government is also planning to build public housing units on the outskirts of Tamsui township in Taipei County when a light rail system is built to serve the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: European debt crisis `just aftershock: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 20:52:58 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The debt crisis in Europe is an aftershock of the global financial crisis and it will be only a small problem, a local expert said Thursday, urging the public not to panic.

"It is impossible not to have aftershocks after the world has experienced such a huge financial crisis, " Chu Yun-peng, a professor of economics at National Central University, said at a seminar organized by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum.
"However, these aftershocks often are smaller, " the former minister without portfolio went on.

He also said that great attention is being paid to the debt crisis affecting Greece, Spain, Portugal and Italy, which will help prevent the problem from developing into a bigger one, as governments are already taking measures.

Bert Lim, president of the World Economics Society, predicted at the seminar that the value of the euro against the U.S. dollar will decrease, as many countries are selling the European currency from their foreign reserves.
"A falling euro will make the greenback a strong currency again, " he noted.

Lim added that international oil and raw material prices will also go up as the U.S. dollar goes down but he also warned that the government should pay close attention to the impact of a rising U.S. dollar on Taiwan's exports.
Lin Chien-fu, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said decreasing tax revenues and an increasing financial deficit have taken Taiwan's debt-to-GDP ratio to nearly 40 percent.
He warned that Taiwan's debt rating might be downgraded as a result.
Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lo Shu-lei expressed similar concerns over Taiwan's debt and urged the government to reconsider whether it is right to expand public expenditure and cut taxes.

Nieh Chien-Chung, a professor at Tamkang University's Banking and Finance Department, pointed out that Greece has had a debt problem for a long time and said the problem will not grow into another global crisis.
He also predicted that the European Central Bank (ECB) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will take action to solve the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beitou cable car project might resume by year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:14:54 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Construction of the trouble-plagued Beitou cable car system might be resumed by the end of this year after a hiatus of almost four years, the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

If the Taipei city government decides to cooperate with the previous winning bidder of the contract and reports to it on the latest situation, the cable car construction project could be rekindled by year-end, as long as the National Parks Planning Committee under the MOI gives its approval, the CPA said.

Late last year, the CPA demanded that the city government, which is in charge of the project, report back within three months on whether it will continue collaborating with the previous winning bidder to carry out the build-operate- transfer (BOT) project. The deadline will expire in late February.

The construction license for the project was revoked in 2005 after then-Vice Minister of the Interior Yen Wan-ching and Cai Bai-lu, then-director of Yangmingshan National Park, were charged with taking kickbacks from a developer who sought to get a construction license for the project.
Yen was sentenced to 15 years in prison after being found guilty on corruption charges in four separate cases, including his acceptance of bribes from the developer.
Cai was sentenced to two years and six months for his involvement in the bribery scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$50 billion to be invested to ensure stable water supply
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:16:14 (By Wen Guei-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed a draft statute Thursday on dredging at three major reservoirs in southern Taiwan in order to stabilize the water supply in the region.

According to the draft statute, the government will spend up to NT$50 billion dredging the Tsengwen, Nanhua and Wushantou reservoirs in Chiayi and Tainan counties, one of Taiwan's agricultural strongholds, over the next six years to ensure a stable water supply in the area.

Of the amount, NT$18 billion will come from a special budget to revitalize the domestic economy and expand infrastructure construction, while the remainder will be financed by central government agencies and special national development funds, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said at a weekly Cabinet meeting during which the draft statute was passed.

The three reservoirs are major sources of water for household, irrigation and industrial use in southern Taiwan. Due to environmental degradation and inadequate conservation efforts, the three reservoirs have become swamped with silt, which has limited their storage capacities and has led to water shortages in the region.
After listening to Shih's report, Premier Wu Den-yih said ensuring a stable water supply in the south is a government priority.

As ecological conservation in the catchment areas and reservoir management are crucial to the functioning of reservoirs, Wu said, the relevant city and county governments should step up monitoring and cracking down on illegal logging, farming and construction in the catchment areas to prevent mudslides in upstream catchment areas.

According to the special statute, no new access roads can be created in the three reservoirs' catchment areas and construction of sand dams must meet the provisions set forth in the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law.
The new project will also include the improvement of existing access roads in the regions, but the roads will not be allowed to expand.
"The whole project will be finished in six years," Shih said at a news conference after the Cabinet meeting.
The statute will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for screening and approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fishing boat, crew released by Somali pirates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:31:28 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessel and all its crew were released Thursday after the boat's owner paid a ransom to Somali pirates, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
The 700-ton longliner Win Far 161, with a crew of 30, was hijacked by Somali pirates near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6 last year, a MOFA official said Thursday.
Since the incident, the MOFA used every means over the past 10 months to seek assistance from various international organizations in an effort to rescue the vessel and crew, the official added.

After receiving information that the ship was to be released, the MOFA also helped the owner to contact international maritime and anti-piracy organizations to ask them to provide humanitarian aid and protection for the ship and its crew upon the release, according to the official.
Through their efforts, the crewmen were provided with food, water and fuel and were given health checks and other support, the official said.
The government also expressed gratitude for the help provided by the international organizations.

The rescue efforts were made even more difficult because of the Somalian interim provisional government's inability to rule the country and because of the withdrawal of U.S., British and U.N. bases and other international organizations from the country due to the political unrest there, according to the official.
The MOFA warned that Taiwanese fishing vessels should steer clear of waters near East Africa to avoid the many Somali pirates who operate there with near- impunity.

Those that insist on sailing in the area should be registered with the European Maritime Safety Agency through its Web site: www.mschoa.com. The agency is responsible for improving maritime safety by providing technical assistance, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese poachers arrested on Kinmen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:34:30 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Three men aboard a fishing boat from China's Fujian Province were arrested Thursday for poaching fish in waters off Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities said later that day.

The poachers were arrested and 159 kg of high-value fish worth NT$2 million seized after coast guard fired warning shots at the boat, which had intruded into waters near Dayan Islet, to force it to stop for an inspection.

During the raid, the poachers tried to destroy evidence related to the crime -- a burning fuse -- and attempted to ram the two multi-function patrol boats mobilized by the CGA, according to the authorities.
The officers also discovered 39 torpedo tubes aboard the vessel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former GIO chief impeached for misusing fund for DPP drive
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:55:23 (By Sophia Yeh and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Former Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey was impeached Thursday by the Control Yuan for improperly using a government reserve fund to finance a publicity drive for a referendum bill launched by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations.
The referendum, which was initiated in 2007 by the then-ruling DPP to ask voters whether Taiwan should join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," was vetoed March 22, 2008.
The Control Yuan, the country's top watchdog agency, approved by a 10-2 vote the motion submitted by yuan members Ma Hsiu-ju and Ma Yi-kung to impeach Hsieh
Ma Hsiu-ju said Hsieh twice transferred from the Cabinet's reserve fund a total of NT$45 million to finance a publicity campaign to urge the public to support the referendum bill.
During the investigation process, Hsieh agreed that government funds should not be used in support of any drive launched by a political party, according to Ma Hsiu-ju.

In addition, he added, almost all the amount of money was spent before the March 22 voting day, without considering the fact the U.N. General Assembly session opened in September -- a clear indication that Hsieh simply used the publicity campaign to boost the DPP's bill rather than to actually promote Taiwan's U.N. membership.
The Control Yuan also censured the Executive Yuan, the GIO, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and the Sports Affairs Council in collaborating with Hsieh in using the funds.
Hsieh said the Control Yuan's decision was "unacceptable" but that he would not decide how to respond until after he had read the official impeachment letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan defeated by Japan in football tourney
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:59:16 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei was defeated Thursday by Japan in the East Asian Women's Football Championship 2010 being held at the Japanese National Stadium in Tokyo.

Japan scored in the 35th minute and continued an offensive strategy in the second half of the game, scoring again in the 59th minute and hammering the final into the Taiwanese coffin in the 84th minute.
The 3-0 defeat was the second setback for Chinese Taipei since the start of the tournament after it was beaten by South Korea Feb. 7.
The team is slated to play China Feb. 13, the final day of the competition, which will feature two matches -- Chinese Taipei vs. China and Japan vs. South Korea.
Thursday's victory put Japan into the lead in the competition rankings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bombardier officials visit Taiwan to promote new plane
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 23:05:19 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Officials from Canadian transport manufacturer Bombardier wrapped up a two-day visit to Taiwan Thursday in which they gave demonstrations aimed at promoting the company's lower-emission and fuel-efficient airliners.

Bombardier Aerospace arranged two demonstration flights of its Q400 NextGen turboprop airliner at Taipei's Songshan Airport for representatives from almost all Taiwan's air carriers, many of which expressed interest, said Kelvin Hung, a representative of Bombardier's commercial agent in Taiwan.
"The demo tour received positive responses from the representatives but they will conduct reviews before making decisions," Hung said.

The visit to Taiwan, part of an Asia-Pacific tour, presented an opportunity to showcase one of the world's most technologically advanced turboprops optimized for the short-haul regional market, said Trung Ngo, the company's Asia Pacific vice president of sales.

Taiwanese carriers are looking to replace older airliners in their fleets and, after the Taiwan High Speed Rail began operating in 2007, have changed their operating strategies to focus on flights serving outlying islands such as Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu instead of other domestic flights, Hung said.

They are expected to use their jet planes for direct flights between Taiwan and China and to use turboprop airliners with a capacity of between 56 and 80 passengers for flights to the outlying islands, he added.

The planes could also be used for the "mini three links" that allow for limited postal, transport, and trade links between China's Fujian Province cities of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou, and Taiwan's islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68% of local firms have plans to recruit: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 19:21:30 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Following an improvement in the unemployment situation, 68 percent of enterprises that responded to a recent survey plan to recruit new employees after the Chinese New Year holiday, an online job bank said Thursday.

According to the results of the survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank among 604 companies Jan. 14-20, of the 68 companies planning to recruit, 49.5 percent have listed job vacancies before the holiday.

The survey shows that 77 percent of the respondents said they believe that this year, Taiwan's economy will revert to how it was before the global financial crisis, while 53 percent even expressed optimism that the recovery will take hold in the first half of this year.

Finance, investment consulting and insurance providers are the most optimistic of economic recovery, with 64 percent predicting that the economy will rebound to the level of before the financial crisis in the first half of this year.

Their optimism is based on the hope that the signing of memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial regulatory cooperation with China and the opening to Chinese investment in Taiwan will give a boost to teh local economy, said Fang Guang-wei, public relations manager for 104 Job Bank.

Meanwhile, 60.8 percent of companies from the information technology, software and semiconductor sector, and 60 percent from the construction industry, expect the economy to recover to the level of before the financial crisis during the first six months.
Less than 40 percent of enterprises in the logistics and warehouse sector, as well as in the tourism, leisure and sports sector had the same opinion.

Among those with the highest demand for new employees are computer, consumer electronics and semiconductor manufacturers, the insurance, financial and banking industry, and the optics and photonics sector.
In terms of occupation, marketing and sales representatives, finance professionals, technicians, customer service personnel and R&D specialists in engineering are in highest demand.
According to another survey by the same job bank, the number of job-seekers in February dropped 10.5 percent year-on-year.
Over the past two months, unemployed people spent an average of 6.42 months finding a job.

Of those looking for work, people in the medical and health care sector and the environmental sanitation sector spent the least time of about 3.6 months before finding a job, while those in the construction and real estate sector spent 3.6 months and those in financial and insurance companies spent 3.8 months before finding work.

It took 5.4 months for service sector workers to find a job and 5.8 months for those in the manufacturing sector, while it took 8.5 months in the computer- related industry, 9.8 months in the cultural and education sector and 9.9 months in the wholesale and direct-sale business.
People who are still unemployed have been out of work for an average of 8.04 months, Feng added.
