DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 20:52:58 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The debt crisis in Europe is an aftershock of the global financial crisis and it will be only a small problem, a local expert said Thursday, urging the public not to panic.

"It is impossible not to have aftershocks after the world has experienced such a huge financial crisis, " Chu Yun-peng, a professor of economics at National Central University, said at a seminar organized by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum.
"However, these aftershocks often are smaller, " the former minister without portfolio went on.

He also said that great attention is being paid to the debt crisis affecting Greece, Spain, Portugal and Italy, which will help prevent the problem from developing into a bigger one, as governments are already taking measures.

Bert Lim, president of the World Economics Society, predicted at the seminar that the value of the euro against the U.S. dollar will decrease, as many countries are selling the European currency from their foreign reserves.
"A falling euro will make the greenback a strong currency again, " he noted.

Lim added that international oil and raw material prices will also go up as the U.S. dollar goes down but he also warned that the government should pay close attention to the impact of a rising U.S. dollar on Taiwan's exports.
Lin Chien-fu, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said decreasing tax revenues and an increasing financial deficit have taken Taiwan's debt-to-GDP ratio to nearly 40 percent.
He warned that Taiwan's debt rating might be downgraded as a result.
Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lo Shu-lei expressed similar concerns over Taiwan's debt and urged the government to reconsider whether it is right to expand public expenditure and cut taxes.

Nieh Chien-Chung, a professor at Tamkang University's Banking and Finance Department, pointed out that Greece has had a debt problem for a long time and said the problem will not grow into another global crisis.
He also predicted that the European Central Bank (ECB) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will take action to solve the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beitou cable car project might resume by year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:14:54 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Construction of the trouble-plagued Beitou cable car system might be resumed by the end of this year after a hiatus of almost four years, the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

If the Taipei city government decides to cooperate with the previous winning bidder of the contract and reports to it on the latest situation, the cable car construction project could be rekindled by year-end, as long as the National Parks Planning Committee under the MOI gives its approval, the CPA said.

Late last year, the CPA demanded that the city government, which is in charge of the project, report back within three months on whether it will continue collaborating with the previous winning bidder to carry out the build-operate- transfer (BOT) project. The deadline will expire in late February.

The construction license for the project was revoked in 2005 after then-Vice Minister of the Interior Yen Wan-ching and Cai Bai-lu, then-director of Yangmingshan National Park, were charged with taking kickbacks from a developer who sought to get a construction license for the project.
Yen was sentenced to 15 years in prison after being found guilty on corruption charges in four separate cases, including his acceptance of bribes from the developer.
Cai was sentenced to two years and six months for his involvement in the bribery scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$50 billion to be invested to ensure stable water supply
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:16:14 (By Wen Guei-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed a draft statute Thursday on dredging at three major reservoirs in southern Taiwan in order to stabilize the water supply in the region.

According to the draft statute, the government will spend up to NT$50 billion dredging the Tsengwen, Nanhua and Wushantou reservoirs in Chiayi and Tainan counties, one of Taiwan's agricultural strongholds, over the next six years to ensure a stable water supply in the area.

Of the amount, NT$18 billion will come from a special budget to revitalize the domestic economy and expand infrastructure construction, while the remainder will be financed by central government agencies and special national development funds, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said at a weekly Cabinet meeting during which the draft statute was passed.

The three reservoirs are major sources of water for household, irrigation and industrial use in southern Taiwan. Due to environmental degradation and inadequate conservation efforts, the three reservoirs have become swamped with silt, which has limited their storage capacities and has led to water shortages in the region.
After listening to Shih's report, Premier Wu Den-yih said ensuring a stable water supply in the south is a government priority.

As ecological conservation in the catchment areas and reservoir management are crucial to the functioning of reservoirs, Wu said, the relevant city and county governments should step up monitoring and cracking down on illegal logging, farming and construction in the catchment areas to prevent mudslides in upstream catchment areas.

According to the special statute, no new access roads can be created in the three reservoirs' catchment areas and construction of sand dams must meet the provisions set forth in the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law.
The new project will also include the improvement of existing access roads in the regions, but the roads will not be allowed to expand.
"The whole project will be finished in six years," Shih said at a news conference after the Cabinet meeting.
The statute will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for screening and approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fishing boat, crew released by Somali pirates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 21:31:28 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessel and all its crew were released Thursday after the boat's owner paid a ransom to Somali pirates, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
The 700-ton longliner Win Far 161, with a crew of 30, was hijacked by Somali pirates near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6 last year, a MOFA official said Thursday.
Since the incident, the MOFA used every means over the past 10 months to seek assistance from various international organizations in an effort to rescue the vessel and crew, the official added.

After receiving information that the ship was to be released, the MOFA also helped the owner to contact international maritime and anti-piracy organizations to ask them to provide humanitarian aid and protection for the ship and its crew upon the release, according to the official.
Through their efforts, the crewmen were provided with food, water and fuel and were given health checks and other support, the official said.
The government also expressed gratitude for the help provided by the international organizations.

The rescue efforts were made even more difficult because of the Somalian interim provisional government's inability to rule the country and because of the withdrawal of U.S., British and U.N. bases and other international organizations from the country due to the political unrest there, according to the official.
The MOFA warned that Taiwanese fishing vessels should steer clear of waters near East Africa to avoid the many Somali pirates who operate there with near- impunity.

Those that insist on sailing in the area should be registered with the European Maritime Safety Agency through its Web site: www.mschoa.com. The agency is responsible for improving maritime safety by providing technical assistance, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese poachers arrested on Kinmen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:34:30 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Three men aboard a fishing boat from China's Fujian Province were arrested Thursday for poaching fish in waters off Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities said later that day.

The poachers were arrested and 159 kg of high-value fish worth NT$2 million seized after coast guard fired warning shots at the boat, which had intruded into waters near Dayan Islet, to force it to stop for an inspection.

During the raid, the poachers tried to destroy evidence related to the crime -- a burning fuse -- and attempted to ram the two multi-function patrol boats mobilized by the CGA, according to the authorities.
The officers also discovered 39 torpedo tubes aboard the vessel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former GIO chief impeached for misusing fund for DPP drive
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:55:23 (By Sophia Yeh and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Former Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey was impeached Thursday by the Control Yuan for improperly using a government reserve fund to finance a publicity drive for a referendum bill launched by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations.
The referendum, which was initiated in 2007 by the then-ruling DPP to ask voters whether Taiwan should join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," was vetoed March 22, 2008.
The Control Yuan, the country's top watchdog agency, approved by a 10-2 vote the motion submitted by yuan members Ma Hsiu-ju and Ma Yi-kung to impeach Hsieh
Ma Hsiu-ju said Hsieh twice transferred from the Cabinet's reserve fund a total of NT$45 million to finance a publicity campaign to urge the public to support the referendum bill.
During the investigation process, Hsieh agreed that government funds should not be used in support of any drive launched by a political party, according to Ma Hsiu-ju.

In addition, he added, almost all the amount of money was spent before the March 22 voting day, without considering the fact the U.N. General Assembly session opened in September -- a clear indication that Hsieh simply used the publicity campaign to boost the DPP's bill rather than to actually promote Taiwan's U.N. membership.
The Control Yuan also censured the Executive Yuan, the GIO, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and the Sports Affairs Council in collaborating with Hsieh in using the funds.
Hsieh said the Control Yuan's decision was "unacceptable" but that he would not decide how to respond until after he had read the official impeachment letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan defeated by Japan in football tourney
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 22:59:16 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei was defeated Thursday by Japan in the East Asian Women's Football Championship 2010 being held at the Japanese National Stadium in Tokyo.

Japan scored in the 35th minute and continued an offensive strategy in the second half of the game, scoring again in the 59th minute and hammering the final into the Taiwanese coffin in the 84th minute.
The 3-0 defeat was the second setback for Chinese Taipei since the start of the tournament after it was beaten by South Korea Feb. 7.
The team is slated to play China Feb. 13, the final day of the competition, which will feature two matches -- Chinese Taipei vs. China and Japan vs. South Korea.
Thursday's victory put Japan into the lead in the competition rankings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bombardier officials visit Taiwan to promote new plane
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/10 23:05:19 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Officials from Canadian transport manufacturer Bombardier wrapped up a two-day visit to Taiwan Thursday in which they gave demonstrations aimed at promoting the company's lower-emission and fuel-efficient airliners.

Bombardier Aerospace arranged two demonstration flights of its Q400 NextGen turboprop airliner at Taipei's Songshan Airport for representatives from almost all Taiwan's air carriers, many of which expressed interest, said Kelvin Hung, a representative of Bombardier's commercial agent in Taiwan.
"The demo tour received positive responses from the representatives but they will conduct reviews before making decisions," Hung said.

The visit to Taiwan, part of an Asia-Pacific tour, presented an opportunity to showcase one of the world's most technologically advanced turboprops optimized for the short-haul regional market, said Trung Ngo, the company's Asia Pacific vice president of sales.

Taiwanese carriers are looking to replace older airliners in their fleets and, after the Taiwan High Speed Rail began operating in 2007, have changed their operating strategies to focus on flights serving outlying islands such as Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu instead of other domestic flights, Hung said.

They are expected to use their jet planes for direct flights between Taiwan and China and to use turboprop airliners with a capacity of between 56 and 80 passengers for flights to the outlying islands, he added.

The planes could also be used for the "mini three links" that allow for limited postal, transport, and trade links between China's Fujian Province cities of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou, and Taiwan's islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 12, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: The emergence of `Hu Su phenomenon'

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and former Premier Su Tseng-chang -- two politicians known for their baldness -- have recently become the most sought-after men within the blue and green camps, respectively. While all five special municipalities that are set to hold mayoral elections this year want Hu to run in their regions, Su is in a dilemma of whether to run in the special municipality elections or skip the elections and concentrate on the 2012 presidency.

This phenomenon can be linked to President Ma Ying-jeou. Had Ma's approval rating not fallen to such low levels, Hu would not have had such a sudden emergence. Had Ma's governance ability not been called into question, Su would not have had the idea of running straight for the 2012 presidency.

Hu, Su and Ma have one thing in common. Throughout their political careers, their integrity has never been doubted. However, Hu and Su differ from Ma in that, unlike the president, they are both very good at communicating.

Su is one of the few green camp leaders who does not speak in radical political language, while Hu has been recognized as a skilled communicator since he was first appointed to head the Government Information Office in 1991. None of his successors have been able to surpass him in this regard.
Up until now, Ma probably still has not figured out why Hu and Su are considered good communicators. Communication does not mean playing hypocrisy but putting oneself in other people's shoes.

Ma, who is desperate to boost his plummeting popularity, should take the "Hu Su phenomenon" seriously. Whether Ma will face the pair as his rivals or learn from their strong points humbly is key to whether he can stop the downswing of his reputation. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: College students empower tiny village

TEXT.P: The people of a small village in Houbi urban township in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, with the help of students from the Tainan National University of The Arts, have succeeded in transforming their community into one that combines traditional lifestyle and art.
Tugou is one of 21 villages in Houbi. Although its size accounts for 10 percent of the township, the village has only 460 households and 1,700 people.

Nearly all of the village's land is given over to farming and the residents, mainly farmers, are conservative and live life at a slow pace. Like most of the farming villages in Taiwan, it suffers from a drain of youth who move away for school or work, leaving only the old folks at home.
However, the situation changed in 2000 when Chang Chia-hui was elected village chief and began trying to improve the lives of the people by improving the environment.

He formed a community empowerment society with some of the more active villagers in Tugou, trying to grace the village by planting flowers and refurbishing unused land into a public square where the villagers can sit and chat while their grandchildren play.
"The people will support community empowerment once they begin to enjoy the benefits of it," he said.

Community empowerment is about people and government working together to bring about improvements. It allows more people the chance to influence decisions about their communities and take responsibility for tackling local problems, rather than expecting others to do it for them.
The idea is that government cannot solve everything by itself and nor can the community, so it's better for them work together.
Chang's efforts came to the attention of Tseng Shu-Cheng, a professor at the Tainan National University of the Arts (TNNUA), who used to serve as deputy magistrate of Tainan County.

Tseng believed that his students at the university's Graduate Institute of Architecture could help the villagers and told them they could learn by applying the expertise they study in classroom to Tugou and writing theses on their experiences.
Shortly after that, the first group of students moved into Tugou.
"This is more than just study or homework. In order to find plans most suited to the needs of the villagers, you have to be a part of them and to think like them," Tseng cautioned the students.

The first project worked out by the students in their 20s and the local residents, many in their 80s, was converting a disused pig pen owned by Chang Chia-hui into a public living room decorated with graceful artworks that would impress even big city-dwellers.
The second project drawn up together by the students and local people involved the renovation of a public space in an even smaller settlement with only 29 households called Chuzichiao.
The students asked painter Yin Chia-hui to paint the outer walls of the houses and sculptor Ho Chia-fu to carve stone snails for the space to symbolize peace.
Bao A-mo, an old lady living in the settlement, said that after the renovation, the square has attracted local people to gather there to chew the fat.
"It is a more pleasant place now, and has strengthened the association between neighbors," she said.
The students who live in the settlement have also been assimilated and have become residents themselves.
"The local people are upfront with their feeling. If they don't like my ideas they will reject them outright, " said Yang Han-ya, one of the students.
"I got so frustrated that I often burst into tears in discussions at the beginning. I couldn't understand why they insisted on their own feelings and didn't trust my expertise."

However, after living among them for more than a year, Yang now counts herself as one of the villagers. Local residents yell greetings at her when she rides her scooter through Chuzichiao and stop her for a chat when she walks around Tugou.

Lu Yao-chung was one of the first group of students to move into Tugou. He graduated from the Graduate Institute of Architecture after living there for two years, only to return to the village to open his own design firm after finishing his military service.
He was glad to see the program had entered its sixth year, carried on by a sixth group of students.
Lu said Tugou is a beautiful place that inspires him to turn out work that is different from that of his competitors.
"Of course, the cheap cost of opening a firm here is another reason why I chose here over a big city to set up my studio, " he added.
Lu is not alone. Ho Chia-fu, the sculptor who produced many of the works for Tugou, has built a studio there, based on the design of the students, and has become the 30th household in Chuzichiao.

"Before, when asked `where do you live, ' local people used to reply with `near the city of Hsinyin,' or `alongside Baihe township,' because few outsiders would know where Tugou is, but now they simply say `Tugou,'" Chang said with pride. CNA photo: 20, 21 By Maubo Chang CNA staff writer

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Security aide's resignation sparks speculation
DOC.DATELINE: 02/12/10 11:42:18 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: In a surprise move, National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi announced Thursday that he will resign from his post after just 20 months and 20 days in office.
His unexpected resignation ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday immediately sparked speculation about a possible follow-up personnel reshuffle in the President Ma Ying-jeou administration.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi told a news conference shortly after Su's announcement that Ma has reluctantly accepted Su's resignation and will appoint Hu Wei-jen, a career diplomat with 35 years of diplomatic and intelligence experience, as his new top national security adviser.
The transfer of office will take place Feb. 23, Wang added.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the event: United Daily News:

National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, who has recently faced harsh criticism over his inept handling of the U.S. beef import controversy, bowed out Thursday, citing family and health reasons.

At a hastily called press conference, Su, who President Ma lauded as having helped bolster relations with the United States, China and Japan over the past 20 months since he took office, said that a new era has dawned across the Taiwan Strait, as the two sides have increasingly reciprocated economically while a political win-win situation is taking shape.
Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic tactic has also worked to win the greatest possible dignity and international maneuvering space Taiwan has ever had, he said.
"I believe my mission has been completed," Su said.
Hu Wei-jen, Taiwan's former representative to Singapore and to Germany, will pick up where Su left off in terms of national security policy immediately after the Lunar New Year.
China Times:
Su's wife Grace Chen, formerly a local TV anchorwoman and later a health food guru, welcomed the top national security aide's resignation.
Noting that Su has "not taken a single day off" since he joined Ma's campaign team as a former Kuomintang legislator, Chen said that "now he can relax."
Chen rebutted allegations that Su might return to the Ma administration soon after the U.S. beef and arms sales controversy calms down, saying that "Su is a determined man who does not waver easily."

Chen, known for having cured Su's liver cancer with organic drinks she developed, said her husband had shown apparent fatigue when he last time accompanied Ma on a trip to the U.S. and Central America in January.
The Liberty Times:
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) criticized Su for having wasted too much time before stepping down.
Su should have resigned earlier, given his ineptitude in handling the U.S. beef import controversy and other crucial issues, the DPP blasted.
The DPP also questioned the political integrity of Su's successor, as Hu "had publicly criticized his own government" when he served as Taiwan's envoy to Singapore during the Chen Shui-bian era.

Hu is a seasoned veteran on foreign affairs and national security matters. His father Hu Tsung-nan was a high-ranking general and a close confidant of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in the Kuomintang (KMT) government during World War II and the Chinese civil war in the 1950s.
Hu has a long political pedigree and he is a "politically correct" choice for Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lighting-up ceremony held for first cross-strait lantern fair
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, China, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 12:01:58 (By Feng Chao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A lighting-up ceremony for the first lantern fair co-sponsored by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait was held in Nanjing, China Thursday, attended by both Taiwanese and Chinese officials.

The Qinhuai Lantern Fair is an annual celebration of the Lantern Festival in the Nanjing area, but this year marks the first time Taiwan has taken part in the event amid improved cross-strait relations and growing engagement.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen Wei-jen, Taiwan's vice minister of transportation and communications, said he is very pleased to see increased cross-strait exchanges in various fields, including the Lantern Festival.

He congratulated Nanjing City on its successful bid to host the second Summer Youth Olympic Games in 2014 and expressed gratitude for a promise by Jiangsu Province to allow up to 100,000 tourists from the region to visit Taiwan this year.

Liang Baohua, the top Jiangsu Province official, who attended in his capacity as secretary of the Communist Party of China's Jiangsu chapter, and Nanjing Mayor Ji Jianyeh, as well as Janice Lai, director-general of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, also spoke at the ceremony.
Ji said the Nanjing city government will send specially designed lanterns to be displayed in the 2010 Taiwan Lantern Festival to be held in Chiayi City in southern Taiwan Feb. 28-March 7.

The lighting-up ceremony took place along the banks of the Qinhuai River in light snow. Huge dragon-shaped lanterns prepared by the Jiangsu provincial government and a pair of phoenix-style lanterns presented by Taiwan's Grand Hotel were installed on the two sides of the river to symbolize good fortune and good luck in the new year.
When Liang pushed the button to light up the dragon lantern, dazzling fireworks exploded like a waterfall drifting down from the lantern, drawing exclamations and applause from the spectators.
In addition to fireworks, the ceremony also featured music and dance presentations, with many Taiwanese folk and pop songs performed by singers dressed in Taiwanese indigenous outfits.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Taiwan laborers bracing for disaster
DOC.DATELINE: 02/12/10 12:10:54 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: As local people are ushering in the Chinese New Year, President Ma Ying-jeou's administration gave them a red envelope by announcing an easing of restrictions on flat-panel display makers' investments in China.

According to the new regulations, the makers may invest in plants in China to produce panels of sixth generation and below, while producing panels beyond sixth generation will remain subject to certain restrictions.

Although the sixth generation panels are not the most advanced products, its plants employ the biggest workforce in this field, and the easing of the restrictions will encourage them to leave for China just as the country's personal computer makers did several years ago.
As for wafer foundries, the restrictions on their relocation to China remain, but they have been allowed to invest in or take over Chinese foundries through mergers.
Anyway, it is all bad news for local laborers, who should brace themselves for the results of the decision.
Ma claimed that his administration will address the general public's grief as its own grief, but what he has done is to pour gasoline on the fire and make the grief even more bitter.

Under Ma's "excellent leadership" in the last one year, Taiwan's industries have moved rapidly outward, and the unemployment rate has hit a high of 6 percent, while the average income of local households has declined to the level of 13 years ago.
As if this were not bad enough, Ma's negotiation of a trade pact with China will eventually open the island to Chinese agricultural produce and laborers, to the cost of local farmers and workers.

Taiwan's economic development is the result of the efforts of the local people over the last several decades, but Ma is letting it go down the drain by doing nothing to help small- and medium-sized enterprises while encouraging the giant ones to relocate to China.

Now the question facing the people is not a political one but an economic one: Whether they can keep their jobs or not. All of those who do not want to see their offspring working as laborers for the Chinese should rise up and punish Ma with action. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: The resignation of Su Chi
DOC.DATELINE: National Security Council (NSC) 02/12/10 12:39:08 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Secretary-General Su Chi resigned Thursday for what he claimed were health reasons. However, due to the sensitivity of the position, it is difficult not to speculate about the political reasons behind his decision.

During Su's term as a legislator, what impressed the public the most was his obstinate obstruction of plans by the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian to purchase weapons from the United States.

Under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou, the tough Su made himself the most domineering NSC secretary-general since Taiwan's democratization. This led to conflicts with some related agencies, especially the Ministry of National Defense. His opposition to arms procurement also made him very unpopular among the military top brass.
Ma's and Su's negligence of Taiwan's relations with the United States has resulted in Taiwan's leaning toward China.

China has thus taken advantage of the chance to spend big money buying the support of the U.S. Congress, think tanks and scholars. As a consequence, an increasingly larger number of articles published in important periodicals are advocating that the United States should not clash with China for the sake of Taiwan, and some have even proposed abolishing or amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
This trend is endangering Taiwan's security. Should the NSC secretary-general not be held responsible? Should the president not be held responsible?

We hope the government will pay attention to U.S. relations and strengthen its diplomacy with Washington. Only if we attach ourselves closely to the United States will we be able to engage peacefully with China on a secure basis. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in morning Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 12:52:54 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar closed at NT$32.098 at the end of morning trading Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.053 from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: All crew released by Somali pirates safe: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 12:53:49 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: All 30 crew members of a Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessel are safe and on their way back to Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Friday, rebutting media reports that three of its crew had died.

The 700-ton longliner Win Far 161 and its crew of 30 were released the previous day by Somali pirates who hijacked the vessel near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6, 2009 and held them for 10 months.

According to the ministry's most recent contact with the boat's owner, the crew of 30, including 17 Filipinos, six Indonesians, five Chinese and two Taiwanese, are safe, a MOFA official said, adding that military vessels in adjacent waters will escort the boat and its crew, as well as provide food, water and health services during its return voyage to Taiwan.
"Reports of the death of two Indonesians and a Chinese are false and groundless, " the official said.

The official also rebutted reports that the hostages' respective authorities did not provide any assistance in attempts to facilitate humanitarian relief, saying that the rescue was a coordinated international effort that involved many international organizations.

The MOFA helped the owner to contact various international maritime and anti- piracy organizations to seek humanitarian aid and protection for the ship and its crew upon release, according to the official.

The ministry had also been in contact with United Kingdom's Maritime Trade Operations, the office of the U.S. Navy Fifth Fleet in Bahrain, the United Nations' International Maritime Organization, as well as government agencies in Somalia and the Seychelles for assistance over the past 10 months, the official went on.

The rescue efforts were fraught with difficulty because of the Somalian interim provisional government's inability to rule the country and because of the withdrawal of U.S., British and U.N. bases and other international organizations from the country due to the political unrest there, the MOFA said.
According to the maritime watchdog Ecoterra International, the Win Far 161 had been poaching in Somali waters when it was hijacked in the longest-running case of Somali piracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: President shops for New Year treats
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 12:54:42 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou accompanied his 80-year-old mother on a shopping trip to a Taipei traditional market Friday for Lunar New Year treats, one day prior to New Year's Eve.

The president and his mother shopped at the Xinglong Market for festive dishes, where he told reporters that his mother used to prepare afeast for the Lunar New Year Eve dinner and that one of his favorite dishes was braised lamb chops.
"Now it's only a sweet memory, since mother is too old to cook," he said.

The president was also pleased when he saw couplets pasted on the frame of a dumpling store in the market that read "helping the people do business" on one side and "elevating Taiwan's competitiveness" on the other, with "go for ECFA" across the top.
"How amazing it is that even a dumpling seller supports our ECFA plan," he said.

The president has been pushed for the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in a bid to raise Taiwan's international competitiveness and prevent the country from being further marginalized amid the present globalization and regional economic integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials mum on government reshuffle speculation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 14:04:20 (By Lee Ming-chung, Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two government spokesmen declined to comment Friday on media speculation that the Cabinet will undergo a minor reshuffle after the Feb. 13-21 Lunar New Year holiday.
The rumors about government personnel changes arose after National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi unexpectedly announced his resignation a day earlier.

In a pre-emptive action to stem speculation and ensure that there would be no break in NSC operations, President Ma Ying-jeou had already named Hu Wei-jen, a career diplomat with 35 years of diplomatic and intelligence experience, to succeed Su as his top national security adviser. The transfer of office is scheduled for Feb. 23.
However, the speculation now focuses on a possible Cabinet reshuffle in the wake of the Lunar New Year holiday and changes of Presidential Office and Executive Yuan spokesmen.
According to a China Times report, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi might be replaced.

Responding to press inquiries Friday while accompanying Ma on a shopping trip for New Year treats photo-op, Wang said he had no information about any job reassignments or government personnel changes.
"For me, the most important thing is to fulfill my present mission to the best of my ability," Wang told reporters.

Newspaper reports also said Government Information Office Minister Su Chun- pin, who concurrently serves as Executive Yuan spokesman, will step down to take up a position in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Asked whether he will indeed become the KMT's new spokesman, however, he pointed out that such speculation has been circulating for more than three months.

"The speculation has disturbed me to some extent... If I had any information in this regard, I would be pleased to share... But I really have no such information, " he said, adding that he had also heard nothing about a Cabinet reshuffle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese American missing in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 14:34:35 (By Shinyao Shih, Lee Ming-tsung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Chinese American woman who came to Taiwan Feb. 2 for a short visit has been reported missing since Feb. 5, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office said Friday.
Fo Duong Vuong, 62, stands at 155 cm and suffers from early stage Alzheimer's disease and high blood pressure. She was in Taipei to visit her siblings.
Vuong was wearing a pale blue top and a light green jacket on the day she went unaccounted for, and was carrying a red umbrella. She carried no money or identification, according to AIT.
The institute said that anyone knowing of Vuong's whereabouts is urged to call a Taipei city government immigration hotline on 02-2389-2650, or the police.
