DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: ECFA up in the clouds
DOC.DATELINE: 02/12/10 15:22:09 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has offered a defense in person of his proposal to strike an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, but he is not so naive as to think his briefing will dispel all the questions surrounding the deal.
On the contrary, his briefing has raised more questions about the pact and has betrayed the government's bungled efforts to tout it.
Ma summarized his proposal by saying that it was aimed at helping Taiwanese to do business and enhancing the country's competitiveness.
During his briefing, Ma showed his confidence in the proposal and his eagerness to get his message across, but the answers to the questions are no less vague after his briefing.

The first question is that the president said there is no timetable for the pact, which is contrary to repeated announcements by the Mainland Affairs Council, the Executive Yuan and even Ma's close aides that the deal is expected to be clinched in the first half of this year.

Is Ma putting the brakes on its progress, or is there something else? Taiwan's top negotiator with China, Chiang Pin-kung, has hinted that negotiations with China have passed through the easy part and are moving into a phase bristling with difficulties.

If these are indications that the conclusion of the pact is to be delayed because of difficulties, then the next question is: What are these difficulties? and how is Ma's administration going to deal with them?

The administration perhaps would rather not air these difficulties to avoid complicating the issues, but that would confirm critics' claims that the talks are back room politics and lack transparency.

A survey carried out by the Common Wealth monthly found that half of the CEOs of the country's top 1,000 companies are concerned about the government's ability to defend Taiwan's core interests, although 90 percent of them support the ECFA negotiations.

The third and the last question concerns the Ma administration's failure to specify the content of the proposed agreement. This is probably because of the government's uncertainty about the results of the talks and its reluctance to reveal its bottom line in the talks.

All these questions show that the government has underestimated the general public's ability to debate the issue sensitively from the beginning and that it has been trying to convince them with simplistic, brief and vague answers that only further stoke the people's anxiety.
Ma should come down from his cloud and get down to earth in his efforts to defend ECFA. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Creativity lacking in innovation bill

TEXT.P: The proposed industrial innovation statute, which has been listed by the Cabinet as a priority bill for the next legislative session, is aimed at encouraging industry to "innovate." However, the measures adopted by the government to achieve the purpose are totally lacking in "creativity."

The bill is intended to continue some of the tax breaks stipulated in the Statute for Upgrading Industries that were repealed at the end of 2009. The controversy surrounding the new bill lies mainly in Article 30, which offers a preferential 15 percent corporate income tax rate to multinational companies with their headquarters in Taiwan.

This controversy would not have existed had the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou allowed all tax breaks to come to a complete stop. Had the administration opted to break the myth of tax breaks that has prevailed in the country for 50 years and rebuild a fair tax environment of "low tax rates, broad tax base, " it would have written a new chapter in the country's tax history.

It is a pity that the administration, having failed to adapt to circumstances, is sticking to the rigid canon of turning Ma's "campaign promises" into "policies." A great opportunity for innovative reforms has been missed as a result.
We can now only urge the administration to remove Article 30 of the industrial innovation bill. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei exhibitions present Lunar New Year attractions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 15:50:39 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Museums and galleries in Taipei are presenting various exhibitions featuring the Lunar New Year and are offering a variety of tours to attract visitors during the 10-day holiday period that begins Feb. 13.

The Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 28 this year, is one of the most colorful events during the Lunar New Year season, and an exhibition of 223 lanterns hand-painted by local artists at the lobby and corridor of the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei from Feb. 10-March 28 has been attracting crowds.

At the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, visitors will find another type of artwork reflecting the festive mood in a show of paper-cuts of tigers, birds, flowers and landscapes by Taiwanese and Japanese artists that is running Feb. 3-March 21.

In addition to its permanent exhibition, meanwhile, the National Palace Museum is running three special exhibitions: "Gold and Glory -- The Wonders of Khitan" is a collection on loan from the Inner Mongolia Museum; "The Lost Frontier" presents maps marking the changes in the northwestern boundaries of the Qing Dynasty; and "The Magic of Kneaded Clay" depicts the history of Chinese ceramics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTC monitoring commodity pricing ahead of Lunar New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb 12. (CNA) 02/12/10 16:04:35 (By Yuan-hsuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With the prices of some commodities rising ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission said Friday that it will monitor the situation to prevent price gouging.

The prices of some commodities are higher this year than last year amid a recovering economy, and the FTC said it has started to collect information on vendors' cost of goods or import declarations to determine if the higher prices can be justified or if they are being manipulated.

FTC Vice Chairwoman Shih Hui-fen said that according to the commission's initial investigation, the price hikes of dried foods are mostly due to an imbalance in supply and demand and climate change in areas where the foods were grown or produced.
Shih vowed, however, to continue the commission's investigation into pricing issues.
Shops found manipulating prices in the run-up to the Chinese New Year could be fined up to NT$25 million (US$781,000), the FTC warned.

Meanwhile, the commission said that there are currently plentiful supplies of agricultural, livestock, and fishery products, as most product marketing companies and markets have taken measures to increase supplies ahead of the holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-owned oil refiner to cut fuel prices again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 16:12:27 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: State-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) announced Friday that it would cut domestic gasoline prices by NT$0.7 per liter and diesel prices by NT$0.6 per liter, effective midnight Saturday.

With the adjustment, CPC's wholesale price of 92 octane unleaded gasoline will drop to NT$27.9 per liter, while that of 95 octane unleaded gasoline will be NT$28.6, 98 octane unleaded will be NT$30.1, and prime-grade diesel will fall to NT$25.5.
It is the third oil price cut announced by CPC within a single week, following a NT$0.1 cut in its gasoline and diesel oil prices announced Monday and a NT$0.4 cut Wednesday.
Based on the existing floating pricing mechanism, the CPC should have announced the planned oil price cuts Feb. 14, or the first day of the first lunar month.

However, the CPC decided to bring forward the announcement of the oil price reduction to Friday to reflect a decline in international crude oil prices and to give motorists the benefit of the price cut a little earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: China should follow Taiwan's success
DOC.DATELINE: 02/12/10 16:29:51 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Many parts of China have announced they will raise minimum wages by between 10-15 percent this year, which will inevitably bite into the already slim profits earned by Taiwanese businessmen operating there and could accelerate inflation.

But in order to expand domestic consumption and narrow the wealth gap between rich and poor, China must raise minimum wages, and Beijing would do well to heed the lessons of Taiwan's experience in cushioning the impact of such a move.

Taiwan implemented a series of measures in the 1950s and 1960s to boost the development of labor intensive industries and exports, which led to average annual growth of 24 percent in exports, 16 percent in domestic investment, and 7.5 percent in manufacturing jobs between 1961 and 1972.
However, the consumer price index rose by only 3.3 percent annually during that period of time, similar to the 3 percent of the developed countries.

The secret to maintaining stable commodity prices amid rising wages was enhancing labor productivity, which increased by 10 percent during the period, enough to offset rising wages and even drive down labor costs per unit of production by 2 percent.
China is now facing the same situation Taiwan experienced between 1960 and 1970, and the Beijing authorities should send some people here to learn the lessons of Taiwan's success. (Feb. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 17:28:52 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.055 to close at NT$32.1.
A total of US$623 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.045 and fluctuated between NT$32.041 and NT$32.102.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier confirms GIO chief to leave Cabinet for KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 17:32:21 (By Wang Shu-fen, Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih confirmed Friday that Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Su Jun-pin will soon quit to take up a position in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
"Although I am not happy to see him leave the Cabinet, it is a done deal, " Wu said while reviewing operations at Songshan Airport ahead of the Feb. 13-21 Lunar New Year holiday.
According to media reports, Su will step down from his current GIO post to serve as the KMT's new spokesman.
Wu did not mention Su's future role within the party, saying only that he was searching for Su's replacement.
"Su's successor will be determined after the Lunar New Year holiday, " Wu said, adding that a formal announcement will be made before March 1.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said later in the day that Su will replace Lee Chien-jung as head of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, a job that includes serving as the party's spokesman.

Lee, a journalist-turned-politician, will move to the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), King said, because he is familiar with cross- Taiwan Strait affairs as he has covered many major cross-strait high-level meetings and legislative deliberation of related statutes. King further said the handover ceremony will take place Feb. 24.
The confirmation of GIO and KMT personnel changes came a day after National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi unexpectedly announced his resignation.

In an effort to prevent speculation and ensure that there would be no break in NSC operations, the Presidential Office announced the same day that Hu Wei-jen, a career diplomat with 35 years of diplomatic and intelligence experience, will succeed Su as President Ma Ying-jeou's top national security adviser.
The transfer of office is scheduled for Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dongguan school follows Taiwanese education norms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 17:35:09 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Dongguan-based school has become a highly popular educational oasis for children of Taiwanese businessmen working in China's Pearl River Delta by following Taiwan's academic and teaching norms.

The Taiwan Businessmen's Dongguan School (TBDS) , currently the largest school in China established for children of Taiwanese expats there, provides a welcome alternative to international schools or local Chinese schools that the children would otherwise have to attend.

In implementing Taiwan's academic curricula for students aged between 3-18, it has carved out a real niche and even surpassed services offered by some schools in Taiwan, boasts the school's principal Wen Ming-cheng.
"The school has done more for the children of Taiwanese businessmen than day schools in Taiwan because TBDS is a boarding school," Wen said in an interview with the Central News Agency.
For example, he said, TBDS offers 34 classes per week for its elementary students, 11 more than offered by regular elementary schools in Taiwan.
Of the 34 classes, six are for English learning, two for computer training and four for music and the arts, Wen added.
The philosophy and academic norms in the Dongguan, Guangdong province school, also clearly differ from those found in Chinese schools, Wen observed.
While Taiwanese schools generally steer clear of politics, Chinese schools are operated "under the guidance of the Communist Party of China."

At the same time, Chinese teachers are disciplinarians and their students are afraid to ask questions, while Taiwanese students are more independent, lively and creative and are better at absorbing knowledge, Wen observed.

The Dongguan school, set up in September 2000 and was the first of three schools for Taiwanese children in China, currently has some 1,700 students, nearly half of the 3,500 children of Taiwanese businessmen working in the Pearl River Delta area.

In order to provide them with an at-home feeling, Wen said, the school divides its more than 700 elementary students into 40 families, with the teachers as "parents," the voluntary workers there as "uncles and aunts, " and the sixth graders as "big brothers and sisters."

Although the school costs more than 10,000 Chinese yuan for each student per semester, 180 children who previously attended Chinese schools in Guangdong transferred to TBDS in 2009, and 35 more will transfer there during the winter break, Wen said, the latest indicator of how important it is to Taiwan's expat community there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese researchers find enzyme structure of mint scent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12. (CNA) 02/12/10 17:43:00 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica said Friday that researchers have detailed the structure of an enzyme involved in the production of the scent given off by the mint plant, and added that the research was published in American journal "The Plant Cell" in its Feb. 5 issue.

In an effort to better understand the process by which the mint plant produces scent, Academia Sinica Vice President Andrew H.J. Wang and his team from the Institute of Biological Chemistry (IBC) used x-ray crystallography, as well as biochemical and genetic studies, to solve the structure of an enzyme that catalyzes the first critical step in the biosynthesis pathway of the mint scent formation.

The volatiles that evaporate from plants to produce scent are very important in nature to attract pollinators and herbivorous predators and emit signals that ward off pathogens. They are also of interest to humans as medicines; however, very little is known about them.

The group discovered that the enzyme is composed of two different proteins -- a catalytic protein and a regulatory protein. Through protein-protein interactions, the regulatory protein can remodel the active-site cavity of the catalytic protein for synthesizing the precursor of menthol, which is released from the plant as mint scent.

The research was conducted and financed by Academia Sinica and the provision of the protein crystallography synchrotron facility was supported by the National Genomic Medicine Research Program, a project funded by the National Science Council.

The article, titled "Structure of a Heterotetrameric Geranyl Pyrophosphate Synthase from Mint (Mentha piperita) Reveals Intersubunit Regulation" is available on The Plant Cell Web site at http://www.plantcell.org/cgi/content/abstract/tpc.109.071738v1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese currency in circulation likely to hit new high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 17:44:44 (By Kao Chao-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The volume of Taiwanese currency in circulation is expected to surge to a record NT$1.5 trillion (US$46.7 billion) Friday, the last business day before the week- long Lunar New Year holiday, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) said that day.
The rise is mainly attributable to an increased demand for cash among the public in the period leading up to the New Year, CBC officials explained.
According to CBC statistics, the volume of currency in circulation has been rising by NT$10 billion per day since the start of February, topping NT$1.48 trillion for the first time Feb. 11.
With the volume usually reaching a peak the day before Lunar New Year's Eve, chances are high that it will exceed the NT$1.5 trillion mark Friday, the officials said.
A volume of NT$1.39 trillion was recorded on the same day last year, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local journalists reflect on media coverage of earthquake in Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 18:14:45 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese journalist said Friday that reporters should have put themselves in the shoes of survivors of the devastating Haiti earthquake when covering rescue and relief efforts there and better communicated the reality on the ground.

"When rescue teams were about to conduct their mission, they were warned of widespread rioting and were told they had to be careful, " said China Times Group reporter Liu Ping when commenting on the difference between Haiti as it was reported and the actual situation.

"But other reporters and I figured out that if these teams encountered victims, were the victims going to rob the teams of their shovels or life saving devices? " he told a workshop organized by Taiwan's national Central News Agency (CNA) and Awakening News Networks.

"Everyone was trying to survive, because they were looking for food and water, " the Washington-based correspondent said. "If there was more empathy in news reporting, the perspective would be different."

Liu also lashed out at peacekeeping troops in Haiti. He said the troops told Taiwan's second rescue team not to go outside because it was not safe, but what the reporter saw were people who were staring over airport walls at the relief goods they hoped to receive as soon as possible.

Lin Shen-hsu, a CNA reporter who volunteered to cover the aftermath in Haiti, said some media outlets distorted the truth by reporting that local people in Haiti were too poor and were eating mud cakes as a result.
"Reporters should have used common sense and figured out that these people could have just eaten dirt instead of buying mud cakes, especially when they had no money," he said.
"After a looking into it, we realized that mud cakes were a kind of local specialty that helps pregnant women get mineral nutrients, " the reporter explained.
Lin, who had never traveled abroad before visiting Haiti, said there were widespread reports of serious disorder and robberies, but he did not feel that the situation was that bad.
"When supermarket buildings collapsed, a lot of food and goods were inside. Were you going to wait until the food went rotten? " he said.
Many people "robbed" the supermarkets because they had nothing to eat. "I don't consider it a crime," Lin said.

Huang Kwang-chun, CNA's former correspondent based in Panama who rushed to Haiti after the disaster, said that Haitians were particularly friendly toward people from Taiwan as Taiwan has provided much aid to its diplomatic ally for years.
He also observed that bridges and buildings in Haiti constructed by Taiwan's Overseas Engineering and Construction Co. sustained no damage.
"I believe that this has left a good impression on the people of Haiti," he said at the workshop.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manufacturers get boost from popular national flag scarves
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 18:19:11 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The manufacturer of scarves designed in a Republic of China national flag pattern has become increasingly popular after the scarves became a hit at a Jan. 1 official flag-raising ceremony to mark the beginning of 2010.

Building on the success of the scarves, which were snatched up within minutes of their distribution amid angry scuffles during the ceremony, Soxlink Co., a sock manufacturer in Changhua County, central Taiwan, has received numerous orders from several international name brands, according to Soxlink President Hsiao Ming-tsun.

Soxlink has been contracted to produce socks, scarves and textile hats for various international companies, including sport shoe manufacturers Adidas, Nike and Reebok, as well as Pierre Cardin, Hsiao said.
It has also been commissioned by the Walt Disney Co. to produce children's stocks under the theme of the company's cartoon movie Toy Story, Hsiao went on.

Hsiao, who has worked in the hosiery business for more than 40 years and whose company is one of the world's major producers, said that although the traditional labor-intensive hosiery industry is under growing threat of substandard sock products from China, he has nevertheless decided to keep the company's roots in Taiwan and has no plans to manufacture in China.

In addition to working as a contract maker, the company will build its own brand name by producing value-added products such as "bamboo shoot socks, " functional stockings and personal protective gear, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting proposal still in the works
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:15:55 (By Lee Ming-chung , Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The proposal to introduce absentee voting is still in the works, and no final decision has been made, a senior Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Friday.
"The proposal is still in the works. It's not a done deal, " said MOI Vice Minister Chien Tai-lang.

"Absentee voting is designed to protect average citizens' voting rights. We will extensively solicit opinions on the issue before implementing it, including consulting with the opposition parties," he added.

Chien was responding to a newspaper report claiming that the MOI has decided to introduce absentee voting in the 2012 presidential election, which drew a strong reaction from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

According to the United Daily News (UDN) report, the MOI called a cross-agency meeting Thursday, during which a consensus was reached on the scope and form of absentee voting to be introduced in the 2012 presidential election.
Under the reported plan, Taiwanese businessmen in China and other emigrees would be excluded from voting by mail.

It was also decided that Taiwan's absentee voting system would be a "transfer ballot" system, meaning eligible voters would be allowed to cast ballots in constituencies in which they work rather than where their households are registered, the UDN report said.
It added that the MOI will send a draft statute on the system in June to the Legislative Yuan for consideration and approval.
Responding to the report, the DPP called a news conference Friday to question the propriety of introducing such a system at this moment.
"At present, many people are out of work and badly need emergency relief, " said DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang. "We see no urgency to introduce an absentee voting system."
The spokesman contended that if the MOI insists on steamrolling through a new voting system before a social consensus is reached, local society could be plagued by conflicts and mistrust.

In light of Taiwan's political reality, Lin said, promoting absentee voting would definitely ignite doubts and misgivings, particularly by allowing military service members, policemen and prison inmates to vote outside constituencies where their households are registered.

Claiming that polling stations inside military barracks and prisons are in a "closed" and "autocratic" environment, Lin said soldiers and prison inmates would feel pressure and could not vote their consciences in such surroundings.
"We hope the interior ministry will re-evaluate the feasibility of introducing a transfer ballot system as it is planning," Lin said.
DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yee said the MOI has never communicated with the opposition party on the introduction of the so-called transfer ballot system.
"Such a working style will hinder the development of a healthy inter-party interaction, which might eventually lead to disaster, " Lee warned.

Noting that candidates tend to be barred from campaigning in military barracks and near police offices, Lee said ruling party candidates may gain unfair advantages if polling stations are set up inside military barracks and police bureaus.
But KMT legislative whip Lin Hung-chih said such worries were not justified.
"Taiwan is already an open democratic society. The public sector can no longer rig or manipulate any election. The DPP should have confidence in our democratic system, " Lin said.

He indicated that the KMT legislative caucus supported the MOI's plan to introduce a well-devised transfer ballot system to protect the voting rights of a large number of eligible voters who work or study outside the area where their household is registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai will focus on local market in 2010: chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:19:49 (By Anita Pan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract maker of electronics, will focus on the domestic market after the Chinese New Year by launching several major investment projects, the group's chairman Terry Gou said Friday.

At a party hosted by the group for its employees ahead of the Chinese New Year, Gou said that if the group could increase its 2009 turnover of NT$2.4 trillion by 10 percent, it would represent a big gain.

In the coming year, the group will shift its focus on exports to expanding the local market, and it intends to recall senior Taiwanese executives stationed in China back home to lead the next phase of high-tech development, Gou said.
Their return, however, does not signal an intent to abandon the Chinese market, Gou said, but will instead give the company's Chinese employees more development opportunities.

The Hon Hai chairman, who announced recently that he would continue to lead the company for the next 10 years, described the coming decade as a crucial period because the global industrial structure would change rapidly.
He said he felt responsible to lead his colleagues in facing those challenges and create a new era for the group.

Comparing the 35-year-old group to a 35-year-old man who should be full of vitality, vigor and drive, Gou said his priority over the next 10 years would be to pass on his experience and cultivate people capable of taking over the business group.
He reiterated that Hon Hai will not be a family-run group and that his children will not take over its operations. Any Hon Hai employee would have the chance to take over the group, he stressed.
Describing himself as a coach, Gou said a good coach should be able to devise good strategies and select good athletes.
He expressed the hope that he could help the group in maintaining its status as the world's largest contract electronics maker and opening a wider lead over its rivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier still considering GIO chief candidates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:41:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that he is consulting with potential candidates to head the Government Information Office (GIO) , after it was announced that incumbent GIO chief Su Jun-pin would take a job in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

The ideal candidate will be someone who is clear-minded, deeply understands people's feelings, can clearly express the government's positions, and is willing to work hard without complaining, Wu said in response to reporters' questions while reviewing operations at the Taipei train station.
Earlier in the day, Wu said that Su's successor will be determined after the Lunar New Year holiday, and a formal announcement will be made before March 1.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung confirmed earlier Friday that Su will replace Lee Chien-jung as head of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, a job that includes serving as the party's spokesman.
Meanwhile, Wu said he has not heard that KMT Secretary-General King intends to ask Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu to run in the New Taipei City mayoral election at the end of the year.
Wu said, however, that any party wants to nominate its best candidates for the elections, and he praised Chu performing well in whatever post he has held.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI ranked as leading patent recipient among research institutes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 21:02:14 (By Jackson Chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's nonprofit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) received 397 U.S. patents last year, the most of any research institute in the world, according to an annual corporate ranking released by IFI Patent Intelligence.
ITRI has received a steadily growing number of U.S. patents in recent years, going from 229 in 2007 to 286 in 2008.
The 397 patents it received last year made it the only R&D research institute to rank among the world's top 50 corporate patent recipients in 2009, according to the IFI ranking.

The top placing is a result of ITRI efforts to encourage its researchers to create innovative, high value inventions and to develop new technology and new industries that can stay competitive in the global market, an ITRI spokesman said Friday.

The ITRI filed 2,330 international patent applications last year and was awarded a record high 1,308 patents. The institute hopes not only to obtain more patents in the future but also to enhance the quality of its inventions, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-born food guru makes her name in London gastronomic world
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/12/10 21:37:42 (By Jennifer Huang and Sofua Wu)

TEXT.P: Ching-He Huang, a vivacious Taiwan-born food entrepreneur in Britain, won high acclaim Thursday when she spoke on her culinary art and gave a live demonstration at an Asian food fair being held in London.

The young self-taught cook was the first culinary guru to be invited to speak at the Asian Food Festival organized by Asia House, a group aimed at promoting business, cultural and diplomatic interaction between Asia and Britain.

Sumi Ghose, Asia House's director of public programs, told the Central News Agency that Huang was the keynote speaker in the festival's first event mainly because she has emerged as the leading spokeswoman in Britain for modern Chinese cuisine.

Ghose, himself a Chinese food aficionado, said Huang's popularity lies in her ability to infuse new life and taste into Chinese dishes by extensively exploring traditional Taiwanese and Chinese food ingredients and cooking them in creative and tasteful styles.
Ghose also said it was very meaningful to invite her to speak and prepare Chinese dishes ahead of the new lunar year, which begins on Feb. 14.
Huang said she was honored to be invited to give a demonstration in the Asian Food Festival's first presentation program.

Huang introduced the origin and history of Lunar New Year celebrations in ancient China and Taiwan and also prepared two New Year's dishes -- deep-fried glutinous rice cakes and salty rice dumpling soup.
She told a packed house that the rice cake symbolizes good fortune and that the salty rice dumpling represents the reuniting of families for the holiday.
The pleasing aroma and flavors inspired curiosity and whet people's appetites, compelling spectators to rush to get a taste of Huang's creations and ask about her cooking secrets.
Among those in attendance was Chang Siao-yue, Taiwan's representative to the U.K., who said Huang enjoys high popularity in Britain through her cooking programs on TV and cookbooks.
"Through her introductions, many British citizens have become more interested in Chinese cuisine. Huang is truly a Chinese food ambassador," Chang said.

Accoding to the diplomat, Huang has stood out because of her ability to articulate convincingly the complex methods of cooking Chinese dishes. "Her explanations have helped enhance her fans' self-confidence in preparing tasty Chinese dishes," Chang said.
The 32-year-old Huang moved to South Africa along with her parents at the age of 5 and relocated to London six years later.
She opened a food company after graduating from London University, selling health drinks and adapted Chinese dishes that made inroads into upscale department stores, such as Harrods and Selfridges.

It almost seemed inevitable that she would end up on television, and in 2005, her Ching's Kitchen made its debut on UKTV Food. Since then, Huang has made TV appearances on ITV's Saturday Cooks and Daily Cooks, UKTV's Market Kitchen and Channel Five's Cooking the Books.
Her first cookbook, China Modern, was published in 2006, and her second, Chinese Food Made Easy, was released to accompany the BBC series of the same name she presents on TV.
The program has enjoyed good ratings and the cookbook emerged as a bestseller.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting proposal still in the works
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:15:55 (By Lee Ming-chung , Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The proposal to introduce absentee voting is still in the works, and no final decision has been made, a senior Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Friday.
"The proposal is still in the works. It's not a done deal, " said MOI Vice Minister Chien Tai-lang.

"Absentee voting is designed to protect average citizens' voting rights. We will extensively solicit opinions on the issue before implementing it, including consulting with the opposition parties," he added.

Chien was responding to a newspaper report claiming that the MOI has decided to introduce absentee voting in the 2012 presidential election, which drew a strong reaction from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

According to the United Daily News (UDN) report, the MOI called a cross-agency meeting Thursday, during which a consensus was reached on the scope and form of absentee voting to be introduced in the 2012 presidential election.
Under the reported plan, Taiwanese businessmen in China and other emigrees would be excluded from voting by mail.

It was also decided that Taiwan's absentee voting system would be a "transfer ballot" system, meaning eligible voters would be allowed to cast ballots in constituencies in which they work rather than where their households are registered, the UDN report said.
It added that the MOI will send a draft statute on the system in June to the Legislative Yuan for consideration and approval.
Responding to the report, the DPP called a news conference Friday to question the propriety of introducing such a system at this moment.
"At present, many people are out of work and badly need emergency relief, " said DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang. "We see no urgency to introduce an absentee voting system."
The spokesman contended that if the MOI insists on steamrolling through a new voting system before a social consensus is reached, local society could be plagued by conflicts and mistrust.

In light of Taiwan's political reality, Lin said, promoting absentee voting would definitely ignite doubts and misgivings, particularly by allowing military service members, policemen and prison inmates to vote outside constituencies where their households are registered.

Claiming that polling stations inside military barracks and prisons are in a "closed" and "autocratic" environment, Lin said soldiers and prison inmates would feel pressure and could not vote their consciences in such surroundings.
"We hope the interior ministry will re-evaluate the feasibility of introducing a transfer ballot system as it is planning," Lin said.
DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yee said the MOI has never communicated with the opposition party on the introduction of the so-called transfer ballot system.
"Such a working style will hinder the development of a healthy inter-party interaction, which might eventually lead to disaster, " Lee warned.

Noting that candidates tend to be barred from campaigning in military barracks and near police offices, Lee said ruling party candidates may gain unfair advantages if polling stations are set up inside military barracks and police bureaus.
But KMT legislative whip Lin Hung-chih said such worries were not justified.
"Taiwan is already an open democratic society. The public sector can no longer rig or manipulate any election. The DPP should have confidence in our democratic system, " Lin said.

He indicated that the KMT legislative caucus supported the MOI's plan to introduce a well-devised transfer ballot system to protect the voting rights of a large number of eligible voters who work or study outside the area where their household is registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai will focus on local market in 2010: chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:19:49 (By Anita Pan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract maker of electronics, will focus on the domestic market after the Chinese New Year by launching several major investment projects, the group's chairman Terry Gou said Friday.

At a party hosted by the group for its employees ahead of the Chinese New Year, Gou said that if the group could increase its 2009 turnover of NT$2.4 trillion by 10 percent, it would represent a big gain.

In the coming year, the group will shift its focus on exports to expanding the local market, and it intends to recall senior Taiwanese executives stationed in China back home to lead the next phase of high-tech development, Gou said.
Their return, however, does not signal an intent to abandon the Chinese market, Gou said, but will instead give the company's Chinese employees more development opportunities.

The Hon Hai chairman, who announced recently that he would continue to lead the company for the next 10 years, described the coming decade as a crucial period because the global industrial structure would change rapidly.
He said he felt responsible to lead his colleagues in facing those challenges and create a new era for the group.

Comparing the 35-year-old group to a 35-year-old man who should be full of vitality, vigor and drive, Gou said his priority over the next 10 years would be to pass on his experience and cultivate people capable of taking over the business group.
He reiterated that Hon Hai will not be a family-run group and that his children will not take over its operations. Any Hon Hai employee would have the chance to take over the group, he stressed.
Describing himself as a coach, Gou said a good coach should be able to devise good strategies and select good athletes.
He expressed the hope that he could help the group in maintaining its status as the world's largest contract electronics maker and opening a wider lead over its rivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier still considering GIO chief candidates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/10 20:41:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that he is consulting with potential candidates to head the Government Information Office (GIO) , after it was announced that incumbent GIO chief Su Jun-pin would take a job in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

The ideal candidate will be someone who is clear-minded, deeply understands people's feelings, can clearly express the government's positions, and is willing to work hard without complaining, Wu said in response to reporters' questions while reviewing operations at the Taipei train station.
Earlier in the day, Wu said that Su's successor will be determined after the Lunar New Year holiday, and a formal announcement will be made before March 1.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung confirmed earlier Friday that Su will replace Lee Chien-jung as head of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, a job that includes serving as the party's spokesman.
Meanwhile, Wu said he has not heard that KMT Secretary-General King intends to ask Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu to run in the New Taipei City mayoral election at the end of the year.
Wu said, however, that any party wants to nominate its best candidates for the elections, and he praised Chu performing well in whatever post he has held.
