DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's percussion maestro has great ambitions for music scene

TEXT.P: As one of the most successful and internationally famous musicians from Taiwan, percussionist Ju Tzong-Ching hopes to take Taiwan's music scene to a whole new level.
As president of the Taipei National University of the Arts as well as the founder of Ju Percussion Group, Ju has been synonymous with the development of percussion in Taiwan for more than 20 years.

He was the first Taiwanese musician to be honored with the lifetime award from the Percussive Arts Society (PAS) , which is considered the highest honor in the worldwide percussion community. The PAS is the largest percussion music organization in the world.
"I feel honored to receive this award, and will continue to promote percussion across all age groups in Taiwan, hoping people will love it and play a role in its development," said Ju.
Percussion has not been a popular form of music in Taiwan, but it has come a long way, according to Ju.

"It has been a long road to promote percussion on the island since I return to Taiwan, " Ju said. "It had been considered to be a career without a future, but now, it is accepted and loved by the audience."

Ju studied in Vienna under Walter Veigl and Richard Hochrainer. He received his Diploma of Music Performer in Percussion from the Vienna Academy of Music in Austria in 1982, the first musician from Taiwan to receive such a diploma.

After returning to Taiwan, he started a percussion performance and education career. During that period, he was not only teaching at school, but also setting up theJu Percussion Groupin the year of 1986, the first percussion ensemble established in Taiwan.
Ju Group has staged over 2,000 performances in Europe, the U.S., Asia and Australia.
In the field of education, Ju's first innovation was to include percussion as a required course in the music programs at some universities where it was originally offered only as an elective course.
From the campus scene to professional performances, Ju has promoted percussion development here in order to show the world the quality of Taiwan percussion.
One of the most famous achievements he promotes is the Taipei International Percussion Convention(TIPC), which is held every three years.
He said that next year's TIPC will be the seventh such convention to be held in Taiwan; its preliminary concept is to bring new music from all over the world to Taiwan.
"Next year's TIPC will feature a great deal of new percussion music, as well as cross-boundary creativity which will capture the attention of audiences," he mentioned.

Through the event, he expects to bring many new music trends to Taiwan, which will elevate the level here to keep pace with percussion development in the rest of the world. He even has an ambitious idea to expand the event and hold it annually.

"If this turns out to be the case, the development of Taiwan percussion could keep pace with the rest of the world, moreover, it could propel our music in the percussion field ahead of the rest of the world," he said.
He expects he can help expand percussion's influence in Taiwan and promote more exchange with percussion musicians all over the world. By Sunnie Chen CNA staff reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 13, or the last day of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that happened on this date in the past.
1971: Spiro Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1971: Aided by U.S. aircraft and artillery, South Vietnamese troops enter Laos.
1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghanistan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits performing artists from Taiwan to stage commercial performances in mainland China and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A U.S. missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
1994: A ferry taking illegal Burmese workers home capsizes off Thailand. More than 150 of them are feared dead.
1998: A special convention votes to make Australia a republic and promises a referendum on replacing the queen as head of state in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Wishing for a prosperous Year of the Tiger

TEXT.P: As Year of the Ox comes to an end, people here in Taiwan are sincerely wishing their friends and family "a lucky and prosperous Year of the Tiger." What are the changes that the Taiwanese people hope to see with the arrival of the Lunar New Year?

After a troubled and tumultuous Year of the Ox, the people are tired of uncertainty and economic hardship. They would like an uneventful Year of the Tiger with more employment opportunities and less societal injustice and unfairness.

After President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008, cross-straits relations improved tremendously. Taiwan has already began to reap the "peace dividend". Thanks to improved relations, Taiwan has been able to benefit from China's economic stimulus measures during the global financial crisis. Orders from China helped tide many Taiwanese businesses over during the worst of the slump.

Now Taiwan and China are poised to sign the proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) . Signing the ECFA will be critical to keeping Taiwanese businesses competitive in an increasingly globalized world. It's up to the government to reach consensus with the public and ink the pact as quickly as possible.

The government should also do more about job creation. Taiwan's unemployment rate hit a high of six percent at one point last year, with 600,000 people jobless. It's not enough for the government to create temporary jobs and subsidies. The real solution is boosting private sector investment, which has plunged since 2008.

Six promising new sectors such as bio tech, green energy and tourism have been selected by the government for intensive development and NT $200 billion has been earmarked from the budget to support those emerging industries. However, we have not seen any concrete initiatives from the relevant governmental departments. The sooner those government subsidies can be allocated, the sooner we can grow those new sectors and create real jobs.

Lastly, the government also has to pay more attention to the "hidden worries" of society. Although crime in Taiwan is not as high as it once was, cases such as the audacious robbery that took place in the Taipei 101 building are troubling signs. Other "hidden worries" includes what seems to be a real-estate bubble and the increasingly wide gap between the rich and the poor. ( By Bear Lee)
(by Bear Lee)/ao

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Hon Hai chairman's views on 2010 economy

TEXT.P: During a Chinese New Year party Friday for employees of the world's largest contract chipmaker the Hon Hai Group, its chairman Terry Gou expressed his views on the economic outlook for 2010.

He said the ongoing economic recovery is like the first thawing of icy weather. While the outlook is good for the first half of the year, it might still be "a bit chilly, " he warned. Hard work and confidence would be required to overcome these conditions, he added.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Commercial Times:
Gou said his group, which posted revenue of NT$2.4 trillion in 2009 despite the global financial storm, will continue to aim for the challenging revenue growth target of 30 percent in 2010.
With the group's revenue in January having reached its target and the prospects in March, April and May looking good, chances are high that it will reach its goal for 2010, he said.

According to Gou, the greatest concern in the first half of 2010 could be labor shortage. To cope with that situation, Hon Hai will set up some unmanned factories in Taiwan this year, he said. (Feb. 13, 2010)
Economic Daily News:
Gou also commented on the controversial draft law on industrial innovation, which would offer a preferential 15 percent corporate income tax rate to multinational companies headquartered in Taiwan.

He expressed strong displeasure at lawmakers' plan to exclude Taiwanese businesses from the preferential treatment and threatened to move Hon Hai's headquarters out of Taiwan if the exclusive clause is passed.
Meanwhile, Gou mentioned a letter he received from Central Bank of the Republic of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, in which Perng urged him to continue to contribute to Taiwan's economy.

Asked about the matter, Perng said he had also written to other business owners besides Gou, mainly to encourage them to create more jobs so as to give greater momentum to the economic recovery. (Feb. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises tax incentive program 'will be fair'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/10 16:05:40 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A proposed tax break for businesses setting up headquarters in Taiwan "will be fair," promised Premier Wu Den-yih Saturday. The controversial draft industrial innovation bill has been drawing complaints from a number of quarters, including from local tycoon Terry Guo.

The bill offers a 15 percent reduction in the corporate income tax for the world's top 500 companies if they set up headquarters in Taiwan. However, there has been controversy over whether or not the four Taiwanese companies in the top 500 list should be excluded from the tax incentive.
Hon Hai group Chairman Terry Guo has threatened to move the company's headquarters out of Taiwan if the bill passes and his company does not benefit.

Premier Wu told reporters that Guo should not be worried, and that if the government decides to give tax breaks to businesses for setting up headquarters in Taiwan, "the rewards will be fairly allocated."
Wu added that all businesses, large or small, will be rewarded for being innovative and creating jobs.
The bill is now being reviewed by the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: What's the future Taiwan's CPBL?

TEXT.P: Supporters of Taiwanese star pitcher Wang Chien-ming got some good news earlier when the Washington Nationals reportedly decided to recruit Wang. The Washington Nationals has the poorest record among all Major League Baseball (MLB) teams in the United States, and Wang is coming off a disastrous season and recovering from shoulder surgery. However, there is hope for both the team and the player to stage a comeback with hard work and perseverance. There will be no such comeback for the Taiwanese baseball players recently busted in a game-fixing scandal.

Taiwan prosecutors indicted 24 players in the latest scandal of Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , with two others, including Elephants star pitcher Tsao Chin-hui, escaping indictment only because their improper behavior (including accepting free sex services) has not been directly linked to game- fixing. Together, these 26 players can probably make up the strongest baseball team in Taiwan. However, none of them will ever play, coach or teach baseball professionally in Taiwan ever again.

Unfortunately, these harsh punishments for individual players may not be enough to revitalize the CPBL. There were similar scandals in 1996 and 2005. The same problems occur again and again even though the players involved are thrown out because there are deeper structural issues within the league that remain unresolved.

The fundamental problem for Taiwan's professional baseball lies in the insufficient population base for supporting so many teams. On average, there is about one professional baseball team for every 10 million people in the U.S. and Japan. Currently Taiwan, with 23 million people, has four professional baseball teams.

Now is the time for Taiwan's professional baseball teams to consider joining the leagues of other countries. Japan would be an ideal choice. If Taiwan's baseball teams decide to join Japan's professional baseball league, everybody would benefit. Fans would be able to watch games played at a higher level, and the Japanese league will gain several million additional Taiwanese fans. (By Bear Lee)/ao

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News -- Deeper thinking needed in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: 02/13/10 16:44:55 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chinese New Year Eve -- Feb. 13 this year -- is a time when families come together. This year, the Taiwan people are also celebrating the fact that the global financial storm is almost past and national development is on the move, though at a slow pace.

Economically, people can feel the gradual effects of the improved relations across the Taiwan Strait. Taiwan's economy grew by 6.98 percent in the fourth quarter in 2009, compared with negative growth of 8. 76 percent in the same period the previous year.
However, politically, the country seems to be stagnated under President Ma Ying- jeou's "gentle leadership."
After experiencing several election setbacks, Ma, who is the leader of both the government and the ruling party, appears nonetheless to be stuck in a leadership crisis.
His approach of trying to let the political wounds in the society heal naturally has proved to be a failure due to relentless attacks by the opposition camp.
In addition, his administration's slow response to the public's needs has led to disappointment with the charismatic president.

However, it would be immature to put all the responsibility on the shoulders of the president. Although the public's anxiety has been stirred by politicians who make showy and inflammatory speeches, the people must try to think more deeply.

For example, some of the debates on controversial issues like U.S. beef imports and the H1N1 national vaccination program have been meaningful and have prompted the government to correct its mistakes, but some are geared more toward ideology and populism.

On the more complicated issue of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, the public debate should have moved long ago from whether or not Taiwan should sign the pact to the question of how it should be signed.
The country has been in a quandary for the past year over whether or not to sign the trade agreement.
It is not just Ma who's in a political predicament, but also the whole country. (Feb. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times -- No sunny day in years of cloud and rain
DOC.DATELINE: 02/13/10 17:05:33 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: It seems that the outlook is not good for Taiwan to regain peace and prosperity in the Year of the Tiger that begins on Feb. 14, after the many disasters in the Year of the Ox.
As long as President Ma Ying-jeou remains in power, hard times can be expected to continue in the Year of Tiger because of Ma's incompetence, arrogance, and pro-China policies.

Under Ma's administration, the country suffered in the Year of the Ox the worst economic recession ever, a record high unemployment rate, a wage drop that saw the incomes of workers shrink to the level of 13 years ago, and an expansion of national deficits.

Although the Ma government is touting economic recovery and an expected economic cooperation framework agreement with China as signs that the bad luck has gone for good, Taiwan is not likely to take a turn for the better in the coming year as long as its leader remains on his own political course.
The people must force the Ma government to change its policies in the new year, if the country is to overcome its crises. (Feb. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Aspiration in Year of Tiger -- Vigor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/10 17:49:27 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, in a Lunar New Year holiday greeting to the people, said that he wished people in Taiwan would maintain their vigor, using a well-known expression to describe the power of the tiger, the zodiac animal of the new year.

As Chinese around the world celebrate the coming of Tiger Year -- the third earth branch year in the Chinese Zodiac's 12-year cycle of animals -- tiger motifs can be seen everywhere, in paintings, decorations, toy designs, clothing and accessories, on posters, and at festive banquets.
Rather than fierceness, the Tiger zodiac sign symbolizes toughness, generosity and wealth earned through hard work.

Each of the Chinese Zodiac's 12 animals -- rat, ox, tiger, rabbit, dragon, snake, horse, ram, monkey, rooster, dog, and pig -- has its own characteristics which in Chinese legends are associated with people's personalities, fortune, and abilities.

In these legends, mighty generals in battle are dubbed "Tiger Generals, " and a person's speedy and energetic actions are compared to the tiger's powerful movements. In Chinese legend, tigers command the wind, while dragons empower the clouds.

As the Mandarin pronunciation of tiger (hu) is similar to that of luck (fu) , the Year of the Tiger is believed to be one of economic prosperity. One of the most popular spring scrolls this year is "Lucky Tiger."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plays role in AMS particle detector experiment
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/10 18:09:52 (By Jou Ying-cheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A series of tests are being conducted in Europe in preparation for the launch of the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer (AMS) , the first large acceptance particle detector designed to operate in space.
Many people, however, may not know that scientists from Taiwan have taken part in the project.

According to the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), 15 countries have participated in the AMS experiment, which was designed and developed by an international team of physicists led by American Nobel laureate Sam Ting.
Manufacture of the AMS components was a joint effort, with France, Germany, Italy, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland, China, the United States and Taiwan making significant contributions, the CERN said.

The participating institutes from Taiwan are the Academia Sinica, the Chung Shan Institute of Science and Technology (CSIST), National Central University (NCU) , National Cheng Kung University, National Chiao Tung University, and the National Space Program Office (NSPO).
Lin Chih-hsun, an associate research scientist from the Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics, told the CNA that Taiwan's role in the project mainly covers three areas.

According to Lin, most of the detector's electronic equipment was manufactured at the CSIST, and its main computer and trigger system were jointly designed, manufactured and tested by Academia Sinica, NCU, CSIST and the U.S.-based Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The CSIST and NSPO were responsible for thermal modeling and analysis, and the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. produced the AMS ground support equipment and cooling panels.
The main scientific purpose of AMS is to search for dark matter and antimatter.
The CERN said the AMS will be transported from the European Space Research and Technology Center towards the end of May aboard a special U.S. Air Force flight to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
Lift-off aboard the space shuttle Discovery is scheduled for July, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times -- Blockbuster Monga and the promotion of Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: 02/13/10 19:26:58 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The locally produced film Monga set a record Feb. 5 for the highest box office sales on premiere night in Taiwan in the last decade, beating out the Hollywood blockbuster Avatar.

Monga's take on opening night in Taiwan was NT$18 million, far bigger than Avatar which had a start at the Taiwan box office of NT$6.97 million, and the hugely successful local film Cape No.7 which opened last year with NT$460,000.

Because of the huge spike in tourism in Hengchun, the filming location of Cape No. 7, local governments have become more accommodating and supportive of filmmakers, with an eye on promotion of their cities and towns.
This is why Monga had the Taipei City government's full support.
Set in the oldest district in Taipei, Monga is a violent and bloody film that deals with themes of youth, loneliness, intimacy, friendship, and self- identification.

The story of the dark side of the Monga district, which is now called Wanhua and is home to several ancient temples, could prove to be risky for the city government that provided financial and administrative support in the hope that the city and the Wanhua district will receive positive publicity. (Feb. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President promises better life for people of Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/10 19:34:38 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that life will get better for the people of Taiwan with the start of the lunar new year because the economy is recovering.
Ma said that Taiwan had survived many challenges in the past year and that his government will continue to work hard to boost the economy as unemployment continues to fall.
"I believe that everyone's life will get better, " he said in a 4.5-minute video address released on Lunar New Year's eve.
He recalled that around the same time last year, the government had to give people shopping vouchers as part of its efforts to revive the sluggish economy, but this year buying has been strong.
Dressed in a traditional Chinese outfit, Ma spoke in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and an indigenous dialect as he wished the Taiwan people all the best for the new year.
He pledged to boost the economy and to create a healthy physical environment for children.
He said he was recently moved by a letter from a local primary school student who called for a reduction of global warming.
Wang Chi-wei, a first grader in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, told Ma that his dream is to help "restore the Earth to its former glory and reduce global warming, " according to the president.
Ma said he was happy to see the members of more than 800 households, which were devastated last year by Typhoon Morakot, moving into new homes before the nine- day holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Editor's note:
DOC.TEXT: CNA will suspend its CEP service on Feb. 14 and Feb. 15 during the Chinese New Year holiday. We wish all our subscribers a happy festive season.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan loses 0-3 to China in women's football
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/10 19:48:03 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan lost to China 0-3 Saturday in its final game on the last day of the East Asian Women's Football Championship 2010 in Japan.
The loss, which followed two others to South Korea and Japan, put Taiwan at the bottom of the rankings in the competition.
Chou Tai-ying, head coach of the Taiwan team, said that despite the losses, all the players performed well in light of the fact that the team is quite new.
She said at present, Taiwan has only about 200 female football players and it has recently begun to select elementary students for training in an effort to expand its football talent pool.
Commenting on the overall competition, Chou said the Chinese team had the advantage because of its high quality of play, and the South Korean team's pugnacious spirit was impressive.
The Japanese team was not the best in terms of overall quality, physical fitness or speed, but it stood out among the competitors because of its team work, Chou said.
All these are strong points that the Taiwan team can learn from, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets sights on India's tourism market
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/10 20:23:45 (By Ho Hung-ju and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is eying India as a source of potential tourism income, in light of the increasing number of Indians who are traveling abroad on sightseeing tours, according to the Taiwan representative office in India.
Since 2004, the number of Indian tourists traveling overseas annually has grown by 15 percent to exceed 10 million in 2009, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi.
However, only around 23,000 Indian tourists visited Taiwan in 2009, accounting for 0.2 percent of the total number who traveled abroad, officials of the center said.
These figures indicate that the India tourism market is a big one that Taiwan can explore, the officials added.
A group of tour agency representatives from Taiwan, headed by a Taiwan Visitors Association advisor Ju Hung-mei, are currently attending two major travel fairs in New Deli, India.
According to Ju, the delegation hopes to promote high-quality Taiwan tour packages to Indian consumers during the two events -- the Travel and Tourism Fair and the Outbound Travel Mart.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 16, or the third day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
2004: Taiwan's Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel International announce a cooperative project on documentary production aimed at introducing Taiwan's natural beauty and cultural legacy to the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Taiwan has to look out for itself

TEXT.P: China reached its target of 8 percent economic growth in 2009 and that figure is expected to rise to 10 percent this year. Many top economic analysts agree, based on the United States' strong performance in the last quarter, that its economic prospects for 2010 are promising.

Taiwan is expected to benefit from the global economic recovery that is being led by the two major economies. But in the meantime, Taiwan also faces severe challenges as a result of increasingly sharp global competition, especially with the formation the "ASEAN plus one (China)" free trade area.

The most important issues for Taiwan in the Year of the Tiger are economic and political. The two major questions are whether the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China could be signed as scheduled and produce the desired positive effect, and whether the year-end elections in the five special municipalities could be held smoothly.

President Ma Ying-jeou's popularity has been declining over the past year or so due to the economic meltdown and high unemployment. But the president's poor leadership with regards to communication, judgment and execution is also a contributing factor.
Looking ahead, Taiwan's economic future may rest on whether the administration could convince the general public of the need to sign the cross-strait trade pact.

However, the "hot political season" will start soon in Taiwan, with the legislative by-elections in four constituencies at end of February and preparations for the more important year-end special municipality elections. The government therefore has to gear up to deal with the ECFA issue, otherwise, Taiwan's competitiveness would suffer greatly.
Success in all these areas depends on President Ma and his administration's determination and perseverance. (Feb. 16, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to set up Taiwan academies around the world: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 15:53:51 (by Garfie Lee and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said recently that he has instructed the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) to implement as soon as possible a plan to set up Taiwan Academies around the world to promote traditional Chinese language and culture.

The "Taiwan Academy" project is one of President Ma's campaign promises. He said such academies are necessary in view of the fact that the Confucius Institutes set up by China in many countries around the globe have somehow dominated the teaching of Chinese language and culture in non-Chinese speaking populations.

Admitting that his proposal has not gotten off the ground as expected, the president said that the CCA and the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) should work out concrete measures to implement the plan.
Currently, the CCA has cultural centers in some foreign capitals and the OCAC runs quite a few Chinese-language schools on all continents.

President Ma suggested that the Taiwan academies should incorporate the functions of language institutes and cultural centers, because many of the OCAC's language schools, although they have a long tradition, do not have sufficient resources, and the CCA's cultural centers are focused on the promotion of culture and Taiwan's contemporary arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Optimistic economic outlook

TEXT.P: The global economy is definitely on a path to recovery, but there are still many hidden crises and risks lurking ahead.
Taiwan took a beating during the global economic crisis, with its economy contracting 9.6 percent in the first quarter of last year, which was the worst stage for Taiwan.

However, with the massive economic stimulus measures taken by the governments of the leading economies, global financial markets rebounded and the economic slide halted in the second quarter of 2009. Since then, the good news has included a 5.7 percent economic growth posted by the United States in the last quarter of 2009 -- its highest since 2003 -- and the 8.5 percent growth in China last year.
For Taiwan, the economy has bottomed out for sure, as the stock market has rebounded from its decline since early last year and a 6.89 percent GDP growth was recorded in the fourth quarter of 2009.
In addition, many local enterprises, which had forced their employees to take unpaid leave during the crisis, have begun to recruit new staff and make new investments.
However, all this good news does not necessarily mean guaranteed recovery and growth, as many hidden crises and risks are brewing despite the recent economic stability.
The first such uncertainty is whether the private sector would be able to fill the void that would be left when the world governments withdraw their economic stimulus measures.
Secondly, world governments are facing the dilema of how to sustain economic growth without causing inflation.
Besides, unemployment, which is around 10 percent in the U.S. and most of the European Union and just under 6 percent in Taiwan, could become a nightmare for countries around the world.
Therefore, in the Year of the Tiger, there are many unpredictable and uncontrollable factors what require the government to take good care of in order to ensure a promising economy. (Feb. 16, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: More administrative courts to be set up to meet public's needs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 17:08:36 (By Lai Yu-chia & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: As part of the judicial reform process in the country, more administrative courts will be set up in various districts to better serve the public, with effect from 2011, according to the Judicial Yuan.

Currently, Taiwan has three grassroots administrative courts in the cities of Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, which cannot meet the needs in other parts of the country for such service, the Judicial Yuan said.
To make it more convenient for citizens to deal with administrative lawsuits, more courts will be established around the country, it said.
In addition, the administrative courts will handle simple cases such as traffic tickets and national compensation claims involving amounts of less than NT$400,000, the Judicial Yuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Armed forces to engage more in public service: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 17:38:37 (By Sunrise Huang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's armed forces will make public service one of their main tasks, alongside their duty of defending the country, President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday.
Ma made the announcement during a visit to a veterans' home in Taipei City to extend new year greetings to seniors living there.

Taiwan's military has been involved in various types of public service, including the rescue and relief missions in areas ravaged by the typhoon Morakot last August and the ensuing rehabilitation work, he noted.

Just days before Lunar New Year day, which fell on Feb. 14 this year, the Ministry of National Defense sent military transport planes to carry 1,400 passengers to Kinmen and Matsu, after heavy fog on the outlying islands caused the cancellation of commercial flights there, he said.

In addition, on Lunar New Year's Eve, around 1,800 servicemen pitched in with greater efficiency to help build a permanent housing complex donated by the Tsu Chi Foundation for victims of Morakot, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day V Holiday season freeway traffic
DOC.DATELINE: 02/16/10 19:19:13 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Traffic jams have been a regular spectacle on Taiwan's North-South Freeway No. 1 and in the 12.9-kilometer Hsuehshan Tunnel -- which links Pinglin, Taipei County and Toucheng, Ilan County -- during holiday seasons, the Lunar New Year holidays in particular. As drivers tried Monday to endure the recurring frustration of crawling at 20 kilometers per hour on the freeways, Premier Wu Den-yih urged them to be patient.
The following are excerpts of local media coverage of the issue:

China Times: When you are stuck in a traffic on a freeway, can you wind down your window and chat with people in the vehicles near you? That was Premier Wu Den-yih's suggestion to drivers in holiday traffic jams.

Wu said that congestion on the freeways cannot be avoided during the Lunar New Year holiday because there are usually 100,000 to 200,000 vehicles on roads that were built to accommodate a maximum of 10,000 vehicles. It is therefore not possible to drive at speeds of 90 to 100 kilometers per hour, the premier said.

Liberty Times: The traffic usually peaks on the second day of the Lunar New Year -- Feb. 15 this year -- when married daughters traditionally visit their parents. This year, the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau estimated that 2.7 million automobiles would be on the freeways that day, and recurrent traffic jam on several sections could be expected, especially on the North-South Freeway No. 1.
Railway travel was also intensive on Feb. 15, with between 470,000 and 480,000 passengers recorded, according to the Taiwan Railway Administration.

United Daily News: The Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau planned to impose traffic flow control on sections of freeways No. 1, No. 3 and No. 5 on the second day of the Lunar New Year, Feb. 15, as many families were expected to be traveling to their relatives' homes in observation of the traditional custom of married daughters visiting their parents on the second day of the lunar year.
United Daily News: As Lunar New Year's Day fell on Feb. 14, Valentine's Day, this year, many people were sending double greetings via mobile phone text messaging.
On New Year's Day, text messages sent via Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan Mobile, FarEast Tone and other telecommunications carriers were estimated at around 100 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei MRT to open two extended lines later this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 19:43:36 (By Johnson Sun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Metropolitan Rapid Transit system is expected to open two extended lines on its network in the second half of this year, according to the Taipei City Government's Department of Rapid Transit System.
One of the extensions will be on the Bannan Line, from Chunghsiao Hsinsheng Station in downtown Taipei to Luzhou township in Taipei County.
The extension, which will cover 11.6 kms and include 11 stops, will allow passengers to travel between Luzhou and the MRT's Taipei Main Station in only 19 minutes.
Passengers will also have the option of changing trains at Minchuan West Road Station to travel on the Tamsui Line, which will take some pressure off the traffic at Taipei Main Station.
The second extension will also be on the Bannan Line, from Nankang Station to Nankang Exhibition Hall Station, connecting with the Wenhu Line there.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits veterans at Sanshia on Lunar New Year holiday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 19:58:03 (by Huang Shu-sheng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited a veterans home in Sanshia, suburban Taipei, Tuesday to extend Lunar New Year holiday greetings to the seniors there.
The president joined the veterans at lunch. Many of the elderly veterans had defended the nation in battles fought decades ago, and were resettled after they retired from the military.

Earlier Tuesday morning, President Ma went to Hsinhsiu Temple that is dedicated to Guan Yu, a divinized hero in Chinese history (circa 230 A.D.) , to light incense and pray for blessings on the nation. Many visitors to the temple received red envelopes containing chocolate gold foil-wrapped coins, which were handed out by the president.

Red envelopes from the president are much sought after during the Lunar New Year holiday season. Many people who knew that President Ma would visit Ma Kin Village in Miaoli on the second day of the lunar year gathered in the village early that morning to wait for good-luck red envelopes.
Also on Monday, Ma visited a shrine dedicated to Hakka martyrs who had fought against the Japanese in the late 19th century to resist colonization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan orchid growers take part in Tokyo show
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 20:12:00 (By Yang Ming-chu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Seventeen Taiwanese orchid producers are taking part in the Japan Grand Prix International Orchid Festival 2010 being held in Tokyo.
Orchid producers from 18 other countries, including the United States, France, Italy, Canada, Germany, Indonesia and the Philippines, are also participating in the exhibition.
The Japan orchid festival -- the largest and most prestigious in the world -- this year features some 100,000 orchids of 3,000 varieties.
Taiwan's top envoy to Japan, John Feng, visited the show Tuesday and and praised the Taiwan exhibitors for the high quality of orchids they have presented.
One Taiwan exhibitor said that this year's show, which is being held Feb. 13- 21, has attracted the highest number of Taiwan orchid growers ever. The Taiwan participants have won about 10 prizes.
Taiwan is recognized as among the world's best producers of phalaenopsis -- better know as butterfly orchids -- which had an export value of around US$63 million in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker says he has no interest in Kaohsiung mayor seat
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 20:38:02 (by Wang Shu-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday at a Lunar New Year dinner party in Kaohsiung that he has "no intentions or plans" to run for mayor of the new Kaohsiung municipality.

Wang has been mentioned by some politicians and in the media as the ruling Kuomintang's best bet to win the mayoral election in the southern port city in December. However, Wang suggested that people drop that speculation because he is not interested.

The speaker made the statement at a dinner party he threw for nearly 1,000 guests. A native of Kaohsiung County, which will be part of the new Kaohsiung municipality, Wang usually returns to his hometown every year to give Lunar New Year parties.

This year, he entertained incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu at lunch and invited Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, numerous other local politicians and his Legislative Yuan colleagues to the evening banquet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some semiconductor factories taking no holiday break
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 21:02:43 (by Chang Chien-chung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: With demand continuing to surge in the first quarter of this year, several leading manufacturers of semiconductor packaging in Taiwan have kept their production lines running during the Lunar New Year holidays.

A brisk market for liquid crystal displays, monitors, and mobile phones has contributed to the rising demand for semiconductor products, according to a recent report by the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company.
The report stated that the company's production capacity has risen from 56 percent in the fourth quarter of 2009 to 75 percent early this year.

To meet the huge demand in the world market, leading semiconductor manufacturers at the Hsinchu Science Park, including Macronix, Chipbond, and Ardentec, have not closed their production lines over the holidays.

This is sharp contrast to the same period last year when many employees in the science park were forced to take no-pay on leave because their companies had cut production in the face of a sluggish market.

Wang has been mentioned by some politicians and in the media as the ruling Kuomintang's best bet to win the mayoral election in the southern port city in December. However, Wang suggested that people drop that speculation because he is not interested.

The speaker made the statement at a dinner party he threw for nearly 1,000 guests. A native of Kaohsiung County, which will be part of the new Kaohsiung municipality, Wang usually returns to his hometown every year to give Lunar New Year parties.

This year, he entertained incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu at lunch and invited Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, numerous other local politicians and his Legislative Yuan colleagues to the evening banquet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some semiconductor factories taking no holiday break
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/10 21:02:43 (by Chang Chien-chung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: With demand continuing to surge in the first quarter of this year, several leading manufacturers of semiconductor packaging in Taiwan have kept their production lines running during the Lunar New Year holidays.

A brisk market for liquid crystal displays, monitors, and mobile phones has contributed to the rising demand for semiconductor products, according to a recent report by the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company.
The report stated that the company's production capacity has risen from 56 percent in the fourth quarter of 2009 to 75 percent early this year.

To meet the huge demand in the world market, leading semiconductor manufacturers at the Hsinchu Science Park, including Macronix, Chipbond, and Ardentec, have not closed their production lines over the holidays.

This is sharp contrast to the same period last year when many employees in the science park were forced to take no-pay on leave because their companies had cut production in the face of a sluggish market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 17, or the fourth day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1933: Newsweek magazine starts publication.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Washington for a visit.
1949: Chaim Weizmann is elected Israel's first president.
1952: Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) is formed in Taipei.
1959: The United States sucessfully launches its first meteorological satellite "Pioneer II."
1979: A large scale war breaks out on the border between mainland China and Vietnam.
1989: Leaders of Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Lybia and Mauritania sign a treaty to form the North African Common Market.
1992: The Republic of China Ministry of National Defense publishes its first white paper on national defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annette Lu attends UPF meeting in Seoul
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 14:27:34 (By Jiang Yuan-cheng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu of the Republic of China is on a four-day visit to South Korea at the invitation of the Universal Peace Federation (UPF) to attend an international leadership conference Wednesday and Thursday.

Lu and her entourage arrived in Seoul Tuesday. She said upon her arrival that during her stay, she will give a brief speech at the opening ceremony of the leadership conference on Wednesday and attend a banquet in celebration of the 90th birthday of UPF founder Rev. Sun Myung Moon.
Before departing for the United States Friday evening, Lu will also meet with Korean politicians and civic leaders on human rights issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Box office hit 'Monga' to receive at least NT$40m from government
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 16 (CAN) 02/17/10 14:51:21 (by Lin Yu-li and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: "Monga," the Taiwanese gangster movie which depicts the evolution of Taipei's Wanhua district, will receive at least NT$40 million in subsidies from the government in recognition of the movie's remarkable performance at the box office.

"Monga" grossed more than NT$200 million at the box office during its first two weeks in movie theaters in Taiwan, entitling it to hefty incentives, said Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's (GIO's) Department of Motion Pictures, at a GIO reception in Berlin.

Chen explained that under the Taiwanese government's special incentives for the film industry, any locally produced movie with box office receipts exceeding NT$50 million will receive 20 percent of its revenues as a subsidy for the company's next production.
Taiwan also welcomes international movie producers to shoot their films in Taiwan, he said, noting that subsidies for such projects can reach as high as 30 percent of the production costs.
The GIO office in Berlin held a "Taiwan Night" Tuesday evening to introduce members of Taiwan's delegation at the Feb. 11-21 Berlin International Film Festival to cultural and entertainment circles.
The actors playing the leading roles in "Monga, " Mark Chao and Ethan Ruan, were among the guests at the party, which was attended by film industry people from all over the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: New thinking amid cross-strait exchanges

TEXT.P: When the Year of the Tiger was celebrated Feb. 14 by Chinese people around the world, it again provided clear proof that Chinese culture is an asset enjoyed and owned by all of us.

Whether in Taichung, Kaohsiung, Hong Kong, Shanghai or Beijing, the Chinese New Year is the most important holiday for all ethnic Chinese. People on both sides of the Taiwan Strait follow the same traditions to embrace the arrival of another new year, making us profoundly realize that it is thousands of years of Chinese history and the same language and culture that has bonded us together.

Increased cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges have helped people on the two sides deepen mutual understanding and strengthen two-way integration. Although a recent U.S. decision to sell some defensive weapons to Taiwan cast a shadow on the generally positive cross-strait atmosphere, Taiwan-China relations continue to move in the direction of fostering peace and cooperation, lowering hostilities and seeking common ground amid differences.

It is true that China has not yet abandoned its threat of use of force against Taiwan, but both sides are fully aware that it would be a huge tragedy for all Chinese people if the two sides went to war.

To Taiwan, peace, development and dignity are the three major pursuits in cross- strait interactions, and the government should respond to the people's aspirations. Peace in the Taiwan Strait is a blessing for the people in both Taiwan and China and will benefit development in the international arena.

Improved cross-strait ties have made Taiwan and China both realize that they are not necessarily enemies as long as they are willing to compromise. A peaceful environment will push us to think in new ways and create new opportunities to build new models to resolve our disputes. (Feb. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--- Politicians gather at legislative speaker's party
DOC.DATELINE: 02/17/10 15:42:11 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng threw a party for his relatives, friends and supporters in his hometown of Lujhu, Kaohsiung County, Feb. 16 in celebration of the Chinese New Year.
As usual, the annual event brought together political bigwigs in southern Taiwan and was closely watched by political pundits as a barometer of Taiwan's political climate.
The following are excerpts of leading local newspapers' coverage of the event: The United Daily News:
More than 1,000 supporters and politicians from across Taiwan's political spectrum gathered at Wang's party.
Notable among them were Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing.

Both Chen and Yang have announced their intention to run on the ticket of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the mayoral election of the Kaohsiung special municipality, which will be formed by the merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County later this year.
The party was scheduled for the evening, but Chen visited Wang at noon because it was the only opening in her tight schedule that day, and she was treated to lunch by the legislative speaker.
Chen said she called on Wang to offer her New Year's greetings and to thank him for supporting Kaohsiung City's public projects even though Wang is a leading figure of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
As to the year-end mayoral election, Chen said she would of course like to have Wang's endorsement, but she knew it would be difficult. (Feb. 17, 2010) China Times:
Wang was urged by his supporters at the lunch to run for Kaohsiung mayor, but the speaker said he was not interested.
In response to the push for Wang's candidacy, Chen said tongue in cheek that Kaohsiung would be too small a pond for a big fish like Wang.
"He is a national figure and should play at the national stage, " Chen said.
As leader of the legislature, Chen said Wang doesn't treat lawmakers differently because of their political affiliation and is therefore indispensable to the lawmaking body.
Chen's rival for the DPP nomination, Yang Chiu-hsing, arrived at Wang's party Tuesday evening.
He stopped short, however, of asking Wang for endorsement of his candidacy, saying the New Year's party is a social gathering and one that he has attended regularly over the last few years.

"Wang is a well-known national politician from Kaohsiung. There are many issues on which I have to seek his opinion after the merger of Kaohsiung County and Kaohsiung City," Yang said. (Feb. 17, 2010) The Liberty Times:

Legislator Huang Chao-shun, who is hoping to run as the KMT's candidate in the Kaohsiung special municipality race, said "it is good, " when asked about the possibility of Wang running on the KMT ticket. She said Wang is a well-known political leader at the national level and urged KMT authorities not to look down upon him.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said in an interview a couple of days ago that Wang would be a wonderful candidate but that the party should respect his willingness to run.
Lujhu Council Speaker Huang Sung-cheng, a political confidant of Wang, ruled out the possibility that Wang would run in the Kaohsiung race, saying it was out of the question.
"I asked him in person last week and the answer was 'no.'" (Feb. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Save the planet

TEXT.P: At the turn of year, many people make "new wishes" for the coming year. The new wish for people today should be to "save the Earth" because of predictable catastrophes: pollution, global warming and species extinction.

Do not believe that these possible tragedies are remote. Just look at Taiwan. Over the past 100 years, the average temperature on this island has increased by 0.8 degrees Celsius, higher than the world's 0.7 degrees. Torrential rainfall, extreme temperatures, typhoons, and floods may all arrive more frequently the more rapid mutations of viruses and bacteria threaten the Earth.

Despite the signing of the Kyoto Protocol 13 years ago and the holding of the Copenhagen summit late last year, nothing concrete has been done by governments across the globe to improve the situation. Ordinary people should face up to this reality and take action on their own in their daily lives.

First, use car pooling when going out in groups. Second, turn out the lights when possible at home and in the office. Switch off the air conditioning and use power-saving strategies on the roof, such as painting it white. Third, do not use plastic bags and instead use shopping bags as much as possible. Fourth, separate kitchen leftovers and trash. Fifth, use your own cup when drinking coffee outside and do not buy products that are overpackaged, to help save trees that are essential to maintaining normal temperatures and rainfall.
These are trivial things, but they are extremely important to our environment. Any great task starts from the beginning. Now is the time for all of us to get involved. (Feb. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma receives visiting U.S. congressman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 18:34:57 (By Lai Yu-chia and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday told U.S. Representative James Sensenbrenner, Jr. that Taiwan hopes the U.S. Congress will support its efforts to join international organizations and sign a bilateral extradition agreement with the United States.
Sensenbrenner, accompanied by his wife, is on a week-long visit to Taipei that began Tuesday.

Receiving the couple at the Presidential Office, President Ma said progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations is closely related to the development of U.S.-Taiwan relations, citing the significance of U.S. military sales to Taiwan's security and talks with China.

As Taiwan is seeking more international participation, the president asked Sensenbrenner for his support in helping realize the aspiration of Taiwan's people to participate in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) , the International Aviation Organization (IAO), and other international organizations.

Referring to the expectations of President Ma to sign an extradition agreement and a reciprocal visa-free agreement with the U.S., Sensenbrenner, a Republican from Wisconsin, said more discussion is needed before such agreements can be signed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Market for part-time jobs prosperous during winter break
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 18:41:34 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Local students who were eager to find a part-time job during their 32-day winter vacation should not have had a hard time finding one as many local businesses are trying to profit from the New Year's holiday shopping season as the economy recovers.
According to statistics released by local manpower agency 104 Job Bank, the number of available part-time jobs rose to 21,168 in January, up 9.6 percent from the previous month.
This figures corresponded to the 9.89 percent increase reported by another employment agency, the 1111 Job Bank, compared with the same period a year earlier.

Fang Guang-wei, a public relations manager for the 104 Job Bank, attributed the increase to local restaurants' booming business in meeting demand for year-end dinners, which accounted for 21.9 percent of the increase.
Marketing personnel, such as sales promoters in department stores and point-of- purchase salespeople in supermarkets, made up 19.6 percent of the increase.
Education accounted for another 15.4 percent of the rise, thanks to more parents enrolling their children in special classes during the winter vacation.
These job opportunities likely met the demands of many students who were looking for part-time jobs during the vacation.

A survey by 1111 Job Bank showed that 95 percent of students it interviewed said they intended to work part-time during the vacation and expected to earn an average of NT$12,306 (US$383) over that time.

1111 Job Bank spokesman Chang Hsiu-lan said the number of students who intended to work part-time is 10 percent more than in 2008, before the global financial crisis battered Taiwan's economy, and their income expectations were NT$2,000 lower than two years ago.
Eateries, which offered the most job opportunities, were these students' favorite workplaces, followed by supermarkets and jobs as computer input operators.
Theme parks, which are often packed with visitors during the New Year holiday, and manufacturers of video games catering to students also needed many extra hands this winter.

Yuan Hsiang-chieh, the public relations manager for the Leofoo Village Theme Park in Guansi, Hsinchu County, said the park needed 300 student workers in February, 100 more than during the same period last year.
These part-time workers were needed to man the park's shops, restaurants, snack bars and hotels.
On-line games operators who enjoyed a prosperous year in 2009 also needed part- time workers to help them design, test, promote and maintain their new online games, according to the 104 Job Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO mum on its prevailing in patent case against LGD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 19:04:25 (By Chang Chien-chung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) refused to comment on the LCD panel manufacturer's win against its South Korean competitor LG Display Co. (LGD) in a patent infringement case Tuesday in the United States.
The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said his company would not comment before reading the court's judgment, but he reiterated that the company fully respected others patents.
Bloomberg reported Tuesday that a U.S. District Court in Delaware found that LGD had infringed four of AUO's patents for flat-panel video technology.
The case stemmed from a patent infringement complaint filed by LGD in Delaware in Dec. 2006 against AUO and another Taiwanese electronics firm, Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp.
AUO denied the charges and filed a counter action against LGD in March, 2007 for alleged patent infringements.
The company is seeking damages of hundreds of millions of dollars, according to the Bloomberg report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Signing ECFA more complicated than president suggests: DPP chair
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 19:13:10 (by Liu Chia-tai and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said Wednesday that concluding a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will be more complicated than President Ma Ying-jeou has suggested.

Campaigning for Hsiao Bi-khim, the DPP candidate in the Feb. 27 legislative by- election in Hualien, Tsai said that while visiting townships and villages in Hualien over the past few weeks, she sensed grave concern over lost job opportunities and the exodus of job seekers.
Tsai stressed that Taiwan's sovereignty and people's job opportunities should be the priority concern of the government while it seeks to maintain a stable relationship with China.
The opposition party leader said that she found it most helpful to meet people at the grassroots level face-to-face to learn their worries and concerns.
Tsai has been campaigning for DPP candidates in the four legislative by- elections to be held in Hualien, Chiayi, Hsinchu, and Taoyuan counties on Feb. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-tech corridor hopes to create new era for Taipei City
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 19:19:00 (By C. W. Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government has launched a "Taipei Technology Corridor" project that it hopes will turn Taiwan's capital city into a knowledge-based high-tech hub and create a favorable international investment environment.

Chen Wen-hsiung, director of the city's Department of Economic Development, said the goal is to develop Taipei City into a global high-tech, R&D and business operations stronghold by capitalizing on its ideal location within Asia, business friendly environment, strong human and capital resources, and sound Internet infrastructure.

The 893.3-hectare corridor will stretch from the Neihu Technology Park to the Kuandu Industrial Zone, connecting the Nankang Software Park and the planned Shihlin-Beitou Technology Park, according to the city government.
With the corridor increasingly taking shape, more information, biotechnology, communications and cultural innovation companies have set up shops in these parks, Chen said.

Citing the 150-hectare Neihu Technology Park as an example of the corridor's potential, Chen said it has now become a cluster for high-tech businesses, an operations center for the global electronics industry, and the hub of Taiwan's telecommunications industry.
A total of 3,446 enterprises, (including 26 business headquarters and 12 research centers) operate in the park, with a production value of NT$2.7 trillion (US$83.85 billion) per year.

The Nankang Software Park is designed to attract biotechnology, IC design and digital content firms. In addition, the Taipei City government is planning to position it as an Asian Software Park and an Asian R&D center.
Currently, 275 companies, (including four business headquarters and six R&D centers) have moved into the park, racking up NT$182.6 billion in revenues in 2007.
To strengthen the park's cluster effect, a third-stage expansion project was completed in September 2008 and is expected to generate an annual production of US$1.86 billion in the future.
The planned Shihlin-Beitou Technology Park, the third high-tech compound in Taipei City after the Neihu and Nankang technology parks, will be located on a 195-hectare plot.
It will comprise knowledge-based companies in the biotechnology, media and telecommunications sectors and create an estimated 35,000 jobs after its completion, which is projected for 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Northbound lanes on freeways swarm with cars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 21:08:02 (By Chen Hung-jin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Northbound lanes of the island's freeways began to swarm with cars Tuesday as the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday entered its fourth day.
A total of 2.83 million cars hit Taiwan's freeways Tuesday, 84 percent more than last year's daily average, according to the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau Wednesday.
Though traffic was heavy on northbound lanes and average traveling speeds reducing, no major snarls were reported.

Speeds slowed to between 40-60 kilometers per hour in stretches between Neili and Pingjhen in Taoyuan County and near the Yuanlin Toll Station in Changhua County on National Freeway No. 1, according to the statement.

The volume of cars was expected to dip slightly to 2.7 million Wednesday, the bureau said in a statement, adding that 420,000 cars, or 2.8 times more than usual, passed through the freeways' various toll stations between midnight Tuesday and 7 a.m. Wednesday when no toll was charged.

In order to more efficiently utilize the freeways, the bureau said it will allow only cars with three or more passengers to use northbound lanes on the island's two major north-south arteries -- National Freeway No. 1 and No. 3 -- between 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday.
The restriction will be applied to the stretch between Kaohsiung and Neili on freeway No. 1 and between Jiuru in Pingtung County and Dasi in Taoyuan County on freeway No. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates gear up for legislative by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 21:35:08 (By C. T. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Many people in Taiwan may be enjoying their Lunar New Year break, but candidates participating in legislative by-elections in four counties on Feb. 27 have stepped up their campaign efforts over the holiday.
King Pu-tsung, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), was reluctant Tuesday to predict the outcome of the four races, to be held in Taoyuan, Hualien, Chiayi, and Hsinchu counties.
With only 10 days to go before election day, he stumped for KMT candidate Lin Teh-jui in Chiayi County and accompanied him as they canvassed for support on county streets.

Lin is seen as a heavy underdog against former Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, a heavyweight of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the race in the southern Taiwan county, a traditional DPP stronghold.
Accompanied by Chiayi County Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan, Chen handed out Year of the Tiger red envelopes to the public when visiting the Tsu Yun Temple on the same day.

Earlier Tuesday, King campaigned for the KMT's Wang Ting-sheng in eastern Hualien County. Wang will run against Hsiao Bi-khim, a strong DPP contender, and independent candidate Shih Sheng-lang, who has the backing of Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.
Polls indicate that it will be a tight two-way race, with Shih possibly acting as a spoiler.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who stumped for Hsiao in Hualien, said Hsiao stands a good chance of winning the contest even though the KMT traditionally enjoys greater support there.

In Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, KMT hopeful Apollo Chen will challenge the DPP's Huang Jen-shu and two other independent candidates. Signs over the past 20 days indicate that it will be a tight contest between Chen and Huang.

In neighboring Hsinchu County, Cheng Yung-tang of the KMT will battle Perng Shaw-jiin of the DPP. Perng is believed to have the upper hand at present in a battle between veteran members of their respective parties.
