Currently, 275 companies, (including four business headquarters and six R&D centers) have moved into the park, racking up NT$182.6 billion in revenues in 2007.
To strengthen the park's cluster effect, a third-stage expansion project was completed in September 2008 and is expected to generate an annual production of US$1.86 billion in the future.
The planned Shihlin-Beitou Technology Park, the third high-tech compound in Taipei City after the Neihu and Nankang technology parks, will be located on a 195-hectare plot.
It will comprise knowledge-based companies in the biotechnology, media and telecommunications sectors and create an estimated 35,000 jobs after its completion, which is projected for 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Northbound lanes on freeways swarm with cars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 21:08:02 (By Chen Hung-jin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Northbound lanes of the island's freeways began to swarm with cars Tuesday as the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday entered its fourth day.
A total of 2.83 million cars hit Taiwan's freeways Tuesday, 84 percent more than last year's daily average, according to the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau Wednesday.
Though traffic was heavy on northbound lanes and average traveling speeds reducing, no major snarls were reported.

Speeds slowed to between 40-60 kilometers per hour in stretches between Neili and Pingjhen in Taoyuan County and near the Yuanlin Toll Station in Changhua County on National Freeway No. 1, according to the statement.

The volume of cars was expected to dip slightly to 2.7 million Wednesday, the bureau said in a statement, adding that 420,000 cars, or 2.8 times more than usual, passed through the freeways' various toll stations between midnight Tuesday and 7 a.m. Wednesday when no toll was charged.

In order to more efficiently utilize the freeways, the bureau said it will allow only cars with three or more passengers to use northbound lanes on the island's two major north-south arteries -- National Freeway No. 1 and No. 3 -- between 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday.
The restriction will be applied to the stretch between Kaohsiung and Neili on freeway No. 1 and between Jiuru in Pingtung County and Dasi in Taoyuan County on freeway No. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates gear up for legislative by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/10 21:35:08 (By C. T. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Many people in Taiwan may be enjoying their Lunar New Year break, but candidates participating in legislative by-elections in four counties on Feb. 27 have stepped up their campaign efforts over the holiday.
King Pu-tsung, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), was reluctant Tuesday to predict the outcome of the four races, to be held in Taoyuan, Hualien, Chiayi, and Hsinchu counties.
With only 10 days to go before election day, he stumped for KMT candidate Lin Teh-jui in Chiayi County and accompanied him as they canvassed for support on county streets.

Lin is seen as a heavy underdog against former Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, a heavyweight of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the race in the southern Taiwan county, a traditional DPP stronghold.
Accompanied by Chiayi County Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan, Chen handed out Year of the Tiger red envelopes to the public when visiting the Tsu Yun Temple on the same day.

Earlier Tuesday, King campaigned for the KMT's Wang Ting-sheng in eastern Hualien County. Wang will run against Hsiao Bi-khim, a strong DPP contender, and independent candidate Shih Sheng-lang, who has the backing of Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.
Polls indicate that it will be a tight two-way race, with Shih possibly acting as a spoiler.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who stumped for Hsiao in Hualien, said Hsiao stands a good chance of winning the contest even though the KMT traditionally enjoys greater support there.

In Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, KMT hopeful Apollo Chen will challenge the DPP's Huang Jen-shu and two other independent candidates. Signs over the past 20 days indicate that it will be a tight contest between Chen and Huang.

In neighboring Hsinchu County, Cheng Yung-tang of the KMT will battle Perng Shaw-jiin of the DPP. Perng is believed to have the upper hand at present in a battle between veteran members of their respective parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 18, or the fifth day of first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme Court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1974: Jorge Cervantes-Pinzon, outgoing charge d'affaires from Colombia, leaves Taipei for home.
1976: C.C. Yang, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary- general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The US assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
1998: Mya Than Tint, one of Burma's most renowned and admired writers, dies at the age of 69.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Number of Chinese tourists rising steadily: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 14:31:04 (By Lee Hsin-kuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More than 646,000 Chinese nationals made sightseeing trips to Taiwan in the 18 months since the country opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists in July 2008, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

Though Chinese tourist arrival numbers have risen steadily during that time, they are expected to grow even further in years to come after Taiwan and China swap offices governing tourism and travel affairs, the MAC said.
"Once established, the tourism offices will offer faster, more convenient and more efficient services to cross-strait tourists, " a MAC official said.
Between July 2008 and Dec. 31, 2009, 26,488 Chinese tour groups comprising 646,783 individuals took trips to Taiwan, mostly on eight-day, seven-night tour packages.
With daily individual spending estimated at US$250, the Chinese tourists have contributed roughly US$1.13 billion to Taiwan's economy over the past 18 months, the MAC said.
Despite the steady growth, however, the number of inbound Chinese tourists has not reached the average quota of 3,000 per day.

Such a number was not significant in the beginning, MAC officials contend, but following closer communications and coordination efforts between tourism officials and travel agencies on the two sides, tourist arrivals rose to about 3,000 daily in April and May last year.

The number declined slightly after August 2009 because of Typhoon Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters in Taiwan in decades, and the impact of the influenza A (H1N1) epidemic, before picking up again in November, the MAC said.
"Now the average number of inbound Chinese tourists stands about 2,000 daily," the official said.

According to the MAC, only 20 Chinese nationals from among the 646,783 tourist arrivals went unaccounted for, far lower than figures posted in Taiwan before 2008, when on average 36 out of every 100,000 Chinese entering the country absconded.
The ratio is even higher in Japan, where 140 out of every 100,000 Chinese disappear after entering, the MAC said.
Of the 20 who have fled in Taiwan over the past 18 months, two have been nabbed while the remaining 18 have yet to be found, the MAC said.
In 2009 alone, Chinese nationals were the second largest group of foreign visitors to Taiwan, behind only the Japanese, with 972,213 arrivals, including 606,174 traveling as tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Economy flexes muscle in Year of Tiger

TEXT.P: This day on the Chinese calendar is the time to welcome the God of Wealth and also a good day for stores to open after Lunar New Year celebrations.
At the start of the Year of the Tiger, we wish our readers happiness, wealth and good fortune. We also hope our government and people will work in concert to make our economy as vibrant as a tiger.

Unlike the Year of the Ox that started amid a global financial meltdown, the Year of the Tiger opens in an upbeat mood over an increasingly evident economic recovery. Both external and domestic markets provide momentum favorable for economic growth.

Externally, a major consensus reached at the just-concluded World Economic Forum in Davos is that this year's GDP growth rates for the world's major economies -- and emerging economies such as China and India in particular -- will be higher than those forecast a half year ago. This implies a surge in global demand that will give Taiwan's economic development a badly needed shot in the arm.

Internally, private consumption and corporate investment -- the two pillars of domestic demand -- are both bottoming out of a year-long recession. Private- sector investment is expected to be exceptionally robust this year as many industries undergo structural adjustments in the wake of the devastating global financial storm.
Investment in energy conservation, carbon reduction and production capacity expansion to cope with global competition will further fuel growth.
Moreover, the government's four-year NT$500 billion infrastructure construction project will shift into high gear this year, which will serve as yet another engine of sustainable expansion.

With the "four legs" of economic development -- external trade, private consumption, private investment and government investment -- ready to advance simultaneously, we are confident that our economy will no longer be crippled this year.

Steadily improving relations across the Taiwan Strait will offer additional growth momentum as three measures to normalize cross-strait economic relations -- relaxing ceilings on China-bound investment, easing curbs on industries eligible to invest in China, and allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan -- will come to fruition during the year.

The already signed cross-strait memorandum of understanding on financial supervisory cooperation and the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement will help further remove barriers to Taiwan's economic links with the global market and infuse new vigor and vitality into the local economy.

Nevertheless, downside variables still lurk on the global economic horizon, including the winding down of emergency stimulus packages adopted by various countries during the financial crisis, the risk of a hard economic landing in China, and sovereign debt crises in certain countries. The government should not ignore those possibilities and should heighten its vigilance and prepare response strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Two countries' reference clarified by Presidential Office
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 15:52:49 (By Huang Jui-hung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou would not refer to Taiwan and China as "the two countries, " a Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday in clarifying a press release that used the term a day earlier.

The Liberty Times reported that according to a Presidential Office press release issued Wednesday, the president referred to Taiwan and China as "two countries" when he talked with a visiting U.S. congressman earlier in the day.
Spokesman Wang Yu-chi said, however, that the president has not and would never refer to cross-strait relations as relations between two countries.
Wang explained that according to the Republic of China Constitution, the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign state and the Chinese mainland is an ROC "area."

Under this constitutional framework, he said, the ROC does not recognize China as a sovereign nation but "does not deny that in fact mainland authorities are the effective ruling authority in the mainland Chinese area."

Such a constitutional framework has been observed in Taiwan since former President Lee Teng-hui promulgated it 19 years ago, Wang said, and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party did not try to make any changes to the framework during its eight-year rule between 2000 and 2008 either.
"Following such a framework not only is not a sign of weakness, it helps underline the ROC's sovereignty and subjectivity, " Wang said.
The topic is sensitive, however, because Ma's predecessors -- Lee Teng-hui and Chen Shui-bian -- both referred to relations with China as "state-to-state" relations.

But in his effort to improve relations with Taiwan's long-time rival, Ma has backed away from that formula, instead referring consistently to Taiwan and China as the "two sides" of the Taiwan Strait within the context of cross-strait relations.

According to the newspaper report, the Presidential Office press release wrote that Ma described Taiwan and China as the "two countries" when discussing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China with visiting U.S. Representative James Sensenbrenner on Wednesday.
The words "two countries" were later removed from the press release posted on the Presidential Office Web site and changed to "the two sides," according to the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency confirms Wang's signing with Nationals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 17:04:03 (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: The agency representing Taiwanese pitcher Chien-ming Wang has confirmed that the 29-year-old right-hander has signed an incentive laden one-year deal to play for the Washington Nationals.

In a move described as more of a gamble than a purchase by a Washington newspaper, the Nationals will pay Wang a guaranteed US$2 million and up to US$3.2 million in incentives for the 2010 season, according to the agency that represents him, Octagon Baseball.

Among the incentives, Wang will receive US$250,000 if he remains on the Nationals Major League roster for more than 60 consecutive days and another US$200,000 if he wins the Comeback Player of the Year Award.

The former New York Yankee will also earn incentives of various magnitudes for starting between 10 and 27 games in 2010, a tall order considering that Wang is not expected to start pitching until May.

The Yankees non-tendered Wang in December after his up-and-down five-year stint with the club. He won more games than any other big league pitcher (38) between 2006 and 2007, but injuries limited him to 27 appearances over the past two years.
In 2009, when he earned US$5 million, Wang was 1-6 with an atrocious 9.64 ERA before being shut down for the season with a shoulder injury.
Even prior to the injury, however, Wang's sinker was clearly not as effective as in the past, tailing sideways rather than darting downward, making it much easier for batters to hit.

The Nationals are hoping that his woes were simply the result of Wang not being in top shape. He suffered a Lisfranc injury to his right foot in July 2008 and had trouble regaining his fitness level in early 2009 after being told by the Yankees not to do his typical offseason leg exercises.

For the Nationals to cash in on their bet, Wang will have to regain his signature sinker, the one batters have described as like trying to hit a bowling ball, because without it, the Tainan native has little else in his arsenal that can trouble Major League hitters.

Few pitchers in the Nationals organization can match Wang's track record -- a lifetime record of 55-26 with a 4.16 ERA. But the Taiwanese right-hander will have to show that he can regain his pitching touch and revive his career after last year's shoulder surgery if he wants to live up to his advanced billing.

DOC.HEADLINE: The China Times: Best New Year's gift

TEXT.P: The Lunar New Year holiday is the most important festival for Chinese across the world to be reunited with their families. With holiday meals and travel losing their lure for most of Taiwan's people, the holiday provides a good time for children to listen to the elder members of their families.

Many of them went through hard times in their youth, and their experience offers precious lessons. The lives of parents or grandparents are mirrors reflecting the path of their family, their clan and even society as a whole.

It is worthwhile for older people to educate younger generations by sharing their life experiences with them, which will enable younger family members to learn how to respect the elderly and preserve family traditions. Only a society in which venerable senior citizens are well respected by the younger generation can create greater value by handing down its traditions.

As the life span of Taiwanese men and women reached an average of 75.9 and 82.5, respectively, in 2009, Taiwan has effectively evolved into an aging society. To raise the public's awareness of respecting the elderly, the Ministry of Education has proposed to create a "grandparents day" to serve that end.

The 19th century poet Lord Alfred Tennyson compared life to an oak tree that weathers persistent challenges through the four seasons. We should treat our older family members with the same respect because they are our treasures. (Feb. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan International Festival's outdoor opening to be postponed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 18:14:45 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Friday's outdoor opening show of the 2010 Taiwan International Festival (TIF), a dance presented by a renowned Spanish contemporary troupe, has been rescheduled due to the threat of heavy rain.

The National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) announced Thursday that the Sol Pico Dance Company will present the Asian premiere of "Sirena a la plancha" at 6 p.m. on Feb. 21 rather than on Feb. 19 as was originally scheduled.
The dance company, a professional contemporary dance group founded in 1994 by dancer and choreographer Sol Pico, was invited to Taipei by the NTCH for the Chinese New Year holiday.
The show's postponement due to heavy rain in Taipei is rather ironic considering that it presents the issue of a dwindling water supply in the format of a fable.
The show is about a woman who transforms herself into a mermaid to save the world from drought, but is caught by fishermen, sold and lost.
A giant, representing earth, seduces her, creating a story of impossible love, according to a description of the show released by NTCH.
"The focus of the show will be a 9-meter mobile mermaid, a gigantic puppet, and a stage composed of five mobile platforms, " the NTCH said in its synopsis of the performance.
The production made its debut in the summer of 2008 at the ExpoZaragoza 2008, for which it was commissioned.
Local audiences will now be able to see the outdoor performance in the main plaza of the NTCH this Sunday. Admission is free.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Taiwan-U.S.-China relations remain top concern

TEXT.P: Triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations will remain a focus of concern in the Year of the Tiger.

While receiving visiting James Sensenbrenner, Jr., a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, Wednesday, President Ma Ying-jeou said progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations is closely related to the development of U.S.-Taiwan relations, citing the significance of U.S. military sales to Taiwan's security and talks with China.
Although U.S.-China relations have recently been strained over a U.S. arms sale to Taiwan and a planned meeting between U.S. President
Barack Obama and the Dalai Lama, five American warships docked for
a port call in Hong Kong Wednesday. Beijing's approval of the port
call may indicate that the Chinese government will not let its
relations with Washington deteriorate further.
The following are excerpts of leading local newspapers' coverage related to the issue:
China Times:

President Ma told Sensenbrenner during their Wednesday meeting that his government's efforts to improve relations with China over the past 20 months have eliminated the possibility of war in the Taiwan Strait.

Moreover, Ma said, his government has employed similar conciliatory approaches in other diplomatic arenas, hoping to boost mutual trust and cooperation with Taiwan's major trading partners, including the United States, Japan, the European Union and Southeast Asian countries.

Stressing that solid Taiwan-U.S. security relations are crucial to cross-strait reconciliation and engagement, Ma said continued U.S. sale of defnesive weapons to Taiwan has helped enhance the confidence and sense of security among Taiwan's government and people in seeking peaceful solutions to cross-strait disputes. (Feb. 18, 2010)
Liberty Times:
U.S. President Barack Obama will meet with the Dalai Lama Feb. 18, despite China's warning that such a meeting would hurt ties already strained by U.S. weapons sales to Taiwan.

The Dalai Lama's chief envoy said Tuesday that Obama probably will not make a public appearance this week with the Tibetan spiritual leader during a White House visit that is already infuriating China.

Briefing reporters Tuesday on the eve of the Dalai Lama's arrival, Lodi Gyari said Thursday's meeting in the White House between the Nobel Peace laureates, even if out of the public eye, would be an important boost for Tibet and for the broader U.S. commitment to human rights.

A joint appearance by Obama and the Dalai Lama before reporters could make tense U.S.-China ties even worse and further complicate U.S. efforts to secure Chinese help in settling North Korean and Iranian nuclear standoffs and crucial economic, military and environmental problems.

The Dalai Lama, who has met with every U.S. president over the past two decades, is a recurring needle in U.S.-Chinese ties. China accuses the monk of pushing for Tibetan independence, which he has denied repeatedly. Any meeting between the Dalai Lama and a foreign leader is considered by China to be an infringement of its sovereignty.

Meanwhile, political analysts said Beijing's approval of the port call by the USS Nimitz battle group in Hong Kong is an indication that the Chinese government does not want to let Sino-U.S. relations deteriorate further, which would hamper cooperation on the global economy and other issues. (Feb. 18, 2010)
Economic Daily News:
The latest statistics released by the U.S. Treasury Department showed that China trimmed its holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds by US$34.2 billion in December 2009.
The big drop in China's holdings meant that it was no longer the largest foreign holder of U.S. government debt, ceding the top spot to Japan.
Japan increased its holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds in December by US$11.5 billion to US$768.8 billion, exceeding China's total of US$755.5 billion.
China's reductions in holdings, if they continue, could force the U.S. government to make higher interest payments at a time when it is running record federal budget deficits.
Analysts speculated that China's reduction may be a strategy to counter U.S. pressure on it to raise the value of its currency to reflect its rising economic might. (Feb. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Leaping into new era
DOC.DATELINE: 02/18/10 19:35:42 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has a good chance in the Year of the Tiger to take a long leap into a new era if the government and the people work in concert to make the country's economy as vibrant as a tiger.
The much debated economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is one of the issues that will have a crucial impact on Taiwan's economy this year.

We urge the administration to intensify its communications with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and urge the DPP to take Taiwan's overall interests into account so that the ECFA can be signed this year as expected.

After saying goodbye to the Year of the Ox, which was scarred by a global economic crunch, the world ushers in a much more upbeat Year of the Tiger, with evident signs of economic recovery around the world, although some hidden risks still exist.

One of the risks is the heavy injection of financial assistance from major economies to countries in need. The cash flows may have helped those countries tide over their financial difficulties, but they may also lead to the formation of a new capital bubble that could explode any minute.

This trend, combined with rising demand for commodities in emerging economies driving prices higher, could lead countries to wind down economic stimulus packages and increase uncertainty, putting the world at risk of a second recession.
The ASEAN Plus China free trade agreement, which took effect Jan. 1, is also having an adverse impact on Taiwan's export trade and economic growth.
But we noticed in the days leading up to the Chinese New Year a different atmosphere in Taiwan.

First, the Ministry of National Defense for the first time allowed military transports to ferry Taiwanese stuck on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu back to Taiwan proper for the Chinese New Year holiday.

Second, Perng Fai-nan, the governor of Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) wrote letters to leading entrepreneurs in the country before the holiday, promising that the central bank will continue to adopt stimulus measures to help the private sector.
These two events underlined that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has become more "active, " giving it a chance to win back the confidence of the people.

Third, the government issued NT$304.5 billion worth of new bills in the 10 days prior to the Chinese New Year's eve, bringing the cumulative amount of currency in circulation to more than NT$1.5 trillion, a new record high.
The record issuance of currency signifies that people are willing to spend and that consumer confidence is recovering.

Fourth, Taiwan's exports surged in January, with particularly strong growth in exports to China, indicating that Taiwan's foreign trade will definitely benefit from China's economic growth, which is forecast to hit 10 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City seeks to build new regional landmark
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 20:00:17 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government is planning to build a new skyscraper in the Taichung Shueinan Airport Trade Park that will stand as a new landmark in central Taiwan, a city government official said Thursday.

Deputy Taichung Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said the city government will launch an international concept competition before the end of this year for the building of the new landmark, which will be called the Tower of Taiwan.
A second stage competition, an international design competition for the development of the skyscraper, is scheduled to take place in 2011, Hsiao said.

The city wants the Tower of Taiwan to be more than 300 meters high, allowing visitors to have a bird's-eye view of the Taiwan Strait from the tower's west side and of Taiwan's Central Mountain Range from its east side, as well as a panoramic view of all of Taichung City at night, Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Soft power lets Taiwan overcome poverty, survive despotism: Lu
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 20:33:46 (By Jiang Yuan-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has emerged from poverty and authoritarian rule with soft power, Taiwan's former Vice President Annette Lu said here Thursday.

Addressing an international leadership conference organized by the Universal Peace Federation, Lu said Taiwan's soft power lies in its development experience, human rights, peace, true love, and scientific and technological development.

"The ongoing conference is aimed at exploring strategies to promote world peace, a theme that is closely associated with my longtime conviction of pursuing growth and development with soft power, " Lu told an audience composed of politicians, scholars and experts from 67 countries.

Lu said Taiwan's experience provides a convincing example that soft power as evidenced in peace, love, democracy, human rights, science, and technological development can help a country surmount poverty and fight off despotism or authoritarian rule.

After arriving in Seoul, Lu said she found that South Korea offered yet another successful example of the efficacy of soft power, judging from South Korea's even more remarkable economic record than Taiwan's in recent years.

Noting that 2010 is the Year of the Tiger, Lu said she looked forward to seeing all conference goers work together to promote soft power and ensure that human development will be peaceful and full of love.
Her 10-minute speech drew resounding applause.
Religious representatives from Britain and Brazil as well as Jose de Venecia, Jr., the former speaker of the Philippines House of Representatives, also spoke at the conference that opened Wednesday.
Lu arrived in Seoul Tuesday for a four-day visit at the invitation of the UPF to attend the international leadership meeting.
During her stay, Lu has met with Korean politicians, including former President Kim Young Sam, and civic leaders on human rights issues.
She also attended a banquet in celebration of the 90th birthday of UPF founder Rev. Sun Myung Moon.
Lu will depart for the United States Friday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Commercial Times: Spring breeze to blow away ill winds

TEXT.P: Last year, Taiwan suffered its deepest recession in over 50 years because of the global financial crunch, with as many as 1.4 million people affected by the downturn. Despite those economic difficulties, we deeply hope that good luck and fortune will grace the country in the new year.

Taiwan posted many historical lows in 2009. The economy contracted by 2.53 percent and exports plunged 20.3 percent. Many people were forced to take unpaid leave and close to 700,000 people were out of work -- a situation far more serious than the two oil crises in the 1970s and 1980s and the bursting of the dot.com bubble in 2000.

Fortunately, Taiwan's economy began showing signs of recovery in the fourth quarter last year, on a par with the global trend. The benchmark weighted index of the local bourse rose from 4,475 in January to 7,837 by the end of December.

However, worldwide hopes for a sound recovery have been dampened by the recent sovereign debt defaults in the euro zone, sending international stock markets, including Taiwan's, plummeting. Economic uncertainty has again cast a shadow on the global economy.

Looking back at world history, we know that economic ups and downs are normal and that the global economy always seeks to crawl back after hitting bottom. There is no shortcut for the world economy to return to its peak this time around. As the Year of Tiger arrives, we wholeheartedly pray that Taiwan's economy will swiftly regain its momentum, just as we hope for the arrival of spring that will bring a warm breeze to our humble homes. (Feb. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Reservoir, river dredging projects launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 21:42:13 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Projects to dredge sediment and silt from Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County and the Gaoping River in the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area were launched Thursday in an effort to complete them before this year's rainy or typhoon season.

In light of the urgency of reservoir and river cleanup, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs launched the dredging projects in southern Taiwan ahead of the end of the Lunar New Year holiday next Monday.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang presided over the launch ceremony for the Tsengwen Reservoir cleanup project amid chilly winds and a drizzle.

"We launched the urgent project on this auspicius day in hopes of completing it smoothly before the arrival of rainy season, " Shih said, referring to the fifth day of the Lunar New Year when the God of Wealth is welcomed and businesses re- open.

Shih said the project aims to remove 600,000 tons of silt and sediment from the reservoir, a major source of drinking and irrigation water in the Tainan-Chiayi area, one of Taiwan's agricultural strongholds.
Tsengwen Reservoir can store up to 630 million cubic meters of water, but its effective storage capacity is now about 490 million cubic meters because of the massive buildup of silt and mud.

Since Typhoon Morakot devastated southern Taiwan last August, the region has been hit by a dry spell. The Tsengwen Reservoir's water level is now at only 201.3 meters, with yellow silt covering its spillways.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan helps Philippines build automatic weather stations
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Philippines, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 22:11:17 (By Emerson T. Lim and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan donated US$280,000 to the Philippine Weather Bureau Thursday to build 15 automatic weather stations on Luzon Island and install relevant facilities as part of its efforts to expand bilateral meteorological cooperation.

C.T. Lee, Taiwan's representative to the Philippines, handed over the fund to Estrella Alabastro, secretary of the Philippine Ministry of Science and Technology, in a donation ceremony held at the Philippine ministry's conference hall. In the Philippines, the weather bureau is under the jurisdiction of the science and technology ministry.
The fund will finance construction of 15 automatic weather monitoring stations, an information and data display center and two work stations.

It marked the second time that Taiwan has donated funds to the Philippine Weather Bureau. In 2007, Taiwan donated US$170,000 to repair a mountaintop weather monitoring station. Taiwan has since shared weather observation data with the Philippines to enhance its forecast ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City seeks to build new regional landmark
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 20:00:17 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government is planning to build a new skyscraper in the Taichung Shueinan Airport Trade Park that will stand as a new landmark in central Taiwan, a city government official said Thursday.

Deputy Taichung Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said the city government will launch an international concept competition before the end of this year for the building of the new landmark, which will be called the Tower of Taiwan.
A second stage competition, an international design competition for the development of the skyscraper, is scheduled to take place in 2011, Hsiao said.

The city wants the Tower of Taiwan to be more than 300 meters high, allowing visitors to have a bird's-eye view of the Taiwan Strait from the tower's west side and of Taiwan's Central Mountain Range from its east side, as well as a panoramic view of all of Taichung City at night, Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Soft power lets Taiwan overcome poverty, survive despotism: Lu
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 20:33:46 (By Jiang Yuan-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has emerged from poverty and authoritarian rule with soft power, Taiwan's former Vice President Annette Lu said here Thursday.

Addressing an international leadership conference organized by the Universal Peace Federation, Lu said Taiwan's soft power lies in its development experience, human rights, peace, true love, and scientific and technological development.

"The ongoing conference is aimed at exploring strategies to promote world peace, a theme that is closely associated with my longtime conviction of pursuing growth and development with soft power, " Lu told an audience composed of politicians, scholars and experts from 67 countries.

Lu said Taiwan's experience provides a convincing example that soft power as evidenced in peace, love, democracy, human rights, science, and technological development can help a country surmount poverty and fight off despotism or authoritarian rule.

After arriving in Seoul, Lu said she found that South Korea offered yet another successful example of the efficacy of soft power, judging from South Korea's even more remarkable economic record than Taiwan's in recent years.

Noting that 2010 is the Year of the Tiger, Lu said she looked forward to seeing all conference goers work together to promote soft power and ensure that human development will be peaceful and full of love.
Her 10-minute speech drew resounding applause.
Religious representatives from Britain and Brazil as well as Jose de Venecia, Jr., the former speaker of the Philippines House of Representatives, also spoke at the conference that opened Wednesday.
Lu arrived in Seoul Tuesday for a four-day visit at the invitation of the UPF to attend the international leadership meeting.
During her stay, Lu has met with Korean politicians, including former President Kim Young Sam, and civic leaders on human rights issues.
She also attended a banquet in celebration of the 90th birthday of UPF founder Rev. Sun Myung Moon.
Lu will depart for the United States Friday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Commercial Times: Spring breeze to blow away ill winds

TEXT.P: Last year, Taiwan suffered its deepest recession in over 50 years because of the global financial crunch, with as many as 1.4 million people affected by the downturn. Despite those economic difficulties, we deeply hope that good luck and fortune will grace the country in the new year.

Taiwan posted many historical lows in 2009. The economy contracted by 2.53 percent and exports plunged 20.3 percent. Many people were forced to take unpaid leave and close to 700,000 people were out of work -- a situation far more serious than the two oil crises in the 1970s and 1980s and the bursting of the dot.com bubble in 2000.

Fortunately, Taiwan's economy began showing signs of recovery in the fourth quarter last year, on a par with the global trend. The benchmark weighted index of the local bourse rose from 4,475 in January to 7,837 by the end of December.

However, worldwide hopes for a sound recovery have been dampened by the recent sovereign debt defaults in the euro zone, sending international stock markets, including Taiwan's, plummeting. Economic uncertainty has again cast a shadow on the global economy.

Looking back at world history, we know that economic ups and downs are normal and that the global economy always seeks to crawl back after hitting bottom. There is no shortcut for the world economy to return to its peak this time around. As the Year of Tiger arrives, we wholeheartedly pray that Taiwan's economy will swiftly regain its momentum, just as we hope for the arrival of spring that will bring a warm breeze to our humble homes. (Feb. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Reservoir, river dredging projects launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/10 21:42:13 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Projects to dredge sediment and silt from Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County and the Gaoping River in the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area were launched Thursday in an effort to complete them before this year's rainy or typhoon season.

In light of the urgency of reservoir and river cleanup, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs launched the dredging projects in southern Taiwan ahead of the end of the Lunar New Year holiday next Monday.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang presided over the launch ceremony for the Tsengwen Reservoir cleanup project amid chilly winds and a drizzle.

"We launched the urgent project on this auspicius day in hopes of completing it smoothly before the arrival of rainy season, " Shih said, referring to the fifth day of the Lunar New Year when the God of Wealth is welcomed and businesses re- open.

Shih said the project aims to remove 600,000 tons of silt and sediment from the reservoir, a major source of drinking and irrigation water in the Tainan-Chiayi area, one of Taiwan's agricultural strongholds.
Tsengwen Reservoir can store up to 630 million cubic meters of water, but its effective storage capacity is now about 490 million cubic meters because of the massive buildup of silt and mud.

Since Typhoon Morakot devastated southern Taiwan last August, the region has been hit by a dry spell. The Tsengwen Reservoir's water level is now at only 201.3 meters, with yellow silt covering its spillways.
"This provides a good opportunity to get rid of silt and sediment," Shih said.
According to WRA officials, 65 million cubic meters of silt and sediment will be dredged from reservoirs and rivers around Taiwan before the typhoon season this year.

On Thursday afternoon, Shih traveled to Pingtung County to show concern for those working there to clean up the Gaoping River. A total of 14.9 million cubic meters of silt and sediment will be removed from the river before the end of June. About 8 million cubic meters of silt have so far been cleaned up, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 11:38:49 (EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE AT 16:00 GMT SUNDAY, FEB. 18)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 19, or the sixth day of the first month of the Year of the TIger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2003: Adm. Ni Yue-si, a strategy adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found." ENDITEM 2007.02.19.TODAY IN HISTORY
