DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Premier claims no knowledge of deputy's election plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 14:51:07 (By Huang Kuo-fang, Yeh Tzu-kang, Chen Ching-ping and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that he had no knowledge of any plan for his deputy to run for the mayorship of New Taipei City.

Wu made the remarks during a visit to the southern county of Yunlin, where he was asked about media reports that Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu might run for the position after Taipei County is upgraded to a special municipality, while incumbent Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei might be offered a Cabinet position.
The premier declined to comment, saying he had no relevant information on the reports.
However, he added that Chu leaving the Executive Yuan would create "big headaches."
According to Wu, Chu has performed excellently in his past positions as a legislator and as magistrate of Taoyuan County, and has contributed greatly to the Cabinet in his present post.
Wu also said he believes that both Chu and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will carefully consider whether to field him as the party's candidate for the mayoral election.

Also commenting on the issue, former Premier Su Tseng-chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that by giving up on Chou, the KMT would be admitting that Chou has failed to do his job.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: green energy to countryside

TEXT.P: It will not be a smooth year for the global economy in 2010. With the world's third-largest free trade zone formed between China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) taking effect Jan. 1, Taiwan's economy will gradually feel the impact, as the new free trade area accounts for almost 60 percent of Taiwan's export market.
As an export-oriented country -- in which over 70 percent of the economic growth comes from trade surplus with China, Taiwan should not ignore its increasing impact on its economy.
After implementing some policies that hurt its export processing industries in 2008, the Chinese government has been trying hard to expand its domestic demand to support its economic growth.

Its "appliances to the countryside, " "automobiles to the countryside" and "building materials to the countryside" policies, which were designed to boost Chinese rural consumption, have effectively boosted China's consumption and production.

The growing orders from China have not only become a magic pill Taiwanese companies have been seeking, but have also led the whole country to expect more Chinese purchasing groups to bring more money to Taiwan.

Some Taiwanese academic experts recently suggested that the government should consider distributing another round of shopping coupons to lift the economy. However, they fail to realize that handing out shopping coupons are much less effective than the Chinese government's "appliances to the countryside" policy.
In fact, the government does need to boost its domestic demand to compensate for its decreasing external demand and it should also be inspired by the Chinese government's policy.

We suggest that the government should use around NT$20 billion (US$621 million) -- about 20 percent of the total budget for distributing shopping coupons -- to subsidize 20 percent of the cost of providing green energy products such as smart electrical meters, solar concentrators, and solar heaters in central and southern Taiwan. This would help generate billions of dollars-worth of consumption, as well as billions of dollars-worth of production value for small- and medium-sized enterprises and hundreds of thousands of job opportunities.
We believe this would definitely boost Taiwan's economy this year and become the most precious Lunar New Year present from the government to the public. (Feb. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor to seek wife's support in special municipality poll
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/19/10 15:10:59 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday that he plans to place an advertising billboard again to "seek his wife's support" and then communicate with the ruling Kuomintang on his bid to run in the Taichung special municipality mayoral election to be held later this year.
Hu disclosed his plan after addressing an audience of some 200 people to share his experience of governing the city at St. Anthony's College, one of the constituent colleges of Oxford University.

Hu did not reply to a question on whether his wife Shao Hsiao-ling has agreed to support his decision to run for the mayorship, but said he will spend money on an advertising billboard asking for his wife's consent to run for the post.
In 2005 when Hu sought re-election, he carried out a similar publicity stunt, a move that "proved successful."
According to Hu, his wife is very concerned about his health and does not want him to become overworked, so he needs to convince her on whether he should run.
Hu suffered a mild stroke in 2003 while visiting the United States.

He is the leading KMT candidate for the year-end Taichung special municipality election and because the five special municipality elections are deemed crucial for the KMT, he plans to communicate with the party headquarters after he returns to Taiwan Friday.
Asked about KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung's goal of taking at least three out of five in the special municipality elections, Hu said the KMT stands a good chance of winning.

Hu said that if he wins the Taichung race, he will strive to push for the development of the new municipality that will comprise the financially sound Taichung City and the debt-strapped Taichung County.

The mayor also touted what he described as the city's achievements in the aspects of culture, economy and social order and shared his experience in his efforts to make the city an international metropolitan area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan movies perform well at Berlin film festival
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/19/10 15:57:20 (By Lin Yu-li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With three Taiwanese films drawing attention at the Berlin International Film Festival this year, festival director Dieter Kosslick said Thursday that Taiwan's film industry has outstanding performance and he expressed hope that Taiwanese movies will enjoy a brighter future.

Kosslick made the remarks while meeting with Chen Chih-kuan, director of the Government Information Office's (GIO's) Department of Motion Pictures. He added that Taiwanese director Tsai Ming-liang, as well as Taiwan-born Hollywood director Lee Ang, have been award-winners in Berlin, and that three Taiwanese movies have been selected to be screened at the film festival.
The three movies -- "Monga, " "Au revoir Taipei" and "One Day" attracted almost full houses for every show at the film festival, which marks its 60th anniversary this year.

Kosslick, who has been the festival director for nine years, has invited many Taiwanese movies to attend the Berlin film festival, such as "The Wayward Cloud" by Tsai Ming-liang, "God Man Dog" by Chen Singing, "Soul of a Demon" by Chang Tso-chi, "Drifting Flowers" by Zero Chou, "Yang Yang" by Cheng Yu-chieh, and "Miao Miao" by Cheng Hsiao-tse.
Chen also explained to Kosslick about the Taiwanese government's support for international film companies seeking to shoot movies in Taiwan.

Chen said the government will not only help films shot in local scenic spots but will also subsidize 30 percent of the cost of hiring Taiwanese actors and production staff, to attract international film producers to shoot in Taiwan.

According to newly revised regulations announced by the GIO early this month, foreign producers are also eligible to have 25 percent of their production expenses and 15 percent of their transport, accommodation and insurance expenses in Taiwan subsidized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nationals to introduce Wang in Florida spring training
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 16:12:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Washington Nationals of the U.S. Major League Baseball (MLB) is scheduled to introduce Taiwanese pitcher Chien-ming Wang Saturday in Viera, Florida, the team's latest addition, according to the MLB Web site.
A news conference to announce Wang's signing is scheduled to take place at the Space Coast Stadium, the Nationals announced on its official Web site.

Octagon Baseball, the agency that represents Wang, confirmed Thursday that the former New York Yankee agreed to terms with Washington on a one-year, US$2 million contract with an incentive of up to US$3.2 million.
Nationals pitchers Brian Bruney, Tyler Clippard and Ron Villone, who all played with Wang in New York, are elated to learn about Wang being a teammate again, according to the MLB.
Wang will not be ready for opening day because he is recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder. He will not be able to pitch in the MLB until sometime in May.
However, his "new ex-teammates" are still confident in Wang, who is known for his hard sinker and who had a combined 38-13 record with a 3.67 ERA for the Yankees in 2006 and 2007.

"I saw him in 2007 at his best. He was contending for a Cy Young Award that year. He won 19 games in a couple of years. He is a great pitcher... and I am excited that we signed him, " Clippard was quoted as saying.

Bruney, a relief pitcher, said that anyone affiliated with the Nationals or a fan of the Nationals will be happy about Wang's performance, adding that "I would like to come in and get the win for him."
The 29-year-old's signing with Washington has been one of the biggest items of sports news in Taiwan during the nine-day Lunar New Year break.
Fans are looking forward to Wang duplicating his peak performance before injury.

Wang has been plagued by injury in the past two seasons, during which he only pitched in a combined 27 games. In 2008, he did not pitch after the All-Star break because of foot problems. This past season, Wang had a shoulder injury and missed the Yankees' World Series run in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese activists launch Internet revolution
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 16:28:34 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Chinese pro-democracy activist Wang Dan and 20 others have jointly launched a declaration pushing for an Internet revolution aimed at breaking down barriers set by the Beijing authorities to restrict online freedom of speech.
Wang told CNA Friday that he does not encourage the idea of hacking into government Web sites, but urged people to share technology to bypass restrictions imposed on Internet access in China.
He also said that he had yet to see any attack on his Facebook page on account of the declaration.

His Facebook page shows a list of supporting signatures from students, media workers, writers and citizens from Hong Kong, the United States, Singapore, the United Kingdom, France, Canada and Thailand.
Wang said he hopes to solicit more support for the revolution and to unite Chinese online users, who are estimated to exceed 400 million in 2010, according to the declaration.
The declaration, posted on Wang's Facebook page Feb. 12, urges people all over the world to help topple China's "Berlin Wall" that limits access to the Internet.
"Blogs, forums or chatrooms... everywhere can be a battlefield, " the declaration says. However, "no bloodshed or sacrifice is needed," it adds.
"The revolution will not succeed overnight, but with persistence over time, it will shake China's ruling basis, " according to the declaration.
The activists also blasted the Chinese government for handing down an 11-year prison term to Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo.
"Such a heavy sentence... is calling for a revolution, " the declaration reads.

"If the blockade of the Internet is stopped, freedom of the press is no longer restricted, and judicial independence is no longer tampered with, then a democratic China will be born naturally, " the declaration says.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: The shattered Toyota myth

TEXT.P: The world's largest automaker, Toyota, has recently been plagued by a string of complaints about the power steering and braking systems of various of their vehicle models. Denying the problems at first, the company eventually admitted to the deficiencies and recalled more than 8.5 million vehicles. Besides over US$2 billion in preliminary financial losses, the incident has cost Toyota immeasurable damage to its corporate reputation.

The way Toyota has dealt with this crisis has exposed a long-standing problem with Japanese corporate culture: desperation to save face and reluctance to admit errors. Such an attitude can instead cause problems to snowball, eventually doing serious harm to corporate images.

Many businesses in Taiwan also share the same problems. The state-owned petroleum refiner CPC Corp. and the privately run Formosa Petrochemical were recently discovered to have overcharged consumers billions of New Taiwan dollars for air pollution fees and a crude oil fund. The companies have so far not provided consumers with a clear explanation. It is necessary for the authorities to get to the bottom of the matter and investigate the responsibilities of relevant officials.

Toyota's performance in dealing with its latest crisis has completely shattered the Toyota myth. Nevertheless, a government that is slow in response can face even larger crises, because minor problems that are left unhandled can develop into bigger problems.
Both the business and government sectors should learn a lesson so as to prevent repeating the same mistakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's computer plaza expects new role
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 17:08:22 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: One of Taipei's major shopping malls that focuses mainly on computer and digital products is aiming to become a regular venue for major high-tech companies seeking to launch new products, a management chief said Friday.
"Last year, big companies such as Intel and Microsoft unveiled new products at the Guang Hua Digital Plaza, " Tairey Ker, head of an association promoting the plaza's development, told CNA.
"We also hope that more big companies can organize frequent activities at the plaza to promote their products, " he said.
The plaza, a six-story building, is well-known for its variety of electronic products, often at low prices.
Close to the plaza are dozens of other stores and markets selling computers, cameras, agricultural products and antiques.
The plaza reopened Thursday after closing for five days during the Lunar New Year holiday.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin took part in a re-opening ceremony featuring showgirls and a man dressed as the Chinese god of wealth giving away candies.
Hau called on consumers to help protect intellectual property rights by buying only genuine software.
More than 8 million people have visited the plaza since the plaza moved to its present site in 2008, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: What else besides a vigorous Year of the Tiger

TEXT.P: When it comes to this year, the Year of the Tiger, the third in a series of 12 Chinese zodiac signs, many people associate it with vigor, strength and power -- the major character traits of tiger -- and hope they will act speedily and energetically and enjoy booming business throughout the whole year.

It is common to make wishes at the beginning of the lunar year, so we hereby wish for world peace, a global economic recovery, peaceful and stable relations between Taiwan and China to create a win-win situation for both sides, and for everyone's dreams to come true.

However, in addition to wishing everyone is as vibrant as a tiger, we also hope everybody will act like a rabbit, which is considered to be soft and tender, because if people can make good use of the characteristics of the two animals, they will be able to grab business opportunities and know how to avoid risks at the same time.

The Tiger and the rabbit, the fourth animal in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese zodiac, were designed as a pair because they are compatible. The tiger represents bravery, while the rabbit represents prudence and calmness.

The compatibility theory of the tiger and rabbit can be applied to relations between Taiwan and China. For example, China's economy of scale is big but Taiwan's is small. While Taiwan's advantage lies in its soft power, China's is in its hard power. If the two sides can complement each other to boost economic development, it will create a multiplier effect on their economic growth and benefit the people of both sides.
Over the past year, Taiwan and China have launched direct flights across the Taiwan Strait and are negotiating on the signing of a proposed cross-strait comprehensive economic cooperation agreement.

Based on this foundation, if the two sides can enhance their relations further, they are expected to achieve greater economic performance and to contribute more to the world in environmental protection, energy conservation, public health and epidemic prevention, economic reciprocity, cultural exchanges and disaster relief efforts.

However, Taiwan and China should also solve their own problems. For instance, Taiwan should boost local investment, improve the unemployment situation and strengthen research and development to maintain a competitive edge, while China should cultivate its soft power to accelerate economic growth. (Feb. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to hold sale to raise campaign funds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 18:13:42 (Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a sale in March offering cultural and creative artifacts, agricultural products and local delicacies to raise campaign funds for the five special municipality mayoral elections to be held later this year.

A DPP campaign vehicle called "Kitty Hawk, " as well as lunch boxes referring to the name of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will be auctioned off during the event, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said Friday.

According to Tsai, March is a special month for Taiwanese democracy, as the Wild Lily student movement of 1990, the 1996 Taiwan missile crisis and the first direct election of the country's president in 1996, as well as Taiwan's first political power shift in 2000, all took place during the month.

The party plans to collaborate with non-government organizations (NGOs) to organize the market in Taipei City with the aim of promoting local culture and raising campaign money for the candidates for mayors and councilors in the five special municipalities, the spokesman said.
Kitty Hawk, which travels around the island during election campaigns, will be decorated as a stage and will be surrounded by tables when the market takes place, he went on.
The market place will be divided into several zones, including a cultural and creative area for selling dough figurines and other handicrafts, and an NGO zone for books, souvenirs and albums.

A Taiwanese agricultural products zone will feature farm produce from DPP-ruled cities and counties, including smoked duck from Yilan County, oranges from Yunlin County and tomatoes from Tainan County.
Meanwhile, a "Made in Taiwan" area will be dedicated to selling clothes, bags, bedding, towels and other locally made products.
There will be also an interactive game zone offering various arcade games, as well as a fund-raising area where the Hsiao Ing lunch boxes will be auctioned.

Kitty Hawk bicycles, which helped the DPP to score wins in a recent Yunlin County legislative by-election and in Jan. 9 legislative by-elections in Taichung, Taoyuan, and Taitung counties, will also be auctioned during the sale, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of DPP members might drop by half due to direct fee-levying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 19:05:08 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The number of members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is expected to sharply decrease by half to 150,000 after the party begins requiring its members to pay their own membership dues starting from this year, a party official said Friday.

The party's Central Executive Committee passed a regulation late last year that prohibits party members paying membership fees on behalf of others, a decision designed to address the problem of so-called "nominal" party members.

This creates a situation in which a DPP member pays membership dues for people who would otherwise not bother joining the party, in order to take control of their votes and thereby boost his or her influence in party polls.
The DPP membership fee is NT$300 per person per year, so the party is expected to lose total membership fee income of about NT$45 million per year.

Ker Chien-ming, head of the DPP's Finance Committee, said that the party is reviewing several options to make up for the losses, such as increasing the amount of donation to the party from members selected as government officials, or raising the portion of subsidies that candidates receive from the government to be paid to the party.

In the selection of DPP candidates running in government elections, party members' votes account for 30 percent of the total, with public opinion polls accounting for 70 percent. In the past, however, potential candidates had to seek support from the nominal party members, which is seen as a distortion of the party's primary selection, party officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- New Taipei City election

TEXT.P: For months, the public has been guessing who will represent the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the year-end municipality election in New Taipei City, the name of the soon-to-be upgraded Taipei County.
Reports have now emerged that Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu will be the KMT's standard bearer in a fight expected to be against heavyweights from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The reports also say the party will arrange another post for Chou Hsi-wei, the incumbent Taipei magistrate who has several times expressed his interest in continuing to head the upgraded county, even though his approval ratings have often been in the lowest ranks of past surveys.
The following are excerpts from leading local newspapers' coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
The KMT has decided to ask Chu to run in New Taipei City after Chu led all other aspirants in several opinion polls conducted by the party.

Chou, after coordinating with the top brass of the party, has agreed to go along with the party's mechanism of using opinion polls to decide the party's candidate. If the polls still show that Chu is ahead, he could be invited to serve in the Presidential Office or in the Cabinet, according to reports.

Meanwhile, because the KMT has had difficulty fielding a strong candidate in Kaohsiung municipality election, which is a stronghold of the DPP, the ruling party is not ruling out the possibility of asking Lai Feng-wei, deputy secretary-general to President Ma Ying-jeou and atwo-term Penghu magistrate (1997-2005), to represent the party in Kaohsiung, with Chou taking up the post left by Lai.
Economic Daily News:

The year-end municipality elections are widely seen as a forerunner of the presidential election scheduled for 2012, and New Taipei City is expected to be a major battlefield between the KMT and the DPP.
If Chu joins the race, it will not only mean an adjustment of the Cabinet lineup but will also cast uncertainty over the Cabinet's financial policy, which is currently helmed by Chu.
United Evening News:
Ma said Friday that the party's candidate for New Taipei City will be made clear after the Chinese New Year holiday, which ends on Sunday.

Premier Wu Den-yih was also tight-lipped on the reports Friday, saying only that Chu has performed excellently in whatever jobs he has been given, whether in the Legislative Yuan or as Taoyuan magistrate.

But the DPP's Su Tseng-chang, a former premier and a possible aspirant for New Taipei City mayor, said that if the KMT wants to give up on Chou, who is an incumbent and who has the intention of running, then it would be an admittance that Chou has not performed well.

If the KMT wants to get someone outside Taipei City and who has expressed no intention to run, everyone will know that the KMT has only election victory in mind without considering the interests of New Taipei City. (Feb. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT's nominee for New Taipei City mayoral race to be decided soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 19:35:15 (By Lin Jui-yi, Chiu Chun-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said Friday that the party's nominee for the year-end New Taipei City mayoral election will be decided in a couple of months.
The KMT will field the best candidate to run for the position, Ma told reporters during a trip to Hsinchu County, amid media reports that Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu might be nominated.

The main purpose of the trip was to campaign for Cheng Yung-tang, the KMT's candidate for the Feb. 27 legislative by-election in the county. Ma also visited Tienhou Temple in the city of Jhubei and Yungning Temple in Hsinfeng township, where he gave away red envelopes to visitors to wish them a happy Chinese New Year.
At Cheng's campaign rally, Ma told supporters that unity is essential if the blue camp is to win the by-election.
He urged voters to cast their votes for Cheng, whom he described as a down-to- earth, sincere man.
In response, Cheng's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opponent, Peng Shao- chin, said he will solidify the people to win the election with his policies and professionalism.
Also Friday, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen visited Taoyuan County to campaign for Huang Jen-chu, the party's candidate for the Taoyuan legislative by-election, which is also slated for Feb. 27.
Besides the polls in Hsinchu and Taoyuan counties, two other legislative by- elections will also be held that same day in the counties of Hualien and Chiayi.

Commenting on the by-elections, Tsai said the DPP candidates are fighting a hard battle because three out of the four regions have support bases that are predominantly made up of the pro-KMT "pan-blue camp" rather than the DPP's "pan- green camp."

Tsai said, however, that she has very high confidence in her party's candidates, because each of them is very hard-working and has performed excellently in terms of heeding public opinion and keeping track of current issues.

She also expressed strong protest at what she described as Ma's use of government resources to campaign for the KMT's candidates, referring to Ma's distribution of red envelopes to the public in his capacity as president and taking advantage of the opportunity to rally support for his party's candidates.

She noted that Ma has on many occasions insinuated that the DPP candidates have been involved in irregularities or money politics, and she urged Ma to stop using such smear tactics to try to manipulate the election outcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: Work on Suhua highway to start by year end: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 20:05:21 (By J.T. Liu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the construction of a new highway connecting Suao in the northeast with Hualien in the east will start by the end of this year.
Ma made the promise while stumping in Hualien County in his capacity as ruling Kuomintang (KMT) chairman for Wang Ting-sheng, the KMT's candidate in the Feb. 27 legislative by-election there.

He reiterated the government's resolution to improve transport infrastructure in the county and said the construction will begin later this year if the project passes an environmental impact assessment. The highway would combine upgrades of the existing Suao- Hualien highway, with new roads and tunnels circumventing its most dangerous sections.

On measures to increase the number of trains operating between Hualien County and other areas of the country to meet increasing demand during the Chinese New Year break, Ma gave the credit to Wang, saying that he had suggested increasing the number of trains serving the county not only during the New Year holiday but also on ordinary days.

Ma also said he had noticed the inadequacy of rail transport between Hualien and the rest of the island since 2008 and added that the problem was significantly eased after he directed Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi- kuo to come up with a solution.

Ma also noted that fruit and vegetables from Hualien County should be transported as quickly as possible to the consumer market in northern Taiwan, which is why Wang suggested that the government should provide special trains to transport fresh fruit and vegetables, an issue being studied by the MOTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank closely monitoring financial markets after Fed move
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/10 20:14:32 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan, Han ting-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank said Friday that the U.S. Federal Reserve's raising of discount rates to banks for direct loans the previous day does not represent a change of its stance on monetary policy but that the central bank will closely monitor changes to financial markets.

In a statement on the Fed's move, the central bank quoted the Fed as saying that the rate hike does not signal any change in the outlook for the economy or monetary policy and is not expected to lead to tighter financial conditions for households and businesses.
The dollar leapt and the euro hit a nine-month low Friday after the Fed move, which came after the U.S. stock market closed. European and Asian shares, as well as U.S. stock futures, also fell.
Local fund managers and analysts said the unexpected Fed move might have some impact on Taiwan's stock market when it resumes trading next Monday after the Lunar New Year holiday.
Jacky Lu, a fund manager of Allianz Global Investors Taiwan Technology Fund, said that the Fed's rate hike could lead other countries, including Taiwan, to follow suit.

However, with the Dow Jones index rising about 300 points and the Nasdaq advancing 90 points during the holiday period, the impact felt by Taiwanese shares should be smaller than that felt by U.S. shares, Lu said.

Dah Chang Securities manager Chang Shih-dun said that as the Fed's move came during the Chinese New Year holiday and the Taiwan share market's weighted index experienced a major correction prior to the holiday period, the impact from the Fed's move might be diluted when the Taiwanese bourse reopens.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: 2010 is five municipality election year

TEXT.P: Right after the legislative by-elections slated for Feb. 27, the year-end elections for the five special municipalities will become the main show that will last until the end of the year.
The five municipalities to be formed will push changes in the internal power structure within the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) as well as in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The future heads of the municipalities will naturally become heavyweights within their respective parties, but whether this increased number of top brass will be good for the parties' integration or will cause further factionalism has yet to be seen.
One thing is sure, however: The power struggle within the parties will be fiercer and the changes in Taiwan's political scene will become more unpredictable.
With each party fielding its best and brightest in the municipality elections, it also underscores the fact that there is a dearth of talent within both the major parties.
Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu is reported to be the KMT's candidate of choice in the New Taipei City election, where he will face a strong candidate from the DPP, possibly ex-Premier Su Tseng-chang.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu is the KMT's best bet among the five municipality elections, but if he agrees to run, he will lose an opportunity to serve a more suitable or more important job.
There will be new sights and sounds throughout 2010 due to the elections and with 2011 ushering in the beginning of the 2012 presidential election, we are worried that chaos might be unavoidable.
Taiwan has held elections every year in recent years, and chaos has persisted. We need to think deeply about this for the future of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 20, or the seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1437: James I, King of Scotland, is assassinated by a group of nobles seeking to place a rival on the throne. He was 42.
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher, writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1904: Alexei Kosygin, Soviet prime minister from 1964 to 1980, is born.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, opens in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun begins after Chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chooses to attack the French city of Verdun, despite his belief that France will defend it to the last man.
1919: Afghan head of state Habibullah Khan is assassinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire on striking workers, killing two and severely injuring seven.
1933: The U.S. House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law prohibiting the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and German's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding in the case of China.
1952: A meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1960: The third plenary session of the first ROC National Assembly opens in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours, becoming the first U.S. citizen to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, admiral of the U.S. Pacific Fleet during World War II, who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to General Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Major-General Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Uganda Army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote.
1972: Radio telephone service between Taipei and Madrid is inaugurated.
1974: A six-member South Korean Parliamentary Mission led by Oh Joon Suk arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: International Monetary Fund experts and representatives of the ROC Ministry of Finance begin their annual meeting with ROC Vice Minister Wang Shao- yu and the IMF Asia Department's consultant Andreas Abadjis as co-chairs.
1976: Gen. Wego Chiang, president of the Armed Forces University, and 30 foreign cadets studying war techniques in the ROC visit the offshore island of Kinmen.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
1988: Torrential flooding in Rio de Janeiro leaves 500 dead and 10,000 homeless.
1997: Washington refuses to recognize the World Trade Organization's authority in its dispute with the European Union over trade with Cuba.
2000: ROC@opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian stresses that only political party rotation can maintain Taiwan's administrative neutrality and achieve independence of the government's judicial branch.
2004: The ROC government announces that economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2003 was 5.17 percent. This raises the overall GDP growth of 2003 to 3.24 percent from 3.15 percent, the highest GDP of the "four Asian dragons" countries.
2006: The World Health Organization says 13 countries have reported H1N1 virus for the first time.
2007: U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney arrives in Tokyo for a visit of Japan.
2009: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton arrives in Beijing for a visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Administration team needs a breath of fresh air
DOC.DATELINE: 02/20/10 15:06:45 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih hinted at a moderate reshuffle to his Cabinet some time after the New Year, or in February. We are still waiting to see a change in the administration team.

Whether or not the Presidential Office and Executive Yuan can put together an effective "combat team" as the new Legislative Yuan session begins is critical to improving the government's image and effectiveness.

Wu took over the premiership amid chaos last August when Typhoon Morakot devastated southern Taiwan and the previous premier was forced to step down. The team he hastily cobbled together have not stood the test of time. We now have a Cabinet full of ministers so lacking in initiative. Many people do not even know the names of many ministers after months they have been in office.

Being a man of high intelligence, Wu must have noticed that there are problems within his cabinet. The heads of governmental departments should be out in front defending government policies and explaining them to the people. Instead, there are those in the Cabinet who still have no idea of their role.
As the Year of Tiger begins, having some new faces in the Cabinet will be the fastest way to bring a breath of fresh air into the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Urban regeneration needs fresh ideas

TEXT.P: It's been almost twelve years since Taiwan implemented its urban regeneration policies. In that time, the policies have done little to help regenerate cities or improve urban living environment. Instead, they have inadvertently caused real estate price inflation, especially in older, low-rise buildings in the cities. This is an unreasonable state of affairs that the government must work to resolve.

The Urban Redevelopment Act passed in 1998. In Taipei City, 322 projects have been submitted for approval, but only 76 have been approved. In Taipei County, only 96 projects out of 330 submitted have been approved. Each approved project took an average of 7.7 years to complete.
Why has the Urban Redevelopment Act been so ineffective?

The first hurdle is the difficulty in reaching consensus among property owners. According to the act, the minimum area required for urban regeneration is 1,000 square meters. Since property is owned in such small parcels in the cities, dozens of owners might have to give their approval for a redevelopment project to go ahead.

Secondly, there are frequently conflicts of interest between the property owners and the developers. Owners usually expect to get larger and better units after the project, putting them against developers who want to enjoy higher profits.
Thirdly, the urban renewal incentives do not meet the existing owners' needs. Under current urban redevelopment laws, the owners might actually get smaller housing units after the conversion.

Fourth, the appraisal process is unfair to property owners. Under current regulation, the developers gets to decide the appraisal date, which is used for determining the value of the property. Developers also have the right to select which property appraisers to use. With housing prices changing so fast and the review period for the project so long, this is often a cause of dispute between owners and developers.

To resolve these issues, it is necessary to revise the Urban Redevelopment Act and related regulation. The government should raise the incentive for land owners, correct the bias towards developers, and most importantly, raise the legal floor area ratio. This will increase the amount of housing available and drive down the overheated real estate market.
(By Fanny Liu)/ao

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Year-end municipality election

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu seems set to represent the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the upcoming New Taipei City mayoral elections. "New Taipei City" will be the new name of Taipei County when it is upgraded to a special municipality directly under the central government.

In his capacity as KMT Chairman, President Ma Ying-jeou promised Friday that "the KMT will nominate the best candidate and will not let the public wait for too long." Ma said he will decide the party's nominee for New Taipei City a month or two after the Lunar New Year holidays.

The New Taipei City is the key battlefield for the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the five special municipality elections. Both parties are expected to field their strongest candidates because the outcome of the elections is seen as a bellwether to the 2012 presidential election.
The following are excerpts from the coverage of leading local newspapers on this issue:
China Times:
Chu, who is currently vacationing overseas, is expected to announce his intention to run in the New Taipei City elections after he resumes work Monday.

A source said that after the KMT's lackluster performance in the Dec. 5 local elections, Chu told President Ma Ying-jeou that he had no intention to run in the municipal elections. However, since that time the two have met and talked on numerous occasions. "Although they never touched upon the topic of the election, " said the source, "Chu has probably read between the lines."
The source said that Chu has not entirely ruled out the possibility of running. "He knows well that if Ma asks him to run, he has no room for rejection."

Chu has been leading in the opinion polls conducted by the KMT. However, since Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei is seeking re-election, Chu cannot announce his intentions until Ma has paved the way by negotiating with Chou.

The source said Chou has been sporting and unselfish in agreeing to go along with the party's decision to use polls to decide the candidate, thus avoiding a primary. Both Chou and Chu know that the KMT can only prevail in the five municipalities elections through solidarity. (Feb. 20, 2010)
United Daily News:
Ex-premier Su Tseng-chang, widely seen as the likely DPP candidate in the 2012 presidential elections, was asked Friday if he will join the upcoming municipal elections.
Su said that he is still "in the stage of listening to the public will, " and that it is not yet time to decide "whether and where to run."
In an interview with a local TV station, Su thanked his supporters for encouraging him to run, describing himself as a "public property."
"When the country and our society needs me, I will devote myself to the task," said Su, adding "I have no right to choose if I want to run."
Su refrained from saying whether he will run for the 2012 presidential election or join the municipal elections first, saying that he will listen to the public for their opinions first.

But he added that most within the DPP believe in taking on one challenge at a time, and that the party should focus on the Feb. 27 legislative by-elections and then the year-end municipality elections before thinking about the presidential election in 2012. (Feb. 19, 2012)

Liberty Times: Former Premier and two-term Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng- chang said if the KMT nominates Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu for the New Taipei City mayoral election, then it is "giving up" on the incumbent Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei.
This is tantamount, argues Su, to admitting that Chou is doing so badly that the KMT has to find another candidate, even someone from outside Taipei County and has no intention of joining the race.
Su said the decision is driven purely by political consideration rather than in the interest of Taipei County. enditem/ao

DOC.HEADLINE: Water Resources Agency under investigation for Siaolin tragedy

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Agency (WRA) is under investigation for possible improprieties in a number of its projects, including one that has been blamed for the landslides that buried a village in Kaohsiung County during Typhoon Morakot, a source in the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors' Office said Saturday.
Almost 500 Siaolin residents were buried by massive mudslides triggered by the typhoon, which dumped more than 1,800 millimeters of rain on the area over three days.

Some survivors have suggested that explosions set off to excavate a tunnel for the Tsengwen Reservoir water diversion project weakened the stability of the terrain around the village, contributing to the severity of the mudslides.

However, a report released on Feb. 1 by the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) ruled out that possibility and instead attributed the tragedy to the massive rainfall, a conclusion survivors have been unwilling to accept.
Investigators have now decided to look into the process of how public water resource projects have been commissioned to private contractors over the past decade, prosecutors said.

Chen Shen-hsien, the former director-general of the WRA, resigned last September amid reports accusing him of having improper relations with contractors, especially in his role as the decision- maker of the Tsengwen Reservoir water diversion project, allegations he has denied.

Investigators have asked the WRA, PCC, and city and county governments for documents related to water project tenders going back as far as 10 years, including for projects worth NT$360 billion tendered out over the six years that Chen led the agency.

According to the source in the Special Investigation Division, investigators may summon ranking WRA officials and former Director- General Chen for questioning after the Lunar New Year holiday. (by Lin Chang-shun and Lillian Lin)/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Roses and thorns with cross-strait relations

TEXT.P: This is the first Chinese New Year after direct cross-Strait flight links were re-established and Chinese tourists are allowed to visit Taiwan. A few days before the New Year, the rumor was that the number of Chinese tourists fell short of expectations. Some politicians took the opportunity to complain that expectations raised by lifting the ban on Chinese tourists have not been fulfilled.

A few days later, the Tourism Bureau unexpectedly warned travel agencies not to book more Chinese tour groups unless they have confirmed hotel and bus reservations already. That means there were actually so many Chinese traveling to Taiwan that they were stretching capacity.

The same politicians who were mocking Beijing for not delivering enough Chinese tourists to Taiwan are now complaining that Beijing is seeking to bribe the people of Taiwan with tourism dollars. It seems some people will never be happy on this issue one way or another.

Even worse, it looks like most people assume that the number of Chinese tourist in Taiwan is solely dependent on political factors. But instead of looking to Beijing to bring more Chinese tourists, Taiwan should put more effort into raising the quality of the travel industry so that Chinese tourists would actually want to visit Taiwan.

Whether it's cross-Strait tourism, signing the economic coperation framework agreement (ECFA) or dealing with Chinese buyers, Taiwan should be working hard to provide competitive deals to the Chinese. Relying on Beijing to take care of us in return for political gains will only lead to horrible outcomes.

We can use roses as a metaphor for cross-strait relations. If we count on political maneuvers in dealing with the Chinese, we will inevitably be hurt by the thorns. If we improve our own competitiveness and deal with the Chinese on the basis of our talents, then cross-strait relation would smell like roses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold weather brings Penghu islanders good seaweed harvest
DOC.DATELINE: Penghu, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 17:34:16 (by Kao Mao-hsiung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Cold fronts and big waves have kept fishermen on the Penghu archipelago ashore during the Lunar New Year holiday, but the time off has not been a complete loss, as some fishermen in the island county have had strong harvests of seaweed.
According to islanders, seaweed grows bigger and better in cold weather.

Penghu laver, an edible seaweed, is quite popular and sold at relatively high prices in Taiwan's retail markets, because it is harvested from the unpolluted waters surrounding the islands, the county's fishermen said.

However, making money from laver may not be as easy as many people think because the seaweed requires a number of processing steps, from cleaning and drying to packaging, before it can be brought to market, the fishermen said.
Aside from shipping the seaweed to Taiwan, the fishermen have also done a brisk business at home on Kupo Island in the northern part of the archipelago.

The island, which is abundant in the high-value laver, is open to the public during the Lunar New Year holiday, and over the past few days, hundreds of islanders and vacationers have made trips to Kupo to pick the prized seaweed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Employment prospects in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: 02/20/10 17:59:29 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou wished the people of Taiwan a prosperous Year of the Tiger in his Lunar New Year greeting. In particular, he said he hoped that "everyone in the country has a job" in the coming year.

Fighting unemployment is obviously the government's top priority this year. 632,000 people in this country are officially unemployed. An additional 694,000 are jobless but not actively seeking employment. There are fewer and fewer employment opportunities. What's more, many of those without jobs do not have the right skills for today's employment marketplace.

Using 2007 numbers as a baseline, the number of jobs in Taiwan actually increased by 3,000 by the end of 2009. However, this includes a net growth of 53,000 workers in the administrative services sector, thanks in part to the government's employment incentive program.
However, in that time, the manufacturing sector lost 87,000 jobs, the construction sector lost 70,000 jobs and the wholesale and retail sector lost 30,000 jobs.

The number of people working for the hospitality and food service sector increased by 38,000 from 2007 to 2009. The medical and healthcare sector grew by 30,000 workers. The financial insurance sector grew by 19,000 workers.

After the global financial crisis, it seems different industries now have different personnel needs. The fact that Taiwan's wholesale and retail sector lost ground both on sales and the number of workers signals that the sector has come to a turning point.

Uni-President, the conglomerate that operates 7-11 stores in Taiwan, changed its strategy from opening as many new stores as possible to trying to maximize the value of each individual store. This is a part of the general trend in Taiwan's wholesale and retail sector to focus on adding value rather than expansion.
Meanwhile, the productivity of the electronic parts and components manufacturing sector has been growing after the global financial storm even as the sector shed workers.

It looks like Taiwan needs a bold and creative employment policy going forward in order to create new jobs in this new economy. The medical, health care and social services sector is probably the best place for the government to start creating jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scale of national pension fund could reach NT$100 billion in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 18:08:38 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The National Pension Fund could reach NT$100 billion by 2011 according to the Ministry of the Interior.
The ministry said Saturday that as of the end of the 2009, the fund reached NT$65.8 billion and its scale is expected to expand to NT$87.6 billion by the end of this year.

The ministry said that since the national pension system was put into effect on Oct. 1, 2008, the system covered an estimated 4.1 million people, including the jobless, street vendors, housekeepers, naturalized foreign spouses and students older than 25. 1.03 million people have claimed a total of NT$ 40.1 billion from the fund thus far, the ministry added.

The ministry said about 60 percent of those eligible for the National Pension Fund pays their premiums. This is on par with Japan and South Korea. The ministry said they are hoping to convince more people to join the system in order to consolidate Taiwan's social security network.

The national pension system is open to anyone with household registration in Taiwan aged between 25 and 65 who is not covered by other social welfare insurance such as farmer's health insurance, government employee insurance, insurance for military personnel and labor insurance.
Those insured must pay 60 percent of the premium, while the government will pay the remaining 40 percent.
Under the regulations, an insured person who pays a monthly premium of NT$674 for 40 years will receive NT$8,986 every month from the age of 65 -- the standard retirement threshold -- until death.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalist promotes solar cooking, urban gardens
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 18:31:18 (By Sherry Tang and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: To Peter Morehead, cooking a meal does not require the use of natural gas. Sunlight is good enough.
Morehead, who first came to Taiwan in 1990 from Wisconsin as an exchange student, has been teaching local residents how to cook with what he calls a "solar cooker."

The solar cooker can be as simple as a small paper box covered in aluminum foil. One can put a black pot in the middle of the box, and the sunlight's reflection off the aluminum foil will create enough heat to cook the food in the pot.
"People should make good use of energy," he told the Central News Agency during a recent interview. "Never waste energy."

On cloudy days, Morehead uses what he calls his "rocket broiler" instead. Made of iron cans, the broiler relies on the burning of small branches and twigs that can generate high heat in a short time, and the contraption does not release smoke if handled properly.
In addition to passing on tips on how to use natural energy, Morehead has also been promoting the concept of being an urban farmer.
On Earth Day in 2008, he taught people how to grow corn or pumpkins in the square outside the National Taiwan Museum in Taipei.
Growing edible plants can both beautify the environment and reduce pollution caused by the transporting of food, according to the environmentalist.
Morehead, a space-planning expert, believes that vegetable gardens can be set up between city buildings or on rooftops in Taiwan's densely populated urban areas.
"There must be space that can be used, " he said in fluent Mandarin.

Morehead began raising the public's awareness on conserving energy in 2000. Five years ago, he and his wife established a dedicated studio to educate the public about leading an environmentally friendly life.
They named the studio "Earth Passengers" to convey the idea that Earth is like a spacecraft circling the sun, with humans mere travelers along for the ride.
"Humans are not the controllers of the Earth. Instead, they should live in harmony with other living creatures, " Morehead said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online game developers eye China and overseas markets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 18:39:34 (By Lawrence Chiu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With the domestic online game market becoming increasingly saturated, Taiwan's online game companies are starting to focus on expanding to China and seeking more overseas licensing deals in 2010.

Chinese Gamer International, a leading online game developer and the first game developer listed on the stock market in Taiwan, will launch it's popular "Chinese Hero Online" game in China in Q2. The company expects the release to provide a lift to its 2010 revenues.

In 2009, China Gamer International reached a US$13 million licensing deal for "Chinese Hero Online" in China. The company will also get a share of local sales revenue every month after the game is launched.
The game, first launched last August in Taiwan, is so popular that a record- breaking 200,000 Taiwanese players were online at the same time on Feb. 1.
With the Chinese New Year and schools' winter vacation falling in February, institutional investors expect Chinese Gamer International to set a record- breaking monthly revenue for February.
The company's revenue in January was NT$177 million, up 18 percent from the previous month, it announced last Wednesday.
The company set a record revenue in 2009 with NT$2.1 billion.
Meanwhile, other online game companies are also eying overseas markets.

UserJoy Technology is expected to launch its own hit game "Kingdom Hero 2 Online" in China this year after getting a US$5 million licensing deal last year. The company also enjoys a bright outlook because its hit games such as "Angel Love 2" and "Heroes: - Scions of Phoenix" are also expected to reach more licensing deals in China and South East Asia this year.
Taiwan's online game developers, however, will not easily give up their domestic market. This year, they will launch at least five new games for local gamers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Application fee for ePassports to increase next month
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 18:45:27 (By Sinyao Shih and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The application fee for the ePassports will be increased to NT$1,600 starting March 1, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
It currently costs NT$1,200 to apply for an ePassport. It was scheduled to be increased by NT$400 to reflect higher production costs on Jan. 1.
But due to the rising number of applications at the end of last year, the legislature passed a resolution to delay the implementation until March 1.
The passport, which contains a contactless chip and antenna embedded in its back cover with the bearer's biographical data and facial image stored on the chip, was first issued on Dec. 29, 2008.

According to the ministry, the number of applications for the ePassport has steadily increased since they began to issue the document. Combined with the new rule requiring people to apply for passports in person, the new ePassports have effectively deterred the use for forged passports and will hopefully help Taiwan's efforts to gain visa-waiver status from the U.S. and the European Union.
"The ministry is moving toward the goal of applying in person, " one official said.
But to mitigate the inconvenience, the ministry will start a dual system of applying in person and by commission.

Starting May 3, applicants can commission travel agencies to apply for passports, or go to 29 designated locations, including the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, the MOFA's central, southern and eastern Taiwan offices, as well as the household registration offices designated by the 25 cities and counties.
The ministry said that after the legislature passes an amendment to the Statute for Passport, the ministry will require application in person to 369 household registration offices around the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parties gear up for final push to Feb. 27 legislative by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 18:59:02 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling and main opposition parties wasted no time during the nine-day Lunar New Year break to make a final push for the four legislative by-elections that will take place next Saturday, races that both parties see as must-wins.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), spent his holiday campaigning for KMT candidates in the four electoral districts at stake, desperate to reverse a slump that has seen the party lose all three legislative by-elections on Jan. 9 and perform poorly in county and city government elections on Dec. 5, 2009.

The latest polls suggest it will not be an easy task because opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidates are running strong in the four electoral districts, in Taoyuan, Chiayi, Hsinchu, and Hualien counties, and the KMT is split in two of them.

Yet DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who was also on the campaign trail in the four areas during the New Year's break, said the elections will be "a tough battle" because three of the four districts have been traditional KMT strongholds.
But the DPP has momentum on its side, fueled by the government's low approval ratings.

The DPP won the three seats contested in Taoyuan, Taichung and Taitung counties last month to boost its seat total in the Legislative Yuan to 30, more than the one-quarter of the body's 113 seats needed to be able to launch motions to amend the Constitution or recall the president.

Another sweep Feb. 27 would further boost its status after it suffered humiliating defeats in the 2008 legislative and presidential elections and would put it in prime position for the five special municipality elections to be contested late this year.

Ma and his right-hand man King Pu-tsung, the KMT's secretary-general, have stressed in rallies how critical the by-elections are for the party. Regardless of the outcome, the KMT will still control a healthy majority in the legislature, but it clearly wants some electoral success to boost its flagging confidence ahead of the end-of-year mayoral races.

They have also stressed the importance of "consolidation, " especially needed in Taoyuan and Hualien counties, where several KMT members have entered the contests as independent candidates and could draw support away from the party's official nominees.
In Taoyuan, KMT candidate Apollo Chen faces DPP rival Huan Jen-shu and two former KMT memebers, Lin Siang-mei and Wu Yu-tung.
In Hualien, KMT candidate Wang Ting-sheng not only has to face the DPP's Hsiao Bi-khim, who has no connection to the eastern county but has made great strides since the campaign began.
He also must deal with the challenge from Shih Sheng-lan, a former KMT member entered as an independent who has the backing of incumbent Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.

Fu, also a former KMT member, won the race for county magistrate in December with 56 percent of the vote as an independent against two other candidates, one of them the KMTzs official nominee. In the Chiayi County race, DPP candidate Chen Ming-wen enjoys an advantage as the southern county's previous magistrate and its traditional status as a DPP stronghold. But the KMT said last week its candidate Lin Teh-jui has pulled even.

According to the National Cheng Chi University's Swarchy market prediction Web site (http: //nccu.swarchy.org) , which uses a stock market mechanism for members to predict results of future events and has enjoyed relative success in predicting Taiwan's election outcomes in the past, the DPP is ahead in three of four races being contested.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma visits Hualien-area welfare organizations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 19:17:09 (By Andrew Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited more underprivileged children and teenagers in Hualien, eastern Taiwan Saturday.

Following his visit of the Zenlight Nursery School Friday, Ma visited the New Dawn Development Center for the disabled, the Mennonite Foundation and the Mennonite Good Shepherd Center to learn more about the social welfare organizations in Hualien and the problems they face.

Children at the New Dawn Development Center performed "Amazing Grace" to welcome the president. Ma gave the children red envelopes to wish them a happy Chinese New Year. The president then put on an apron and baked some cookies, to the delight of the children at the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taiwan Internationl Festival opens with Aboriginal dance
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 20:25:27 (by Lee Shien-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan International Festival kicked off this Saturday evening on the plaza in front of Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center in Taipei. The festival began with a performance by the Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe.

The month-long festival will feature theater groups from Germany, Denmark, and Colombia as well as dance troupes from Spain, France and Taiwan. Renowned musician Tan Dun, who composed the music for the Oscar-winning movie "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, " is participating.
The festival was originally slated to open with an outdoor presentation of Sirena a la Plancha by the Sol Pico Dance company from Spain. However, that performance was canceled due to rainy weather.
Entering its second year, the annual cultural festival is co-sponsored by the cultural center and several leading local businesses.

Of the 15 performances making their premier performance at the festival, "1433 - The Grand Voyages" is attracting the most attention. It is a Taiwanese/American joint production led by American theater director Robert Wilson and U Theater music director Huang Chih-chun working with the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese visitors expected to surpass Japanese in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 20:29:31 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Although the Japanese were the largest group of foreign visitors to Taiwan last year, they may soon be overtaken by Chinese nationals in 2010. The Tourism Bureau set the target of 1.2 million visits from Chinese nationals this year, higher than the target of 1.1 million for Japanese visitors.

In 2009, the Japanese remains the largest group of foreign visitors. But the number of Japanese visitors fell 7.92 percent in 2009 to 1,000,661. Japanese tourist numbers, however, were down by only 1.76 percent.
Chinese nationals were the second largest group of foreign visitors to Taiwan, with 972,123 arrivals, including 606,174 traveling as tourists.
During the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday, more than 40,000 Chinese tourists (about 1,500 tour groups) were scheduled to visit Taiwan, the bureau said last week.

The bureau is also expecting another record number of foreign nationals visiting TaiwanVwith a target of 4.8 million in 2010, up 9 percent frome the 4.4 million foreign visitors last year. 2009 was in itself a record high that surpassed the government target of 4.1 million by 14.3 percent.
The bureau said it will keep focusing on bringing more Japanese visitors to Taiwan this year. It will also try to promote Taiwan as a travel destination to some emerging markets in Southeast Asia.
To attract more Japanese visitors, the bureau worked with Japanese TV station MBS to produce programs featuring Taiwan's tasty food as well as cycling trips in eastern Taiwan.
