DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma visits Hualien-area welfare organizations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 19:17:09 (By Andrew Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited more underprivileged children and teenagers in Hualien, eastern Taiwan Saturday.

Following his visit of the Zenlight Nursery School Friday, Ma visited the New Dawn Development Center for the disabled, the Mennonite Foundation and the Mennonite Good Shepherd Center to learn more about the social welfare organizations in Hualien and the problems they face.

Children at the New Dawn Development Center performed "Amazing Grace" to welcome the president. Ma gave the children red envelopes to wish them a happy Chinese New Year. The president then put on an apron and baked some cookies, to the delight of the children at the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taiwan Internationl Festival opens with Aboriginal dance
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 20:25:27 (by Lee Shien-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan International Festival kicked off this Saturday evening on the plaza in front of Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center in Taipei. The festival began with a performance by the Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe.

The month-long festival will feature theater groups from Germany, Denmark, and Colombia as well as dance troupes from Spain, France and Taiwan. Renowned musician Tan Dun, who composed the music for the Oscar-winning movie "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, " is participating.
The festival was originally slated to open with an outdoor presentation of Sirena a la Plancha by the Sol Pico Dance company from Spain. However, that performance was canceled due to rainy weather.
Entering its second year, the annual cultural festival is co-sponsored by the cultural center and several leading local businesses.

Of the 15 performances making their premier performance at the festival, "1433 - The Grand Voyages" is attracting the most attention. It is a Taiwanese/American joint production led by American theater director Robert Wilson and U Theater music director Huang Chih-chun working with the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese visitors expected to surpass Japanese in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/10 20:29:31 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Although the Japanese were the largest group of foreign visitors to Taiwan last year, they may soon be overtaken by Chinese nationals in 2010. The Tourism Bureau set the target of 1.2 million visits from Chinese nationals this year, higher than the target of 1.1 million for Japanese visitors.

In 2009, the Japanese remains the largest group of foreign visitors. But the number of Japanese visitors fell 7.92 percent in 2009 to 1,000,661. Japanese tourist numbers, however, were down by only 1.76 percent.
Chinese nationals were the second largest group of foreign visitors to Taiwan, with 972,123 arrivals, including 606,174 traveling as tourists.
During the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday, more than 40,000 Chinese tourists (about 1,500 tour groups) were scheduled to visit Taiwan, the bureau said last week.

The bureau is also expecting another record number of foreign nationals visiting TaiwanVwith a target of 4.8 million in 2010, up 9 percent frome the 4.4 million foreign visitors last year. 2009 was in itself a record high that surpassed the government target of 4.1 million by 14.3 percent.
The bureau said it will keep focusing on bringing more Japanese visitors to Taiwan this year. It will also try to promote Taiwan as a travel destination to some emerging markets in Southeast Asia.
To attract more Japanese visitors, the bureau worked with Japanese TV station MBS to produce programs featuring Taiwan's tasty food as well as cycling trips in eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 21, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: General Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1957: Israel defies a U.N. resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Forty-six manufacturers attend the second European Industrial Machinery Exhibition in Taipei.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a week- long tour.
1974: The Buenos Aires University Club rugby team, champions of South America, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corporation begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corporation.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.
1990: Salvadorean President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1992: Mainland China welcomes foreigners back to its stock market in Shanghai for the first time since 1949.
1998: The U.S. government advises its citizens to leave Iraq, in anticipation of new airstrikes.
2000: ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei arrives in Singapore to attend a five-day Asian Aerospace Show.
2000: Liberian President Charles Ghankay Taylor arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwanese movie wins best Asian film award at Berlin festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 14:39:01 (By Johnson Sun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: "Au Revoir, Taipei, " a romantic comedy featuring Taipei City, won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Prize at the Berlin International Film Festival 2010 Saturday, beating 11 other Asian entries.
The love story, which takes place over the course of one evening in Taipei City, was produced by German director/producer Wim Wenders and directed by budding Asian-American director Arvin Chen.
Chen is no stranger to the Berlin film festival. He won a Silver Berlin Bear- Jury Grand Prix for Short Films for a short he made titled "May" in 2007.

"Au Revoir, Taipei," stars talented actors including singer Amber Kuo, Jack Yao, Joseph Chang and Lawrence Ko, and is a laughter-provoking film that screened to a full audience and won loud applause in Berlin.
Yao received the NETPAC prize on behalf of the film. "Je t'aime Berlin! " he exclaimed on the podium, his use of French accentuating the movie's title.

Frank J.K. Chen, director of the Motion Picture Affairs Department under the Cabinet-level Government Information Office (GIO) , conveyed the government's congratulations to Arvin Chen Saturday over the honor.
By winning the top award of NETPAC, which is an alliance of the Berlin film festival organizers, "Au Revoir, Taipei" now has the opportunity of winning a prize of NT$1.5 million awarded by the GIO.
Another Taiwanese movie, "Monga, " which has enjoyed huge box office success in Taiwan, was also screened at the festival, but did not win a prize.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin welcomed the victory of "Au Revoir, Taipei, " which was made thanks to great support from the city government during shooting.
"`Au Revoir, Taipei' is another example of the city government's cooperation with film producers to sell Taipei," Hau said.
Various Taipei features, including the MRT system, the night markets and the round-the-clock Eslite bookstore, all have prominence in the film.
The city government cooperated with 15 countries in the production of 25 motion pictures in 2009 alone, Hau noted.
The Berlin International Film Festival 2010 was scheduled to close Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-toll collection saved NT$600 million last year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 15:52:44 (By Wang Su-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: More than NT$600 million (US$18.75 million) was saved in energy conservation and carbon emissions reductions in 2009 thanks to the use of an electronic toll collection (ETC) system on the country's freeways, the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau announced Sunday.

Under the existing manual toll collection system, vehicles are required to stop or slow down to pay tolls before speeding up again, which results in a waste of time and energy, as well as an increase in vehicle operating expenses, the bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said.

The bureau plans to implement a total ETC system on freeways by the end of 2012, as the system allows motorists to pay toll charges electronically without having to slow down to pass through a toll booth, therefore helping to save energy.

According to tallies compiled by the bureau, the number of small cars and large vehicles using the ETC system reached 175,674,173 last year, which means around 3.294 million hours were saved for motorists, along with around 3.45 million liters in fuel consumption.
The use of the system also contributed to a cut of 8,525 metric tons in carbon dioxide emissions last year, according to the tallies.

As the biggest source of carbon emissions in Taiwan is the road transport sector, the higher the number of ETC users, the higher the volume of emission reductions can be expected, according to the bureau.
The system can also save the paper and printing costs of toll ticket books. Last year, about NT$23.79 million was saved in this area.

In addition, the system also contributed to total time savings worth NT$487.36 million, savings of NT$86.84 million in fuel consumption and NT$8.98 million in carbon emission reductions, according to the bureau.

However, the ETC usage rate is still low in Taiwan at only 36 percent of freeway users since the system was introduced four years ago, because users have to buy on-board ETC units at their own expense. At present, the price for the installation of an ETC unit is NT$1,199.

To reach the government's goal of boosting the usage rate to 65 percent by 2012, Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co., which was commissioned to set up the ETC service, suggested that the government should offer a 20 percent toll discount for ETC users.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Chinese president plays `main street economy' card

TEXT.P: Chinese leaders usually do not spend the Lunar New Year holiday at home and traditionally travel elsewhere in the country to celebrate the festival along with local communist party cadres and the public.
The selection of the places where top Chinese leaders spend their New Year holiday tend to carry policy implications or epitomize China's new work direction.

Judging from Chinese President Hu Jintao's choice of three Fujian Province cities adjacent to Taiwan -- Lungyen, Zhangzhou and Xiamen, the Beijing government's intention to further promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations during the Year of the Tiger is unmistakably evident.

Most noteworthy is that Hu said while visiting a special park designated for Taiwanese agricultural investors to operate farms or ranches that the Chinese government will do "whatever will benefit the vast majority of the Taiwanese people" and will never back off from this promise.

Hu further said China will keep in mind the interests of the people of Taiwan, particularly farmers, in its negotiations with Taiwan on the proposed cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Hu's remarks were clearly targeting ordinary Taiwanese people. To show his concern for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, Hu also inspected a wharf in Xiamen where some Taiwanese people embarked on direct sailings to Taiwan via Kinmen or Matzu. He also attended a fireworks display co-sponsored for the first time by Kinmen and Xiamen.
The moves were aimed at getting into closer contact with grassroots Taiwanese people, and Hu's main appeal focused on "economy and livelihood."
Hu's goal is actually in compliance with Taiwan's current emphasis on "main street economy, " with people's feelings the main criteria for measuring the country's economic health.
Against this backdrop, we suggest that the two sides sincerely discuss the substantive content of "things that will benefit a vast majority of Taiwanese people," as mentioned by Hu.

Such things should not just be those already in place, such as helping China- based Taiwanese businesses or the procurement of Taiwanese products, but should also include support for Taiwan's bid to joint the "ASEAN Plus One" and the further liberalization of Chinese investment in Taiwan.

If talks on these issues can get started through concerted efforts by the governments on both sides of the strait, China's goodwill in taking care of Taiwan's "main street economy" will really impress ordinary Taiwanese people and contribute to Taiwan's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A holiday too long
DOC.DATELINE: 02/21/10 16:20:54 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The nine-day Chinese New Year holiday 2010 has finally ended. The record-length New Year break, spoiled by cold and wet weather, was not appreciated by many in Taiwan, who have complained that it was a waste of time and boring, because they did not want to go out in the inclement weather.
This reminds us that holidays are good and welcome, but it is not always true that "the longer, the better."

Holidays are costly. Both society and the people have to bear the full cost of them. The government should therefore elaborate on the cost and cost efficiency, as well as the potential risks of a holiday, before determining how long it should be.
The main cost of a holiday is the decline in work and production. At the same time, the marginal benefit of a holiday break might decrease progressively with the length of it.

A holiday that is too long might incur risks. For example, a company might lose an order because it has not maintained contact with the buyer. Long holidays provide the people with the possibility of planning trips overseas, but overseas trips steal economic advantages away from the local tourism sector.
Long holidays of course have their merit. They help relieve the pressure on the government in terms of transport and traffic, as motorists have more travel schedule options.
Longer holidays also provide officials with longer periods to ponder their policy development.

A holiday is not just a day or several days off. It involves various costs and benefits. Thus, we urge the administration to make a wide-ranging study and survey all sectors involved before deciding on the length of a holiday. (Feb. 21, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Taiwanese artist dreams beyond Chinese opera
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 16:24:58 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: From playing a young man in traditional Chinese operas to portraying a clown in a modern drama to acting the role of a teenager in a TV series, young Taiwanese actor Sheng Zhian's performances have amazed both local audiences and international directors.

Sheng Zhian, a guest actor with the Guoguang Opera Company, has been active in the traditional art and theatrical fields for several years. He has been in the spotlight recently due to his unique vocal styling, innovative acting skills and compelling stage presence.
Local drama critics have labeled him the "successor of Wu Hsing-kuo, " an actor who started his career in Chinese opera but later extended his field to modern drama and became a movie star.

Sheng also received more than 20 years of traditional Peking opera training before branching out into other types of performance. He graduated from the Guoguang Art School and the National Taiwan University of Arts, and also became a pupil of Peking opera master Pei Yan Ling.
"Last year, I went back to the Guoguang Opera Company as a guest actor, and also participated in a TV series, as well as trying my hand at appearing in commercials," he told CNA.
In the new year, he will make a cameo appearance in Guoguang's new opera titled "Meng Xiaodong, " the story of an actress who specialized in playing male roles in Chinese opera.
"I started to receive serious training at a Chinese traditional opera school when I was 10 years old. There is no doubt that it is my favorite thing to do," he said.

While he used to focus only on this traditional art, he has since changed his view. "I have studied both Western and Chinese performing styles, such as the theories of Chinese opera maestro Mei Lanfan, German theatrical director Bertolt Brecht, and also Russian director Constantin Stanislavski. Those have enriched my performances greatly," he said.

Sheng now views performing as a "profound calling" that should not be limited to any specific field. "My concept of performance has greatly broadened; I can pursue many other aspects of performing without betraying my passion for Chinese opera," he said.

He revealed that his plan for this year will be to participate in as many different experiences as possible. He expects to complete the script of a new drama by the middle of the year and to then set up a new theatrical group to perform it. He is also contemplating a film career.
"After so many years, I feel that we need an actor-centered theatrical group to provide stimulation and opportunities for good actors," he went on. CNA staff reporter/J

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO denies Cabinet reshuffle report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 17:00:52 (By Shih Sinyao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) denied media reports Sunday that some Cabinet members will be reassigned or will resign.
"The reports are mostly speculative, not factual, " the GIO said in a press statement.

According to a Liberty Times report, the President Ma Ying-jeou administration will undergo a larger-than-expected reshuffle after the Lunar New Year holiday in an effort to rescue its low public approval rating and win back public trust ahead of the year-end mayoral elections for five municipalities.

The report said Ma's national security team will recruit many new faces after Hu Wei-jen replaces Su Chi as secretary-general of the National Security Council in a formal changeover ceremony scheduled for Feb. 23.
Moreover, the report said, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang might also be replaced by a new diplomat.
Other media reports also said that the finance, economics and transport ministers might be reassigned.

However, the GIO statement rebutted the reports as "not true, " saying Premier Wu Den-yih recognized the performance and hard work of all the officials mentioned in the media reports and have asked them to work even harder in the future.
Stressing that the Executive Yuan will inform the public in detail if it has any plans for a personnel reshuffle, the GIO urged the media to stop its unfounded speculation and spurious reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Suggestions on plans for ROC centenary activities

TEXT.P: Speculation has been mounting on what the government is going to put on for celebrations for the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China in 2011 at a time when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is apparently lukewarm over the celebrations and China is planning to expand its celebrations for the centenary of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911.

According to the Council for Cultural Affairs, the main organizer of the celebrations, centennial activities based on the theme of "Republic for a Century -- Democratic New Taiwan" will involve three main segments: the past (Let Academia Interpret History), the present (Let the World See Taiwan) and the future (Let Taiwan Behold the Future).

The centenary serves as not only a good chance to publicize Taiwan around the world, it is also a major event for the people of the country. People in Taiwan and overseas businessmen and expatriates are all concerned about the event.

Although it will be impossible to garner the participation of all the people of Taiwan in the celebrations, the government, while devising the activities, should take into consideration the needs of all these people and try to serve them.

It is also very important to try to allow the people to recall things they have done and the times they have shared in common through the activities, and to try to create things that will touch their hearts.

We suggest setting out a theme of gratitude for the celebrations. People in Taiwan, regardless of ethnic groups, generations, political affiliation, occupation and social status are all worthy of gratitude because all have done their parts and have paid their dues for the country. By celebrating National Day, we should recount the numerous good things that have happened in Taiwan.
We also hope that the activities will help foster warm compatriotism and kindred feelings among the people of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Movies that help sell cities
DOC.DATELINE: 02/21/10 18:32:39 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: "Au Revoir, Taipei, " a late 2009 production that won a special prize at the Berlin International Film Festival 2010 Saturday, gives global audiences a glimpse of Taipei City.

The romantic comedy, made thanks to great support from the Taipei city government during shooting, brought various Taipei features to the big screen, including the MRT system, the night markets and the round-the-clock Eslite bookstore.

Just like its predecessors -- "Cape No. 7, " "Can't Live Without You, " and "Monga," which have all enjoyed huge box office success in Taiwan -- "Au Revoir, Taipei" proves once again that motion pictures make good channels for selling cities.
The following are excerpts from the coverage by leading local newspapers of this issue:
United Daily News:

After "Au Revoir, Taipei" beat more than 30 competitors to win the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Prize at the Berlin film festival, director Arvin Chen said he wrote the screenplay and directed the film with the purpose of underscoring the beauty of Taipei City.

Chen, who won a Silver Berlin Bear-Jury Grand Prix for Short Films for a short he made titled "May" in 2007, said he intentionally brought into the film Taipei's various attractions, as he did not understand why so many people in Taiwan want to go abroad to live or study while ignoring the good parts of their own environment.

Art film giant Wim Wenders, who helped create "Au Revoir, Taipei" as a producer, said he found Chen to be very talented after watching "May." Wenders even traveled to Taipei to help scout locations for Chen's latest work. (Feb. 21, 2010)
United Evening News:

The NETPAC jury commented that the director had successfully captured the vitality of Taipei, a tireless city, as well as combining a group of figures who seem out of tune with their surroundings and therefore creating a laughter- provoking film.

Thrilled over the victory of "Au Revoir, Taipei, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the film is another example of the city government's cooperation with film producers to sell Taipei. He said the city government will help the local motion picture industry more generously in the future.

Deputy Taipei Mayor Lee Yung-ping, who doubles as head of the Taipei Film Commission, flew to Berlin to cheer on the crew of "Au Revoir, Taipei, " although she did not stay long enough to see the film winning this year's NETPAC prize.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. even unprecedentedly closed a stop one evening last year for the shooting of several scenes, where over 500 people were recruited as extras.
China Times:
One of the NETPAC jury commented that "Au Revoir, Taipei" features a unique sense of humor that is rare in most Asian movies. The movie is charming and very impressive, the judge said.
Director Arvin Chen, a Chinese American who came to Taiwan some eight years ago to work, did not stay in Berlin for the announcement of the winners, learning the good news in Paris the next day.
Chen expressed appreciation to the Taipei city government and to Wenders for their assistance. (Feb. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Air marshals trained for anti-terrorism work
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 19:17:59 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Bureau has completed the training of 25 air marshals to serve on U.S.-bound flights operated by Taiwanese carriers under a Taiwan-U.S. anti-terrorism cooperation program, government sources said Sunday.
"All the air marshals have completed their training and can take up their duties at any time, " said an Aviation Police Bureau official.
The training of air marshals is part of a U.S.-led global anti-terrorism cooperation project, the official went on, adding that Taiwan has been very compliant in carrying out the program.

"The United States has been cooperating with countries around the world to counter terrorism since the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States, and we have been very cooperative in taking steps to improve maritime and airborne traffic security, " the official explained.
On the maritime security front, a new monitoring system was inaugurated at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan last November, he continued.

"With the United States providing funds and Taiwan providing manpower, all container shipping centers at the harbor have been outfitted with radioactive substance-detecting instruments to filter all U.S.-bound containers for counter- terrorism purposes," he said.
For aviation security, the official went on, the Aviation Police Bureau was charged with training the 25 air marshals.
"All of them are elite members of our police force, " the official said.

In addition to receiving rigorous training in identifying and detecting explosives, hostage negotiations, shooting, arrest skills, combat in formation, handcuffing, unarmed combat, police baton work and taekwondo, they also had to pass family background checks, loyalty checks and emotional management tests.

As Taiwan is not a high-risk area for terrorist attacks and has consistently imposed stringent security inspections at its airports, the official said, the United States has not yet asked Taiwan to assign air marshals on Taiwanese carriers' U.S.-bound flights.

Even without a U.S. request, though, the official said, Taiwan's civil aviation authorities can dispatch air marshals to execute duties on either international or domestic flights based on their own intelligence and judgment.
Japan and China have deployed plainclothes air marshals on their commercial flights for several years, the official pointed out.

The Aviation Police Bureau plans to send several of the air marshals to the United States to receive additional training in the latest airborne counter- terrorism skills, the official said, adding that they will serve as instructors after their return from the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stocks expected to rally after Chinese New Year break
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 19:58:01 (By Maranda Hsu, Carol Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stocks are likely to rebound Monday, the first trading day after the Chinese New Year holiday, based on strong showings in global stock markets last week and the present domestic and international economic and political situations, analysts said Sunday.

There is a good chance the local stock market will rise Monday, given that the rate of the local bourse closing higher on the first transaction day after the holiday has been more than 70 percent over the past 10 years, according to Capital Investment Trust Corp.

As the market's weighted index experienced a major correction prior to the Chinese New Year holiday period, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) is likely to see a technical rebound and the 8,000 point mark tested after the holiday when foreign investors are expected to reverse their previous position and buy shares, according to an analyst at Yuanta Securities Co.
The Taiex gained more than 200 points over the final two trading days before the Feb. 14-21 holiday to close at 7,441.

Foreign investors registered 15 consecutive trading sessions for net sales of shares worth NT$150 billion (US$6.52 billion) between Jan. 22 and Feb. 10, and the selling pressure is expected to be considerably eased after the holiday break, according to the analyst.

Meanwhile, the analyst went on, the U.S. Federal Reserve's raising of discount rates by 0.25 percent to banks for direct loans Feb. 18 will have only a small negative impact on Taiwanese shares following a rally in world stock markets during the holiday period.
Chang Tao-lang, a senior executive at Jih Sun Securities Investment Trust Co. predicted that the Taiex will hover between 7,500 and 8,000 in the first half of this year.

Several factors are expected to contribute to a bullish market in the near term after the market opens again, including better-than-expected financial reports to be issued later in the year by Taiwanese and American corporations.

In addition, optimism over the signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement, favorable government policies for allowing flat panel makers to invest in China, strong exports, improved industrial production figures and corporate profits, and the warming relations between Taiwan and China will add to the bullishness of the market, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd round of ECFA talks expected to take place in March
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 20:02:33 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Sunday that the second round of official negotiations on a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will probably take place in Taipei in early March.
Taiwan's and China's plans to strike the deal in May remain unchanged, Shih confirmed during a Chinese New Year lunch with local reporters.
The signing of the ECFA, which is expected to have a crucial impact on Taiwan's economy, is one of the major policy goals for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) this year, Shih noted.

According to MOEA officials, among the issues that are expected to be dealt with in the second round of cross-strait ECFA talks will be the "early harvest" lists of each side, naming items that could be first to benefit from the agreement.

Huang Chih-peng, chief of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, and Tang Wei, director of the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under China's Ministry of Commerce, who chaired the first round of talks Jan. 26 in Beijing, will also chair the second round.

Shih said that the administration is fully aware of the stance of the opposition Democratic Progress Party on the issue and that his ministry will intensify its communication with the party until the agreement is signed.
The minister also said that trying to persuade the opposition parties and the public that the ECFA is crucial to Taiwan is a tremendously difficult task.

According to Shih, signing an ECFA will not necessarily cause local industries to relocate abroad, but not signing it will definitely result in a fast exodus abroad of local industries, an opinion that is not shared by critics of the ECFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister to remain in position: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 20:05:35 (By Lin Heng-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi denied a newspaper report Sunday that Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang will be replaced in an imminent Cabinet reshuffle, reaffirming that Yang will retain his position.

"Yang has been working very hard since he took up his current post six months ago and he has won great acclaim for his performance... Media reports about his replacement are baseless and purely speculative," Wu said in response to press inquiries about the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle during a community outreach trip to his home county of Nantou.
He further said there might be minor adjustments of ministers-without- portfolio and management executives of state-owned enterprises in late February or early March.
"But such adjustments should not be characterized as a reshuffle, " Wu argued, pointing out that the Cabinet was reshuffled just last September and will not be subject to a major change anytime soon.
As some management positions at state-owned enterprises have been left vacant for some time, Wu said, those positions should be filled with no further delay.

Asked whether Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu will be nominated by the ruling Kuomintang to run for the mayoral post of the upgraded Taipei County, soon to be known as New Taipei City, Wu said he "has so far not been informed that Chu will run for mayorship of any municipalities."
Wu said Chu has had outstanding credentials in all his previous posts as a lawmaker and as Taoyuan county magistrate.
"During his six months as my deputy since last September, he has also done a very remarkable job, helping me dealing with many issues," the premier added.
Speculation has been rife about the possibility of Chu replacing incumbent Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei to represent the KMT in the year-end New Taipei City mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Gritty reality creates recipe for success

TEXT.P: Riding on the success of the youth gang film "Monga, " Taipei's venerable Wanhua district has emerged as a new tourist attraction.

In recent weeks, large crowds of moviegoers have swarmed to Bopiliao -- a block of stores in Wanhua -- for a nostalgic tour after viewing the box-office hit before feasting on local snack foods in its nearby night market.
The indie film set in Wanhua is yet another success story of city promotion through filmmaking.
The appeal of the film partly lies in its vivid portrayal of the mundane daily grind of everyday people -- their joys and sorrows -- that reflects the aesthetics of their lives.

Since Premier Wu Den-yi took office last September, he has spared no effort to advocate the value of "main street economy" and has constantly weighed the average person's feelings when formulating his policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to recruit more coaches to upgrade students' sport skills
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 21:54:34 (By Johnson Sun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will recruit more full-time coaches this year to help upgrade sport skills of students at the city's elementary and secondary schools, a municipal official in charge of athletic affairs said Sunday.
The city government's Department of Education recruited 44 professional sports coaches last year to work full time on primary and middle school campuses.

"As the program has proved effective in helping upgrade our students' sports skills, we have decided to continue this program in 2010 by recruiting 30-plus additional full-time coaches, " said the official.

Only those who have obtained professional sport coach licenses issued by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council are eligible to register for two phases of examinations scheduled to take place between May and June, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Chinese president plays `main street economy' card

TEXT.P: Chinese leaders usually do not spend the Lunar New Year holiday at home and traditionally travel elsewhere in the country to celebrate the festival along with local communist party cadres and the public.
The selection of the places where top Chinese leaders spend their New Year holiday tend to carry policy implications or epitomize China's new work direction.

Judging from Chinese President Hu Jintao's choice of three Fujian Province cities adjacent to Taiwan -- Lungyen, Zhangzhou and Xiamen, the Beijing government's intention to further promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations during the Year of the Tiger is unmistakably evident.

Most noteworthy is that Hu said while visiting a special park designated for Taiwanese agricultural investors to operate farms or ranches that the Chinese government will do "whatever will benefit the vast majority of the Taiwanese people" and will never back off from this promise.

Hu further said China will keep in mind the interests of the people of Taiwan, particularly farmers, in its negotiations with Taiwan on the proposed cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Hu's remarks were clearly targeting ordinary Taiwanese people. To show his concern for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, Hu also inspected a wharf in Xiamen where some Taiwanese people embarked on direct sailings to Taiwan via Kinmen or Matzu. He also attended a fireworks display co-sponsored for the first time by Kinmen and Xiamen.
The moves were aimed at getting into closer contact with grassroots Taiwanese people, and Hu's main appeal focused on "economy and livelihood."
Hu's goal is actually in compliance with Taiwan's current emphasis on "main street economy, " with people's feelings the main criteria for measuring the country's economic health.
Against this backdrop, we suggest that the two sides sincerely discuss the substantive content of "things that will benefit a vast majority of Taiwanese people," as mentioned by Hu.

Such things should not just be those already in place, such as helping China- based Taiwanese businesses or the procurement of Taiwanese products, but should also include support for Taiwan's bid to joint the "ASEAN Plus One" and the further liberalization of Chinese investment in Taiwan.

If talks on these issues can get started through concerted efforts by the governments on both sides of the strait, China's goodwill in taking care of Taiwan's "main street economy" will really impress ordinary Taiwanese people and contribute to Taiwan's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A holiday too long
DOC.DATELINE: 02/21/10 16:20:54 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The nine-day Chinese New Year holiday 2010 has finally ended. The record-length New Year break, spoiled by cold and wet weather, was not appreciated by many in Taiwan, who have complained that it was a waste of time and boring, because they did not want to go out in the inclement weather.
This reminds us that holidays are good and welcome, but it is not always true that "the longer, the better."

Holidays are costly. Both society and the people have to bear the full cost of them. The government should therefore elaborate on the cost and cost efficiency, as well as the potential risks of a holiday, before determining how long it should be.
The main cost of a holiday is the decline in work and production. At the same time, the marginal benefit of a holiday break might decrease progressively with the length of it.

A holiday that is too long might incur risks. For example, a company might lose an order because it has not maintained contact with the buyer. Long holidays provide the people with the possibility of planning trips overseas, but overseas trips steal economic advantages away from the local tourism sector.
Long holidays of course have their merit. They help relieve the pressure on the government in terms of transport and traffic, as motorists have more travel schedule options.
Longer holidays also provide officials with longer periods to ponder their policy development.

A holiday is not just a day or several days off. It involves various costs and benefits. Thus, we urge the administration to make a wide-ranging study and survey all sectors involved before deciding on the length of a holiday. (Feb. 21, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Taiwanese artist dreams beyond Chinese opera
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 16:24:58 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: From playing a young man in traditional Chinese operas to portraying a clown in a modern drama to acting the role of a teenager in a TV series, young Taiwanese actor Sheng Zhian's performances have amazed both local audiences and international directors.

Sheng Zhian, a guest actor with the Guoguang Opera Company, has been active in the traditional art and theatrical fields for several years. He has been in the spotlight recently due to his unique vocal styling, innovative acting skills and compelling stage presence.
Local drama critics have labeled him the "successor of Wu Hsing-kuo, " an actor who started his career in Chinese opera but later extended his field to modern drama and became a movie star.

Sheng also received more than 20 years of traditional Peking opera training before branching out into other types of performance. He graduated from the Guoguang Art School and the National Taiwan University of Arts, and also became a pupil of Peking opera master Pei Yan Ling.
"Last year, I went back to the Guoguang Opera Company as a guest actor, and also participated in a TV series, as well as trying my hand at appearing in commercials," he told CNA.
In the new year, he will make a cameo appearance in Guoguang's new opera titled "Meng Xiaodong, " the story of an actress who specialized in playing male roles in Chinese opera.
"I started to receive serious training at a Chinese traditional opera school when I was 10 years old. There is no doubt that it is my favorite thing to do," he said.

While he used to focus only on this traditional art, he has since changed his view. "I have studied both Western and Chinese performing styles, such as the theories of Chinese opera maestro Mei Lanfan, German theatrical director Bertolt Brecht, and also Russian director Constantin Stanislavski. Those have enriched my performances greatly," he said.

Sheng now views performing as a "profound calling" that should not be limited to any specific field. "My concept of performance has greatly broadened; I can pursue many other aspects of performing without betraying my passion for Chinese opera," he said.

He revealed that his plan for this year will be to participate in as many different experiences as possible. He expects to complete the script of a new drama by the middle of the year and to then set up a new theatrical group to perform it. He is also contemplating a film career.
"After so many years, I feel that we need an actor-centered theatrical group to provide stimulation and opportunities for good actors," he went on. CNA staff reporter/J

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO denies Cabinet reshuffle report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 17:00:52 (By Shih Sinyao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) denied media reports Sunday that some Cabinet members will be reassigned or will resign.
"The reports are mostly speculative, not factual, " the GIO said in a press statement.

According to a Liberty Times report, the President Ma Ying-jeou administration will undergo a larger-than-expected reshuffle after the Lunar New Year holiday in an effort to rescue its low public approval rating and win back public trust ahead of the year-end mayoral elections for five municipalities.

The report said Ma's national security team will recruit many new faces after Hu Wei-jen replaces Su Chi as secretary-general of the National Security Council in a formal changeover ceremony scheduled for Feb. 23.
Moreover, the report said, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang might also be replaced by a new diplomat.
Other media reports also said that the finance, economics and transport ministers might be reassigned.

However, the GIO statement rebutted the reports as "not true, " saying Premier Wu Den-yih recognized the performance and hard work of all the officials mentioned in the media reports and have asked them to work even harder in the future.
Stressing that the Executive Yuan will inform the public in detail if it has any plans for a personnel reshuffle, the GIO urged the media to stop its unfounded speculation and spurious reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Suggestions on plans for ROC centenary activities

TEXT.P: Speculation has been mounting on what the government is going to put on for celebrations for the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China in 2011 at a time when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is apparently lukewarm over the celebrations and China is planning to expand its celebrations for the centenary of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911.

According to the Council for Cultural Affairs, the main organizer of the celebrations, centennial activities based on the theme of "Republic for a Century -- Democratic New Taiwan" will involve three main segments: the past (Let Academia Interpret History), the present (Let the World See Taiwan) and the future (Let Taiwan Behold the Future).

The centenary serves as not only a good chance to publicize Taiwan around the world, it is also a major event for the people of the country. People in Taiwan and overseas businessmen and expatriates are all concerned about the event.

Although it will be impossible to garner the participation of all the people of Taiwan in the celebrations, the government, while devising the activities, should take into consideration the needs of all these people and try to serve them.

It is also very important to try to allow the people to recall things they have done and the times they have shared in common through the activities, and to try to create things that will touch their hearts.

We suggest setting out a theme of gratitude for the celebrations. People in Taiwan, regardless of ethnic groups, generations, political affiliation, occupation and social status are all worthy of gratitude because all have done their parts and have paid their dues for the country. By celebrating National Day, we should recount the numerous good things that have happened in Taiwan.
We also hope that the activities will help foster warm compatriotism and kindred feelings among the people of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Movies that help sell cities
DOC.DATELINE: 02/21/10 18:32:39 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: "Au Revoir, Taipei, " a late 2009 production that won a special prize at the Berlin International Film Festival 2010 Saturday, gives global audiences a glimpse of Taipei City.

The romantic comedy, made thanks to great support from the Taipei city government during shooting, brought various Taipei features to the big screen, including the MRT system, the night markets and the round-the-clock Eslite bookstore.

Just like its predecessors -- "Cape No. 7, " "Can't Live Without You, " and "Monga," which have all enjoyed huge box office success in Taiwan -- "Au Revoir, Taipei" proves once again that motion pictures make good channels for selling cities.
The following are excerpts from the coverage by leading local newspapers of this issue:
United Daily News:

After "Au Revoir, Taipei" beat more than 30 competitors to win the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Prize at the Berlin film festival, director Arvin Chen said he wrote the screenplay and directed the film with the purpose of underscoring the beauty of Taipei City.

Chen, who won a Silver Berlin Bear-Jury Grand Prix for Short Films for a short he made titled "May" in 2007, said he intentionally brought into the film Taipei's various attractions, as he did not understand why so many people in Taiwan want to go abroad to live or study while ignoring the good parts of their own environment.

Art film giant Wim Wenders, who helped create "Au Revoir, Taipei" as a producer, said he found Chen to be very talented after watching "May." Wenders even traveled to Taipei to help scout locations for Chen's latest work. (Feb. 21, 2010)
United Evening News:

The NETPAC jury commented that the director had successfully captured the vitality of Taipei, a tireless city, as well as combining a group of figures who seem out of tune with their surroundings and therefore creating a laughter- provoking film.

Thrilled over the victory of "Au Revoir, Taipei, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the film is another example of the city government's cooperation with film producers to sell Taipei. He said the city government will help the local motion picture industry more generously in the future.

Deputy Taipei Mayor Lee Yung-ping, who doubles as head of the Taipei Film Commission, flew to Berlin to cheer on the crew of "Au Revoir, Taipei, " although she did not stay long enough to see the film winning this year's NETPAC prize.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. even unprecedentedly closed a stop one evening last year for the shooting of several scenes, where over 500 people were recruited as extras.
China Times:
One of the NETPAC jury commented that "Au Revoir, Taipei" features a unique sense of humor that is rare in most Asian movies. The movie is charming and very impressive, the judge said.
Director Arvin Chen, a Chinese American who came to Taiwan some eight years ago to work, did not stay in Berlin for the announcement of the winners, learning the good news in Paris the next day.
Chen expressed appreciation to the Taipei city government and to Wenders for their assistance. (Feb. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Air marshals trained for anti-terrorism work
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 19:17:59 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Bureau has completed the training of 25 air marshals to serve on U.S.-bound flights operated by Taiwanese carriers under a Taiwan-U.S. anti-terrorism cooperation program, government sources said Sunday.
"All the air marshals have completed their training and can take up their duties at any time, " said an Aviation Police Bureau official.
The training of air marshals is part of a U.S.-led global anti-terrorism cooperation project, the official went on, adding that Taiwan has been very compliant in carrying out the program.

"The United States has been cooperating with countries around the world to counter terrorism since the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States, and we have been very cooperative in taking steps to improve maritime and airborne traffic security, " the official explained.
On the maritime security front, a new monitoring system was inaugurated at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan last November, he continued.

"With the United States providing funds and Taiwan providing manpower, all container shipping centers at the harbor have been outfitted with radioactive substance-detecting instruments to filter all U.S.-bound containers for counter- terrorism purposes," he said.
For aviation security, the official went on, the Aviation Police Bureau was charged with training the 25 air marshals.
"All of them are elite members of our police force, " the official said.

In addition to receiving rigorous training in identifying and detecting explosives, hostage negotiations, shooting, arrest skills, combat in formation, handcuffing, unarmed combat, police baton work and taekwondo, they also had to pass family background checks, loyalty checks and emotional management tests.

As Taiwan is not a high-risk area for terrorist attacks and has consistently imposed stringent security inspections at its airports, the official said, the United States has not yet asked Taiwan to assign air marshals on Taiwanese carriers' U.S.-bound flights.

Even without a U.S. request, though, the official said, Taiwan's civil aviation authorities can dispatch air marshals to execute duties on either international or domestic flights based on their own intelligence and judgment.
Japan and China have deployed plainclothes air marshals on their commercial flights for several years, the official pointed out.

The Aviation Police Bureau plans to send several of the air marshals to the United States to receive additional training in the latest airborne counter- terrorism skills, the official said, adding that they will serve as instructors after their return from the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stocks expected to rally after Chinese New Year break
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 19:58:01 (By Maranda Hsu, Carol Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stocks are likely to rebound Monday, the first trading day after the Chinese New Year holiday, based on strong showings in global stock markets last week and the present domestic and international economic and political situations, analysts said Sunday.

There is a good chance the local stock market will rise Monday, given that the rate of the local bourse closing higher on the first transaction day after the holiday has been more than 70 percent over the past 10 years, according to Capital Investment Trust Corp.

As the market's weighted index experienced a major correction prior to the Chinese New Year holiday period, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) is likely to see a technical rebound and the 8,000 point mark tested after the holiday when foreign investors are expected to reverse their previous position and buy shares, according to an analyst at Yuanta Securities Co.
The Taiex gained more than 200 points over the final two trading days before the Feb. 14-21 holiday to close at 7,441.

Foreign investors registered 15 consecutive trading sessions for net sales of shares worth NT$150 billion (US$6.52 billion) between Jan. 22 and Feb. 10, and the selling pressure is expected to be considerably eased after the holiday break, according to the analyst.

Meanwhile, the analyst went on, the U.S. Federal Reserve's raising of discount rates by 0.25 percent to banks for direct loans Feb. 18 will have only a small negative impact on Taiwanese shares following a rally in world stock markets during the holiday period.
Chang Tao-lang, a senior executive at Jih Sun Securities Investment Trust Co. predicted that the Taiex will hover between 7,500 and 8,000 in the first half of this year.

Several factors are expected to contribute to a bullish market in the near term after the market opens again, including better-than-expected financial reports to be issued later in the year by Taiwanese and American corporations.

In addition, optimism over the signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement, favorable government policies for allowing flat panel makers to invest in China, strong exports, improved industrial production figures and corporate profits, and the warming relations between Taiwan and China will add to the bullishness of the market, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd round of ECFA talks expected to take place in March
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 20:02:33 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Sunday that the second round of official negotiations on a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will probably take place in Taipei in early March.
Taiwan's and China's plans to strike the deal in May remain unchanged, Shih confirmed during a Chinese New Year lunch with local reporters.
The signing of the ECFA, which is expected to have a crucial impact on Taiwan's economy, is one of the major policy goals for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) this year, Shih noted.

According to MOEA officials, among the issues that are expected to be dealt with in the second round of cross-strait ECFA talks will be the "early harvest" lists of each side, naming items that could be first to benefit from the agreement.

Huang Chih-peng, chief of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, and Tang Wei, director of the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under China's Ministry of Commerce, who chaired the first round of talks Jan. 26 in Beijing, will also chair the second round.

Shih said that the administration is fully aware of the stance of the opposition Democratic Progress Party on the issue and that his ministry will intensify its communication with the party until the agreement is signed.
The minister also said that trying to persuade the opposition parties and the public that the ECFA is crucial to Taiwan is a tremendously difficult task.

According to Shih, signing an ECFA will not necessarily cause local industries to relocate abroad, but not signing it will definitely result in a fast exodus abroad of local industries, an opinion that is not shared by critics of the ECFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister to remain in position: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 20:05:35 (By Lin Heng-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi denied a newspaper report Sunday that Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang will be replaced in an imminent Cabinet reshuffle, reaffirming that Yang will retain his position.

"Yang has been working very hard since he took up his current post six months ago and he has won great acclaim for his performance... Media reports about his replacement are baseless and purely speculative," Wu said in response to press inquiries about the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle during a community outreach trip to his home county of Nantou.
He further said there might be minor adjustments of ministers-without- portfolio and management executives of state-owned enterprises in late February or early March.
"But such adjustments should not be characterized as a reshuffle, " Wu argued, pointing out that the Cabinet was reshuffled just last September and will not be subject to a major change anytime soon.
As some management positions at state-owned enterprises have been left vacant for some time, Wu said, those positions should be filled with no further delay.

Asked whether Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu will be nominated by the ruling Kuomintang to run for the mayoral post of the upgraded Taipei County, soon to be known as New Taipei City, Wu said he "has so far not been informed that Chu will run for mayorship of any municipalities."
Wu said Chu has had outstanding credentials in all his previous posts as a lawmaker and as Taoyuan county magistrate.
"During his six months as my deputy since last September, he has also done a very remarkable job, helping me dealing with many issues," the premier added.
Speculation has been rife about the possibility of Chu replacing incumbent Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei to represent the KMT in the year-end New Taipei City mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Gritty reality creates recipe for success

TEXT.P: Riding on the success of the youth gang film "Monga, " Taipei's venerable Wanhua district has emerged as a new tourist attraction.

In recent weeks, large crowds of moviegoers have swarmed to Bopiliao -- a block of stores in Wanhua -- for a nostalgic tour after viewing the box-office hit before feasting on local snack foods in its nearby night market.
The indie film set in Wanhua is yet another success story of city promotion through filmmaking.
The appeal of the film partly lies in its vivid portrayal of the mundane daily grind of everyday people -- their joys and sorrows -- that reflects the aesthetics of their lives.

Since Premier Wu Den-yi took office last September, he has spared no effort to advocate the value of "main street economy" and has constantly weighed the average person's feelings when formulating his policies.

The three rounds of domestic fuel price cuts and the cancellation of a plan to raise the admission fee to a state-run recreational park in central Taiwan are revealing examples of the Cabinet's heeding of the feelings and lives of everyday people.

We hope the government will draw inspiration from "Monga" and support even more creative efforts to explore fun and interest in local grassroots people's daily lives. We believe artistic works based on empathetic understanding of the life of the common man will be moving and will win commercial success and critical acclaim. (Feb. 21, 2010)

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/10 21:54:34 (By Johnson Sun and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 22, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five- and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 09:19:39 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday than its previous close on Feb. 10, moving up 178.03 points at 7,619.87 on a turnover of NT$6.588 billion (US$205.88 million).
Monday is the first trading day on the local bourse after the Lunar New Year break.
The weighted price index rose 80.8 points to close at 7,441.84 Feb. 10, the last trading day before the Lunar New Year holiday.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 10:40:10 (By Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor attends cities summit in Seoul
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 10:59:21 (By Johnson Sun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin is heading to Seoul, South Korea, Monday for the 2010 World Design Cities Summit, at which he will give a presentation on Taipei's efforts to promote cultural innovation.

Hau will be grouped with the mayors of Bangkok, Thailand; Beijing, China; Eindhoven, Holland; and Istanbul, Turkey during the summit which is scheduled to open on Tuesday. His presentation, titled "Taipei: A City of Innovation and Creativity, " will be delivered in English.

Three other Taipei City government officials, Research Development and Evaluation Commission Director Yang Hsiao-tung, Department of Environmental Protection Director Ni Shih-piao, and Commission of Administrative Appeals Director Chen Ye-hsin, are accompanying Hau on his visit to Seoul from Feb. 22-25.
The delegation is expected to call on Seoul Mayor Oh Se-hoon and to observe infrastructure reform and construction in Seoul, which is a sister city of Taipei.
The World Design Cities Summit is an international event organized by the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design in 2005 to promote the idea of city design.

Every two years, a city is appointed "World Design Capital" (WDC) -- a designation that provides a distinctive opportunity for cities to feature their accomplishments in innovative design and to highlight their success in urban revitalization strategies.
Torino, Italy was the World Design Capital in 2008, and this year it's Seoul.
More than 500 Korean and international design industrial experts are expected to attend the 2010 summit.

According to the Taipei City government, Hau's participation in the event is expected to help the city in its efforts to host the 2011 International Design Alliance Congress in October this year. Some 3,000 design professionals from 60 countries will participate in that event.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Loosen grip on China-bound investment
DOC.DATELINE: 02/22/10 11:14:51 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government's latest move to relax restrictions on China-bound high-tech investment has been welcomed as a generous Chinese New Year gift to the industrial sector, but we think that it does not go far enough.

In response to the argument by some people that the decision was "tailor-made" to benefit semiconductor manufacturing giants TSMC and UMC, we ask, why not, if it would help such companies to expand their global reach and influence.

However, for flat panel makers, the new regulations are not attractive enough. Under the revised rules, Taiwanese TFT-LCD makers will conditionally be allowed to invest in facilities more advanced than 6th-generation plants but less advanced than the applicant's Taiwan facility by at least one generation.
Under this rule, only AU Optronics Corp. (AUO), Taiwan's largest flat panel maker, will qualify.
China's flat panel market is the world's largest, absorbing over 16 percent of global production, and Taiwanese TFT-LCD manufacturers enjoy first-choice privilege in terms of investment.
Nevertheless, China no longer wants low-level or old-generation flat panel plants.

While Taiwan remains hesitant in this regard, the South Korean government at the end of 2009 lifted restrictions to allow its companies to establish up to 8.0-generation flat panel plants in China in a bid to give Korean manufacturers an edge over their Taiwanese competitors.

Although the Taiwan government has relaxed its restrictions on semiconductor investment in China, local chip foundries are still prohibited from setting up 12-inch wafer fabs or foundries there using processes more advanced than 0.13 micrometers.
This is tantamount to doing a good deed but not going all the way, or hitting way off the mark.
According to a TSMC spokesman, the latest liberalization move is not enough to help local chip makers expand their market share in China.
We urge the Ministry of Economic Affairs to come up with measures that are more liberal and progressive in order to help Taiwanese makers become more competitive in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government expected to raise 2010 GDP growth forecast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 11:31:56 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government is expected to raise its economic growth forecast for 2010 after an international market research organization last week adjusted its forecast for Taiwan upward, analysts said Monday.
Last week, Global Insight raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 GDP growth to 4.9 percent from the 4.4 percent it predicted in January.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) will release Monday its initial statistics for the country's 2009 economic performance and its economic outlook for this year.

Hu Sheng-cheng, an Academia Sinica academician and a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said he believes the DGBAS will moderately raise its economic growth forecast for this year as the local economy is indeed showing signs of recovery.
The DGBAS forecast late last year that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will post a positive growth of 4.39 percent in 2010 following a 2.53 percent contraction in 2009.
Forecasts by other economic think tanks put Taiwan's GDP growth rate for 2010 at between 4.45 percent and 4.81 percent, while the CEPD has set the 2010 growth target at 4.8 percent.

However, Hu said, Taiwan should remain cautious because there are still several possible risks that could arise amid the current global economic recovery, such as an asset bubble in China and weak recovery of private consumption in high- income European countries and the United States.

Other uncertainties include whether local manufacturers' high-tech orders will remain brisk and how well major countries around the world will deal with the aftermath of emergency measures adopted during the 2009 economic recession, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--- Legislative by-election campaigns gain momentum

TEXT.P: On the first business day after the Chinese New Year, leading local newspapers gave prominent space Monday to the legislative by-elections which will be held Feb. 27.
The following are excerpts of their reports:

Liberty Times: With one week to go before the legislative by-elections in the counties of Hualien, Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Chiayi, both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are gearing up to full-steam in their campaigns.

The KMT is projecting that it will score two sure wins and might take a third or even fourth seat because of the heavy campaigning by the party's Chairman Ma Ying-jeou during the nine-day Chinese New Year.
China Times: In a campaign swing during the Chinese New Year holidays, Ma made whistle stops in Jhongli, Taoyuan County and Minsyon, Chiayi County.
In Jhongli, Ma accompanied KMT candidate Apollo Chen on a three-kilometer walk to seek voter support.
It was Ma's third visit to the small city during the 9-day holiday to stump for Chen.
In Minsyong, Ma and KMT candidate Lin Teh-rui led a campaign parade, but they encountered a group of DPP followers who waved placards in protest against Ma's proposal for a trade pact with China.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen also visited Minsyong Sunday evening to stump for DPP candidate Chen Min-wen, who is considered a front runner in that election.
Tsai urged voters to not only support Chen but give him a resounding victory. (Feb. 22, 2010)
United Daily News: In Hualien, a verbal fight between KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung and Hualien Mayor Fu Kun-chi stole the show.

While stumping in Hualien City for the KMT candidate Wang Ting-sheng, King accused Fu, a self-claimed die-hard KMT supporter, of trying to divide the KMT vote by throwing his weight behind independent candidate Shih Sheng-lang.

Fu, who won the Hualien mayoral election Dec. 5, 2009 against KMT candidate Tu Li-hua, denied the charge, saying that he would support which ever candidate would push for the construction of a freeway to link Hualien and Yilan. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei magistrate will not run for New Taipei City mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 12:09:49 (By Chen Ching-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei announced his decision Monday not to enter the race for the mayoral post after the county is upgraded to a special municipality to be known as New Taipei City, a move that had been expected.

Addressing a festive gathering on the first day of work after the nine-day Lunar New Year break, Chou also said he will definitely not take up any position in the Presidential Office or the Executive Yuan, contrary to media speculation.
Chou further said he is also unlikely to take up any post in any state-run enterprise as a "political reward service."
"I will remain at my current post until the last day of my term," he reiterated.
Chou said speculation has been rife over the last two years that he would be recruited into President Ma Ying-jeou's administration in exchange for his promise to not seek a second term.

"Such speculation is meaningless. I assure all of you that there will not be any trade in political posts... I will stick to my post until my term of office expires late this year, " Chou told the staff of the Taipei county government.

Chou's announcement is expected to pave the way for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to nominate Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu to run in the year-end New Taipei City mayoral election. Chu is widely believed to stand a better chance of winning the critical race than Chou, who has suffered from consistently poor approval ratings.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said Sunday that the party attaches great importance to the New Taipei City mayoral race because the outcome of the election will be seen as a bellwether for the KMT's chances in the 2012 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Academic to head Government Information Office
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 15:22:13 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Monday that outgoing Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin will be succeeded by Johnny Chiang, a Soochow University associate professor.

Chiang, who is also an acting director of the Department of International Affairs under the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) , a local think tank, had been tapped before the Chinese New Year holiday to be the replacement for the position left vacant by Su, who is expected to take over as ruling Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman and to begin preparing for the year-end special municipality elections.
Su worked closely with KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung during the party's successful 2008 presidential election campaign.
Ma made the confirmation during a party hosted by the KMT to mark the first office day after the long Chinese New Year holiday.
Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, exhorted all party members to strive to make the KMT a party that stands by the people.
"The KMT should be a party that knows the suffering of the people, is able to deliver on the people's expectations and to fulfill the goals set by our founding father, Sun Yat-sen," Ma said.
He disclosed that from this year, the defunct Sun Yat-sen Scholarships will be reinstated to continue helping nurture more talent for the KMT.

He said many government officials, including himself, King, KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, Examination Yuan President John Kuan and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, were recipients of the Sun Yat-sen Scholarships, allowing them to pursue advanced studies overseas.
Johnny Chiang, 38, was also a recipient of the prestigious scholarship, Ma noted.
"We would not have had the opportunity to pursue advanced studies abroad if there had been no such state scholarship," he went on.

Chiang is the son-in-law of KMT Legislator-at-large Liu Shen-liang and his paternal uncle is Antonio Chiang, former deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council under the previous Democratic Progressive Party government.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: The Xinbei City mayor seat
DOC.DATELINE: 02/22/10 16:15:22 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: If Eric Lilun Chu decides to run for mayor of New Taipei City, also knowned as Xinbei City, Su Tseng-chang will have no choice but to run against him. If Chu doesn't run, Su may choose to contest the election in either Taipei City or Xinbei City.

Any decision by Chu to run in Xinbei City would be made on the assumption that he would be up against Su, therefore, Su would have to take up the challenge if he doesn't want to hand the KMT an easy victory and sink his political career in the process.

There would be no need for Chu to enter the race in Xinbei City, let alone replace the incumbent mayor Chou Hsi-wei as the KMT candidate, if Su rules out the possibility of competing in either Taipei or Xinbei.
But once Su reveals that he is flirting with the idea of throwing his hat into the ring, Chu would not be able to turn down the KMT's request for him to compete.
As he is being forced to make the decision because of Su, Chu should announce his candidacy before Su does and thus force Su to show his hand.
Su has said he would rather not to run at all, but if he has to, he would prefer to do so in Taipei City and that New Taipei City would be his last choice.

Su's preference for Taipei is understandable because he could use the old pro- China versus pro-independence issue in his campaign against incumbent Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin. In addition, a win against Hau would be considered a political feat and a defeat would not necessarily ruin Su's chances of making a bid for the presidency in 2012.

However, in a race against Chu, the DPP's traditional strategy of playing the Taiwan versus China card won't work. Furthermore, unlike incumbent Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei whose public approval rating is low, Chu is unlikely to be the underdog in a competition against Su.
Meanwhile, Su certainly cannot afford to lose a race against Chu, but a victory in Xinbei City could trap Su in city hall for four years and cost him his chance at the presidency in 2012.

On the other hand, if Su wins the mayoral election in Xinbei City this year but later chooses to give up the seat to pursue the presidency in 2012, Chu may win the mayor's seat in the resulting by-election, and Su may lose the bid for the presidency. (Feb. 22, 2010)
