DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: The end of the easy money era

TEXT.P: Two important external events occurred during the Chinese New Year holiday that deserve attention. First, The People's Bank of China, China's central bank, announced that it will raise the deposit reserve requirement ratio for Chinese financial institutions by 0.5 percentage points to 16.5 percent from Feb. 25 this year.

It was the second time this year the reserve ratio has been raised, following a similar 0.5 percent hike on Jan. 18, 2010. The central bank was compelled to hit the brakes harder after seeing new lending rise by 1.4 trillion Chinese yuan in January, more than in the entire previous quarter.
The other major news item was the U.S. Federal Reserve's raising of its discount rate to 0.75 percent.

The combined economic scale of the United States and China is nearly US$20 trillion, or around 30 percent of the world economy. The moves by both have sent clear messages to the public -- that easy monetary policy is on its way out and that the way to move on is through cautious finetuning rather than a comprehensive hike in interest rates.
Many believe that only when the Fed starts to raise the federal funds rate will a period of credit tightening truly begin.
But it is undeniable that the exit of easy monetary policy has formally begun, and the frequency and scale of future money tightening moves could grow larger.

The U.S. and China are reminding all investors and businesses that as liquidity drops, funds will not be as easily accessible as in 2009, and they therefore should make the necessary adjustments to their operations and strategies. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President paints rosy economic outlook
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 17:03:22 (By Chang Min-kun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that Taiwan's economy has been recovering, that the outlook for this year is upbeat and that Taiwan can grab the opportunity to achieve a full and strong recovery.

Addressing an annual Chinese New Year party for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, Ma said that the same time last year was the worst period for the economy, so the government decided to distribute shopping coupons in an effort to boost the economy.

This year, however, the government no longer needs to do so because most department stores, discount stores, restaurants, movie theaters and amusement parks have been enjoying brisk business, which signals that Taiwan's economy has been recovering, Ma said.
"I believe our economic performance this year will be very good," he added.

Ma also said he hopes to see an economic recovery "featuring Taiwanese characteristics." The recovery should be nationwide -- not just benefiting only one industry or department, and it also needs to increase job opportunities, he went on.
It should also be innovative and the structure of the economy needs to change, Ma continued.

The president said the government will soon implement a new industrial innovation law, in which small- and medium-sized enterprises in traditional industries will be eligible for government subsidies of NT$10,000 per month for six months for every additional worker they employ.
Ma stressed that the innovation should not be limited only to the hi-tech field but should also apply to agricultural products.

Touching on energy saving and carbon emissions reduction, he said that in the past two years Taiwan has made great achievements in this field and will keep following the Kyoto Protocol and the Copenhagen Accord on reducing emissions.
Ma further said that Taiwan needs to participate in regional economic integration.
"It is definitely necessary for us to sign an economic cooperation agreement with China, and we need to do it quick, " he said.
"Without signing a trade pact with China, other countries might not be willing to sign free trade pacts with us, " said Ma.

Taiwan needs to become more flexible and open, he continued, adding that he must create opportunities to let Taiwanese people feel respected in international society, "otherwise, I do not deserve to be president."
Ma said government officials need to let the public know that the government is eyeing 10 or 20 years ahead, not just the next one or two years.
If Taiwan can achieve all this, the economic outlook will be very strong and optimistic, the president concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares rally on first trading day after Lunar New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 17:37:24 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) closed 1.58 percent higher Monday on the first trading day after the Lunar New Year holiday, with the benchmark index rising 118.20 points to finish at 7,560.04.
Reflecting a rally in world stock markets, the stock market opened at the day's high of 7,619.87 before dropping to a low of 7,553.29.

The strong showing came after U.S. stocks finished higher Friday for a second consecutive week despite the Federal Reserve's raising of discount rates to banks for direct loans by 0.25 percent and a lessening of market fears over sovereign defaults in the euro zone.
An easing in selling pressure prior to the holiday also helped give a boost to the local bourse, analysts said.
A total of 3.19 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.44 billion (US$2.95 billion).
All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks the biggest gainers with a rise of 3.9 percent.
Foodstuff issues gained 2.3 percent, while construction issues and cement shares, as well as plastic and chemical stocks, were all up 1.7 percent.
Paper and pulp shares gained 1.4 percent, electronics and machinery issues rose by 0.9 percent and textile stocks increased 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,534 to 1,411, with 241 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$3.43 billion-worth of shares.
The Taiex had gained more than 200 points over the final two trading days before the Feb. 14-21 holiday to close at 7,441.
Foreign investors registered 15 consecutive trading sessions for net sales of shares worth NT$150 billion (US$6.52 billion) between Jan. 22 and Feb. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 17:42:58 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0. 01 to close at NT$32.099.
A total of US$603 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.120 and hit a low of NT$32.003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: People have the right to decide how to embrace Spring
DOC.DATELINE: 02/22/10 17:50:43 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, which ended Feb. 21, should have been a time for people to rest completely from their work over the past year and for individuals, enterprises, politicians and parties to engage in self-reflection and planning for the new year.

In 2009, the world experienced the worst recession in years, which was brought about by a financial crisis. We think it is time for a reversal of misfortune. However, that depends on not just on opportunities but also on wisdom and hard work.

From that perspective, we do not expect the Ma Ying-jeou government to achieve a reversal of misfortune, judging from its failed performance last year. It is worrisome that the government failed to boost industrial development or to lower the unemployment rate.

We see Taiwan as trapped in a crisis of "pseudo recovery, " with people being misled into thinking that the recession has bottomed out. In fact, the country is facing an even bigger crisis -- that of the ruling party masking the pseudo recovery with its theory of a "V-type" economic recovery, in an attempt to cover its incompetence.

We think President Ma Ying-joeu is the first person who should have stayed home during the Lunar New Year holiday to review his mistakes. The president has failed completely to deliver on any aspect of his "633" plan to achieve an annual economic growth of 6 percent, per capital income of US$30,000, and an unemployment rate of less than 3 percent by 2012.
It was sad to see Ma busy campaigning for Kuomintang (KMT) legislative by- election candidates during the new year holiday, rather than staying at home to engage in self-reflection.
Since he took office in 2008, his public approval rating has plunged from over 70 percent to some 20 percent, reflecting public discontent with his China- tilting policies and incompetence.

However, Ma seems to think it's all a problem of poor public relations on the part of his administration. He's convinced that he can win public support for his policies, including the controversial economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, once his administration holds as many press conferences as possible to explain the details.

However, we do not think the government can force people to accept whatever they are being offered. If the Ma administration cannot give the people what they want, it should at least let them decide their own future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Good performance of duty is best commitment: vice premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 17:55:05 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu declined to answer a reporter's question Monday on whether he is ready to represent the ruling Kuomintang and run for the mayoral post of Xinbei City, saying only that "good performance of duty is the best commitment."

Chu expressed admiration for Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei for his demonstration of grace and magnanimity when he declared at a function earlier in the day that he will not enter the race for the mayoral post of Xinbei City, as the upgraded Taipei County will be known, and promised to throw his support behind Chu.

According to Chu, Chou's performance as Taipei magistrate over the past several years is obvious and laudable, and he urged society and the media to give him "fair appraisal." Chou has suffered consistently poor approval ratings for his performance.

On the question of when will he formally throw his hat into the ring for the Xinbei City mayoral election, Chu said the KMT, just like any other political party, runs a nomination mechanism, so it would be inappropriate for him to speculate in this regard.
"What I should do at present is my duty as vice premier, including tackling the unemployment issue and reviving the domestic economy," Chu said.
Chou announced his decision not to enter the Xinbei City mayoral election at a festive gathering on the first day of work after the long Chinese New Year break.

He also said he will definitely not take up any position in the Presidential Office or the Executive Yuan, contrary to media speculation. He further elaborated that he will remain at his current post until the last day of his term.
Chou's announcement was expected to pave the way for the ruling KMT to nominate Chu, who is widely believed to stand a better chance of winning the critical race than Chou.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said the previous day that the party attaches great importance to the Xinbei City mayoral race because the outcome of the election will be seen as a bellwether for the KMT's chances in the 2012 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eslite to hold vinyl record exhibition and sale next month
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 22(CNA) 02/22/10 18:04:01 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Eslite bookstore will hold its annual "Vinyl Underground" exhibition and sale from March 5-14 to encourage people to discover the beauty of vintage music albums, according to the organizers.
The Dunhua branch of the bookstore will showcase more than 10,000 vinyl albums, with sale prices ranging from NT$99 to NT$30,000.

The exhibits will include Michael Jackson's "Black or White" and "Remember the Time, " Madonna's colored vinyl records, and the baseball music album "Baseball and Me" that was released in the first year of the local Chinese Professional Baseball League.

The exhibition is being supported by nine companies, including London Vintage International, Goodiscs and Joy Audio, and some individuals have offered to add their personal collections, the organizers said.

Vinyl records were the primary medium used for commercial music reproduction for most of the 20th century, but they are no longer in the mainstream. However, many fans and collectors still love the vintage sound they produce.
According to Eslite bookstore, the event has attracted many local and foreign fans in the last two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Strategy top, diplomacy only comes second

TEXT.P: The public has responded positively to seasoned diplomat Hu Wei-jen's appointment as secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC).

The NSC is the top strategic reference agency for the president, but its role should not be confined to that of national security and should be expanded to one with a broader vision and a wider strategic perspective.
Taiwan is facing the three biggest economies in the world -- the United States, Japan, and China -- and the relationships among the three are sensitive and complex.

To ensure national security and enhance the nation's wellbeing, it is in Taiwan's best interests to maintain balanced and complementary relations with each of the three. The Chinese classic "Sun Tzu on the Art of War" says strategy is the top approach to victory, and this is what we hope for in the new NSC secretary-general.

In reality, although the three countries are "strategic cooperation partners, " they are also enemies when their interests -- especially their economic interests -- clash, and it is for this reason that the NSC should not confine itself only to national security.

In terms of strategic planning, the economy should be further liberalized so that Taiwan can become a bridgehead for other countries making inroads into the Chinese market and other countries will be persuaded to set up their Asia- Pacific operations headquarters here.

Taiwan should also use all its available resources and non-conventional strategies, including networks, international publicity campaigns, lobbying and even humanitarian assistance to upgrade the nation's image internationally and solicit international support.
Adopting such an approach would be the best policy for consolidating Taiwan's security. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges `Taishang' to help publicize ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 18:19:42 (By Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of relations with China urged Taiwanese people with business operations in China -- known in Taiwan as "Taishang" -- to help publicize a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan urged the "Taishang" not only to support Taiwan's signing of the ECFA with China, but also to step forward to help publicize and promote the plan.

Speaking at a festive gathering to mark the first day of work after the Lunar New Year holiday, Lai called on the "Taishang" to expound to the public on the advantages that are expected to be created for all Taiwanese people by the signing of the ECFA.

The gathering was sponsored by Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), the MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China.
More than 200 "Taishang" representatives from all over China attended the function.

Addressing the gathering, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said the fifth round of talks with his Chinese counterpart -- Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will be held in the first half of 2010 as scheduled.
Major issues expected to be tackled at that meeting will include the signing of the ECFA, protection of intellectual property rights and avoidance of double taxation, Chiang said.

In related news, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that same day that a legislative mechanism should be established to allow the Legislative Yuan to supervise Taiwan's signing of any trade pact with China.

Since there is no law to serve as a legal basis for the legislature to oversee or screen agreements signed during talks between the SEF and ARATS, Wang urged all lawmakers to offer their opinions and suggestions to help build such a supervisory mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magistrate's decision not seek reelection draws mixed reactions

TEXT.P: Heavyweights of the ruling and opposition parties expressed mixed reactions Monday to Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei's announcement that he would not seek reelection in December after the county has been upgraded to a special municipality called Xinbei City.

Chou made the announcement following news reports that he had agreed to let Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu stand as the Kuomintang (KMT) candidate in light of the incumbent's low approval ratings in various opinion polls.
According to the reports, the KMT thinks Chu has a better chance of winning the election.

Chou said he reached the decision on his own and that there had been no pressure from KMT authorities. KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was given no advance notice of the decision before it was announced publicly, Chou added.
There is no law that requires an elected official to seek two consecutive terms, Chou noted, adding that he would perfer to be known as an exemplary single-term magistrate.

He pledged that when his term expires at the end of this year, he would leave his successor adequate funds and a well-developed infrastructure, in keeping with his promise when he assumed office four years ago.
The magistrate denied that he was offered some other government post in return for stepping aside, and he promised to support Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu in his bid for the Xinbei City seat.

Responding to Chou's announcement, KMT lawmaker Hung Hsiu-chu said she felt sorry for him because he was treated unfairly in the opinion polls but admires him for putting the party's interests ahead of his own by stepping aside for Chu.
However, Wu Bing-rui head of the DPP's Taipei County Chapter, said Chou's decision confirmed the DPP's long-held view that he was doing a poor job and should be replaced.
The KMT should apologize for Chou's performance, Wu added.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen said it is regrettable that Chou has become a lame duck one year before the end of his term.

DPP Secretary-General Su Chia-chuan declined to comment on Chou's decision, saying only that his party will stick to its own process of choosing its candidates regardless the KMT's decisions. (By Sophia Yeh, Chen Ching-ping, Wang Hung-guo and Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Climate change should be national security issue: TV host
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 18:55:36 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make climate change one of the national security issues as island nations will be the first to suffer the impact of climate change, a noted political commentator and TV presenter said Monday.

"We hope that the climate change issue will be elevated to the national security level, " Sisy Chen told reporters ahead of a preview of her new documentary titled "Plus or Minus 2 Degrees Celsius" at a local movie theater.

"If I were president, I would definitely spend national defense funds on environmental protection and not the other way around, " said the producer of Taiwan's first documentary on the impact of climate change on the country.
Chen said that defense funds should be mainly used to buy rescue- related equipment such as helicopters.
"And I would make sure our troops were trained in disaster rescue operations," she went on.
Chen said she has watched many foreign films on climate change, none of which have covered the situation in Taiwan.
"I thought this meant Taiwan would be lucky enough to avoid much damage from climate change," she added.
After talking with experts, however, she said she realized that Taiwan would be among the first group of climate change victims.
She explained that by the time low-lying countries like the Maldives and Kiribati are inundated by rising sea levels, many parts of Taiwan would also be underwater.

They will include the port of Tungshih in the southern county of Chiayi, Tungkang and Linbian townships in the southern county of Pingtung, and Mailiao township in the southern county of Yunlin, where Taiwan's largest petrochemical industry is located.

She also said Taiwan's biggest environmental problem is its thermal power plants. Chen added that encouraging people to adopt a vegetarian diet would also a good way to help reduce global warming, as the livestock industry has been blamed for creating much of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.
She also said Taiwan should invest in green energy technologies. "The smart grid, for example, could help households save up to 70 percent in electricity costs."
Chen urged the public to use their votes to tell politicians at all levels that they will not receive support in elections if they fail to take action.
The documentary also calls on viewers to send e-mails to President Ma Ying-jeou to urge him to help save the planet.

Millions of people in Taiwan are expected to watch the world's devastating climate changes that have occurred in the past six months, as well as footage of Typhoon Morakot-ravaged southern Taiwan during the 70-minute film, which will be broadcast on TV and screened at special events around the country in the coming months.

It took less than five months to complete the shooting of the film, which had funding of NT$8 million from several business tycoons. The film's title reflects the widely held belief that the Earth's temperatures should be controlled within 2 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of young travelers coming to Taiwan up last year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 19:09:24 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The number of young travelers visiting Taiwan grew 8.19 percent to 1,060,196 last year, according to National Youth Commission (NYC) tallies published Monday.
"The increased number of foreign travelers in the 15-30 age bracket shows the potential of Taiwan's tourism market," the NYC said in a press release.
According to NYC statistics, more than half of the visitors came to Taiwan for the purpose of sightseeing.

The tallies also show that tourists from Hong Kong and Macau comprised the largest group, with a 15.44 percent increase from last year to 241,923. Tourists from Japan, however, decreased 0.72 percent to 189,766, while the number from South Korea dropped 25.85 percent to 36,715.
Comparing tourist numbers from the West with those from Asia, the statistics show that the majority -- more than 900,000 -- were from Asia, with females accounting for 543,000.
Visitors from Europe, the Americas and Africa, however, were mostly male.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier makes renewed push for innovation bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 19:36:11 (By Lee Shu-hua, Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Deh-yih argued Monday that a proposed bill to stimulate industrial innovation is not a giveaway to high-tech industries or conglomerates, as critics charge, and he said he hopes the bill can be passed in the new legislative session.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng promised that the bill will be listed as the top priority in the next legislative session, which is scheduled to start Tuesday and end on June 15.

Rebutting the legislation's critics, Wu said the bill is not intended to benefit any particular industry but will provide incentives to any industry or company that focuses on innovation, R&D, talent cultivation, and job creation.

To make the bill more palatable to critics, however, the Cabinet decided to withdraw the controversial Article 30, which would have offered a preferential 15 percent corporate income tax rate to any of the world's 500 biggest companies that locate their headquarters in Taiwan.
Those opposing the clause argued that the special rate would have unfairly benefited Taiwan's handful of companies in the top 500.
But the chairman of one of those companies, Terry Gou of the Hon Hai Group, has threatened to move the company's headquarters out of Taiwan if the bill passes and his company does not benefit.

Meanwhile, to boost employment, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday that a provision will be added to the bill that would grant small- and medium- sized enterprises (SMEs) in conventional industries a subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for six months for every additional worker they employ.
If the SMEs hire older workers, the subsidies could be extended to one year.

According to ministry officials, the average cost of subsidizing an additional worker would be NT$100,000, so the plan's NT$3 billion budget could create about 30,000 job opportunities, they estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate drops to one-year low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:04:46 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate slid to 5.68 percent in January, with 626,000 people out of work, marking the lowest figure in the past year, according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure represents a drop of 0.06 percentage points from the previous month and marked the fifth consecutive month in which the jobless rate decreased.

However, the number of jobless people aged between 45 and 64 grew to 142,000 in the same month, an increase of 1,000 people from the previous month. It marked the highest-ever January level and the largest growth scale among the various age groups, according to Liu Tien-tzu, deputy director of the DGBAS' fourth department.
Liu pointed out that most of the middle-aged jobless were elbowed out of their positions, which he described as a worrying phenomenon.
In January, the number of working people in Taiwan reached 10.39 million, an increase of 4,000 from last December, Liu went on.

The number of workers in the industrial and service sectors had risen to 6.41 million as of the end of December, representing a month-on-month growth of 24,000 and marking the highest figure for nearly 12 months, Liu said.
Even wages recorded growth, with the average monthly wage standing at NT$43,140 in December, posing an annual growth of 2.96 percent, Liu added.
Meanwhile, the number of people jobless for more than 12 months increased to 115,000 in January, up by 1,000 from the previous month and marking the highest level since 2004, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting a must: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:11:33 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that it is imperative to adopt an absentee voting system to protect the constitutional and human rights of Taiwan's electorate.
Ma said absentee voting is a necessity in a democratic country, though he suggested that it would be implemented gradually and that the extent of the measure would be open to discussion.
"It is something that must be done, " to protect the human rights of the country's citizens enshrined in the Constitution, the president said at a seminar held by the governing Kuomintang (KMT).
The idea should not be ignored simply because there is a lack of consensus, insisted Ma, who doubles as the KMT's chairman.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said the ministry has adopted a "more stable, fair" approach on absentee voting and intends to implement it gradually.

The government's plan would allow "transfer voting, " enabling election workers, military personnel, students and inmates to cast ballots in constituencies in which they are working, studying or serving sentences instead of in the electoral districts where their households are registered.
The ministry hopes to implement the proposal for the 2012 presidential election, Jiang said.

At present, Taiwan's voters must cast ballots in areas where their households are registered, but because many of them do not work or reside in the electoral districts where they are registered, they have to return to their registered addresses to vote.

Jiang stressed, however, that absentee voting by mail will not be allowed, meaning Taiwanese businessmen in China and other citizens living abroad would still be required to return home to cast their ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government raises 2010 GDP growth forecast to 4.72%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:46:55 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government statistics bureau has revised upwards its forecast for the country's economic growth in 2010 on the strength of a sustained global economic recovery, a senior official said Monday.

Shih Su-mei, the head of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , said the agency expects Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) to grow 4.72 percent this year, up from an earlier forecast of 4.39 percent.

Increased global demand for a number of new high-tech products, including e-readers, LED televisions, and touch screen and cloud computing products will bring enormous business opportunities to local industries, Shih said, leading the agency to adjust its forecast higher.

Taiwan's GDP is expected to reach NT$13.43 trillion (US$419.69 billion) this year and per capita gross national product (GNP) will hit US$18,175, both historical highs for the country, the official said.

Taiwan's U.S. dollar-denominated merchandise exports are expected to post 20.91 percent annual growth this year, Shih said, regaining much of the strength lost in 2009 when exports plummeted by more than 20 percent.
With the domestic economy regaining momentum, she also forecast private consumption to grow at a moderate 1.81 percent clip in 2010 and private investment to rise by 14.81 percent for the year.
If it pans out, the estimated private investment growth rate would be the highest since 2003, when domestic investment plunged amid the SARS outbreak, Shih said.
Meanwhile, the DGBAS forecast this year's GDP quarterly growth rates at 9.24 percent for Q1, 6.05 percent for Q2, 3.95 percent for Q3, and 0.66 percent for Q4.

The estimated growth rates for the first three quarters were all higher than forecasts made late last year, but the fourth quarter projection was adjusted downward because the baseline set in the fourth quarter of 2009 was higher than anticipated, Shih explained.

According to preliminary DGBAS estimates, Taiwan's GDP grew at a 9.22 percent rate in Q4 because of stronger-than-expected private consumption and robust growth in triangular trade and other service exports.
The GDP figure was 2.33 percentage points higher than the previous forecast and represented the highest quarterly growth rate since Q3 2004, said a DGBAS department chief.
"It also marked the first time that Taiwan posted positive year-on-year quarterly growth since Q3 2008, " said Tsai Hung-kun, head of the DGBAS' Third Bureau.
Nevertheless, Tsai said, Taiwan's economy still contracted by 1.87 percent for the whole of 2009 because of the global economic slump.
"Although the rate of negative growth rate was lower than the previous forecast of 2.53 percent, it was still the highest rate of contraction in our history," Tsai noted.

The better-than-expected 2009 Q4 economic numbers were the result of 6.27 percent growth in private consumption during the quarter, far higher than the 3.86 percent growth originally projected, Tsai said.
"Increased auto sales due to the imminent expiration of preferential automobile excise taxes contributed 1.8 percent in private consumption growth for the quarter, " Tsai said.
The stock market's rally during the period also helped boost private spending, as mutual fund trading service charges posted 154 percent growth for the quarter.

Service exports, and triangular trade in particular, also helped fuel Q4 growth, with triangular trade services (receiving orders in Taiwan while delivering goods from overseas destinations) amounting to US$4.5 billion, far exceeding the US$2.6 billion in revenues registered in Q4 2008.
A 22 percent increase in Chinese visitor numbers also contributed to the strong quarter, Tsai added.
As for inflation, Tsai said the agency projected the consumer price index to rise 1.27 percent in 2010.
"Although the figure is 0.92 percent higher than the previous forecast, the expected inflation rate is moderate, " said Tsai, who added that no inflationary pressures were expected during the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Los Angeles Dodgers could add one more game in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:56:54 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Dodgers could add an extra game to the two-game exhibition series they plan to play in Taiwan in mid-March, the event's promoter said Monday.
BROS Sports Marketing Co. said it asked Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) if it were willing to play another game, and the league has given its consent in principle.
The request for the extra game has also been relayed to the U.S. side, and an answer will be received on Tuesday at the earliest.
"If the Dodgers agree to play one more game, we will start selling tickets next week, " a BROS Sports Marketing executive said Monday, with the game to played in Taipei on March 12.
The Dodgers are currently scheduled to play two games in Taiwan in mid-March against a CPBL All-Star team, on March 13 in Taipei and on March 14 in Kaohsiung.

The executive said Taipei's Tienmu Baseball Stadium can only accommodate a crowd of 8,500 after seats with bad viewing angles are eliminated, prompting many fans to complain about the lack of tickets and leaving them hoping that the Dodgers could play one more game.
BROS revealed that several Dodgers felt it would be fine to play an extra game in Taipei.
This will be the Dodgers' second trip to Taiwan, and the third time since 2008 that a Major League team from the United States has traveled to Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: End tax exemption for servicemen, teachers

TEXT.P: During its last session, the Legislative Yuan shelved a draft amendment to the Income Tax Act aimed at revoking the income tax exemption for military servicemen and public school teachers.
At President Ma Ying-jeou's insistence, the ruling Kuomintang-controlled legislature has agreed to list the package as a priority bill to be passed during its new session.

The bill has become a test of Ma's moral integrity and his commitment to uphold fairness and justice in tax policy, as he promised on the presidential campaign trail. If the bill clears the legislative floor, we believe Ma will receive support and praise from independent voters.

One of the reasons the bill should be passed is because military and teaching jobs are no longer low-paying, as they were in the past. The incomes of teachers and military servicemen are actually much higher than the national average. Moreover, they enjoy lifelong pensions and many other fringe benefits. It is extremely unfair for them to be exempted from income tax payments.
A fair tax system is an important gauge of social progress. No other advanced country in the world offers tax exemptions for soldiers or officers.

Some senior military officers have reportedly threatened Ma not to reinstate income taxes on service members. They said the ruling Kuomintang's embarrassing defeat in January's legislative by-election was the result of a boycott of family members of many military servicemen due to their discontent with Ma's income tax reinstatement plan.
If such reports were true, we feel ashamed by the selfishness of our soldiers, and we hope Ma will never yield to their threat. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Local climate change film launched to raise awareness
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 21:35:03 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A locally produced documentary designed to warn people of the threats climate change poses to Taiwan and the world made its debut Monday in Taipei after hundreds of audience members shouted, "Save the Earth."

To mark the film's opening, Premier Wu Den-yih and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng joined other administration officials, lawmakers, business tycoons, entertainers, celebrities and volunteers in shouting, "Save the Earth. Save Taiwan. Save children."

The documentary titled "Plus or Minus 2 Degrees Celsius, " which reflects the widely held belief that the Earth's temperatures should be controlled within 2 degrees Celsius, was screened at a hall considered to be Taiwan's first public facility using green building technology.

The 70-minute film, which receiving NT$8 million in funding from Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, Quanta Computer Chairman Barry Lam and several other local businessmen, was completed less than five months after Typhoon Morakot ravaged southern Taiwan in August last year.

Sisy Chen, the main producer of what is being described as Taiwan's first documentary on the impact of climate change on the country, said she had watched many foreign films on climate change, but none had covered Taiwan.
"I thought this meant Taiwan would be lucky enough to avoid serious damage from climate change, " the noted political commentator and TV presenter said at a preview earlier in the day.
After talking with experts, however, she said she came to realize that Taiwan would be among the first group of climate change victims.
She explained that by the time low-lying countries such as Maldives and Kiribati are submerged by rising sea levels, several parts of Taiwan would also be under water.

They include the port of Dongshih in the southern county of Chiayi, Donggang and Linbian townships in the southern county of Pingtung, and Mailiao Township in the central-southern county of Yunlin, where Taiwan's largest petrochemical complex is located.
Chen therefore urged the government to elevate the climate change issue to the national security level.
The film features devastating climate changes that have occurred in the past six months, scientific graphics and footage of the Typhoon Morakot disaster.
The documentary will be broadcast on TV and screened at special events around the country, free of charge, in the coming months, with the number of viewers expected to be in the millions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of applicants for OTC listings to double to 40 this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 22:13:57 (By Han Ting-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The number of companies applying to list on Taiwan's over-the-counter (OTC) market is expected to double to 40 in 2010, the GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) said Monday.
GTSM Chairman Gordon Chen said that during last year's economic slump, only 20 companies applied to be listed, and he expected the number to increase to 40, or even 50, this year.

Among the potential applicants, 10 companies operating abroad are eyeing primary listings in Taiwan, including enterprises from China, Southeast Asia, and Silicon Valley in the United States, Chen said.
A company applying to engage in OTC trading must have paid-in capital of at least NT$50 million (US$1.56 million) . At present, there are 548 companies listed on the OTC.
Chen also expected that another 50 companies would apply to list on GreTai's emerging stock market in 2010, with 15 to 20 of them companies operated by Taiwanese businessmen abroad.
There are 235 companies currently listed on the emerging stock market.

Emerging stocks are common stocks traded on the GreTai Securities Market by means of negotiation. The companies listed have no revenue, capital, years of operation or shareholder number requirements, but they have registered their supervision agreement with recommending securities firms with GTSM.

DOC.HEADLINE: Millions to attend Lantern Festival celebrations around the island
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 22:39:38 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Fascinating lanterns and special events celebrating the Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 28 this year, will attract millions of visitors from home and abroad and boost business in the tourism sector, the Tourism Bureau said Monday.
Since 1990, the Tourism Bureau has pulled together the resources of local governments and the private sector to actively promote one of Taiwan's most celebrated and colorful traditional festivals.

It has staged the official Taiwan Lantern Festival celebration in a different city every year, and this year's host, Chiayi City in central Taiwan, is expecting the week-long festivities to draw 420,000 visitors and pump NT$1.68 billion into the local economy.

In Taipei, festivities at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall plaza will open on Feb. 26 and last until March 7, with student groups performing folk dances in the afternoons and professional dance troupes, bands and singers performing in the evenings.

Kaohsiung City opened its celebration of the Tiger Lamp Festival along the Love River on Feb. 20. The festivities will last until March 7 and feature shows showcasing performing artists from the United States, Japan, and Korea in addition to local music, dance and drama groups.

While lantern exhibitions around the island will highlight the traditional festival -- marking the 15th day of the first moon in the lunar calendar -- many practices related to folk beliefs are also big attractions for domestic and international tourists.

The most prominent include the "Fengpao" ceremony, where thousands of firecrackers hung on a tall wooden stand are set off in Yanshuei, Tainan County, and the spectacle of hundreds of lanterns being launched into the sky in Taipei County's Pingsi.
Also, on Feb. 27, large crowds will jump into the ocean near the scenic Yehliu Geopark on Taiwan's northern coast in a ritual bath in observance of local deities' visit to the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eslite to hold vinyl record exhibition and sale next month
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 22(CNA) 02/22/10 18:04:01 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Eslite bookstore will hold its annual "Vinyl Underground" exhibition and sale from March 5-14 to encourage people to discover the beauty of vintage music albums, according to the organizers.
The Dunhua branch of the bookstore will showcase more than 10,000 vinyl albums, with sale prices ranging from NT$99 to NT$30,000.

The exhibits will include Michael Jackson's "Black or White" and "Remember the Time, " Madonna's colored vinyl records, and the baseball music album "Baseball and Me" that was released in the first year of the local Chinese Professional Baseball League.

The exhibition is being supported by nine companies, including London Vintage International, Goodiscs and Joy Audio, and some individuals have offered to add their personal collections, the organizers said.

Vinyl records were the primary medium used for commercial music reproduction for most of the 20th century, but they are no longer in the mainstream. However, many fans and collectors still love the vintage sound they produce.
According to Eslite bookstore, the event has attracted many local and foreign fans in the last two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Strategy top, diplomacy only comes second

TEXT.P: The public has responded positively to seasoned diplomat Hu Wei-jen's appointment as secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC).

The NSC is the top strategic reference agency for the president, but its role should not be confined to that of national security and should be expanded to one with a broader vision and a wider strategic perspective.
Taiwan is facing the three biggest economies in the world -- the United States, Japan, and China -- and the relationships among the three are sensitive and complex.

To ensure national security and enhance the nation's wellbeing, it is in Taiwan's best interests to maintain balanced and complementary relations with each of the three. The Chinese classic "Sun Tzu on the Art of War" says strategy is the top approach to victory, and this is what we hope for in the new NSC secretary-general.

In reality, although the three countries are "strategic cooperation partners, " they are also enemies when their interests -- especially their economic interests -- clash, and it is for this reason that the NSC should not confine itself only to national security.

In terms of strategic planning, the economy should be further liberalized so that Taiwan can become a bridgehead for other countries making inroads into the Chinese market and other countries will be persuaded to set up their Asia- Pacific operations headquarters here.

Taiwan should also use all its available resources and non-conventional strategies, including networks, international publicity campaigns, lobbying and even humanitarian assistance to upgrade the nation's image internationally and solicit international support.
Adopting such an approach would be the best policy for consolidating Taiwan's security. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges `Taishang' to help publicize ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 18:19:42 (By Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of relations with China urged Taiwanese people with business operations in China -- known in Taiwan as "Taishang" -- to help publicize a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan urged the "Taishang" not only to support Taiwan's signing of the ECFA with China, but also to step forward to help publicize and promote the plan.

Speaking at a festive gathering to mark the first day of work after the Lunar New Year holiday, Lai called on the "Taishang" to expound to the public on the advantages that are expected to be created for all Taiwanese people by the signing of the ECFA.

The gathering was sponsored by Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), the MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China.
More than 200 "Taishang" representatives from all over China attended the function.

Addressing the gathering, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said the fifth round of talks with his Chinese counterpart -- Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will be held in the first half of 2010 as scheduled.
Major issues expected to be tackled at that meeting will include the signing of the ECFA, protection of intellectual property rights and avoidance of double taxation, Chiang said.

In related news, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that same day that a legislative mechanism should be established to allow the Legislative Yuan to supervise Taiwan's signing of any trade pact with China.

Since there is no law to serve as a legal basis for the legislature to oversee or screen agreements signed during talks between the SEF and ARATS, Wang urged all lawmakers to offer their opinions and suggestions to help build such a supervisory mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magistrate's decision not seek reelection draws mixed reactions

TEXT.P: Heavyweights of the ruling and opposition parties expressed mixed reactions Monday to Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei's announcement that he would not seek reelection in December after the county has been upgraded to a special municipality called Xinbei City.

Chou made the announcement following news reports that he had agreed to let Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu stand as the Kuomintang (KMT) candidate in light of the incumbent's low approval ratings in various opinion polls.
According to the reports, the KMT thinks Chu has a better chance of winning the election.

Chou said he reached the decision on his own and that there had been no pressure from KMT authorities. KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was given no advance notice of the decision before it was announced publicly, Chou added.
There is no law that requires an elected official to seek two consecutive terms, Chou noted, adding that he would perfer to be known as an exemplary single-term magistrate.

He pledged that when his term expires at the end of this year, he would leave his successor adequate funds and a well-developed infrastructure, in keeping with his promise when he assumed office four years ago.
The magistrate denied that he was offered some other government post in return for stepping aside, and he promised to support Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu in his bid for the Xinbei City seat.

Responding to Chou's announcement, KMT lawmaker Hung Hsiu-chu said she felt sorry for him because he was treated unfairly in the opinion polls but admires him for putting the party's interests ahead of his own by stepping aside for Chu.
However, Wu Bing-rui head of the DPP's Taipei County Chapter, said Chou's decision confirmed the DPP's long-held view that he was doing a poor job and should be replaced.
The KMT should apologize for Chou's performance, Wu added.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen said it is regrettable that Chou has become a lame duck one year before the end of his term.

DPP Secretary-General Su Chia-chuan declined to comment on Chou's decision, saying only that his party will stick to its own process of choosing its candidates regardless the KMT's decisions. (By Sophia Yeh, Chen Ching-ping, Wang Hung-guo and Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Climate change should be national security issue: TV host
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 18:55:36 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make climate change one of the national security issues as island nations will be the first to suffer the impact of climate change, a noted political commentator and TV presenter said Monday.

"We hope that the climate change issue will be elevated to the national security level, " Sisy Chen told reporters ahead of a preview of her new documentary titled "Plus or Minus 2 Degrees Celsius" at a local movie theater.

Chen said that defense funds should be mainly used to buy rescue- related equipment such as helicopters.
"And I would make sure our troops were trained in disaster rescue operations," she went on.
Chen said she has watched many foreign films on climate change, none of which have covered the situation in Taiwan.
"I thought this meant Taiwan would be lucky enough to avoid much damage from climate change," she added.
After talking with experts, however, she said she realized that Taiwan would be among the first group of climate change victims.
She explained that by the time low-lying countries like the Maldives and Kiribati are inundated by rising sea levels, many parts of Taiwan would also be underwater.

They will include the port of Tungshih in the southern county of Chiayi, Tungkang and Linbian townships in the southern county of Pingtung, and Mailiao township in the southern county of Yunlin, where Taiwan's largest petrochemical industry is located.

She also said Taiwan's biggest environmental problem is its thermal power plants. Chen added that encouraging people to adopt a vegetarian diet would also a good way to help reduce global warming, as the livestock industry has been blamed for creating much of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.
She also said Taiwan should invest in green energy technologies. "The smart grid, for example, could help households save up to 70 percent in electricity costs."
Chen urged the public to use their votes to tell politicians at all levels that they will not receive support in elections if they fail to take action.
The documentary also calls on viewers to send e-mails to President Ma Ying-jeou to urge him to help save the planet.

Millions of people in Taiwan are expected to watch the world's devastating climate changes that have occurred in the past six months, as well as footage of Typhoon Morakot-ravaged southern Taiwan during the 70-minute film, which will be broadcast on TV and screened at special events around the country in the coming months.

It took less than five months to complete the shooting of the film, which had funding of NT$8 million from several business tycoons. The film's title reflects the widely held belief that the Earth's temperatures should be controlled within 2 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of young travelers coming to Taiwan up last year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 19:09:24 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The number of young travelers visiting Taiwan grew 8.19 percent to 1,060,196 last year, according to National Youth Commission (NYC) tallies published Monday.
"The increased number of foreign travelers in the 15-30 age bracket shows the potential of Taiwan's tourism market," the NYC said in a press release.
According to NYC statistics, more than half of the visitors came to Taiwan for the purpose of sightseeing.

The tallies also show that tourists from Hong Kong and Macau comprised the largest group, with a 15.44 percent increase from last year to 241,923. Tourists from Japan, however, decreased 0.72 percent to 189,766, while the number from South Korea dropped 25.85 percent to 36,715.
Comparing tourist numbers from the West with those from Asia, the statistics show that the majority -- more than 900,000 -- were from Asia, with females accounting for 543,000.
Visitors from Europe, the Americas and Africa, however, were mostly male.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier makes renewed push for innovation bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 19:36:11 (By Lee Shu-hua, Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Deh-yih argued Monday that a proposed bill to stimulate industrial innovation is not a giveaway to high-tech industries or conglomerates, as critics charge, and he said he hopes the bill can be passed in the new legislative session.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng promised that the bill will be listed as the top priority in the next legislative session, which is scheduled to start Tuesday and end on June 15.

Rebutting the legislation's critics, Wu said the bill is not intended to benefit any particular industry but will provide incentives to any industry or company that focuses on innovation, R&D, talent cultivation, and job creation.

To make the bill more palatable to critics, however, the Cabinet decided to withdraw the controversial Article 30, which would have offered a preferential 15 percent corporate income tax rate to any of the world's 500 biggest companies that locate their headquarters in Taiwan.
Those opposing the clause argued that the special rate would have unfairly benefited Taiwan's handful of companies in the top 500.
But the chairman of one of those companies, Terry Gou of the Hon Hai Group, has threatened to move the company's headquarters out of Taiwan if the bill passes and his company does not benefit.

Meanwhile, to boost employment, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday that a provision will be added to the bill that would grant small- and medium- sized enterprises (SMEs) in conventional industries a subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for six months for every additional worker they employ.
If the SMEs hire older workers, the subsidies could be extended to one year.

According to ministry officials, the average cost of subsidizing an additional worker would be NT$100,000, so the plan's NT$3 billion budget could create about 30,000 job opportunities, they estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate drops to one-year low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:04:46 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate slid to 5.68 percent in January, with 626,000 people out of work, marking the lowest figure in the past year, according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure represents a drop of 0.06 percentage points from the previous month and marked the fifth consecutive month in which the jobless rate decreased.

However, the number of jobless people aged between 45 and 64 grew to 142,000 in the same month, an increase of 1,000 people from the previous month. It marked the highest-ever January level and the largest growth scale among the various age groups, according to Liu Tien-tzu, deputy director of the DGBAS' fourth department.
Liu pointed out that most of the middle-aged jobless were elbowed out of their positions, which he described as a worrying phenomenon.
In January, the number of working people in Taiwan reached 10.39 million, an increase of 4,000 from last December, Liu went on.

The number of workers in the industrial and service sectors had risen to 6.41 million as of the end of December, representing a month-on-month growth of 24,000 and marking the highest figure for nearly 12 months, Liu said.
Even wages recorded growth, with the average monthly wage standing at NT$43,140 in December, posing an annual growth of 2.96 percent, Liu added.
Meanwhile, the number of people jobless for more than 12 months increased to 115,000 in January, up by 1,000 from the previous month and marking the highest level since 2004, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Absentee voting a must: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:11:33 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that it is imperative to adopt an absentee voting system to protect the constitutional and human rights of Taiwan's electorate.
Ma said absentee voting is a necessity in a democratic country, though he suggested that it would be implemented gradually and that the extent of the measure would be open to discussion.
"It is something that must be done, " to protect the human rights of the country's citizens enshrined in the Constitution, the president said at a seminar held by the governing Kuomintang (KMT).
The idea should not be ignored simply because there is a lack of consensus, insisted Ma, who doubles as the KMT's chairman.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said the ministry has adopted a "more stable, fair" approach on absentee voting and intends to implement it gradually.

The government's plan would allow "transfer voting, " enabling election workers, military personnel, students and inmates to cast ballots in constituencies in which they are working, studying or serving sentences instead of in the electoral districts where their households are registered.
The ministry hopes to implement the proposal for the 2012 presidential election, Jiang said.

At present, Taiwan's voters must cast ballots in areas where their households are registered, but because many of them do not work or reside in the electoral districts where they are registered, they have to return to their registered addresses to vote.

Jiang stressed, however, that absentee voting by mail will not be allowed, meaning Taiwanese businessmen in China and other citizens living abroad would still be required to return home to cast their ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government raises 2010 GDP growth forecast to 4.72%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:46:55 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government statistics bureau has revised upwards its forecast for the country's economic growth in 2010 on the strength of a sustained global economic recovery, a senior official said Monday.

Shih Su-mei, the head of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , said the agency expects Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) to grow 4.72 percent this year, up from an earlier forecast of 4.39 percent.

Increased global demand for a number of new high-tech products, including e-readers, LED televisions, and touch screen and cloud computing products will bring enormous business opportunities to local industries, Shih said, leading the agency to adjust its forecast higher.

Taiwan's GDP is expected to reach NT$13.43 trillion (US$419.69 billion) this year and per capita gross national product (GNP) will hit US$18,175, both historical highs for the country, the official said.

Taiwan's U.S. dollar-denominated merchandise exports are expected to post 20.91 percent annual growth this year, Shih said, regaining much of the strength lost in 2009 when exports plummeted by more than 20 percent.
With the domestic economy regaining momentum, she also forecast private consumption to grow at a moderate 1.81 percent clip in 2010 and private investment to rise by 14.81 percent for the year.
If it pans out, the estimated private investment growth rate would be the highest since 2003, when domestic investment plunged amid the SARS outbreak, Shih said.
Meanwhile, the DGBAS forecast this year's GDP quarterly growth rates at 9.24 percent for Q1, 6.05 percent for Q2, 3.95 percent for Q3, and 0.66 percent for Q4.

The estimated growth rates for the first three quarters were all higher than forecasts made late last year, but the fourth quarter projection was adjusted downward because the baseline set in the fourth quarter of 2009 was higher than anticipated, Shih explained.

According to preliminary DGBAS estimates, Taiwan's GDP grew at a 9.22 percent rate in Q4 because of stronger-than-expected private consumption and robust growth in triangular trade and other service exports.
The GDP figure was 2.33 percentage points higher than the previous forecast and represented the highest quarterly growth rate since Q3 2004, said a DGBAS department chief.
"It also marked the first time that Taiwan posted positive year-on-year quarterly growth since Q3 2008, " said Tsai Hung-kun, head of the DGBAS' Third Bureau.
Nevertheless, Tsai said, Taiwan's economy still contracted by 1.87 percent for the whole of 2009 because of the global economic slump.
"Although the rate of negative growth rate was lower than the previous forecast of 2.53 percent, it was still the highest rate of contraction in our history," Tsai noted.

The better-than-expected 2009 Q4 economic numbers were the result of 6.27 percent growth in private consumption during the quarter, far higher than the 3.86 percent growth originally projected, Tsai said.
"Increased auto sales due to the imminent expiration of preferential automobile excise taxes contributed 1.8 percent in private consumption growth for the quarter, " Tsai said.
The stock market's rally during the period also helped boost private spending, as mutual fund trading service charges posted 154 percent growth for the quarter.

Service exports, and triangular trade in particular, also helped fuel Q4 growth, with triangular trade services (receiving orders in Taiwan while delivering goods from overseas destinations) amounting to US$4.5 billion, far exceeding the US$2.6 billion in revenues registered in Q4 2008.
A 22 percent increase in Chinese visitor numbers also contributed to the strong quarter, Tsai added.
As for inflation, Tsai said the agency projected the consumer price index to rise 1.27 percent in 2010.
"Although the figure is 0.92 percent higher than the previous forecast, the expected inflation rate is moderate, " said Tsai, who added that no inflationary pressures were expected during the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Los Angeles Dodgers could add one more game in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 20:56:54 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Dodgers could add an extra game to the two-game exhibition series they plan to play in Taiwan in mid-March, the event's promoter said Monday.
BROS Sports Marketing Co. said it asked Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) if it were willing to play another game, and the league has given its consent in principle.
The request for the extra game has also been relayed to the U.S. side, and an answer will be received on Tuesday at the earliest.
"If the Dodgers agree to play one more game, we will start selling tickets next week, " a BROS Sports Marketing executive said Monday, with the game to played in Taipei on March 12.
The Dodgers are currently scheduled to play two games in Taiwan in mid-March against a CPBL All-Star team, on March 13 in Taipei and on March 14 in Kaohsiung.

The executive said Taipei's Tienmu Baseball Stadium can only accommodate a crowd of 8,500 after seats with bad viewing angles are eliminated, prompting many fans to complain about the lack of tickets and leaving them hoping that the Dodgers could play one more game.
BROS revealed that several Dodgers felt it would be fine to play an extra game in Taipei.
This will be the Dodgers' second trip to Taiwan, and the third time since 2008 that a Major League team from the United States has traveled to Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: End tax exemption for servicemen, teachers

TEXT.P: During its last session, the Legislative Yuan shelved a draft amendment to the Income Tax Act aimed at revoking the income tax exemption for military servicemen and public school teachers.
At President Ma Ying-jeou's insistence, the ruling Kuomintang-controlled legislature has agreed to list the package as a priority bill to be passed during its new session.

The bill has become a test of Ma's moral integrity and his commitment to uphold fairness and justice in tax policy, as he promised on the presidential campaign trail. If the bill clears the legislative floor, we believe Ma will receive support and praise from independent voters.

One of the reasons the bill should be passed is because military and teaching jobs are no longer low-paying, as they were in the past. The incomes of teachers and military servicemen are actually much higher than the national average. Moreover, they enjoy lifelong pensions and many other fringe benefits. It is extremely unfair for them to be exempted from income tax payments.
A fair tax system is an important gauge of social progress. No other advanced country in the world offers tax exemptions for soldiers or officers.

Some senior military officers have reportedly threatened Ma not to reinstate income taxes on service members. They said the ruling Kuomintang's embarrassing defeat in January's legislative by-election was the result of a boycott of family members of many military servicemen due to their discontent with Ma's income tax reinstatement plan.
If such reports were true, we feel ashamed by the selfishness of our soldiers, and we hope Ma will never yield to their threat. (Feb. 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Local climate change film launched to raise awareness
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 21:35:03 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A locally produced documentary designed to warn people of the threats climate change poses to Taiwan and the world made its debut Monday in Taipei after hundreds of audience members shouted, "Save the Earth."

To mark the film's opening, Premier Wu Den-yih and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng joined other administration officials, lawmakers, business tycoons, entertainers, celebrities and volunteers in shouting, "Save the Earth. Save Taiwan. Save children."

The documentary titled "Plus or Minus 2 Degrees Celsius, " which reflects the widely held belief that the Earth's temperatures should be controlled within 2 degrees Celsius, was screened at a hall considered to be Taiwan's first public facility using green building technology.

The 70-minute film, which receiving NT$8 million in funding from Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, Quanta Computer Chairman Barry Lam and several other local businessmen, was completed less than five months after Typhoon Morakot ravaged southern Taiwan in August last year.

Sisy Chen, the main producer of what is being described as Taiwan's first documentary on the impact of climate change on the country, said she had watched many foreign films on climate change, but none had covered Taiwan.
"I thought this meant Taiwan would be lucky enough to avoid serious damage from climate change, " the noted political commentator and TV presenter said at a preview earlier in the day.
After talking with experts, however, she said she came to realize that Taiwan would be among the first group of climate change victims.
She explained that by the time low-lying countries such as Maldives and Kiribati are submerged by rising sea levels, several parts of Taiwan would also be under water.

They include the port of Dongshih in the southern county of Chiayi, Donggang and Linbian townships in the southern county of Pingtung, and Mailiao Township in the central-southern county of Yunlin, where Taiwan's largest petrochemical complex is located.
Chen therefore urged the government to elevate the climate change issue to the national security level.
The film features devastating climate changes that have occurred in the past six months, scientific graphics and footage of the Typhoon Morakot disaster.
The documentary will be broadcast on TV and screened at special events around the country, free of charge, in the coming months, with the number of viewers expected to be in the millions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of applicants for OTC listings to double to 40 this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 22:13:57 (By Han Ting-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The number of companies applying to list on Taiwan's over-the-counter (OTC) market is expected to double to 40 in 2010, the GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) said Monday.
GTSM Chairman Gordon Chen said that during last year's economic slump, only 20 companies applied to be listed, and he expected the number to increase to 40, or even 50, this year.

Among the potential applicants, 10 companies operating abroad are eyeing primary listings in Taiwan, including enterprises from China, Southeast Asia, and Silicon Valley in the United States, Chen said.
A company applying to engage in OTC trading must have paid-in capital of at least NT$50 million (US$1.56 million) . At present, there are 548 companies listed on the OTC.
Chen also expected that another 50 companies would apply to list on GreTai's emerging stock market in 2010, with 15 to 20 of them companies operated by Taiwanese businessmen abroad.
There are 235 companies currently listed on the emerging stock market.

Emerging stocks are common stocks traded on the GreTai Securities Market by means of negotiation. The companies listed have no revenue, capital, years of operation or shareholder number requirements, but they have registered their supervision agreement with recommending securities firms with GTSM.

DOC.HEADLINE: Millions to attend Lantern Festival celebrations around the island
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/22/10 22:39:38 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Fascinating lanterns and special events celebrating the Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 28 this year, will attract millions of visitors from home and abroad and boost business in the tourism sector, the Tourism Bureau said Monday.
Since 1990, the Tourism Bureau has pulled together the resources of local governments and the private sector to actively promote one of Taiwan's most celebrated and colorful traditional festivals.

It has staged the official Taiwan Lantern Festival celebration in a different city every year, and this year's host, Chiayi City in central Taiwan, is expecting the week-long festivities to draw 420,000 visitors and pump NT$1.68 billion into the local economy.

In Taipei, festivities at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall plaza will open on Feb. 26 and last until March 7, with student groups performing folk dances in the afternoons and professional dance troupes, bands and singers performing in the evenings.

Kaohsiung City opened its celebration of the Tiger Lamp Festival along the Love River on Feb. 20. The festivities will last until March 7 and feature shows showcasing performing artists from the United States, Japan, and Korea in addition to local music, dance and drama groups.

While lantern exhibitions around the island will highlight the traditional festival -- marking the 15th day of the first moon in the lunar calendar -- many practices related to folk beliefs are also big attractions for domestic and international tourists.

The most prominent include the "Fengpao" ceremony, where thousands of firecrackers hung on a tall wooden stand are set off in Yanshuei, Tainan County, and the spectacle of hundreds of lanterns being launched into the sky in Taipei County's Pingsi.
Also, on Feb. 27, large crowds will jump into the ocean near the scenic Yehliu Geopark on Taiwan's northern coast in a ritual bath in observance of local deities' visit to the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 23, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."
