DOC.HEADLINE: DOH mulls financing artificial births
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 12:18:59 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is considering financing artificial births as a last resort to boost Taiwan's declining birth rate, after a spate of measures to reverse the trend have not produced the desired results.
The DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion is expected to propose the idea at a meeting called by the Ministry of the Interior that will discuss policy incentives to increase Taiwan's birth rate.
Wu Hsiu-ying, deputy director-general of the bureau, said Taiwan can emulate its Asian neighbors, including Japan, Singapore and South Korea, to financially support artificial reproduction.

In South Korea, Wu said, married women under the age of 45 who are unable to have babies are allowed to apply up to two times for a grant of NT$50,000 (US$1,563) to participate in the artificial reproduction plan.
Professionals with the Taiwanese Society for Reproductive Medicine welcomed the idea.

Wu Kuo-chang, director of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Tri- Service General Hospital, said that about 8,000 to 10,000 child-seeking Taiwanese couples try to have babies through artificial reproduction each year at an average cost of NT$100,000 per attempt.

"If the government subsidizes half of the cost, equal to about NT$400 million to NT$500 million a year, it would help those who want to have children but can't, contribute to the birth rate," Wu said.

Chen Hsin-fu, a doctor with National Taiwan University Hospital's Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility Division, said the number of couples seeking to reproduce artificially increased by over one-third in South Korea after its government implemented its financial assistance plan.
If Taiwan follows suit, based on an average test tube baby success rate of 25-35 percent, an additional 1,000 new babies could be born in the country each year, Chen said.

Lee Mao-sheng, a board member of the Taiwanese Society for Reproductive Medicine, said Taiwan has among the lowest birth rates of any country in the world at 8.3 births per 1,000 people, comparable to Germany and even lower than Austria and Japan, countries with traditionally low birth rates.
Citing statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior, Lee said that in 2009, there were 191,310 babies born in Taiwan, a decrease of 3.7 percent from the previous year.
With roughly about one in seven married couples finding it difficult to have a child, the financial assistance idea could help stem the decline, Lee contended.
"If the funding incentive is implemented, child-seeking Taiwanese couples, financially-disadvantaged ones in particular, will directly benefit," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Taoyuan airport needs a new vision

TEXT.P: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the nation's gateway to the world, has not performed satisfactorily despite the nation's progress in developing its infrastructure.

Airports Council International (ACI) recently announced the top performing airports in its annual airport service quality passenger survey, with Asia Pacific airports sweeping the top spots. The top honors went to the airports in Seoul, Singapore, Hong Kong, Beijing and Hyderabad.
The Taoyuan airport's ranking, on the other hand, plunged to 27th place in 2009 from 14th in 2007. We have to reflect upon the big drop.

Those who have visited the five top airports will immediately notice the difference. The first would be the flow of passengers of every race, color and dress, as well as the airports' fully packed restaurants and boutiques.
In comparison, restaurants at the Taoyuan airport are poor in quality and quantity, and charge prohibitively high prices even though they do not showcase Taiwan's many gourmet cuisines.

The shops have no cultural features and the design of the airport has no style. It seems that there is no overall concept to its management, and it is not well connected to mass rapid transportation systems.

The government should strengthen its facilities and management and aim at making the airport an important hub in Asia by strengthening links with local tourism, promoting cultural marketing, soliciting more passengers and building a convenient transportation network.

We know that the airport's many woes result from low passenger numbers, making operational costs higher. We therefore believe the government needs to give it more support, at least in the initial stage. But in the longer term, it will need a visionary national marketing plan. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan reports fastest economic growth in years
DOC.DATELINE: Gross domestic product (GDP) 02/23/10 13:01:53 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: in Taiwan surged 9.22 percent in the fourth quarter on a year-on-year basis, 2.33 percentage points higher than previously forecast.
The government statistics bureau attributed the rebound to robust exports, strong private consumption and increasing visits by tourists from China.

The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) also revised upwards its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth in 2010, predicting GDP will grow 4.72 percent rather than the previously forecast 4.39 percent.
The following are excerpts from local newspaper coverage of the issue:
Commercial Times:

According to preliminary DGBAS estimates, Taiwan's GDP grew 9.22 percent in Q4 because of stronger-than-expected private consumption, robust growth in triangular trade (receiving orders in Taiwan and shipping the goods from overseas destinations) , and an increase in Chinese visitors.
The figure represented the highest quarterly growth rate since Q3 2004.
The DGBAS also forecast that Taiwan's per capita gross national product (GNP) will hit a historical high of over US$18,000 this year.
Taiwan first posted per-capita GNP of US$10,000 in 1992, which grew to US$17,000 in 2007, before the onset of the global financial storm.
China Times:

Most scholars remain cautious over the perception that rising GDP growth will benefit the labor market. National Dong Hwa University's College of Management Dean Wu Chung-shu believes the economic outlook will continue to get better.

However, although the DGBAS forecast a 4.72 percent GDP growth rate for this year, such a performance can only be seen as a "gradual recovery " instead of a "robust recovery, " Wu said, casting doubt that the recovery will greatly help improve unemployment.
Economic Daily News:

Although the DGBAS predicted the country will enjoy an economic growth rate of 4.72 percent this year, the recovery still faces four potential problems -- credit issues, appreciation of the Chinese yuan, currency policy and the ending of easy monetary policies.

Scholars and Council for Economic Planning and Development officials suggested extra attention should be paid to the possible impact of the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement between the two sides across Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Bert J. Lim, head of the World Economics Society, asked the government to ponder the possible challenges facing Taiwan's economic growth, including doubts that growth in "triangular trade" can promote the expansion of the domestic manufacturing and commercial services sectors.
Lim also appeared cautious about a solid recovery in Taiwan this year, citing the DGBAS' forecast of a gradual quarterly decline in the real GDP growth rate.
It is also debatable whether increasing investment -- mostly from high-tech industries -- can greatly help strengthen domestic income, employment and tax revenues, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier mum on successor issue of his deputy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 13:10:23 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih would not speculate Tuesday on who will succeed Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu if Chu becomes the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) nominee in the year-end mayoral election in Xinbei City, as the upgraded Taipei County will be known.

Noting that Chu is still working as vice premier and the KMT has yet to complete the nomination process for a candidate in the race, Wu said the issue of Chu's successor will be discussed at a later date.

Meanwhile, Chu declined to comment on a poll conducted by The China Times, which says that former Premier Su Tseng-chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party would beat Chu by 11 percentage points in the Xinbei City mayoral election. The election is widely seen as a bellwether of the KMT's chances in the 2012 presidential race.

Chu asserted that he remained focused on his duties as vice premier, which he defined as tackling unemployment and bringing the jobless rate to under 5 percent, reviving domestic economic growth to at least 4.8 percent, and stabilizing commodity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--- Chou Hsi-wei forsakes bid for re-election
DOC.DATELINE: 02/23/10 14:12:34 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei's decision not to run for re-election in year-end elections dominated local newspaper headlines Tuesday.
The following are excerpts of the leading newspaper's report about it:
China Times:

Although Chou decided to step aside to make way for Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu to run for the top spot in Xinbei City, as the upgraded Taipei County has been provisionally named, Chu lags behind his possible Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Su Tseng-chang, in a poll conducted by the China Times.
The survey carried out Monday after Chou announced his decision showed that Su leads Chu 40 percent to 29 percent.

Su's support rate remained almost unchanged compared to a similar survey by The China Times in February when he received 41 percent of the vote, while Chu's support rate declined by 7 percentage points, probably because of the public's sympathy for Chou.
However, Chu would defeat three other DPP leaders -- Tsai Ing-wen, Yu Shyi-kun and Frank Hsieh -- in a two-way race, according to the survey.
Although Chou's decision was made with the presumption that Su will be the DPP's nominee in the race, the former premier kept his cards close to his vest Monday.
One of Su's aides said Su would not rule out any possibility for the time being.
DPP lawmakers were split over how the party should respond to Chou's decision.

Legislator Wang Sing-nan said Su should take up the challenge because whichever party wins three of the five seats up for grabs in the year-end special municipality elections will gain an advantage in the 2012 presidential election.

On the other hand, Legislator Gao Jyh-peng said the move was a trap set for Su by the KMT, and he urged Su not to play into the KMT's hands by running in Xinbei City. (Feb. 23, 2010) The Liberty Times:
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen dismissed Chou's decision as a KMT campaign trick designed to boost its underdog candidates in the Feb. 27 legislative by- elections.
"It is regrettable that Chou became a lame duck one year before the end of his term. It hurt Chou, Chu and the voters of Taipei County." Tsai said. (Feb. 23, 2010) United Daily News:

Chou has only himself to blame for his low approval rating, especially after he tarnished his image irrevocably in 2007 when he led a group of officials to track a tiger that had reportedly eaten goats in a county town.
The tiger turned out to be a stray dog, turning Chou into a laughingstock.
However, he will be remembered as an unselfish statesman who put his party's benefit ahead of his own because of his decision not to seek re-election.
His decision, however, does not ensure Chu's election in Xinbei City, as the KMT administration's overall approval rating is still flagging.

Furthermore, local elected officials in Taipei County who will lose their jobs after the county is converted into a municipality might vote for the opposition party out of anger, and by the same token, Chou's followers might not support Chu in an election. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may hold LPGA tournament in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 15:05:02 (By Lin Chingping and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may be included as a stop on the Ladies Professional Golf Association (LPGA) tour next year if sponsors can be found to help finance a tournament that may carry a US$4 million price tag.

Eily Ho, manager of the Peitou Kuohua Golf County Club in Taipei, said she discussed the possibility of holding an LPGA tournament in Taiwan with LPGA officials on the sideline of the 2010 PGA Merchandise Show in Orlando, Florida early this month.
"They responded positively," she said.

Ho has targeted Oct. 25, 2011, during the LPGA Tour's yearly Asian swing in the fall, as the date for the tournament in Taiwan. She hopes to offer a purse as high as US$2 million, US$700,000 more than the US$1.3 million in prize money put up at the Honda PTT LPGA Thailand, which concluded Feb. 21 in Pattaya.
In addition to the prize money, another US$2 million is needed to finance the cost of holding the tournament, said Ho, who has begun to look actively for sponsors.

Taiwan-born LPGA star Yani Tseng, who urged President Ma Ying-jeou last year to have the government sponsor an LPGA tournament in Taiwan, told the Central News Agency in Pattaya Tuesday that she looked forward to a tour event being played in her home country.

Noting that the Honda PTT LPGA Thailand had brought together more than 30 of the top female golfers from around the world, Tseng said she was sure a tour stop in Taiwan would attract even more top players and spectators and enhance the island's profile significantly.

The LPGA Tour has been hit hard by the global economic downturn, with many sponsors dropping their support of women's golf. Thirty-three events were scheduled last year (though only 30 were played), compared to 26 tournaments scheduled for 2010.
That has left many open dates for those interested in holding LPGA tournaments, but it has proven to be a tough sell in today's difficult economic environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The appreciation of China's currency

TEXT.P: China raised its deposit reserve requirement ratio prior to the Chinese New Year holiday for the second time this year. The international community saw it as an attempt to cushion inflationary pressures due to the influx of hot money, which flowed into the country in anticipation of the appreciation of the Chinese yuan.

With Goldman Sachs predicting yuan appreciation and the possibility that the Obama administration could force China to appreciate its currency, the speed and scale of hot money flowing into China will only accelerate, affecting its economic stability and straining already tense U.S.-China relations.
If the tensions deepen, it will affect the nascent global economic recovery, and Taiwan will not come out unscathed.
Is yuan appreciation unavoidable? We believe the answer is positive.
The appreciation of the yuan will lead to China losing its edge in labor- intensive industries, but it will also force China to embark on upgrading its industrial base.
In that case, there will no longer be a vertical division of labor between Taiwan and China. Instead, the two will be pitted against each other as direct competitors.
And that means the yuan appreciation will not only be China's problem but a threat to Taiwan's economic future as well. Facing such a threat, how is possible not to prepare seriously to counter it?

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP heavyweight to make Xinbei bid known after by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 16:00:52 (By Andrew Liu, Wang Hung-kuo, Vicky Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweight Su Tseng-chang, widely believed to be the DPP's nominee in the year-end mayoral election in Xinbei City, as the upgraded Taipei County will be called, said Tuesday that he will make his intentions known after Feb. 27 legislative by-elections.

Su, who served as premier under former President Chen Shui-bian, said in the eastern county of Hualien that he will not "dance to the tune" of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , which he accused of having schemed to upgrade or merge several cities into new municipalities and to force Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi- wei to forsake his bid to enter the Xinbei City mayoral race.
"All these schemes targeted me, " he claimed during a campaign rally in Hualien to drum up support for DPP candidate Hsiao Bi-khim in the legislative by- election there.

Meanwhile, three DPP councilors of Taipei County urged Su Tuesday to announce his bid for the Xinbei City mayoral election as soon as possible to generate a "coattails effect" for the DPP, as the popular politician's endorsement could boost the DPP's chances in the race.

In related news, KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih said that same day that the ruling party should immediately name Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu as the KMT's nominee for the Xinbei City mayoral race, an election widely seen as a bellwether of the KMT's chances in the 2012 presidential election.

Noting that according to a China Times poll, Su would beat Chu by 11 percentage points in a Xinbei City mayoral election, Wu said Chu should quit his post now and begin his campaign drive to broaden his support base before it is too late.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: The public has read the president's mind

TEXT.P: Legislative by-elections will be held in the four counties of Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Chiayi and Hualien Feb. 27.
The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) presently has 74 seats in the legislature, compared with the 30 seats held by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
In the face of this huge imbalance in the legislature in his favor, why is President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, making such all-out efforts to stump for KMT candidates?
His extreme uneasiness can be traced to his keen desire to have more of his people in the legislature to rubberstamp his "China-tilt" policy.

We know that policy toward China is the most sensitive issue in Taiwan, and one that requires an internal consensus prior to earning public trust. But whether it has been signing agreements with China, amending laws or administrative orders, the Ma administration has conducted all of them in closed-door meetings and has refused to countenance even the minimum of legislative supervision.
It should be clear now why Ma is putting aside his duties as the nation's president and is so busy stumping for his men prior to the elections. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier forecasts 2010 economic growth of 4.9%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 16:25:10 (By Kelven Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that Taiwan's gross domestic product for 2010 will rise to 4.9 percent, higher than the government's bureau of statistics' estimate.
In his policy address to the Legislative Yuan, Wu highlighted the government's plans to achieve economic development.

Citing the latest forecast by Global Insight, Wu said Taiwan economic recovery will be steady and economic growth of 4.9 percent will be achieved this year, which will be higher than the projected average 2.9 percent globally. Taiwan will also surpass the economic growth rate of the United States, Japan, the European Union, Hong Kong, and South Korea this year, he predicted.
He said his Cabinet's economic goals for 2010 include lifting Taiwan's ranking in the World Business Environment Survey 10 notches higher than its 46th place in 2009.
The Cabinet also aims to improve the country's business and investment environment and has set a private investment target of NT$1 trillion (US$31.22 billion) this year, he said.

He further expressed hopes that the production value of the country's six main emerging sectors -- biotech, green energy, tourism, health care, quality agriculture and cultural innovation -- will increase from the projected NT$2.1 trillion for this year to NT$2.8 trillion in 2012 and will provide 152,000 new job opportunities.

Speaking of the government's efforts to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Wu predicted that the pact will help boost Taiwan's GDP by 1.65 percent to 1.72 percent and produce 257,000 to 263,000 jobs.
The ECFA will "help people do business, and boost Taiwan's competitiveness," the premier said.
Other government initiatives will include building housing units for low-income and less-privilege families and providing low-interest loans for the young people to lease or purchase homes, he said.
On the issue of global warming, Wu promised that all governmental institutions and public schools around the country will adopt measures to save energy and reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
He also mentioned plans to formulate criteria for the development of low-carbon cities and to promote low-carbon sightseeing tours in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FamilyMart stores begin selling high speed rail tickets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 16:41:42 (By S. F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A total of 2,425 FamilyMart convenience stores across the country started offering high speed rail ticketing services Tuesday, enabling passengers to buy or pick up tickets outside train stations in mere minutes.
As of 9: 45 a.m., 345 orders for tickets had been placed at Taiwan FamilyMart Co. convenience stores countrywide, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) said Tuesday.

The convenience store's ticketing system hopes to cash in on the ticket buying habits of high speed rail passengers. According to THSRC research, 70 percent of its customers buy tickets earlier on the same day that they travel.

Using the FamilyMart service network, passengers will be able to book tickets for trains departing from one hour to 15 days after the purchase is made for an extra service charge of NT$10 per ticket, THSRC said.
In addition, the company explained, the public can also book high speed rail tickets on the Internet or by telephone in advance and then pick them up at FamilyMart convenience stores.

FamilyMart has invested some NT$50 million (US$1.56 million) in the ticketing system, and the tickets passengers get at its stores will have upgraded anti- forgery safety measures and QR code numbers. A QR code is a two-dimensional bar code.
More than 4,000 7-Eleven convenience stores are also expected to offer the high speed rail ticketing system in May after the negotiations between the two companies come to a conclusion, THSRC added.
According to a THSRC spokesman, the company is planning to launch stored value cards in the form of ticket books and monthly passes with discounts in the months ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Career diplomat takes over as National Security Council chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 16:46:16 (By Garfie Lee and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Hu Wei-jen, a former de facto ambassador to Singapore, assumed office Tuesday as secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC) , Taiwan's top authority governing national security affairs.
In a ceremony hosted by Vice President Vincent Siew, Hu accepted the official seal from his predecessor Su Chi, who resigned Feb. 11 citing health and family reasons.

In his address, Siew conveyed President Ma Ying-jeou's recognition of Su's contributions to the country with his efforts to seek stable cross-Taiwan Strait relations, as well as mutual trust between Taiwan and the United States, one of Taiwan's closest allies.
All three NSC deputy secretaries-general -- Ho Szu-yin, Lee Hai-tung, and John Chen-chung Deng -- attended the ceremony.
According to Hu's close aides, the new NSC secretary-general began work soon after the handover ceremony in order to get up to speed on his new job as soon as possible.

Hu is a career diplomat with 35 years of experience in diplomatic and national security affairs. As well as having served as Taiwan's representative to Singapore, he has also been the country's representative to Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News---- Chou Hsi-wei rising from the ashes
DOC.DATELINE: 02/23/10 17:11:04 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei is a typical example of how a politician could be hurt by attempts to play to the gallery.

Few people can explain why Chou is so unpopular in various surveys. He is known to have impeccable integrity and to be diligent in his work, although his performance may not be very excellent. Chen Hsin-ching, speaker of the Taipei County Council, lauded Chou as the most hard-working Taipei magistrate in memory.
But Chou made a fool of himself in 2007 when he led a 32-member posse in an attempt to track a tiger that was reportedly mauling goats on farms in Linkou, Taipei County.
The purported tiger turned out to be a stray dog, and Chou, who tried to milk publicity from the incident, became a laughingstock.

His political rivals dubbed him "The Rear" because he often brought up the rear in public opinion surveys. Thisis a nickname he can hardly shed now, although he has not been assessed objectively in the polls since that incident.
Voters are not always rational -- they sometimes support election candidates suspected of corruption but they cannot stand ridiculous public figures.

Chou could have used drastic means to fight the unfair treatment he usually gets in opinion polls, but he chose to step aside in favor of his Kuomintang (KMT) colleague with a grace rarely seen in modern politics.
His decision has defused a KMT crisis and served to refurish Chou's political image. This could spur a political rebirth for him.
Politicians who like to play to the gallery would do well to keep in mind the lesson that Chou learned the hard way. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport ministry unveils new measures
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 18:04:33 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In order to enhance the competitiveness of Taiwan's ports, the government will push for several new measures this year, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuang S. Yeh said Tuesday.

Speaking at a gathering of local shippers, Yeh said the volume of goods loaded and unloaded in Taiwan declined to 605 million tons in 2009 from 670 million tons in 2008 owing to the global financial crisis.
In order to reverse the decline, the vice minister said his ministry will continue to develop the nation's five freeports, which already accommodate 63 companies.
Also, Yeh said, a shipping port bureau will be formed under the Transport Ministry to pave the way for the establishment of a harbor company to operate the country's four international harbors.
The ministry is also working on a computerized single-window service platform that will serve shipping carriers around the clock.

Yeh further said the ministry has received approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs to allow local shipping carriers' vessels built in China without the approval of the Taiwanese authorities to be registered in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 18:09:37 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed 0.49 percent higher Tuesday on consolidation.
The weighted price index rose 37.40 points to finish at 7,597.44. The local bourse opened at 7,575.62 and fluctuated between a high of 7,597.44 and a low of 7,502.45.
More than 2.99 million shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$91.29 billion.
Six out of the eight major stock categories gained ground. Plastic and chemical stocks were the biggest gainers, with a rise of 2.3 percent.
Foodstuff issues increased 1.6 percent, cement shares and construction issues climbed 0.6 percent, and electronics and machinery issues and paper and pulp shares gained 0.3 percent.
Textile issues lost 0.5 percent, and financial stocks shed 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,480 to 1,321, with 313 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$613 million worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 18:14:24 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.049 to close at NT$32.050.
A total of US$516 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.130 and reached a low of NT$32.030 before rebounding slightly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banned Chinese day lily enters Taiwan from Vietnam: lawmakers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 18:17:04 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A large amount of dried day lily from China is entering Taiwan illegally by being passed off as a product of Vietnam, hurting local farmers' interests, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers charged Tuesday.

The lawmakers suggested that the large volume of the banned imports has violated President Ma Ying-jeou's promise to safeguard the rights and livelihoods of local farmers at a time when Taiwan is in talks with China over a proposed pact to expand trade.

Taiwan currently bans the import of 830 Chinese agricultural products, including dried day lily, and the president has vowed that the restrictions would be maintained even if a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China is signed.
But banned Chinese agricultural products have found their way into Taiwan either through smuggling or being represented as the product of a third country.

Citing customs statistics, DPP Legislator Pan Men-an said Tuesday that 73,830 kilograms of dried day lily, purportedly from Vietnam, were imported into Taiwan in 2009, a 27 percent rise from the 58,108 kilograms that entered Taiwan's market in 2008.
Last month alone, another 39,984 kilograms of dried day lily were imported into Taiwan to satisfy higher demand during the Lunar New Year holiday, Pan said.

The shipments have invariably been accompanied by Vietnamese certificates of origin, but Pan said Vietnam does not produce a lot of day lily, and he contended that fake certificates of origin were used to get around the ban on importing the agricultural product from China.
"A certificate of origin can be bought at the price of less than US$350," he said.
One customs official familiar with the case told the Central News Agency, however, that the certificate of origin is not the only document checked when screening incoming shipments.
Importers' transaction and transportation documents are also checked to ensure the origin of the imported goods.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak on the record, said Vietnamese customs officials are also working with Taiwan to prevent their country from being blamed unfairly for helping other countries engage in illegal imports.
But the DPP lawmakers are convinced the day lily invading Taiwan comes from China.
DPP Legislator Lai Kun-cheng said a percentage of the imported dried day lily had been found to contain excessive amounts of sulfur dioxide, posing a threat to human health.
Lee Wang-ting, a day lily farmer from Taitung County in eastern Taiwan, said that the low price of the Chinese day lily has had a serious impact on the livelihoods of local farmers.
Taiwanese day lily is being sold at the wholesale price of about NT$500 per kilo, while the price of Chinese day lily is less than NT$170 per kilo, he said.
Lee also pointed out that dried Chinese day lily often looks whiter than the Taiwanese product because it has been bleached.

DOC.HEADLINE: British Council to offer free English classes on Feb. 28
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 19:02:18 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The British Council in Taipei will host an open day Feb. 28 to allow people to sample its English courses for free.
The sample classes will include English for adults, English for young learners and International English Language Testing System (IELTS) preparation, the council announced Tuesday.

Alison Marwick, director of the council's English Language Services, said that the British office has invested a great deal of money in upgraded classroom equipment, such as interactive white boards and notebooks, to improve the learning process.
The introduction of modern electronic equipment in English teaching has raised student interest, Marwick indicated.
People interested in sampling the council's English programs are advised to call 8722 1000 to register or email englishcourses@britishcouncil.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier clarifies content of industrial innovation bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 19:46:43 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Regardless of its nature or size, any business deemed to be engaged in industrial innovation and job creation can be eligible to receive incentives provided by a bill that aims to upgrade industrial innovation, Premier Wu Den- yih said Tuesday.

Replying to questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Shiow-yen at a legislative meeting, Wu said the bill is not designed to benefit only big multinationals, and that local small- and medium-sized businesses that meet the two conditions, irrespective of their size or the sector in which they operate, can apply for the incentives suggested in the bill.

As the Executive Yuan listed the industrial innovation bill as the top priority that needs to be swiftly cleared by the Legislative Yuan in the new session that opened that day, the move provoked strong suspicion that the bill was customized for foreign conglomerates, Lu said.

Noting that clauses in the bill stipulating that only the world's 500 biggest enterprises that have set up operations in Taiwan can be subject to a 15 percent corporation income tax break have been scrapped, the premier said that "in the future, any new provisions added to the bill must not be discriminatory and must not benefit only alien firms. "
The disputed clauses, deemed as benefiting only foreign enterprises, had stirred up widespread discontent among leading local business groups.

Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo threatened in mid-February that he would move his company's headquarters out of Taiwan if the Legislative Yuan were to grant the 15 percent tax break only to "foreign" enterprises.
"Why does the government treat us as worthless, while treating foreign companies like treasure?" asked an angry Guo.
Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said large enterprises in Taiwan have been defamed and warned the government that they would be forced to leave Taiwan if the bill were to pass the legislature.

Pointing out that five or six foreign governments have provided incentives to Acer in the hope of attracting the computer firm to set up operations hubs in their countries, Wang urged the government not to "sacrifice large business groups' interests to court small companies."
In the same legislative meeting, Wu also answered Lu's questions concerning a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.
The premier said the Executive Yuan will do its utmost to push for the sealing of the trade pact that will allow some Taiwanese products to enter the Chinese market tariff-free.
"Taiwan cannot afford to wait any longer in the face of the formation of the ASEAN plus one trade bloc," he said.
"If Taiwan fails to sign the ECFA with China in time, local businesses will be increasingly impacted and quickly hollowed out, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still wants F-16 C/D fighter jets, submarines: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 19:55:14 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Sinyao Shih and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that Taiwan will not forsake plans to purchase the more advanced F-16 C/D fighter jets as well as diesel-electric submarines from the United States, amid a U.S. government report which suggested the island's current fleet was too old and weak.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Wu pointed out that the recent US$6.4 billion package of arms that Washington announced in late January it wants to sell to Taiwan does not include the advanced F-16 C/D fighter planes and diesel-electric submarines long sought by Taiwan.

Taiwan's current fleet of older F-16 A/B fighter jets and submarines are several years old. The arms package instead consists of 60 UH-60M Black Hawk helicopters, two Osprey Class mine hunting ships, 12 ATM-84L and RTM-84L Harpoon Block II Telemetry missiles, 114 Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missiles and communications equipment.
Despite the absence of the advanced F-16 planes and the submarines from the list, Wu said, the United States has never shut the door to future sales of F-16 C/D fighters and submarines to Taiwan.
"The two sides are still talking over this matter, " the premier told lawmakers.

Wu noted that military capabilities across the Taiwan Strait have tilted in favor of China for many years. Developing "lean and mean, small, but excellent" weaponry to beef up Taiwan's self-defense preparedness remains Taiwan's basic military policy, he said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense on Tuesday refuted a report by the U.S. government's Defense Intelligence Agency that said many of the island's 400 combat aircrafts would not be able to help Taiwan withstand an attack from rival China.

"In recent years, the Chinese People's Liberation Army has increased the quantity and sophistication of its ballistic and cruise missiles and fighter aircraft opposite Taiwan, which has diminished Taiwan's ability to deny PRC efforts to attain air superiority in a conflict," the U.S. agency's report said.
The one-off report, ordered by the U.S. Congress, says upgrades are needed for Taiwan as China gets stronger.

Discounting the report's description of the Republic of China Air Force's fighter planes as not capable of withstanding an attack from China, Han Keng- sheng, deputy Air Force chief of staff, said the description was untrue.
"Despite being old, our fighter planes are operationally capable of meeting minimum combat needs," Han said.
However, the defense ministry acknowledged it is an undeniable truth that China has become increasingly strong militarily compared to Taiwan.
Both Wu and the defense ministry made the remarks Tuesday in response to reports by foreign wire service agencies from Taipei the day before about the U.S. report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Bring export processing manufacturers home

TEXT.P: Half a century ago, Taiwan's economy shone, maintaining an annual growth rate of 9 percent for three consecutive decades. During this period of rapid economic growth, it also achieved a more equitable distribution of wealth.
"Made in Taiwan" products flooded Western countries and helped contribute to Taiwan's boom.

But the glory faded about 20 years ago due to drastic changes in the domestic political and economic environment, laws and tax systems, as well as the catching up of several neighboring countries that emulated Taiwan's success model.
The closed-door policies advocated by former presidents Lee Teng-hui and Chen Shui-bian also meant that Taiwan missed a great opportunity to use China as a conduit for export processing.
But as wages in China have increased, along with a shortfall in workers and surges in taxes and land prices, a window of opportunity has opened, giving Taiwan a chance to retrieve its past glory.

The government should turn idle land surrounding Taichung and Taipei harbors into special trade zones with the incentives of low taxes, high efficiency and plentiful foreign labor. This will persuade Taiwanese export processing manufacturers who have scattered overseas to return home.

If tens of thousands of down-stream manufacturers were to flock in, bringing funds, equipment and orders, and make good use of the products of Taiwan's mid- and up-stream industries, the lifeline of Taiwan's export industry would be ensured.

When the down-stream industry has become robust, a comprehensive supply chain comprised of the mid- and up-stream industries will be formed. In this way, the country's design, quality and technology will also be upgraded and the rapid economic growth that ended 20 years ago will resume. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: President: Pretender or muddlehead?

TEXT.P: It is strange for President Ma Ying-jeou to say Monday that he only learned about the bowing out of Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei from the mayoral election in Xinbei City, the name by which the county will be known after being upgraded to a special municipality, after reading about it the newspaper.

When Chou, with tears in his eyes, announced his withdrawal, he said he talked "twice" to both Ma, who is also Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, and KMT Secretary- General King Pu-tsung. Is it not bizarre, therefore, for Ma to claim he only knew about it after reading the paper?
If Ma knew in advance but professed to have no knowledge, it would be a pretense, but if Ma really did have no knowledge, it would be even worse.

We are worried about whether the president is indeed stupid, or whether he thinks it is everyone else who is stupid. We would prefer it to be the latter, because if not, then it means he is being kept in the dark.

If a president rules the country by reading the newspaper, then it would be better to seek a newspaper chief to serve as president. DOC.HEADLINE: Central Bank has record overall balance surplus in 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 21:08:26 (By Tien Yu-ping and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The balance of payments of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) in 2009 registered a record surplus of US$54.13 billion, reflecting an increase in the bank's reserve assets, according to statistics released by the bank Tuesday.

The bank reported that for 2009, the bank's current account showed a surplus of US$42.57 billion, up 69.46 percent from that of the previous year, while its financial account had a net inflow of US$13.98 billion, the first net inflow since 2005.
The impressive growth in current account could be attributed to a recovering world economy in addition to a lower base effect, according to the report.

In the fourth quarter of last year, when more local insurance companies were investing in bonds overseas and many individual investors were using overseas mutual funds, direct and portfolio investment exhibited net outflows of US$0.89 billion and US$4.12 billion, respectively, while residents' portfolio investments abroad registered a net outflow of US$10.88 billion, the bank reported.

Meanwhile, non-residents' portfolio investments showed a net inflow of US$6.75 billion, induced mainly by foreign capital inflows targeting domestic stock and bond markets. Other investments exhibited a net inflow of US$9.07 billion, largely attributable to a decrease in external lending by the banking sector and an increase in the withdrawal of overseas deposits by the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recovery signs clear in hi-tech parks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 21:29:29 (By P.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Boosted by a global economic recovery, business growth and job openings in the country's three major high-tech parks will be conspicuous this year, the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) said Tuesday.

The NSC reported that the three facilities -- the Hsinchu Science and Industrial Park in Hsinchu County, the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County and the Central Taiwan Science Park in Taichung city and county -- recorded a combined turnover of NT$1.58 trillion (US$49.56 billion) in 2009, a 13.9 percent slide from the previous year, as a result of the global economic downturn.

Despite the deep recession last year, the three parks posted a combined turnover of NT$951.8 billion in the second half of the year on the back of an initial economic recovery. The figure was 16.2 percent up compared to the year-earlier level, the NSC said.
According to the NSC, the parks are expected to provide as many as 18,000 jobs this year.

The Hsinchu Science and Industrial Park Administration said the northern Taiwan hi-tech park is to sponsor a job fair March 13 with 4,000 jobs on offer. Administration officials estimated that the park will offer some 5,000 jobs for the whole of 2010.
A total of 132,161 workers were employed in the Hsinchu park last year, up by 1.2 percent from the 2008 level, according to the administration.
The park mainly hosts companies in the semiconductor and optoelectronic sectors.

Meanwhile, the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration said between 6,000 and 10,000 jobs could be on offer this year in the park, thanks to business expansion among the companies operating there. Leading enterprises such as Chi Mei, TSMC and UMC will be the major drivers of the job creation, it added.
In 2009, a total of 48,626 workers were employed in the park's mostly biotechnology and medical equipment companies, marking a small increase of 1 percent compared to the 2008 figure.

The Central Taiwan Science Park Administration said for its part that there will be 2,000-3,000 jobs available in the park this year. Last year, 19,845 employees worked there, down from the 20,736 employed in 2008, it said. The hi-tech park is a prime cluster for the photovoltaic industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier supports national holidays dedicated to women, children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 22:41:43 (By Su Lung-chi and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that he is in favor of making International Women's Day -- March 8 -- and Children's Day -- April 4 -- national holidays and that the Ministry of the Interior has been studying the issue.
Children's Day and Women's Day were separate national holidays in Taiwan until 1993, when the government decided to combine the two holidays and to have a single Women and Children's Day April 4.
In 1998, when two-day weekends were implemented in Taiwan, the government decided that Women and Children's Day would no longer be a national holiday.

In recent years, the Interior Ministry has received suggestions from various sectors that March 8 and April 4 should be reinstated as national holidays, and has held several meetings to discuss the economic impact of establishing more national holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier clarifies content of industrial innovation bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 19:46:43 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Regardless of its nature or size, any business deemed to be engaged in industrial innovation and job creation can be eligible to receive incentives provided by a bill that aims to upgrade industrial innovation, Premier Wu Den- yih said Tuesday.

Replying to questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Shiow-yen at a legislative meeting, Wu said the bill is not designed to benefit only big multinationals, and that local small- and medium-sized businesses that meet the two conditions, irrespective of their size or the sector in which they operate, can apply for the incentives suggested in the bill.

As the Executive Yuan listed the industrial innovation bill as the top priority that needs to be swiftly cleared by the Legislative Yuan in the new session that opened that day, the move provoked strong suspicion that the bill was customized for foreign conglomerates, Lu said.

Noting that clauses in the bill stipulating that only the world's 500 biggest enterprises that have set up operations in Taiwan can be subject to a 15 percent corporation income tax break have been scrapped, the premier said that "in the future, any new provisions added to the bill must not be discriminatory and must not benefit only alien firms. "
The disputed clauses, deemed as benefiting only foreign enterprises, had stirred up widespread discontent among leading local business groups.

Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo threatened in mid-February that he would move his company's headquarters out of Taiwan if the Legislative Yuan were to grant the 15 percent tax break only to "foreign" enterprises.
"Why does the government treat us as worthless, while treating foreign companies like treasure?" asked an angry Guo.
Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said large enterprises in Taiwan have been defamed and warned the government that they would be forced to leave Taiwan if the bill were to pass the legislature.

Pointing out that five or six foreign governments have provided incentives to Acer in the hope of attracting the computer firm to set up operations hubs in their countries, Wang urged the government not to "sacrifice large business groups' interests to court small companies."
In the same legislative meeting, Wu also answered Lu's questions concerning a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.
The premier said the Executive Yuan will do its utmost to push for the sealing of the trade pact that will allow some Taiwanese products to enter the Chinese market tariff-free.
"Taiwan cannot afford to wait any longer in the face of the formation of the ASEAN plus one trade bloc," he said.
"If Taiwan fails to sign the ECFA with China in time, local businesses will be increasingly impacted and quickly hollowed out, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still wants F-16 C/D fighter jets, submarines: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/23/10 19:55:14 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Sinyao Shih and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that Taiwan will not forsake plans to purchase the more advanced F-16 C/D fighter jets as well as diesel-electric submarines from the United States, amid a U.S. government report which suggested the island's current fleet was too old and weak.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Wu pointed out that the recent US$6.4 billion package of arms that Washington announced in late January it wants to sell to Taiwan does not include the advanced F-16 C/D fighter planes and diesel-electric submarines long sought by Taiwan.

Taiwan's current fleet of older F-16 A/B fighter jets and submarines are several years old. The arms package instead consists of 60 UH-60M Black Hawk helicopters, two Osprey Class mine hunting ships, 12 ATM-84L and RTM-84L Harpoon Block II Telemetry missiles, 114 Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missiles and communications equipment.
Despite the absence of the advanced F-16 planes and the submarines from the list, Wu said, the United States has never shut the door to future sales of F-16 C/D fighters and submarines to Taiwan.
"The two sides are still talking over this matter, " the premier told lawmakers.

Wu noted that military capabilities across the Taiwan Strait have tilted in favor of China for many years. Developing "lean and mean, small, but excellent" weaponry to beef up Taiwan's self-defense preparedness remains Taiwan's basic military policy, he said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense on Tuesday refuted a report by the U.S. government's Defense Intelligence Agency that said many of the island's 400 combat aircrafts would not be able to help Taiwan withstand an attack from rival China.

"In recent years, the Chinese People's Liberation Army has increased the quantity and sophistication of its ballistic and cruise missiles and fighter aircraft opposite Taiwan, which has diminished Taiwan's ability to deny PRC efforts to attain air superiority in a conflict," the U.S. agency's report said.
The one-off report, ordered by the U.S. Congress, says upgrades are needed for Taiwan as China gets stronger.

Discounting the report's description of the Republic of China Air Force's fighter planes as not capable of withstanding an attack from China, Han Keng- sheng, deputy Air Force chief of staff, said the description was untrue.
"Despite being old, our fighter planes are operationally capable of meeting minimum combat needs," Han said.
However, the defense ministry acknowledged it is an undeniable truth that China has become increasingly strong militarily compared to Taiwan.
Both Wu and the defense ministry made the remarks Tuesday in response to reports by foreign wire service agencies from Taipei the day before about the U.S. report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Bring export processing manufacturers home

TEXT.P: Half a century ago, Taiwan's economy shone, maintaining an annual growth rate of 9 percent for three consecutive decades. During this period of rapid economic growth, it also achieved a more equitable distribution of wealth.
"Made in Taiwan" products flooded Western countries and helped contribute to Taiwan's boom.

But the glory faded about 20 years ago due to drastic changes in the domestic political and economic environment, laws and tax systems, as well as the catching up of several neighboring countries that emulated Taiwan's success model.
The closed-door policies advocated by former presidents Lee Teng-hui and Chen Shui-bian also meant that Taiwan missed a great opportunity to use China as a conduit for export processing.
But as wages in China have increased, along with a shortfall in workers and surges in taxes and land prices, a window of opportunity has opened, giving Taiwan a chance to retrieve its past glory.

The government should turn idle land surrounding Taichung and Taipei harbors into special trade zones with the incentives of low taxes, high efficiency and plentiful foreign labor. This will persuade Taiwanese export processing manufacturers who have scattered overseas to return home.

If tens of thousands of down-stream manufacturers were to flock in, bringing funds, equipment and orders, and make good use of the products of Taiwan's mid- and up-stream industries, the lifeline of Taiwan's export industry would be ensured.

When the down-stream industry has become robust, a comprehensive supply chain comprised of the mid- and up-stream industries will be formed. In this way, the country's design, quality and technology will also be upgraded and the rapid economic growth that ended 20 years ago will resume. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: President: Pretender or muddlehead?

TEXT.P: It is strange for President Ma Ying-jeou to say Monday that he only learned about the bowing out of Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei from the mayoral election in Xinbei City, the name by which the county will be known after being upgraded to a special municipality, after reading about it the newspaper.

When Chou, with tears in his eyes, announced his withdrawal, he said he talked "twice" to both Ma, who is also Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, and KMT Secretary- General King Pu-tsung. Is it not bizarre, therefore, for Ma to claim he only knew about it after reading the paper?
If Ma knew in advance but professed to have no knowledge, it would be a pretense, but if Ma really did have no knowledge, it would be even worse.

We are worried about whether the president is indeed stupid, or whether he thinks it is everyone else who is stupid. We would prefer it to be the latter, because if not, then it means he is being kept in the dark.

If a president rules the country by reading the newspaper, then it would be better to seek a newspaper chief to serve as president. Some have mocked Ma on the Internet that he only knew he was elected president after reading about it in the paper and that the first step when China invades Taiwan will be to destroy all newspapers so that Ma will know nothing about it. (Feb. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 24, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
2004: A Taiwan-developed hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor is unveiled.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction of man-made lake in southern Taiwan to start in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 10:36:01 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Construction on Taiwan's first large man-made lake will get underway next year on the border of Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan to help alleviate the area's water shortages, an official said Wednesday.

"We have completed planning for the first phase of construction of the man-made Jiyang Lake, and if all goes well, construction will start early next year, " said Joses Y.H. Wu, deputy director of the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

With a maximum storage capacity of 27.6 million cubic meters of water, the lake will be able to supply up to 140,000 cubic tons of water per day, equal to the daily consumption of 420,000 people, to the greater Kaohsiung area when it is completed in 2015, Wu said.
The lake will cover 310 hectares of land at the confluence of the Cishan and Laonong rivers that straddles Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.

According to Wu, 70 percent of the water needed in the Greater Kaohsiung area is currently drawn from the Gaoping River. Without a reservoir to store water, the region has often faced water shortages.
"Such headaches will be largely eased after the completion of Jiyang Lake," Wu promised optimistically.

The Jiyang Lake project is included in a draft special statute on dredging out Tsengwen, Nanhua and Wushantou reservoirs in the Tainan-Chiayi area that was approved by the Executive Yuan before the Lunar New Year holiday, Wu said.
The statute will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for screening in the near future.
The Jiyang Lake project passed an environmental assessment seven years ago, but it has been stalled because of conflicting interests involving gravel supplies.

With gravel prices dropping to NT$520 per cubic meter from a high of NT$620 after Typhoon Morakot hit southern Taiwan last August, the biggest obstacle to construction of the country's first large man-made lake has been removed, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Dealing with financial reshuffle carefully

TEXT.P: Since the inauguration of the Ma administration, the Cabinet's two vice premiers have been selected for their financial expertise.

Now that Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu is set to represent the ruling party to run in the Xinbei City mayoral election at year's end, we believe the selection of his replacement to preside over financial and economic affairs in the Cabinet should be dealt with carefully.

The person Premier Wu Den-yih will select as his deputy after a reshuffle has been a hot topic recently. And whether Wu likes it or not, the public will see his Cabinet as the Cabinet taking the government into the 2012 presidential election.
Wu is a seasoned politician and he is sensitive to the public's will, but this could also be a weakness.
He knows that from now until the 2012 presidential election, every policy that his administration makes will affect the public and hence the election's outcome.

With this in mind, it is easy to understand why hikes in national health insurance premium rates or the ending of income tax-exemption for military personnel and teachers have been halted or at least put on hold under his leadership.

But we believe a Cabinet that is oversensitive to public opinion will be unable to attract truly talented people. If Wu does not show any mettle for reform, he will not be able to draw the caliber of person the Cabinet needs.

An administrative team has to take into consideration governing as well as elections. But the two are not contradictory. In fact, they are complementary. If it can provide good governance, it will be the best boost for future elections. (Feb. 24, 2010)
