DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- National library opens manga reading section
DOC.DATELINE: 02/24/10 11:34:38 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The National Central Library opened a new reading section for comic books (also known as manga) , a landmark measure justifying manga's status in the publishing sector and its value for readers in Taiwan.
Over 10,000 volumes form the collection, but only people over the age of 18 are allowed to enter the section. The comic books cannot be checked out.
The following are excerpts of local newspaper coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

The section not only features popular comics circulating at manga stores, but also old comics from China, collections of works by famous French artist Jean Giraud -- known for his pseudonym Moebius -- and "Mafalda" by illustrator Joaquin Salvador Lavado (pen name Quino) from Argentina.
The national library should be the place that stores the most comic books in Taiwan, in line with regulations requiring publishers to offer copies of their new books for the library to keep.
However, under the old restriction barring the national library from putting comic books on open shelves, the library gave away the comics it collected to local libraries until recent years.

Commenting on the rule that bans young people under 18 years old from using the comic book reading section, library official Yen Wen-ying explained that the national library plays a different role from other local and school libraries. It is entrusted with tasks to "collect, manage and keep nationwide books, " as well as to promote academic research, she noted.
Once books show signs of damage, they are taken out of circulation, Yen said, and the same regulation is applied to comic books.
The restriction, however, drew protests of teenage manga fans. Li Tzi-yang, a high school student, suggested the national library open another section for under-18-year-old manga readers.
China Times:
The National Central Library will put 10,000 volumes of comic books on its shelves, but more than 90 percent are Japanese or translations of Japanese works.
"If you read comics in Taiwan, you would have the impression that Taiwan is Japan's dependency, " renowned Taiwanese manga artist Liu Hsin-chin complained.

Taiwanese manga has been deeply influenced by Japan, Liu said. To develop the manga industry in Taiwan, the government should create an environment for local manga artists to create without having to worry about their livelihoods, he stated. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Government as source of new storm?

TEXT.P: The impact on Asian countries, especially Taiwan, will be great if the United States and China clash. The Obama administration reportedly may try to pressure China into appreciating its currency to divert attention from the U.S.' government budget and trade deficits.

The U.S. is said to be playing the 3T cards -- trade, Tibet, and Taiwan -- against China, while China is anxious to ingratiate itself with Taiwanese. Under the circumstances, it seems favorable for Taiwan to gain from both sides, but that may not necessarily happen.

It will depend on the Ma administration making good use of the situation. It is fortunate that he has reiterated recently that he wants to sign a trade pact -- the economic cooperation framework agreement -- with China as soon as possible this year.
In terms of internal affairs, the Cabinet under Premier Wu Den-yih has made the livelihood of the people the focus of his Cabinet, and he has achieved speedy results in resolving public grievances.
But in addition to small services, the public will be hoping for the government to establish a more sustainable financial and economic system.

If the public makes short-term gains, but does not see a fairer or more reasonable tax system or see the government miss the opportunity to plug big financial holes, it will end up paying the price in the future.
We expect the government to shoulder its responsibility and not become an obstacle for the sustainable development of the nation's economy. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: President does not deserve job

TEXT.P: The Ma Ying-jeou administration, far from giving up the thought of signing a controversial trade pact with China, pushed for it even more aggressively by singing a duet with China during the Lunar New Year holiday.

Chinese President Hu Jintao, while visiting Taiwanese businessmen in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province on Lunar New Year's Eve, said China is not mincing words in signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with Taiwan and that the pact will not only benefit China and will also not hurt Taiwan.
Ma said later during a gathering with Taiwanese businessmen operating in China that the signing of the agreement is absolutely vital for Taiwan.
While the majority of the Taiwanese public oppose the pact, why is Ma sticking to his guns against the will of the people?
The reason is that Ma advocates ultimate unification with China and that the signing of an ECFA will make Taiwan rely on China completely and subject to its annexation.
Moreover, because of the low approval rating of the Ma administration, it is uncertain whether Ma will win a re-election bid.

If Ma loses in the 2012 presidential election and a native party comes to power, then the trade pact will certainly not succeed, and the dream of unification will be shattered. This is why the Ma administration and China have such a sense of urgency over signing it soon, no matter what.
Although he is still the president, his plummeting approval ratings show that Ma has lost his legitimacy to decide the future of the nation's people.

As this paper has said repeatedly, the ECFA is not a tonic but a drug that will have only a short-term euphoric effect. Ma, who is insisting on signing the pact in disregard of the interests of the 23 million people of Taiwan, does not deserve to be the nation's president. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. urged to take Taiwan's need for F-16s seriously
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/24/10 13:03:40 (By Zep Hu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urged Washington Tuesday to decide whether or not to sell F-16C/D fighters to Taiwan as soon as possible, saying that although it has agreed to continue arms sales, it should not ignore Taiwan's stated self defense requirements.

Lu made the remarks during a visit to Washington, D.C., where she has met with several U.S. officials from the Department of State and the American Institute in Taiwan, as well as pro-Taiwan U.S. congressmen.
In an interview with CNA, Lu expressed thanks to the U.S. government for approving the latest arms sales to Taiwan, but said she regrets that the F-16s are so far not included in the package.

She also revealed that U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus Co-Chair Lincoln Diaz- Balart has promised to seek the endorsement of congressmen to a request for the administration to decide on the F-16C/D sale project as soon as possible.
Asked about the dispute over U.S. beef exports to Taiwan, Lu said the U.S. is more concerned that Taiwan has failed to keep its promises than about the export benefits.
In this regard, she suggested an end to calls by various civic groups for the public to reject U.S. beef, which she said has harmed Taiwan-U.S. ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: New GIO head vows to boost development of creative industries
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 14:28:12 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: New Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Johnny Chiang said he will push for the injection of more public and private resources into cultural and creative industries because the sector has the potential to create another economic miracle.

Speaking after taking over the helm of the GIO, Chiang said Taiwan's cultural and creative industries are full of promise and vitality, as evidenced by the box office success of the youth gang film "Monga" and award-winning screening of Taiwan's "Au Revoir Taipei" at the just-concluded Berlin International Film Festival.

"The cultural and creative industries indeed offer a good opportunity for Taiwan to rise to excellence and may also allow Taiwan to create yet another economic miracle, " Chiang said, referring to the export processing industry that fueled Taiwan's first economic takeoff in the 1970-1980s.

Chiang was responding to remarks made at the changeover ceremony by his predecessor Su Jun-pin, who said he dreamed of helping Taiwan's television, filmmaking and pop music industries find their optimal niches in the Chinese- speaking world.
Praising Chiang as a cool-headed, resourceful and methodical person, Su said he believes the GIO will operate steadily and smoothly under Chiang's stewardship.
In response, Chiang said he felt honored to be recruited into Premier Wu Den- yih's Cabinet to serve the country.

"I am taking office with solemnity and will work to the best of my ability to fulfill my mission, " said the 38-year-old Chiang, previously an associate professor in Soochow University's Department of Political Science.

On the development of creative and cultural industries, Chiang promised to infuse more resources into the sector by integrating public and private sector strength to upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness and influence.
Su, who took the GIO post Jan. 1, 2009, will be transferred to serve as the ruling Kuomintang's spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Economic recovery at science parks
DOC.DATELINE: 02/24/10 15:24:31 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The three major high-tech parks in Taiwan -- the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu City, the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County and the Central Taiwan Science Park in Taichung city and county -- have shown signs of economic recovery since the second half of 2009 and more jobs are expected this year, while the number of employees on unpaid leave has dropped to less than 1,000, approximately 0.4 percent of the total workforce.
The combined turnover of the three industrial parks in 2009 totaled NT$1.58 trillion, far short of the forecast of NT$2 trillion and a 13.9 percent slide from the previous year.

However, boosted by a global economic recovery, the combined turnover in the second half of the year amounted to NT$951.8 billion, a 16.2 percent growth compared with the same period of the previous year.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:

Commercial Times: The National Science Council predicted Tuesday that combined turnover the three major high-tech parks might be back to the level of 2007 and reach NT$1.9 trillion in 2010, after an annual slide of 13.9 percent in 2009.

The administrative offices of the three science parks pointed out that most manufacturers faced serious setbacks in the first half of last year in the wake of the global financial crisis. Fortunately, businesses have gradually picked up since the beginning of the second half of the year, and growth has been seen since September.

While biotechnology remained the only branch that continued to grow in the past year, manufacturers of IC, opto-electronics, computer peripherals, precision machinery and communications equipment also registered negative revenue growth from minus 10 percent to minus 20 percent.

In the second half of 2009, combined turnover of the three industrial parks amounted to NT$951.8 billion, up 16.2 percent over the same period of last year, while the amount of new investments, mostly in IC designs and manufacturing, were also double the amount of the same period of 2008. New investments in the Central Taiwan Science Park are mostly in opto-electronics manufacturing, and the cluster effect is also seen in the south with more and more biotechnology and medical equipment companies having moved in.

Radio Taiwan International: To ease the burden on manufacturers, the administrations of the three major high-tech industrial parks in Taiwan reduced the annual management fees by half in 2009 as the global financial crisis had impacted the economy.

The discount allowed companies, which had to put their employees on unpaid leave, to further reduce their operational costs. At its peak last February, the number of employees on unpaid leave in the three parks exceeded 130,000, a figure that had been reduced to under 1,000 at the end of the year, according to Jou Jing- yang, vice minister of the National Science Council (NSC).

Jou added that although businesses in the science parks showed signs of recovery in the second half of last year, the NSC decided to continue the discount in 2010 by charging only 75 percent of the normal management fees, in order to help the manufacturers achieve an earlier recovery. (Feb. 24, 2010)
China Times: The combined turnover of the three major high-tech industrial parks registered a record low in five years at NT$1.58 trillion, comparable to the level of 2005.

According to Jou, as businesses in the industrial parks have been gradually picking up since the second half of last year, it is expected that combined turnover will reach NT$1.9 trillion, comparable to the level of 2007 at NT$1.98 trillion.

He added that with the economy gradually coming out of recession, there are an estimated 4,000 jobs on offer in the Hsinchu Science Park, between 2,000 and 3,000 in the central park and up to 10,000 in the south. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Feb. 24

TEXT.P: in China 7. Lawmaker expresses worries about leaking Taiwan Beer formula 8. MOEA to hold investment briefing sessions in China 9. Talk of the day - Economic recovery at science parks 10. Minister: children's day may be reinstated as national holiday

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker expresses worries about leaking Taiwan Beer formula
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 15:32:30 (By Justin Su and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Tobacco & Liquor Corp. (TTL) executive has dismissed concerns of an opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker that TTL's plan to produce Taiwan Beer in China could hurt it and Taiwan in the future.

DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher said Wednesday that he wanted to see the state-run company expand into overseas markets, but he was worried that its plan to contract a Chinese manufacturer to produce its beer in China would result in the leaking of the formula for Taiwan Beer and related production know-how.
"The beer produced in China could even make its way back into Taiwan, " Huang said, fearful that the plan would undermine the state-run company's NT$26 billion in annual sales of the popular beer.

But TTL Senior Vice President Hang-liu Yu said the move was typical of how beer companies move into new markets -- first by exporting, then working with a local producer and then setting up their own plant.

The company began exporting Taiwan Beer to China last July, earning it NT$100 million in revenues to date. But contract manufacturing in China is necessary, Yu said, because the beer and the bottles are heavy and make the product less competitive when exported to China's market.

Yu stressed that Taiwan Beer produced in China would not be exported back to Taiwan. He said the formula used to produce the beer there will be different from that used in Taiwan, and the beer bottles will carry special markings to indicate their origin.
"The flavor will not be completely identical, but will mainly cater to the taste of consumers there," he added.
Yu also denied that the production of Taiwan Beer in China will affect the interests of TTL employees in Taiwan.

Despite Yu's comments, Chen Hsueh-hsiang, deputy director general of the National Treasury Agency under the Ministry of Finance, which supervises the operations of TTL, said the agency will ask the company to address Huang's misgivings.
"The MOF will respect TTL's business strategy but will also supervise and monitor related projects," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Time to scrap military personnel tax exemption

TEXT.P: A bill to scrap the income tax exemption for military personnel and teachers failed to clear the legislature again due to a so-called lack of "complementary measures."
The proposal to end the tax exemption has been discussed since 1985, but it has been blocked every time due to the pressure of vested interests and election considerations.

The income tax exemption for military personnel and teachers can be traced to a specific era when their salaries were relatively low, but that phenomenon no longer exists in the wake of several rounds of salary hikes.

A poll has found that up to three quarters of the public are in favor of ending this preferential treatment. Reckless tax cuts, the erosion of the tax base and the unfair tax system have long constituted public grievances against the government.
The end of the income tax exemption for military personnel and teachers would be a major step toward eliminating preferential treatment based on vocation or status.

But this would be only the beginning of establishing a fair tax system. Imposing capital gains taxes on stock and real estate income should also be addressed. We expect the Ma administration to show resolve in reforming the tax system. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor promises to improve living environment through design
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 16:21:31 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin's presentation on his city's development has attracted the attention of the participants in the 2010 World Design Cities Summit taking place in the South Korean capital of Seoul Feb. 23-24.
Hau delivered the presentation, titled "Taipei: A City of Innovation and Creativity, " in fluent English Tuesday.

With the aid of photographs, Hau introduced Taiwan's capital as a safe and convenient living environment, as well as open to different cultures, according to Taipei city government officials accompanying Hau at the summit.
The presentation caught the eye of a Korean movie producer who told Hau that he feels Taipei is more friendly toward film makers than Seoul, the officials said.

Hau, who is among various city representatives from countries including Thailand, China, Holland and Turkey, was the only person to mention the film industry in his presentation at the two-day conference -- an international event initiated by the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design in 2005 to promote the idea of urban design.

Every two years, a city is appointed "World Design Capital, " a designation that provides an opportunity for cities to feature their accomplishments in innovative design and to highlight their success in urban revitalization strategies.

On Wednesday, Hau and the other participants in the conference's Mayor's Round Table session signed a declaration in which they promised to improve the living environments of their cities through design.

Hau explained that the declaration is aimed at ensuring all the cities involved will cooperate with and learn from each other, as well as encourage them to apply design ideas and theories on city management and administration.
More than 500 Korean and international design industrial experts attended the 2010 summit.

According to the Taipei city government, Hau's participation is expected to help the city in its efforts to host the 2011 International Design Alliance Congress in October next year, which is expected to draw the participation of some 3,000 design professionals from 60 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children's Day may be reinstated as national holiday by 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 16:28:23 (by Shih Sinyao and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday that Children's Day on April 4 will be reinstated as a national holiday in 2011, if a related provision is approved by the Legislative Yuan.
He said related government agencies reached a consensus on the issue last November after holding several meetings over the previous months.
Taiwan currently observes Women and Children's Day on April 4, but it is not a national holiday.

Jiang said it was decided at the November meeting to separate Women's Day from Children's Day, because reinstating Women's Day as a national holiday requires more discussion, taking into consideration its potential impact on the nation's economy.
Children's Day and Women's Day were separate national holidays in Taiwan until 1993, when the government decided to combine the two holidays and to have a single Women and Children's Day April 4.
In 1998, when two-day weekends became the norm in Taiwan, the government decided that Women and Children's Day would no longer be a national holiday.

As to whether to have an extra holiday if Children's Day were to fall on a Saturday or Sunday, the minister said the overall number of holidays in a year should be taken into consideration in deciding on a make-up holiday.
Many legislators and outside observers have suggested that the total number of days off in a year, including two-day weekends, not exceed 116 days, based on the practices of most developed countries.
There are a total of 112 days off on Taiwan's calendar in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to hold investment briefing sessions in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 16:41:49 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taking advantage of a labor shortage in China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to hold up to eight briefing sessions in China this year to try to persuade Taiwanese businesses there to return and invest in Taiwan, an economic affairs official said Wednesday.

The sessions will mainly take place in the Yangtze River Delta and the Pearl River Delta areas, where many Taiwanese businesses are clustered, according to Yu Chi-zen, deputy director-general of the Department of Investment Services.
Special attention will be given to those engaged in conventional industries in Dongguan and Shenzhen, which are most likely to be affected by the labor shortage, Yu said.
He said the MOEA will update the businesses on Taiwan's investment environment and the various preferential programs that are available.
The ministry will also assist these businesses in making use of Taiwan's R&D resources and encourage them to inject funds into technology R&D, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to evaluate impact of allowing medical experts to work in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 16:52:05 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday that it will closely monitor whether medical manpower in Taiwan will be affected by the decision to allow health personnel to practice in China.
Shih Chung-liang, director-general of DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, noted that qualified Taiwanese pharmacists and nurses will be soon permitted to practice in China without a license.
The DOH will have to evaluate whether this new measure will have an adverse impact on Taiwan's supply of such personnel, he said.

At present, medical doctors and dentists are allowed to practice in China, once they obtain a certificate of good standing issued by the DOH to prove that they have not violated any healthcare laws, Shih said.
To date, about 100 people have applied for the certificates, he added.
Taiwan, with a population of 23 million, has 40,000 doctors and 120,000 nurses, while China has only 40,000 doctors and 50,000 nurses to serve its population of over 1.3 billion.

China therefore hopes to recruit medical personnel from Taiwan, but Taiwanese medical experts generally work to a high professional standard and are much better paid than their counterparts in China, Shih said.

In light of this situation, very few Taiwanese health professionals would consider working in China, which means that the new policy is unlikely to have much of an impact on the health sector in Taiwan, he added.
Every five years, Taiwan's medical sector conducts a study on the demand for medical human resources in the following decade, according to Shih.

He acknowledged that an exodus of medical professionals to China could severely affect Taiwan's medical labor market, but gave the assurance that the DOH will continue to closely monitor the situation.
In addition, he said, China may also ask Taiwan to open its healthcare sector to Chinese medical personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma hopes to visit Solomon Islands again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 17:10:39 (By Garfie Lee and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the Solomon Islands was the only one of Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region which he had visited, expressing hope of going there again.
Ma indicated his wish in a meeting with outgoing Solomon Islands Ambassador to Taiwan Beraki Jino at the Presidential Office.
Jino, who has served in Taiwan for six years, has been appointed to serve as the Solomon Island's high commissioner to Australia.
A new ambassador to Taiwan has not been announced by the Solomon Islands government yet.
Recalling his visit to the country 13 years ago, Ma said he was deeply impressed by the Solomon Islands' scenic landscape and its history of having been a battlefield during World War II.

Ma has yet to visit any of Taiwan's allies in the South Pacific since becoming president in 2008. His predecessor former President Chen Shui-bian had paid numerous visits to the countries, in his efforts to maintain diplomatic allies for Taiwan to counter China's efforts to woo them.

Ma has adopted a different approach of not competing with Beijing for diplomatic allies, but simply trying to strengthen relations with various countries, regardless of whether they have formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
However, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ma is planning to visit South Pacific allies sometime between March and April to attend a Taiwan-South Pacific leaders' summit.
In the meeting with Jino Wednesday, Ma thanked Jino for his efforts to promote friendship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: What does Chou's withdrawal from mayoral race mean?

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei's announcement of his decision not to throw his hat into the ring in the race for the Xinbei City mayoral post epitomizes the superiority of democracy.

If Taiwan were still under an authoritarian party-state system as it was during the martial law era, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) could have arbitrarily insisted on fielding Chou in the year-end election, even though it was fully aware of Chou's consistently poor approval ratings.

Now that Taiwan has evolved into a democracy, however, the KMT dare not follow this path; otherwise, it could lose the race to the opposition party. Even if the KMT has to pay a price for not fielding Chou, it dare not defy public opinion.

In a democratic political system, a politician suspected of corruption tends to stand little chance of winning re-election. Multiparty competition and regular elections of public officials will indeed help weed out corrupt and incompetent officials.

Public monitoring and supervision forces politicians to honor their promises even if they were made spuriously. Chou's withdrawal has once again proved the strength and merit of democracy. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Fight against swine flu successful: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 18:07:00 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the fight against swine flu, officially known as influenza A (H1N1), has been successful, so much so that the Central Epidemic Command Center was disbanded a day earlier.

The president noted that around 25 percent of the nation has been immunized, with the inoculation rate reaching as high as 75 percent among those aged under 18, so that the disease has been brought firmly under control.
"The war against the disease has been successful," Ma said.
The nationwide immunization program kicked into gear last Nov. 1, with health care personnel and people affected by Typhoon Morakot among the first to receive the shots.
Ma cited as another tangible result of his administration the reconstruction work in the wake of Morakot.

He pointed out that 800 households rendered homeless by the typhoon moved into permanent shelters before the Lunar New Year, while those who remain in temporary accommodation in military barracks have had their living units converted into a more homely style with greater privacy.

The president estimated that "the settlement of 2,000 households should be possible" by the first anniversary of the disastrous typhoon that took place Aug. 7-9, 2009, bringing the heaviest rain in half a century that caused serious mudslides and flooding in southern Taiwan.

Speaking to the board directors and supervisors of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce as well as the heads of local chambers of commerce from 20 cities and counties, the president said "the biggest problem now is unemployment."
He noted that the unemployment rate was 5.68 percent in January and that the number of medium- and long-term unemployed has continued to increase.
The top priority is to cut unemployment, Ma said, adding that the government has worked out strategies and measures that will be unveiled soon.
On Taiwan's economic recovery, Ma said he was elated to see tallies released earlier in the week by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The economic growth in the fourth quarter of last year reached 9.22 percent, the highest in nearly a decade. Even though this was because the basis for comparison was low, he said it is nevertheless still a positive development.
The DGBAS also adjusted economic growth for this year upward from 4.39 percent to 4.72 percent, Ma went on, adding that the Executive Yuan has set the target at 4.8 percent.
If the development continues, per capita income could exceed US$18,000 this year, Ma said.
Ma reiterated the missions of economic recovery this year as job creation, innovation promotion, energy conservation and carbon emission cuts, as well as involving Taiwan in regional integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-born conductor named music director of American orchestra
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 18:22:57 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born conductor Chen Mei-Ann has been named the new director of the Memphis Symphony Orchestra (MSO) in Memphis, Tennessee, according to the orchestra's Web site.
Chen will be the fourth music director of the orchestra, said an announcement posted on the Web site. Her three-year contract with the MSO will begin in the 2010-2011 season.

Currently an assistant conductor and a League of American Orchestras Conducting fellow with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Chen is considered one of America's most exciting and promising young conductors.

"Chen's artistry, her relentless pursuit of excellence, and her understanding of how an orchestra needs to be truly relevant on and off the concert stage are all reasons she was the search committee's selection, " Ryan Fleur, President and CEO of the Memphis Symphony Orchestra, said in the announcement released.
Following a two-year search process, Chen was selected from among four finalists, all of whom had conducted the symphony and met with musicians, the search committee and the public.

The other finalists were Alastair Willis, former associate conductor of the Seattle Symphony; Thomas Wilkins, music director of the Omaha Symphony; and Robert Moody, music director of the Portland (Maine) Symphony and the Winston- Salem Symphony.
Born in Taiwan, Chen has lived in the United States since 1989. She holds a Doctor of Musical Arts degree in conducting from the University of Michigan.
Chen was the first student in the New England Conservatory's history to receive double master's degrees simultaneously in violin and conducting.
Her resume includes working as an assistant conductor and music director in Baltimore, Atlanta and Portland, Oregon.
While having worked in the U.S. for many years, Chen has not forgotten her birth country.
She is scheduled to come back to Taiwan to conduct the local National Symphony Orchestra (NSO) in May.
"I am thrilled to have the opportunity to lead the Memphis Symphony Orchestra as its next music director, " said Chen in the orchestra's news release.
"Together, the orchestra and I will introduce new ideas and exciting music that will inspire and engage all who come in contact with this wonderful orchestra."
The Memphis Symphony Orchestra has been around since 1952.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-premier to announce decision soon on Xinbei mayorship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 18:27:52 (By Chen Ja-fo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday his decision on whether to run for the Xinbei mayorship will be announced after the Feb. 27 legislative by- elections.

Su was responding to reporters' questions on the issue during a visit to Chiayi County to campaign for Chen Ming-wen, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate who is running for one of the legislative seats.

The question of Su's political path has been given much play in the media because he is seen as the DPP's most likely candidate for the 2012 presidential election. He is reportedly in a dilemma over whether to run in the mayoral election or to concentrate on the presidential bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Taiwan squad to clash with Australia in Davis Cup first round
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 18:45:00 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has opted to send a young Davis Cup team to face Australia in the first round of Asia-Oceania Zone Group I play next month in Melbourne, Australia after its top veteran players decided not to play.

Representing Taiwan in the world's premier team tennis competition against Australia will be Yang Tsung-hua, Yi Chu-huan, Huang Liang-chi and Lee Hsin-han, all 22-years-old or younger, the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association (CTTA) announced recently.

Taiwan's top players Lu Yen-hsun and Wang Yeu-tzuoo decided to pass on the tournament so that younger players could have an opportunity to gain valuable experience in major international competitions, according to a statement released by the association.
The pair believed that the exposure would benefit the development of these young talents as well as Taiwanese tennis in the long run, the CTTA said.

Lu currently ranks 103rd on the ATP (Association of Tennis Professionals) Tour while Wang was ranked as high as 85th in 2006 before sustaining various injuries that have kept him out of competitive tennis for much of the past two years.
Wang hopes to resume tournament play in the coming weeks after doctors cleared him to play following wrist surgery last year.

Lu and Wang could still join the team in later rounds, whether it means gaining promotion to the World Group or avoiding relegation to Asia Oceania Group II, said CTTA Secretary-General Liu Chung-hsing.
The absence of Lu and Wang is somewhat unfortunate since Australia will be without veteran stalwart Lleyton Hewitt and could be vulnerable.
The Australian team will consist of Peter Luczak, ranked 75th in the world, 17 -year-old phenom Bernard Tomic, Davis Cup veteran Carsten Bell and doubles specialist Paul Hanley.

Taiwan's tennis association has high hopes for its new faces, led by 19-year-old Yang Tsung-hua. Yang is currently ranked 330th in the world, and had the top singles/doubles combined ranking for juniors in 2008.
Yang will be hoping to avenge a loss to Tomic in the boys' singles final of the 2008 Australian Open.
Huang Liang-chi was ranked No. 3 in the ITF Junior ranking at one point while Yi and Lee won the men's doubles gold in the World University Games last year.

It will be only the third time that Taiwan's Davis Cup team will not have either Lu or Wang since the country won promotion in 2004 to Asia-Oceania Group I, just one step away from the top level World Group.

At the time, most tennis observers believed that with two players of their caliber, Taiwan would have plenty of opportunities to finish in the top two of the eight-team Group I and get a shot at a playoff to reach the World Group.

But injuries, conflicts with the CTTA, and disappointing performances have derailed those hopes, and without Lu or Wang this year, the six-year streak of not reaching the World Group playoffs is likely to continue.
In the other matchups of the Asia-Oceania Zone, Japan meets the Philippines, China takes on Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan will play South Korea.

If Taiwan beats Australia, it will play the winner of the Japan-Philippines clash in a battle for promotion, but if it falls, it will have to play the loser of the Japan-Philippines match in a relegation battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: No Chinese imports into Taiwan via Vietnam: envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/24/10 18:55:47 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese trade representative to Taipei rebutted allegations Wednesday that Chinese agricultural products have been imported into Taiwan via Vietnam and demanded supporting evidence.

Ho Quoc Phi, deputy head of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (VECO), told CNA that the allegations have formed a major barrier to the import of Vietnamese goods into Taiwan, even though he has already clarified the situation to Taiwan's top agricultural authority.

He admitted that there were cases of smuggled Chinese farm produce being brought into Taiwan through Vietnam, including tea, cigarettes and garlic, in 1991, but pointed out that "those involved in those acts could not get Vietnamese certificates of origin."
His remarks came after lawmakers recently leveled the accusation and said that a Vietnamese certificate of origin can be bought for less than US$350.
Ho urged the lawmakers to provide a copy of the counterfeit document to his office, so that its authenticity can be checked.
He also expressed doubt that any Vietnamese official would issue counterfeit certificates of origin, as they would face serious punishment.
The Vietnamese government began cracking down on this kind of corruption from the end of 1994 and there have been no such recorded cases since 1995, he said.
Ho also noted that labor costs in China are relatively high at present and said it would not make economic sense to ship goods from China to Taiwan through Vietnam.

"We are willing to help investigate whether the allegations are true. If they are true, we will shoulder all the investigation costs. If they turn out to be spurious, those who made the allegations should pay the bill," Ho said.
He said the Vietnamese authorities have been cooperating with Taiwanese customs officials to investigate suspicious Vietnamese imports into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier outlines principles for energy tax
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 19:28:32 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih outlined Wednesday the Cabinet's principles in introducing an energy tax, saying that before imposing such duty, the government will first make sure it is the right policy at the right time and that the method of implementation is right.
In addition, the policy should be supported by a comprehensive package of complementary measures and should be promoted in a step-by-step manner, Wu said.
The premier made the remarks during a meeting of the National Council for Sustainable Development.
On the question of land conservation, Wu said Taiwan must take the issue of climate change seriously after experiencing the disastrous consequences of Typhoon Morakot last August.

According to Wu, the public should increase their participation in land conservation efforts, while the central and local governments should also step up their cooperation and form closer partnerships.

In the future, land conservation will be the responsibility of a ministry of environmental resources that is expected to be established in 2012, Wu said. This will help improve the present situation in which land conservation-related affairs are scattered among several different agencies, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canada-Taiwan forestry management workshop to be held Thursday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 19:35:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A workshop will be held Thursday to study and share forestry management experience and development in Canada and Taiwan, with the goal of maintaining a sustainable and livable environment, organizers said Wednesday.

The "Sustainable Forestry Management Workshop", organized by the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) and Forest Products Association of Canada, will be a one-day event to discuss sustainable forest management in Canada and study the development of a forest product industry in Taiwan.

"With 10 percent of the world's forests, Canada accepts the reality that its forest management has global implications, " CTOT Executive Director Scott Fraser said. "Every year, Canada regenerates close to 700,000 hectares of forest -- more than all other countries combined."
Fraser said he hopes the workshop will provide both countries with an opportunity to share that experience.

Taiwan is currently one of Canada's biggest trading partners and imports about C$60 million (US$56.8 million) worth of lumber from Canada every year. Taiwan, once a lumber exporter, has 72 percent forest coverage, according to the CTOT.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Dual-head system needs strong leadership

TEXT.P: The replacement of President Ma Ying-jeou's top national security aide has shed light on deformities in our dual-head central government system as prescribed in the Constitution.

The real cause behind Su Chi's resignation as National Security Council (NSC) secretary-general was closely related to two controversial incidents -- which agency had the authority to decide whether Taiwan should accept foreign aid in the wake of Typhoon Morakot and which agency was empowered to decide whether Taiwan should open its market to U.S. ground beef and bovine offal.
The disputes could stem from our crippled dual-head political system.

The system is patterned after the French system, which actually has only one top government head. When both the presidency and the parliament are controlled by the same political party, the president is the real government head. When the presidency and the parliament are controlled by different parties, the president has to name the head of the majority party in the parliament as the prime minister, who is the real government head.

Our Constitution, however, fails to provide a viable or workable mechanism for implementing such a system. It only defines that the president is authorized to deal with defense, diplomacy and cross-strait affairs, while the agencies responsible for such affairs are all under the jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan.

As secretary-general of the NSC under the Presidential Office, Su Chi thought the U.S. beef was the president's responsibility. However, it was the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan that faced the public complaints and protests and in the end, the ruling Kuomintang-controlled legislature passed an amendment to annul the U.S. beef trade deal struck by the president.

The incident was an incredible mess in Taiwan's political history. Given such a crippled dual leadership system, Ma should show mettle and courage, and should resolve to ensure the smooth operation of our government. (Feb. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 20:01:37 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped by 67.77 points Wednesday, with the benchmark weighed index finishing at 7,529.67 on a slim turnover of NT$83.885 billion (US$2.62 billion) .
The three major institutional investors sold a net value of NT$4.663 billion in Taiwanese shares, which included net sales of NT$5.192 million by foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs.
According to analysts, the local bourse followed the drop in the U.S. stock market the previous night and was an indication of a lack of buying interest among investors.
Of the eight major stock categories, plastic and paper shares gained the most, while steel, automobile, and construction shares fell the sharpest.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP aims to take at least two seats in legislative by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 20:06:45 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would deem it a victory if the party wins two seats in the four legislative by-elections that will take place Saturday to fill the seats left vacant in Taoyuan, Hualien, Hsinchu and Chiayi counties, a DPP spokesman said Wednesday.

The DPP expects to secure the seat in Chiayi County, a DPP stronghold in southern Taiwan, but given that the races in the other three counties are uphill battles, winning two of the four seats up for grabs in the by-elections would be considered a victory for the party, according to DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang.
Lin said that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen gave a directive Wednesday at a party meeting that all DPP members should go all-out to campaign for candidates in the four by-elections.
The aim is to score wins in the constituencies in order to provide checks and balances against the ruling party Kuomintang, Lin quoted Tsai as saying.

According to Lin, Tsai told party members to stick to their guns to sincerely solicit voters' support and properly respond to any possible use of negative election tactics in the run-up to the by-elections.

DPP candidates in the by-elections are former Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen in Chiayi, Huang Jen-shu in Taoyuan County, former DPP lawmaker Peng Shao-chin in Taoyuan, and another former DPP lawmaker Hsiao Bi-khim in Hualien.
Taiwan has 25 counties and cities. Currently the ruling party's members hold the top elected positions in 17 of them, while the DPP controls eight of them.
The seats in the four counties which will hold the by-elections were made vacant because local lawmakers were elected county magistrates Dec. 5, 2009.

The elections Saturday and the elections for the heads of five of the biggest municipalities in Taiwan in December are widely seen as a gauge of the popularity of the ruling party KMT, which also controls the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Respected Taiwanese singer-songwriter dies at 82
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 20:13:10 (By Tsai Hsin-hua, Chen Li-ting, Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Hung Yi-feng, a highly respected Taiwanese singer-songwriter, died of pancreatic cancer Wednesday at Taipei Medical University Hospital. He was 82.
Hung was diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer Dec. 7, 2009, according to his family.
He was hospitalized Dec. 26 after he fell into a coma following a bout of pneumonia, and was transferred to a hospice ward Feb. 11.
Commenting on Hung's death, Premier Wu Den-yih said he regrets the loss of a great artist who contributed to Taiwanese music, show business and recording industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Hsinchu mayor to join Cabinet as minister without portfolio
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 21:13:54 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Former Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer has been appointed as a minister without portfolio in the Executive Yuan and will serve concurrently as governor of Taiwan province, the Cabinet announced Wednesday.

Lin, 66, who holds a Master's degree from National University in the U.S. and a Bachelor's degree from Soochow University, had served previously as an associate professor at National Chiao Tung University, a Hsinchu County councilor, a member of the National Assembly and a legislator.
The governor of Taiwan position was previously held by Minister without Portfolio Chang Jin-Fu.
Meanwhile, Minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Tsai Hsung-hsiung will no longer hold the concurrent post of minister without portfolio, according to the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT deputy personnel officer resigns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 21:58:15 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Wu Jui-ying, the new deputy personnel officer of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , resigned Wednesday amid reports that he had sexually harassed a woman four years ago.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said he has approved Wu's resignation, which came just 24 days after Wu assumed the position.
Wu, a former a vice president of 1111 Job Bank, was recruited by King to join the KMT management and officially took office Feb. 1.

However, the tabloid Next magazine reported Wednesday that in 2006 Wu made numerous unwelcome phone calls to a National Tsinghua University student -- actions that the magazine said amounted to sexual harassment.
Wu did not deny he had called the woman but argued that the calls did not constitute sexual harassment.

Wu made headlines in January when he acknowledged that he had once had an affair with entertainer Pan Hui-ju. He disclosed that the affair had led to his divorce from his wife, but said he was planning to remarry her.
Asked Wednesday if Wu's appointment to the KMT position was ill advised, King said he could not comment because Wu had not had a chance to display his expertise in personnel management.
King expressed disapproval over the media's preoccupation with Wu's private life, and said Wu would probably not have been subjected to such close scrutiny had he not been recruited into the KMT.
King said he is seeking a replacement for Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to sponsor at least 8,000 Haitian children: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 22:12:57 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday civic groups and charities in Taiwan will sponsor 8,000 to 10,000 Haitian orphans and children from low-income families.

Addressing a Lunar New Year party held by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in honor of foreign diplomats and representatives stationed in Taipei, Ma said Taiwan has finalized an aid package to help its Caribbean ally get back on its feet after a devastating magnitude-7 earthquake in January.

In addition to the child sponsorship program, Ma said, the aid package will include a Taiwan healthcare center in Haiti to train medical and healthcare staff, 1,200 permanent houses that will be able to accommodate 6,000 displaced families, and vocational training centers for 3,500 job seekers.

Ma, who made a stopover in the Dominican Republic Jan. 28 on his way home from Honduras to show his concern for earthquake-battered Haiti, said Taiwan will be a responsible stakeholder in the international community under his leadership.
The Republic of China will be a peacemaker, not a troublemaker, a humanitarian aid provider, not an apathetic bystander, Ma said.
According to the president, his administration's top foreign policy goal is to make Taiwan an internationally respected country.
On external relations, Ma said his government's efforts to improve relations with China will also contribute to Taiwan's relations with other major countries around the world.
He also expressed the hope that China will show more goodwill and less obstructionist tendencies with regard to Taiwan's bid to join international governmental and non-governmental organizations.
"If China can do this, the people of Taiwan will be more willing to support my administration's efforts to deepen cross-strait engagements, which in turn will lead to a benign cycle," Ma added.

In an effort to make Taiwan a hub for Asia-Pacific trade, Ma said, his administration is working to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China to smooth the way for similar free trade agreements with its other major trade partners.
"All these efforts are aimed at protecting us from being marginalized in this era of globalization and regional economic integration," Ma added.
Stressing Taiwan's efforts to develop soft power, Ma said his government plans to offer more Taiwan scholarships to attract young foreign students.
The dinner party at Taipei Grand Hotel featured dishes and delicacies made with local ingredients such as Hsinchu rice noodle, Puli winter mushrooms, Penghu seafood and Yilan duck.
Members of the Taipei diplomatic corps, senior government officials and prominent business executives attended the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Rotarians join global polio eradication efforts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/10 22:40:16 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese Rotarians from all seven districts are joining Rotary International's anti-polio efforts by beaming the words "End Polio" from Taiwan's landmark skyscraper Taipei 101 from now until Feb. 28.

Michael Liu, spokesman for Taipei Financial Center Corp. which manages the skyscraper, said Wednesday that the company is pleased to take part in the global social welfare campaign because it will help enhance the image of both Taipei 101 and Taiwan.

According to Rotarians from District 3520 in Taiwan, although the global organization Rotary International has been promoting a polio-free world since 1985, the crippling disease is still endemic in four countries -- Pakistan, Afghanistan, India and Nigeria. This means further efforts are needed to eradicate polio, they said.

In a bid to wipe out polio worldwide, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates has so far donated US$355 million to the Rotary Foundation through the Mellinda and Bill Gates Foundation, the local Rotarians added.

The Global Polio Eradication Initiative, the largest internationally coordinated public health project, was spearheaded and is being carried out by Rotary International, the World Health Organization (WHO) , the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and UNICEF (the United Nations Children's Fund).

To mark the 105th anniversary of Rotary International, the seven district governors have established a cross district public service platform to push the "10 Great Projects to Make Taiwan Better, " with the aim of forming 540 Rotary Clubs in Taiwan and recruiting 18,500 new members.
In addition to lighting the "End Polio" signs on Taipei 101, Taiwanese Rotarians said, they also plan to erect 600 billboards around the country to promote the spirit of public service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 25, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: John P. Morgan, one of the greatest financiers in the United States, founds the United States Steel Corp.
1913: The U.S. Congress passes the 16th amendment to the Constitution, paving the way for an income tax levying system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cambodians thankful for fearlessness of Taiwanese Good Samaritan

TEXT.P: Wei-lin Yang was working as a flight attendant with Taiwan's flagship carrier China Airlines 20 years ago when she decided to dedicate herself to problems far more momentous than keeping airline passengers happy.

Confronting the despair experienced in Cambodia following a lengthy period of war and killing, Yang decided to actively improve the lives of the country's refugees, and her vision has remained firm to this day despite facing personal danger, cultural obstacles, funding shortages, and a long illness.
Her efforts were recently recognized by Reader's Digest, which named her as one of six nominees for the Asian of Year Award 2010.
Though she did not win the top prize, her Field Relief Agency of Taiwan (FRA) has consistently been a winner among the 70,000 Cambodian children she's helped over the years.
Ironically, it was through her job with China Airlines that Yang found her life's devotion.

Yang had already worked as a volunteer with Taiwan's 119 rescue hotline before graduating from college, and her compassion for the underprivileged became "globalized" after joining the airline in 1983.

One of her regular stops was Bangkok, and she could not look on dispassionately when Cambodian refugees from the Thai-Cambodian border gathered in the city in the mid-to-late 1980s -- the legacy of a decade-long civil war in the western part of the country following the murderous Khmer Rouge's rule between 1975 and 1979.
She quit the airline in 1989 to join a refugee service center at the Thai border run by the United Nations High Commissioner of Refugees.

Working for five years at the center, where she came face to face with death, injuries, horror and extreme despair on a daily basis, Yang became convinced that the temporary centers were not the long-term solutions to the Cambodian refugees' problems.

Crystallizing her conviction was something she saw in her first year on the Thai-Cambodian border. A fatherless girl, whose mother had also just died, was begging in a local market, carrying her six-day-old baby brother in a swaddling cloth on her chest.

The girl left after receiving some money for food, but Yang said that the image of the infant's wide-open mouth and dying face lingered in her mind for a long time and convinced her that money alone would also not solve the problem.
Betting on education, Yang eventually established the FRA in 1995 to help Cambodian people in poor and heavily mined areas get a better chance in life.
Over the next four years, Yang helped establish 15 makeshift schools, sponsored some 700 orphans, and managed to recruit 27 volunteer teachers from Taiwan to work in the schools.

But those four years also taxed her health and her sanity, posing the most formidable challenges she had ever faced in a philanthropic environment -- employee infighting, unfit Taiwanese volunteers, and funding shortages.
And some of the very orphans she was trying to help were skeptical of the group's intentions, fearing they would be sold or re-sold to human traffickers.

Yang was also undone by a series of mishaps -- a car accident she was lucky to survive; a serious burn to her hand sustained when she put out a fire in a frying pan when an aide was cooking in the wild; and a near-encounter with bandits, who were tracking her vehicle, hoping to get their hands on her relief supplies.

The encounter was averted when some acquaintances came to her rescue at the last minute, but that experience, and her mounting problems, left her so mentally and physically exhausted that she fell ill for six months in late 1999.

During that time, FRA operations in Cambodia came to a virtual halt, but her illness gave her valuable time to reflect on her campaign, and she concluded that more than compassion and enthusiasm was needed to deal with the orphans or refugees' problems and the conflicts within her organization.

Realizing that she needed to change her management strategy and raise more money, Yang returned to her base in Poipet -- a Cambodian town on the country's northwestern border with Thailand -- and restarted FRA operations.
She actually lowered the wage she paid to local employees from US$200 to US$100 per month, a shock that made them less prone to infighting and more diligent.
She also screened Taiwanese staff and volunteers more strictly, declining the help of those who could not withstand hardships or challenges.
And those orphans or refugees who were skeptical of the FRA's intentions were allowed to leave FRA shelters if they chose to.
The result is that over the past 15 years, Yang has helped over 70,000 children in Cambodia, taking in orphans and those afflicted with AIDS while providing financial support to others.
Vocational training centers have been built to help adults -- many of whom are survivors of land-mine explosions -- learn skills and make a living for themselves.
She has also trained Mandarin- and Cambodian-language teachers to teach at the schools she established and to travel to rural areas in 10 provinces around the war-battered country to help the needy.

"This is a labor-intensive job, and one's work is never done, " admitted Yang, a Kaohsiung City native who is also a writer for the United Daily News and author of two books. "I've probably been defeated by difficulties, but I never gave up."

Funding and donations remain a concern, but in early 2008, Yang caught a break. She told a Liberty Times reporter that she needed 3,500 stationery kits to be distributed to Cambodian children, many of whom had never seen a tube of glue or a pencil sharpener in their lives.
The story was posted online, and to Yang's surprise, stationery supplies flooded her Taipei office from all corners of Taiwan.

The FRA packaged the scissors, staplers, erasers, pencils, sharpeners and white- out received into kits, which were then transported to Cambodia in three 40-foot containers. The kits have been distributed over the past two years on weekends to 66,000 children, many of whom live in villages that are inaccessible by car.
"All the work is worth it when you see the amazement and happiness on the children's face when they open the kits, " she explained.

In recent years, Yang's organization has moved beyond its core education programs. It has helped drill wells in areas where tap water was just a dream, after making sure the underground water was safe to drink, she said.

When the underground water in a village in Ratanakiri province in northeast Cambodia was found to have an excessive amount of arsenic, the FRA bought 625 6,000-liter water containers made of gravel and cement locally to distribute to local families to collect rainwater.

In another village in the province, Yang and the FRA workers took action when they found a hospital with only one operating table and no beds for women to rest on after giving birth, buying two medical beds for the facility.
"We don't turn our back on problems. We look for them, " said Yang, whose goal for 2010 is to build a hospital in the province if she can raise NT$5 million.

The hospital will be a "land-mine hospital" because many residents in the area were victims of land-mine explosions who need constant medical attention, said Yang, who has twice been given the medal of national honor by Cambodia's government.
The 50-year-old Good Samaritan said her longer-term goal is to hand down her skills and vision and plant more altruistic "seeds."

Yang actually began preparing for the goal two years ago when she began studying for a doctorate at National Dong Hwa University -- her ticket to teaching at the university level where she hopes to cultivate the Yangs of the future and broaden her impact on the underprivileged in Cambodia and Asia.
ENDITEM/ls
CNA photos 2-5
by Deborah Kuo, CNA staff writer
