DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Taiwan urgently needs green revolution
DOC.DATELINE: 02/25/10 11:11:37 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The premiere of the film "Plus or Minus Two Degrees Celsius, " which is the Taiwan version of "An Inconvenient Truth, " has raised hopes among many local people that the problem of Taiwan's deteriorating environment would finally be addressed.
Global warning is a worldwide issue. A U.N. panel had warned that the survival of the human race could be at risk if global temperatures rise by 2 degrees Celsius.
The question is how should Taiwan deal with this problem?
Climate experts have forecast that the Arctic could be free of summer ice by 2020 to 2037, which would raise sea levels worldwide by six meters.
In such a senario, Taiwan would be among the first victims. Areas on the island that are currently less than 100 meters above sea level could be immersed.

Last year, Typhoon Morakot brought 3,000 mm of rain to Alishan. If half of that should fall in the Shimen Reservoir area, the reservoir would break and flood Taipei County and Taipei City with 300 million tons of water, scholars have said. The Taipei 101 tower would be the only landmark above the water in the Taipei basin, if that should happen, according to the scholars.
Because of Taiwan's special geographical figures, it is likely to suffer heavier erosion damage than other Asian states from torrential rain.

Typhoon Morakot will not be the last storm to hit Taiwan. The island should brace itself for more powerful typhoons carrying heavier rains and for more drastic weather patterns alternating between torrential rain and drought and between very hot and very cold temperatures.

The U.N. panel has called for all countries in the world, including Taiwan, to work toward defusing the climate crisis. We support the idea of everyone writing a letter to the president, urging him to take action to save the island, the country and our children. (Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan invites South Korean tourists to attend Lantern Festival
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 11:44:54 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Tourism Bureau is pitching the Lantern Festival to South Koreans as one of Taiwan's major tourist attractions.

Chen Pei-tsen, head of the Taiwan Tourism Bureau office in the South Korean capital, said the 2010 Taiwan Lantern Festival, to be held Feb. 26-March 7, will be centered for the first time in the southern city of Chiayi and is expected to attract millions of visitors from home and abroad.
It takes only an hour and a half to travel from Taipei to Chiayi City via high- speed rail and three and a half hours by highway bus, Chen said.

In addition to Chiayi, she said, other cities around Taiwan, including Taipei, Taitung, Tainan and Kaohsiung, as well as Taipei County, are preparing to hold festive galas to celebrate the Lantern Festival.
Korean visitors will be offered a number of gifts, including a lantern symbolizing the Year of the Tiger and a commemorative lantern festival mug and towel, Chen added.
The Lantern Festival, which signifies the end of the Chinese New Year holiday and the arrival of spring, is one of the major festivals in Taiwan, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Pre-election payment of senior citizen stipend

TEXT.P: The financially strapped Hsinchu County government decided Wednesday to distribute the senior citizen stipend for January before the legislative by- election this weekend and to include wealthy elderly residents.
But the county government said that with effect from February, senior citizens from rich families will not be eligible to receive the benefit.

The controversial decision has drawn a range of reactions. Some critics have said that the distribution of the stipend before the election is a vote-buying gambit that would favor the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) candidate, while some KMT supporters have expressed worry that the decision to stop the payment to wealthy senior residents with effect from February may draw backlash against the KMT in the by-election.

With only two days to go before the legislative by-elections in four counties, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is urging prosecutors to take precautionary action against possible election bribery.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times: Since taking office last year, Hsinchu Magistrate Chiu Ching-chun, who vacated the legislative seat in the county, has repeatedly complained about the county's financial woes.

Under heavy pressure to help the KMT legislative candidate Cheng Yung-tang win the seat, Chiu announced Wednesday that the county government has earmarked NT$130 million for distribution to the county's over-65 residents, as the January stipend, in the next two days.

In accordance with the central government's instructions, the county government had originally decided to exclude senior citizens from rich families from the NT$6,000 monthly stipend with effect from January, but Chiu said this will not be implemented until February.
Because of local governments' limited financial resources, the payment of senior citizen stipends tend to be delayed for months.

Hsinchu County government spokesman Chang Chien-chia rebutted the accusation that the decision to pay the January stipend before the election was a form of election bribery. He stressed that the delay in payment until now stemmed mainly from the county's financial problems.
He also explained that the decision to stop the payment to rich senior citizens from February was in line with a Control Yuan directive.
"The watchdog body has repeatedly asked us to do so in the first few months of the year," he added.
Exclusion of rich citizens from the stipend will save the county more than NT$1 billion a year. (Feb. 25, 2010)

Liberty Times: The Hsinchu County government began to distribute asenior citizen stipend of NT$5,000 per month in 1994. The amount was later raised to NT$6,000. Over the past 16 years, the county has spent NT$25.7 billion on the program.
Of the northern county's annual social welfare budget of about NT$3 billion, the senior citizen stipend accounts for NT$2.6 billion.
A county government official said Wednesday that once rich senior citizens are excluded from the stipend, the annual budget for the program will decrease to just over NT$700 million.

The official further said the decision has nothing to do with the upcoming by- election. The exclusion of wealthy citizens will take effect in February mainly because the county government needs time to finalize bureaucratic procedures for the systematic changes, the official said. (Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New top security adviser vows to protect national dignity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 14:05:25 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's new top national security adviser said Thursday that his priority is safeguarding the country and its people and protecting national dignity.

Hu, who assumed the post of secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC) two days ago, said during a meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng that he will make every effort to assist President Ma in formulating and executing national security policies.

"I usually keep a low profile at home but, as far as national security affairs are concerned, I will take a firm stand and even lift my voice abroad to defend our national dignity and sovereignty," Hu said.
For his part, Wang described Hu, a former Taiwan representative to German and Singapore, as a rare diplomatic talent who is also well versed in national security affairs.

There is no doubt that Hu, also a former deputy NSC secretary-general and a former deputy director of the National Security Bureau, will make an able NSC chief and will serve as one of President Ma's right hand men, Wang said.
Hu has replaced Su Chi, who resigned Feb. 11 for health and family reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Don't count on spokesmen to lift government image
DOC.DATELINE: 02/25/10 14:33:01 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In an effort to refurbish the government's image, President Ma, in rare move, has replaced the spokesmen for the Presidential Office, Executive Yuan and the Kuomintang all in one go.
However, we have to point out that the president is looking in the wrong direction. What he should be doing is replacing those Cabinet members who are hardly worth their salt.
The Cabinet's failure to live up to public expectations is one of the reasons behind Ma's falling approval rating.

According to one opinion poll, nearly 40 percent of the Cabinet members are familiar to only about 10 percent of the public. It is incredible that so few people knew the members of the two-year old Cabinet. This is something the president should be concerned about.
Another problem is that Ma tends to select the members of his administration mainly from among his former staff at Taipei City Hall and researchers at Kuomintang think tanks.
An administrative team assembled in this way would be obviously incapable of dealing with the rapidly changing political situation. Ma should expand his horizons in the selection of his ruling team.

For example, former Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tzer was offered the lightweight post of minister without portfolio in the Cabinet, despite the fact that he had the highest approval rating among local government chiefs during his terms as mayor.
Has Ma ever thought of drawing on Lin's experience to boost his own approval rating?
It will be naive of Ma to think that he could lift his approval rating by replacing his administration's main spokesmen instead of its Cabinet members. (Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Support for referendum on trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: 02/25/10 14:57:55 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is going all out to clinch atrade pact with China despite the fact that it will put Taiwan's sovereignty, safety and economy at risk.

In order to let the people have the final say on this issue, Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei said he will push again for a referendum on the proposed pact, as the first attempt by the Democratic Progressive Party was quashed by Ma's administration.
Ma has said that the trade agreement with China will neither undermine Taiwan's sovereignty nor alter its status and therefore should not be put to a referendum.

However, he said on another occasion that the pact will be an agreement between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland, which is a negation of Taiwan's sovereignty as it implies that China comprises a mainland and Taiwan.
Ma has claimed that such a trade agreement with China will facilitate negotiations by Taiwan for similar pacts with other countries.
But a Chinese trade official rebutted that any states which intend to follow China's lead in sealing trade pacts with Taiwan should first seek Beijing's approval.

As we have pointed out many times, such a pact will speed up the relocation of local factories to China and strip more people of their jobs. If we allow President Ma to get his way, Taiwan will undoubtedly be downgraded into another Hong Kong, against the will of the people.

A referendum will be an effective way to scuttle Ma's plot, and it cannot be delayed until the next presidential election, as the Ma administration has already begun negotiations with China on the trade agreement.(Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- High school graduate scholastic ability test
DOC.DATELINE: 02/25/10 15:58:26 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: High school seniors had lower mathematics scores in their general scholastic tests this year than in previous years. In the tests, which were held islandwide Jan. 29-30, more than 2,000 students scored zero in mathematics, according to the results released Wednesday by the College Entrance Examination Center.

Of the five subject areas -- Chinese, English, mathematics, natural science and social science -- English was found to be the weakest among the 140,000 examinees, as 15,523 students scored zero in the Chinese-English and English- Chinese translation section.

The results of the scholastic tests are used by high school graduates to apply for admission to universities and colleges. This year, 112 students achieved a perfect score of 75 in the examination, which comprised 15 levels in five categories.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:

China Times: Following the announcement that 2,106 students had scored zero in the mathematics test, even teachers of some cram schools have suggested that the mathematics test method this year was especially challenging. Last year, the number of students who failed to achieve a score in mathematics was 1, 093.
The College Entrance Examination Center announced Wednesday that this year 2,059 students had achieved a full score of 15 in mathematics, as compared to 1,745 the previous year.
An analysis by the examination center showed that more than half of the 140,000 students who took the tests failed to attain the average of 5 points in mathematics.

Liberty Times: Traditionally, students with a perfect score of 75 points in the exam are most likely to be recruited by medical schools, law schools, and popular departments such as information technology and electrical engineering at prestigious schools.

However, Kuo Wei-cheng, who achieved a full score of 75 in the tests this year, said Wednesday that his first choice will be the Department of Atmospheric Sciences at National Taiwan University because he wants to become a "doctor to save the earth."

Kuo took many people by surprise, not only because of his choice of major, but also because he is from an average public school in rural Taitung County, rather than a school in the major cities of Taipei, Taichung, Tainan or Kaohsiung.

Among the 112 students who achieved full score, 17 are from Jianguo High School in Taipei, 11 from First Girls High School in Taipei, 11 from First Boys High School in Tainan, nine from Taichung First Boys' High School, and seven from Taichung Girls' High School. Most of these students are interested in attending medical school.
The entrance threshold for the medical schools at National Taiwan University (NTU), National Yang Ming University (NYMU) and National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) is 74 points.
United Daily News: The College Entrance Examination Center sent out the individual reports of the high school graduate scholastic ability tests to students Wednesday.

As students prepare to apply for admission to universities and colleges, some teachers at local cram schools have noted that the country's most sought after medical school -- NTU's -- requires a full score of 75; NTU department of electrical engineering requires 73 points; NTU department of law, 74 points; and the law schools of private universities, including Fu Jen University, Soochow University and Tamkang University, at least 50 points.
Some private universities are offering scholarships of up to NT$2 million over four years to attract top students.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA confirms Taiwanese fishermen detained in Tanzania
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 16:04:08 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese nationals have been detained in a Tanzanian prison since last March after a Taiwanese vessel was arrested for poaching in Tanzania waters, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Thursday.

FV Tawariq-4, an Omani-registered fishing boat with a Taiwanese owner and a crew composed of 15 Chinese, five Vietnamese, two Taiwanese, eight Filipinos, five Indonesians and three Kenyans, was detained March 8, 2009 and the crew have been held in two prisons ever since, according to a report from maritime watchdog Ecoterra International.

Samuel Chen, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, confirmed the case and the detention, which had not been reported previously, but said the ship owner did not seek help from the ministry until last October.
The Philippines' Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) also confirmed the detention of the eight Filipinos.

The ministry first learned of the case after receiving information from the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) office based in Nairobi, Kenya late last year, MOFA's Department of African Affairs section chief Huang Chih-yang said.

Upon learning the news, the MOFA requested representatives of the TAITRA office in Nairobi to visit the detained fishermen and provide necessary assistance and relief, MOFA spokesman James Chang said.
"After the visit, we are sure that there are no safety or health concerns for the crewmen, " Chang said.

Overseas Taiwanese in Tanzania also helped arrange the visit and communication, Huang went on, adding that the case is now in the Tanzanian judicial procedure, with the next trial expected to take place in March. He said the department will monitor the progress of the case closely.
The Omani company to which the vessel is registered has been trying to deal with the case, Yang went on, and the fishing company and the owner are expected to be fined subject to Tanzanian laws.
The detained Taiwanese are believed to be a crewman and the vessel's owner, who went to Tanzania to help with the case but was also detained due to identification and license troubles, he said.

Ecoterra has reported that one of three Kenyan crew of Tawariq-4 died under mysterious circumstances in a Tanzanian prison and that the crewmen, who have appeared in a Tanzanian court three times, have complained that none of their embassies have been following the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to open travel liaison offices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 16:10:01 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Travel associations in Taiwan and China are expected to open semi-official tourism liaison offices on each other's territory, maybe on the same day, if various technical problems can be solved, an official of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau said Thursday.

The Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Tourism Association and China's Cross-Straits Tourism Exchange Association will hold talks in the coming days to discuss issues related to setting up the liaison offices in Beijing and Taipei, respectively, according to Wayne Liu, secretary-general of the bureau and executive secretary of the Taiwan Strait Tourism Association.
The two associations are semi-official organizations set up to promote tourism between Taiwan and China.

Liu said he expects the two associations to open their offices on the same day and that both Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai and Shao Qiwei, chairman of the China National Tourism Administration (CNTA) , hope to attend the two opening ceremonies in Taiwan and China.

There are no stipulations about whether the two associations should open offices on the same day but it is a tacit agreement between the two sides, although more discussion will be needed between him and Man Hongwei, head of CNTA's Department of Affairs on Tourism of Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan, in either Hong Kong or Beijing, according to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 16:31:48 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 102.71 points, or 1.36 percent, to close at 7,426.96.

The local bourse opened at the day's high of 7,568.42, before moving to the day's low of 7,400.42. Market turnover increased to NT$100. 91 billion (US$3.14 billion) , up from NT$83.885 billion the previous day.
Of the eight major stock categories, only plastic and chemical shares gained ground, advancing 0.2 percent.

The other seven categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most at 2.1 percent. Banking and financial shares, as well as construction issues lost 1.7 percent. Machinery and electronics issues dropped 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 1.0 percent, foodstuff shares shed 0.6 percent, and textile shares were down 0.2 percent.
The three major institutional investors sold a net value of NT$11.2 billion in Taiwanese shares, which included net sales of NT$8.87 billion by foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Advance bravely toward the future

TEXT.P: The labor shortage in China and rising wages for factory workers after the Lunar New Year are hitting several export hubs in China's coastal regions hard. It is estimated that Taiwanese businessmen operating there are facing a labor shortfall of between 30 percent and 40 percent.

Some people might think this has nothing to do with Taiwan, but the fact is that tens of thousands of export businesses in China's coastal regions are of extreme importance to Taiwan's economic growth, with 75 percent of them relying heavily on Taiwanese textile and electronics shipments to these hubs in China.

Its cheap labor force was in the past a great advantage for China in global competition, but rising wages have slashed its competitive edge. Worst of all, the labor shortage is exacerbating the situation and might be pushing China's export- and cheap labor- driven economy into a dead end. As China is the lifeline for Taiwan's dwindling economy, this cannot be ignored by the Taiwanese authorities.

However, opportunity often comes with crisis. At a time when many Taiwanese businessmen in China are being driven to the wall, Taiwan can serve as a shelter. As long as Taiwan's authorities remove barriers in taxation and labor supply for them, a large number of Taiwanese companies should be willing to return home.

Although chances are slim that the Ministry of Finance and the Council of Labor Affairs will give way on either of these two issues, there is another option -- developing offshore exclusive zones in plots adjacent to Taipei Port and Kaohsiung Port, where a universal 17.5 percent tax rate could be implemented and where foreign laborers could be allowed to work based on the Singapore model. In the initial stage, only foreign companies would be permitted to open business headquarters or R&D and financial centers there.
As long as hundreds of foreign enterprises establish themselves there, investment and local demand for construction and services would take off, offsetting the losses in Taiwanese exports to China.

The idea could be immediately put into practice if the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou were to give the go-ahead. Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, who has announced that he will not seek election in year-end municipality elections, could achieve a great deal in this regard in the last 10 months of his tenure. (Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA denies plan to adopt multiple minimum wages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 16:39:06 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) denied Thursday media speculation that it might adopt a multiple minimum wage system that allows wage differences by category.
CLA Deputy Minister Pan Shih-wei said his council "has absolutely no intention of doing such a thing."
Although some experts have recommended that such a system be implemented, the CLA has assessed the feasibility but "has never accepted it," Pan said.
According to a report published Thursday in the Liberty Times, there is a proposal to set different minimum wages for workers in the northern, central, southern and eastern regions.
Also, "sub-minimum wages" might be set for marginal workers such as teenagers and women, the report claimed.

Sun Pi-hsia, head of the CLA's Department of Labor Standards, noted that multiple minimum wages are usually implemented in countries with vast territories or wide urban-rural divides, situations that obviously do not apply to Taiwan.
The CLA has assessed the proposal many times, and on each occasion, it has concluded that such a system is "unfeasible, " Sun said.

On the question of whether government representatives will withdraw from the minimum wage review committee, Sun said government representatives will not be completely absent from the committee, although their ratio on the committee will be reduced.
Also that day, legislators expressed strong opposition to the proposal of multiple minimum wages.

Yang Li-huan, a deputy whip of the ruling Kuomintang's legislative caucus, pointed out that differentiating minimum wages by region would simply result in the migration of workers from low- to high-wage regions.
Hou Tsai-feng, another caucus deputy whip, said any such proposal would be "ridiculous" and "inconceivable, " because it would divide the country's citizens into different classes.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators Chai Trong-rong, Huang Wei-cher and Huang Sue-ying said multiple minimum wages would be in violation of the principle of "equal pay for equal work."
It would be discriminatory to set lower minimum wages for women and disabled workers, Huang Sue-ying noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Give students due respect
DOC.DATELINE: 02/25/10 16:48:03 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of 112 students achieved perfect scores in the General Scholastic Ability Test, according to the College Entrance Examination Center that administers the test.

Seventeen of the students with perfect scores were from Jianguo High School in Taipei, which was the highest number from any one school. One of the Jianguo students sports red hair, while another has a goatee beard. In the eyes of parents and the conservative school faculty, they were both mavericks.
However, their achievement has debunked the myth that students whose appearance is unconventional are no good.
School faculties tend to adhere to tradition and prefer to see students wearing uniforms and crew cuts.

Such faculties are usually hostile to non-conformists and often brand them as bad students. In recent decades, many students have been disciplined for showing individualistic tendencies, and as a result their interest in studying has dampened.

In the 1970s, when the late U.S. Senator Robert F. Kennedy was asked to comment on the hippie subculture that embraced long hair and flouted convention, he said people should look at what is under the scalp, not what is on the scalp.
Instead of forcing students to adhere to tradition, faculties should give them due respect and help them to develop their individualism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will benefit from strong Chinese yuan: economists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 16:50:01 (By Erin Ho and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Taiwanese business operators in China will benefit from an appreciation of the Chinese currency, as a stronger yuan will lead China to buy more, which in turn would boost Taiwan's exports, economists of a local think- tank said Thursday.

Chen Miao, director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research's Macroeconomic Forecasting Center, said a stronger Chinese yuan will spur other countries to adjust commodity prices and will have a positive impact on foreign trade in Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries.

Sun Ming-te, deputy director of the center, agreed that appreciation of the yuan will be good news for Taiwan and its business operators in China because Taiwan's exports will rise as result of China's stronger purchasing power.

Quoting the latest world trade statistics, Sun said China posted a mild 20 percent growth in export trade in January, but its imports jumped by a whopping 80 percent during the same month. China remained Japan's major export market in January, he noted.
China's central bank has raised its savings reserve requirement rates twice recently, which is an indication of Beijing's growing worry over possible property and stock market bubbles, he said.

Beijing is now caught in a dilemma of whether to strengthen the yuan, he added. A stronger yuan will help boost China's foreign trade, imports in particular, but could also spur an influx of hot money that could fuel property and stock market bubbles, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC Group to inaugurate 5th blast furnace
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 17:50:08 (By Lawrence Chiu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Dragon Steel, a subsidiary of CSC Group, will inaugurate its first blast furnace Friday, adding to five the total number of such facilities owned by the country's leading steel refinery.

After the furnace starts operation, Dragon Steel's crude steel production will reach up to 2.5 million tons a year, and the total production by CSC Group will total 12.5 million tons a year, CSC officials said.
CSC Group is so far the only steel refinery in Taiwan that owns blast furnaces. The other four furnaces, belonging to China Steel, were inaugurated between 1971 and 1997.
The upcoming inauguration of the furnace at Dragon Steel is considered a great progress in CSC's production capacity.
Dragon Steel is expected to build its second blast furnace in 2011, which will further raise CSC's crude steel production to 15 million tons a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seoul mayor invited to attend world design congress in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Korea, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 17:52:22 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin on Thursday invited his Seoul counterpart Oh Se-hoon to attend a massive world design conference to be held in Taiwan's capital city next year.
Hau, who arrived in the South Korean capital Monday to take part in the 2010 World Design Cities Summit, paid a courtesy call on Oh, who readily accepted the invitation to join the conference.

Taipei has won the bid to host the 2011 International Design Alliance (IDA) World Congress. This means that the world's oldest and most authoritative international design event will be held for the first in Taiwan and in Asia.
Hau said that when Oh arrives in Taipei for the event next year, they will take a cycling tour along the scenic Danshui River to view the beauty of Taipei.

During Thursday's meeting, the two mayors exchanged views on a range of topics related to urban development, including Seoul's success in cleaning up two rivers that flow through the Korean capital-- Han River and Cheonggyecheon -- as well as Taipei's experience in the Danshui River cleanup.
They also shared experiences in dealing with traffic congestion issues and other matters of mutual concern.
Hau thanked Oh for inviting him to attend the design cities summit, saying that it provided him with an opportunity to reach out to top leaders of 32 metropolises in 17 countries.

"The event has helped lay a basis for inter-city exchanges and cooperation and has allowed urban planners and administrators in various countries to share their visions and experiences, " Hau said, adding he has learned much through such dialogue.
For his part, Oh thanked the Taipei City government for providing training programs for Seoul civil servants and scholarships for Korean students.

"We also appreciate Taipei City's active participation in our annual cultural gala 'Hi Seoul Festival' by sending performing troupes to present traditional Chinese arts and crafts, " Oh said. Such exchanges have helped to foster goodwill and friendship between the people of the two countries, he added.
Hau will wrap up his visit to Seoul and return to Taipei late Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Unemployment remains despite economic recovery

TEXT.P: According to tallies recently published by the Directorate General of Budget and Statistics, Taiwan will record a 4.72 percent economic growth rate for 2010 and its January jobless rate dropped to 5.68 percent. Although the government top brass is upbeat about an improved economy, unemployment remains serious in Taiwan and the government must not underestimate the issue.

The authorities should remember that the pattern of Taiwan's foreign trade is changing fast. While Taiwan is receiving more foreign orders amid the global economic recovery, this does not mean it will help enhance production or produce more jobs, as more and more local companies are engaged in the so-called "triangle trade, " in which they take orders in Taiwan from the U.S. or Europe but produce the goods overseas.

This "triangle trade" has contributed markedly to Taiwan's GDP in recent years, but has helped very little in creating jobs, causing grave concern among the public. We are highly skeptical of how much momentum can be injected into Taiwan's manufacturing sector and how much benefit the local job market will see amid the global economic recovery.

In the face of a volatile world economy, a noticeable influx of speculative capital and snowballing debt in Europe and the U.S., Taiwan must consolidate at every step when seeking to adjust its economy for both the short and long terms. At a time when the Legislative Yuan is screening an industrial innovation bill, lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition camps should take the drastically changing economic structure facing Taiwan into serious consideration. (Feb. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Two crewmen of Taiwanese vessel die during Somali hijacking: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 18:27:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Two crewmen -- an Indonesian and a Chinese national -- of a Taiwanese fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates that was later used to attack the U.S. container ship Maersk Alabama, have died, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

The MOFA also said it had not received any information from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) which reportedly wants the original crew of the Win Far 161 for questioning in connection with the piracy attack against Maersk Alabama.

The 700-ton longliner Win Far 161 and its crew of 30 were released Feb. 11 by Somali pirates who hijacked the vessel near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6, 2009. Two days later, the vessel was reported to have been used by Somali pirates as a mother ship in the April 8 attack against the U.S. ship.

Earlier this month, the MOFA said all the crew were safe and denied a report from the maritime watchdog Ecoterra International saying that three men -- two Indonesians and one Chinese crewman -- had died of malnutrition and disease.
The Win Far 161 is expected to return to Taiwan in mid-March, said Samuel Chen, director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs.
According to Ecoterra International, the 10-month Win Far 161 ordeal was the longest-running case of Somali piracy.

"During the 10 months the vessel was held in Somalia, information received by the ministry was vague and conflicting due to a lack of electronic communication, " Department of African Affairs section chief Huang Chih-yang said.

The ministry had trouble sending staff to Somalia due to safety concerns and had to rely heavily on the ship owner for information. The ship's owner did the negotiation for ransom and did not allow the ministry to interfere, Huang noted.

Chen rebutted reports that the hostages' respective authorities did not provide assistance to the crewmen and said the rescue was a coordinated international effort that involved many international organizations.

The ministry is aware of the report that the Win Far 161 was used to attack the Maersk Alabama right after it was seized, Huang went on, adding that global positioning system information shows the Taiwanese vessel was close to the U.S. ship at the time.
"It could have been used, but there is no way for us to confirm that at present, " Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 18:29:29 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, appreciating NT$0.03 to close at NT$32.12.
A total of US$816 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.09 and hit a low of NT$32.04 at one point during the session before gaining ground to close at the day's high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's premier approves disbandment of H1N1 center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 19:11:32 (CECC), which was set up in April to fight the new influenza A (H1N1) (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that he has approved the disbanding of the Central Epidemic Command Center pandemic, but he added that the center will resume operations if a third wave of H1N1 cases occurs.

After receiving a briefing by the Department of Health (DOH), Wu said that he agreed with the department's decision to disband the center two days ago because it has accomplished its mission of disease prevention and control and has reduced the negative impact of H1N1 on the nation to the lowest level.
However, Wu cautioned that the disbandment of the center does not mean the H1N1 pandemic is over or that epidemic prevention work has been suspended.

He said the government will continue its efforts in monitoring the epidemic situation, providing vaccination and health care services, stockpiling anti-flu medications and promoting the concept of health.
The government will also help and provide health care for patients who experienced side effects after receiving the H1N1 vaccine, the premier added.
According to DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang, H1N1 flu cases have waned significantly worldwide, except for South East Asia and South America.

Yaung said although the World Health Organization has advised that it was too early to conclude that the pandemic was in a post-peak period, the flu infections in many developed countries have waned because of the countries' well-established monitoring systems and vaccination programs for epidemic control.
The total number of confirmed H1N1 deaths in Taiwan was 41, while the number of Americans who died from H1N1 was about 11,000.
Taiwan's death rate from H1N1 per million people is the third lowest in the world, while its H1N1 inoculation rate is the fourth highest in the world, Yaung noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet scraps plan for 15% corporate income tax rate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 20:21:49 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has decided in principle to scrap a controversial proposal to grant an extra-low 15 percent corporate income tax rate to multinational companies that set up their headquarters in Taiwan, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou said Thursday.

Hwang explained that the preferential tax rate, covered in Article 30 of the proposed industrial innovation statute, is aimed at encouraging foreign companies -- primarily those among the world's 500 largest -- to set up their headquarters in Taiwan.

However, after consultations with the foreign business community, it was pointed out to the ministry that foreign investors would be unlikely to move their headquarters to Taiwan just because of a low tax rate, Hwang said.
Furthermore, he continued, only four Taiwan businesses would be eligible for the lower tax rate if the policy were adopted, which is considered unfair to local businesses.

The controversial article, deemed as benefiting only foreign businesses, had drawn strong protests from local business leaders, including Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo, who threatened to move Hon Hai's headquarters out of Taiwan if the plan went ahead.
In light of the controversy, Premier Wu Den-yih told legislators recently that the Cabinet had decided to remove the article from the bill.
According to Hwang, the bill would provide tax breaks as incentives to encourage businesses to engage in research and development.
Besides the manufacturing sector, there might also be tax breaks targeting the service sector, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taiwanese industries optimistic on future outlook: think tank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 20:35:33 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: More industries in Taiwan expressed optimism over the economic outlook in the next six months, according to a monthly business climate survey released by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Thursday.

According to the results of the survey of the manufacturing and service sectors, 43.8 percent of the businesses which responded to the survey in January expressed optimism about the outlook in the next six months, up from 42.3 percent in December.

Meanwhile, 47 percent of the respondents held a reserved outlook for the same period, a drop from 47.7 percent in the previous month, while only 9.1 percent thought it will get worse, down from 9.9 percent in December, the survey shows.

Chen Miao, director of the TIER's Macroeconomic Forecasting Center, said that as January and the next six months are the low-season for sales of consumer electronics, some manufacturing companies expressed reservations on the outlook in the next six months.

However, anticipating that sales could be boosted with strong demand from emerging markets and the gradual recovery in the global economy, the manufacturing sector as a whole predicted Taiwan's economy in the next six months would grow slightly, Chen noted.
The January business climate index in the manufacturing sector stood at 117.97, up by 0.4 points from the figure in December, the survey shows.

The same index for the service sector registered 125.31, down by 0.50 points from the previous month, according to the TIER, which attributed the decline to a fall in profits in securities firms because of steep drops in the local stock market in January.

Chen also said he expects that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will present better-than-expected data concerning sales in the wholesale, retail and catering sectors. The ministry was scheduled to release relevant figures later Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA vice president to be new Presidential Office spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 20:38:47 (By Garfie Li and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office announced Thursday the appointment of CNA Vice President Lo Chih-chiang as its new spokesman.
Lo, who served as a spokesman for President Ma Ying-jeou's 2008 election campaign, will assume his new post March 1, the Presidential Office said in a statement.
Lo will succeed Wang Yu-chi, who will stay in the Presidential Office as a secretary.
Lo, who earned a master's degree in law from National Chengchi University, is pursuing a doctorate in diplomacy at the same university.

DOC.HEADLINE: Value of January export orders reaches new high: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 20:49:43 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan received US$30.37 billion worth of export orders in January, a new monthly high that marked the largest annual growth rate of 71.81 percent, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Thursday.

Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Statistics, said China (including Hong Kong) was the leading source of orders for Taiwan-based companies last month. The value of orders placed by Chinese businesses in January hit US$8.595 billion, setting the second-highest annual growth rate of 134.99 percent, he noted.

Orders from China were mainly for electronics, precision machinery (large- and middle- sized panels), basic metal, engineering and chemical products, while orders from the United States and Europe were mostly for telecommunications and information industry goods.

The value of orders received from Japan and from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) last month were also new single-month highs, reaching US$3.512 billion and US$2.946 billion, respectively, according to Huang.
However, he pointed out that Taiwan enterprises will see a drop in order value in February as a result of a labor shortage since the Lunar New Year in China's manufacturing hubs in coastal regions.
The MOEA also reported that Taiwan's industrial production index in January stood at 112.12, a record high increase of 69.7 percent on an annual basis.

A steady economic recovery around the world and rising demand from China and the United States, as well as a lower base in 2009 after the global economic downturn, are behind the astounding expansion, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to help produce documentary on `king of song'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 21:49:54 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi promised Thursday to help with the production of a documentary on Hung Yi-feng, better known as "the king of Formosan song" who died of pancreatic cancer a day earlier at the age of 82.

During a visit to Hung in hospital in January, Wu announced for the first time that the Government Information Office will come up with a plan to preserve musical works representative of Taiwan's culture, life and art.
He also said at that time that the government will appropriate NT$4 million (US$125,000) to help finance the production of a documentary on Hung's legendary life and musical career.
The premier reaffirmed the promise Thursday when he paid his respects to Hung at a memorial hall at Taipei Medical University Hospital.
Earlier in the day, President Ma Ying-jeou also paid his respects to Hung and expressed his condolences to Hung's bereaved family.

Ma told Hung's three sons, all of whom are prominent figures in the local music scene, that he admired Hung's musical achievements and outstanding contributions to Taiwan's musical and cultural development.

Hung, who was blessed with a deep, resonant voice and was a prolific songwriter, is familiar to middle-aged and elderly Taiwanese-language music fans. Oldies such as "Memories of an Old Love" and "The One I'm Missing" are still very popular among patrons of local KTVs.
Chiu Kun-liang, a professor at National Taipei University of the Arts who grew up listening to Hung's songs, said Hung awoke many local people to their Taiwanese identity.
"He was unfortunate to have been born in Taiwan... If he were to have lived in another country, he would have long been recognized as a national treasure," Chiu said.

Chuang Yung-ming, a Taiwan history researcher, said Hung's contribution to Taiwanese-language songs lies in his inheritance of Taiwanese people's independent creative spirit during Japanese colonial rule.

"A group of talented Taiwanese song artists composed many lyrical Taiwanese- language songs between 1932 and 1940. However, their development came to an abrupt halt after Japan launched a campaign to turn `Taiwanese people into loyal subjects of the Japanese emperor,'" Chuang said.

Hung managed to succeed the Oriental five note scale musical style popular in the 1930s and incorporated special features of Japanese enka and jazz music that made their way to Taiwan in the 1950s, Chuang said.
"As a result, he created a unique blend or hybrid style that reflects the complexity of Taiwanese history," Chuang explained.
Hung was diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer Dec. 7 last year, according to his family.
He was hospitalized Dec. 26 after he fell into a coma following a bout of pneumonia, and was transferred to a hospice ward Feb. 11.
A Christian memorial service will be held for him March 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: India bomb blast hero returns to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 21:50:22 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man who was hailed as a hero in India for his bravery in a Feb. 13 bomb attack returned home Thursday for medical treatment.
With the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Huang Chih-ming was taken to Taipei's Shin Kong Wu Ho-su Memorial Hospital as soon as he arrived.

Huang was injured in the bomb attack that took place in a restaurant in the Indian city of Pune. Despite his injuries, he helped other victims to safety and went back inside the building to rescue two other injured persons.
He was described by Indian media as "Pune's hero from Taiwan."
In a telephone interview with CNA, Huang said he received burns to his shoulders, hands and legs and had surgery at an Indian hospital Feb. 17 to remove debris from his right leg.
According to Hung Tzu-jen, president of the Shin Kong Medical Club, Huang decided to return to Taiwan for further treatment after he was discharged from the Indian hospital Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to attract 4.8 million tourists through promotions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 21:59:47 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau announced Thursday at a Cabinet meeting that it plans to draw up 100 tour routes around Taiwan with the aim of attracting 4.8 million tourists from around the world this year, and 5 million in 2011.

The plan, titled "Travel Taiwan, Touch 100" has been devised to promote tourism and mark next year's 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, after the "Tour Taiwan 2008-2009" campaign project achieved 7 percent growth in visitor arrivals, according to the bureau.

In addition to the 100 travel routes, other activities included in the program include lantern festivals, lantern design competitions, cycling events, a Taiwanese fine food fair and a Taiwanese hot springs and delicacies carnival, designed to enable tourists to experience Taiwan's natural beauty and the richness of its culture.

The project will promote the 100 routes by integrating delicacies, different means of transport and shopping spots into the itineraries for each. The routes will be divided into 10 groups with 10 different themes, according to the bureau.
In April, the bureau will invite tourism and travel business operators to exchange views on rolling out special deals and tourism packages to mark next year's centennial.

After hearing the briefing, Premier Wu Den-yih expressed admiration for the plan and instructed the relevant agencies to work together to enhance Taiwan's image, including improving sanitation and environmental protection, upgrading service quality at airports and renewing traffic signs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks on civil aviation services expected in March
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 22:16:23 (By Wan Shu-fen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are expected to hold a new round of negotiations in Taiwan in March on increasing the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights to meet the increasing market demand, Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Lee Long-wen said Thursday.
Direct flights between Taiwan and China were inaugurated last August, with the number of the flights set at 270 per week.

Lee said the talks will address additional flights being made available on routes with heavy demand, and that proposed direct flight services between Taipei SongShan Airport and Hungqiao Airport in Shanghai will also be discussed.
Taiwan will also bring up the "fifth freedom" -- an issue aggressively sought by Taiwanese airlines -- in the talks, in spite of the fact that China has been reluctant to touch upon it.
The "fifth freedom" would allow airlines of each side to extend flight services to destinations beyond Taiwan and China to a third country.

Lee said Taiwan will also use the occasion to complain to the Chinese side that the number of Chinese flights during the Lunar New Year holiday increased by three times those of Taiwanese flights, and that many of the Taiwanese flights were poorly timed, with late-night departures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves amendments to allow foreign-funded hospitals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 22:45:39 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved a package of amendments Thursday in its weekly meeting that pave the way for foreign investors to open hospitals in Taiwan, although it remained unclear whether Chinese investors will be eligible for the new measures.

In line with the amended provisions, which provide tax incentives, investors in international medical services can establish hospitals in an exclusive biomedical park in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu County in the form of a corporation. They can also issue shares.
"This will help lay a foundation for Taiwan to develop international medical services and medical tourism" said Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang.

The DOH has agreed to allow foreign investors or joint ventures to set up the hospitals based on the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model on a 7.85-hectare plot within the planned 38-hectare biomedical park in Hsinchu.

Shih Chung-liang, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the DOH, said that a briefing session on the issue will be held March 5 and that relevant projections are slated to kick off in June. It is estimated that foreign capital ranging between NT$2 billion and NT$3 billion (US$94 million) will be attracted to Taiwan as a result of the plan, he added.
"Whether Chinese investors will be included in the opening measures will be decided in the near future," Shih went on.

"The DOH does not restrict international investors from setting up medical facilities in appointed zones, nor does it limit the number of such facilities, " he pointed out, saying that "Kinmen Island would also be an acceptable location."
According to Shih, such international hospitals will not waste Taiwan's medical resources, as they are profit-making establishments that target only top clientele who must pay all their own expenses.
The law amendments must be approved by the Legislative Yuan before they can be implemented.

Lee Yuan-teh, an emeritus professor at National Taiwan University's College of Medicine, however, expressed concern about turning medical services into a business deal to make money, although he added that Taiwan's medical level is on par with international standards and can compete with Singapore, Hong Kong and Dubai.
"It is not good to weigh patients as profit-making items, " he said. "A balance must be maintained in saving lives and seeking monetary gain," he added.
Hung Tzu-jen, general manager of the Shin Kong Medical Club, said conditions are not yet ripe for Taiwan to develop international medical services.

According to Hung, his club has tried hard to lure foreign visitors into having physical checkups, but foreign customers only account for 2.5 percent of the total -- lower than the minimum threshold of 5 percent for a facility to offer international medical services.

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi promised Thursday to help with the production of a documentary on Hung Yi-feng, better known as "the king of Formosan song" who died of pancreatic cancer a day earlier at the age of 82.

During a visit to Hung in hospital in January, Wu announced for the first time that the Government Information Office will come up with a plan to preserve musical works representative of Taiwan's culture, life and art.
He also said at that time that the government will appropriate NT$4 million (US$125,000) to help finance the production of a documentary on Hung's legendary life and musical career.
The premier reaffirmed the promise Thursday when he paid his respects to Hung at a memorial hall at Taipei Medical University Hospital.
Earlier in the day, President Ma Ying-jeou also paid his respects to Hung and expressed his condolences to Hung's bereaved family.

Ma told Hung's three sons, all of whom are prominent figures in the local music scene, that he admired Hung's musical achievements and outstanding contributions to Taiwan's musical and cultural development.

Hung, who was blessed with a deep, resonant voice and was a prolific songwriter, is familiar to middle-aged and elderly Taiwanese-language music fans. Oldies such as "Memories of an Old Love" and "The One I'm Missing" are still very popular among patrons of local KTVs.
Chiu Kun-liang, a professor at National Taipei University of the Arts who grew up listening to Hung's songs, said Hung awoke many local people to their Taiwanese identity.
"He was unfortunate to have been born in Taiwan... If he were to have lived in another country, he would have long been recognized as a national treasure," Chiu said.

Chuang Yung-ming, a Taiwan history researcher, said Hung's contribution to Taiwanese-language songs lies in his inheritance of Taiwanese people's independent creative spirit during Japanese colonial rule.

"A group of talented Taiwanese song artists composed many lyrical Taiwanese- language songs between 1932 and 1940. However, their development came to an abrupt halt after Japan launched a campaign to turn `Taiwanese people into loyal subjects of the Japanese emperor,'" Chuang said.

Hung managed to succeed the Oriental five note scale musical style popular in the 1930s and incorporated special features of Japanese enka and jazz music that made their way to Taiwan in the 1950s, Chuang said.
"As a result, he created a unique blend or hybrid style that reflects the complexity of Taiwanese history," Chuang explained.
Hung was diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer Dec. 7 last year, according to his family.
He was hospitalized Dec. 26 after he fell into a coma following a bout of pneumonia, and was transferred to a hospice ward Feb. 11.
A Christian memorial service will be held for him March 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: India bomb blast hero returns to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 21:50:22 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man who was hailed as a hero in India for his bravery in a Feb. 13 bomb attack returned home Thursday for medical treatment.
With the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Huang Chih-ming was taken to Taipei's Shin Kong Wu Ho-su Memorial Hospital as soon as he arrived.

Huang was injured in the bomb attack that took place in a restaurant in the Indian city of Pune. Despite his injuries, he helped other victims to safety and went back inside the building to rescue two other injured persons.
He was described by Indian media as "Pune's hero from Taiwan."
In a telephone interview with CNA, Huang said he received burns to his shoulders, hands and legs and had surgery at an Indian hospital Feb. 17 to remove debris from his right leg.
According to Hung Tzu-jen, president of the Shin Kong Medical Club, Huang decided to return to Taiwan for further treatment after he was discharged from the Indian hospital Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to attract 4.8 million tourists through promotions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 21:59:47 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau announced Thursday at a Cabinet meeting that it plans to draw up 100 tour routes around Taiwan with the aim of attracting 4.8 million tourists from around the world this year, and 5 million in 2011.

The plan, titled "Travel Taiwan, Touch 100" has been devised to promote tourism and mark next year's 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, after the "Tour Taiwan 2008-2009" campaign project achieved 7 percent growth in visitor arrivals, according to the bureau.

In addition to the 100 travel routes, other activities included in the program include lantern festivals, lantern design competitions, cycling events, a Taiwanese fine food fair and a Taiwanese hot springs and delicacies carnival, designed to enable tourists to experience Taiwan's natural beauty and the richness of its culture.

The project will promote the 100 routes by integrating delicacies, different means of transport and shopping spots into the itineraries for each. The routes will be divided into 10 groups with 10 different themes, according to the bureau.
In April, the bureau will invite tourism and travel business operators to exchange views on rolling out special deals and tourism packages to mark next year's centennial.

After hearing the briefing, Premier Wu Den-yih expressed admiration for the plan and instructed the relevant agencies to work together to enhance Taiwan's image, including improving sanitation and environmental protection, upgrading service quality at airports and renewing traffic signs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks on civil aviation services expected in March
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 22:16:23 (By Wan Shu-fen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are expected to hold a new round of negotiations in Taiwan in March on increasing the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights to meet the increasing market demand, Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Lee Long-wen said Thursday.
Direct flights between Taiwan and China were inaugurated last August, with the number of the flights set at 270 per week.

Lee said the talks will address additional flights being made available on routes with heavy demand, and that proposed direct flight services between Taipei SongShan Airport and Hungqiao Airport in Shanghai will also be discussed.
Taiwan will also bring up the "fifth freedom" -- an issue aggressively sought by Taiwanese airlines -- in the talks, in spite of the fact that China has been reluctant to touch upon it.
The "fifth freedom" would allow airlines of each side to extend flight services to destinations beyond Taiwan and China to a third country.

Lee said Taiwan will also use the occasion to complain to the Chinese side that the number of Chinese flights during the Lunar New Year holiday increased by three times those of Taiwanese flights, and that many of the Taiwanese flights were poorly timed, with late-night departures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves amendments to allow foreign-funded hospitals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/25/10 22:45:39 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved a package of amendments Thursday in its weekly meeting that pave the way for foreign investors to open hospitals in Taiwan, although it remained unclear whether Chinese investors will be eligible for the new measures.

In line with the amended provisions, which provide tax incentives, investors in international medical services can establish hospitals in an exclusive biomedical park in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu County in the form of a corporation. They can also issue shares.
"This will help lay a foundation for Taiwan to develop international medical services and medical tourism" said Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang.

The DOH has agreed to allow foreign investors or joint ventures to set up the hospitals based on the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model on a 7.85-hectare plot within the planned 38-hectare biomedical park in Hsinchu.

Shih Chung-liang, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the DOH, said that a briefing session on the issue will be held March 5 and that relevant projections are slated to kick off in June. It is estimated that foreign capital ranging between NT$2 billion and NT$3 billion (US$94 million) will be attracted to Taiwan as a result of the plan, he added.
"Whether Chinese investors will be included in the opening measures will be decided in the near future," Shih went on.

"The DOH does not restrict international investors from setting up medical facilities in appointed zones, nor does it limit the number of such facilities, " he pointed out, saying that "Kinmen Island would also be an acceptable location."
According to Shih, such international hospitals will not waste Taiwan's medical resources, as they are profit-making establishments that target only top clientele who must pay all their own expenses.
The law amendments must be approved by the Legislative Yuan before they can be implemented.

Lee Yuan-teh, an emeritus professor at National Taiwan University's College of Medicine, however, expressed concern about turning medical services into a business deal to make money, although he added that Taiwan's medical level is on par with international standards and can compete with Singapore, Hong Kong and Dubai.
"It is not good to weigh patients as profit-making items, " he said. "A balance must be maintained in saving lives and seeking monetary gain," he added.
Hung Tzu-jen, general manager of the Shin Kong Medical Club, said conditions are not yet ripe for Taiwan to develop international medical services.

According to Hung, his club has tried hard to lure foreign visitors into having physical checkups, but foreign customers only account for 2.5 percent of the total -- lower than the minimum threshold of 5 percent for a facility to offer international medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 26, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North- South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2003: The world's oldest Asian elephant living in captivity Lin Wang dies at the Taipei City Zoo at age 86.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 09:50:30 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday than its previous close, moving up 24.21 points at 7,451.17 on a turnover of NT$2.1 billion (US$65.63 million).
The weighted price index lost 102.71 points or 1.36 percent to close at 7,426.96 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 10:20:30 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.073 at 10 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.047 from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Diplomacy is a non-partisan issue

TEXT.P: An aircraft donated by Taiwan to Panama for rescue purposes was recently found to have been used as a presidential plane. Control Yuan members investigating the case believe that Taiwan was duped, but they have also urged the blue and green camps to stand united to face the outside world. In fact, the Control Yuan members have expressed a view shared by the entire nation.

In the international arena, Taiwan and China have very different statuses, and China's economic power has grown despite the global economic downturn. This is Taiwan's general situation and the country has to face up to it, whether it is the blue or the green camp that is in power.

Everyone hopes to live in an environment that is peaceful, safe, prosperous and dignified. Political parties must fall in line and seek to fulfill this basic wish of the people instead of using national interest as a tool in malicious partisan struggle.

China is the root cause of Taiwan's diplomatic deadlock. To break the deadlock, Taiwan must be able to make changes to cross-Taiwan Strait relations and create a model for peaceful interaction so as to gain time and space for its own survival and development. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Magnitude-5.7 earthquake jolts Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 10:34:07 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A magnitude-5.7 earthquake struck off the southeast coast of Taiwan Friday, the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center said.
There were no immediate reports of property damage or human casualties.

The earthquake struck at 9: 07 a.m., with the epicenter located 131.7 kilometers southeast of the bureau's seismology monitoring station in the eastern city of Hualien at a depth of 31.1 km beneath the seabed, seismologists said.

The strongest intensity on land was recorded in Changpin township in the neighboring Taitung County, where the quake registered at Intensity 3. Intensity in other parts of Taiwan ranged between 2 and 1.
Taiwan is often hit by earthquakes as it lies near the the junction of two tectonic plates. A 7.3-magnitude quake killed around 2,400 people in Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Tax concessions and corporate responsibility
DOC.DATELINE: 02/26/10 11:06:03 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: There has been some controversy over a lawmaker's proposal to grant a concessionary 15 percent corporate income tax rate to multinational companies that set up headquarters in Taiwan, even though the plan has been scrapped in the interest of parity.

The question that is often raised is why should big companies be eligible for preferential tax treatment while small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which have always contributed to the development of Taiwan's economy, are left out.

Data shows that preferential tax rates, allowed under Article 30 of the proposed industrial innovation statute, would benefit only four Taiwan businesses. However, the government's decision to withdraw the special tax rate plan spurred threats by large enterprises to move their headquarters out of Taiwan.

It is regrettable that these threats have not only hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people who helped build those businesses, but have also tarnished the big companies' image with regard to corporate social responsibility.
We all know that big companies can decide a society's fate, but because of interdependency, the concept of corporate social responsibility is too important to be ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Commercial Times: Window of opportunity for marketing Taiwan

TEXT.P: Following the successes of "Cape No. 7, " "Monga" and "No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti, " another Taiwanese film, "Au Revoir Taipei, " was recently awarded the Network for The Promotion of Asian Cinema Prize at the Berlin International Film Festival 2010. This highlights the fact that "city marketing" can not only inject life into the film market, but also help Taiwan develop people-to-people diplomacy.

Encouraged by the situation, major cities in the northern, central and southern parts of Taiwan have shown strong interest in being used as locations for film and television shoots. In turn, this can help create a friendly environment for the film and television industry.

We believe this development is worthy of attention. The government and private sector should join forces and use the soft power of cultural creativity to turn Taiwan into a new type of attraction for foreign visitors.
Indeed, film shoots and screenings are a fast track to marketing a city or country. However, not many cities in Taiwan have so far made any great effort in this regard.

Meanwhile, film and television shoots are not the only way to market a city. Literary works can also be used to achieve the same purpose. Some cities in Taiwan have thus invited foreign writers to make their bases there, which is a practice worth promoting. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Fallout over tax incentives
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 12:49:15 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government's decision not to introduce a concessionary tax rate for multinational companies with operations headquarters in Taiwan has come under fire from local key players, with some threatening to move out of the country.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) rushed to put out the fire, saying that a new bill, currently under review by the Legislative Yuan, will give tax credits of up to 30 percent to companies contributing to talent nurturing and research and development (R&D).
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

The Cabinet has decided in principle to scrap a controversial proposal to grant a concessionary 15 percent corporate income tax rate to multinational companies that set up their operations headquarters in Taiwan, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou said Thursday.

The proposal, part of a draft statute on promoting industrial innovation, was sponsored by a group of ruling Kuomintang legislators led by Ting Shou-chung. It states that multinational companies with corporate headquarters in Taiwan and which meet certain other requirements could be entitled to a flat business income tax rate of 15 percent -- 10 percentage points lower than the currently adopted rate.

J. T. Wang, chairman of Acer Computer, the second largest PC manufacturer in the world by market share, expressed worry over the issue late Thursday. He warned that the corporate income tax incentives should not be removed from the draft statute. "It is a chess piece that could tip the scales in Taiwan's high-tech industrial development," he said.

The government should go ahead with the 15-percent tax break program, Wang suggested, arguing that while the measure would mean a loss of NT$500 million a year in tax revenues, the government could scoop some NT$50 billion a year if Fortune Global 500 businesses set up operations centers in Taiwan.

MOEA officials said Thursday that Taiwan's high-tech manufacturing sector had enjoyed unprecedented tax breaks under the Statute for Industrial Upgrading that expired at the end of 2009. The tax concessions totaled nearly NT$590 billion (US$18.44 billion) between 2004 and 2008, according to MOEA tallies. (Feb. 26, 2010)
Commercial Times:

Acer Chairman J. T. Wang, who doubles as chairman of the Taipei Computer Association, held a heated debate on the issue with Woody Duh, director-general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, on a TV talk show Thursday.

Wang said the 15-percent corporate income tax incentive proposal, to be known as Article 30, would a "magic number" that could lure the world's 500 largest companies to set up operations centers in Taiwan.
Wang urged the Legislative Yuan to retain the proposal, saying that it could be one of the most crucial pieces of legislation in Taiwan in the next 10 years.

Duh, meanwhile, admitted that the government's withdrawal of the plan has stirred widespread discontent among leading local business groups. He said the MOEA should not allow one article to hamper passage of the draft statute on promoting industrial innovation.
Duh told Wang that the MOEA will reassess industry needs and come up with appropriate measures. (Feb. 26, 2010)
The Liberty Times:

Deputy Economics Minister Hwang Jung-chiou said Thursday that the Cabinet has decided to scrap Article 30 in light of the controversy over the proposed tax concessions. Very few Fortune Global 500 companies would be interested in moving their headquarters to Taiwan to take advantage of a low tax rate, he said, adding that only four Taiwanese high-tech giants, including the Hon Hai Group, would benefit from the plan. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day---Legislative by-elections in home stretch
DOC.DATELINE: 02/26/10 13:12:50 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: With one day to go before the legislative by-elections in four counties, both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are pulling out all the stops to win the four seats up for grabs.
The followings are excerpts of local leading newspapers' coverage of the elections: The Liberty Times:
The DPP has called on voters in Hualien, Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Chiayi to punish the arrogant ruling KMT by supporting the DPP legislative candidates.
"Voting against that party will cut them down to size and force them to humbly heed the voice of the grassroots people," a DPP leader said.
DPP spokesman Lin You-chang said his party's candidate in Chiayi is the front runner, but the others are engaged in a neck-and-neck races in the three other constituencies.
"Any victory in these three areas will be a historical record." he said.
KMT leaders have been putting almost all of their efforts into helping the party's candidates in Hualien and Taoyuan.

In Hualien, which is considered a KMT stronghold, the KMT's Wang Ting-sheng is facing a strong challenge from independent candidate Shih Sheng-lang who has the support of Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.
