In Taoyuan, the KMT candidate Apollo Chen was criticized by his rivals as an outsider because he was a two-term legislator elected in Taipei City.
Chen's DPP rival Huang Ren-chu was under investigation for allegedly trying to buy support by wining and dining voters.

DPP Secretary-General Su Chia-chuan cried foul over the prosecutors' investigation, claiming that they had turned a blind eye to the fact that Chen's campaign manager Ye Bu-liang had also thrown a party for voters on Chen's behalf. (Feb. 26, 2010) China Times:
The issue of carpetbag politicians is a hot one in the legislative by-election campaign.

In Hualien, the KMT candidate Wang Ting-sheng painted his DPP contestant Hsiao Bi-khim as a carpetbagger who descended on the eastern Taiwan county to try to gain a legislative seat rather than to do anything for the county.
In response, Hsiao said that what matters most is whether a candidate can serve his or her constituents, not where he or she comes from.

However, Wang's argument was used by DPP candidate Huang Ren-chu against KMT candidate Apollo Chen in Taoyuan, and again by KMT candidate Cheng Yung-tang against DPP candidate Peng Shaw-jiin in Hsinchu. (Feb. 26, 2010) United Daily News:
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou accompanied KMT candidate Lin Rui-teh on a walk in Chiayi Thursday to canvass support.
Ma will also barnstorm for party candidates in Hualien, Hsinchu and Taoyuan on the eve of the election.
A party official said that KMT candidates face uphill battles in Chiayi and Hsinchu, and are in tight races in Hualien and Taoyuan.
"In order to win at least two seats in the by-elections, the party has to encourage its supporters to turn out to vote, " the official said.
He said that a big voter turn out would favor the party. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gives green light to trading of red chip stocks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 13:14:52 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Individual Taiwanese investors will soon be able to invest in "red chip" stocks listed in Hong Kong and Macau, through their accounts at local securities brokerage companies, as the ban will be removed in the coming few days.
The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) approved Thursday a draft regulation that will allow domestic securities brokerage firms to trade "red chip" shares, such as China Mobile and Lenovo.

Red chips are shares in Chinese companies that are incorporated outside China and listed in Hong Kong and Macau. At present, local individual investors have to open accounts in Hong Kong and Macau in order to trade "red chip" shares.

The new measure marks a step forward in the government's liberalization policy on trading of shares in Chinese companies, and follows a raising of the ceilings on investments by mutual fund operators in red chips, H shares and Chinese stocks more than a year ago.

"The new measure will take effect after the FSC finalizes administrative formalities, " Wu Guei-mao, chief secretary of the FSC's Securities and Futures Bureau, said, adding that local stock investors will no longer need to open accounts in Hong Kong or Macau to trade 130 "red chip" stocks in the future.
However, trading in H shares -- stocks of 156 China-based companies listed in Hong Kong and Macau bourses -- will remain off-limits, he said.
"We will adopt a gradual liberalization of investment in Chinese securities," Wu added.

Market analysts said the new liberalization measure will have limited impact on the local bourse because there are already many channels for both local individual and institutional investors to invest in shares listed in Hong Kong and Macau.
"The 'red chip' trade liberalization is more symbolic than substantial and it mainly symbolizes closer financial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait," a market analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Challenges associated with unemployment
DOC.DATELINE: 02/26/10 13:58:06 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Government statistics show that although the unemployment rate in Taiwan is dropping, there are problems related to the unemployed population.
First, the number of people who have been jobless for more than one year has increased from one in every 7.2 unemployed persons to one in every 5.5.
Second, there has also been an increase in the number of unemployed people between the ages of 45 and 64, with statistics showing that one in every 4.4 jobless persons are in that age group.

The statistics also show that although the number of people who lost their jobs because of business closure or downsizing has declined over the past few months, nearly four-fifths of them have not been able to find another job so far.
The figures indicate that it is still difficult for unemployed middle-aged people to find a job, despite their experience.
Furthermore, while the population census shows an increase of 36,000 people from November last year, there has been no proportionate rise in the number of people joining the job market.
The population increase may be one of the factors that contributed to the lower unemployment figures. However, there is also a worrying trend of more and more people seeming not to want to work.

The government needs to take urgent action to fix the unemployment problems in the short term, and in the long run it should initiate policies to increase exports, because once Taiwan's exports recover fully, investment, consumption and employment will grow. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Taiwan consciousness in crisis

TEXT.P: Chou Wan-yao, a professor of history at National Taiwan University, revealed recently that the Ministry of Education is trying to revise the history curriculum in senior high schools to double the weight of Chinese history.

The thinking of the China-leaning camp is very simple: Taiwanese history must be framed within Chinese history, because Taiwan is part of China. They are attempting to brainwash the Taiwanese people for good and train them to identify with China. Therefore, that camp would never allow Taiwanese history to take the same precedence as Chinese history, or be separated from Chinese history.

The fact is, Taiwan has never been part of China. The Kuomintang regime is using political means to distort historical truth. The alien regime that is dominating Taiwan does not have sovereignty over Taiwan.

Now, students in Taiwan are facing the crisis of being brainwashed. This is a most vicious conspiracy by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to link Taiwan to China. Far-sighted people must take effective action to stop the Ma administration from erasing the Taiwan consciousness of the Taiwanese people. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Avoid making public policy behind closed doors

TEXT.P: A bill on industrial innovation and a proposal on minimum wage reform have been strongly challenged by the private sector.

The industrial innovation bill is well-intentioned, but an article designed to provide an extra-low 15 percent corporate income tax rate for international businesses with headquarters in Taiwan has whipped up waves of controversy. This forced the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to make repeated changes to the article. The latest decision by the MOEA is to remove the article altogether.
Why did the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou not fully seek public opinion or draw on the examples of other countries before putting forward the bill?
The administration has encountered opposition on all sides because it failed to adhere to the policy-making process of a democracy.
Likewise, the proposal for Taiwan to adopt a multiple minimum wage system has come under attack by both the blue and the green camps.

These two incidents have demonstrated the importance of public discussion in the process of making public policy. The ruling party cannot do whatever it pleases simply because it holds an absolute majority in the Legislative Yuan. (Feb. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet firm on withdrawal of tax incentive proposal: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 15:05:09 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih confirmed Friday that the Cabinet has decided not to introduce a controversial proposal to grant an extra-low 15 percent corporate income tax incentive to multinational companies that set up their operations headquarters in Taiwan.

Wu said the proposal, known as Article 30 of a draft statute to foster industrial innovation, is seen by society as unfair to local businesses and an extension of the Statute for Industrial Upgrading (SIU) that expired at the end of 2009.
The SIU offered tax breaks, totaling nearly NT$590 billion (US$18.44 billion), to Taiwan's high-tech conglomerates between 2004 and 2008, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The premier stressed that the government's latest decision on the tax issue is based on upholding fairness. Regardless of the size or nature of a business, once it is engaged in industrial innovation and job creation it should be eligible for incentives, under the industrial innovation bill, he added.
Article 30 was withdrawn to avoid favoring only a few industrial conglomerates, Wu contended.
The draft bill will be implemented only after it is passed by the Legislative Yuan, the premier said.
Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday that the new bill will offer the same tax incentives to all companies from home and abroad.
Shih said he does not think the withdrawal of Article 30 will have a huge impact on the development of Taiwan's high-tech industry.

Dispelling rumors that some key players such as the Hon Hai Group will move out of the country because of the decision, Shih said that for as long as he can recall, Hon Hai founder Terry Gou's stance has been similar to the government's policy.
Any stimulus initiative aimed at spurring investment should offer the same incentives to all companies from home and abroad, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:29:25 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 9.14 points, or 0.12 percent, to close at 7,436.1.
The local bourse opened at 7,451.17 and fluctuated between a high of 7,479.28 and a low of 7,383.68. Market turnover totaled NT$80.46 billion (US$2.5 billion).
Of the eight major stock categories, five categories gained ground. Construction issues gained 1.9 percent, the most of any category, followed by paper and pulp issues, which rose 0.6 percent.
Cement, plastic and chemical, and banking and financial shares all advanced 0.5 percent, respectively.
Textile shares remained unchanged, while foodstuff shares and machinery and electronics issues both lost 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,772 to 941, with 298 remaining unchanged.

Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs sold a net NT$1.52 billion in shares, the third consecutive day in which they sold more than they bought. For the week, they were net sellers of NT$11.52 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung international marathon attracts 20,000 competitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:31:19 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Some 20,000 runners from 24 countries and areas have registered to compete in the 2010 Kaohsiung International Marathon Mizuno Cup in the southern port city Sunday.
It will be the first major sports event to be held in the port city since the 2009 World Games and its biggest marathon in 15 years, according to its Department of Sports.

The event will feature three races -- a full-length marathon, a demi-length race of 24.235 kilometers, and a 4.47 km run. City officials said Friday that 1,679 runners have signed up for the full-length race, including six athletes from Kenya, Ryuji Suematsu of Japan and Ma Tianxing of China.
Taiwan's Wu Wen-chien, who achieved a personal best of 2 hours 16 minutes in the 2008 Xiamen international marathon, will compete in the men's category of the Kaohsiung marathon.
Hsu Yu-fan, Taiwan's first female Olympic marathoner and a National Games record holder, will be among the competitors in the women's race.
The city's mass rapid transit system will offer free service on Sunday to runners in the international sports event, according to city officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley shelves bank plan in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:42:48 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Global financial services provider Morgan Stanley has put on hold a plan to open a bank in Taiwan because of resistance from the government, which is focusing on controlling risk in the wake of the global financial crisis, according to a local newspaper.

The Financial Supervisory Commission, Taiwan's top financial regulator, has ruled out the possibility of allowing Morgan Stanley to operate a bank in Taiwan, Taiwan's Chinese-language United Daily News quoted an anonymous commission official as saying Wednesday.
According to Taiwan's rules, qualified foreign banks must have global capital or global assets that rank among the world's top 500 and meet certain financial standards, the official said.

However, Morgan Stanley, which set up a branch in Taiwan in 1982, transformed itself from an investment bank to a bank holding company only last year, the official noted, leaving it short of the requirements.
It remains to be seen whether Morgan Stanley will meet the threshold for entry in the future, the official added.
The report said Morgan Stanley had yet to file a formal application for the plan but learned about the financial regulator's sentiment after trying recently to gauge how it would respond to the idea.

According to the report, risk control has become the Financial Supervisory Commission's main focus following the global financial meltdown, with the commission not wanting commercial banks to engage in high-risk or highly complex financial products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospitality helps promote tourism: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:45:29 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan people's hospitality and considerateness give the island a tourism advantage.

He cited the example of a passerby who, in response to a request for directions, accompanied a Chinese writer to a bus station from which the writer was able to travel to Yangmingshan to view the flowers there.
Another example featured a shoe-store clerk in Kenting, Pingtung County, who applied a band-aid to the blisters on the foot of a Chinese graduate student, the president said.

The student had gone to the store to buy a new pair of shoes because the ones he had been wearing had hurt his feet, Ma said, adding that the Chinese student was deeply touched by the clerk's gesture.
"Taiwanese hospitality and considerateness are important resources that will help promote the island's tourism." Ma said at a ceremony to mark March 1 Tourism Day.

Reiterating the government's goal of NT$500 billion (US$15.58 billion) in tourism revenues this year, the president said his administration wants to see not only an increase in the number of visitors but also better quality tours.
First time tourists who have a pleasant experience will want to return a second time for more in-depth sightseeing, and a third time for long-term vacation, the president said.

Citing government statistics, Ma said 4.4 million tourists visited Taiwan last year, representing an annual growth of 14.3 percent, despite the global financial crisis, the outbreak of influenza H1N1 and the destruction caused by Typhoon Morakot.

These tourists brought some NT$400 billion worth of business to Taiwan and contributed to growth in the transport, eatery and travel sectors, which pushed tourism into the ranks of the top six industries in the country, the president said.

In order to increase tourism output value by another NT$100 billion this year, Ma said, his administration will funnel NT$30 billion into the industry, in addition to the NT$25 billion to be invested by the private sector to build and refurbish hotels.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:48:14 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.035 to close at NT$32.085.
A total of US$572 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.13 and then fell to a low of NT$32.06 before regaining ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: Output of Taiwan's textile sector projected to top NT$430b
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 16:59:34 (By Shu Wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The 2010 production value of Taiwan's textile sector is projected at NT$430 billion (US$13.44 billion) , a year-on-year increase of 17.6 percent, the Industry and Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) said Friday.

Taiwan's textile industry is expected to rebound this year from a slump in 2009 when output shrank by 15.7 percent year-on-year, the ITIS said. The integration of various sections of the industry and higher production and research and development levels will contribute to better performance of the sector this year, according to the ITIS.

The ITIS analysis, which was based on a report by the non-profit Taiwan Textile Research Institute, noted that Taiwan's textile industry sector, battered by the global economic crunch, posted an overall production value of NT$365.67 billion in 2009, down 15.7 percent from the 2008 level.

However, with global economies picking up again, Taiwan's textile industry's output will gain momentum this year if manufacturers seek to develop higher value-added products such as bamboo charcoal fabrics made with the use of nanotechnology, the ITIS forecast.
It suggested that the local textile industry also try to create new business niches by developing advanced fabrics and textiles that can be used in energy and transportation technology applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei temperatures shoot up to record high of 31.8 degrees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:09:16 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Temperatures in Taipei City shot up to 31.8 degrees Celsius Friday, a record high for the city in the month of February, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The last time Taipei experienced a similarly hot February day was on Feb. 23, 1979, when the mercury hit 31.4 C, the CWB said.
Temperatures were high around the island Friday, climbing to 32.9 C in Dawu, Taitung County, at around noon.
The warm weather there was attributed to foehn winds, a warm dry wind that occurs on the leeward slopes of a ridge of mountains after the air mass has released its moisture on the windward slope.
Other areas around Taiwan that also witnessed high temperatures Friday included Keelung in the north (30.5 C) , Chiayi in the south (30.2 C), and Taichung in central Taiwan (30.1 C), CWB reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animated film funded by Chunghwa Telecom to open next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:20:43 (By Amy Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: "Port of Return, " the first animated film funded by Chunghwa Telecom (CHT), will open in cinemas around Taiwan March 5, the company announced Friday.
The film was directed by Mike Chang and produced by Spring House Entertainment Inc., a subsidiary of the leading telecommunications firm.
Yang Kuei-fang, CHT's marketing director, said that the company has always given its best to help develop the cultural creativity industry.
CHT Chairman Lu Shyue-ching offered to fund the film after he learned that Chang had planned the project a few years ago but lacked capital, Yang said.
The film, which took four years and NT$60 million (US$1.88 million) to be completed, made its debut at the 2009 Taipei Film Festival and was nominated in the feature film category.
It was also screened at the 2009 Pusan International Film Festival as one of the selected Asian feature animations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Piracy costs Monga NT$80 million: director
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:28:28 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's latest box office hit, Monga, has lost an estimated NT$80 million (US$2.5 million) as a result of piracy, the director of the gangster film said, urging the government to take action.

"I am definitely angry to learn that people are stealing the film, " Doze Niu was quoted as saying in the Chinese-language Apply Daily, Friday. "But I have been thinking about what I should do to stop the piracy."
Niu said that people should view the film at movie theaters, as Monga has certain effects that cannot be experienced on a computer screen.
On Feb. 21, the director angrily responded to a message left by a local Internet user on the social Web site Plurk minutes after the user said he had watched Monga in his bedroom, the report said.

The Chinese online video site, PPS.tv, had attracted 110,000 viewers of the pirated version of the film as of Thursday night, the paper reported. The film can also be viewed for free on another Chinese Web site, Tudou.com, it said.
Pirated VCDs of the movie are also available at Taiwan's night markets at half the price of movie tickets, the report stated.

Shih Show-yi, a deputy officer on a police task force that is responsible for protecting intellectual property rights, was quoted in the report as saying that the task force had busted 13 piracy cases at local night markets during the Lunar New Year holiday.
The task force has also found five download links on a local social Web site, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Autographed Dan Brown books up for auction on Taiwan Web site
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:38:00 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Five autographed Chinese-language copies of the book "The Lost Symbol" by American writer Dan Brown were put up for auction Friday on Yahoo! Taiwan.
According to the China Times Publishing Company, all proceeds from the auction will be donated to the Christian charity World Vision to help the victims of quake-stricken Haiti.
Bidding for the five books will run from Feb. 26 to March 7.

Prior to the Taiwan publication of the fifth book by the bestselling author, the general editor of the publishing company Lin Sin-gin flew to the United States last month to interview the writer and obtained Brown's autograph in the books.

"Dan Brown is pleased to know that he has many readers in Taiwan, especially as the Chinese edition of 'The Da Vinci Code' has sold more than one million copies since it was published here in 2004, " Lin said.
Lin also mentioned that Brown expects to visit Taiwan some day to meet his readers.

The film rights to "The Lost Symbol" have been sold to Columbia Pictures. Award winning American actor Tom Hanks is expected to reprise his role as professor Robert Langdon in what will be the third film in a series based on Brown's books.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan could sink without trade pact with China: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:58:37 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will face serious economic danger unless it concludes a controversial economic cooperation framework agreement with China, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

"Not signing it would bring immediate and unlimited danger. We would be finished, " said Wu at the Legislative Yuan in response to a lawmaker's question on what the administration would do if Taiwan fails to clinch the trade pact with China.
"The government will spare no effort to push for its success."

He told the legislature that if the pact were not signed, it would be difficult to imagine the suffering the country would endure as more and more members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) join in a regional trade bloc from which Taiwan is excluded.

When South Korea joins the bloc in the future, for instance, Taiwanese goods will have trouble competing against Korean goods in China, as Korean products will be exempted from 9 percent import duties while Taiwan-made goods will be subject to the tariffs, the premier said.
"No business can survive (under those circumstances)," Wu said.

The premier argued that the pact would help Taiwan's businesses sell their goods abroad and enhance the country's competitiveness in general, as it would exempt locally made products from tariffs, safeguard the investment of local companies in China, and protect their intellectual property.
The premier also reiterated the government's promise that the pact would not open Taiwan's market to more Chinese agricultural products or allow Chinese laborers to work in Taiwan.

On the same occasion, Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang allayed lawmakers' concerns that in exchange for letting Taiwan sign trade pacts with ASEAN countries, China could ask ASEAN states to require that Taiwanese goods carry "Made in Taiwan (China) " or "Made in Chinese Taipei" origin labels.
"Taiwan has sold its products abroad using the 'Made in Taiwan, ' label. This practice won't be changed." Shih said.

Wu's administration is negotiating the trade pact with China in hopes of clinching it later this year. Critics of the pact argue that it will tie Taiwan more closely to China and undermine the country's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chip, panel makers ready to apply to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 19:19:38 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: New regulations that will allow Taiwan's chip makers and LCD panel makers to invest in China formally took effect Friday, and several companies are expected to file investment applications beginning March 1.

Under the new laws, approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Feb. 23, Taiwan's flat panel sector will be permitted to build up to three 6th generation and above TFT-LCD production lines in China.
Local companies will only be allowed, however, to run factories that are at least one generation behind their most advanced plants in Taiwan.
That means AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , the world's third-largest LCD maker, can apply to build a 7.5-generation facility, while Chi Mei Optoelectronics can only apply to set up a 6.5-generation plant.
AUO said Friday that it would soon submit an application to set up a 7.5-generation plant in eastern or southeastern China to maintain its competitiveness against Korean rivals in the Chinese market.

The South Korean government approved in late December the plans of Samsung Electronics and LG Display, the world's two biggest panel makers, LCD manufacturers, to set up a 7.5-generation and an 8th-generation panel plant in China, respectively.
AUO refused, however, to confirm media reports that it would collaborate with a Chinese panel maker to set up the facility in Kunshan in China's Jiangsu province.
MOEA officials said the ministry has formed a review panel headed by MOEA Deputy Minister Huang Chung-chiou to assess and handle applications, which are expected to be received beginning March 1.
Meanwhile, the new regulations also allow Taiwanese chip manufacturers to invest in China, but they will not be allowed to build new fabs there.
Instead, they will be limited to acquiring a full or partial stake in Chinese chip makers whose foundries are at least two generations behind the investing company's most advanced factory in Taiwan.
Under those rules, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) will be allowed to invest in 90-nanometer fabs in China because it has begun making chips in Taiwan using 45nm process technology.
United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) has started 65nm production in Taiwan and will therefore will be allowed to invest in chip companies using 0.13 micron process technology in China.

Previously existing investment regulations stipulated that only three chip fabs could be built by Taiwanese chipmakers in China, under which TSMC, ProMOS Technologies and Powerchip Semiconductor all gained approval to build 8-inch wafer plants there using less advanced processes.
But Powerchip has yet to act, and if it does not invest by August when its permit expires, the MOEA said it will allow other manufacturers to apply for the slot.
Powerchip was recently reported as showing renewed interest in its China fab project, with Xuzhou in Jiangsu province mentioned as a potential site.

The new regulations will also provide a legal basis for TSMC's acquisition of a 10-percent stake in Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. (SMIC) and UMC's acquisition of a controlling stake in Chinese wafer foundry He Jian Technology (Suzhou) Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotai expects higher market share despite Toyota recalls
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 19:35:15 (By Sophia Yeh and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwanese distributor of Japanese car maker Toyota Motor Corp., is aiming to raise its market share in Taiwan to 40 percent this year as its sales have been little affected by Toyota's worldwide recalls.
Hotai Motor's market share in Taiwan rose from 35 percent in 2008 to 38 percent last year, an equivalent of 111,000 vehicles, the company's president Daniel Chang said Thursday.
It was the seventh consecutive year that Hotai was Taiwan's best car-selling company, posting sales of NT$72.48 billion (US$2.3 billion), according to Chang.
The company plans to sell 104,100 vehicles in what is expected to be a weaker market this year, Chang noted.

Hotai has revised upward its forecast for Taiwan's market in 2010 from 230,000 vehicles to 260,000, but that will still fall behind the 290,000 vehicles sold in the country in 2009, when excise taxes were lowered to stimulate a car market depressed by the global economic downturn.

Toyota may be in big trouble after having to recall 8.5 million vehicles, but Chang said Taiwan has not been seriously affected because the defective accelerator pedal at the center of the controversy is not used in Toyota cars marketed in Taiwan.
Hotai has also rebooted the computer software in more than 600 2010 Prius hybrids that were subject to the recall, representing a completion rate of close to 99 percent, Chang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health insurance bureau urged to explain its bank loans
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 20:42:00 (By Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Civil groups suggested Friday that the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) make public details of bank loans that have reached NT$130 billion (US$4.1 billion) before taking action to raise the national insurance premium.

The Department of Health (DOH) , which supervises the BNHI's operations, has asked the Executive Yuan to raise health insurance premium rates to save the insurance system from financial collapse as deficits mount.
Premier Wu Den-yih, however, has instructed the DOH to suspend the premium adjustment plan.

Hsieh Wu-chi, an executive member of the Taiwan Hospital Association, said in a meeting of the National Health Insurance Audit Commission Friday that the BNHI is obliged to explain to the public why the insurance system is suffering massive deficits and has huge loan obligations before asking for higher premium rates.

BNHI Director-General Cheng Shou-hsia responded that the bank loans were needed to cover shortfalls from three sources -- back premiums owed by local governments, including Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, a growing divergence between revenues and expenditures, and the timing of government premium payments.
Cheng promised to provide detailed information of the loans if requested by the audit commission.

According to the bureau, the shortfalls have resulted primarily from a growing disparity between premium revenues, which grew at an average of 4.34 percent a year between 1996 and 2008, and expenditures, which grew 5.34 percent a year over the same period.
This imbalance has forced the bureau to not only exhaust its reserve fund but also accumulate deficits surpassing NT$45 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Property agency defends public land sales
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:10:07 (By Lin Yi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The National Property Administration (NPA) defended its sales of small plots of public land Friday after a land parcel in Taipei City fetched a near record price in an open tender a day earlier and fueled worries of a possible property bubble.
"It would be a waste of resources if we failed to auction off small-size public plots for private use when the market has strong demand," the bureau said in a statement.

Stressing that selling small plots of land through a market mechanism is a normal strategy to spur and sustain economic development, the statement said the bureau has consistently followed the principle of selling only public plots of less than 500 pings, or 1,650 square meters.

In a public auction Thursday, a 121-ping piece of public land on Jianguo S. Road in Taipei City was sold for NT$731 million (US$22.84 million) . The unit price of NT$6.03 million per ping was the second highest unit price for residential land ever recorded in Taiwan.

The sale followed the auction of two other plots in the city in January, which also were sold for high prices. The deals have fed criticism that the NPA is fanning property speculation and driving housing prices in urban areas, particularly Taipei City and Taipei County, to levels that are unaffordable for most local families.
The bureau rejected the allegations, arguing that public land sales accounted for only a negligible share of the domestic real estate market.

Citing 2009 sales, the NPA said the 13.85 hectares of public land it auctioned off last year for NT$10.8 billion accounted for only 0.04 percent of all the land sold in Taiwan and 0.68 percent of the total transaction value.
"Given such marginal numbers, public land sales were unlikely to affect normal property market prices," the statement contended.

Noting that the few public lots that fetched record-setting prices were all located in Taipei City, the statement said the phenomenon mainly reflected the decreasing amount of prime land available in a city that is the leading indicator of economic development in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises no hike in health insurance premiums March 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:23:50 (By Justin Su and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that national health insurance (NHI) rates will not be raised on March 1 and that any rate adjustment will be accompanied by complementary measures.

Wu said that before the passage of amendments launching a second-generation health insurance system, insurance premium rates will only be adjusted after the feasibility of proposed measures is carefully studied.

The second-generation health insurance scheme refers to a proposal that would calculate premiums based on total household income, including both earned and unearned income, rather than on salary, as is the case at present.
Wu said that any premium adjustment will be made based on the principle of fairness and after the waste and abuse of medical resources has been improved.

He added the government will also ensure that any rate adjustment will not place an extra financial burden on low- and middle-income individuals, and it could even provide added subsidies to low-income insurees.
In the future, Wu said, health insurance premiums will be designed to make high- income earners pay more and low-income earners pay less.

The Department of Health has been pushing for a premium rate hike to cover the National Health Insurance system's growing deficit, caused primarily by a growing disparity between expenditures and premium revenues.
The Taipei and Kaohsiung city governments also owe the system more than NT$50 billion in back payments for contributions to premiums of individuals working in those cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Attorney brings laws suit against KMT for 228 victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:41:27 (by An Chi-hsien and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Attorney Wellington Koo on Friday filed a class action suit against the Kuomintang on behalf of 33 victims and 75 relatives of victims of the 228 Incident, an anti-government uprising on Feb. 28, 1947 that was violently suppressed by the military.
Koo and dozens of relatives of 228 victims gathered in front of the Taipei District Court, where the suit was filed, demanding that the Kuomintang stand trial and that Taiwan be given justice.

The attorney said that although the government has made Feb. 28 a national holiday in memory of the victims of the tragic incident and paid compensation to families of the victims, the truth has not been fully revealed and some murderers have yet to be prosecuted.
Because the incident occurred at a time when party rule prevailed over the government, the Kuomintang, which held power at the time, should be held responsible, Koo argued.
He is demanding that the KMT pay NT$2 billion for the construction and future operations of a National Taiwan 228 Memorial Museum at the 228 Peace Park in Taipei.
The 228 Incident remained a taboo subject in Taiwan until the early 1990s, when the Executive Yuan commissioned a study to find out what really happened.
In 1997, the Executive Yuan designated Feb. 28 a national holiday and since then commemorative activities have been held around the island every year.

On Feb. 28 this year, President Ma Ying-jeou will lead central government officials in attending commemorative activities in Tainan in southern Taiwan, including memorial services, exhibitions, and concerts.
Since the Lantern Festival, the 15th day of the Chinese Lunar New Year, falls on Feb. 28 this year, some local governments held memorial services to mark the occasion in advance.
In Chiayi and Tainan, local government officials and the public laid wreaths in front of memorial monuments on Friday.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih suggested during the memorial service that Feb. 28 should be designated Taiwanese Youth Day as a tribute to the young victims of the 228 Incident and a reminder to young people of their responsibilities to society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Virtual lantern shows in Taipei opened during lantern festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:04:06 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Lantern Festival opened Friday night with greetings from the giant mascot "Happy Tiger" and a late night virtual show that drew thousands of local residents and overseas tourists.
Combining strong lighting, visual arts and pop music, the giant virtual show titled " New Year Blossom Trilogy" captivated the gathered crowd.

Divided into three parts -- "Folk Flower, " "Akibo's Flower" and "Universal Flower" -- it screened the works of artists from different generations on the exterior wall of City Hall, according to the designer of the festival, Akibo Lee.

"Another creative approach was to select head shots of 6,666 people and turn them into a large work of art to be projected onto the walls, " said Chen Kuan- fu, deputy commissioner of Taipei City's Department of Cultural Affairs.
In addition to the virtual show, traditional and specially designed lanterns are also being displayed around the city to highlight the festival.

One of them, a big tiger "HoKi" lantern shining at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall plaza, is another focal point of the planned festivities, with professional dance troupes, bands and singers performing there Friday night to celebrate the traditional event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expansion of Songshan Airport may be delayed: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:45:39 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The expansion of Taipei Songshan Airport to accommodate more international flights may not be ready by October, and passengers may have to be patient, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Friday.

Replying to a question at a Legislative Yuan question and answer session, Mao said Songshan Airport had been a domestic airport for many years until recently, creating inconveniences for passengers on international flights.

The airport needs to be expanded after the airport's management concluded agreements to open international routes that will connect the city airport to Tokyo's Haneda Airport, Seoul's Gimpo International Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport, he added.
Although it has limited capacity, the airport can become a "small but efficient" airport after the expansion of terminal one for international flights is completed, Mao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy continues to show signs of recovery: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:49:56 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy flashed a "yellow-red" light in January for the third consecutive month, an indication that the economy's recovery from last year's global economic downturn is on a steady track, according to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Hung Jui-pin, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said Friday that the composite score remained at 37 points, only one point short of turning the light red, which would indicate overheating.

January's leading indicators index, which forecasts economic activity over the next three to six months, rose by 1.9 percent from December 2009 to 107.6, while the annualized six-month rate of change of the index edged up by 0.6 percentage points to 21.2 percent.

Six of the seven components that form the leading indicators were up from a month earlier, including average monthly overtime in the manufacturing and service sectors, the book-to-bill ratio of North American semiconductor equipment firms, export orders, and producers' inventory.
Also higher were the stock price index and variation rate of money supply M1B, but building permits were down.
In the same month, the index of coincident indicators, which tracks the current pace of economic activity, posed a monthly drop of 0.2 percent from a month earlier.

Four of the seven components that form the indicators showed rises, including industrial production, real customs-cleared exports, real machinery and electrical equipment imports and nonagricultural employment.

The CEPD adopts a five-color gauge for the country's economic performance: red reflects the economy is overheated, yellow-red signals a heating economy, green shows stable economic growth, yellow-blue indicates an economic slowdown, and blue indicates a recession.

Hung said the indicators showed the financial, manufacturing and trade sectors have turned for the better and consumption has become more active but that there is still room for improvement in employment.
However, he expects the global economic recovery to continue over the next six months, which could give a boost to Taiwan's export-oriented economy.

Lin Tsu-chia, a professor in National Chengchi University's Department of Economics, said the "yellow-red" light indicated that Taiwan's economy has improved considerably compared with a year earlier, but more effort is needed for the economy to recover to its level before the financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says 2010 is job creation year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:54:15 (By Worthy Shen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated his resolve on the campaign trail Friday to ease the unemployment situation, declaring that this will be a year for job creation.
He said that he will ask related government agencies to thrash out plans to create more jobs.

The government will also work with the private sector to boost employment, the president said, adding that the unemployment rate should fall to 4.9 percent by the end of 2010 as forecast by the Council for Economic Planning and Development from the 5.68 percent in January.
"The creation of jobs should not depend on the Council of Labor Affairs alone, " he said, while campaigning in Hualien for the ruling Kuomintang's candidate in Saturday's legislative by-election.
He also said that as long as private businesses reach a certain level of new hirings or reduce layoffs, the government will offer them subsidies.
"Whether the businesses are small or large, they should work with the government to help more people find work," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Party heavyweights making last-minute campaign for candidates
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 23:06:41 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Heavyweights of the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party gathered in Jhongli Friday evening, making a last minute push for their respective candidates in Saturday's legislative by-election in Taoyuan County.

Legislative by-elections will be held Saturday in Taoyuan, Hualien, Hsinchu and Chiayi counties, but the contest in Taoyuan, with four candidates who all have strong backing, is considered the most challenging for both parties.

The KMT, which failed to win any of the three legislative seats in legislative by-elections held in early January, is expecting to recover public support in Saturday's by-elections, while the DPP, boosted by its sweep last month, is contending for more representation in Taiwan's legislature.
At present, the ruling KMT holds 74 seats, the DPP 30 seats, and independents five seats in the 113-seat Legislative Yuan.
President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, had a busy schedule Friday, traveling from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to the northern counties of Hsinchu and Taoyuan.
KMT candidates Wang Ting-sheng in Hualien, Cheng Yung-tang in Hsinchu, and Chen Hsueh-sheng in Taoyuan are all facing fierce competition from DPP and independent candidates.
Many of the independents are KMT mavericks who have decided to run despite facing party discipline.
In Hualien County, Wang is fighting a two-front battle against DPP candidate Hsiao Bi-khim and independent Shih Sheng-lang, who has close connections with Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.
Fu is a former KMT member who had a big win over the KMT's candidate in the magistrate election last December.

KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said Saturday that as long as KMT supporters show up at the polls and cast their ballots for Wang on Saturday, there is good chance for the KMT candidate to win the legislative seat for Hualien.

Meanwhile, campaigning for DPP candidate Peng Shao-chin in Hsinchu Saturday afternoon, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said that although KMT-leaning voters were the majority in three of the four constituencies in past elections, the DPP is expecting a reversal this time.

A total of 233,116 voters in Taoyuan County's third electoral district, 358,854 in Hsinchu County, 221,816 in Chiayi County's second electoral district, and 197,426 in Hualien County are eligible to cast votes Saturday.
Polling stations will be open from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei temperatures shoot up to record high of 31.8 degrees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:09:16 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Temperatures in Taipei City shot up to 31.8 degrees Celsius Friday, a record high for the city in the month of February, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The last time Taipei experienced a similarly hot February day was on Feb. 23, 1979, when the mercury hit 31.4 C, the CWB said.
Temperatures were high around the island Friday, climbing to 32.9 C in Dawu, Taitung County, at around noon.
The warm weather there was attributed to foehn winds, a warm dry wind that occurs on the leeward slopes of a ridge of mountains after the air mass has released its moisture on the windward slope.
Other areas around Taiwan that also witnessed high temperatures Friday included Keelung in the north (30.5 C) , Chiayi in the south (30.2 C), and Taichung in central Taiwan (30.1 C), CWB reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animated film funded by Chunghwa Telecom to open next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:20:43 (By Amy Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: "Port of Return, " the first animated film funded by Chunghwa Telecom (CHT), will open in cinemas around Taiwan March 5, the company announced Friday.
The film was directed by Mike Chang and produced by Spring House Entertainment Inc., a subsidiary of the leading telecommunications firm.
Yang Kuei-fang, CHT's marketing director, said that the company has always given its best to help develop the cultural creativity industry.
CHT Chairman Lu Shyue-ching offered to fund the film after he learned that Chang had planned the project a few years ago but lacked capital, Yang said.
The film, which took four years and NT$60 million (US$1.88 million) to be completed, made its debut at the 2009 Taipei Film Festival and was nominated in the feature film category.
It was also screened at the 2009 Pusan International Film Festival as one of the selected Asian feature animations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Piracy costs Monga NT$80 million: director
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:28:28 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's latest box office hit, Monga, has lost an estimated NT$80 million (US$2.5 million) as a result of piracy, the director of the gangster film said, urging the government to take action.

"I am definitely angry to learn that people are stealing the film, " Doze Niu was quoted as saying in the Chinese-language Apply Daily, Friday. "But I have been thinking about what I should do to stop the piracy."
Niu said that people should view the film at movie theaters, as Monga has certain effects that cannot be experienced on a computer screen.
On Feb. 21, the director angrily responded to a message left by a local Internet user on the social Web site Plurk minutes after the user said he had watched Monga in his bedroom, the report said.

The Chinese online video site, PPS.tv, had attracted 110,000 viewers of the pirated version of the film as of Thursday night, the paper reported. The film can also be viewed for free on another Chinese Web site, Tudou.com, it said.
Pirated VCDs of the movie are also available at Taiwan's night markets at half the price of movie tickets, the report stated.

Shih Show-yi, a deputy officer on a police task force that is responsible for protecting intellectual property rights, was quoted in the report as saying that the task force had busted 13 piracy cases at local night markets during the Lunar New Year holiday.
The task force has also found five download links on a local social Web site, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Autographed Dan Brown books up for auction on Taiwan Web site
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:38:00 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Five autographed Chinese-language copies of the book "The Lost Symbol" by American writer Dan Brown were put up for auction Friday on Yahoo! Taiwan.
According to the China Times Publishing Company, all proceeds from the auction will be donated to the Christian charity World Vision to help the victims of quake-stricken Haiti.
Bidding for the five books will run from Feb. 26 to March 7.

Prior to the Taiwan publication of the fifth book by the bestselling author, the general editor of the publishing company Lin Sin-gin flew to the United States last month to interview the writer and obtained Brown's autograph in the books.

"Dan Brown is pleased to know that he has many readers in Taiwan, especially as the Chinese edition of 'The Da Vinci Code' has sold more than one million copies since it was published here in 2004, " Lin said.
Lin also mentioned that Brown expects to visit Taiwan some day to meet his readers.

The film rights to "The Lost Symbol" have been sold to Columbia Pictures. Award winning American actor Tom Hanks is expected to reprise his role as professor Robert Langdon in what will be the third film in a series based on Brown's books.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan could sink without trade pact with China: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 17:58:37 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will face serious economic danger unless it concludes a controversial economic cooperation framework agreement with China, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

"Not signing it would bring immediate and unlimited danger. We would be finished, " said Wu at the Legislative Yuan in response to a lawmaker's question on what the administration would do if Taiwan fails to clinch the trade pact with China.
"The government will spare no effort to push for its success."

He told the legislature that if the pact were not signed, it would be difficult to imagine the suffering the country would endure as more and more members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) join in a regional trade bloc from which Taiwan is excluded.

When South Korea joins the bloc in the future, for instance, Taiwanese goods will have trouble competing against Korean goods in China, as Korean products will be exempted from 9 percent import duties while Taiwan-made goods will be subject to the tariffs, the premier said.
"No business can survive (under those circumstances)," Wu said.

The premier argued that the pact would help Taiwan's businesses sell their goods abroad and enhance the country's competitiveness in general, as it would exempt locally made products from tariffs, safeguard the investment of local companies in China, and protect their intellectual property.
The premier also reiterated the government's promise that the pact would not open Taiwan's market to more Chinese agricultural products or allow Chinese laborers to work in Taiwan.

On the same occasion, Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang allayed lawmakers' concerns that in exchange for letting Taiwan sign trade pacts with ASEAN countries, China could ask ASEAN states to require that Taiwanese goods carry "Made in Taiwan (China) " or "Made in Chinese Taipei" origin labels.
"Taiwan has sold its products abroad using the 'Made in Taiwan, ' label. This practice won't be changed." Shih said.

Wu's administration is negotiating the trade pact with China in hopes of clinching it later this year. Critics of the pact argue that it will tie Taiwan more closely to China and undermine the country's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chip, panel makers ready to apply to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 19:19:38 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: New regulations that will allow Taiwan's chip makers and LCD panel makers to invest in China formally took effect Friday, and several companies are expected to file investment applications beginning March 1.

Under the new laws, approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Feb. 23, Taiwan's flat panel sector will be permitted to build up to three 6th generation and above TFT-LCD production lines in China.
Local companies will only be allowed, however, to run factories that are at least one generation behind their most advanced plants in Taiwan.
That means AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , the world's third-largest LCD maker, can apply to build a 7.5-generation facility, while Chi Mei Optoelectronics can only apply to set up a 6.5-generation plant.
AUO said Friday that it would soon submit an application to set up a 7.5-generation plant in eastern or southeastern China to maintain its competitiveness against Korean rivals in the Chinese market.

The South Korean government approved in late December the plans of Samsung Electronics and LG Display, the world's two biggest panel makers, LCD manufacturers, to set up a 7.5-generation and an 8th-generation panel plant in China, respectively.
AUO refused, however, to confirm media reports that it would collaborate with a Chinese panel maker to set up the facility in Kunshan in China's Jiangsu province.
MOEA officials said the ministry has formed a review panel headed by MOEA Deputy Minister Huang Chung-chiou to assess and handle applications, which are expected to be received beginning March 1.
Meanwhile, the new regulations also allow Taiwanese chip manufacturers to invest in China, but they will not be allowed to build new fabs there.
Instead, they will be limited to acquiring a full or partial stake in Chinese chip makers whose foundries are at least two generations behind the investing company's most advanced factory in Taiwan.
Under those rules, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) will be allowed to invest in 90-nanometer fabs in China because it has begun making chips in Taiwan using 45nm process technology.
United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) has started 65nm production in Taiwan and will therefore will be allowed to invest in chip companies using 0.13 micron process technology in China.

Previously existing investment regulations stipulated that only three chip fabs could be built by Taiwanese chipmakers in China, under which TSMC, ProMOS Technologies and Powerchip Semiconductor all gained approval to build 8-inch wafer plants there using less advanced processes.
But Powerchip has yet to act, and if it does not invest by August when its permit expires, the MOEA said it will allow other manufacturers to apply for the slot.
Powerchip was recently reported as showing renewed interest in its China fab project, with Xuzhou in Jiangsu province mentioned as a potential site.

The new regulations will also provide a legal basis for TSMC's acquisition of a 10-percent stake in Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. (SMIC) and UMC's acquisition of a controlling stake in Chinese wafer foundry He Jian Technology (Suzhou) Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotai expects higher market share despite Toyota recalls
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 19:35:15 (By Sophia Yeh and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwanese distributor of Japanese car maker Toyota Motor Corp., is aiming to raise its market share in Taiwan to 40 percent this year as its sales have been little affected by Toyota's worldwide recalls.
Hotai Motor's market share in Taiwan rose from 35 percent in 2008 to 38 percent last year, an equivalent of 111,000 vehicles, the company's president Daniel Chang said Thursday.
It was the seventh consecutive year that Hotai was Taiwan's best car-selling company, posting sales of NT$72.48 billion (US$2.3 billion), according to Chang.
The company plans to sell 104,100 vehicles in what is expected to be a weaker market this year, Chang noted.

Hotai has revised upward its forecast for Taiwan's market in 2010 from 230,000 vehicles to 260,000, but that will still fall behind the 290,000 vehicles sold in the country in 2009, when excise taxes were lowered to stimulate a car market depressed by the global economic downturn.

Toyota may be in big trouble after having to recall 8.5 million vehicles, but Chang said Taiwan has not been seriously affected because the defective accelerator pedal at the center of the controversy is not used in Toyota cars marketed in Taiwan.
Hotai has also rebooted the computer software in more than 600 2010 Prius hybrids that were subject to the recall, representing a completion rate of close to 99 percent, Chang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health insurance bureau urged to explain its bank loans
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 20:42:00 (By Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Civil groups suggested Friday that the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) make public details of bank loans that have reached NT$130 billion (US$4.1 billion) before taking action to raise the national insurance premium.

The Department of Health (DOH) , which supervises the BNHI's operations, has asked the Executive Yuan to raise health insurance premium rates to save the insurance system from financial collapse as deficits mount.
Premier Wu Den-yih, however, has instructed the DOH to suspend the premium adjustment plan.

Hsieh Wu-chi, an executive member of the Taiwan Hospital Association, said in a meeting of the National Health Insurance Audit Commission Friday that the BNHI is obliged to explain to the public why the insurance system is suffering massive deficits and has huge loan obligations before asking for higher premium rates.

BNHI Director-General Cheng Shou-hsia responded that the bank loans were needed to cover shortfalls from three sources -- back premiums owed by local governments, including Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, a growing divergence between revenues and expenditures, and the timing of government premium payments.
Cheng promised to provide detailed information of the loans if requested by the audit commission.

According to the bureau, the shortfalls have resulted primarily from a growing disparity between premium revenues, which grew at an average of 4.34 percent a year between 1996 and 2008, and expenditures, which grew 5.34 percent a year over the same period.
This imbalance has forced the bureau to not only exhaust its reserve fund but also accumulate deficits surpassing NT$45 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Property agency defends public land sales
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:10:07 (By Lin Yi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The National Property Administration (NPA) defended its sales of small plots of public land Friday after a land parcel in Taipei City fetched a near record price in an open tender a day earlier and fueled worries of a possible property bubble.
"It would be a waste of resources if we failed to auction off small-size public plots for private use when the market has strong demand," the bureau said in a statement.

Stressing that selling small plots of land through a market mechanism is a normal strategy to spur and sustain economic development, the statement said the bureau has consistently followed the principle of selling only public plots of less than 500 pings, or 1,650 square meters.

In a public auction Thursday, a 121-ping piece of public land on Jianguo S. Road in Taipei City was sold for NT$731 million (US$22.84 million) . The unit price of NT$6.03 million per ping was the second highest unit price for residential land ever recorded in Taiwan.

The sale followed the auction of two other plots in the city in January, which also were sold for high prices. The deals have fed criticism that the NPA is fanning property speculation and driving housing prices in urban areas, particularly Taipei City and Taipei County, to levels that are unaffordable for most local families.
The bureau rejected the allegations, arguing that public land sales accounted for only a negligible share of the domestic real estate market.

Citing 2009 sales, the NPA said the 13.85 hectares of public land it auctioned off last year for NT$10.8 billion accounted for only 0.04 percent of all the land sold in Taiwan and 0.68 percent of the total transaction value.
"Given such marginal numbers, public land sales were unlikely to affect normal property market prices," the statement contended.

Noting that the few public lots that fetched record-setting prices were all located in Taipei City, the statement said the phenomenon mainly reflected the decreasing amount of prime land available in a city that is the leading indicator of economic development in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises no hike in health insurance premiums March 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:23:50 (By Justin Su and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that national health insurance (NHI) rates will not be raised on March 1 and that any rate adjustment will be accompanied by complementary measures.

Wu said that before the passage of amendments launching a second-generation health insurance system, insurance premium rates will only be adjusted after the feasibility of proposed measures is carefully studied.

The second-generation health insurance scheme refers to a proposal that would calculate premiums based on total household income, including both earned and unearned income, rather than on salary, as is the case at present.
Wu said that any premium adjustment will be made based on the principle of fairness and after the waste and abuse of medical resources has been improved.

He added the government will also ensure that any rate adjustment will not place an extra financial burden on low- and middle-income individuals, and it could even provide added subsidies to low-income insurees.
In the future, Wu said, health insurance premiums will be designed to make high- income earners pay more and low-income earners pay less.

The Department of Health has been pushing for a premium rate hike to cover the National Health Insurance system's growing deficit, caused primarily by a growing disparity between expenditures and premium revenues.
The Taipei and Kaohsiung city governments also owe the system more than NT$50 billion in back payments for contributions to premiums of individuals working in those cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Attorney brings laws suit against KMT for 228 victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 21:41:27 (by An Chi-hsien and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Attorney Wellington Koo on Friday filed a class action suit against the Kuomintang on behalf of 33 victims and 75 relatives of victims of the 228 Incident, an anti-government uprising on Feb. 28, 1947 that was violently suppressed by the military.
Koo and dozens of relatives of 228 victims gathered in front of the Taipei District Court, where the suit was filed, demanding that the Kuomintang stand trial and that Taiwan be given justice.

The attorney said that although the government has made Feb. 28 a national holiday in memory of the victims of the tragic incident and paid compensation to families of the victims, the truth has not been fully revealed and some murderers have yet to be prosecuted.
Because the incident occurred at a time when party rule prevailed over the government, the Kuomintang, which held power at the time, should be held responsible, Koo argued.
He is demanding that the KMT pay NT$2 billion for the construction and future operations of a National Taiwan 228 Memorial Museum at the 228 Peace Park in Taipei.
The 228 Incident remained a taboo subject in Taiwan until the early 1990s, when the Executive Yuan commissioned a study to find out what really happened.
In 1997, the Executive Yuan designated Feb. 28 a national holiday and since then commemorative activities have been held around the island every year.

On Feb. 28 this year, President Ma Ying-jeou will lead central government officials in attending commemorative activities in Tainan in southern Taiwan, including memorial services, exhibitions, and concerts.
Since the Lantern Festival, the 15th day of the Chinese Lunar New Year, falls on Feb. 28 this year, some local governments held memorial services to mark the occasion in advance.
In Chiayi and Tainan, local government officials and the public laid wreaths in front of memorial monuments on Friday.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih suggested during the memorial service that Feb. 28 should be designated Taiwanese Youth Day as a tribute to the young victims of the 228 Incident and a reminder to young people of their responsibilities to society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Virtual lantern shows in Taipei opened during lantern festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:04:06 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Lantern Festival opened Friday night with greetings from the giant mascot "Happy Tiger" and a late night virtual show that drew thousands of local residents and overseas tourists.
Combining strong lighting, visual arts and pop music, the giant virtual show titled " New Year Blossom Trilogy" captivated the gathered crowd.

Divided into three parts -- "Folk Flower, " "Akibo's Flower" and "Universal Flower" -- it screened the works of artists from different generations on the exterior wall of City Hall, according to the designer of the festival, Akibo Lee.

"Another creative approach was to select head shots of 6,666 people and turn them into a large work of art to be projected onto the walls, " said Chen Kuan- fu, deputy commissioner of Taipei City's Department of Cultural Affairs.
In addition to the virtual show, traditional and specially designed lanterns are also being displayed around the city to highlight the festival.

One of them, a big tiger "HoKi" lantern shining at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall plaza, is another focal point of the planned festivities, with professional dance troupes, bands and singers performing there Friday night to celebrate the traditional event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expansion of Songshan Airport may be delayed: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:45:39 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The expansion of Taipei Songshan Airport to accommodate more international flights may not be ready by October, and passengers may have to be patient, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Friday.

Replying to a question at a Legislative Yuan question and answer session, Mao said Songshan Airport had been a domestic airport for many years until recently, creating inconveniences for passengers on international flights.

The airport needs to be expanded after the airport's management concluded agreements to open international routes that will connect the city airport to Tokyo's Haneda Airport, Seoul's Gimpo International Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport, he added.
Although it has limited capacity, the airport can become a "small but efficient" airport after the expansion of terminal one for international flights is completed, Mao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy continues to show signs of recovery: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:49:56 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy flashed a "yellow-red" light in January for the third consecutive month, an indication that the economy's recovery from last year's global economic downturn is on a steady track, according to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Hung Jui-pin, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said Friday that the composite score remained at 37 points, only one point short of turning the light red, which would indicate overheating.

January's leading indicators index, which forecasts economic activity over the next three to six months, rose by 1.9 percent from December 2009 to 107.6, while the annualized six-month rate of change of the index edged up by 0.6 percentage points to 21.2 percent.

Six of the seven components that form the leading indicators were up from a month earlier, including average monthly overtime in the manufacturing and service sectors, the book-to-bill ratio of North American semiconductor equipment firms, export orders, and producers' inventory.
Also higher were the stock price index and variation rate of money supply M1B, but building permits were down.
In the same month, the index of coincident indicators, which tracks the current pace of economic activity, posed a monthly drop of 0.2 percent from a month earlier.

Four of the seven components that form the indicators showed rises, including industrial production, real customs-cleared exports, real machinery and electrical equipment imports and nonagricultural employment.

The CEPD adopts a five-color gauge for the country's economic performance: red reflects the economy is overheated, yellow-red signals a heating economy, green shows stable economic growth, yellow-blue indicates an economic slowdown, and blue indicates a recession.

Hung said the indicators showed the financial, manufacturing and trade sectors have turned for the better and consumption has become more active but that there is still room for improvement in employment.
However, he expects the global economic recovery to continue over the next six months, which could give a boost to Taiwan's export-oriented economy.

Lin Tsu-chia, a professor in National Chengchi University's Department of Economics, said the "yellow-red" light indicated that Taiwan's economy has improved considerably compared with a year earlier, but more effort is needed for the economy to recover to its level before the financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says 2010 is job creation year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 22:54:15 (By Worthy Shen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated his resolve on the campaign trail Friday to ease the unemployment situation, declaring that this will be a year for job creation.
He said that he will ask related government agencies to thrash out plans to create more jobs.

The government will also work with the private sector to boost employment, the president said, adding that the unemployment rate should fall to 4.9 percent by the end of 2010 as forecast by the Council for Economic Planning and Development from the 5.68 percent in January.
"The creation of jobs should not depend on the Council of Labor Affairs alone, " he said, while campaigning in Hualien for the ruling Kuomintang's candidate in Saturday's legislative by-election.
He also said that as long as private businesses reach a certain level of new hirings or reduce layoffs, the government will offer them subsidies.
"Whether the businesses are small or large, they should work with the government to help more people find work," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Party heavyweights making last-minute campaign for candidates
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/10 23:06:41 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Lillian Lin)
