DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 27, 2010 or the 14th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the- troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: KMT should not give up on the south
DOC.DATELINE: In the opinion of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 02/27/10 12:36:41 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: , the year-end mayoral elections in the southern municipalities of Tainan and Kaohsiung will be a piece of cake. On the contrary, the Kuomintang (KMT) has so far failed to find suitable candidates to run in the races.

Over the past decade, Taiwan's politics has developed a trend in which the south is dominated by the green camp, while the north is controlled by the blue camp. The KMT itself is to blame for the situation. In power in Taiwan for many years, the KMT has often tended to "value the north above the south." How can the KMT reverse its downfall in the south?

The policy of the central government is a priority. Targeting the disaster-prone southern regions, the central government must work out precautionary measures. It also needs to present plans to bridge the north-south development divide.
With communication failures being a common problem within the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, how to communicate with voters in southern Taiwan is another major issue.

Certainly, a lack of talent in the south is the most crucial issue. The KMT should nurture new talent and recruit capable individuals to return to their hometowns to run for public office, so as to rebuild the party's foundation in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 1 million eligible voters expected to cast votes Saturday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 13:09:03 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Eligible voters in Taiwan's Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Chiayi and Hualien counties are casting their votes at polling stations between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Saturday, to elect four legislators to fill four legislative seats that have been left vacant.

The seats in the four counties that are holding the by-elections were made vacant because local lawmakers which held them were elected to serve as county magistrates on Dec. 5, 2009. Legislators Chang Hwa-kuan from Chiayi, John Chih- yang Wu from Taoyuan, Chiu Ching-chun from Hsinchu and Fu Kun-chi from Hualien were elected magistrates in their respective constituencies in the elections in December.

A total of 233,116 voters in Taoyuan County's third electoral district, 358,854 in Hsinchu County, 221,816 in Chiayi County's second electoral district, and 197,426 in Hualien County are eligible to cast votes in the by-elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ceremonies, Hollywood movie remember 228 Incident after 63 years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 15:00:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A series of ceremonies, exhibitions and concerts are being held across Taiwan and a Hollywood movie is being screened in the U.S. over the weekend to commemorate the 228 Incident, an anti-government uprising on Feb. 28, 1947 that was violently suppressed by the military and government at the time.

The incident, in which the beating of a Taiwanese woman selling unlicensed cigarettes by then-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) police led to rioting that spread across the island and was brutally crushed by KMT troops sent over from China.

It marked the start of the KMT's infamous "White Terror" purge of "dissidents, " which is considered one of the darkest periods in modern Taiwan history. People suspected of being anti-government were jailed and many of them died or disappeared, with no explanations given to their families.

On Sunday, President Ma Ying-jeou will attend an annual ceremony, with a theme of "remember the past, embrace the future, " organized by the government in southern Tainan city, while local groups will also organize various events in Taiwan's major cities.

In the United States, a film about the assassination of a Taiwanese-American in the United States in 1983, during Taiwan's martial law period, is being screened this weekend across America. The film "Formosa Betrayed, " a political thriller, takes its title from abook published in 1965 by former U.S. Consul George Kerr, who documented his observation of the incident.
It is produced by second-generation Taiwanese-American Will Tiao and directed by Adam Kane.

Discussion about the 228 Incident is no longer a taboo, which had been the case during the 38 years (1949-1987) of martial law in Taiwan, although it is sometimes seen as a tool for political mobilization and a topic that could destabilize ethnic harmony between longtime Taiwanese residents and people who immigrated to the island from China in the late 1940s.
President Ma as well as former presidents Lee Teng-hui and Chen Shui-bian have all offered government apologies over that period of history in official settings.

More than a dozen memorial monuments to commemorate the victims of the 228 Incident have been erected around the island. One of them, the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum, was established in the 228 Memorial Park, which was renamed by then-Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian in 1996.
Taiwan's Executive Yuan or Cabinet designated Feb. 28 a national holiday in 1997 and completed a full investigation report of the incident in 2003.

"Only when we can face historical truths squarely, without any cover-ups, will we strike the right attitude," President Ma said last November in a ceremony to mark the integration of the planned memorial hall and the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum.
However, there are still controversies surrounding the incident.

Death counts in the incidents ranged from less than 1,000 to "somewhere between 18,000-28,000, " as stated in the Executive Yuan's report. Some victims and families of victims disagree on the amount of compensation offered from the government as well as whether Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was the person responsible for ordering the brutal killings.

Almost 63 years after the incident, a class action suit was filed Friday against the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) by 33 victims and 75 relatives of victims, who demanded that the KMT pay NT$2 billion for the construction and future operations of a National Taiwan 228 Memorial Museum. The group also demanded the KMT - the ruling party at the time - apologize.

Wellington Koo, an attorney representing the 228 Incident victims in the case, said that although the government has made Feb. 28 a national holiday and paid compensation to families, the truth has not been fully revealed and some murderers have yet to be prosecuted.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for support for Taiwanese film by rejecting piracy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 15:08:20 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called for people who have watched pirated versions of Taiwan's latest box office hit "Monga" to watch the film again at movie theaters as a way to support locally produced films.
Ma made the call in his latest weekly online administration journal. "Rejecting piracy is supporting locally produced films, " he wrote.

He noted that a pirated version of Taiwanese film "Cape No.7" -- one of Taiwan's best-selling films -- hit the market three months after its release in June 2008, and that the same piracy attacked "Monga" less than four weeks after its release.
This rampant copyright infringement not only strikes a blow to the creativity and confidence of local film makers but also hinders the Taiwanese film industry from making progress, he said.
The greatest harm is unauthorized downloading from the Internet, which causes incalculable damage, Ma said.

"Innovation" is the way for Taiwan to grow stronger and what it fears the most is the practice of intellectual property theft, he added, noting that he has instructed the Executive Yuan to reinforce measures to crack down on piracy.

It has been estimated that "Monga, " a film set in Taipei's old Wanhua district and featuring brotherhood, justice and love among gangsters, has lost some NT$80 million (US$2.5 million) as a result of piracy.

It grossed NT$18 million at the box office on its first day in local cinemas Feb. 5, marking the highest box office sales ever on premiere night in Taiwan, beating out the Hollywood blockbuster Avatar, which debuted Dec. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: No more bribes in by-elections

TEXT.P: Legislative by-elections will be held Saturday in Taoyuan, Hualien, Hsinchu and Chiayi counties. People should not ignore the fact that some of the by-elections have been held recently because the legislative seats were made vacant following the invalidation of their election wins involving bribery scandals.

However, rumors still swirled about alleged bribing in by-elections. Authorities should keep investigating election bribery and encourage people to report suspected bribery cases and give cash rewards for information or tip offs.

In fact, the reason for the ruling Kuomintang losing three legislative seats in legislative by-elections held in early January, was the KMT voters' lack of interest in voting, instead of any increase of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's voters.
The KMT voters did not want to vote partly because they did not get the money they expected, and also because of the under performance of President Ma's government.

Without money or strong local connections, the party can hardly win voters' support. Those candidates who lack local connections and are just designated by the party, are usually accused of not caring much about local interests.
The KMT and DPP have been accusing each other nominating candidates who lack understanding of local affairs. However, that approach in election campaigns may no longer have much impact on voters.

The key to winning the election will be how to ask their voters to vote. Traditionally, the DPP voters are much more passionate than the KMT's, and that is the DPP's advantage. And the KMT seems better on managing local factions and interest groups.
However, if a party decides to send another candidate who lacks local background to run by-elections, the party's other candidates with long-term local connections may get angry.
On this front, the KMT has a bigger problem than the DPP. The KMT might even lose by-elections again if they fail to maneuver their election strategies properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Justice yet to be served for 228 Incident

TEXT.P: A group of victims of the 228 Incident and their families filed a lawsuit against the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Friday demanding that the party pay NT$2 billion for the construction and operation of the National Taiwan 228 Memorial Museum. This appeal, which points directly to the core of the historic tragedy, deserves the attention of society.

The 228 Incident of 1947 resulted in the highest casualties for a single incident in Taiwanese history and is also the one that has had the most profound impact. It is unacceptable that after 63 years have passed, the truth has yet to be revealed and that justice has in no way been upheld. The exact number of deaths remains unclear and there has not been a single main KMT persecutor who has admitted his guilt and apologized.
With transitional justice yet to be achieved, the truth of the 228 Incident is considered taboo, and many people still lack sufficient understanding of Taiwan's history.

The latest example of this is President Ma Ying-jeou's honoring of historian Huang Chang-chien early this month for his efforts in uncovering the truth of the 228 Incident. Huang claims that only 673 people were killed in the massacre, that the incident was properly managed by Kaohsiung Garrison Commander Peng Meng-chi, and even that the crackdown was actually instigated by U.S. diplomat George Kerr. Such shockingly arbitrary conclusions, which run contrary to those reached by other historians, have won Ma's favor and this highlights Ma's unapologetic attitude toward the incident.

More vicious still, on every anniversary of the 228 Incident or in election campaigns, Ma has made the best of his political showmanship and has displayed various insincere gestures, including apologizing to the families of the victims.
The Taiwanese people should spike the guns of the KMT so that it can no longer cheat them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Controversial public land sales
DOC.DATELINE: A 121-ping (one ping equals 3.3 square meters) 02/27/10 15:35:06 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: plot of public land in Taipei City was sold for NT$731 million (US$22.74 million) in a public auction Thursday. The unit price of NT$6.03 million per ping is the second-highest unit price for residential land ever recorded in Taiwan.

As the public is complaining about unaffordable housing prices, whether the National Property Administration's (NPA's) decision to sell public land at this time is fueling surging real estate prices or contributing to the property bubble has become a focus of concern.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:
Finance Minister Lee Sush-teh said the sale of the public land accounts for only a fraction of all land sold in Taiwan and urged the public to be rational and to respect the market mechanism.
The NPA defended its decision too, saying that if it does not sell land to meet the needs of the private sector, it would be a "waste."
The release of public land through market mechanism helps spur economic development, it continued.
It said the use of national land is based on the principle of "public land for public use" and that it gives priority for the use of the central and local governments.
The NPA said it also follows the policy of "selling small pieces of land but keeping the large ones, " and has sold only public plots of less than 500 pings.
It also said public sales account for a negligible share of the domestic real estate market.

Citing 2009 sales, the NPA said the 13.85 hectares of public land it auctioned off last year for NT$10.8 billion accounted for only 0.04 percent of all the land sold in Taiwan and 0.68 percent of the total transaction value of NT$1.58 trillion.

It explained that in the sales, the few that fetched exorbitant prices were invariably located in Taipei City, which is mainly because Taipei City is an index area of economic development and the available land is now decreasing. (Feb. 27, 2010)
United Daily News:
Real estate businesses think the government should suspend the sale of public land for the time being to dampen the overheated housing market and help the sound development of the property market.

Chang Hsin-ming, president of the Pacific Assets Management Co., said that obtaining land in urban areas has become more difficult in recent years and that public land has become a shortcut for developers.
Some bidders often scramble to buy small pieces of land near public land and await their chances to get windfall profits.
Chang noted that once public land in one area fetches a good price, other construction projects and even second-hand houses in the area will ride on the coattails and see price surges.

Tamkang University professor Chuang Meng-han said public land sold by the NPA has continued to set record prices, which will whip up panic among the public that if they do not act quickly to buy a house, they will never be able to afford one.
The public land sold by the NPA over the past two years has mostly fallen into the hands of the conglomerates, and the prices have continued to set records, he said.
If the government wants to return to the fundamentals of housing prices, he suggested that it suspend sales of public land to cool the market.
Liberty Times:
Land Bank of Taiwan Chairman Wang Yao-hsin said it is "outrageous" to see one ping of land being sold for over NT$6 million.
Wang took the NPA's approach to task, saying that the bidding for land in Taipei City has lost all rationality.

The NPA should not stimulate land price hikes through its public land sales. He also said land priced at over NT$6 million per ping is beyond the risk management of a bank and that his bank will never undertake such financing. (Feb. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Fireworks festival in Tainan County unveiled with deafening fanfare
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 15:37:33 (by Yang Szu-jui and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: An annual two-day fireworks festival -- the Yenshui Beehive Fireworks Festival -- opened in the town of the same name in southern Taiwan's Tainan County Saturday morning and will culminate in a finale on Sunday night.
On Saturday, a palanquin carrying a statue of the legendary hero Kuanyu (dating back to the early 3rd century) and over 100 martial arts troupes began a parade to ward off evil spirits.
The Yenshui Beehive Fireworks Festival originated from the folk custom in the region of the late 19th Century when villagers suffering from serious cholera epidemics sought protection.

They held religious services, asking help from Kuanyu, a heroic figure in Chinese history who was made a saint in folk belief. They also tried to scare away evil spirits which they believe had brought them the disease by setting off masses of firecrackers.

While explosions of firecrackers still highlight the festivities nowadays, as well as the light and sound of fireworks shooting off everywhere as the palanquin travels through the streets, the highlight of the festival falls on the night of the Lantern Festival, Sunday this year, when piles of fireworks in the shapes of huge teapots, chariots, and golden ingots are lit.
In recent years, the annual event attracted thousands of visitors from home and abroad to the small township and has become a tourism promotion feature.
Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-jhih invited foreign guests from 17 countries to attend the festivities at Yenshui this year.

He recommended that visitors see the exhibitions featuring sculpture, teapot designs and performing arts by local artists being held in the neighborhood of the Kuangyu Temple while appreciating the fun of folk customs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Control Yuan controversies

TEXT.P: Over the past several months there have been many negative media reports about the Control Yuan, such as controversial leadership or remarks by the Control Yuan president, controversial handling of a corrective proposal causing a company to make a newspaper announcement against it, improper handling of political cases, and the issuing of too many administrative instructions.
If the Control Yuan does not review its problems or make improvements, its legitimacy and authority will be undermined in the long run.

The public expectations for Control Yuan President Wang Chien- shien were very high when he first took office in 2008. However, his behavior -- such as getting personally involved in investigations, participating in the examination committees of cases of impeachment and imposing restrictions on voluntary investigation cases -- have caused internal controversy and a split within the Control Yuan.

There have also been other controversies, such as the Control Yuan applying a new law retroactively and correcting local governments by saying they misused their administrative ruling authority, that have affected the public interest.
The Control Yuan has also used distorted figures as evidence in corrective proposals that have jeopardized a legitimate company's interests and reputation.

In addition, the impeachments of Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen and State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming were passed under media pressure after a second review. This indicates that the reasons for impeachments might not be sufficient and that the procedures were rather unconvincing.
We hope the Control Yuan president can assist the yuan to establish sound conditions for carrying out investigations and be more cautious when making comments.

In order to protect the rights of the people and the Control Yuan's reputation, we also expect the Control Yuan members to exercise their rights and powers with extreme caution, as well as to collect complete and accurate evidence during investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 28,000 people apply for e-passport in one day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 16:13:11 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 28,000 people in Taiwan applied for electronic passports Friday, the last day before charges for a new Republic of China passport were raised NT$400 to NT$1,600 (US$50), the director-general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs said Saturday.
Lo Yu-chung called the figure the country's highest ever in terms of new passport applications.
The adjusted charge for a regular e-passport with a 10-year period of validity will take effect March 1.
Taiwan began to issue e-passports Dec. 29, 2008, becoming the 60th country to issue this type of passport, which boasts increased anti-fraud and security features.
As of last Dec. 31, some 1 million e-passports had been issued, with another 250,000 issued so far this year, according to Lo.

The e-passport, also called a chip passport, has a small contactless integrated circuit embedded in the back cover. It looks similar to a regular passport except for the designation of e-passport on the cover, 52 pages instead of 48, and scenic or folk custom themes printed on the inner pages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei fashion trade fair to open in August
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 16:59:34 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The annual Taipei In Style (TIS), a fashion trade fair "spotlighting the new power of brands, " is scheduled to take place at the Taipei World Trade Center Aug. 27-29.
The event has been organized by the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council every year since 2006 to showcase the country's brand creators and design talent.

The 2010 event will be expanded compared to previous years so that it will continue its success in drawing media and public attention and serving as a meeting point for buyers and designers from around the world, according to a TTF press release.
TIS 2009 attracted buyers, sales agents and reporters from 22 countries and areas, the press release said.

This year, world-renowned Japanese designer Issey Miyake has been invited to present a collection that has never been shown anywhere other than Paris Fashion Week, the TTF said, adding that Michel Klein, a highly respected designer known for his mastery of brand development, will also attend the event.

The TTF said that now is the time for fashion designers to explore business opportunities in China amid talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement.
The federation welcomes fashion brands and designers to use the TIS as a platform to establish business partners for market development in Taiwan and China, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP overwhelms KMT in Chiayi by-election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 17:42:16 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Chen Ming-wen, a veteran opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politician in Chiayi who was county magistrate for eight years until last December, announced victory in the legislative by-election in the southern county Saturday when votes for him exceeded those for his ruling Kuomintang (KMT) opponent Lin Teh- jui by over 30,000.
Right from the start of vote-counting, Chen took the lead and by around 5 p.m., one hour after the polling stations closed, he had already garnered more than 56,000 votes against Lin's 26,000.
The legislative seat for Chiayi County was made vacant in December when Chang Hwa-kuan changed her career track from the legislature after being elected Chiayi county chief.

Starting his career in local politics in 1981 as a member of the Chiayi county council, Chen was county council spokesman, member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, and county magistrate from Dec. 20, 2001 to Dec. 20, 2009.
With his good connections and abundant experience, Chen was assumed by many as a shoo-in for Saturday's by-election.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Can Tainan City transcend the past?

TEXT.P: This year, a central government ceremony to mark the anniversary of the 228 Incident will take place in Tainan City, with the theme of "remembering the past, embracing the future."

However, Tainan City is not known as a main scene of the 228 Incident. The main heritage site related to the incident in the city is a park where lawyer Tang Teh-chang was executed. Instead, it is better known as the capital of the Koxinga Dynasty founded by Ming loyalist Cheng Cheng-kung in the 17th century.

For many years, Tainan City has been labeled as a stronghold of the green camp led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and this year's 228 commemorative ceremony will probably be manipulated by local politicians in a "green" direction.

The merger of Tainan City with Tainan County and Kaohsiung City with Kaohsiung County next year means that southern Taiwan will almost be completely "greenified." If the DPP continues to indulge the people with the memory of the 228 Incident, we have no idea how it will meet the challenges of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, not to mention releasing Taiwan from the spell of blue-green confrontation.
Tainan City should transcend the anti-Ching experience of the Koxinga era and transcend the political shadow of the Tang Teh-chang period.

If the DPP can unlock complete memories of history and face up to the realistic panorama of cross-strait ties and globalization, it will naturally find out how to "remember the past and greet the future."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF calls for support for summer camp program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 18:06:08 (By Chang Ming-kun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An official of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Saturday that its summer camps for children of Taiwanese businessmen in China have become ever more popular over the years and he urged more support for the program.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Kao Wen-cheng also said the government has only limited resources and that the program will need more public support to allow more children of the Taiwanese businessmen to come to Taiwan to learn about the country.
There are an estimated 800,000 Taiwanese businessmen or officials working for Taiwanese businesses operating in China.

At present, there are four schools in China dedicated to educating the children of Taiwanese businessmen in China -- in Donggong, Shenzhen, Shanghai and Kunshan, with another currently in the planning stages in Xiamen.
The SEF, in cooperation with the Wei-Chuan Cultural and Educational Foundation, first held the summer camps in July 2004.
In the first year, more than 100 children attended the camps.

Since then, the SEF has held the camps every year to explore the beauty of Taiwan, with courses ranging from learning traditional Chinese, phonetic pronunciation, appreciating traditional folk culture such as hand puppetry and getting a taste of Taiwan's infrastructure and economic development.

The SEF will arrange for more of these children to attend summer camp in Taiwan this year, an SEF official said. The official said that 480, including 330 students from elementary schools and 150 from junior and senior high schools, will attend the camps to help them learn more about their native land.
"The activity has been warmly welcomed by Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, " Kao said.
Kao said the camps have become more popular over the years due to support from the Mainland Affairs Council -- the nation's top China policy-making body -- and the Ministry of Education.

However, he said that even with the number of students increasing to 480 this year, it is still a far cry from meeting demand, noting that the number of students enrolled at the Taiwanese Businessmen's Dongguan School in Guangdong Province alone is nearly 1,800.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pianist to present Chopin repertoire March 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 18:08:15 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: To celebrate the 200th anniversary of the birth of Polish virtuoso Frederic Chopin, Chinese pianist Fou Ts'ong will present a repertoire of the composer in a recital at the National Concert Hall in Taipei March 1.
Fou was the first Chinese musician to win the honor for the best performance of mazurkas -- the music for a lively Polish dance -- at the International Chopin Piano Competition in 1955.
He has chosen to present some of Chopin's rarely heard early works in his recital.
"Audiences will hear the obvious contrast between Chopin's early pieces, which are simple and fresh, and his later works, which are more complicated and profound," according to the 76-year-old Fu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP claims victory in Taoyuan by-election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 18:10:15 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Huang Jen-shu claimed victory in Saturday's by-election for a legislative seat in the third electoral district of Taoyuan County, defeating former Legislator Chen Hsueh-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Huang, a Taoyuan county assemblyman, was more than 2,000 votes ahead of Chen when he made his victory announcement at 5:20 p.m.
The seat was left vacant by Wu Chih-yang of the KMT, who was elected Taoyuan magistrate in December 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP claims win in Hsinchu County by-election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 18:16:48 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Perng Shaw-jiin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced victory Saturday in the legislative by-election in Hsinchu County after outstripping his ruling Kuomintang (KMT) rival by more than 10,000 votes.
Perng made his announcement at 5:30 p.m., claiming a win over the KMT's Cheng Yung-tang, the younger brother of former Hsinchu Magistrate Cheng Yung-chun.
Perng is a former prosecutor at the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office and served as a two-term legislator between 1996 and 2002, with a third term from 2005 until 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT declares victory in Hualien by-election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 18:20:23 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Wang Ting-sheng, a ruling Kuomintang candidate in Saturday's legislative by- elections, announced victory in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County by garnering 39,331 votes compared with 33,209 votes for former Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Wang, 44, is an associate professor at National Dong Hwa University, and the son of former Hualien Magistrate Wang Chin-feng.

Hsiao, 39, is director of the DPP's Department of International Affairs. She was first elected in 2001 as a supplementary member representing overseas constituencies in the Legislative Yuan, and reelected in 2004 representing Taipei City's First Constituency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy Daily News: Expecting rain after hearing thunder

TEXT.P: Last week's decision by the Fed to raise its discount rate by a quarter of a point jittered global stock markets. In late last year and at the beginning of this year, all major international research institutes expected that the U.S. was not going to change its easy monetary policy this year. However, in less than two months, the Fed not only raised its discount rate but also implied a possible rate hike in the second half of this year.
The U.S. interest rate move not only affects the monetary policies of many other countries but also affects the global flow of funds and the trend of the U.S. dollar.

Since January, the euro and the sterling lost ground against the U.S. currency by 5 percent and 6 percent, respectively. This reflected not just the crisis in Greece and Spain but also somewhat revealed the future trend of the greenback.

With the U.S. dollar likely to move higher this year, the Chinese yuan -- if pegged to the U.S. currency -- will also move up against a basket of foreign currencies. However, some media have reported that China may scrap the yuan- dollar peg.
If this happens, the Chinese yuan might not follow the U.S. dollar in appreciation and the Chinese government might therefore be criticized by the U.S. and European countries.

However, if the Chinese government decides to let the yuan advance further against the greenback, that might bring more funds into China and create more bubbles, as well as cause greater impact on its export-oriented manufacturing industries, which have been struggling with labor shortage problems.
The appreciation of the Chinese yuan -- like the U.S. rate hike -- looks inevitable, but we do not know when that will happen.

China might be faced with similar conditions that Taiwan and Japan experienced in their bubble economies -- such as pressure from the U.S., more trade disputes, a continuing labor shortage, rising wages, overheated stock and housing prices, and possible moves in its exchange rates. (Feb. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP savors biggest win in Taoyuan County due to KMT split
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 19:54:47 (By Chiu Chin-ching and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won three out of four seats up for grabs in Saturday's legislative by-elections but tasted its sweetest victory in Taoyuan County.
Analysts said Taoyuan County has been traditionally dominated by the ruling Kuomintang-led pan-blue camp, with the blue majority even more pronounced in the county's Chungli City.
In previous elections, the pan-blue camp could be assured of easy victory as long as it could remain united.

But DPP candidate Huang Jen-shu, a first-time runner for the legislative seat, beat Chen Hsueh-sheng, a former KMT legislator, by a slim margin of just 2,763 votes to make his mark in the legislative by-election.

When choosing its candidate in the Taoyuan County primary, the KMT had to persuade Chungli Mayor Yeh Pu-liang, who was leading in opinion polls, to drop out of the election because of his involvement in a government procurement scandal.
It then nominated Chen, who ranked third in the public opinion polls.

However, the KMT was unable to dissuade two other KMT members -- Wu Yu-tung and Lin Hsiang-mei -- to bow out of the race and the two insisted on running, effectively splitting the KMT vote and spelling disaster for Chen.
Chen had to face attacks from both inside and outside the KMT right from the beginning of the campaign.

He failed in his re-election bid in the 2004 legislative election and failed again to get the KMT's nomination in the Kaohsiung mayoral election of 2006. He was invited to serve as top cultural official by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, then Taoyuan magistrate, in 2007.
Although Chen stayed in Taoyuan for three years, he engaged himself mostly in cultural affairs and his connections with the locals could not match those of the other candidates.
He also had to fight his rival's publicity campaign which made hay of his position as an "outsider, " leaving him to fight a hard battle to the very last minute.

Huang has served as a four-term county councilor. Although he has no brilliant academic or career record and cannot speak eloquently, he has served at the grassroots level for over 20 years and has good credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong university lures Taiwanese talent with big scholarships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 19:56:54 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The University of Hong Kong (HKU) began a recruitment drive at a national university exposition in Taiwan Saturday, seeking local high school graduates with excellent academic performance whom it said would be awarded generous scholarships if they choose to study at HKU.
The two-day fair opened simultaneously in the northern city of Taipei and in the southern city of Kaohsiung that day for schools to enroll new blood.

The Ministry of Education published Feb. 24 the results of the 2010 general scholastic ability tests targeting high school graduates. These scores are school children's tickets for university and college entry.

This year, 112 out of more than 140,000 students taking part in the examination achieved a perfect score of 75, comprising 15 levels in five categories. Students seeking enrollment in Ivy League-level schools in Taiwan such as National Taiwan University must score above 54.
HKU said it will offer scholarships totalling HK$140,000 (US$18,000) over three years to students who score at least 54 in the scholastic ability tests and pass its English proficiency tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supporters send new signal to KMT in by-election defeats: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 20:15:25 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Supporters of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) sent a new signal of discontent to the party Saturday, when the KMT managed to win only one of four legislative by- elections, scholars said later that day.

The ruling party suffered a fresh setback after losing in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County and Chiayi County, with its only victory coming in Hualien County. The by-elections were held because local lawmakers that previously held the seats were elected to serve as county magistrates.

The KMT's supporters sent a clear message by not turning up at polling stations, said Lin Huo-wang, a professor at National Taiwan University who also serves as senior advisor to President Ma Ying-jeou.

"It (the defeat) tells President Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, that he should stop trying to woo voters from the opposition Pan-green camp. A political party will not be able to hold its core support if it drifts further away from its ideals, " Lin said.
The low turnout rate and crushing election results are evidence that the party's supporters staged a "silent protest" by not voting, said Lo Chih-cheng, a political scientist at Soochow University.

The KMT lost three other legislative by-elections last month and also did not fare well in any of the five elections that have taken place since Ma assumed office in May 2008. The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , on the other hand, has gained more ground thanks to the elections, boosting its number of seats in the 113-member Legislative Yuan from 30 to 33.

At a post-election press conference, KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung conceded defeat for the party but pledged continued reforms, saying that introspection is vital for the party if it wants to win back support in future elections.

The candidate nominations were the key reason behind the defeat, according to legislator-turned-television pundit Jaw Shao-kong, who noted that the KMT neither placed local politicians at the top of the nomination lists nor went with the momentum during the nomination process.
"You have to go with the flow rather than trying to create the specific momentum of your desire, " he pointed out, adding that the KMT needs to find a way to "stop bleeding."

The KMT's nomination strategy presented mixed messages, Lo said, because it went with a candidate like Wang Ting-sheng, a university professor who narrowly beat the DPP's Hsiao Bi-khim in Hualien, but compromised with local factions and nominated Cheng Yung-tang in Hsinchu, where he ended up losing.

He noted that the KMT has been having trouble "turning the game around" and said the momentum could cause a ripple effect that will negatively impact its prospects in five special municipality elections at the end of the year that are considered even more important than the two recent legislative by-elections.

"It seems to me that more white-collar workers and middle-class people are supporting the opposition. And bear in mind that there are more voters like this in the five special municipalities, " he said.
There is no such place as a "stronghold" nowadays in Taiwanese elections, Jaw said, because voters are no longer fooled by politicians and political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Voting rates in legislative by-elections relatively low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 20:31:04 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The turnout rates in the four legislative by-elections held Saturday were relatively low -- ranging from 36 percent to 41.37 percent -- compared with previous elections in the past few years, the Central Election Commission (CSC) said after the vote-counting.

The CSC said Huang Jen-shu won the by-election in Taoyuan County with 45,363 votes, Perng Shaw-jin won in Hsinchu County with 71, 625 votes, Chen Ming-wen took Chiayi County with 57,451 votes and Wang Ting-sheng won in Hualien County with 39,379 votes.

The turnout rate in the third electoral district of Taoyuan County, with 233,116 eligible voters, was 41.37 percent, while Hsinchu County had a 36 percent turnout of the 358,854 voters. Chiayi County saw 38.35 percent of the 221,816 voters casting their votes, and 41.59 percent of the 197,426 voters in Hualien County cast their ballots.
The commission will formally announce the legislators-elect after verifying the results March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: By-elections show party loyalty no longer strong factor: DPP leader
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 20:37:49 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The victory of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in three out of four legislative by-elections Saturday proves that only a party with vision can earn voter support and that voters are no longer extremely loyal to a particular party, DPP Secretary-General Su Chia-chyuan said later that day.

Su also quoted the DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen as saying that while she was pleased with the DPP's victory, the special municipality elections scheduled for the end of this year will be the real test for the DPP.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suffered yet another setback after losing in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County and Chiayi County, with its only victory coming in Hualien County. The by-elections were held to fill seats left vacant because the lawmakers who previously held them were elected as county magistrates.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT still has predominant majority in Legislative Yuan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 20:48:17 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Although the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) garnered six of the seven vacant seats in Jan. 9 and Feb. 27 legislative by-elections, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) still has a predominant majority in the Legislative Yuan.
At present, the KMT holds 74 seats, the DPP 30 seats, and independents five seats in the 113-seat Legislative Yuan.
When the newly elected legislators assume office in the second week of March, the KMT will have 75 seats, the DPP 33 seats, and independents five seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Cheng Kung University head to lead group on U.S. visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 20:49:20 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University President Michael M.C. Lai will lead a delegation of local university heads on a visit to the University of California at the end of March, university sources said Saturday.

The delegation members, who will include National Chung Hsing University President Shaw Jei-fu, National Sun Yat-sen University President Yang Hung-duen and Cheng Kung University Vice President Feng Da-hsuan, will observe the operations of the 10 UC campuses with the aim of enhancing the competitive edge of domestic higher education.

Feng said the visit will be significant in both helping upgrade the development of Taiwan's higher education through observing the operations of the UC system and in aiding the development of an alliance formed among Cheng Kung, Sun Yat- sen and Chung Hsing universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former premier might announce Taipei mayoral bid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/10 21:57:41 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Su Tseng-chang, who is considered the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) trump card in the year-end special municipality elections, might announce his intention next week to run for mayor in Taipei City, a source close to Su said Saturday.
According to the source, Su will make the announcement in a press conference after Feb. 28.

Enjoying the highest poll ratings among any of the DPP's politicians and bearing the greatest expectations among party members of victory over ruling Kuomintang (KMT) contenders in either the municipality elections or the 2012 presidential election, Su, who served from 1997 until 2004 as Taipei magistrate, is shown in public polls to be the most formidable opponent for any KMT candidate in northern Taiwan.

The source said that despite the fact that running for mayor in Taipei City could be more challenging, Su thinks it would be more meaningful for him to accept the challenge for his party, emphasizing the pivotal role of the nation's capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 28, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
2004: More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chilean tsunami will have no impact on Taiwan: weather bureau
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 14:25:04 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A tsunami triggered by a massive earthquake that struck Chile early Saturday is not expected to have a major impact on Taiwan, located on the other side of the Pacific Ocean, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Sunday.
The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center (PTWC) in Hawaii removed Taiwan from a Tsunami advisory list earlier in the day, said Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB's Seismology Center.
A PTWC tsunami advisory has been in effect for coastal areas in Pacific Rim countries after a magnitude 8.8 earthquake hit central Chile in the early hours of Saturday.

According to the tsunami warning center, the tsunami reached Hawaii at 6:11 a.m. Sunday, Taiwan time, but the waves averaged only 52 cm high, far smaller than previously forecast by the center, Kuo said.
The earthquake-triggered tsunami was forecast to have subsided further by the time it reached Guam, Kuo added.
"It will have diminished even further by the time it reaches Taiwan's eastern coast at 2:21 p.m., " Kuo forecast, adding that the CWB will not issue a tsunami warning for the Taiwan area.
However, Kuo nevertheless warned the public to stay away from beaches along Taiwan's eastern coast Sunday and the following day, just in case.
As of press time, at least 80 people had been killed by the earthquake in Chile, and the death toll was reported to be still climbing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weight gain bid pays off as Taiwan wins world tug-of-war title
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 15:10:11 (By Johnson Sun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A tug-of-war team from the Taipei Jingmei Girls High School won the 2010 World Indoor Championship in Italy Saturday, thanks to the success of the athletes' strenuous efforts to train and bulk up over the past several months.
The Jingmei team beat teams from China, Japan and Switzerland in three rounds of competition to capture the 540 kg category championship.
The team secured a landslide in the first phase of the round-robin competition and defeated the Swiss squad in the second stage of the contest to enter the finals with a score of 2:0.
In the best-of-three finals, Jingmei lost its first match to a formidable Chinese team, but managed to win the following two matches to clinch the title.
Jingmei school principal Lin Li-hua said Sunday that she takes pride in the team's firm determination, can-do spirit and sporting prowess.
"The whole team endured hardships and overcame many difficulties to qualify for the competition and eventually emerge as the winner, " Lin said.

As the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) would only subsidize teams for the 540 kg competition, the 12 team members had been piling on the pounds to gain weight over the past few months, in addition to doing intense physical training.
The team managed to increase weight by a combined total of 60 kg to qualify for the competition, Lin said, adding that one member even gained 20 kg to reach 93 kg.

Moreover, the school's parents association and teachers donated more than NT$500,000 (US$15,625) to help finance the travel costs for the team. According to government regulations, the SAC could only finance travel for eight members of the team.

Lin said the squad will undergo a five-day weight-loss program immediately after their return Monday in order to qualify for a 500-kg competition in the Asian Cup Tug-of-War Championship scheduled to open March 7. Each athlete will have to lose an average of 5 kilograms so that the aggregate team weight will not exceed 500 kg., Lin said.
The Taipei municipal Jingmei school has won the national tug-of-war championship for six consecutive years.

The 2010 World Indoor Championship, organized by the Tug-of-War International Federation, took place in the Italian city of Cesenatico Feb. 25-28. The Jingmei team also won the championship in an open game held on the opening day of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Another KMT setback in legislative by-elections
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 02/28/10 15:41:24 (Feb. 28, 2010) (Feb. 28, 2010) (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: suffered yet another setback Saturday as it failed to take three out of four legislative seats up for grabs in Saturday's by-elections.

With the latest defeat coming hard on the heels of the party's disastrous performance in last December's local government chief elections and all three seats at stake in Jan. 9 legislative by-elections, some KMT members have expressed concern that a domino effect could hurt the party in year-end mayoral elections for five special municipalities.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took three seats in the legislative by-elections in Chiayi, Hsinchu and Taoyuan counties -- the latter two of which used to be traditional KMT strongholds. The KMT only took the Hualien County seat.

All four-by elections were held to fill seats made vacant when former Legislators Chang Hwa-kuan from Chiayi, John Wu from Taoyuan, Chiu Ching-chun from Hsinchu and Fu Kun-chi from Hualien were elected county magistrates in their respective constituencies in the December elections last year.
Following its latest victory, the DPP will see its seats in the 113- seat legislature grow to 33, compared to 75 for the KMT and five for independents.
The DPP scored the biggest victory in Chiayi, with DPP former Magistrate Chen Ming-wen crushing the KMT's Lin Teh-jui by 57,451 to 27,138 votes, a record high for the DPP in the county.
In Hsinchu, DPP candidate Perng Shaw-jiin obtained 71,625 votes, compared to the KMT's Cheng Yung-tang's 56,342.
In Taoyuan, DPP hopeful Huang Jen-ju cashed in on a KMT split by garnering a slim majority of 45,363 votes over the 42,600 ballots obtained by his KMT contender, Apollo Chen.
The KMT candidates lost in the three counties largely due to internal divisions resulting from candidate nominations and low voter turnout, according to election observers. (Feb. 28, 2010)
United Daily News:

The results mark another failure for the KMT after it suffered a series of setbacks in major government elections since it came to power in 2008 and a fresh blow for KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung since he assumed his post last December.

After the by-elections, President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as KMT chairman, offered an apology in a press release over the defeat, but stressed the importance of continuing with party reforms in the hope of winning back support in future elections.
At a post-election press conference, King did not concede defeat for the party but apologized to supporters for the party's disappointing performance and pledged continued reforms.

King said the party would heed the warning of the low voter turnout but would stand by the party's nomination strategy and strengthen integration of local political forces, which both critics and supporters have blamed for its recent losses.

A new survey released Saturday just after the by-elections conducted by United Daily News put Ma's approval rating at a record low of 29 percent since he took office, down from 33 percent following the party's dismal showing in local elections last December.
Some 65 percent of the respondents said the KMT lost the by-elections, compared with only 3 percent who said the DPP was the loser.
On the other hand, the survey gave DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen an approval rating of 46 percent, up from 43 percent last December.
Liberty Times:
DPP Secretary-General Su Chia-chyuan said Saturday during a post-election press conference that the results are a demonstration of voters' trust in the opposition party.

Su said the results show that the KMT government's administrative direction, its China-leaning policy and its policies that are hollowing out the national coffers run counter to the people's will and desire.
The three more seats will help the DPP continue to monitor the government's economic policies and Ma's fiscal policies, Su added.
The DPP secretary-general also said that Tsai was pleased with the results but warned that the upcoming year-end mayoral polls in five special municipalities will be the real test for the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Where have KMT supporters gone?
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 02/28/10 15:50:23 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: suffered yet another humiliating defeat in Saturday's legislative by-elections, winning only one out of four seats up for grabs.
Some said a low voter turnout rate was the main reason for the KMT's defeat, but the crux of the KMT's problems is more than that.
The KMT lost three other legislative by-elections in January and Saturday's defeat marked the KMT's fifth election setback since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May 2008.

Over the past more than one year, the administration of Ma -- who won a landslide victory in the 2008 presidential race with a record high number of 7.65 million ballots -- has failed to deliver feedback to the electorate, whether on policy or on rationale.
The Ma administration has not only failed to provide the people with prospects of a bright future, but also has been unable to win their hearts.
Dropping turnouts underscores rising estrangement between the KMT and its supporters. The KMT's string of setbacks also reflects the constituents' disappointment.
If the KMT cannot stop bleeding really soon, the approval ratings of Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, will continue to plummet, putting the nation's political operations in jeopardy.

Saturday's setback points to the truth that the KMT no longer has loyal supporters, unlike the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which has had its morale boosted after winning a string of victories in legislative by- elections and other local elections.

Ma's personal charisma is no longer a cure-all, and unless the party comes up with policies that can really bring about change, the KMT will have little chance of winning in the far more crucial five special municipality elections at the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Problematic industrial innovation statute

TEXT.P: The government has submitted a new version of the draft industrial innovation statute in which the controversial Article 30 of the statute that would offer extra-low 15 percent corporate income tax rate to international businesses, was scrapped.

The government is right to do this in response to mainstream public opinion. But the fate of the article, which is widely regarded as unfair, is still uncertain, since several big conglomerates are still lobbying for its enactment.
With too much attention put on the article, some other unreasonable parts of the bill are being ignored and might cause a lot of negative impact once they are passed into law.

For example, ASUSTeK Computer Inc. might be disqualified for the tax incentive as a result of its ongoing move to separate its affiliates from the mother company, even though it has made far greater contributions to the country than many smaller businesses who might be entitled to the low tax treatment through mergers.

The move by large businesses to aggressively lobby for the passage of the low tax treatment article is unjustifiable, as their contributions to the country are not necessarily greater that those of their small- and medium-sized counterparts.

In seeking favorable treatment, the leading companies have also complained that the tax burden is too heavy in Taiwan and that the lack of tax accords between Taiwan and foreign countries also makes it difficult for them to sharpen their competitiveness.

In fact, however, the small- and medium-sized businesses are facing the same difficulties, and what the government should do is help all businesses streamline operations and seek to strike tax cooperation pacts with foreign countries rather than simply granting tax privileges to big companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free five-in-one vaccine for babies to be available March 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 16:53:59 (By Chen Ti-ting and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A five-in-one vaccine will be available free-of-charge for infants and children from March 1, replacing the traditional three-in-one vaccine, the deputy head of the Centers of Disease Control (CDC) said Sunday.

From Monday, the free five-in-one vaccine which will give protection against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio and haemophilus influenza type B (Hib) , will be included in regular vaccination coverage among children, replacing the existing three-in-one shots that cover only diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, according to CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yih.
Under the new vaccination program, infants should receive a shot of five-in-one vaccine at two months, four months, six months and 18 months, Shih said.
In the past, parents had to pay between NT$800 and NT$1,200 per shot.

If parents are worried that a single dose of five-in-one vaccine are not enough to immunize their children who have not received a shot against Hib, they can consult with a doctor to determine whether they should pay for a booster shot out of their own pockets, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade normalization with China to be major challenge for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 17:23:52 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing's insistence that bilateral trade relations across the Taiwan Strait should be normalized before the two sides sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will be a major challenge to Taiwan's negotiators with China, an economics official said Sunday.

Negotiators in the second round of official cross-strait negotiations on the ECFA are expected to exchange "early harvest" lists for each side, naming items that could be first to benefit from the agreement, but Beijing's trade normalization requirement will put Taiwan's political wisdom and trade stance to the test, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Since the 1st round of ECFA talks took place in Beijing Jan. 26, with negotiators from the two sides exchanging views on matters of principle, Taiwan's officials have known, however, that the "bottom line stances" of each side -- China's requirement of an overall trade normalization and Taiwan's hope of not opening its agricultural market further to Chinese imports -- remain unchanged.

Since it was admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002, Taiwan has gradually opened its domestic market to agricultural and industrial products from China, although imports of 865 agricultural products and 1,377 industrial items from China are still banned, the official said.

Taiwan will unavoidably face pressure of lifting its ban on industrial products from China, given the prerequisite that the ECFA should cover over 80 percent of actual trade across the Taiwan Strait and that imports of the 865 agricultural products will remain banned, the official forecast.

Huang Chih-peng, chief of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, and Tang Wei, director of the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under China's Ministry of Commerce, who chaired the first round of ECFA talks in Beijing, will also chair the second round, which will probably take place in Taipei in the second week of March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan helps Haitian quake survivors rebuild homes, livelihoods
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 17:30:21 (By Shih Sinyao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (Taiwan ICDF) is cooperating with the U.S. charity Mercy Corps in hiring Haitian earthquake survivors to clean up debris and rebuild their homes, an official said Sunday.

"The employment replaces relief" program is designed to create jobs to allow Haitian people displaced by the magnitude-7 earthquake that struck the Caribbean ally Jan. 12 to rebuild their homes and livelihoods with self-help, the official said.

The program has been in practice since Feb. 1, with Mercy Corps responsible for execution in four quake refugee settlement centers in the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince, the official said, adding that the project will last for six months in the initial stage.
Under the program, Mercy Corps employs quake victims to clean up the wreckage and carry out temporary construction work, with each worker receiving US$5 (about NT$160) per day.

"`The job replaces relief' program is different from the conventional `give and take' method of aid disbursement, " the official explained, adding that the program will enable quake survivors to receive regular incomes in the post- disaster rehabilitation and reconstruction process and get back on their feet as soon as possible.
"We believe this style of assistance will allow aid recipients to maintain dignity through self-help and regain peace of mind through stable jobs," the official added.

An estimated 1,400 Haitian earthquake survivors are expected to benefit from the project, the official went on, adding that the project will cost over US$116,000, with the money coming from the Humanitarian Cooperation Fund jointly set up by the Taiwan ICDF and Mercy Corps.

Since the catastrophic earthquake struck Haiti, the Taiwan ICDF has launched many emergency aid programs and post-disaster reconstruction projects in cooperation with domestic and foreign charities and private groups in hopes of helping the survivors rebuild their lives soon, the official noted.
The Taiwan ICDF is the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' international aid arm.

DOC.HEADLINE: President: election defeat severe warning for KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 18:04:10 (By Chang Hung-hsiang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said Sunday that the latest defeat in the legislative by-elections the previous day comes as a "severe warning" for the party.

The KMT took only one of the four seats up for grabs in the by- elections held in the counties of Chiayi, Hsinchu, Taoyuan and Hualien, with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party winning the other three, including the constituencies of Hsinchu and Taoyuan, which had previously been considered KMT strongholds.
The KMT has suffered four election defeats since Ma won a landslide victory in the 2008 presidential election.

Ma said while responding to press queries after presiding over a ceremony in the southern Taiwanese city to mark the Feb. 28 Incident of 1947 that the defeat highlights that the KMT has not done enough to win public support, and he offered an apology to party supporters.
"It is my firm belief that we should insist on reforms in order to win stronger support. Only by doing so can we complete party integration and forge party unity to win future elections," Ma said.

Most local political analysts were of the opinion that with its latest defeat, the KMT will face an uphill battle in the more crucial mayoral elections for the five special municipalities to be held at the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Korean tourism promoter to attend Lantern Festival
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 18:36:17 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The head of the Korean Tourism Organization (KTO) will attend a lighting ceremony Sunday to mark the opening of the 2010 Taiwan Lantern Festival in Chiayi, southern Taiwan.

At the invitation of Taiwan Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai, Lee Cham, president of KTO, a government-invested corporation responsible for the Korean tourism industry, arrived in Taiwan accompanied by several heads from the Korea Association of Travel Agents (KATA).
The visit is seen as a big step forward in tourism exchanges between the two countries, said Chen Pei-tsen, a Tourism Bureau official stationed in Seoul.

A record 23 representatives from South Korea's tourism and media sectors will take part in the ceremony, which shows the importance Taiwan's Tourism Bureau attaches to the South Korean market, according to Chen.
Lee, a German who became a naturalized Korean citizen in 1986 and who was appointed KTO president last year, is scheduled to stay in Taiwan for three days.
He will visit the National Palace Museum in Taipei, experience Taiwan's high speed railway and visit some hot springs.
Chen said over 600,000 visitors have traveled between Taiwan and South Korea every year in recent years.
The 2010 Taiwan Lantern Festival will kick off in Chiayi with a ceremony hosted by President Ma Ying-jeou and will run through March 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Speed up cross-strait ECFA signing

TEXT.P: Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao will deliver a government work report at the opening of the annual session of China's National People's Congress (NPC) March 5 to outline the country's major policy guidelines and work agenda for the year.

Economic structural adjustments will be China's priority tasks, as its economic scale has grown to be on par with Japan's. A major overhaul and upgrading is badly needed for China to sustain its spectacular growth recorded in the past decade.

As a result, economic exchanges and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait will gain momentum and grow even faster and closer after the NPC annual session, as there is much Taiwan can assist China in its economic restructuring.

For one thing, Taiwan can help with China's high-tech industry development. China has relied heavily on foreign provision of core technology in high-tech production, but with its higher level of industrial know-how, Taiwan can cooperate with China in developing new technologies or operating systems and create new styles of high-tech industries with "cross-strait characteristics."

On China's current endeavor to expand its domestic demand and private consumption, Taiwanese companies, while gearing up to penetrate the vast Chinese market, can assist in upgrading the quality and functions of various consumer products.
Taiwanese companies can also help with the introduction of a modernized marketing and distribution mechanism in China to enhance operational efficiency.

Moreover, Taiwan can assist in bridging regional gaps in development in different parts of China. Taiwan-owned companies in coastal Chinese provinces are presently troubled by serious labor shortages, indicating that investment in coastal regions has become saturated. Taiwanese investors remain divided on whether they should relocate to China's hinterland.
If governments on both sides of the strait can reach a cooperation deal, more Taiwanese companies will be willing to relocate to inland Chinese provinces to help with their development.
With this in mind, the NPC session is expected to pass decisions that will allow for greater room for cross-strait cooperation.

We hope both sides will speed up negotiation and signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement to lay the groundwork for tariff concessions, market access and intellectual property rights protection that will help facilitate closer cross-strait cooperation. (Feb. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: 228 Incident can help Taiwan to move ahead: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 19:10:48 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Addressing a ceremony held in Tainan City in southern Taiwan Sunday to commemorate the 228 Incident of 1947, President Ma Ying-jeou said he hopes the anti-government uprising and its aftermath will serve to help Taiwan to forge ahead.

Ma offered an apology to the victims of the 228 Incident, in which an anti- government uprising was brutally suppressed by the military on behalf of the Kuomintang (KMT) government, which held power at the time.
He said the incident, which occurred 63 years ago when the then-KMT government was corrupt and inept, wrought extreme pain on the people, with many losing their lives or freedom.

The president recalled that he heard about the 228 Incident as a high school student but did not quite understand it. It was not until he went to the United States for advanced studies and read historical archives that he gained a clearer picture.

Twenty-nine years ago, when he returned to Taiwan to work at the Presidential Office, the first thing he discussed with his superiors on the first day of his work was that the incident should be handled properly, Ma said.
When he served as minister of justice, he went on, he helped enact a 228 victim compensation statute and made the acquaintance of some of the victims' families.

He admitted that no remorse or apology from the government can change the facts or erase the torment of the victims and their families, but what is more important is finding ways to prevent similar tragedies from occurring again and making sure that the younger generations are given better education in democracy and human rights.

Also speaking at the commemorative ceremony, Premier Wu Den-yih said that although the government has established the 228 Memorial Foundation to facilitate compensation for the families of the victims, urgent measures are still required to uncover the truth and to clear the victims' names.
The 228 Incident remained a taboo subject in Taiwan until the early 1990s, when the Executive Yuan commissioned a study to find out what really happened.
In 1997, the Executive Yuan designated Feb. 28 a national holiday and since then, commemorative activities have been held around the island every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Toyota crashes into store
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/10 19:14:11 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Toyota collided with a pillar in front of a convenience store in central Taiwan Saturday as the driver was parking the car, local reports said Sunday.
According to the driver, a 36-year-old woman, she was putting the car into parking gear when her four-year-old Toyota Wish lurched forward and hit the store in Taichung County.
"The car had stopped. But when I was shifting gears, it lurched forward on its own and the brakes did not work," she said.
No casualties were reported, but the driver's mother, who was sitting in the front passenger seat when the incident occurred was taken to a hospital complaining of chest pains, the reports said.

A Toyota technician who rushed to the scene to check the problem said there would be an investigation into the case, which came after Toyota recalled some 8.5 million vehicles worldwide since October last year due to problems with the accelerator pedal and braking system.
Toyotas sold in Taiwan use a different brand of accelerator pedal than the one that has been causing problems elsewhere.
